According to statements made in Victoria some of the sealing vessels of that port complain that they have been warned by our Government cruisers not to go to the Russian side of Bering Sea, and have been threatened with arrest and punishment if they attempt to do so. Such a statement is likely to convey a wrong impression.

Consul Gen. New returned from England to take charge of Harrison's contest for a renomination. Other high officials returned from abroad to aid in securing the same political end. There were, it is stated, more than a hundred office holders present at Minneapolis to boost Harrison into a renomination.

A gentleman who had induced a large publishing house to take his son, as boy, into its employ at a moderate rate of pay, not long since, was especially anxious in his request that the young man should be made to work and learn the business.

The peaceful dreams of such of the members of New York's Naval Reserve as wear white working clothes were disturbed at 6 o'clock yesterday morning by the noise of drum and life sounding reveille on board the old frigate New-Hampshire, swinging to her single anchor in Gravesend Bay. The slumbers of the officers were not disturbed until a later hour.

In the opinion of many eminent members of the British medical faculty, the torment of insomnia is far more prevalent among certain classes of English folk than was the case even a quarter of a century ago, and its rapid increment of late years is attributed to a variety of causes.

The American Institute of Christian Philosophy continued the sessions of its sixteenth Summer school at National Prohibition Park, Staten Island, yesterday. Each of the two sessions were attended by fully 1,500 persons.

Brother Philemon Myers, Superior of the Catholic educational Order of the Brothers of the Holy Cross is in this city, the guest of Christ's Mission, at 142 West Twenty-first Street. He has been here a week. Brother Philemon Myers has renounced Catholicism and is now regarded as a convert to the doctrines of evangelical Protestantism.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- One of the largest pieces of metal ever handled in the United States was that which was a few days ago shaped into what the ordnance experts call the "jacket" for the huge thirteen-inch gun. The immense forging of steel weighed 40,000 pounds and came from the Bethlehem Iron Works in Pennsylvania.
The racing this week will include three days of sport at Brighton and three at Monmouth Park, the sport beginning at Brighton to-day. Entries there for this afternoon's sport are as follows:

Thomas Quinn is a foreman in the Street-Cleaning Department, and lives at 629 Hudson Street. Where Quinn had been Saturday night nobody knows, but when he went home at 1 o'clock yesterday morning he was puzzled by the resemblance between the steps of 627 and those of his own house, and, walking up them, rang the bell of William Loeffler, who lives on the first floor.

From Practical Electricity. So far as has come under our notice, the wellknown general abandonment of hill farms in New-England is almost universally bewailed. Though a sentiment of slight melancholy must usually attach to an abandoned homestead, we take a brighter view of the conditions, since these are to the advantage of the country at large.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 17 -- A Sunday paper to-day says:

SHANGHAI, China, June 1 -- Probably the worst-governed people on the globe are the natives of the Philippine Islands. Those islands were discovered in the sixteenth century by a Spanish navigator, and have since been the seat of the Governor General of the Spanish colonies in the far East. The natives have proved to be quiet and peaceable, and on account of their yielding nature have been greatly oppressed by their Spanish masters.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 17 -- At the crossing of the Atlantic City Railroad and the West Jersey Railroad, on the meadows, about one mile out of this city, a serious accident was averted shortly after 10 o'clock this morning, to prevent which a part of the Reading's 9 o'clock "Flier," from Philadelphia, was precipitated out on the meadows.

Those politicians who went to the Oriental Hotel on Manhattan Besch yesterday afternoon where Mr. Thomas C. Platt has his Summer home, did not see Mr. Platt. He was away. Early in the day he left the hotel, giving no information as to where callers should be directed, and remained away all day and well into the evening.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- S.G. Brock, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, has just issued the statement of foreign commerce and immigration for June, 1892, which, he says, is preliminary and subject to slight change, but which is plainly so constructed as to direct the attention of Republican newspapers to a view of our commerce that will reflect credit upon Republican legislation, rather than the unpartisan forces of nature.

The mysterious disappearance of a package of valuable jewels -- diamonds, rubies, and pearls -- from a big box of sundry merchandise, between the Appraiser's office, in the Second Division of the Custom House, Laight and Washington Streets, and the store of Albert Lorsch Co., jewelers, 37 Maiden Lane, on Friday afternoon last, is still puzzling that firm and the detectives.

LONDON, July 17 -- All the Cabinet Ministers have been summoned to London for Thursday next. Mr. Balfour, arriving in town yesterday, proceeded to Hatfield House to see Lord Salisbury. Lord Salisbury went to Windsor to-day to meet the Duke of Devonshire, who has been staying at the castle for some time. Here he had a conference with her Majesty and returned to London this evening, accompanied by the Duke of Devonshire.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 17 -- Extra precautions are being taken just now among all Southern ports against any possible introduction of cholera from Europe. These extra precautions are especially necessary at Charleston, Savannah, Brunswick, Mobile, and New-Orleans, which ports do, at all seasons of the year, a large business with the countries of South Europe.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 17 -- Of the many Indian wars in the history of the United States, there is none about which the people of the country at large know less than that waged in the Pacific Northwest in the years of 1855 and 1856. The other wars have been fought in times when the newspapers have had correspondents in the field, or in places since so thickly settled that their history has become important.

The yawl Micso, flagship of the Biscayne Bay (Florida) Yacht Club, arrived in port yesterday She sailed on July 10 and made Cape Lookout on the 13th. Squally weather was met with. Capt. Monroe and two members of the club were on board.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 17 -- Since first the opprobrious epithet was applied to it, "Seab" Hill was never in such glory as to-day. All roads led thither, and on them toiled a multitude of 10,000 persons, bending their steps toward the cloud of white tents on the summit, where are encamped the soldiers of the Keystone State.

From the Davenport (Iowa) Democrat. The Prohibitionists are in a pickle, but one they can get out of by a little trouble. It all comes from the new voting law, which requires that to have tickets printed at the expense of the State -- and no others will be used -- the party presenting candidates must have cast at least 2 per cent, of the total vote at the preceding general election.
CATANIA, July 17 -- Enormous incandescent rocks and immense clouds of steam continue to be thrown out of the craters of Mount Etna.

The death on Saturday last at Rutland, Vt., of Mrs. Lucy Fayerweather, widow of Daniel B. Fayerweather, will recall to the minds of persons interested in the disposition of large estates the contest which Mrs. Fayerweather began against her husband's will, which was finally compromised greatly to the widow's advantage.

While labor organizations are receiving an object lesson, at no small cost to the State of Pennsylvania, as to their right to seize property or to kill "Pinkertons," public attention may wisely be called to what practically amounts to a conspiracy on the part of these organizations to exclude Americans from many employments by forbidding our young countrymen to learn a trade.

PORT ROYAL, S.C., July 17 -- Three-fourths of the excavating work on the new naval dry dock at the Port Royal Naval Station has been completed. Within the next thirty days the work of excavating will have been entirely finished. The Government contractor, Mr. Justin McCarthy of Washington, D.C., has now 100 men at work on the new dock.

Those persons who are inclined to sigh for the good old times they road about should seek consolation in the present activity of Mount Etna. It they had lived in these good old times such a phenomenon would probably have made them even unhappier than they are now, for, like their brethren of those days, they would have seen the devil's handiwork in Etna's steaming summit.

The first vessel which has arrived at this port from St. John's, N.F., since the fire which swept two-thirds of the town out of existence is now lying at Woodruff's Stores, Brooklyn. She is the steamship Miranda, commanded by Capt. H.E. Leseman, who got Into St. John's during the fire and was evidently impressed by the sight.

In the brief discussion that took place in the Senate a few days ago over the conflict at Homestead, words were uttered by Senator Palmer that must have surprised many of his friends who were accustomed to look up to him with a good deal of respect as a good representative of the substantial interests of the country, and as one not likely to speak hastily when important interests are involved.

One may descant on tons of iron, yards of cloth, or bushels of grain, manufactured or grown in the United States, but if you are a politico-economist, after looking at the bread-and-beef question, you ought to study that other food problem, which is one of fish. Conditions might be readily understood when there would be an increase of all alimentary substances, fish excepted.

The prohibition of his play, "Salome," by the Lord Chamberlain has cut Mr. Oscar Wilde to the heart, and he has informed a correspondent of the Gaulois that he is about to part with an ungrateful country and have himself naturalized as a Frenchman. His statement to the representative of that journal is characteristic, remarks the London Standard. He said:

BOSTON, July 18 -- Patrick Maguire, who is one of the committee appointed, at Chicago to notify the candidate for the Presidency of his nomination, will leave for New-York on the "White Train" at 3 P.M. to-morrow. Mr. Josiah Quincy will go in the evening on the Fall River boat, which will also have ex-President Cleveland on board.

Chairman Thomas H. Carter of the Republican National Committee made it about his first business yesterday morning to call upon Thomas C. Platt, who has during the time the Executive Committee has been in this city religiously and coldly kept away from Mr. Harrison's cohort.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 18. -- Dr. C. C. Terry died to-night under exceptionally sad circumstances. Prof. Castaldi of Newport was giving him his usual weekly lesson in fencing at his rooms in the Young Men's Christian Association Building, when Castaldi's foil broke the mask on Terry's face and out a flesh wound near the nose.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 18 -- Basil B. Gordon, Chairman of the Democratic Committee of Virginia, recently requested an authoritative statement from the ex-President of his views on the Force bill. Mr. Cleveland's answer was as follows:

NORWICH, Conn., July 18 -- The Norwich Cutlery Works are closed on account of a strike or lock-out that was precipitated last Saturday. The shop is a branch of the large Rogers Silver-Plating Works at Hartford. TUe cutlery is produced here and plated in Hartford. The local works employ seventy-five men, thirty of whom are export grinders and finishers, earning large wages, and are uncertain workmen.

ROSE TERRY COOKE. Mrs. Rose Terry Cooke, the authoress, died at Pittsfield, Mass., at 10 o'clock yesterday morning of congestion of the lungs. Last Winter she had an attack of the grip, which left her quite weak. A few days ago she contracted a cold which brought on her old enemy, but none of her friends were alarmed at her condition until within a few hours preceding her death.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House this morning adopted a resolution providing for final adjournment of Congress on the 25th, one week from to-day.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 18 -- American oarsmen are beginning to arrive here for the annual regatta of the Canadian Association of Amateur Oarsmen, to be held on Wednesday and Thursday of this week. Montreal oarsmen are not taking part, so that the contests lie between Canadians and Americans, and the chances will be more favorable for the latter than it Lachine oarsmen competed.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Col. G.L. Gillespie, the engineer officer in charge of river and harbor work in the vicinity or New-York City, has Bent to the Chief of Engineers an interesting report of what has been done in the works of which he has charge during the past year and what he thinks ought to be done next year.

According to the story told to the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, by Louisa Wild, aged nineteen years, of 13 Beaver Street, Brooklyn, her uncle, William Devine, who was recently declared to be dead by a Coroner's jury in Philadelphia, ia alive and well and has spent about $2,000 which was paid to his supposed widow by several Philadelphia benefit lodges.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 18 -- A.H. Austin, a commercial traveler, whose homo Is la Bridgeton, N.J., died at the Palmer House at 6 o'clock today from an overdose of morphine. Whether the drag was taken with suicidal intent or by accident is not definitely known, but that Austin thought death might be near is evident.

ROME, July 18 -- The Pope, receiving the pupils of the Propaganda, delivered an animated eulogy on Archbishop Ireland, praising his many virtues, his vigor as a thinker, and his anergy in action. The Archbishop, he said, was a true republican and genuine democrat, and since leaving Home had done good work for the Church in Paris.

Capt. "Harry" Cornell, the owner of the fishing sloop Ella, and his mate, Albert Brunhart, rescued on Sunday afternoon, near the wreck of the Italian brig, off Rookaway Shoals, at the mouth of the inlet which widens into Jamaica Bay, four amateur fishermen from Williamsburg, who had hired a small catboat that morning and had anchored off the shoals tot a day's fishing.

The Rev. G.Q.A. Rose, an Episcopal missionary from San Antonio, Texas, who is now staying at the See House in Lafayette Place, yesterday gave to a reporter for THE TIMES some details of the drought in Southwestern Texas.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 18 -- The Harrison managers in Indiana are panic stricken over the Blaine secessionists of Fort Wayne. Saturday Harry C. Hanna, a prominent lawyer and influential Blaine Republican of Fort Wayne, resigned his membership on the State Committee because he could not conscientiously work for Harrison.

The bill yesterday reported to and passed by the House concerning Government architecture is the same measure heretofore explained and commended in these columns. Some of the most eminent of American architects, and the representatives of the professional societies, have taken the trouble to go to Washington to argue in behalf of this bill in committee, and the bill may be said to have received the support of the entire body of American architects.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator Washburn (Rep., Minn.,) realizes to-night that he has undertaken a large contract in trying to get the Anti-Option bill through the Senate. He managed, last Friday, to defeat the motion to adjourn until Monday, and this was taken as an indication that he would be able to call up the Anti-Option bill whenever he saw fit.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Senator Quay dropped into the city very quietly this evening, and expects to meet a few of the city leaders to-morrow.

There was no nothing very exciting about the races that were run at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, though but two of the favorites were successful in their races. But the winners of all the contests were well played, and the favorites in two or three cases were false ones, the winners carrying more money than the horses that the bookmakers had decided were the beat ones in the race.

As the sun went down over the Canarsic meadows last night eighteen ball players were struggling for supremacy on the diamond at Eastern Park, and 2,000 enthusiasts were in a very excitable frame of mind. They had watched fourteen brilliantly-played innings, and when the umpire called the game with the scores even they lelt the grounds thanking their stars that their favorites had not suffered defeat.
HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 18 -- The pasttwentyfour hours have been fraught with interest and excitement to the people of Homestead.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18 -- "Jim" Corbett, the pugilist, who is training here for his fight with Champion John L. Sullivan, is an all round athlete. On Saturday Corbett donned the uniform of the local baseball club and covered first base in good style, his line playing winning the game for his club. Corbett is also a speedy short-distance swimmer.
SYDNEY, N.S.W., July 18 -- The Captain of the Steamer Catterthun reports that on June 29, he called at Timor and found there a Dutch steamer that had left Great Sangir Island on June 17.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The special committee appointed to investigate the Homestead labor troubles, of which Mr. Oates is Chairman, will probably have a formal meeting to-morrow, but it is expected that nothing will be done at the meeting.

Barring injunctions and other causes or delay, the political geography of the city, so far as the Assembly districts are concerned, will all be changed to-day, and instead of being represented in the lower branch of the Legislature by twenty-four men New-York City will hereafter be represented by thirty men.

Mayor Boody put a temporary stop yesterday to the scheme of the Brooklyn Aldermen to give away franchises for trolley roads to the Union Railroad Company and the Coney Island, Fort Hamilton and Brooklyn Company by vetoing the resolutions recently adopted.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Major Powell, Director of the Geological Survey, has shown great activity in responding to the demand of the Senate to be given a complete list of all the persons who are now, or hare been in the year past, connected in any way with the work of the Geological Survey and the figures representing their salaries.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18 -- There came another move to-day on that grim chessboard whereon is being waged the life or death struggle for supremacy between the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, with $25,000,000 capital, on the one side, and the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, with 25,000 members, on the other.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Without opposition the House, under the motion to suspend the rules, this afternoon passed the bill reported by Mr. Tarsney, (Dem., Mo.,) from the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to obtain plans and specifications for public buildings to be erected under the supervision of the Treasury Department, and providing for local supervision of the construction of the same.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18 -- The wealthy and fashionable Euclid Avenue Baptist Church is stirred from centre to circumference by a firstclass sensation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18 -- There was no change in the situation at the upper and lower Union Mills to-day. The foundry, forge, and mechanical departments were still in operation find the yardmen were at work, but everything else about the big plants was still.

NEW-YORK, Monday, July 18 -- P.M. There was a very light attendance of members at the Stock Exchange to-day and speculation was uninteresting. In the great dullness prices sagged off somewhat, but there was no pronounced weakness. The heaviest trading was in St. Paul, Burlington, and Chicago Gas.

Our late Minister to Russia, Mr. CHARLES EMORY SMITH, contributed to a recent number of the North American Review an extremely lucid and impressive statement of the causes of the Russian famine. Mr. SMITH'S article had especial weight and authority owing to his intimacy with the subject and his official connection with it -- a connection, we may add, marked on his part by great energy and capacity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 18 -- Judge Barnard this morning heard testimony in the suit of Thomas K. McCahill, a prominent Westchester County lawyer, to regain possession of the McCahill homestead in Larchmont, valued at $25,000, which he convoyed to his wife in 1882 while under the belief that he was going to die.

The New-York German Gun Club had its regular monthly shoot at Dexter Park, Long Island, yesterday. A good lot of birds had been supplied and the scores were small in consequence. The club shoot is at eight live birds, modified Long Island rules, gun below the elbow, the use of both barrels. There were six in the ties for the two gold medals of the club, with six each.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Although the joint Immigration Committee had concluded its investigation into the workings of the immigration laws and the expenditures at Ellis Island, the inquiry has been reopened at the instance of the Secretary of the Treasury, who desired further testimony to be taken.

A sub-committee of the House Committee on Manufactures declares in a report concerning Trusts and similar combinations that "existing legislation in regard to Trusts" [meaning the Federal Anti-Trust law] is ''insufficient and impracticable." It may be that the statute is not of much value, but it has not been tested.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Representative Bland of Missouri is one of the strongest and best known of all the silver men in the House and in this country. He is also one of the straightest of all the Democrats of the silver side in the House.
LONDON, July 18 -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon the total returns received show the election of 311 supporters of the Government ana 347 members of the Opposition.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- An old man, beardless, kindly of face, incapable of speech, overwhelmed with unexpected yet long-hoped-for success, was in the corridor of the House this afternoon, receiving the congratulations of many persons who had seen him lingering about the Capitol for many years in the hope of accomplishing the result that was reached in the House under the order of suspension of the rules.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala,) called up the resolution offered by him on July 14 directing the Committee on Finance to report a bill to give all paper money issued by the United States a legal tender for debts, and to all standard silver dollars the full legal tender given by law to coins of gold, and addressed the Senate in explanation and advocacy or it.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Jacob M. Patterson of New-York registered at the Arlington about 9 o'clock to-night. As soon as he had made arrangements for a room with a breeze, he started for the apartments of Senator Hiscock and remained with the Senator until 10 o'clock. Soon after his arrival Mr. George W. Lyon, Surveyor of the Port of New-York, also placed his name on the Arlington register.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 19 -- The State Convention of the Democrats of Missouri met here to-day. The purpose of the gathering is The selection of a full State ticket, a State Committee, and seventeen Presidential Electors.

Mayor Boody yesterday signed the illegal resolution of the Brooklyn Aldermen altering the ward boundaries in spite of the objections made to it by many citizens. Before doing so he obtained from Corporation Counsel Jenks a long opinion to the effect that the Aldermen Had the power to make these changes.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 19 -- The entire Fire Department of the city was called to a fire in the Hennessy and the Cooney Buildings in Canal Street shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon. The fire originated in an upper story of the five-story Cooney Buildings, and before a line of hose could be laid flames were bursting out of the upper windows on all sides of the building.

The Twenty-third Assembly District Republicans held a mass meeting last evening at Madison Hall, Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. It had been announced that Whitelaw Reid, Chauncey M. Depew, and other prominent Republicans, besides many erators of local fame, would speak. Speeches were made by Henry C. Robinson, John Proctor Clark, and Gen. George A. Sheridan.

Nine questions were recently propounded to the Board of United States Engineers in this city, coming from the Senate Committee on Commerce at Washington, through the Secretary of War, and bearing on the question of Harlem River improvement. Six of these questions were of a purely technical nature, or had reference to matters already acted upon.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 19 -- Grover Cleveland, Gen. A.E. Stevenson, Gen. Ewing, Private Secretary O'Brion, and some half dozen newspaper men left here on the 4:50 P.M. train for New-York via the Fall River Line. The departure was a quiet one. The party reached the station soon after the train arrived, and Mr. Cleveland, in some haste, purchased the tickets and afterward with the others took seats in the through Fall River car.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 19 -- The Erie County Beard or Supervisors met to-day to reapportion the county into six Assembly districts. The board has a Democratic majority of eight, and Liout, Gov. Sheehan's plan of apportionment was put through. It makes live of the districts Democratic and one Republican. Under the old apportionment there were there Democratic districts and two Republican.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 19 -- It is Semi-officially stated that the plague has broken out in the province of Khorassan, Persia.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 19 -- The People's Party State Convention, which meets in this city to-morrow, derives special importance from the fact that Georgia is an October State.

The advantages resulting to a section of country from good and improved roads are so many and so marked that it is almost strange that each improvements are not made more rapidly. Advance in this direction is hailed as indicating the beginning of a new condition of things.

A correspondent who says that he has passed all his active life in business, "principally banking," requests us to state the grounds of our objection to the Sub-Treasury plan of the People's Party. He says that he has examined the plan carefully and thoroughly and it does not strike him as "visionary or impractical," and he thinks many others are anxious to understand why it is objectionable.

But two matches were played yesterday afternoon in the handicap tournament of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club, Brook Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-first Street, but what was lacked in quantity was made up in the quality of the play. The first match of the day was in the second round of the gentlemen's singles between Edwin P. Fischer of Central Park and Ray D. Thurber of the Lenox Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Threatening weather did not seriously interfere with the annual parade of the League of American Wheelmen to-day, and fully 2,500 cyclists passed in review before President Harrison, who stood on the balcony of the White House with President Burdett of the league. In point of numbers, the parade broke all previous records, being the largest turn-out of cyclers ever seen in this country.

BOSTON, Mass., July 19 -- Boston society, or that part of it which is still in town, came out to-day to witness the continuation of the playing at the Longwood tennis tournament. The large audience was disappointed at the non-appearance of Richard Stevens, but they saw several good contests between well-known players. The best playing of the day was done by S. T. Chase, the Western champion, and R.D. Wrenn, the Harvard expert.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 19 -- The tournament of the Baltimore Gun Club, which opened at Tolchester Beach yesterday, has been an unqualified success. Tolchester Beach is a popular Summer resort on Chesapeake Bay, thirty miles from Baltimore, and each day a large number of persons came down from the city to witness the shooting. Among the visitors on the opening day were Henry Gulick and William Wagner of Washington, D.C.;

It is a curious and unique testimony to the unpopularity of the New-York Central Railroad that it should be deemed sufficient to cast odium upon any measure of municipal improvement that the Central is in favor of it or that it would benefit the Central. This feeling was exhibited yesterday at the hearing of the Board of Engineers upon the proposition to fill in the Harlem between Third and Eighth Avenues.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Yo Tambien, making her own pace throughout and without a touch of whip or spur, to-day, at Washington Park, made a new record for a mile and a sixteenth, going the distance in 1:45 1/2, half a second faster than the best previous time on record. The mile from wire to wire was made in 1:39 1/4. Faraday and Goldstone were the only horses that opposed the lilly in the race.

ROUND LAKE, July 19 -- Every one will remember "Becky" Jones as the once famous witness who was imprisoned in Ludlow Street Jail some years ago for refusing to take the oath in the great Hamersley will case and to tell all she know about the queernesses and oddities of her old employer, Mr. Hamersley.

For the purpose of having a big international regatta arranged to take place during the World's Fair, William O'Connor, champion oarsman of America; Edward Hanlan, ex-champion of the world: George H. Hosmer of Boston, and Wallace Ross, the New-Brunswick sculler, called on Christopher Clarke, Richard K. Fox's representative, yesterday, and asked him to offer a purse of $5,000 for the event.
In its weekly review of the anthracite coal trade, the Philadelphia Ledger says:

The House of Representatives has made itself even more ridiculous than the Senate by retaining the Sunday-closing proviso to the appropriation in the Sundry Civil bill in behalf of the World's Fair while striking out the provision that was to contribute $5,000,000 toward the general expenses of the exhibition.

The arrangements for the great ceremonies of notifying Messrs. Cleveland and Stevenson, which will take place in the Madison Square Garden to-night, are practically completed. The candidates will arrive here together this morning. The exercises will begin at 8 o'clock. As already indicated in THE TIMES, they will be no different in character from the notification exercises of past years except in the fact that they are to be public.

PESTH, July 19 -- A band of 180 reapers, men and women, employed at Bebar, Hungary, struck to-day for an increase in their wages. When their demands were refused they seized a wagon loaded with corn, declaring that that would be a fair share of the profits. Their employer summoned the gendarmes to restore order and get back his property.

The fight between the Long Island Railroad Company and the New-England Terminal Company, which has caused a cessation of traffic on the new Long Island and Eastern States line, got into the courts yesterday, when Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Special Term. Brooklyn, granted an attachment for $100,000 against the New-England Terminal Company.

LEBANON, Penn., July 19 -- The order to break camp was received at 2:3O o'clock this morning by Geu. Beckert. Immediately upon receipt of the order the sleeping camp was aroused, and quiet was replaced by noise and movement.

HOMESTEAD, Penn, July 19 -- Will the workmen yield, or will they continno the fight is the one absorbing question in Homestead outside of the circles of the strikers. Assistant Superintendent Otis H. Childs said to-day that to-morrow over 300 of the old men would return to the mill. On the other hand, every workman that was asked asserted that not a man would return.

The Board of Aldermen in special session reapportioned this city into thirty Assembly districts just after noon yesterday. This important business was done under the law passed by the last Legislature. There were no hitches, no injunctions, and the official part of the business was done with great expedition.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10 -- A controversy between the friends of Lawrence T. Neal and Congressman Tom L. Johnson of Cleveland as to which should be given the credit for the evolution of the tariff plank in the Chicago platform has been practically terminated by the following statement from Mr. Neal:

PITTSBURG, July 19 -- The ponderous iron door of the Allegheny County Jail yawned wide today, but none of the Homestead rioters passed within its gloomy portals. Back in the cavernous recesses of the prison lingered Burgess McLuckie, much against his will, denied the companionship and comfort which misery loves.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Capt. Borup, the officer who was recalled as military attache of the United States Legation at Paris, is still in the city -- still in more senses than one. He maintains an attitude of polite reticence, pending the decision in his case, daily expected from Secretary Elkins, with whom Capt. Borup has had frequent conferences since his arrival here.

DETROIT, Mich., July 19. -- The third renewal of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Stake for 2:24 trotters brought another large crowd to the Driving Park this afternoon, but the race was a very easy victory for Nightingale, a steady-going mare from Franklin, Ohio. She was a pronounced favorite in a large field and was never headed from the moment she stopped off in the lead early in the first Leat.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- When John I. Davenport sets up his concern to assist the Republican National Committee to run the New-York City campaign out of the public taxes he will find in operation a committee representing the opposition end of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Secretary of State Foster announced to-day that an entirely cordial and mutually satisfactory settlement had been reached between the Government of the United States and Chile, respecting the indemnity to be paid by the latter on account of the assault upon the crew of the Baltimore at Valparaiso on Oct. 16 of last year.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, July 19 -- P.M. It was another day of intense dullness in the stock market, and quotations were only slightly changed. There was some investment buying of New-York Central and Lake Shore, but otherwise the market was without feature.
I want to commend THE TIMES for the great good it has done in the interest of the Christian Endeavor Society.
Brooklyn vs. Louisville. Enstern Park, Vesta Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; Kings County Elevated and Atlantic Avenue Rapid-Transit Roads.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Capt. T.L. Casey, Jr., who has charge of the river and harbor work on the southwestern shore of Long Island and near Staten Island, N.Y., and in Northeastern New-Jersey, in his annual report to the Chief of Engineers deals with the following: places in the vicinity or New-York:

The news of the death by suicide, at Northport, L.I., yesterday morning, of Dr. Charles D. Scudder, the son of the late Henry J. Scudder, the former law partner of James C. Carter, now of Carter Ledyard, and the son-in-law of ex-Senator William M. Evarts, caused a shock among his many friends in this city.

About one-third of the members of the National Democratic Committee were in this city yesterday, and they, with many other prominent Democrats who had come to attend the ceremonies of notifying the candidates on the national ticket, were about the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broadway and Twenty-third Street, all day.

LONDON, July 19 -- There have now been elected 667 members of the House or Commons out of the 670 composing that body. With the result of the North Kerry election, duo to-day, the polling in Tipperary, which takes place to-day, and the polling in the Orkney Islands, which takes place next week, the contest will be over.

TRENTON, N.J., July 19 -- The argument in the suit of the Attorney General against the Philadelphia and Reading, the Port Reading, and the Central Railroad Companies began before Chancellor McGill this morning. Attorney General Stockton, Barker Gummere, and ex-Judge F. W. Stevens represented the State, and ex-Chancellor Williamson, Thomas N. McCarter, Theodore Mashart, Jr., J. G. Johnson, Samuel Dickson, R.W. De Forest, and John R. Emery appeared for the railroads.

Yesterday was one of the dullest days that Wall Street, accustomed as it is at present to inactivity, has ever witnessed. Wall Street has gone to sleep. Utter stagnation prevails on the Stock Exchange. During the first hour hardly anything was done to start trading, and throughout the day brokers went around in a half-listless fashion, without even attempting to give the appearance of business to the Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Articles of incorporation of the Union Law School of Chicago have been issued by the Secretary of State, with M.D. Ewell and others as incorporators. Mr. Ewell gives the causes and objects of the incorporation as follows: "The Union Law School or Chicago is organized as a protest against the present methods of instruction at the Northwestern University Law School.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 19. -- A defective flue in the bakeshop of the Atlantic Hotel, on Ocean and Morris Avenues, Long Branch, caused a fire at about 3 o'clock this morning. E. S. Lustig, the proprietor, was awakened by his wife, who smelled smoke. He ran to the rooms of the different guests to give the alarm.

It is satisfactory to see that the Secretary of the Treasury is reported to be entirely unmoved by the suggestions of some of his own friends (political friends) that he can take measures to check the export of gold by redeeming the Treasury notes of 1890 in silver dollars, whenever he is convinced that, if redeemed, in gold the gold would be exported.

Thomas Cook, the originator of the system of personally-conducted tours, died yesterday at his homo near Leicester, England, of paralysis, in his eighty-fourth year. He was born in Melbourne, Derbyshire, England, Nov. 22, 1808, in humble circumstances, and began his business life as a florist. When he was about twenty-five years old he moved to Market Harborough, in Leicestershire, and started a job printing office, which he managed along with his work as florist.

The decision of the authorities in charge of the World's Fair that foreign exhibitors will be permitted to display upon placards attached to their goods the prices of the goods at the place of manufacture and also the prices of the same in this country after the McKinley tariff duties have been added, is not regarded with approval by our esteemed contemporary the Iron Age, which says:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 19 -- The Monroe County Board of Supervisors met to-day and refused to comply with the new apportionment law on the ground that the act is unconstitutional. William A. Sutherland submitted this opinion:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 19 -- The disaffection of the majority of Republicans of Neptune Township on account of the President's appointment to the Asbury Park Postmastership of E. G. Harrison, at the behest of "Boss" Sewell, ignoring the indorsement by the Republican workers of George W. Treat, as already described in THE TIMES, came to a head last night at the meeting of the Young Men's Republican Association.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 10 -- A dispatch was received hero to-day from Saltillo, Mexico, stating that Lester H. Gale and J.E. Turner, the bank robbers of Nashville, Tenn., who were arrested in the former city four days ago, have been fully identified by J.H. Clark, Chief of Police of Nashville, who arrived this morning.

OMAHA, Neb., July 19 -- The visit of the Inter-State Commerce Commission to Omaha has not stirred up much of a hornets' nest, at least so far as surface indications are concerned. In fact the investigation was barren of all results. Only one witness was examined, C.W. Varney of Lincoln, Neb., who claimed to have a tale he could unfold touching alleged discriminations in rates by the Wabash Railroad.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19 -- The most sensational suit brought in Minnesota for years was filed by four prominent citizens of Stillwater in the United States Circuit Court to-day. In it ex-Senator Sabin, Thomas B. Walker of Minneapolis, A.H. Wilder of St. Paul, and many other prominent gentlemen of the Northwest are charged with conspiracy to sequester pine lands belonging to soldiers' homesteads to the value of nearly $1,000,000.

LOUISVILLE Ky., July 19 -- Cudahy, the Chicago packer, who recently made extensive purchases here and has just opened an extensive butchering and packing house, has disagreed with the local butchers, and a war of great extent is promised.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 19 -- A resolution that Chapter 397, laws of this year, directing a reapportionment of the Assembly districts is unconstitutional was voted down by the Albany Supervisors to-day by a strict party vote of 16 to 13. It was offered by the Republicans. The county was then reapportioned so that every district of the four is Democratic.

The arrangements for the notification of the Democratic candidates at the Madison Square Garden this evening have been all completed. The committee in charge has published a statement as to the nature and extent of the proceedings, which are to be very simple, and will take probably not more than an hour altogether.
We find in one of our contemporaries the following remark about carpets, credited to the Press of this city:

The Naval Reserves yesterday went out to practice at a target with the guns of the Chicago and Atlanta. They came back last night covered with glory and powder stains. The conditions were not altogether favorable for fine work with the big guns, but the practice was remarkably good.

The will of the late Cyrus W. Field was read to the family yesterday afternoon at Ardsley Park, the Fields' country place, near Dobbs Ferry, Westchester County. It will be offered for probate within a day or two in the office of the Surrogate of Westchester County in White Plains.

TRENTON, N.J., July 19 -- Senator John R. McPherson steps forward to controvert the opinion of Mr. James Smith, Jr., as to the Issue on which the next Gubernatorial campaign should be conducted and as to the candidate who should lead it, and to serve notice on the party managers that he proposes, when the proper time arrives, to take an active part in the controversy.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 20 -- Burgess John McLuckie of Homestead, no longer drunk and full of braggadocio, as when he surrendered on a charge of murder and rioting, but meek and sober, and looking as pious as a Baptist Elder, was brought from his cell in the Allegheny County Jail this morning and taken before Quarter Sessions, Judge Magee, in one of the lofty chambers of the new Court House.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- There is a general impression to-day that the appropriation of $5,000,000 to aid the World's Columbian Exposition, which was lost yesterday by 12 votes, may yet be approved by the conference committee of the two houses.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 20 -- The swiftest, most destructive, and most formidable naval vessel in the world, the much talked of and written about Pirate, or Cruiser No. 12, will be launched at Cramp's shipyard at 3:42 o'clock next Tuesday afternoon. When the contract was awarded to the Cramps, Oct. 4, 1890, there began almost endless speculation among those interested in the United States Navy.

If those foolish persons who say that everybody has gone out of town since the weather grew blazing hot had been in the neighborhood of Madison Square last night, they would have learned something about the numbers and enthusiasm of the plain people who stay here through heat and cold to attend to their Business and vote the Democratic ticket.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 20 -- Sheriff Hicks of Union County has an order in his hand to Bell the plant of the Metropolitan Gas Company of this city, on Aug. 24, at public auction, to satisfy a claim held against it by the Central Trust Company of New-York for $350,000 with interest.

BOSTON, July 20 -- New legal talent has been summoned to assist District Attorney Alien In preparing sew indictments against Messrs. French and Potter of the Maverick Bank. The Grand Jury will not come in before Aug. 16, and it is agreed that no arrests shall be made before the Grand Jury has considered the cases.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 20 -- J.M. Brown's IroquoisBrunette colt G.W. Johnson added another stake to his credit at Washington Park. The Quickstep, at half a mile, which brought twelve youngsters to the post, and was worth $3,450 net to the winner, was merely a gallop for him. Summaries:
HOMESTEAD, Ponn., July 20 -- Hush O'Donnell returned to Homestead at midnight. With him was Master Workman Dempsey of the Knights of Labor organization, District No. 3, of Pittsburg.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 20 -- The released Burgess returned to Homestead on the 1:33 train this afternoon. News of his arrival had spread quickly -- all news spreads quickly in Homestead -- and "when he stepped from the train between 600 and 800 men, a brass band, and two carriages wore on hand to give him an ovation.

Lieut. Sidney H. May of the navy committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the head with a revolver, in his room at the United Service Club, 16 West Thirty-first Street. He did not recover consciousness after firing the shot; and died within half an hour.

The attempt of the agents of the old GormanBrice combination to develop a sentiment which would elect Mr. Brice or Mr. Gorman Chairman of the National Democratic Committee at its meeting to-day was successfully checked yesterday. Little was heard of it, and as the members of the committee came to the city and the Democrats opposed to any such trifling got together, an effectual quietus was put on the attempt.

DETROIT, Mich., July 20 -- After two days of rather one-sided sport with the harness racers, this afternoon furnished a number of sensations, beginning with the 2:30 trot, in which two young California trotters, both by Guy Wilkes, met in their first race. Muta Wilkes, a five-year-old, is one of John A. Goldsmith's stable, and Hulda, a year younger, is in Hickok's care.

JACKSONVLLE, Fla., July 2O -- About 250 delegates composed the convention of the Florida People's Party, which was called to order at the Sub-Tropical Exposition Building this noon. Twenty-nine out of forty-five counties were represented.

LIVERPOOL, July 20 -- Further details of the loss last night of the British ship Maxwell off the bar at the mouth of the Mersey show that she was run into by a schooner, whloh struck her amidships and stove a large hole in her side. She soon filled and sank, but the water where she went down was not deep enough to cover her.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 20 -- Though the Yale football eleven will report for duty at Newport on Aug. 20, the management of the team is making every effort to induce the candidates to practice at their homes all Summer. To this end a football has been sent to every member of the team and the substitutes. Twenty have been sent out from this city, the last lot being shipped to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 20 -- The People's Party will be the first to make nominations in this State this year. The call for the convention to be held in this city will be issued in a few days, and the nominations will be made not later than the first week in August.

The Boston Athletic Association players and the Staten Island Crickets had a lively tussle on the letter's grounds yesterday,and the visitors won by a score of 6 to 4. "Jack" Highlands, the famous left-handed pitcher of Harvard College and Hewo did the pitching for the Bostons. Both played good ball. In fact, the work of all the members of the visiting team was of a very high character.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 20 -- The coming Congressional fight is already beginning to attract a great deal of interest on the Republican side. A compromise is looked for by which all factions will be represented, Warmoth being nominated for Congress in the First District, and Albert H. Leonard, the leader of the rival faction, standing for the Fourth.

With magnificent enthusiasm, and under circumstances without prececent in political annals, Grover Cleveland and Adlai E. Stevenson were officially informed of their nominations for President and Vice-President of the United States in the Madison Square Garden last night. The ceremonies were of the simplest character, dignified and impressive.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20 -- James Burns of this city was fatally injured and two boys, Joseph and Clipper Garrison, aged seven and nine, were killed at the Pennsylvania Railway crossing at Firth Street, East Newark, this afternoon. Burns was employed as n driver by the Illingworth Steel Works on the meadows, and between 3 aud 4 o'clock this afternoon approached the crossing at Fifth Street with a truckload of steel.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 20 -- The Republican State Central Committee met at the Allyn House in this city this evening, holding the first session for the campaign. The attendance was unusually large for the first meeting, only two Senatorial districts in the State failing to be represented.
TRENTON, N.J., July 20. -- The argument in the "coal deal" suit was continued before Chancellor McGill this morning.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Chicagoans were considerably put out by the action of the House in refusing to concur in the Senate amendent to the Sundry Civil bill appropriating $5,000,000 for the World's Fair. When the news reached the directory consternation ruled supreme in the headquarters.

The plan of an auxiliary organization of the Democrats of the State of New-York, based on the enrollment made before the Syracuse Convention, is an excellent one, which every Democrat sincerely anxious for the success of the national ticket and for the development of the full strength of the party in the State will approve.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The distribution of the $75,000 awarded by the Chilean Government, in the case of the Baltimore, will be made, by the Secretary of the Navy, who has as yet however, had no opportunity to consider the question.

The invitation handicap tournament of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club has been favored with phenominally good weather: for yesterday it was again all that could be desired for tennis, and a large number of porsons came to see the matches. The principal contest of the day was the semi-final match at gentlemen's singles between E.P. Fischer, (scratch,) and Ross Burchard. (fifteen.)

Reports were current in Jersey City yesterday that Pennsylvania Railroad interests were concerned with a scheme to "get even" with the roads in the Philadelphia and Reading combination by striking at their suburban passenger traffic.

Both of the local clubs were beaten yesterday by their opponents from the West, and the defeats were both surprises for the talent. It was the Chicagos' first victory of the second series, and naturally enough everybody expected to see the New-Yorks win. At Eastern Park, in Brooklyn, where Ward's men have been playing grand ball, they sucoumbed to the prowess of "Fred" Pleffer and his team from the big Kentucky city.

The Jersey City Board of Finance remained in session Tuesday night till it had arranged the tax budget for the fiscal Tear commencing next December. The notable feature of it is that it is $100,000 larger than the ring tax levy of last year. The appropriations, as compared with the appropriations to the several boards for the current fiscal year, are as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Three members of the House Judiciary Committee -- Wolverton, (Dem., Penn.,) Layton, (Dem., Ohio,) and Broderick, (Rep., Kan.,) -- have just completed an investigation, under a resolution introduced by Mr. Oates (Dem., Ala.,) of irregularities in the conduct of United States Commissioner Hallett and J.G. Stetson, Clerk of the United States Circuit Court at Boston.

The Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club has issued the following circular about its sweepstakes race for ninety-foot schooners, to be sailed Sept. 15 over a triangular course, ten miles each leg, outside of Sandy Hook:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- At last the Republican National Committee is provided with its complement of officers. Ex-Representative Louis E. McComas of Maryland accepted, this evening, the invitation of the President to be Secretary of the committee.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 20 -- Homewood Park had a trotting carnival to-day fully up to Grand Circuit Farm. Five thousand persons saw ten well-fought and exciting heats. The track, always good, was in tiptop shape, and when Starter Woodmartin rang up the 2:29 class trotters thirteen responded. Alter a good many changes in the opening betting it finally settled on Dirigo at $50; Raven, $30; the tield, $30.

LONDON, July 20 -- High winds and heavy rains are general in Great Britain. The storm came in from the Atlantic and reached Scotland yesterday. It traveled in a southeasterly direction, developing into a gale. From many parts of the coast a number of minor shipping casualties are reported.

The contribution of the Fifty-second Congress, at its first session, to the new steel fleet, although small in the number of vessels it adds, is unequaled in their character. The battle ship and armored cruiser which it provides will surpass anything in their respective classes, and for their displacements, yet undertaken on this side of the ocean, or probably on the other.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Serious trouble threatens the Western roads in consequence of the order of the Inter-state Commerce Commission reducing the rates on lumber from Eau Claire, Wis., to the Missouri River. The conferences that have been held this week have not had the effect of diminishing the gravity of the situation, because the interested lines were unable to agree upon a plan of concerted action.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 20 -- The Sunday law was not enforced last Sunday any more than on any other Sunday. The strict law has been inoperative almost since its passage, because the saloon keepers organized such a strong opposition to it that no jury could be found to convict. Now, however, there are signs of the times which indicate that New-Orleans will soon be a Sunday-closing city through the force of interested public sentiment.
CORK, July 20 -- Steam was got up to-day in the boiler of the donkey engine on the wrecked Inman Line steamer City of Chicago, and the work of saving her cargo is again in progress.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 20 -- Gov. Pattison expressed himself in plain language to a doctor of Homestead who called this afternoon to persuade him to remove the National Guard, on the ground that the town was quite orderly. The Governor said:

FRANCIS AQUILA STOUT. Mr. Francis A. Stout, whose death at Alexandria Bay Monday was announced in THE TIMES yesterday, was a man very highly regarded by a wide circle of friends. He had never been in business, and, perhaps owing in part to the fact that his health had been at no time strong, had never been very prominent in public affairs.

ALBANY, N. Y., July 20 -- The fact that the contract for finishing the canal between Poconic and Shinnecock Bays, on the further end of Long Island, was closed to-day will be hailed with delight by the residents and property owners along the shores of those bays. The canal was began six years ago, and is 40 feet wide, with two to one side slopes.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 20 -- There has been practically no change to-day in the labor situation at the Carnegie plants at Upper and Lower Union and at Beaver Falls. Several hundred men are working in the Upper and Lower Union Mills, but they are laborers, not skilled workmen. None of the Amalgamated men have returned.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Sledge-hammer blows were dealt the Anti-Option bill to-day by Senator Vest (Dem., Mo.,) in a speech of over two hours' length. In all the years of his service, he declared, he had never encountered a more pernicious measure. There was not the slightest doubt that it was unconstitutional and thoroughly vicious.

There is a new factor to be taken into account in calculations upon the chances of the next Presidential election, the force and effect of which are practically unknown. The ballot-reform movement received a strong impetus after the election of 1888, and it was largely due to the scandals connected with the campaign of that year.

LONDON, July 21 -- True to its general character of unexpectedness, the general election came to a close with a failure of the Liberals to win the three seats they absolutely counted on and to hold one other seat that no one had dreamed was in danger. They stand now, at the finish, where they did Sunday.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 20 -- Missouri Democrats have never before seen such a political gathering as assembled at the State Capitol for the purpose of nominating a lull State ticket. The weather was the hottest Known this Summer, and for two days and nights the delegates sweltered and suffered.

SARATOGA, July 20 -- The weather-wise shook their heads last Saturday night after the display of the aurora and predicted a cold spell, and the early hours of Sunday seemed to indicate the fulfillment or the prophecy, for the air was decidedly sharp, but the atmosphere soon mellowed, and a succession of lovely days with sunshine, tempered by cool pine-laden breezes, has followed.

LONDON, July 20 -- In the Bow Street Police Court to-day Sir John Bridge remanded for trial Sir Gilbert Edward Campbell of Barnard's Inn, Charles Montague Clarke of Glen Lagen, Droma, Ireland; William James Morgan of Lynette Avenue, Clapham Common; David William Tolmie of Lady Margaret Road, Camden Town, and Edwin Sherwin, who are charged with conspiring to defraud.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 20 -- The aquatic event of the season in Canada was the thirteenth annual regatta of the Canadian Association of Amateur Carsmen held here this afternoon. The course was laid out off Hanlan's Point, within a stone's throw of the romantic spot at the edge of a lagoon where Edward Hanlan first began training for his successive victories.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 21 -- Moosup, conn., the principal manufacturing centre in Plainfield Township and a village of over 2,000 inhabitants, was visited by the most destructive conflagration in its history this morning, the business centre of the village, including its hotel, the railroad station and freight house, and six other buildings, including two dwellings, being entirely destroyed.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland and William C. Whitney went from Mr. Whitney's residence to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broadway and Trrenty-third Street, a little after 10 o'clock yesterday. The exercises of the night before had not wearied the ex-President at all, so far as could be seen, and he seemed in the finest spirite as he entered the corridor and stopped to shake hands with a few acquaintances.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Considerable of a sensation has been caused by the announcement of the Atchison, Topeka ana Santa Fe Road that it will make a rate of $12 from Chicago to Denver and return on account of the Triennial Conclave of Knights Templars. The other roads are filled with consternation by this startling cut. The reason given by the Atchison people for taking this step exposes a rather surprising state of affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The joint Immigration Committee to-day took up the Ellis Island investigation at the request of some of the Treasury officials, who desired to submit further testimony in connection with the alleged malconstruction of the buildings.
ROME, July 21 -- The Italian cruiser Giovanni Bansan has been ordered to proceed to NewYork in October to take part in the Columbus monument celebration.
The following business was transacted at the NewYork Real Estale Salesroom yeaterday, Thursday, July 21:

Nearly all the arrangements have been completed for the formation of a company which will absorb the big flour mills of this city. The new corporation is to be a seven-million-and-a half affair, and will practically control the milling business in New-York and its neighborhood.

A story from Boston that the Directors of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad had voted to withdraw from the Western Traffic Association next October caused a flutter of interest among the Western railroad men in this city yesterday. The reason given for thi alleged action of the Burlington Directors was that the Advisory Board had failed to carry out the terms of the agreement.

-- The century ran of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs from Newark to Princeton and return will be held to-morrow. The start will be made at 4 A.M., and an average pace of eight miles an hour will be made. The riding time is to be twelve hours, with rents for meals of three hours. Any one riding ahead of pacemaker will be counted out.

These are the officers chosen by the National Democratic Committee at a meeting held yesterday in Parlor D R of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broad-way and Twenty-third Street. Every State and Territory, except Alaska and Indian Territory, was represented either by the member of the committee or by a proxy.

At Westminster Police Court on July 11 John Knott, twenty-nine, described on the sheet as a bookmaker, having no fixed abode, was placed in the dock charged before Mr. De Rutzen with burglariously breaking and entering 35 Belgrave Square, the residence of Lieut. Col. Arthur Paget, Scots Guards. Inspector Porter, B Division, watohod the case for the Commissioners of Police.

-- A mastiff dog, weighing 100 pounds, was inadvertently looked in a vacant store at Toronto, Ontario, on June 18, and it was not discovered until Wednesday night that he was imprisoned. The dog was still alive after its thirty-two days' fast, but weighed only 24 pounds. A skilled veterinary surgeon thinks he can save the animal.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Many of the Republican Senators are very much disappointed at the decision of Commissioner Carter to accept the Chairmanship of the Republican National Committee. They are much pleased to have the business of the Land Office go along smoothly, as it has done, during Mr. Carter's administration.

While sixty Texas steers were being driven from the foot of Norht Eighth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, to the Johnson Avenue slaughter house two of them escaped and dashed down Maspeth Avenue toward Nowtown Creek. Three men on horseback were in charge of the herd and they went after the runaways. They were joined by several mounted policemen and a crowd of men and boys.

Apparently without any trouble the New-Yorks won from the Chicagos yesterday. They outbatted and outfielded their oppanenents and played without making any blunders. At the outset Anson made a good bid for the game, but the New-Yorks' superior batting began to tell as the game were on, and he had to accept the inevitable. Rusie is in splendid condition, and he pitched one of his very best games.

In the sale paddocks at Monmouth Park yesterday Col. Brace sold at auction twenty-five yearlings, the produce of the Brookdale Stud, the property of the estate of Mr. D.D. Withers, and eleven from the Ashland Stud. Mrs J.M. Clay, or owned by L.O. Appleby. There was some lively competition for the Brookdale yearlings and good prices were obtained, the twenty-five head bringing $26,475, an average of $1,059.

NEW-YORK. -- Cotton Exchange members yesterday voted to ratify amendments to the by-laws permitting brokers to take friends with them on the floor of the Exchange, and providing for an increase in the membership of the Warehouse and Delivery Committee from five to six.
The National Association of Jobbers in American Watches, as an officered organization. has ceased to exist. The actual benefits resulting from a combination, however, will continue.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The following proclamation was issued this afternoon by the President:

LONDON, July 21 -- Mr. Gladstone left Pitlochry for Chester this afternoon. He was given an enthusiastic reception upon his arrival at Perth, and some of his admirers presented him with baskets of fruits and flowers. He looked well and showed no sign that his campaign had affected his health.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary Tracy has issued a circular providing for continuous-service certificates and good-conduct medals. It is provided that all persons honorably discharged from the naval service after having served an enlistment for three years, general service, who may re-enlist for three years, general service, within three months from the date of discharge, shall be given a continuous-service certificate in lieu of such discharge.

E.R. Holden, Vice President of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway, spent an uncomfortable two hours yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel before the State Senate committee which is investigating the Reading Coal combination. Mr. Holden is a stout, florid old gentleman, with flowing Burnsides and a very poor opinion of the public generally, and newspaper people in particular.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 21 -- The result of the contest in the Republican State Convention over the question of a candidate for Governor fully verified the predictions already made in THE TIMES'S dispatches. The Hon. John T. Rich of Lapeer County was nominated on the first ballot by a two-thirds majority, the vote standing Rich, 579 1 2; Hazen S. Pingree of Detroit, 201 1 2; scattering, 6.

An examination of the papers of Lieut. Bidney H. May, made yesterday by Coroner Shea, did not reveal any motive for the suicide of the unfortunate naval officer. The letter from his mother was simply such a letter as an affection ate mother would write to a dutiful son. The statement that in this letter Mrs. May reproached.
Edward Collings Knight, the sugar refiner of Philadelphia, died at his Summer cottage, Cape May, K.J., at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, after an illness of three months of pneumonia.

Bernhard Rueger was employed in the Flushing Avenue Iron-Clad Works. Brooklyn, until a week ago, and then lost his position because of intoxication. He then got drunker than ever and went to his home, 181 McKibbin Street, and quarreled with his wife.

CINCINNATI, July 21 -- A Commercial Gazette Washington special gives Capt. Comiskey as authority for the statement that the Cincinnati team has made an exchange with the New-York. Club of Pitoher Tony Mullane for Pitcher Amos Rusie. Muliane, who is here, has not been notified, bat says he is willing to go if he can got his price.
Congressman McMillin of Tennessee said yesterday:

BOISE CITY, Idaho, July 21 -- United States Marshal Pinham has gone to Ceur d'Alene with warrants for eighty of the rioters, charging them with contempt of the federal court in having violated the injunction restraining them from interfering with the operations of mines. The policy of the Federal officers, however, has heen changed.

LONDON, July 21 -- A dispatch to the Lancet from Paris says that the cholera in the suburbs of that city is stationary and exhibits no tendency to extension within the fortifications. Officially the disease is styled epidemic choleriforme. It develops so slowly that time for preparations to combat it can be readily taken. It does not seem to have taken root within the walls of the city.
TAMPA, Fla., July 21 -- Some of the Cuban agitators bore and in Key West are not a little exercised, at reports of their movements having been sent to the New-York press.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Faraday picked up his 120 pounds, giving all the way from 3 to 25 pounds to his field, and galloped home winner of the Dearborn Handicap, for three-year-olds, at Washington Park to-day in the presence of 5,000 people. The day was perfect and the track fast. Faraday opened and closed favorite in the betting, 6 to 5 being the longest price laid against him.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the following nominations of Ministers:

Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation or Labor, acting on the advice of Secretary Foster, called on Col. Weber yesterday at Ellis Island and had a long talk with that gentleman as to the advisability of having two labor men appointed to see that the provisions of the contract labor law are vigorously enforced.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Cameron (Rep. Penn.,) has teen trying to work up a sentiment in the Senate antagonistic to the confirmation of George Shiras, Jr., of Pennsylvania, as Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. Mr. Cameron was not consulted by the President regarding this nomination, and he feels that Mr. Harrison desired to humiliate him.
Acting Secretary Burke of the Republican National Committee said yesterday that it was as good as settled that the headquarters would be at 518 Fifth Avenue.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 21 -- Toronto oarsmen were rather disappointed over the results of the second day of the Canadian Amateur Oarsmen's Association regatta this afternoon, the most important event being taken by one of the American scullers, whereas it was looked upon as about certain that a local oarsman would carry away the honors of the day. The weather was again perfect and the course all that might be wished.

The Harvard boys who are here as representatives of the Boston Athletic Association are playing great ball. They have not lost a game on the trip. Yesterday the New-Jerseys met them on the grounds at Bergen Point and felt confident of success, notwithstanding the fact that the great "Jack " Highlands was in the pitcher's box. It takes more than confidence, however, to win ball games, and the NewJerseys are aware of that fact to-day.
LONDON, July 22 -- A dispatch from Tangier, giving a detailed account of the experiences of the British Mission to Fez, says:

LIBERTY, N.Y., July 21 -- Mrs. Solomon Lewis of Glen Wild, Sullivan County, recently celebrated the one hundred and third anniversary of her birth. Her sight and hearing are but little impaired, and she is so active that she made a trip to Wurtsborough by carriage last week without experiencing any unusual fatigue.

-- Samuel F. Corey Clerk of the Saratoga Police Board, died yesterday morning from pheumonia. He was thirty eight years of ago. He was the son of Judge John A. Corey and was a member of the Saratoga Jeffersonian Club. He leaves a wife and six children.

BOSTON, Mass., July 21 -- Over a thousand people witnessed to-day's tennis matches at Longwood, which for this season of the year is a very large gathering. The favorable weather continued and the eonrts were in excellent condition. As a result of to-day's contests the finals of to-morrow will be between F.H. Hovey, the inter-collegiate champion, and Malcolm Chace of Providence, the young winner of the interscholaslio event.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Gen. J.B. Weaver and Chairman Taubeneck arrived in St. Louis this morning from Vincennes, Ind., and went directly to the National People's Party headquarters. Gen. Weaver had abandoned his linen duster and was attired in a handsome suit of broad-cloth and wore a derby hat. When askod how he was pleased with the prospects after the grand rally at Vincennes, Ind., he replied:

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Homestead-Pinkerton investigation will be resumed to-morrow morning by the special committee of the House Committee on the Judiciary, and the Pinkertons will be given an opportunity to explain and defend the workings of their system. Chairman Oates received a telegram from the Pinkerton agency, saying that Robert Pinkerton would be present.

NYACK, N.Y., July 21 -- The people of Upper Nyack are greatly excited over the matter of the W.P. Foss dynamite works being removed from Haverstraw to the Hook Mountain, a short distance above the Upper Nyack corporation limits.

Application was made to Justice Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday for an injunction to restrain Edwin Young, executor of Thomas Cornell, from selling the half-interest in the Cornell Steamboat Company belonging to the estate, to S.D. Coykendall, who owns the other half. The application was made by exJudge Donobue, representing Mrs. Catherine Cornell, Thomas Cornell's widow, who is an executrix under his will, and Mr. Cornell's daughter, Mrs. Nellie Carpenter.

BAIREUTH, July 21 -- The Wagner Festival opened to-day with a performance of "Parsifal," the seventy-sixth or that work given here. JL Van Dyck, who was heard in the title role, sang and acted throughout with great dramatic power.

The funeral of Dr. Charles Davies Scudder took place yesterday morning in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, corner of Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue. Dr. Scudder committed suicide while in a demented state at Northport, L.I., last Tuesday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 21 -- There was a great crowd at Homewood Park to-day and the trotting and pacing were of high order. Over $100,000 went into the pool box in the ten heats of the three events. The results:

A meeting of the creditors of John Mason, the young man who, two months ago, closed his Jewelry establishment at 262 Fifth Avenue and made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors, was held yesterday morning at the office of the New-York Jewelers' Association, 146 Broadway. The creditors decided to make efforts to induce some Individual or syndicate to purchase the stock of the establishment in bulk.

The surrender of O'DONNELL and ROSS, two of the ringleaders at Homestead, is a fresh vindication of the course that has been pursued by the authorities of Pennsylvania from the beginning of the troubles at Homestead. The local authorities showed weakness in the first instance, probably assuming that the trouble would "blow over" and making only a perfunctory attempt to put it down.

The hospitality of the Sagamore Club was extended to Candidates Cleveland and Stevenson last night with a degree of vociferous enthusiasm that must have reminded the Democratic standard bearers of the ovation they received at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The previous literature on the civil forces employed at the navy yard has made necessary another regulation circular from the Navy Department settling some of the disputed points in the regulations established by previous orders. Among the matters dealt with are the following:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 21 -- The question was raised to-day whether the action of the Republican Supervisors in refusing to apportion the county would not have the effect of depriving the county of representation altogether in the next Legislature.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 21 -- The question was raised to-day whether the action of the Republican Supervisors in refusing to apportion the county would not have the effect of depriving the county of representation altogether in the next Legislature.

The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, which contains the provision for Government aid to the World's Fair at Chicago, is in the hands of a conference committee consisting of three Senators and three Representatives. All three of the members on the part of the Senate and one of those for the House are favorable to the appropriation, but the other two House members, Messrs. HOLMAN and SAYRES, are opposed to it.

The range at Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by a battalion of the Fourteenth Regiment, composed of Companies A, F, G, H, and I, under command of Major Stern and numbering 120 men. The weather was fair, with a light 12 o'clock wind.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 21 -- This is the last day of grace for the striking workmen at the upper and lower Union Mills. Few of the old hands applied to go back, and the serious break in the ranks of tno strikers which Secretary Lovejoy professed to expect did not occur. Tomorrow, or as soon thereafter as possible, the company say that they will start the mills, or a portion of them, with non-union men.

Dr. Join J. Paulsen of 335 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, when returning from a call at an early hour yesterday morning, was met at Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street by a policeman who at once began to club him. The doctor was so surprised that he offered no resistance, and the next instant he found that the policeman had slipped a pair of handcuffs on his wrists.

Neither of the two Internal Revenue Collectors in this city, Gen. Michael Kerwin for the Second District and Ferdinand Eidman for the Third District, has yet enforced the Chinese Exclusion act, as the Internal Revenue Department at Washington has not furnished the necessary provisions for its enforcement.

ON BOARD NEW HAMPSHIRE, PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 21 -- The wearied victors and vanquished of Wednesday's mimie fray on the beach at Fort Hamilton encountered some of the roach edges of amateur sailor life, when they had to tumble out of their hammocks before daylight yesterday morning.

The reapportionment of the city into thirty Assembly districts has kept the politicians very busy thinking, figuring, and guessing. The Republicans protest that it is unfair, say that they are depending upon the result of the contention in Monroe County to declare the work unconstitutional, and then they add that they got more districts than they expected to get.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, July 21 -- P.M. The stock market was perceptibly broader today, the trading being exceptionally well distributed and prices higher. For some time conditions have been so shaping themselves that the improvement was only a matter of time, and now that it is here the brokers are asking how long it will last.

TAMWORTH, Ontario, July 21 -- A fatal collision occurred about lour miles west of Tamworth early this morning on the Bay of Quinte Railway. A regular passenger train was coming from Tweed, on time when it was met by a special from Erinsville consisting of an engine and tender. Both engines and several cars were wrecked.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jnly 22 -- Two more Homesteaders were added to-night to the little colony of rioters in the Allegheny County Jail. They were Peter Allen, Jr., and Matthew Foy. They were arrested at supper time at their homes in Homestead by Detective Jesse Morris. Allen was found at his house in the midst of his family and friends.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, July 22 -- A tornado swept over the milling town of Hiteman, just west of here, yesterday, blowing down and unroofing several residences. Several persons were injured, one man probably fatally.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- It is a pity that the people -- not the Northwestern millers -- who are urging Congress to pass the Anti-Option bill, under the mistaken notion that it will prove a boon to the farmers and the people generally, could not have heard the speech in opposition to the bill which Senator White (Dem., La.,) concluded this afternoon.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Acting under instructions ot L.A. No. 7,212, I respectfully submit the following resolutions, which have been adopted by this body:

The Chicago, Burlington and Quincey Railroad Company has given the required ninety days' notice of its intention to withdraw from the Western Traffic Association. Some of the members of the association in this city received their notices yesterday.
