MASCOUTAH, Ill., July 25 -- News has just reached here of a bloody riot at a turner picnic at Queen's Lake, seven miles southeast of here, in Clinton County, last evening. The fight lasted about two hours and was bloody from start to finish.

A contest was begun yesterday in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court over the will of the late Mrs. Elizabeth K. Howe, who was the widow of Judge William C. Howe, for many years Associate Justice of Sessions in Westchester County.

Policeman Thomas W. Walsh killed Charles Reilly, an ash-cart driver, in Thirty-ninth Street, near Second Avenue, last night, by shooting him in the back of the head with a revolver. The officer was shot in the forehead.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- President Harrison has not accepted the invitation to be present at the dedicatory ceremonies next October, and the Fair Directors are wondering why. They have been wondering for many weeks. They do not know whether the President intends to snub them or whether his private secretary has thrown the answer to the invitation which the head of the Nation received last May into the waste basket.

In spite of all that has been done to exterminate the "green-goods" man he still flourishes, and his ingenuity is unflagging. These enlightened days demand progressive methods, and the "green-goods" swindler keeps up with the times. His methods of working have been exposed time and again by the newspapers all over the country, but the supply of gullible persons seems to keep up with the demand.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 25 -- Charles M. Cromwell of New-York, the guest of the West End Hotel who was robbed of a watch and diamond jewelry on Friday last by George T. Gadon, is expected back to-day from Albany, where Gaden was arrested with the stolen property in his possession.
-- An agent of the Customs Service is to be sent to Germany to investigate charges that fancy papers, large quantities of winch are sent to this country, are made in Berlin jails.

-- A fire broke out in the Quinnipac Building, on the south side of Chapel, below Union street, New Haveu, Conn., yesterday, and before it was brought under control the building and its occupants had sustained a damage of about $16,000. The fire originated in the attie, probably from spontaneous combustion.
Charles Davis, aged fifty-two, of Elm Street, Fort Richmond, has disappeared, and it is believed that he has committed suicide. Mr. Davis's family consists of his wife and three grown children.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25 -- Owing to a thunderstorm at 6 o'clock to-night telegraphic communication was shut off here from 6:10 to 10:30. Miss Burbidge, the talephone operator in the central office, was knocked senseless and several telegraph poles were shattered by lightning at 6:10.

MORRIS COVE, Conn., July 25 -- The yachts of the Atlantic Yacht Club reached here this afternoon on their annual cruise to the eastward. The ran from Black Rock was a close and exciting one, Capt, E. B. Haven's sloop Athlon winning over the flagship Water Witch and the sloop Gulnare. The wind was light, from the southwest, when the yachts got under way.

BAY CITY, Mich., July 25 -- The greatest confiagration that ever visited Bay City broke out at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the lumber manufacturing establishment of Miller Turner, situated on Water Street, west side, at the foot of Twenty-ninth Street.

Anarchists of this city, those of the pronounced type as well as their more moderate brethren, say they are of the opinion that Alexander Berkmann, who attempted to kill H.C. Frick in Pittsburg last Saturday, had no accomplice, or at least that no plot was hatched in this city to put the Carnegie manager out of the way.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Secretary of State having suggested the advisability of sending an American war ship to Honduras to look after the American interests in that country, in the event of further trouble, the Secretary of the Navy has selected the Kearsarge, now at Portsmouth, N.H., for that service. She will start for Honduras in a few days.

The old ship New-Hampshire presented a very busy scene yesterday in spite of the fact of the Naval Militia having taken their departure. Express wagons, drays, and other vehicles paid frequent visits to the old vessel, carting away the numerous things that had been put aboard for the comfort and accommodation of her crew.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25 -- Charles Robinson and Victor Stehlen, employed in Wolter's produce store on Mulberry Street, engaged in a fatal skylark this afternoon. Robinson shied a piece of watermelon at Stehlin, striking him on the neck. Stehlin advanced toward Robinson to strike him, and Robinson, retreating, fell over a chair and then to the street, his head striking the pavement.

SARATOGA, July 25 -- The arrivals by the Saturday night and to-day's trains have been very heavy, and what promises to be a stirring week is inaugurated with large crowds. The races beginning to-day and the regatta to-morrow form a double attraction to sport lovers and to those who come to the Spa every Bummer at this time.

Isaac Maguire, the Marshal of the Forty-seventh Regiment, Brooklyn, who recently shot Private Charles Dovan, was to have been examined before Police Justice Goetting of Brooklyn yesterday, but he was not in court. His friends admitted that he had left the State, but said he had merely gone to New-Jersey to attend the funeral of his sister.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25 -- Hugh O'Donnell And his fellow-prisoners, Hugh Ross and Peter Alien, Sr., were released from jail to-day on furnishing security in $10,000 each for their appearance for trial in September on a charge of murder in the second degree. O'Donnell had trouble in finding confiding bondsmen.
TORONTO, Ontorio, July 25 -- The Empire, the chief Government organ, in an article on the Retaliation bill, says:

In the event of the plans of the Strowger Automatic Telephone Exchange being carried out the days of the "Hello!" girl may be said to be numbered. With the assistance of the device patented and now being put upon the market by this corporation, the necessity for a "central" office is done away with and telephone subscribers will be happily relieved of the "personal equation" in the shape of the switchboard tender.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 25 -- The interest as to the identity of the dead body seen floating in the kills at Tremley Point, N.J., Saturday, has been increased by the announcement that two men are missing from the Grasselle Chemical Works, and it seems probable that one or both of them met with foul play.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop to-day received word tnat Henry F. Hardy, the noted "soap box" bank thief, has been apprehended at Frankfort-on-the-Main, in Germany, for pursuing his old schemes.

The publication of the results of an inquiry concerning the condition of the tin mine of the San Jacinto Company in California has drawn from the high-tariff press of San Francisco some curious assertions about the duty on tin plate and the prospective duty on tin. The Call of the 12th inst. makes the following lucid explanation:

-- Ladies' clubs are springing up all over the country. One was formed at West Somerville, Mass., recently called the Clarendon Cycle Club. Its officers are: President -- Mrs. Emma Libbey; Secretary -- Mrs. Foster; Treasurer -- Miss Nellie Perry; Committee on Runs -- Miss Carry Perry.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 25 -- The attendance at the opening of the Saratoga race meeting to-day was large and the new grand stood was fairly filled. The weather was hot, but the heat was somewhat modified by hazy clouds. The track was in fine condition.

-- The offers of silver to the Treasury Department aggregated 836,000 ounces. The amount purchased was 170,000 ounces at $0.8650. The department having purchased the amount of silver authorized by law for the current month, on further offers will be considered until Monday, Aug. 1.
In the August Forum Mr. Louis Windmuller has this, among other things, to say in his article, "The Folly of the Silver Agitation":

The Brooklyns failed to play with their accustomed skill yesterday. They made several mistakes which gave the game to Pittsburg. In the seventh inning Baldwin should have been forced out at the plate, hut he scored his run. The Brooklyns led in the batting, but the loss of the game was due to carelessness more than anything else. Hart pitched effectively, and the Pittsburgs played a strong game in the field.

A dinner was given to Alderman Michael J. Coffey of Brooklyn by his friends of the Twelfth Ward of that city at the Brighton Beach Hotel, Coney Island, last night. ExCongrossman Daniel O'Reilly of New-York City, presided, and over 200 politicians were present. There was speech-making and singing until 1 A.M., when a special train of the Brighton Beach Company carried the jolly party back to Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Hot weather is rapidly melting away the Congress, and unless an effort is made immediately to finish the business in hand it is doubtful whether it will be possible to do anything with a quorum or without a special dispensation from Mr. Bailey of Texas, who has registered a vow that nothing shall be done without a quorum.

Samuel Stevens Sands, who died on Sunday at his country place, Elmhurst, New-Hamburg, N. Y., was only one or two places from the head of the list of Stock Exchange members in point of length of connection with that institution. He joined it in 1854. For many years he was head of the firm of S.S. Sands Co., acting as a broker for many important financial interests, including the Astors'.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25 -- No sooner do the strikers hear good news from one quarter than bad news comes from another. To-day Amalgamated headquarters were depressed over the announcement that between 150 and 200 nonunion men had reached Homestead from the East. They came in cars attached to the fast mail express, which does not ordinarily carry passengers.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 25 -- Official reports received here to-day show that nineteen deaths from cholera have occurred in the City of Viatka. There have also been fresh outbreaks of the disease on the Volga River.

WHEELING, West Va., July 25 -- The severe storm which passed over this portion of the country last night was more disastrous in its results than was at first dreamed of. It is now Known that there was considerable loss of life besides some destruction of property by lightning on Long Run, in Marshall County, a few miles south of Wheeling.

The intense heat, coupled with the prospects of rain, prevented a big turn-out at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, the attendance being the smallest of any day since racing was begun at the track this year. Before the showers the heat was something awful, and even after the rainfall there was not enough breeze to make it habitable in the bettingring.

Pearl button makers at least are not to be classed with the cold, hard men in the iron trade who pay their employes the market rate of wages and no more. The pearl button makers of Newark, we learn from the Tribune, now pay their hands, under the McKinley tariff, from $18 to $24 weekly, instead of from $8.50 to $12 under the preceding lower tariff.

Two auction stands were sold yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange. They had been leased for the year ending next May to Bryan L. and William Kennelly. George R. Read, President of the Exchange, bought one and Richard M. Montgomery the other, each agreeing to pay $112,50, the balance of rent for the unexpired term.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 26. -- The trial heats in the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen was rowed on Saratoga Lake this afternoon in fairly rough water for about half the distance.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 26 -- After the most successful run of the cruise the yachts of the Atlantic Club anchored this afternoon off the Pequot House. The day was an ideal one for yachting, and had the weather been made to order it could not have been more perfect. The flagship Water Witch did some clever running before the wind and beat the Athion into the harbor by two miles.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday , July 26 -- P.M. Considerably more than a third of to-day's business was in the industrial stocks, and they were all higher. Sugar was the most active and sold at 105 1/2, and, although it closed a fraction lower, it scored a net gain of 1 68 points. The buying was of the same character as in recent weeks, and it was stimulated by Mr. White's personal operations on the floor.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 26. -- The New-York and New-England Railroad Company and its objecting minority stockholders were again given a hearing before Controller Staub this afternoon on a petition of the former for the registration of $2,000,000 worth of new bonds. The Controller had as his counsel the Hon. Dwight Loomis, ex-Judge of the Supreme Court, while Prof. Baldwin appeared for the road and Attorney Webb for the objectors.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 26. -- The two days' cricket match between the Wanderers of Halifax and the Germantowns of Philadelphia resulted in a victory for the Americans by a score of 164 to 131 without need of a second inning.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 26. -- Judge Hall's finding in the Phelan vs. Walsh quo warranto case is to be announced to-morrow.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Provisions were stronger, in sympathy with grain. There was some realizing that caused a temporary break. Business was comparatively light. Packers made some attempt to hammer the market, but were good buyers of ribs, through brokers, at all times. Shipments of product were liberal, and, as receipts of hogs were small and prices at the yards showed an upward tendency, some of the shorts were run in.

As finally settled upon by Congress, the new Fortifications bill is a very fair and generally judicious measure. Some of its provisions are particularly commendable. It has appropriated the entire amount needed to complete the equipment of the south wing of the gun factory at West Troy, and the House concurs even in an additional Senate item for Watervliet Arsenal.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 26. -- What is called the Retaliatory bill, passed by the United States Congress, has aroused grave apprehension among Canadian vessel owners. The bill, as is known, gives the President power after Aug. 1 to levy a toll, not to exceed $2 a ton and $5 a passenger, on Canadian vessels going through the Sault Ste. Marie Canal.

CORRY, Penn., July 26 --The three days' tournament of the Corry Gun Club opened here to-day with an attendance of fair size. There are no shooters here from a great distance, but quite a number from nearby cities in Pennsylvania and New-York State. The grounds of the club are about as pleasantly situated and as completely fitted up as any other shooting grounds in the country.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Only one bill now remains to be disposed of before Congress can adjourn and go home. The conferrees today agreed upon the General Deficiency bill and reported to both houses, the houses agreed to the report, and the bill ass cone to the President. All that now remains to be agreed upon is the Sundry Civil bill, with the disputed Items concerning the Chicago exposition.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 26 -- The third week of the Grand Circuit opened here to-day. As usual at Cleveland there was, a large and enthusiastic crowd of horsemen. The betting booths were crowded from an early hour and from the opening of the pool auctions. But three horses were backed to win their respective races. The track was in good shape, and just previous to racing received a liberal sprinkling of salt.

Word was passed around the old Fourth Ward last night that "Campbell the Stoveman" was dead and that all his old neighbors were invited to his wake. "Campbell the stoveman," whose official baptismal appellation is John, is the Oak Street dealer in stoves and old furniture who for several days past has been carryiug on a war of words with Samuel Solerwitz, who does business in the same line as himself just across the street.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 26. -- The great Homestead strike or lock-out has had its back broken. Hugh O'Donneli has been practically deposed as leader, and the Advisory Committee will hereafter conduct affairs in its own way.
LONDON, July 26. -- The representative of the Associated Press was admitted to Mr. Carnegie's presence to-day. He opened the interview by saying to Mr. Carnogie:

HELENA, Mon., July 26. -- If President Hamson selected Commissioner Carter for Chairman of the Republican National Committee with the idea that he would thereby strengthen his own chances in this doubtful State, he made a mistake of judgment.

"It would be a great convenience if a telephone could be put in between the White House and the National Republican Committee headquarters, or if the President would imitate the Vice Presidential candidate and settle himself near the rooms where he is to conduct his campaign," said a gentleman yesterday who has been watching the strategles of the committee in its attempts to begin business.

A section of the large building of the New-York Biscuit Company, one of the largest and most complete plants of the kind in the world, was burned early yesterday morning, involving a loss of probably $150,000, which is fully covered by insurance. Fortunately, the fire was not attended bf injury to any person, although Chief Hugh Bonner had a narrow escape from death or serious injury by the collapse of a water tower.
HOMESTEAD, Ponn., July 26. -- To the merry tune of "Home Again" the Eighth Regiment, Col. Magee, marched down Carnegie Hill this afternoon at 4:30 homeward bound.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 26. -- California Republicans met in convention at Sacramento to-day for the second time this year. The convention to-day was for the purpose of nominating Presidential Electors, and Congressmen. Incidentally the Senatorial fight betweeen M.H. De Young and Senator Charles N. Felton was made a considerable part of the convention contests, the two Senatorial candidates working for their friends in their light for Congressional honors.

Because the lawyer whom Policeman Alexander E. Ward of the Eighth Brooklyn Precinct had retained to defend him against the charge of brutally clubbing Dr. John J. Paulsen of 335 Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, was busy trying a criminal case. Police Commissioner Hayden yesterday postponed the trial of the accused officer for two weeks.

"We allowed a few days ago that the difference between the wages paid in this country and the wages paid in Great Britain for the production of a ton of steel rails from the ore is only $3.78. This is the difference as discovered by the Commissioner of Labor under the Harrison Administration, Mr. CARROLL D. WRIGHT, and by him reported to Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26. -- Fifty thousand voices raised in mighty yell, the bellowing of a fleet of steam launches, tugs, and other vessels, handclapping and unbounded enthusiasm were the distinctive features of the baptism of the cruiser Columbia at Cramp's shipyard on the Delaware this afternoon. It was 3:36 o'clock when Miss Edith Morton, daughter of the Vice President of the United States, said:

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Hot though, it has been to-day, the Senate has spent five hours in manufacturing campaign material. Mr. Aldrioh (Rep., R.I.,) called up the Hale resolution as to the relative merits of protection and tariff for revenue only, and a tariff discussion ensued which reminded many of those in the chamber of the debates which excited so much interest two years ago.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 26. -- Last week the Rev. Edward Bean of Cookstown, in this county, started for his home from a Philadelphia hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment. He had a railroad ticket through to his home, but the conductor put him off at this place. Mr. Bean was very weak and acted a little strange after being put off the train.
No business of any importance was transaoted at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom yesterday, Tuesday, July 26.

Yesterday was the hottest July 26 in all the twenty-one consecutive years during which the official weather record has been kept in this city. The highest point scored by the thermometer on the Broadway sidewalk at Hudnut's was 98; the highest marked at the weather office on top the Equitable Building was 9612.

The capitalists who compose the Metropolitan Traction Company propose to reorganize that corporation under the laws of this State. Its present charter was obtained in New-Jersey. The new company will have a capitalization ot $30,000,000. Each holder of 100 shares of stook in the present company will receive 120 shares of the new stock, the extra 20 shares representing dividends that should have been paid during the long litigation with the New-York authorities.

PITTSBURG, July 26. -- The condition of H.C. Frick was better to-day than is was yesterday despite the great heat, and no complicating symptoms have appeared. Dr. Litchfield, one of his physicians, said to-night that if everything progressed favorably, two or three days would bring Mr. Frick beyond the last danger point.
BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 26. -- After returning from a fishing trip yesterday afternoon, Mr. Cleveland conversed at length about his visit to New-York to attend the notification meeting.

Umpire Wyckoff, the gentleman who presented the Cleveland Club with a victory on Monday, said that he was too lame to umpire yesterday, and in consequence his place was taken by Edward Crane, one of New-York's pitchers. The latter's name was acceptable to both Bides, and the local players won. It was a good game, though, the result being in doubt until the last man was retired in the ninth inning.

The funeral services of Michael Honnessy. the veteran newspaper man, for years the commercial editor of THE TIMES, were held yesterday morning in St. Peter's Charch. Warren and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn. About 200 friends assembled at the Hennessy residence, 227 Baltic Street, shortly before the hour for the funeral and accompanied the body to the church.

SARATOGA, July 26. -- A story of love and politics, of conflict between personal desire and party or family duty, is told in "The Courting Campaign," produced here to-night at Putnam Music Hall by Wilson Miner's players. The play pleased all who saw it, and its authors -- Albert M. Downes and Will P. Wilson -- received congratulations from their friends and the applause of the audience.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 26. -- Canadian newspapers continue to be exercised over the prospect of the retaliation measures proposed by the United States Government being put in force and threaten to get back on the United States in a manlier that will cause regret for the effort to bulldoze Canada. The Toronto News, a supporter of the present Dominion Government, says:

Dr. Henry G. McGonegal, the septuagenarian practitioner who gained notoriety about a year ago because he was convicted of killing Annie Goodwin, a cigarette maker, by performing a criminal operation upon her, is now a prisoner in the Queen's County Jail. Long Island City, charged with having in the same way caused the death of Mrs. Louisa Webb.

ROCK SPRINGS, Wyoming, July 27. -- The event in to-day's proceedings at the Democratic Convention was a speech by Walter R. Stoll, the brilliant young Cheyenne attorney. He made the address in resigning the Chairmanship of the State Committee. The wrath of mouths was uncorked, grievances were marshaled, charges answered, and individual traducers were given attention.

There was a lively time yesterday before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen. The final hearing on the application of the Fiftieth Street. Astoria Ferry, and Central Park Railway Company for a franchise was up for consideration, and a delegation of lawyers and property owners was on hand to put in a most earnest protest against the granting of the franchise.

There was a slight change for the bettor in the temperature yesterday, and the heat was not as intense as that of the day previous. The highest figure reached by the thermometer on Broadway, in front of Hudnut's, was 96, while at the Weather Bureau at the Equitable Building it registered at the same time 92. The mean temperature for the day was a little over 80.

WASHINGTON, Jnly 27. -- Gen. Martin T. McMahon, Grand Marshal of the Columbian parade, which is to be held in New-York City Oct. 11 and 12, consulted with Secretaries Tracy and Elkins to-day and received assurances that the Government would do all in its power to make the naval and military displays successful.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Judge George W. Greene and "Charlie" Swan made a push today to bring the New-York and New-Jersey paper bridge bill to final passage in the Senate.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27. -- Justice Rumsey's Special Term court room was filled to-day with members of the bar and politicians, to hear arguments on the ordor for the Board of Supervisors to show cause for refusing to obey the apportionment law. William A. Sutherland appeared for the board and City Attorney Kiehl, also a Republican, argued the case for the Democratic side.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., July 27. -- William Olark retained from Ritchfleld Springs this morning and declared that he had secured a well-known banking firm in New-York to take the Richfield Springs and Fort Plain Railroad off the hands of the local association of capitalists and construct it, "We do not propose to surrender the right of way which we control," said Mr. Clark, "until the road is completed.

We condole with LUKE EMERSON, Esq., of Bowling Green, Mo., who came to misfortune undeservedly within the limits of this town oil Monday last. To be sure, Mr. EMERSON, to a certain extent, is chargeable with his own misfortune. He was undeniably rash, knowingly to undertake to travel across the ocean in company with 168 personally conducted asses.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 27. -- "It is an election dodge," said Mr. Henry Beatty, manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway steamships on Lakes Huron and Superior, speaking of the retaliatory bill passed by Congress. "It will injure directly many United States interests far more than ours. For that reason I do not believe that the toll will amount to anything.

CORRY, Penn., July 27. -- The second day of the Corry Gun Club tournament was favored with beautiful weather and a fair attendance. It was not so hot as on the opening day, and as those present were more in the humor for shooting, a greater number of events were shot. As on the previous day, targets were used in the morning and live birds after dinner.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 27. -- The prison life of Dr. R.P. Wright ended at the Arkansas Penitentiary at 7 o'clock this morning. July 24, 1888, Wright was sentenced to a five years' term in prison for bigamy. His first wife then lived, as she does now, at Centre, Shelby County, Texas, and was instrumental in Wright's conviction.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 27. -- The appointment by President Harrison of Watson K. Sperry, editor of the Wilmington Morning News, as Minister Resident and Consul General of the United states at Teheran, Persia, is accepted hero as a move in the direction of uniting the warring factions of Delaware Republicans by officially recognizing those who have heretofore been left out in the cold.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27. -- Although the heat was oppressive, many spectators witnessed the finals in the national regatta to-day. They saw some close finishes, good rowing under difficulties on rough water, and not a few fouls aud upsets.
AMSTERDAM, July 27. -- The Handelsblad of this city publishes letters from Celebes giving details of the recent eruption or the volcano Gunona on Great Sangir Island.

The political deal by which the Dolmar-Barrett syndicate expects to put a trolley railroad along Union Street, Brooklyn, without paying a cent for the privilege is not going through as smoothly as its backers hoped. As announced in THE TIMES yesterday a suit is to be brought under the Tilden act for waste of the public funds.

LORD SHERBROOKE. Viscount Sherbrooke, more familiarly known as the Right Hon. Robert Lowe, died in London yesterday. He was born in Bingham in December, 1811, and was educated at Winchester and at University College, Oxford, where he was graduated in 1833. He was elected Fellow of Magdalen in 1834, and became a private tutor at Oxford.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 27. -- The Democratic State Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning with 1,200 delegates present. The morning session was devoid of interest. Gov. A.B. Fleming presided, W.L. Wilson being detained at Washington. United States Senator C.J. Faulkner was made permanent President.

Boston, Maas., July 27. -- The three-masted schooner Everett Webster, which struck the wreck or Vanderbilt's yacht Alva Tuesday evening, is of and from Philadelphia, bound for Salem with 700 tons of coal on board. She ran directly across the yacht's deck, carrying away her topmast and smokestack. She set signals of distress, and the tug George M. Winslow went to her assistance.

From all appearances now New-Yorkers nave a baseball team that they need not feel ashamed of. The club is rapidly forging to the front, and to-day is third and within easy hailing distance of Philadelphia and Brooklyn.
DUBLIN, July 27. -- The prominent members of the Pornellite party were present at the meeting of the Irish National League held in this city to-day, and a number of addresses were made.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 27. -- While Mr. Frick is gaining in strength every day, it must be a source of congratulation to him, if not of notification to the people of Pittsburg, that the attempt on his life has resulted in the smoking from their holes of as flue an assortment of Anarchists as ever threatened life, threw a bomb, or stabbed a victim in a dark alley.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The survey for a telegraph cable between California and the Hawaiian Islands has been completed and the report of the work on board the Thetis and the Albatross has been sent to Congress by Capt. Richardson Clover, the chief hydrographer of the navy, who had charge of the survey from the Washington end.

By a unanimous rote the Aqueduct Board yesterday decided to reject all the bids for the construction of the new storage dam at Cornells, on the Croton River. The reason for this action, as set forth in a report submitted to the full board by a sub-committee composed of Controller Myers and Commissioner Gilroy, is the alleged financial irresponsibility of the lowest bidders for the contract, the Ryan McDonald Construction Company of Baltimore, Md.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27. -- There was a good attendance at the track to-day. The weather was warm, but a breeze made it comfortable watching the races. The tract was in fine condition. There will be no racing to-morrow. The results:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27. -- The big programme for the second day of the Grand Circuit meeting was only partly disposed of this afternoon, two of the three regular events being decided after twelve heats were trotted and paced. Part of the delay was caused by the storm that came up soon after the horses were started, and the track was very heavy before the second race was finished.

The murder of a broker in Philadelphia, followed by the suicide of the customer who was his murderer, seems to be so far out of the range of common crimes as to be a grotesque freak, or if one prefers long words, a "psychological phenomenon." As a matter of fact, though the tragedy is, perhaps, without any precedent, it is not because stock gambling does not nourish the worst passions of human nature.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 27. -- Stock gambling in margins brought about a tragedy today as a result of which Charles H. Page, a well-known broker, lies dead at his home, assassinated by a customer, Ronald Kennedy, who closed his own account with the same weapon that ended the broker's career. No one witnessed the murder and suicide.

The question of appropriating $5,000,000 for the World's Fair through the peculiar device of issuing souvenir half-dollars was not absolutely settled in the House yesterday, although there was a vote by a narrow majority to concur in the Senate amendment making the appropriation. Mr. HOLMAN, who is bent upon defeating the proposition if possible, voted in the affirmative and then moved a reconsideration.

Chairman Harrity of the Democratic National Committee accomplished a great deal of work yesterday. In spite of the terrible heat he was busy all day preparing to open the campaign. He had a conference with William C. Whitney at Mr. Whitney's house, at which, in a general way, the campaign work was discussed. After that he devoted himself to securing a house for headquaters.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Thomas H. Carter, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, reached Washington early this morning from New-York, and is still here. He says he came "to finish up the little odds and ends" of Land Department business, which he was unable to complete at the time he handed in his resignation.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27. -- The fifteenth annual meeting of the American Paper Makers' Association was held here to-day. There were 250 members present representing the leading paper firms of the United States. President William A. Russell of Boston presided and made the opening address. Vice Presidents representing each branch of paper making reported business generally good, including the wood pulp interests.

Stephen White, a track driver, who lives at 2,434 Eighth Avenue, walked into Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning, his clothing saturated with blood which had flowed from several cuts on the head. He said he had been struck on the head With a brick or a stone by one of the strikers on duty as pickets at the brickyard of Canda Kane, Avenue D and Fourteenth Street, where there is a strike on.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 28 -- A serious international complication may arise from the mistake of Mrs. W.D. Bordo of Baltimore last evening at Bay Ridge. She went up to a dairy and made a purchase, laying her fan and pocketbook down, as she thought, on a case on the counter. When she picked up her fan she found that her pocketbook was missing.

The Irish Nationalists of New-York held a set of unregistered games at Jones's Wood, Sixty-seventh Street and East River, yesterday afternoon. They were poorly managed, but the spectators got lots of fun out of them.

The decision of the Supreme Court of the State of Michigan that the apportionment acts of 1891 and of 1885 are both unconstitutional as based upon a disregard by the Legislature of the positive requirements of the Constitution in respect to the division of counties. The requirements are similar to those of this State.

CORRY, Penn., July 28. -- The tournament of the Corry Gun Club ended here to-day. The number of shooters was much smaller than on either of the previous days, but those who remained enjoyed a beautiful day and lively sport, both at targets and live pigeons. The latter were an excellent lot of filers, the best birds having been reserved for the last day.

DENVER, Col., July 28. -- The People's Party State Convention was called to order in Coliseum Hall yesterday. Stephen R. Pratt of Denver, was nominated for temporary Chairman and unanimously elected. L.C. Paddock of Boulder, was elected Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- It is surely about time that the Congress should adjourn. That the strain upon the Congressional mind is becoming too great, and that there is danger of something cracking, may be assumed from the discovery made to-day of the tendency of honorable gentlemen, who are supposed to be laboring to provide for the Chicago Pair and save the country.

ORANGE, N.J., July 28. -- The little town of Milburn and the surrounding country was shaken at 7:55 o'clock to-night by a terrific explosion, which shook the houses and ground and caused terror to the inhabitants for several miles about. The explosion occurred at the Celluloid Zapon Works at Springfield, a mile and a half south of Short Hills, and the concussion was heard as far away as the City of Newark.

PITTSBURG, July 28. -- Superintendent Roger O'Mara arrived here to-night on the Pennsylvania limited with Anarchist Mollick, whom he arrested at Long Branch yesterday for complicity in the attempted assassination of Frick. From thirty to fifty sallow complexioned, shaggy-bearded, long-haired individuals curiously watched at a respectful distance the Superintendent and his prisoner when they alighted from the train.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 28. -- The first meeting which the Republican City Committee has held, called for the purpose of naming the time and places for holding the caucuses in the Congressional election, was held to-night in the Assembly Room of the new City Hall. It was the most disgraceful fracas of all the broils of the contest between Congressman James J. Beldon and his opponents of the Hiscock-Hendricks ring.

-- The Director of the French School at Cairo in Egypt has sent to the Academie des Inscriptions four busts in terra cotta, painted, which were found in the Great Oasis at El Kargeh. They have been taken from the lids of sarcophagi; but the peculiarity about them is that the heads were not in the same plane with the body, but, as it were, erect.

LONDON July 28 -- The Paris correspondent of the London Lancel telegraphs that M. Netter, a member or the Hygiene Publique, reports that in twenty-nine out of forty-nine cases of illness reported as cholera which he has investigated, he has found the true cholera bacillus. M. Ketter further says that the true cholera is limited to the suburbs of Paris, and that only that form of the disease known as cholerine exists in the city.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 28. -- A clouded sunrise this morning started the day more hopefully than was the case with the three preceding days, and although the sun shone later there was an appreciable lowering of the temperature. Saratoga has not escaped the hot wave which has swept over the country, but Saratoga has mitigating circumstances which make a hot wave bearable.

A less funereal-looking collection of men, despite their business, could hardly be imagined than the members of the Casket Salesmen's Protective Association -- casket being a rather euphemistic term for coffin, by the way -- who met yesterday morning at the Broadway Central Hotel, it being the first of the three days that are to be devoted to the sixth annual meeting of the association.

William Washington, who lived with his parents at 209 West One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged with robbing the premises of Mrs. Hattio Miller, who lived on the floor below the Washington family.

At the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, yesterday, July 28, William Kennelly, under a foreclosure decree, Daniel F. Martin, Eeq., referee, sold the five three-story dwellings, with plot of land 100.11 by 79.3, 771 to 779 West End Av. southwest corner of 103d St; and similar house, with lot 20.2 by 100.11, 303 West 103d St. south side, 189.8 feet west of West End Av. for $132,850, to New-York Lumber Wood Working Company.

ROCK SPRINGS Wyoming, July 28. -- The State Democratic Convention which ended here this evening was the greatest event in the political history of the State. The advice given in ex-Chairman Stoll's great speech of yesterday was followed closely. John E. Osborne, a wealthy young wool baron of Carbon County, was nominated for Governor on the thirty-seventh ballot.

For a year past the large carpet and upholstery dealers of the country have been considering the advisability or forming a national club for the purpose mainly of creating a more fraternal feeling in the trade. Two meetings of representative dealers were held, one at Coney Island and the other in this city. The outcome was the formation of the Renaissance Club of the United States, which on Wednesday was incorporated at Albany.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 28 -- G.W. Coffin, Naval Secretary of the Lighthouse Board at Washington, arrived hero to-day on the Lighthouse Department: steamer Azalea, which came up from the vicinity of the wrecked yacht Alva. Secretary Coffin has been in these waters for the past week looking after aids to navigation that come under his supervision.

That New-York should be the headquarters for almost every "green-goods" gang in the country is a severe criticism on the Police Department and its detective bureau, which pride themselves so much, on their efficiency, and yet it undoubtedly is true. Nearly all of the addresses given with the circulars with which the swindlers flood the country every week are in this city.

BAIREUTH, July 28 -- After an intermission lasting since Monday, tlie Wagner Festival performances were resumed to-day, the date set for beginning the second series. The performance was a repetition of "Parsifal," with which the festival was opened a week ago. There will be en more performances of 'Parsifal," and three more each of "Tristan and Isolde," "Tannhauser," and "Meistersinger."

The very worst of the gang of Jersey City ballot-box stuffers came to grief in Judge Lippincott's court yesterday. The four were known as the No. 3 Engine House gang. They were Michael Hughes. James Scanlon, Michael Cassidy, and Theodore Schultze Hughes is a driver at No. 3 Engine House for the ring. Cassidy holds a ring place as Weiphmaster at the City Water Works.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 28 -- Cholera has brokon out in the towns of Kharrkolf and Orenburg, and several cases of the disease have occurred along the Volga River above Nijni-Novgorod.
The follwing are copies of two letters to and from ex-President Cleveland which speak for themselves:

BOSTON, Mass., July 28. -- The special race of the Eastern Yacht Club for invited yachts which do not exceed 21 feet, water-line measurements, or 25 feet, racing measurement, was sailed off Halfway Rock, Marblehead to-day. The following yachts were entered: Catspaw, Walter Abbott; Sirocco, W.P. Fowle; Freak, J.B. Paine; Tadpole, W.E. Waterhouse; Kooaali, R.C. Robbins; R.D., Robert McIntyre; Pyxie, Oswald Sanderson; Reaper, H.P. Benson, and Alpha, J.F. Brown.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Two reports setting forth the majority and minority views of the House Immigration Committee, which has been engaged for the last six months in conjunction with the Senate committee in investigating the expenditures for the Ellis Island buildings, were presented in the House to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28. -- The luncheon of Miss Leary of New-York to-day was certainly the most charming event of the season thus far, the large attendance of prominent cottagers showing a great appreciation of Miss Loary's efforts to entertain her many friends. While the reception was at its height the scone on the lawn was one of exceptional beauty, many of the ladies present wearing bewitching costumes.

George K. Sistare, one of the family of that name which started to do business on Wail Street more than a half century ago, and continued to operate there until the firm of George K. Sistare's Sons went under with a crash, April 7, 1890, killed himself by putting a bullet through his brain in the reception room of the Manhattan Club, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday morning.

LANSING, Mich., July 28 -- The Supreme Court has banded down opinions declaring unconstitutional the two acts of the last Legislature reapportioning the representative and Senatorial districts in the State. The title of the case involving the Senatorial gerrymander was "Theron F. Gidding vs. Secretary of State," and that involving the representative redistricting "Supervisors of Houghton County vs. Secretary of State."

It is a curious illustration of how completely the House of Commons has become the governing body of Great Britain, and how unfortunate it is for an ambitious politician to be born a Lord, that so few of the people who have tolerably distinct impressions of the character and career of ROBERT LOWE even recognize him under the title of Lord SHERBROOKE.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 28. -- Gen. Snowden and the balance of his staff left for Philadelphia this afternoon. All the troops have gone except the Fifth, Fifteenth, and Sixteenth Regiments, four companies of the Tenth, the Sheridan Troop, and Battery B. Over 800 men are at work in the mills.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 28 -- The workingmen of the city are a good deal "hotter" than the weather to-day over Secretary Foster's appointment of the allen William Evans as Immigration Inspector at $5 a day. The announcement that Evans is not a citizen, as made in THE TIMES and the Baltimore papers this morning, started the comment Evans came over from Wales as a tin-plate worker.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 28. -- Punctually at 12:30 to-day President Edwards called the unfinished 2:27 trot at the Grand Circuit meeting here. H.C.T. was still the choice at 5 to 3, but the black stallion from Elmira was the freshest of the trio and finished an open length ahead of Magnolia.

Although the heat on the Polo Grounds yesterday was almost intolerable the enthusiasts who journeyed there were well paid their visit, as they witnessed the best game of ball ever played by a New-York team. The Giants had for their opponents the strong Louisville players, but they disposed of them with the ease and grace that characterized game of their early Spring games against amateur clubs.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28. -- E.L. Hall and W. A. Larned are the two men who will contest the finals in the men's singles of the Southampton tennis tourney, the winner to play V.G. Hall for the championship. Once before this season, at Tuxedo, have Hall and Larned met for the concluding match, Hall being the victor; but with the Cornell player's present improved form he should stand a good chance of winning to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Not even the persistent heat, which was as oppressive in the House to-day as it was yesterday, prevented the members who are in favor of and opposed to the appropriation for the Chicago Exposition from continuing the fight begun yesterday, when the majority decided that the House should concur in the Senate proposition to give the World's Fair $5,000,000.
SARATOGA, N.J., July 28. -- The postpones races of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen were rowed on the lake this morning, the start being made at 11 o'clock.

LONDON, July 29. -- The returns from the last of the constituencies, that of the Orkney and Shetland Islands, to elect a member to the new Parliament have been received. They show, as was expected, the election of the Liberal candidate, Mr. L. Lyell, who received 2,617 votes, against 1,614 cast for his Dissident Liberal opponent, Mr. W. Younger, thus Riving Mr. Lyell a majority of 1,003.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29. -- The Rev. Patrick Connolly, pastor of the Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary, Elizabeth, N.J., died suddenly tonight at the parsonage from heat prostration. Ho had been up the greater part of Thursday night attending to sick calls, and two hours before his death was called to attend a case at the Elizabeth Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29. -- Major Gen. George R. Snowden, and several members of his staff, returned from Homestead this morning. Gen. snowden had hardly reached headquarters before he was asked to talk.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 29. -- It appears that unless the Governor Interferes by pardon or commutation of sentence, Col. H. Clay King, the murderer of David H. Poston, has but thirteen and a half more days on earth. The decision of Jadge Jackson of the United States Circuit Court, sitting in chambers at Nashville yesterday, practically destroys all hope of even a temporary escape from the gallows through the interference of the Federal authority.

Chairman Harrity of the Democratic National Committee yesterday made public the names of members of the Executive end Campaign Committees. The formation of these committees is a matter to which he has assiduously devoted himself. He has endeavored to select those men whose service would best-advance the ends of the party.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 29. -- The significant events of the flay have been the holding of Berkman for trial in $14,000 bail and attacks on non-union workmen at Homestead and at Duqueane. These attacks are not important in themselves, but they indicated in a measure how the strikers regard the decrease in the numbers of troops on guard.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 29. -- Hiram Harris of Southampton, who has been confined in the Suffolk County Jail hare for several weeks awaiting the convening of the Grand Jury, for whose action he was hold on several charges of burglary, escaped yesterday.
The following amendment to Chapter 119, Laws of 1888, passed by the Legislature last Spring, was read at the meeting of the Police Board yesterday:
WHAT A GOOD REPUBLICAN DID RATHER THAN EAT IT. "What do you call this, Mary?" demanded the husband as the wife served him his dessert, something in a saucer that he was to eat with a spoon.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29. -- It was very warm at the tract to-day, and but for a southwest breeze it would have been uncomfortable work watching the races. There was a goon attendance. The results follow:
Congressman Joseph E. Washington of Tennessee was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29. -- Congressman Outhwaite of the Capitol district, whose opposition to the Congressional appropriation of $5,000,000 for the World's Fair won for him the designation of chief filibustor, has been the recipient of numerous telegrams of protest from the business community here and he will be compelled to do elaborate explaining when he reaches here to-morrow in response to a telegram to the effect that his wife is ill.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 29. -- Chairman Thomas H. Carter of the Republican National Committee and James S. Clarkaon, his predecessor, departed this evening for Old Point Comfort. A rumor had reached them that a delightful breeze prevailed there, and after broiling in Washington two days they were glad enough to board the Norfolk boat and start for the cooler clime.

There was little comfort in the fact, but yesterday was another record breaker in the way of heat, that is, for the given date, July 29. Not since the Weather Bureau has been keeping tabs on the thermometer has the mercury mounted so high on the last but two of July's calendar days. The official maximum degree reached was, according to Forecaster Bonn's instrument, 9512, and this was at 2 P.M.

CHICAGO, July 29. There was little doing in provisions, and an all-around decline was scored. Fluctuations were frequent within a narrow range, but the market was featureless. Receipts of product were moderate, with a fair demand. Scalpers were the best sellers, with the packing companies buying on the decline. Cash pork was quoted $12@$12.05; September pork opened at $12.20, sold to $12.07 1/2, and closed at $12.10.

RICHMOND, Va., July 29. -- The statement that the Republican National Committee Intends to make an earnest effort to break the solidity or the South and capture Virginia and some other States in this section is no surprise to Democratic politicians here. There are some reasons for believing that steps have already been taken to accomplish this object.

Morello had another narrow escape from defeat at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday afternoon, and Fitzpatriok had to ride him all out to beat Prince George by a nose in the three-quarter-mile dash for two-year-olds. Morello has not yet been beaten at the Beach, bat he has had three very narrow escapes from defeat, and in two of thorn only Fitzpatrick's skill prevented what seemed certain.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- There are a couple of very needful bills pending in the House providing for the construction of light-houses and two new cruising revenue cutters which officers of the Lighthouse Board and the Revenue Marine fear have little prospect of becoming laws at this session. The measures are in charge of the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce.

No class of people have been hoping more fervently for a cool spell than the trackmen and the superintendents of the surface car lines. They have been on pins and needles ever since the hot spell began, because the heat has been very hard on the horses, and there has not been a surface road which has not lost some of its stock.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Representatives Cummings (Dem., N.Y.,) and Bailey, (Dom., Texas,) perspiring at every pore and weary from perpetual fan pushing, held the Congress up by the tall to-day to keep it out of the way of the advocates of the appropriation for the Chicago Fair. Mr. Outhwaite (Dem., Ohio,) having gone home in consequence of illness in his family, the office of leader devolved upon Cummings.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- For several days the House has been obliged, owing to imperfections in the roles and the persistency of Messrs. Watson (F.A., Ga.,) and Wheeler (Dem., Ala.,) to bear the punishment of listening to a personal squabble between those two rather tiresome members. The Speaker has tried to stop the business, but both members are windy and both are hairaplitters.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Representative Hatch, (Dem., Mo.,) from the Committee on Agriculture, to-day submitted to the House a report prepared by the committee on too effect of the present tariff law upon agriculture, which will doubtless sound the keynote in the Democratic national campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Many persons around the Capitol who had rejoiced when the House passed the bill referring the claim of William McGarrahan to the Court of Private Land Claims were sympathizers to-day with McGarahan when the President sent to Congress a veto of the bill for the passage of which he had waited since 1868.

"I do not know that there have been any differences," said Mr. CLEVELAND at the Sagamore Club reception on the night following the grand notification meeting at the Madison Square Garden. Evidently the leading Democrats of the country are all forgetting that there have been any differences, and are uniting heartily for the work of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Hot weather and the tariff hare his it off together in the Senate end of the Capitol. Mr. Aldrich (Rep., R.I.) picked out the hottest day of the Boason to air the alleged benefits of protection in a speech which filled thirty pages of the Records.

With the Columbia, at last in the water, the next launch to be looked forward to in our navy appears to be that of the harbor-defense ram, which is not many weeks away. This craft, now under construction at the Bath Iron Works in Maine, is a novelty for the new fleet, and indeed a novelty anywhere.

Angling in the salt water has been good all the week. The hot weather especially has pleased the weakfish. It is impossible to have the weather overhead too clear and warm for them, though it is not probable that down in the sea that they are much affected by the conditions outside. It has been noticed, however, by experienced anglers that weakfish will not bite till after a spell of hot weather.

From the San Francisco Chronicle, July 22. "I am deeply interested in the extermination of rabbits in Australia and New-Zealand, and am on my way to those colonies to watch the passing of the new act in New South Wales," said Charles W. Kent of London last night.

BOSTON, July 30 -- The heat this week melted the pride clean out of Bostonians, who have been wont to boast the claims of the Hub to Summer comfort. This city has fared even worse than its near neighbors throughout the present month. From the 3d to the 24th no rain fell. Not since the time of the famous world's peace jubilee in 1872 has Boston endured such an infliction of torrid weather.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30 -- The first session of the Westbury Quarterly Meeting was held to-day at this place. A large number of Friends from New-York and Brooklyn came out this morning and were met at the station by carriages which conveyed them to the meeting house. Adjoining this is the old burying ground and about this the Friends strolled for an hour or more before the assembly.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 30. -- Gov. John P. Buchanan to-day issued an address to the Democracy of the State announcing his withdrawal as a candidate for ronomination by the convention which will meet here on Aug. 9.
Two generations ago few rich Americans followed the English custom of erecting solid, lasting manor houses to stand as family monuments and homes for their descendants.

LONDON, July 30 -- It seems after all that the Tories and Unionists really have been very found of Mr. Gladstone these past six years. One would hardly have thought it, so skillfully did they dissemble their love, but concealment is no longer possible. Nothing more touching has been seen for a long time than their present great solicitude for the health of this venerable distinguished citizen.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The death of Representative Craig (Dem., Pa.,) helped the filibusters to-day in their fight against the appropriation for the World's Fair, and, in spite of the appeal of Mr. Reed to the other side to waive custom and be content to respect the memory of their associate by passing a resolution of respect and regret and then to pass the Sundry Civil bill, the House adjourned.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 30 -- The Republican State Committee met here this week. Sixteen of the seventeen members were present. There were also a number of Republican leaders from different portions of the State on hand. The question before the committee was whether a convention to nominate a candidate for Governor and other State officers should be called.

BARON JOSEPH ALEXANDER HUBNER. Baron Joseph Alexander Hubner, the well-known Austrian diplomatist, is dead. Baron Hubner was born in 1811 in Vienna. After completing his studies there he traveled for some time in Italy, and on his return, in 1833, received from the late Prince Metternich a post in the State Chancellerie.

The interesting statement was recently made that a leading trunk line is about to connect Brooklyn with the rest of the world by a ferry, stopping at New-York en route, and making the metropolis a way station, as it were. The analogy to one of the most ambitious -- and, we may add, most improbable -- schemes of Manhattan rapid, transit is at once apparent.

Some of our contemporaries are very severe in their comments on the refusal of the Carnegie Company to submit their differences with their former Homestead employes to arbitration. THE TIMES can hardly be suspected of any prejudice in favor of the Carnegie Company or of its particularly offensive chief.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., July 30 -- The first armorplate test made on the proving grounds of the Bethlehem Iron Company took place to-day. The plate tested was a ten and a bull inch Harveyized nickel-steel plate, eight feet by six, and weighed 18,600 pounds. In tempering the plate it was treated with the ice-water process, which rendered its aurface exceedingly hard and brittle.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 30 -- There are five local branches of the Order of the Iron Hall in this city. Naturally the news by the Associated Press from Indianapolis last night that a receiver had been applied for to settle the business of the order created consternation among the members here. It is hinted that members here will stop paying monthly dues till the case is settled.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 30 -- There was just a chance this morning that the grand circuit meeting here would be declared off. Dark clouds overhung the city and rain fell at intervals, but toward noon the weather cleared and a brisk wind sprang up. The track at 1 o'clock was in a wonderfully good condition considering the drenching it had yesterday.

The Leader mentioned the circumstance a few weeks ago or a prominent Brunswick County Democrat writing Mr. Cleveland to the effect that North Carolinians were for him, and that the delegates did not express by their vote at Chicago the sentiments of the people. The following letter was received in reply. Mr. George H. Bellamy's Democracy is too well known in Brunswick County and North Carolina to need comment:

From the London Standard. Mr. Gladstone has been propping up home rule for Ireland by holding up Canada as an example of the working of the fad he has adopted. As an old Canadian, since 1844, I think that I know something of what home rule has done for Canada. In one word, it has made that country, from being very economical to live in, more expensive than any part of England.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 30 -- It is quite probable that John C. Bills of Davenport will be chosen to head, the Electoral ticket of Iowa at the Democratic State Convention to be held at Davenport on Aug. 18. There are special reasons why Mr. Bills would make a strong candidate just now -- probably the strongest that could be named.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, July 30 -- P.M. To-day's stock market was fairly active for a midsummer half holiday. Prices were somewhat lower, owing to the taking of profits. St. Paul was exceptionally strong, and the other Grangers scored fractional gains, but the general list was irregular. Sugar lost a point.

RICHMOND, Va., July 30. -- Gen. Mahone as a bearer of the olive branch is a brand-new wrinkle in Virginia Republican politics. Heretofore Mahone has been known only as a tenacious fighter and a leader who was always ready to permit his lieutenants to make concessions, but never did anything in that line himself.

Throughout the month the August sun hurries away toward the south and the days shorten, the lengthened nights admitting of satisfactory repose after the heat and humidity of the dog days. Rather more than nine degrees of declination mark the path of the sun between the first and the last days of the month, his speed, being half as much greater at the close than it is to-day.

"Hum!" exclaimed the Lieutenant, as he saw the hoarse and string of carriages come rattling off the bridge, " I must say that the modern funeral savors a good deal of the rattle his hones over the stones' sort of thing."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- Considerable prominence has been given here to the statement from Honolulu that the British cruiser Champion had left that port with the intention, it was understood, of annexing Johnston Island to the British possessions. The records at Washington show that the island is under the protection of the American flag, having been taken possession of in 1852 by Capt Parker of the brig Reindeer, who found there large guano deposits.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A friend of mine makes the argument that the reason of this continued hot spell is because the Mc-Kinley bill, by reason of putting a very high duty on foreign storms, has made their entry into this country prohibitive, and that, in consequence, many storms originating in Canada hare been stopped at the border and not allowed to enter this country.

In air laden with the perfume of wild flowers, with real boughs swaying and leaves breathing sweet music overhead, Rosalind and Orlando have told their tender story again in a scene of nature's setting. Arden's romance has been shifted to the hills of Pocantico, past which the Hudson sweeps, and testimony seed not be wanting that in that reposeful spot lovemaking is as easy, as pretty, and as natural as fancy may require.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., July 30 -- The trains traveling the steep grade from the Water Gap to Pocono have been frequently drawn by double engines of late. The beautiful Pocono country has never been more attractive, and people are trooping in daily. The arrivals of the last few days include the following:

From the London Globe. Some years ago I formed one of the crew of a ship called the Wooljammer, She was an iron clipper, owned by a well-known London firm. We were lying in Port Lyttelton, New-Zealand, alongside the breakwater, having just completed taking in a cargo of wool, and were going to sail on the following morning for home.

INDIANAPILIS, Ind., July 30 -- Shortly after noon to-day Albert R. Baker, Homer A. Sampsell, and Daniel W. Kneffler, through their attorneys. Winter Elam, filed a complaint against the supreme sitting of the Order of Iron Hall, wherein they asked for the appointment of a receiver. The complainants state that there are 1,200 local branches throughout the Union with a membership of 60,000.

The resort to the courts growing out of the refusal of Prof. George Chase, Dean of the New-York Law School, to countersign the diploma granted by the Board of Regents to Thomas C. O'Sullivan, besides being of interest from the questions of law involved in it, shows that the new law school came very near having an unpropitious first commoncement.
VICTORIA, B.C., July 30. -- The Canadian Pacific Company steamship Empress of India brings news of a serious insurrection in Fat-Shan, China, caused by the extortions of the Chinese customs officers.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 30 -- The point of interest shifts rapidly at Bar Harbor; last week reports of robberies filled the air; this week it is as if no robberies had happened and people existed only for social enjoyment.

ROUND LAKE, July 30 -- The Ministers' Institute, which has been in progress during the week, has proved unusually interesting. It opened, with a few instructive remarks on the necessity of a higher grade of scholarship in the pulplc, in which Bishop Newman, Dr. Josoph E. King, Prof. Van Benschoten, and others took part.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 30 -- The cricket match between the combined Halifax teams and the Germantown Cricket Club ended to-day in an easy defeat for the home players. The Germantowns yesterday made 207 in their first; the Halifax eleven followed and were all not out for 71. In their second inning to-day they made but 105 runs, victory thus going to the Americans by innings and 31 runs.

Importers and merchants in general who have dealings with the Custom House are dissatisfied with the administrative law, which was enacted with a view of expediting the settlement of disputed points respecting classifications. They say there is too much machinery in the law, and that the old system, where cases of appeal went direct to the Treasury Department, had much to commend it.

The sunlight streaming through the half-opened port cast a ruddier glow upon the bronzed visage of a commander of one of the big passenger steamships which ply between this and European ports. Seated opposite to him was an inquisitive young man, pencil and notebook in hand.

It is not so very long since the proposition to harness Niagara and make, the great waterfall do duty for manufacturing purposes, like any ordinary little cascade, was regarded as well high impossible. And yet that same thing is now an almost accomplished fact, Canals are dug, tunnels are bored, shafts sunk, and the whole work is so far advanced that this Fall will see the completion of it.

San Diego Letter to the Christian Union. Up in one of the river valleys not many miles distant there are many water blackbirds, which weave unique nests among the tules. A specimen of unusual design which I discovered not long since was bound about with meshes to the upright tule stems, laced over, under, in, and out, in the most intricate manner, until the little basket-shaped receptacle was of the desired size.

In the wild-beast house at Central Park certain pearl-gray cats in size half way between tiger and lynx may be observed for their small heads, slender build, and softfooted, slinking gait as they pace to and fro behind the bars.

From the Seattle (Washington) Telegraph. "It is no trick to catch them. They are pulled out with hook and line from the deep waters of the Sound just like fish, and are found on the rocky bottoms of the fishing banks," said a fisherman. "Look at this," continued he, raising the slimy mass of legs and pointing to a perfect counterpart of a parrot's black beak.

WILLSBOROUGH POINT, N.Y., July 30 -- The American Canoe Association will begin its annual meet here next Friday. The first convention of canoeists was at Crosby Side Park, Lake George, in 1880, and the American Canoe Association, the outcome of the convention, met also on Lake George in 1881, 1882, and 1888. To please the Canadians in the association the meet in 1883 was on Stony Lake, in the Province of Ontario.

From London field. It may seem somewhat paradoxical to talk of "dangerous tame animals," but this peculiar variety is distinctly recognized by this law, and it is only in the case of those tame or domosticated animals known to their owners or owners' servants to be of a ferocious or dangerous disposition that the law admits any liability for injuries arising from an exhibition of the peculiar characteristics of the variety.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 30 -- The Democratic and Republican leaders are making plans for the nomination of their favorite candidates for local offices. The Senatorial contest will be the most important. Heury S. Terhune, nephew of Henry Stafford Little of Matawan, will no doubt be the Democratic nominee for Senator, while present indications point to the nomination of ex-Mayor Wilbur A. Heisley of Long Branch by the Republicans.

DANVERS, Mass., July 30 -- Bisecting the Columbian era is that dark thread of history which marks the witch hunt of 1692. The bi-centennial celebrations of the direful events have been widely advertised in newspaper and periodical, though apart from historical integrity the silence of oblivion would better seem to befit such an anniversary.

If there is one thing that the fastidious and epicurean American host prides himself on more than another among his male friends it is the quality of his cigars, and yet there is probably none of his luxuries about the preparation of which he is in denser ignorance.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- A cable dispatch from London, declaring that the Government of Victoria, Australia, bad increased the import duty on Oregon pine $6.25 per 1,000, and the duty on canned fruit to 6 cents a pound, or about 15 cents per tin, caused much excitement here, as it is justly regarded as the first gun in the foreign fight against the McKinley bill that hurts tills station and coast.

Capt. Amos Chapman of Boston, but formerly of Provincetown, has arrived on the Cape, and is shipping a crew ol old experienced whalemen for a new and novel voyage -- to capture a live sperm whale, to be taken to the World's Fair at Chicago.

Copyrighted, 1892. by the N.Y. Associated, Press. BERLIN, July 30 -- The cholera has to-day made its appearance in two localities in Galicia and, worse still, nine cases of the disease are reported through Pressburg, Hungary, as having occurred at Dimazer Dabely, twenty-five miles from that populous centre. The outbreak in Austrian Galicia is meantime limited to the frontier villages of Molcszowa and Szcrakowa.

Bedlow's Island does not need to be located for the average New-Yorker. It is a conspicuous point in the harbor. Lying at the city's threshold, no one is likely to pass it by unnoticed. Even if the island, escapes, the Statue of Liberty will assert itself. It cannot be said that Bedlow'e is now a thing of beauty, yet it was once as fair a spot as could be found in the United States.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 30. -- Ex-President Adams or Cornell University has accepted the Presidency of the University of Wisconsin.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 30 -- The features at the races to-day were the American Hotel Stakes event and the Okolona Steeplechase. The weather was clear, and as showers last night had reduced the temperature so that it was enjoyable watching the running, there was a large attendance.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $163,463,050, as follows: Currency 6s, $11,611,000; 4 per cents. $129,864,200; 2 per cents. $21,987,850.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Most of the trade in provisions was in the way of changing over to the later deliveries. Receipts of hogs were moderate, with a steady market at the yards, and the packing companies were generally buyers of product. Scalpers were the sellers. September pork opened at $12.07 1/2, sold off to $12.02 1/2, gradually advanced to $12.17 1/2, and closed at $12.15, cash being $12.07 1/2 @ $12.10.

The well-to-do New-Yorkers who have been condoling with each other during the past week about the oppressiveness of the weather and exchanging accounts of their sufferings over cooling drinks have simply no conception of what the weather has meant to a very great majority of the inhabitants of this island.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 30 -- The hot weather has greatly increased travel to the Catskiils and it has been a very busy week for railroad employes.

WATCH HILL, July 30 -- The hottest weather known here in years has prevailed this week, and the thermometer has been up in the vicinity of 80, but only for a short time. The hotel men are happy, and if the season continues during August as it has been in July they say they will make some money this Summer.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 30 -- A cablegram was received here to-day announcing that the appeal of the Roman Catholics of Manitoba to the Privy Council of England to compel the Government of Manitoba to maintain their separate schools has been dismissed. This victory for the Government was entirely unexpected, inasmuch as the Supreme Court of Canada had unanimously rendered a decision in favor of the maintenance of Catholic schools.

From the New-Haven Register. That the old saying, "Faithful as a dog," is a slur on the cat kingdom is well proved by a little incident which Wallace B. Miller of 88 Lyon Street relates of a tiger cat. The tabbie In question was raised by Mr. Miller's family, and is about four years old. It has always been called Tessie, and is a great pet.

From "Properly: Its Origin and Development." Never among mankind can we find so absolute and complete an absorption of the individual by the social group as in the cities of ants and bees, where individual property has never, it seems, been imagined. In these republics what one citizeness has for herself belongs to the others.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 30 -- To-day has looked like an April moving day in Homestead. All the wagons which could be secured were in use transporting the household effects of about sixty families out of company houses. In front of each door all the moving vans were drawn up and carried away furniture which had not been moved for years, as the tenants were old employes of the company.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The names of the members of Congress whom Mr. Watson (Dem., Ga.,) had in mind when he wrote in his book about drunken Congressmen on the floor of the House did not come out this morning in the investigation of the special committee appointed yesterday to inquire into the charges made by Mr. Watson.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 30 -- Knold and Bauer, the Anarchists, had a hearing before Judge Gripp at the Central Police Station this afternoon and were held for court in $2,000 bail each on the charge of conspiracy. The men were unable to furnish ball and were committed to jail.

An important speech was delivered yesterday by M. Hauser, President of the Swiss Confederation, at an official banquet in connection with the triennial Federal shooting meeting which is being held at Glaris. In answer to recent articles in Italian journals and pamphlets he made the following declaration:
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Mrs. Ewing, wife of Dr. Ewing, United States Army, with her little daughter, is spending the Summer with Admiral Febiger at Easton, Md.

ALBANY, July 30 -- The names of the successful candidates for the free State scholarships at Cornell, one from each Assembly district, have been prepared by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction. Competitive examinations were held in every county on June 4, and where a sufficient number did not pass from any county the deficiency was made up from other counties which had excesses.

A week ago, in reply to a correspondent, we submitted some observations on the Sunday question, with special reference to the opening or closing of the World's Fair on the first day of the week. We are now asked by another correspondent to consider the probable state of things in Chicago on Sunday during the Fair, in case it should be closed, and in case it should be open.

LENOX, Mass., July 30 -- The mercury has climbed higher this week than in any week in July that has been known since Lenox became a Summer resort. While the thermometer has shown from 80 to 90 in the middle of the day for four days in succession, yet the nights have been cool, so that there has been no difficulty in getting a good night's sleep.

DENVER, Col., July 30 -- A short history of the life of Donna Maddixa, who is well known throughout the country as an actress, has been filed in the United States court in an answer by the heirs of William B. Daniels to her suit to have the divorce obtained from her set aside and to establish her claim to one-half of his estate.

Here in Michigan there is nut a single species of poisonous snake among the twenty-five or more kinds that I Know. The dangerous one is the common massasauga or prairie rattlesnake, (Caudisona tergomina.) Many times have I been called upon to decide on a specimen supposed to bo poisonous, but always have found that the so-called copperhead or moccasin resolved itself into an innocuous water snake or milk snake.

One of the famous legal complications which Boston has witnessed managed to involve in its intricacies quite a number of notable men. For many years one or the law offices in the old Joy Building was occupied by a veteran lawyer known as "Jerry" Brown. Quite Into in life this old gentleman was married to one of his clients, who not long after died.
The game at Englewood yesterday was played under protest, the home team claiming that Umpire Paasch rendered a wrong decision. Wild's home run won the name for the New-Jersey Athletic Club The score:

From the London Times. In April, last year, a committee was appointed by the Government of Bengal to consider the nature and extent of the poverty and destitution prevailing in Calcutta among Europeans and Eurasians. The report which has now been Issued is confined to the domiciled European community of Calcutta and to Euraslana of all degrees of mixed blood, the expression "Indo-European" being employed to include both these classes.

San Diego Letter to the Chirtstian Union. Some of my most intimate acquaintances have been the mocking birds in these California groves. It seems almost unnecessary to cage them, they are so happy among the ever-blooming trees; but cages happy in balconies, at doors and windows, all about the courts, and under the eaves; and passing down the streets one hears at all hours rushes of melody from the wonderful mimickers in their prisons.

ASBURY PARK, July 30 -- The social season at this resort was opened Friday evening, when the first german was danced at one of the hotels. Twenty couples participated. The german was led by Mr. J.H. Sheldon of New-York and Miss Nellie Horr of Philadelphia. Others who took part were:

From the London Daily Telegraph. Is there not an old English glee describing the fate of a "Franklyn's doggo "? The lives and adventures of many a sagacious creature on view in Islington Market may never be told in song or narrated in music.
