WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A question has been raised, under Article I., Section 6, of the Constitution of the United States, as to the lawfulness of the appointment by President Harrison of Senators Allison of Iowa and Jones of Nevada and Congressman McCreary of Kentucky as Commissioners to represent the United States in the proposed International Monetary Conference, which is to be held next October.

From the Portland (Me.) Press, Aug. 11. The announcement that W.R. Sheldon has been appointed receiver of the Fort Payne Coal and Iron Company marks a crisis in that memorable and gigantic financial enterprise.

AMENIA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Two bottles were mixed up in this town to-day with disastrous results to twenty-five or thirty members of the Presbyterian Church, for the mistake resulted in many of those who attended communion services at the church sipping the contents of a cap filled with a combination of powerful chemicals, instead of wine.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 14. -- Some of the mine managers of Colorado within a short time will be called upon by the English investors whose interests they are supposed to represent to give an accounting of their stewardship. The plain, unpolished fact of the matter is that an investigation into the affairs of the companies in which they have money invested is being pushed by a number of the large English companies operating in Colorado.

Our Washington dispatches yesterday morning reported that the intimates of the White House circle were considerably exercised as to what course Mr. HARRISON will take in his letter of acceptance upon the thorny question of a force bill, and they represented the President's own mind as in a state of some perplexity on that point.

For some time the newspapers of Philadelphia have said nothing in their editorial columns about the Anthracite Coal Trust except, as we have shown, in three or four brief paragraphs that gently reproved the combination for going a little too fast in the philanthropic work of developing "economies" of production by repeatedly increasing the price of coal to the consumer.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Discount was a shade firmer the past week, at 1 for three months and 1/2 for short. Autumnal bills are absorbing some money, and a stronger demand for gold for the Continent has also relieved the plethora. Still the demand from every source has been insufficient to do more than stiffen rates. The continuous tall in silver causes uneasiness in financial circles.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- There is no further disguising the fact that the strike of the Erie and Lehigh Valley switchmen is a serious matter. Riot and incendiarism mark its tidal wave.

Exactly a week ago yesterday, at 4:31 o'clock in tie afternoon, the Guion steamship Alaska, just out from Queenstown, passed Fastnet Point, bound westward to this port. Before she had brought the deep sea swell underfoot, the Cuparder Aurania had swung out from her anchorage in Queenstown, and with propeller churning the wayes into foam under her counter was following the track of her old antagonist.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 14. -- Unquestioned authority here confirms the truth of the statement that Harry Shirling of Harrison, Hiss.,' who was assassinated last Sunday at the house of Ben Duncan, in Marion County, was acting in the capacity of a detective of the Southern Express Company, under their Chief Detective Jackson of Aberdeen.

-- Mr. John Bigelow, one of the trustees of the Tilden estate, has written for the September number of Scribner an article with the title. "The Tilden Trust Library: What Shall it Be?" in which he discusses Mr. Tilden's intentions and makes a proposal in regard to the site for the building. Another article on Mr. Tilden has been written for the Atlantic by James C. Carter, the New-York lawyer.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Aug. 15 -- A.M. The stock market last week was somewhat irregular. The Government crop report was not quite so favorable as had been expected. The price of silver certificates fell to 82's, the lowest point they have ever touched and, the Street became somewhat alarmed over the situation.

From Blade and White. A little square-built stone house, almost hidden from the coach road by thick trees, and overlooking the beautiful Valley of Derwentwater and Baasenth waite, with the town of Keswick lying below -- such is Hawthorns, the homo among the English Lakes of the author of "The Scapegoat," "The Bondman," and "The Deemster."

To-day Mr. Gladstone will go to Osborne House to kiss the Queen's hand, by that ancient ceremony expressing his obedience to her command to form a new Ministry. In that Ministry Mr. Gladstone will at an age nearer eighty-three than it is eighty-two and for the fourth time in his life, be chief.

Pasqualina Marotti, a handsome Italian girl of eighteen years, had been missing from her home in a tenement house at Sixty-first Street and Fourteenth Avenue, Bath Beach Junction, since last Wednesday. As the young woman had no relatives in the house and rented her own room, nothing was thought of her disappearance and no questions were asked.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- Six thousand representatives from naval, military, civic, and patriotic organizations to-day joined in the funeral procession of Charles W. Riggin, boatswain's mate of the United States steamship Baltimore who was killed in the streets of Valparaiso by Chilean soldiers and at the command of a Chilean officer while wearing the blue of the American navy.

Two very small people were married yesterday afternoon with much ceremony and merry-making at Victoria Hall, Lexington Avenue, near Fifty-fourth Street. They were Leopold Kahn, better known, as Admiral Dot, and Lottie Naomi Swartwood, midgets so diminutive that in their wedding garments they looked more like pretty little children than like a man and woman about to embark on the uncertain sea of matrimony.

-- The Boston Journal notes regarding the annual report of the school at the Museum of Fine Arts just published that the total number of pupils of the last year was 202. A deficit in the school's treasury has been made up, and last year the reserve fund was increased from $1,500 to $4,000. This fund is now $7,500. This will enable the establishment of new lecture courses.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14. -- Important political work will be mapped out here to-morrow night and plans discussed which will have a vital heaving in determining which party will win Virginia's electoral vote this year. The Democratic State Central and Executive Committees and Mahone's Republican State Committee will meet here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Secretary of the Treasury will soon advertise for proposals for the construction of a new revenue cutter for service on the Baltimore station to replace the old Ewing. This is the first vessel designed for the cutter service since the superintendence of designing and constructing vessels was turned over to officers of that service, and great care has been taken with her.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- President M.E. Ingalls of the Big Four is evidently greatly concerned over the recent disclosures in connection with systematic stealings in the freight department of the road. He declines, without a knowledge at the inside facts, to express his belief in the reports. Treasurer Comstock is examining the accounts of the Columbus office.

"W.H.M." -- (1) What influences reduced President Lincoln's majority in 1864 in New-York State so far below his majority in 1860? (2) What influences elected Seymonr Governor in 1862? (3) What changed the Republican plurality to a minority in 1868?

SPRINGFIELD, Aug. 14. -- But for the coolheadedness of two men, the town of Hadley would have been the scene of a lynching yesterday, the cause being the attempt of a tramp to assault a young woman. A lynching in the state of Massaonusetts would have been an unprecedented occurrence.

WELLSBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The fun of the canoe meet begins to-morrow, the opening day of the races. That is, if the weather permits, but it must be said that the prospects are not very good, for this has been the wettest camp so far in the history of the association.
"Don't yawn like that again, Harry. In the first place, it's not polite to yawn in the presence of other persons, and in the next place. it's dangerous busines, this yawning."

TKENTON, Aug. 14. -- It is likely that at Its meeting on Tuesday next the Republican State Committee will fix the dote of the convention at which the Republican nominee for Governor is to be chosen. A few weeks ago the managers of the party were disposed to held back the convention till the Democrats had shown their hand.

From the London Daily Telegraph. In the old fort at Vincennes are quartered, with a battalion of rifles and other troops, a body of men who are employed as blacksmiths, carpenters, sawyers, locksmiths, bakers, and so on, the corps being known as the "Twenty-third Section of Workmen of the Administration," to give it its full title.

Persons having interests in Chile and Peru are beginning to speculate as to whether the Peruian Province of Moquegna, which the Chilean Government took possession of under the treaty of Oct. 20,1883, shall be reacquired by Peru or whether it shall remain as a part of Chile.

From the London Daily News. Why did Moses Cudworth, the weaver of Earby, kill his wife? The man has been found guilty at the Yorkshire Assizes and condemned to death, but the evidence throws little light on this question. The couple had been married nineteen years, and according to the evidence had "lived happily together."

The Roman Catholic educational institutions and colleges in this city and in this State propose to make a large and creditable showing in the Roman Catholic educational exhibit at he World's Fair. Pope Leo is much interested in this representation of an important branch of the work of the Church in America, and has recently written several leters to Bishop Spaulding of Peoria, Ill., who is superintending the affair, manifesting much concern in its success.

A saloon passenger of the Aurania was very much surprised yesterday morning when a gray-mustached person, who had boarded the vessel at Quarantine, tapped him on the shoulder and asked for a few minutes' private conversation with him. The stranger proved to be a rather inquisitive sort of porson, and the passenger showed signs of uneasiness when a certain jewelry establishment in London was mentioned in the inquiries.
BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- A special to the Herald from Quebec says:

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 14 -- The ring of Federal office holders who have been manipulating local politics here in the interest of Senator Higgins received a severe rebuke at the Republican primaries throughout New-Castle County yesterday. The urimaries were held for the purpose of nominating candidates for county offices, and, as usual, the ring had its candidates for all the positions to be filled.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Ang. 14. -- The trouble that the East Tennessee Coal and Iron Company, of which Thomas C. Platt is President, is baring at Tracy City is but a continuation of the trouble which began in the mines of the Cumberland Range a year or so ago on account of the opposition of the miners to the employment of convict labor.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 15 -- The political sensation of the day in Tennessee is the announcement made this evening by Gov. Buchanan of his independent candidacy for re-election.

ORILLIA, Ontario, Aug. 16. -- Gaudaur had practically a walk-over in the race to-day with Stephenson, the Australian. The race was three miles, with a turn, for $500 a side. Five thousand people witnessed the event. Betting was at even money.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- The polo tournament arranged for this week came near ending in a contretemps to-day in consequence of several teams in the schedule being short one man, and an effort was made to have the matches played with three men on a side. This, however, was overruled, with the result that the Newport team dropped out of the series, the tour members joining those short so as to make full complements.

Judge Dngro, in the Special Term of the Superior Court, yesterday board the continuation of the arguments on the application for a bill of particulars on the claim of Florice Von Ax that ahe is the widow, by a common-law marriage, of Jacob Halsted, the seventy-three-year-old millionaire, who died in June, 1891, a supposed widower.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The case of Lizzie Borden, charged with the murder of her father and stepmother, assumes no new features as the time for the preliminary hearing approaches. It has been noticeable here since yesterday forenoon that intelligent persons have censed giving positive opinions on the merits of the case.

If the prompt resort to violence and law-lessness on the part of the striking switchmen of the Erie and the Lehigh Valley Railroads at Buffalo is to be attributed to the lesson taught at Homestead, it argues a strange lack of intelligence and discretion among the workmen, for it was precisely that kind of conduct that ruined the cause of the Pennsylvania steel workers.

It is expected that the Iron steamboat Cepheus, which was beached last Friday night 100 feet off the shore at Norton's Point, Coney Island, will he raised early this morning, unless a storm or an accident of some kind intervenes. Eight pumps were placed on the deck of the vessel Sunday and yesterday a ninth pump was put in place.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Great excitement prevails at Waverly, N.Y., and Sayre, Penn., just over the State line, on account of the strike of the Lehigh Valley switchmen. Fifty-one Lehigh men are out. Only four of the Erie switchmen at Waverly are union men. Two Lehigh freight trains slipped out, the trainmen doing their own switching, but with these exceptions no trains have gone through Sayre since Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The little flatter occasioned by the suggested ineligibility of Senators Allison and Jones and Congressman McCreary as Monetary Commissioners has quieted down.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The switchmen's strike on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, while viewed with seriousness by the Reading management, occasions no apprehension as to the outcome. Men in numbers more than sufficient to fill the places of the strikers have been secured, it is said.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Federation of Trades began this morning in the Assembly Chamber of the State House. Sixteen local unions were represented from Paterson, Newark, Jeraey City, Camden, and Trenton.

-- An interesting feature of the Presidential situation is the fact that Mr. Cleveland can be elected this year without the six votes of West Virginia, provided he holds the other States he carried in 1884. That year he received 219 votes against 182 for Mr. Blaine, 204 being necessary for a choice. This year 223 votes will be required to elect.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The season touched high-water mark yesterday, with a perfect day and hotels crowded with Summer loiterers to enjoy it. Fully 2,500 persons reached the village by Saturday's train a The United States Hotel has nearly 900 guests beneath its roof, with more expected to-day, "and," said Mr. Tompkins yesterday, "we have just rented three cottages for September, which augurs a late season."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Van Fradenburgh yesterday celebrated her one hundred and fifth birthday. Her eyes are still bright, her hearing good, and she never wore spectacles or false hair. Although crippled by an accident to her hip several years ago, she still walks around unaided. Her father had a truck patch in New-York at the foot of Grand Street.

JOSEPHINE POLLARD. Miss Josephine Pollard, a well-known writer on religious topics and a favorite author with children, died at her home, 409 West Eighteenth Street, yesterday, after a long illness. Among the best-known of Miss Pollard's works are "Bible Stories for Children," "The Old Testament in Words of One Syllable," "The New Testament in Words of One Syllable," and "The Life of Christ for Young People."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Police Commissioners were busy to-day swearing in special policemen on account of the switchmen's strike. The Sheriff was also busy swearing in special deputies for duty in the yards at Cheektowaga, which is outside the city limits and beyond the jurisdiction of the city police. The Sheriff will not call upon the military, except as a last resort.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A story was published, in the Newark evening papers to-day to the effect that Henry W. Howes, a livery stable keeper, and Miss Lillian Brandies of Orange, a well-known and handsome young lady, a member of the First Presbyterian Church, had eloped. Howes has lived in Orange but a few months, He is a fine-looKing man, and made himself very popular.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- So many yachts being here, with tennis and polo attractions, caused the biggest crowd of the season at the Casino dance to-night, when many lovely costumes were worn for the first time. It was noticed that the exclusive set danced the square dances together. "Practicing for the Subscription ball," so said one of them.

There was a fairly good day's racing at Brighton Beach yesterday, though the number in attendance to enjoy the sport was smaller than usual on a Monday. Just why this was so was not very plain, as the card was fully up to the average. But the 5,000 people at the Track wore there for business, as was shown by the continued crush in the betting ring between the races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- As far as the Chilean end of the negotiations is concerned, the proposed Claims Commission to pass upon the Cochet and Landreau claims appears to be an accomplished fact. Minister Egan's dispatch announcing that the Chilean Congress has not only approved the Baltimore indemnity but has ratified the Claims Convention is again made the subject of self-congratulations by the State Department.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 -- For two innings to-day the Cincinnatis were the game. After that point the Beds failed to hit the delivery of Busle, and, as the New Yorks played good tall, they failed to score a solitary run, the New-Yorks winning with the greatest of ease. The visitors showed a marked improvement in their work, and gave every evidence of being out for championship honors in the second series.

Stray does, however innocent they may seem, to a cursory observer, are not likely to tin received in future with, much favor by those inhabitants of Avenue B who live near Sixth Street. These people are still agog about the adventure they had with a mad dog yesterday afternoon.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The New-Jersey Postal Telegraph Company's office in this city is in trouble. When the office was established two years ago difficulty was experienced in securing a franchise, and that was annulled some time ago because of the company's failure to fulfill its terms.

WILLSBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The series of storms has ended, and the canoe camp is now drying out. About 150 are now registered. Among the arrivals of Saturday and to-day were T.E.H. Barrington, W.P. Stevens. T.M. Shurtliff, and H.S. McKeag of New-York, and ex-Commodore R.J. Wilkin of Brooklyn. On Saturday evening the ladies at the hotel gave a dance to the canoeists.

Capt. Gallagher of the Eighteenth Precinct and Detective Reilly arraigned James Redmond of 343 East Twentieth Street, John O'Neil of 136 East Seventeenth Street, and George J. McWeeney of 346 East Fifteenth Street in the Yorkville Court yesterday on charges of impersonating an officer and getting money on false representations.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- John Farrell, a well-known baseball player, who was arrested for drunkenness last evening at the house of his wife, on Clifton Avenue, was fined by Police Justice Conlon to-day. Mrs. Farrell says that the ball player became her husband in Hoboken some years ago. His drunken habits made him obnoxious to her, and she secured a separation from him.

We recently published a letter written by Prof. HARRINGTON, chief of the Weather Bureau, and addressed to his superior officer, Secretary RUSK. In this letter, the subject of which was the proposed establishment of weather signal stations on two islands in Lake Huron, Prof. HARRINGTON told the Secretary that he had been compelled to double his original estimate of the cost of the telegraph cable required, because of a change in the tariff.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15. -- The switchmen employed by the various Big Four lines passing through this city today made a formal request for an increase in wages to those paid in Chicago, the highest in tho country. The request was taken under consideration by the road managers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- An interesting suit in which millions of dollars are involved, has just been begun at Lebanon, Penn., the defendants named being mostly Philadelphians or persons living in this vicinity.

More visitors were at the headquarters of the National Democratic Committee yesterday than on any previous day. Mr. Smalley of Vermont, member or the Campaign Committee, was present part of the day, until he left for Vermont to consult with his friends who have charge of the campaign there. Mr. Smalley is the Democratic candidate for Governor of his State.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 15. -- There are more Democratic and Republican leaders here tonight than have been gathered together in the city for some time. Their assembling is occasioned by the meeting of their respective State Committees, which are in session to-night, and are likely to sit until a very late hour.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Mr. Gladstone, accompanied by Sir Algernon Edward West, left Carlton Gardens at Boon to-day en route for Osberne House, Isle of Wight, to lay before her Majesty the names of those who will comprise his Cabinet and to carry oat the old custom of the statesman who is summoned to form a Government by kissing the hand of the sovereign.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 15 -- The Republican mind is secretly agitated by the action of Secretary of the Treasury Foster in calling Chairman Dick and Secretary Molloy of the Executive Committee into his presence at Middlebass. It is believed that Secretary Foster's visit to Ohio has to do with the recently-developed jealousy between the regular campaign organization and the league, and that he is bent upon relegating that auxiliary to the rear.

There is no denying that the chronic trouble which has just broken out anew between the miners and the employers of convict laborers in the coal mines of Tennessee is far more disgraceful to the people and the Government of the State than it is to the miners, even when their indignation and resentment drive the miners to become rioters.

Many troubles hang over the Republican camp, which has its headquarters tent pitched at 518 Fifth Avenue. Life has boon burdensome to the commltteemen who went there ever since President Harrison began his policy of dictating how business should be carried on, and yesterday affairs became so badly mixed that something had to be done.

The Hide and Leather Democratic Club opened the campaign in the "Swamp" yesterday with a banner raising and a noonday meeting that almost blocked Gold Street. In order that the workmen and clerks who attended the meeting in large numbers might not be kept away from their work beyond the noon hour, the speeches wore all short.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Force bill dilemma still awaits solution at Loon Lake and, according to private advices received here, is no nearer that much-desired end than it was ten days ago.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 16. -- The Democratic State Convention at Dover to-day was a somewhat perfunctory affair, as far as its proceedings were concerned. Its chief work was the selection of candidates for Presidential Electors and the unanimous renomination of Congressman John W. Causey for a second term in accordance with party usage.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 16. -- Concerning the news of Gov. Buchanan's announcement as an independent candidate for Governor of Tennessee at the coming election. Chairman W.H. Carroll of the State Democratic Committee said to an Associated Press reporter last night. "I was of the opinion, and it is confirmed, that the Democracy made no mistake when it refused to renominated Gov. Buchanan.

From the London Times. If Sir George Dibbs has not been able to accomplish all that he had hoped when he left Australia as Ambassador in General to the mother country, he must have quitted England at least satisfied with himself and having greatly modified the republican sentiments to which he gave so distinct utterance only a few months ago.

-- More than three centuries ago Sir Thomas Gresham of London vested the title of the Royal Exchange in a committee called the Gresham, after the donor; it is still that committee which lives on as owner of the great centre of the world's finance. This committee has been considering the question of decorating the interior of the Exchange.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The Duke of Devonshire to-day married Countess Louise, Dowager Duchess of Manchester. The ceremony took place at Christ Church, Down Street. It was the intention to keep the fact of the marriage an absolute secret, and only a few of the most intimate friends of the Duke and Duchess were present.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The new Government was officially announced this evening. It is as follows:

ST. Louis, Aug. 16. -- At no time were the Browns dangerous to-day. They failed to bat the delivery of young Stein, while the Brooklyns batted Hawke, Von der Ahe'a now phenomenon, out of the box. Breitonstein was substituted, and he fared bat little better.

Senator Redfield Proctor and M.S. Coburn, the member from Vermont of the Republican National Committee, had an extended conference yesterday with such members of the National Executive Committee as were in the city. They wanted the National Committee to send some campaign speakers to the Green Mountain State at once.

There threatened to be a general strike of all the nurses and employes at the S.R. Smith Infimary on Staten Island Monday night, in which case the thirty sick and injured patients would have been left to suffer.

From the Levant Herald. A sight as pretty as it was novel to Constantinople was witnessed on Saturday evening at Kalender, on the Upper Bosporus . Baroness Winspeare with her friends had organized the preliminaries of a battle of flowers, which was to be fought by land and sea.

The officials of various railroads Been yesterday expressed themselves as not at all apprehensive that the switchmen's strike in the Lehigh Valley and Erie yards at Buffalo would take a sympathetic turn and extend to this city. At the same time, however, many of them said that predicting the turn a labor strike would take when so bitterly waged as the one at Buffalo was not a safe thing to do.

DELMAR, Del., Aug. 16. -- Fully three-fourths of this village was flame-swept to-day, and tonight 300 people are homeless. One person was burned to death. The fire started in a little room back of the Post Office building, on Main Street, which runs north and south. A strong northeast wind fanned the flames, which spread rapidly southward and licked up about fifty dwellings and business houses.

BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- Four indictments were today reported against Asa P. Potter, Jonas P. French, and Thomas Dana, ex-officials of the Maverick National Bank, by the Grand Jury, before Justice Putnam, in the United States Circut Court. French was admitted to bail in $10,000, John Stetson going his surety. Dana has not yet been arrested.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A decision has been reached by the State Railroad Commission upon the complaint of the residents of Arverne, a settlement of about eighty cottages in Hempstead, on the line of the New-York and Rockaway Beach Railway, against the Long Island Railroad Company, which operates the trains under a traffic agreement.
Dr. J. Albert Kimball, a dentist widely known in this city, committed suicide at some early hour yesterday morning, cutting his throat with a razor at his residence, 23 West Twenty-sixth Street.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 16. -- The Democratic State Convention meets here to-morrow, and more than half of the delegates have already arrived. The one conspicuous feature is the open dislike of Gov. Winan entertained by the delegates from the city districts. In spite of Chief Justice Morse's recent letter of declination, in which he stated point blank that he would not accept the nomination if made, scores of delegates are wearing Morse badges.
The second trial of the ten-inch, pneumatic gun carriage took place yesterday afternoon at the Government Ordnance Grounds at Sandy Hook.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 16. -- Judge Bond, sitting in the United States Circuit Court here to-day, heard argument on the question of making the receivership of the Richmond and Danville Railroad permanent. Receivers Huidekoper and Foster were present, as wore several officers of the company and some twenty or more prominent lawyers representing various interests.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Gov. Flower and party visited the St. Lawrence Hospital for the Insane, at Ogdensburg, yesterday and today. The citizens tendered a reception to him at the Opera House there this afternoon, and the local company of militia acted as his escort to the station when he left.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- On the Toledo, Walhonding Valley and Ohio Railway, a branch of the Pennsylvania system now in course of construction, six miles north of here, at a point known as Richeson's gravel pit, six men were crushed to death last night and fifteen others terribly injured.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The Chronicle thinks that Mr. Gladstone selected the members of his Cabinet rather on the theatrical star company system. It says:

The Standard Theatre was full of reminiscences or the days at fine old Bowery melodrama last night. "Clambering" came out as "ca-lamb-er-ing," and there were enough "rs" in "revenge" to stock a spelling book. There is a great deal of revenge in "Lady Lil," which Mr. Lawrence Marston has written and Miss Lillian Lewis, Guatavus Levick, several Other persons, a nice old olrous horse, and a stuffed tiger presented last night.

Exactly what was to be expected has happened in Tennessee. The free laborers who hive been discharged from the employ of T.C. PLATT'S company, while the convict laborers were retained, have marked their sense of the nature of the transaction by throats to pull down the stockade that inclosed the convicts.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 16. -- At an early hour this morning a mob composed of from 150 to 250 miners attacked the stockade at Oliver Springs, situated six or seven miles from Coal Creek, and were driven back by the small force of guards.

London Standard from Nord Deutsche Zettung. Half an hour before noon on the 15th inst. the Emperor and five gentlemen of his suite went on board the whaling steamer Duncan Grey, while the other gentlemen embarked on board a companion vessel, the Nancy Grey. Both vessels belong to the wealthy whale fisher. Herr Johannes Gjaver, who was on board the former, and whose son was on board the other.

-- Mississippi has a constitutional prevision which rigorously excludes persons who cannot read, white and black, from the ballot box. People who will not learn to read simply disfranchise themselves. It is in their own power to remove the disqualification. Such a provision as that of Mississippi would have a wholesome effect in Pennsylvania.

Some of our Republican contemporaries are still talking about tin dinner pails and milk pans. We sometimes see in their editorial columns the assertion that the price of these useful articles has fallen about 25 per cent. under the benign influence of the McKinley tariff's increased duty on the raw material out of which they are made.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The Board of Trade hold a special meeting last night it the City Hall for the purpose of bearing representatives of the Philadelphia and New -England Railroad Company, which contemplates extending its line to this city through the Shawangunk Valley, providing the residents of Kingston will raise a fund of $50,000 toward its construction.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 16. -- The Picayune's Houston (Texas) special says: As previously outlined in these dispatches, the Democracy is rent in twain and a double-barreled convention is the result. The same scenes which were enacted in this city four years ago during the Stewart-Hutchinson campaign occurred to-day.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The investigation by the Law Committee of the City Council into the Veteran Zouaves and the use the latter put their armory to lasted until 11 o'clock last night.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16. -- In the opening inning the New-Yorks won to-day's game. Chamberlain was wild and the visitors took advantage of his erratic delivery. The men who did not get their base on balls hit hard, and before the third man had been retired half a dozen men had crossed the plate. The Giants had a winning lead, and they simply toyed with their opponents throght the remainder of the contest.

Representatives of many Democratic organizations met at the Hoffman House last night and made preliminary arrangements for entertaining the delegates to the monster convention which will be held in this city on Oct. 4 under the management of the National Democratic Association of Clubs. The meeting was called by the Young Men's Democratic Club of the Empire State.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 16. -- The People's Party State Convention met in this city to-day. Marion Butler, President of the State Alliance, was made temporary Chairman, and was afterward made permanent Chairman. Seventy-two counties were represented by 580 delegates.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The military have stood guard since 3 o'clock this morning over the scene of dispute at the William Street yards, and under the protection thus afforded the Erie and Lehigh Valley have been enabled to move their freight trains to-day for the first time since the blockade of Sunday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- The Mutual Banking Surety Trust and Safe Deposit Company, in which a large amount of funds belonging to the Order of the Iron Hall is deposited, failed to open its doors this morning. Inquiry developed the fact that the Directors of the bank had made an assignment for the benefit of the stockholders and depositors to A.E. Stookwell of this city, attorney for the bank.

MAPLEWOOD HOTEL, New-Hampahire, Aug. 16. -- The first annual tennis tournament of the inter-White Mountain hotels opened on the Maplewood tennis courts at 10:30 this morning. The courts were in an excellent condition and were surrounded by a crowd of brilliantly dressed women.

Nearly every member of the National Democratic Campaign Committee was in this city last night preparatory to a meeting which will be held at headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, to-day. Senators Gorman and Brice arrived early in the evening. Chairman Dickinson came at about the same time, and in the course of the evening E.C. Wall of Wisconsin, who had not been expected, put in an appearance.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- There was a good, deal of speculative activity in the provision pit at the opening, which lasted for about an hour. Prices started higher by 60 in pork and ribs and 7 1/2c in lard than those articles closed at on the previous afternoon. The state of affairs at the stock yards was sufficient to infuse courage in the holders and to create alarm among the shorts.

WILLSBOROGH, N.Y., Ang. 16. -- A number of outsiders having applied to enter the canoe races, it has been announced that none but members of the Amercan Canoe Association, unless upon the invitation of the Regatta Committee, shall be permitted to enter its races, and no canoe shall enter that is not enrolled on the Secretary's books.

Mr. CLARKSON, the President of the League of Republican Clubs, has made up his mind to postpone the grand national meeting of those organizations, which he had called for Sept 1, until Sept. 15. His explanation of this action is that the farmers will not be ready to take part in the movement at the earlier date, being occupied with the more profitable and possibly more agreeable business of gathering their early Fall crops.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Clear weather and a fair card attracted a large crowd to the races to-day. The track was in excellent condition and fast. There were no special features and no stake events.

MONTREAL, Aug. 17. -- Edmund D. Lyons, the male star of the New-York Comedy Company, sleeps to night in the Montreal Jail, and all on account of a bill for $377.31 which he and a boy ran up in St. Lawrence Hall in a little over two months.
Mr. Patrick Calhoun, a Director of the Richmond and Danville Company, sent a letter to President W. G. Oakman of the Richmond Terminal Company yesterday, in which he said:

A good many people lost sight of Mr. Talmage after his sensational trip through Palestine and were beginning to wonder what had become of him. Now he rises serenely into view ("bobs up" is the colloquial expression) at St. Petersburg, where he has been hobnobbing with the Emperor and trying to represent the United States.

The time for filing briefs in the matter of the application of the Fiftieth Street. Astoria Ferry and Central Park Railroad Company for a franchise which will enable it to hold many of the cross-town streets up town either for speculative purposes in the matter of railroads or to gridiron that portion of the city with tracks and to secure an entering wedge for a railroad on Fifth Avenue, expired yesterday.
Mme. severine of the Figure has interviewed the Pope on Anti-Semitism, and her long report is accepted by the Catholic papers as at least founded on fact.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 17. -- While the indorsement of Jerry Simpson as a candidate for Congress was certain to be the result of the Democratic Convention at Dodge City, that indorsement was made the stronger by the withdrawal of King in the Second District. The Populist Committee met, withdrew the name of King, and placed on their ticket that of Moore, the Democratic nominee.

NAGASAKI, Japan, July 25. -- The court-martial ordered for the trial of Commander Felix McOurley for the grounding of the United States steamer Alliance upon the breakwater of Yokohama on Feb. 26 last met on board the Alliance on the 11th and adjourned on the 20th. The court was composed of Capt. A.H. McCormick as President, Commanders Bartlett, Gridley, and Dickens.

Cotton is essentially a sun plant. After sunset, before the shades of night have fallen, the leaves of the cotton plants turn down and droop toward the stalk, as if depressed at the withdrawal of their beloved King. With the earliest beams of the next day's sun they straighten out and resume their daily dask of growing and maturing their wonderful product.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The most interesting feature of the new Cabinet is the fact that Labouchere is not in it. This, moreover, is a fact which will be remembered when every other detail of its composition has been forgotten.

Jabez A. Bostwiek, the Standard Oil millionaire and railroad capitalist, came to his death shortly before midnight on Tuesday in a most tragic manner. Two other men, Thomas and Henry Atkinson, stable hands, lost their lives at the same time, being burned to death.

Late Tuesday evening a railroad tie was found on the tracts of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad at One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street and it was at first thought it had been placed there by some one who had a grievance against the road, and who did it to show sympathy for the switchmen who are out.

One of the most astonishing of the many curious sights to be witnessed in the streets of Paris is -- to an English visitor -- the complete indifference of the drivers and conductors of omnibuses to frantic appeals of would-be passengers who rarely succeed in "catching the eye" of one of these officials, much less in causing the ponderous vehicle to come to a stop.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 17. -- The situation in the mining regions of East Tennessee is more grave to-night than at any time since the beginning of the reign of lawlessness five days ago. Eight hundred miners assembled at Oliver Springs last night, compelled the soldiers and guards at the prison stockade to surrender, captured the stockade, burned it, and forced the troops to conduct the convicts to Clinton for transportation to Nashville, via Knoxville.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17. -- From the present outlook the New-Yorks are out for the championship. They left here for Cleveland to-night after administering three successive defeats to the local club, and, if they put up the same ball in Cleveland as they did here, Capt. Tebeau will be lucky if he gets one of the three games to be played.

The Campaign Committee of the National Democratic Committee was in session at headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, yesterday for about five hours. Important matters were under consideration, on which, however, no final action was reached, and adjournment was taken until 11 o'clock this morning.

The third day's trial of the pneumatic disappearing gun carriage was held at the Sandy Hook proving ground yesterday. The test was mainly to determine the strength of the carriage and its appliances, and for this purpose three full-service charges were tired from the gun.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 17. -- Marshal Hilliard, Medical Examiner Nolan, and other officials connected with the Borden murder case were formally summoned this afternoon to appear in the District Court on Monday and bring with them every article taken by them from the Borden household after the murders were discovered.

The Democratic Party in the East is undisturbed by third party movements and united in support of its declared principles. In the West it seems to be steadily gaining strength, and the People's Party is likely to draw less from its ranks than from those of its opponents. The silver infection appears to have subsided and will have little effect in the national canvass.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Now that Europe is experiencing the horrors of a cholera epidemic and the authorities of the different cities are giving their attention to the subject of quarantine and other restrictions, let us see what we are doing. Some people say the Americans are an intelligent people. The Health Department of the city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17. -- The Republicans are much disturbed to-night over the discovery that a determined effort is on foot to capture the colored vote of Ohio lor Cleveland. It has just leaked out that about thirty prominent colored men held a conference in Akron last Sunday, and decided to issue a call for a convention to be held in Akron Sept. 15 and 16, when their demands and position would be definitely formulated.

The striking switchmen at Buffalo have certain perfectly definite and well-established rights, which cannot be denied to them, and which will, unless we are very much mistaken, be cordially recognized by the public. The chief of these and the one most important to the strikers themselves is the right to firm, effective, and equal enforcement of the law which protects the personal liberty and the property of all citizens and the property of all corporations.

The players in the Central Park invitation tennis tournament took advantage of the bright weather yesterday afternoon to continue the matches in that event. Two contests took place, and in both the play was very interesting. The feature of the day, however, was the marked improvement in Towns- end's play, in his match against Thurber he came to the net frequently and volleyed across court with wonderful accuracy.

CHATHAM, N.B., Aug. 17. -- A storm that began last Wednesday night and ended to-day was in its effects the most disastrous felt at Chatham for years. Four ships stranded in Miramichi Bay and one schooner wrecked off the bar so far have been reported.

The Park Board recently invited William Van Valkenburgh, who has been for years property clerk in Central Park, to resign on Aug. 15. The Commissioners of Accounts in their recent investigation into the affairs of the Park scored Van Valkenburgh for his methods and management and recommended his dismissal. The Part Board, however, thought it would be pleasanter to let him resign.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Still the crowds come and faster and faster turns the whirligig of pleasure here at the American spa. Three perfect days, with cloudless skies and tempered heat, have permitted uninterrupted enjoyment.
LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The first meeting of the new Cabinet was held to-day. Mr. Gladstone presided. The session lasted two hours.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The third city in this great State finds itself to-day in a remarka- ble position. Its traffic is threatened with paralysis, its provisions are threatened to be out off, and all because an irresponsible dema- gogue, named Sweeney, the Grand Master o the Switchmen's Union, has come to Buffalo and ordered all the switchmen on the great railroads that run into Buffalo to shut off work.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 17. -- Harmony, with a very large-sized "H," was the rule to- day in the largest Democratic Convention which Michigan ever saw. The withdrawal of Gev. Edwin B. Winans left smooth sailing in respect to Gubernatorial honors, and there was searcely enough rivalry in regard to the minor places on the ticket to make the proceedings interesting.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 17. -- The nomination of ex-Senator John C. Spooner by the Republican State Convention to-day was made necessary by the candidacy of Major Upham, a large mill owner. Many delegates had been instructed for Upham, and it was feared by the party managers that the charges that he had paid his workingmen in scrip on his store, and had made himself unpopular with workingmen generally, would hurt the Republicans in the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Gen. Grant, who is acting as Secretary of War, said this afternoon that the War Department had no information whatever regarding the labor troubles in New-York and Tennessee beyond what is furnished by the press dispatches, and that he had no rea- son to apprehend a call for Federal interference in either case.

Superintendent Byrnes has solved the mystery of the great tobacco theft, in which twenty-five bales of fine Sumatra tobacco, valued at $12,000, and belonging to A. Cohen Co. of 142 Water Street, were stolen under the very noses of the customs officers from the pier of the Netherlands American Line at Hoboken.

There is a new sensation at Cumberland, and this time it is the long-talked-of tarpon. One of the charming lady visitors at Cumberland sends the Telegraph an account of a tarpon catch made by Capt. Butts of Macon.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- The following was given out for publication this afternoon:

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 17. -- A daring attempt was made at 11:45 o'clock last night to rob the Denver Pacific train from Denver to Cheyenne. At La Salle station, sixty miles south of this place, three masked men entered the passenger coach with drawn revolvers and demanded that the passengers give up their valuables.

BEVERLY, Mass., Aug. 17. -- At 5:40 this afternoon Passenger Train No. 112, Rookport to Boston, met an extra freight at Paradise Crossing, on the Boston and Maine, Railroad at Beverly and a collision ensued. The passenger train was going thirty miles an hour and the freight twelve miles. Both engines were totally demolished, and with their coal and water tanks were piled in one heap.

ALBANY, Aug. 17.-" Every man of the 13,000 National Guardsmen is at the service of the civil authorities of Erie and other counties if needed." said Gov. Flower this evening, "but we cannot order the militia out at the request of any corporation."

WILLSBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- For years Paul Butler has been trying hard to win the trophy sailing race at the annual canoe camp. Last Summer he broke his boat just before the race was called. To-day he gained the prize, winning the race in fine style. The canoes that competed and their time are as follows:

Railroad Jack, the great dog traveler, ar- rived, at Jacksonville Tuesday night at 8:30 from New-Orleans, He has traveled more miles by railroad than any other of the canine family ever did or perhaps ever will. Jack belongs to the Wells-Fargo Express Company, and left Albany, N.Y., on July 5 for a trip around the United States.

Chairman Harrity was yesterday waited upon at Democratic headquarters by the committee of the Democratic Clubs of the City of New-York appointed by the meeting at the Hoffman House on Tuesday evening to inform the National Committee of the plan of campaign. The committee consisted of MacGrane Coxe, P.T. Wall, and A.A. Ailing.

Gen. James W. Husted, who is dangerously sick at his home in Peekskill, Westchester County, did not pass such a comfortable day yesterday as he did Tuesday. At 6:30 o'clock last evening there was another consultation, Dr. Seal going from this city to Peekskill. Dr. S.N. Tilden and Dr. Perley H. Mason of Peekskill were present.

We are not aware whether our esteemed contemporary the Tribune has as yet published in pamphlet form the remarkable supplements which purported to give a complete and classified list of the millionaires of the country, setting forth whether their fortunes had been amassed by honest labor or by protected industry at the expense of their fellow-citizens.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Aug. 17. -- The State Convention of the People's Party met here this morning with about 250 delegates present, rep- resenting but 39 of the 88 counties. H.F. Barnes of Tiffin was elected permanent Chair- man and Hugh Cavanaugh of Cincinnati permanent Secretary. The ticket nominated is as follows:

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The second day's session of the State Firemen's Association opened this morning. Coney Island and Oswego asked for the convention in 1893. On ballot the vote was -- Coney Island, 228; Oswego, 146. George Anderson of Schenectady nominated Orange B. Ingram of Troy for President. He was declared the unanimous choice of the convention.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 17. -- The Republicans of Western Maine opened the Fall campaign tonight with a meeting at the City Hall. Charles F. Libby presided and made the opening address, outlining the issues of the coming campaign. Thomas B. Reed was then introduced. In substance he said:

The new "adulteration law," approved by the Governor on May 16, will go into effect on Sept. 1. A New-York newspaper which printed the bill in full yesterday accompanied it with the statement that the wholesale grocers of this city were opposed to its provisions. This statement was found to be inaccurate by a TIMES reporter who investigated the matter yesterday.

A striking illustration of the power of the democracy, even under a despotic Government, is now being given in the neighboring town of Fat-Shan. It was there where, six months ago, the Mandarins, in defiance of the Tien-Tain treaty, confiscated the warehouse and goods of a British subject and imprisoned his servants for no other crime than that of being his servants for an indefinite term.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Supervising Architect Edbrooke says that the new eight-hour law will cost the Government $3,000,000 more a year on its building contracts alone.

When the historian of social manners in the latter half the nineteenth century arrives at the consideration of the table customs of this epoch, one of the most interesting chapters with which he will delight and instruct his readers will un- doubtedly be that treating of the degradation and abolition of the spoon, for the spoon is ap- parently doomed to extinction as an instrument of gastronomic comfort.

CATSKILL, Aug. 17. -- The warm weather of late has tended to crowd the many hotels and boarding houses in this region. As a native of the mountains expresses it, they are "chockfull." The event of the season thus far was the fancy dress hop at the Prospect Park Hotel last Saturday night. The parlors were crowded with guests, and many rich and fancy dress costumes were displayed.

That ardent advocate of McKinleyism, the Utica Herald, will doubtless be shocked by the discovery that on the 13th inst. it was guilty of publishing in its editorial columns a "miserable libel on the men who control and conduct the great business enterprises of the country." We quote the assertion to which we refer:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Kindly attow a word regarding the evidently wellintentioned notice in to-day's issue of St. David's Church, Brooklyn, with its special mission to deatmatea. While intended as a blessing to the several hundred of our people there, the weekly attendance though fair has not yet reached the number mentioned.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 17. -- The auditorium at the Conneaut Lake Exposition ground was well filled this afternoon when Congressional Nominee Sibley was announced as Chairman of the day. He then introduced United States Senator Peffer as an " illustrious child of Pennsylvania and citizen of Kansas."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- A midnight confer- ence between Brig. Gen. Doyle, Mayor Bishop, Sheriff Beck, Superintendent of Police Morgen- stern, H. Walter Webb. Daniel H. McMillan, W. S. Bissell, and E.C. Sprague on behalf of the railroads and several citizens resulted in agreeing to send the following telegram to the Governor:

CHILLICOTHE, Mo., Aug. 18. -- Delegates and visitors to the Missouri State Road Improvement Convention were formally received by the Mayor, F. H. Hoppe, at the Opera House last night and given the freedom of the city.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- On April 29, 1886, the State Railroad Commission made a report on the complaint that the Third Avenue Bailroad Company, in New-York City, had failed to fully operate Ha road for some days after April 16 of that year. The majority report, written by John D. Kernan, and signed by him and William E. Rogers, contained this suggestion, which Me teen totally disregarded by the persons whom it would benefit:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 18. -- There is a possibility that, unless the Governor reconvenes the Legislature and the election law is re-enacted, Kentucky's vote may not be counted for President. The Sims election law was passed by the Legislature in precisely the same manner as the Corporation bill, and the same objections to its unconstitutionally existed.

Senator FRYE has become one of those Republican conspirators who are trying to discredit that "Report on Price," which was brought out for campaign use by his Republican associates, Senators ALDRICH, ALLISON, and HISCOCK. In a speech delivered at Portland, Me., on the 10th inst., Mr. FRYE said:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The streets of this city bore a warlike appearance this morning, as the Fifteenth and Nineteenth Separate Companies filed out of the new armory at noon and marched to the Hudson River Railroad station, where they boarded a special train for Buffalo. The companies are in command of Major Haubennestel, one of the most efficient officers in the State.
From the Ludgats Weekly. Young woman, beware of the man who seeks to bind you to a long engagement. No matter what this pretext may be, his motive is almost always a selfish one.

The story published in a morning paper to the effect that the safe in Sheriff Courtney's office, in the Court House, Brooklyn, had been broken open on Sunday and $2,000 extracted was positively denied yesterday by Under Sheriff McLaughlin and all his assistants. Any one who called was shown the safe, apparently intact.

From the Albany Argus, Aug. 15. At 12 o'clock last night the deer hunting season opened. The time has been looked forward to by sportsmen in Albany and vicinity this year more than usual, because of the encouraging reports that the fleet-footed animal is unusually plentiful. In fact, Adirondack guides say that they are more plentiful this season than they have been before in twenty years.
Major John Byrne, who returned from Europe Wednesday on the Majestic after a few weeks' absence from this country, said yesterday:

The Government tests of the ten-inch pneumatic gun carriage, the invention of Henry A. Spiller, the Superintendent of the South Boston Iron Works, were practically concluded yesterday at the Sandy Hook proving grounds. The terms of the contract with the Government for the testing of the carriage stipulated that thirty shots shall be fired to demonstrate its practicability.

What a difference between organized labor's rich candidate for Vice President of the United States and the struggling college boy. Flitting about the country in a luxurious palace car which cost in the neighborhood of $16,000, Mr. Reid will have no use for crocks of home-made butter or buttermilk cakes. A gentle pressure of the electric button at his elbow will bring to him dainty dishes in great variety.

People who came back from the races yesterday on the steamer Monmouth of the Sandy Hook route had a narrow escape from what might have been a very serious accident or series of accidents. Just as the steamer was making for her dock at the foot of Rector Street the big excursion steamer Grand Republic came down the Hudson River, making for her landing place at Castle Garden.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The thermometer registered 87 to-day, but the air was so dry that there was little discomfort. The arrivals are heavier than usual, and the Summer gayety is at its height. The event of to-day was the concert in the Grand Union Hotel ballroom this evening by Miss Kittie Burger, the zither player.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18. -- R.D. Wrenn of Harvard and S.T. Chase of Chicago, the Western experts, will to-morrow meet in the final round of the Mossley Hall open singles, the winner meeting E.L. Hall for the championship and the trophy. The former is playing good tennis, while Chase played this morning as well as he ever has in his life.

-- Mrs. Virginia Montgomery, who died on Wednesday at the family homestead at High Bridge, was the widow of R.W. Montgomery, a merchant of this city. She was the daughter of Solomon High of New-Orleans, and the granddaughter of Peter Gasquet of Norfolk, Va. For a number of years Mrs. Montgomery had lived at her beautiful country place near High Bridge, adjoining the homes of Mrs. William Ogden, Fordham Morris, Mrs. Leas, and Edward Camp.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18. -- The excitement which has existed here over since the beginning of the mining troubles in East Tennessee has increased since the reception of the news of the movement on Coal Creck to proportions unprecedented since the war. The spirit of Indifference which was at first exhibited has entirely disappeared, and the situation is discussed only in great earnestness.

PHILADELPHIA, Aup. 18, -- The first serious effects of the railroad strikes at Buffalo were felt in this city to-day among the big receivers of Chicago dressed beef. As a direct consequence, the wholesale price jumped 2 cents per pound, with a very scanty supply at that.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 18. -- There has been work done in the Seventh District during the past few days that demonstrates that fusion does not fuse' and that Jerry Simpson will have more trouble this Fall than he ever had before.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 18. -- The Iowa Democrats, in their large and enthusiastic convention held here to-day, nominated a complete Electoral and State ticket, which is in many respects the strongest which has been submitted to the people of Iowa for their ratification by either party in many years.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 18. -- The great croquet tournament is more than half over, and the results in the third and fourth divisions are plainly apparent. Another day will in all probability enable the prize winners to be confidently selected. Many of the citizens of Norwich were in attendance to-day, while a fringe of gaily-colored dresses showed a strong feminine interest.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Rumors were floatin about to-day that the Nickel Plate switchmen would be the next to strike, but nothing definite was known until late this afternoon. Efforts had been made since the beginning of the strike to have the Nickel Plate handle some of the Lehigh's freight, and the men had steadily refused to move a car of it.

Treasurer Bliss of the National Republican Committee entertained a distinguished coterle of Republicans, all possessed of standing in the party and considerable wealth, at the Union League Club house last night. It was an invitation "affair," which, was kept as secret as possible. "The Campaign, and How to Carry It On" was the subject of the discussion, which was said to have been very informal.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18. -- The Republican campaign in this State opened to-day with the calling to order at noon of the convention of the State League of Republican Clubs. The principal number on the programme of the convention was the speech of Whitelaw Reid. Mr. Reid and his party arrived from Chicago a little late, having been delayed by a freight wreck.

The Republican National Committee is centreing its attentions just now on Pennsylvania in an effort to bring all factions of that State into a frame of mind to contribute to Mr. Harrison's campaign fund. The Federal officeholders, the manufacturers, and the professional politicians who have wealth, are being approached, it is said, in the most diplomatic manner possible in the interests of this fund.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 18. -- To-day's meeting of the Typothetae Association was the most important of the convention. The morning session was taken up with a discussion of the nine-hour question. The committee was composed of J.J. Little, New-York; Richard Evans, St. Louis, and J. Stearns Cushing, Boston, Mass.

The announcement that Thomas C. Platt had climbed over the tailboard of Mr. Harrison's icewagon and insisted on having a ride in that vehicle did not awaken the enthusiasm in the breasts of Republicans which some had predicted yesterday. That he wonld climb aboard eventually was said to be a matter of course, and if he wanted to make public the fact few had any objections.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18. -- The State Convention of the People's Party met here to-day, in adjourned session from June 28. Col. H.E. Garrett of Smith County presided.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- A severe shook of earthquake was felt at 12:25 o'clock this morning at Milford Haven, Wales. The movement lasted for twelve seconds. At 1:40 A.M. another shock was felt, which lasted five seconds. The last shock resembled an explosion.

A fairly good crowd was at the Monmouth Park track yesterday to see the six races that were on the card decided. There was some good sport, and the judges managed to get through the day with only one mistake in the placing of the horses, though singularly enough the sufferer by the misplacing was the same horse, Hazelhurst, that was misplaced in her race on Saturday last.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The following letter was sent to the State Arbitration Board by Third Vice President Webb of the Central, in answer to the board's letter asking if the Central would submit to arbitration:

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 18. -- Henry Carnegueay, the Belt-confessed, accomplice of the famous Bunch in the train robbery at Newson's brick yard on the Illinois Central Railroad last April, reached the city late this evening in the custody of the officers who will see him safely landed in the Louisiana penitentiary.

Branch headquarters of the Democratic National Committee's Campaign Committee are to be established at once in Chicago. This is an innovation in Democratic national politics. It indicates that the effort to gain Electoral votes in the West this year is to be a determined one.

From the Springfield Republican. About four miles west of Westfield, Mass., at the foot of Monnt Tekoa, is an old house in which the great-grandfather and grandmother of ex-President Cleveland spent a good share of their lives. In this house the esteemed man of his time, Richard Falley, great-grandfather of the Democratic nominee for the Presidency, was born and lived many years.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- Considerable interest was shown in the polo contest to-day between the Morristowns and Meadowbrooks, which resulted in the shutting out of the latter from the tournament, which is rogretted after their splendid victory of Monday. The attendance was very large and there was considerable enthusiam and excitement from beginning to end, the players going into the game with a vim.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- After the great smoke and little fire about General Headquarters yesterday, the issuing of orders and the rescinding of them, an order was sent out from here early this morning calling the 11,000 members of the First, Second, and Third Brigades to arms. This placed the entire National Guard under arms.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The first gun in the New-Jersey Gubernatorial fight was loaded in this city to-day by a meeting of forty of the leaders of the Democratic Party in South New-Jersey in the Hotel Lafayette.

WILLSBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The tables of last night giving the racing record of the canoe meet showed a tie between Knappe ana Gray. The corrected figures to-day show Knappe the winner with 15 points. The others stand as follows: Moore, 14 points; Gray, 13 points; Sparrow, 11 points; Hale, 6 points, and Foster, 4 points. The order of finish in paddling was Knappe, Moore, Sparrow, Hale, Gray, and Foster.

George Victor Drogo Montagu, the eighth Duke of Manchester, died at Tanderageo Castle, County Armagh, Ireland, yesterday. He was born June 17, 1858, and was the eldest son of William, the seventh Duke of the same name, who died and whom he succeeded March 21, 1890. The house of Montagu is originally of Italian descent.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Work has been stopped on the new Pennsylvania Railroad bridge, the company having learned that a syndicate in this city has claims on some of the land. The land in dispute is seventy feet wide and extends from the west side of the Raritan River at low-water mark across the canal to Nellson Street, a distance of several hundred feet.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Albert B. Waever, an eighteen-year-old Bergen Point youth, went to Jersey City last evening and secretly married the sixteen-year-old niece of Charles V. Foller, a liquor dealer at 334 Grand Street, that city. The niece had only a few hours previously been adopted by Foller, and he was very angry when he received a telegram from the mother of young Waever announcing the marriage.

The suggestion to restore the military divisions which were abolished by Secretary PROCTOR, or at least to give Gen. HOWARD and Gen. MILES division commands, naturally attracts attention in army circles. Up to the recent change the Major Generals, ever since the reorganization after the close of the civil war, had been in command of divisions; but Mr. PROCTOR'S order reduced them to the command of departments.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18 -- Midnight -- Gen. Carnes is moving a part of the distance between Clinton and Coal Creek on foot. Major Carpenter and the militia stopped their train at Cain Creek, and proceeded from there on foot. The movement was made on foot for fear of derailment on the track. Whether or not they have been attacked is not known.

There are in every bank, but more especially in the banks for savings, many deposits which are marked as "closed," but which have balances standing to the credit of depositors who never appear to lay claim to them. In an old savings bank like that in Bleecker Street these unclaimed deposits foot up many thousands of dollars.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 18. -- The Republican State Convention at Dover to-day was a quiet and, on the whole, harmonious political gathering, with at least the regulation amount of enthusiasm. As usual in this little State, with its three little counties, the convention was only a ratification of the county caucus selections, each county being accorded one Presidential Elector and the Congressional nomination being conceded to Kent.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The attention of the Post Office authorities has been drawn to a queer matrimonial agency which Sylvan B. Downs has established in East Orange. His remarkable circular soliciting business explains itself and is here reproduced:

Sir regiments from this city and Brooklyn started for Buffalo yesterday. Two from New-York -- the Twelfth and Twenty-second --- and one from Brooklyn -- the Thirteenth -- were on their way by noon. In the evening the Ninth and Seventy-first of this city and the Twenty-third of Brooklyn followed them.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The members of the late Ministry left the Victoria station at 9:30 o'clock this morning on a special train on route for Osborne House to deliver their seals of office to the Queen. The event attracted little interest, and only a small crowd gathered at the station to witness their departure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Chairman Carter and his associates have reason to be worried over the question of raising Republican campaign funds in Washington this year. The Civil Service Commission has taken an entirely expected position in opposition to campaign assesments and given Government employes to understand that it will support any of them who choose to rebel against attempts to force them to contribute to the Republican exchequer.

From the Albany Argus. Along in 1870 or 1871 -- Boss Tweed's time -- the Board of Trustees of the village of Greenbush consisted of the following persons: Duncan McFarland, President Alexander D. Schutt, Clerk, and Trustees Luke Conniff, Patrick McNalley, John Mullaney, James Stevens, James Donnelly, James Wins, Timothy Dunn, and J. E. Curran.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 19. -- After a most turbulent session, lasting two days, the Republican Convention adjourned this morning. W. J. McConneil, a wealthy merchant and banker of Moscow and ex-United States Senator, was nominated for Governor; T.B. Willis of Center County for Lieutenant Governor; James A. Curtis for Secretary of State, and Willis Sweet of Moscow for member of Congress.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Prof. Charles A. Collin of the Statutory Revision Commission said to-night that Grand Master Switchman Sweeney could be punished under Section 449 of the Penal Code, if it could be proved that he recommended, assisted, or got others to assist in the destruction of the railroad property burned and wrecked.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- An important point in the strike has been reacted. It can now be said almost certainly that the locomotive firemen on the Lehigh, Erie, Lake Shore, and West Shore and Central Roads will go out between 6 o'clock to-morrow evening and Sunday morning. The members of the Brotherhood of Trainmen and Conductors on the above roads and possibly the telegraphers will follow the firemen.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Mr. Gladstone's selection of some minor members of the Radical section for minor posts in the Government has not remedied the tactical mistake made in the exclusion of Radical representatives from the Cabinet. Thorough Radicals further declare that there is not a man among the whole of the latest appointments who is genuinely attached to progressive opinions -- Sydney Bruxton, perhaps, excepted.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Fine weather and a fast track drew a large crowd to the races to-day. Backers at the favorites returned with empty pooketbooks.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- It is a matter of regret that Adjt. Gen. Porter, the ranking general officer in the State, was not in Buffalo today. He would have seen that the present military organization of this State, while admirable for the purposes of State camppionics, is totally worthless when the National Guard is ordered into the field for an emergency.

Anglers who have visited the resorts where Weakfish are acoustomed to gather have had no reason to complain during the week, though the fishing has not been phenomenal, The luck of the fishing smacks which bring in loads of the gayly-tinted fish which so soon fade and whose delicate flaver is even more quickly lost after they have been taken out of their native element has been more remarkable.

BERNE, Aug. 19. -- Telegraphic communication has been restored with Grindelwald, the village which was threatened with destruction by fire yesterday. In some directions the fires caused in the forest by the flying sparks are still smoldering. It is estimated that fifty buildings were destroyed. Embers from the burning structures were carried a long distance, and a number of chalets miles away from Grindelwald were set on fire.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- Great indignation is manifested by the press over the long marches required of the troops during the present tropical heat. Fourteen hundred man were on the road from Treviglio to Meana from 2 o'clock in the morning until 4 in the afternoon. Fifteen were sunatruck and one became delirious and shot himself.
WILLSBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The central division race for the Jabberwook Prize was not sailed to-day for lack of enough entries. Neither was the war-canoe race.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 19. -- The best and most fortunate week of sport ever had at Hampdon Park ended here this evening. Generally a day or two is lost by rain or wet tracks, but though rain fell soon after the last heat, each of the four days has been sunny and right for racing.

According to cable dispatches received from London yesterday the English Government has at last released George McDonnell and Edward Noyes Hill, who were implicated in the great Bank of England forgeries. McDonnell and Hill are both Americans, and with George and Austin Bidwell they were sentenced to life imprisonment in 1873 for swindling the "Old Lady of Threadneedle Street" out of a round half million pounds sterling.
COAL CREEK, Tenn., Aug. 19. -- The captured miners, 100 in number, were put on box cars tonight, ready for shipment.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Two young girls lost their lives in a drowning accident here this evening. A party of girls were standing on the banks at the river laughing and joking, when two of them, Sadie White and Elizabeth Magrundy, proposed getting into an old row boat which lay at the bank and pushing out from shore.

A dead cat has been lying near the junction of Fiftieth Street and Madison Avenue for four days. Carts and attaches of the Department of Street Cleaning, the Board of Health, and the police force, have passed it daily, but not one representative of these bodies has taken a step to remove the dead animal, which, has caused a great deal of annoyance to the whole neighborhood.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Hiram Westbrook was a prominent resident of Ridgewood and one of the first settlers of the place. He was identified with all its public improvements, and was considered a shrewd business man. Lately, however, he met with business reverses, and this made him very despondent.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 19. -- It is now pretty cer- tain that the Empire Construction Company, which has an unfinished contract for building a portion of the Orange sewer system, and which stopped work on the sewers Wednesday, has not thrown up its contract nor become insolvent, but is merely playing a game of "bluff" to force the city to pay for work not included in the contract.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Gov. Flower was nettled this evening for the first time since he accepted the situation at Buffalo and placed the railroad yards there under martial law. Adjt. Gen. Porter, who was in a more peaceful state of mind than at any time since Monday, had just concluded a conference with the Governor when THE TIMES'S representative was admitted.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- This was an off day at the meeting at Washington Park. Nothing sensational occurred. The three events on the card -- the 2:20-class pacing, the 2:19-class trotting, and the 2:33-class trotting were won in straight heats, the winner in each being an overwhelming favorite. The average time, perhaps owing to last night's heavy rain, was slower than on any other day during the meeting.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Medical Examiner Snow this morning received a report on the result of the examination of the organs of the victims of the Salisbury Beach poisoning case from Prof. Hills of Harvard. The report states that the deaths were caused by paris green. The question now to be decided is, Was the poison administered with intent to kill.

The recent exhibitions of violence and disorder in this country are calculated to give the impression that there has been a decline in the spirit of respect for law and obedience to public authority. To some extent, we fear, such an impression is justified, but there are certain causes that should be taken into consideration in judging the matter.

Sunol has remained "the Queen of the Trotting Turf" for less than a year. Her supremacy has not been at any time un- challenged, for there have all along been trotting men who held that the 2:08 3/4 of Maud S. over an ordinary track was a bet- ter performance than the 2:08 1/4, of Sunol over a kite-shaped track.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19. -- R.D. Wrenn of Harvard to-day won the first prize in the Mossier Hall singles by defeating S.T. Chase of Chicago in the final round, and to-morrow will meet E.L. Hall for the championship and possesion of the cup. As Wrenn is playing a brilliant game of tennis up here and the court is just to his liking, a close contest is expected.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- The collision which occurred between Charles and Albert Riesan, brothers, of 3615 North Eighteenth Street on Wednesday evening, while riding bicycles, has resulted in the death of Charles at the Samaritan Hospital.

The Navy Department is entirely justi- fied in resenting the groundless insinua- tions recently thrown out that, while it has eagerly made known its successful trials of ship armor, it has concealed the unsuccessful ones. To begin with, there have been no such failures to conceal; but even that fact does scant justice to our naval officers.

Freeholder Ellis, a Democratic member of the ring county board, that as a rule runs things in Hudson County in the interest of " Bob " Davis, warned his party friends of the odium they were bringing upon their party at the meeting of the board in Jersey City Thursday night, and carried a little point in the interest of reform.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The trunk lines that have been tied up by the striking switchmen made encouraging progress to-day. The New-York Central accepted and handled every particle of freight that came to it. The Erie pushed out seven trains in the course or the day, and the Lehigh Valley seven trains. The Lake Shore succeeded in moving only two trains.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- The wholesale dealers in beef announce that the price of beef to-morrow will be advanced 2 cents, and the retail dealers, who secure their supply from the agents of the beef companies here, will increase the price to consumers 5 cents. This is the result of the scarcity of beef caused by the strike on the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Peter J. Demsrest, the New-York commission dealer of Reade Street, who was arrested here yesterday on a Sheriff's capias, charged with misappropriating the funds of an estate of which he was executor, was at noon to-day consigned to the county jail, being unable to secure the requisite bail of $10,000.
