WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- There is a scheme in process of development which will illustrate the audacity of pension claim agents in this city, who have enjoyed a monopoly under the Harrison Administration. It is the purpose of a shrewd combine of these attorneys to use the Grand Army encampment, which will take place in this city next month, for political ends.

An "informal dinner" was given last night at the Manhattan Athletic Club in celebration of the improvements and decorations of its roof garden, which is now a most enjoyable Summer restaurant. It has been arranged to be a Winter as well as a Summer garden, and at the first suggestion of storm and stress of weather, the large area can be changed into a veritable crystal palace of glass and iron.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 24 -- Every line was represented at the Southern Railway and Steamship Association meeting here to-day. The purpose of the meeting is to sign an agreement to continue the association another year from Sept. 1. At the New-York meeting a few weeks ago all the principal lines except four south of the Potomac and Ohio and east of the Mississippi signed or agreed to sign the agree, ment.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 24 -- About a dozen trapshooters took advantage of yesterday's cool weather and came to this town to take part in the final day's sport of the Hackettstown Gun Club. The shooting was good, despite a tricky wind, which sent the targets on erratic courses.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24 -- Heavy arrivals by every train continue. The hotels report larger business than last week, which was considered the height of the season. Lawyers from almost every State in the Union are in attendance upon the Bar Association meeting. Vice President Morton will go with Gen. Curtis to the Veterans' Reunion at Schuylerville to-morrow.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- The Board of Health intends to keep the cholera out of Boston, and to that end has decided that all immigrants from Hamburg must be landed at quarantine and thoroughly disinfected. There are on the ocean several vessels loaded with immigrants from Hamburg bound for this port, and the Board of Health has taken up this matter in time to prevent this disease getting a foothold.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Ang. 24 -- Two games were played by the Pittsburg and Brooklyn teams here to-day. In the first some lucky hitting gave the victory to the home nine, as base hits were few on both aides. Terry and Stein were both effective. Errors and bases on balls gave the visitors the second game. Score:

William H. Roberts, whose transactions in the South have been told in many columns of newspaper reports, and who for some time has been known as President of the "Finance Trading Company, capital $50,000," at 10 Wall Street, with a certificate of A1 from a commercial-rating agency, was arrested yesterday with Neil McCullum, his alter ego, on a warrant issued by Police Justice Ryan.

Since the receipt yesterday of the news that Asiatic cholera had been discovered in Hamburg and that a steamship from that port was on its way to New-York there has been a tendency in certain quarters to raise a scare over the danger of an epidemic in this city. As a matter of fact, such a danger is remote.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 24 -- The large crowd of visitors in the town has been greatly augmented since yesterday and the streets are filled with sightseers. The important event of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary this forenoon was the firemen's parade, which was witnessed by thousands of people. The procession was the longest ever seen in Essex County.
ROME, Aug. 24 -- The constitution of a Gladstone Ministry in England has caused the relations between England and the Vatican to enter upon a now phase.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 -- Popular interest in the biennial Pythian encampment centred to-day in Camp Shaw. The only feature of the programme was the competitive drilling, which began promptly at 9 o'clock. It will continue each day of the encampment until every organization has had an opportunity to drill. Camp Shaw was early a scene or bustling animation.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24 -- In a large hall used by various societies as a lodge room, on an upper flour at Swan Street and Main, the State Arbitration Board gathered at 10 o'clock this morning. Forty minutes after the hour named for opening Mr. Sweeney ocme in, and Chairman Purcell, calling the board to order, announced the statute under which the hearing was to be had.

The time is ripe now for the wary Republican managers to let it "leak out" that they are deeply concerned lest there should be remarkably decreased Republican pluralities in Vermont and Maine at the September elections.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24 -- Quite a cholera scare was worked up here to-day by an evening paper and a number of correspondents for sensational American and English journals. When the reports were read in the morning papers that the death-dealing disease had broken out in Hamburg there was great excitement in business circles, as the Hamburg-American Packet Company run a weekly steamer direct to this port.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Gandaur and Hoamer took their first practice spin this afternoon over the course on the Genesee River, on which they will row against Hanlon and O'Connor on Labor Day for the international double scull championship.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 25.-The official cholera report continues to show the usual fluctuations in the oases and deaths reported, yesterday's new cases were 174 in excess of those reported on Tuesday, while the deaths were 84 in excess of these reported on the same day. Yesterday's totals, according to the official figures, were 5,679 new oases and 2,743 deaths.

-- John C. McRae, the skillful steel-plate engraver, who did business in this city a quarter of a century ago, died last Tuesday night, aged seventy-six years, at his home, in Pamrapo, N.J. He was born in Scotland and had lived for thirty-five years in America. He married twice, two sisters, Elizabeth and Henrietta White. Five children by the former survive him, the two by the latter being dead.

The "Tariff Reform Red Book," which has just been issued, is a well-compiled and thoroughly-indexed collection of the most valuable numbers of Tariff Reform, the semi-monthly publication issued by the Reform Club. There are very few facts bearing on the tariff question which are not in some manner touched upon in this volume.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 -- A soon an the news was received last night that the strike was off, the Twenty-second Regiment drew in the grand guard which it has maintained at the Erie freight station on Louisiana and Ohio Streets. This morning when the new switchmen went to work they found in the place of the troops a crowd of hoodlums, who welcomed them with a shower of stones.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 -- Grand Master Frank Sweeney went before the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration this morning to tell what he knew about the cause, development, and effect of the strike. He told the story of his connection with the strike. He said he was powerless to order strikes, and that he did all in his power to avert the trouble, so long as he saw there was any possibility of adjustment.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 -- This morning the State Board of Arbitration resumed its hearing into the causes and circumstances of the late switchmen's strike. Grand Master Sweeney was the only witness examined up to noon. He detailed his connection with the strike and the position of toe union with respect to the various roads.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- President McLeod was not at all worried about me granting of the injunctions, and when seen to-night he said that the Reading had been prepared for just such a contingency.

The conciliatory and moderate tone of the little speeches in which the German Emperor has broken an unaccustomed silence of several weeks is naturally explained by the portentous appearance of BISMARCK in the character of a Liberal. That appearance itself is explained by the exigencies of the old stateman's vindictiveness.

The entries for the second annual cycling carnival of the Manhattan Athletic Club to be held to-morrow on Manhattan Field, One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, have closed, and the following is a list of a few of the well-known competitors. The entry list is an exceedingly large one: Quarter-Mile, Open -- A.A. Zimmerman, W.W. Windie, George F. Taylor, P.J. Berlo, C.M. Murphy, and George A. Banker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25, -- The following additional correspondence with reference to the question of tolls on vessels passing through the St. Mary's Falls Canal, in transit to any port of the Dominion of Canada, was made public at the Department of State to-day. It is supplementary to that given to the press on the 20th inst., when the President's retaliatory proclamation was issued:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States Consul at Hamburg cabled to the State Department this morning as follows:

Hugh O'Donnell, the leader of the recent strike at Homestead, lectured at Cooper Union last evening "for the benefit of the suffering Homestead strikers." The admission fee was 25 cents. There were 250 persons in the hall outside of the policemen and speakers. This means that if everybody paid the admission fee $62.50 was taken in at the box office.

Almost all the big Democratic leaders who are connected with the management of the campaign were at the National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. Chairman Harrity of the National Committee, Chairman Dickinson of the National Committee's Campaign Committee, Senator Arthur P. Gorman, Senator Calvin S. Brice, ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, Bradley B. Smalley.

WINNEPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 25 -- The Bitter feeling aroused over the question of the abolition or maintenance of Roman Catholic separate schools in the Canadian Northwest resulted, in the Legislature to-day, in over-throwing the Northwest Government by the adoption of a motion of no confidence. The feeling aroused is now intense, and developments are awaited with much anxiety.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 -- For a while to-day the situation here was more uncertain and exciting than at any time since the outbreak of the switchmen's strike. Within an hour events occurred which seemed to justify the retention of 75 per cent, of the military force.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25 -- About 18,000 people were present at the third day of the Columbus Driving Park. The track was last. Hal Pointer and Direct were the star attractions, though the latter had sore feet and was in no form. Splan could not handle Hal Pointer. In the third heat he broke a hundred yards from the wire and had to he pulled to a standstill, losing eight lengths and letting Direct in.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 25 -- The North German Lloyd steamship Dresden, Capt. W. Kruhoffer, arrived to-day from Bremen. She brings 632 immigrants.

The persecution of the Rev. Dr. BARTLETT at Boudour, near Smyrna, is a case peculiarly adapted to excite President HARRISON'S Presbyterian sympathies. Dr. BARTLETT is not merely incapable of knowingly violating any law. His experience is such that it is quite impossible that he should even accidentally and unintentionally have infringed any rightful regulation imposed by the Sultan.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- John Randolph Tucker of Virginia pronounced at this morning's session of the American Bar Association the annual address to the members. It was a scholarly effort, and required two hours for its delivery. Then followed the report of the Standing Committees on Jurisprudence and Law Reform, Judicial Administration and Remedial Procedure, Legal Education and Admission to the Bar, and Commercial Law and International Law.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The condition of many of the Jewish emigrants who pass through this city is such that should cholera break out among them it would find a fertile field for its spread. The Jewish committee here state that within a month 1,000 Jews, refugees from Russia, have passed through Paris, moat of whom were on their way to the United States.

It would be as foolish to overlook the possible arrival and spread of cholera in this country as it would be to get into a fever of alarm about it. As nearly as can now be judged, we are exposed to the infection in various ways, but in none that vigilance, energy, and patient care will not guard us against.

The anthracite coal combination moved up prices again yesterday and gave consumers another chance to perceive the beauties to the public of "economies of administration" by the concern in the combine. Last month some of the companies advised an advance in rates, but others opposed it, on the advice of counsel, Wall Street rumors said.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Aug. 25. -- The Democratic State Convention resumed its session at 11 o'clock this morning. The amended reports of the Committee on Credentials and Permanent Organization were received and adopted, the temporary officers being made permanent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 -- A pleasant dance to 150 guests was given this evening at the Havemeyer villa in honor of Mrs. E.C. Potter, who is visiting her parents here. The decorations were very pretty, the flower banks and shrubbery being arranged in artistic combinations. The cotillion was led by Mr. Richard Peters and Mrs. Potter.

LOON LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- President Harrison will go to Malone to-morrow, leaving here at about 11 o'clock. It is expected that he will arrive in Malone at about noon, and it has been planned for him to lunch with some prominent citizens at the Howard House.

The health, officers are taking active stops to be able to cope with the cholera should it appear here. A meeting of the Health Board was hold in the room of President Wilson at Sanitary Headquarters yesterday, at which Mr. Wilson presided. The other officers present were City Sanitary Superintendent Dr. Cyrus Edson, Dr. J.C. Bryant, Dr. Roberts, Chief of the Division of Contagious Diseases, and Gen. Emmoiis Clark, Secretary of the Board.

For the third time this season the "Newton Diamond Badge," emblematic of the Atlantic Rod and Gun Club's best shooter, was won yesterday by Charles Morris, the President of the Atlantic Club. He had to kill twenty-one straight to do it. "Dick " Dwyer gave him a tight race, but was beaten one bird. The second prize in the club was divided by O. Furgueson, Jr., D. Moasees, C. Meyer, R.R. Street, and D. Deacon.
The success of the Westchester County Fair as a social event last year has nerved the promoters to renewed efforts to make it even a more notable affair tills Fall.

NEWCASTLE, Aug. 25 -- The climax of the bitterest and most rancorous contest on record was a comparatively uneventful polling day. There was an enormous display of rival colors, which appeared to rather favor Mr. Morley, Both Bides were well served with vehicles. Mr. Morley drove to every corner of the constituency.

President Harrison has established a factory for the making of campaign material at the brownstone building 518 Fifth Avenue. It is working at a lively gait and is turning out good McKinley tariff material at a rate second only to the Congressional Record during a debate.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- With a feeling that the actions of the past two weeks regarding the switchmen's strike had been satisfactory to the law-abiding citizens and content to leave the winding up of the trouble to his Adjutant General and the law officers. Gov. flower will leave at midnight for Watertown to conclude the outing in the North Woods which was interrupted by the strike.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 25. -- Old Gloucester never before presented such a holiday appearance as to-day, with her buildings gaily decked with the national colors, with bunting, and with shields. The streets were crowded with people, the early trains bringing in large delegations from neighboring towns and cities, and every available vantage ground for witnessing the parade was occupied long before the appointed time for the procession to start.

Chairman Harrity of the National Committee, ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, Senator Arthur P. Gorman, Arthur Sewall, the National Committeeman from Maine; Bradley B. Smalley, Josiah Quincy, and Don M. Dickinson were all at the Democratic National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, at one time or another yesterday. Most of them spent the whole day there.
OLYMPIA, Washington, Aug. 26 -- The Democratic State Convention, which began its work here on Wednesday, has nominated the following ticket:

BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- This afternoon a woman became suddenly ill in an omnibus and was taken to the Central Railway Station and thence to the Moabit Hospital, where she was pronounced to be suffering from Asiatic cholera. The authorities have ordered that the woman's lodgings and the Central Railway Station be disinfected and the omnibus stopped.

The Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will begin this afternoon, and racegoers will do well to remember that the races will begin a half hour earlier than they have begun at the other tracks, that is, at 2 o'clock. So those that want an opportunity to see the races from a comfortable seat on the grand stand will do well to go to the track a trifle earlier than usual.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The track was heavy to-day, owing to last night's rain, and the time made was rather slow. There was a fair attendance. No special features characterized the events. Rain fell after the third race.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Although the heavy rain of yesterday has been repeated, large arrivals continue at the hotels. The Grand Union has over 200 fresh names since morning and the United States shows a large list. A high-class excursion party over the Pennsylvania Road reached the Union to-night from Maryland and Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- On the Stock Exchange this morning there was very little desire to trade at current prices, a bearish feeling having taken the place of the late buoyancy. Chicago Brewing common sold at 44 1/4. North Chicago ruled dull at 264, buyer 15, followed by sales at 260. Street's Stable Car sold at 33 1/4 @34. West Chicago opened at 200 bid and 212 asked; trades were made at 207 @202 1/2.

Harper's for the last hot month of the Summer has a peculiarly gay and social look, as becomes the feelings of its hosts of readers, who need something that stimulates and pleases. The Editor's Drawer has its illustrations to comic themes, the Editor's Easy Chair is fronted by a full-page drawing by Du Maurier which hits off the ungallantry of boys, and there are two pieces of verse by Messrs.

The death is announced in Paris of Charles Andre de la Jaille, Vicomte, General, and formerly Senator. He was born at Baie Mahault, in Guadalupe, April 15, 1824. In the Crimean War he was Captain of Artillery; in the Italian campaign at Magenta his battery took from the Austrians the Bridge of NaviglioGrande.

William H. Roberts and Neil McCallum, who are under arrest for running a bogus banking business at 10 Wall Street, known as the Finance Trading Company, were yesterday brought into the Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge O'Brien, on a writ of habeas corpus granted to their counsel, Denis McMahon. They have been in Jefferson Market prison since Wednesday, The formal charge against them is one of grand larceny.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- The Philadelphia and Reading Ballroad Company's statement for the month of July, 1892, allows gross traffic receipts, $1,881,253.39; gross expenses, $996,409.73 profit for the month, $991,970.76. From this is deducted $13,079.97 expended for permanent improvements, and $625,000 as one-twelfth of current year's fixed charges, leaving a surplus of $352,990.79, a decrease of $69,582.86 compared with the month of July, 1891.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- This city to-night has resumed its normal appearance. The groups of military officers have abandoned the Iroquois Hotel corridors, no private soldiers are seen on the streets, the railways are running as usual, no threatening strike stories are abroad, all the New-York troops are homeward bound, and the $19,000,000 worth of railway property is left practically in charge of Gen. Doyle's Fourth Brigade, Sheriff Beck, and Mayor Bishop.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- There is now no doubt that cholera has at last entered England. The disease was brought here by the steamer Gemma, which arrived at Gravesend yesterday from Hamburg. It was reported that the steamer was infected, but the authorities, after examining the passengers, allowed them to land.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 26 -- The second day of the Borden trial developed much interesting testimony and many significant incidents. Rapid progress in the examination of witnesses was made, and late in the afternoon Bridget Sullivan, the domestic, who is generally regarded as one of the most important witnesses for the prosecution, was placed upon the stand.

The raw east wind that swept over the city yesterday, bringing with it at intervals a rain that savored more of the late Fall than August, damped the ardor of the anglers who had arranged for an outing to-day or to-morrow. Experience had taught them that fishing in such weather conditions was seldom attended by success.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- Big Edward Crane, the New-York pitcher, proved an enigma to the batemen of the local club here today, and the New-Yorkers won the game in an easy manner. While Crane was keep ing down the base hits of the Browns, excellent timely batting by Capt. Ewing and third-baseman Lyons scored the winning runs for the Giants.
"It was what might be termed a big day at the National Republican Headquarters."

BOSTON, Aug. 26 -- The steamer Kehrwelder, from Hamburg; arrived in quarantine at noon to-day with seventy steerage passengers aboard, mainly recuited from Russia and Poland. It is needless to say that all the precautions of a rigid quarantine will be enforced before the immigrants are allowed to land in Boston.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- News was received here to-night of the drowning in Georgian Bay yesterday of Hiram W. Sibley, his wife, daughter, and son, and two young ladies of this city, who were guests of the family.

It must be owned that the recent strikes have had very valuables uses for the militia of the States of New-York and Pennsylvania. The emergency in each case -- at Homestead and at Buffalo -- was clear. The Governor of Pennsylvania deliberated before calling out the militia, and insisted that the local authorities should exhaust their own resources before invoking those of the State.

The Western States and the Indians take up a large portion of the September Scribner's, which is an American number from cover to cover, all the writers being Americans. "The Indian Who Ia Not Poor" shows what it is to live with the Indians, for Mr. C.F. Lummis does not write like a tourist, but as one who has shared the sports and council fires of a peculiar people -- peculiar even to other redskins.

The Pacific Mail subsidy question occupied the attention of the Transcontinental Association all of yesterday afternoon at the Windsor Hotel. A temporary arrangement was made, by which the present agreement between the roads in the Transcontinental Association, and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company will be continued for four months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- All that the Government can do toward lessoning the chances of cholera gaining a foothold in this country is being done with expedition. The news that the dread disease has invaded England has served to put the officials most interested on their mettle, and with many English, French, and German ships reaching American ports each week the importance of an effective quarantine is fully realized.

LOON LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- President Harrison to-day went to Malone, where he was tendered a reception by the citizens. He was met at the station by a committee, and, after luncheon, was escorted to the park, where several thousand persons had gathered. He was introduced by the Hon. F.D. Kilburn, and spoke as follows:

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 26 -- A series of accurate and careful soundings was run to-day by the United States Revenue steamer Morrill along the now Jetties Channel entrance to Charleston Harbor, with the view of ascertaining, in the interest of navigation, the exact amount of water now obtainable in the new entrance.

Baron Raymond de Seilliere and his Wife, formerly Mrs. Livermore, were in the city yesterday in response to a telegram from the French Consul, the Vicomte d'Abzao, in relation to the death of the Baron's brother Roger. There was a great deal of mystery in the matter, and nearly every one concerned had ready the answer, "My lips are sealed."

The organization of political clubs throughout the country, especially in the Northern States, in the last four years promises to work a practical revolution in campaign methods. It is in effect an organization of the party forces throughout the rank and file. So far as parties can be said to have been organized at all before, it was practically an organization of the working politicians rather than of the voters.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- A fearful mining accident occurred this morning at the Parkslip coal pit, near Bridgend, a mining town in Glamorganshire, Wales. The day shift of 150 miners had not been long in the mine before a moat terrible explosion was heard. The explosion caused the earth and rook to fall, and the mouth of the pit was closed. Not a single man of the 150 in the mine had made his escape.

The success which attended the recent trials at Sandy Hook of a carriage for the ten-inch disappearing gun points to an early acquisition of devices of this sort for our harbor defenses. It must be remembered that the system of the Pneumatic Gun Carriage and Power Company thus tested was only one of three or four American inventions for this purpose, all seeking recognition from the Government.

At Lafayette, on the Sohuylkill River, to-day the swimming championships of the United states will be decided. The contests will be held under the auspices of the Philadelphia Amateur Swimming Club. Arthur Kenney, the Australian champion, will make an effort to lower some of the records. Some of his performances have been discredited, but if he does any record breaking to-day the Amateur Athletic Union will have to recounize his work.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- The Brooklyn players, contrary to their own expectations and the fears of many of the Cleveland enthusiasts, did not head off the lenders to-day. The home club continued to climb upward by winning both games.

At the recent session of Congress the bill for the collection and arrangement of the records of the American Revolution and the war of 1812, under the direction of the War Department, became a law. The project doubtless takes its rise from the success which has attended the much more extensive work done for the civil war, and like this latter will be of inestimable value to the historian.

No doubt President McLEOD of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company is an authority on the subject of the practical effect of the decision of Chancellor McGILL on the operation of the railroads in the coal "combine," but when he undertakes to criticise the regularity of the court's action he goes out of his province.

Thomas H. Rodman, a lawyer formerly very active at the bar in this part of the State, died yesterday at his home, 169 Congress street, Brooklyn, from the effects of scolds received while in his bathtub on Thursday afternoon. Mr. Rodman had been in falling health for a long time and had been living a retired life.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 26 -- The annual dis play of light-harness pyrotechnics began at the kitoshaped track to-day. For the first time since the mooting opened on Monday, the course was in fair condition. But it is not yet fully dried out, and horsemen estimate it to be still one second slow. During the afternoon no less than five world's records were beaten.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 26 -- The Populists are mailing arrangements for a general attack in Virginia early in October. Weaver will speak here on Oct. 1, and Field at Lynchburg on the same day. The Democrats, however, are not apprehensive of any unfavorable results because of their visit. It may be that the coming of the third-party Presidential candidate will be turned to the advantage of their opponents.

-- The United States schoolship Constellation, Commander G.M. Chester, arrived at Annapolis yesterday with the cadets on board. All the cadets except the fourth-class men and a few others upon whom restrictions hare been placed will go on leave, lasting until Oct. 1. The fourth-class men will be quartered on the Santee till the return of the other classes at the beginning of the academic year.
Two tons of decaying fruit, spoiled fish, and bad eggs were dumped at the foot of Rutgers Street yesterday, the result of a morning's raid by the officers of the Board of Health.

The preparations of the Health Officer of this port to shut out the cholera are systematic, intelligent, and apparently as complete as it is possible to make them. A General in command who should make a correspondingly skillfull disposition of his troops would in all probability be successful against any invading force not of greatly superior numbers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 26 -- With a continuation of the wet weather of Thursday, to-day settled the question of Charter Oak's success or failure, and what promised to be the blue-ribbon meeting of the Grand circuit is virtually ruined. This morning opened damp and gloomy, but at noon Secretary King telegraphed from the tract, "If no more rain will start at 1."

The contract for building the mighty Croton Dam at Cornell in the town of Cortlandt, Westchester County, was awarded yesterday afternoon by the Aqueduct Commissioners to the lowest bidder, James S. Coleman, formerly Street-Cleaning Commissioner. Mr. Coleman's bid was $4,150,573, and for this he will build the largest dam in the world.

NEW-YORK. -- At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday the following Sergeants were transferred: George F. Brennan from the Ninth Precinct to the Seventh, Ezra D. Strope from the Twentieth to the Ninth, Lorenzo D. Lovell from the Thirty-first to the Twentieth.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- General headquarters was re-established at the Delavan House this evening. Adjt. Gen. Porter, accompanied by Major Horace G. Young of the Third Brigade staff and Lieut. Edward E. Hardin of the United States Army, reached here on the Empire State Express, which came along an hour ahead of the first train of the day containing returning troops.

None of yesterday's incoming steamships was from an infected port, and the Quarantine officer had only routine work to occupy their attention. In the morning Health Officer Jenkins made a tour of inspection of the quarantine establishments on Hoffman and Swinburne Islands. Upon his return he said that everything was in perfect condition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $163,770,050, as follows: Currency 6s, $11,761,000; 4 per cents, $129,958,700; 2 per cents, $22,050,350.

From the Denber Republican. As if the scenic beauty above ground was not attractive enough for the visitors of Manitou, nature formed caverns beneath the surface deep into the subterranean formations and there evolved from her fertile brain the most delicately-wrought crystals, grotesquely-shaped stalagmites, and lovely stalactites.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- The weather for the first day of the Fall meeting of the Latonia (Ky.) Jockey Club was beautiful. Recent rains bail left the track lumpy and a trifle slow. About 4,000 people witnessed the first day's sport. Favorites won in the first four races. In the fifth race Sister Mary, who sold oven with Shadow, each going for 2 to 1, failed to show on the finish.

From the New-Haven Palladium. Several traits of lightning have been discovered by photography that were not previously suspected. This is particularly true of the course taken by a thunderbolt. So ephemeral is the flash -- it seldom lasts over a two-hundredth part of a second, and some authorities say that occasionally it endures only a millionth -- that the eye can distinguish little beyond the general route traversed.

One unpleasant fact was told last night of the visit of Secretary of War Elkins to Republican Headquarters. It was intimated to him, it was said, in language very dignified and diplomatic, but so plain that it could not be misunderstood, that for the best good of the Republican Party in this State he had better not attempt to cut much of a figure in New-York State politics for the present.

I'm a little Skye terrier, that's all; but I have a story to tell. If you do not like terriers' tales, drop this here and now; still, I think if you follow it to its ending you will feel a slight flush of indignation, even though you've not gained much wisdom, and, mayhap, you will also feel like championing the cause of other unfortunate dogs who may suffer like me.
The Staten Island Cricket Club was pitted against the Manhattan of Brooklyn yesterday, at the Staten Island grounds, and won easily by a score of 106 to 29. Score:

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 27. -- A Paris dispatch to THE TIMES of Aug. 10 announcing the bombardment of the entire coast of Dahomey by French naval forces, and the invasion and destruction of interior Dahomeyan towns by French naval brigades, had an interested reader in Capt. Frank C. Bonneau of Charleston, the Famous Confederate blockade runner of the last war, who in 1858, on the Dahomeyan coast, escaped capture by the merest accident.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the New-York Times. LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The cholera has come, and we are obviously on the very threshold of a considerable panic. Thus far the British Islands appear not to have assimilated any genuine contagion, though we know less about several suspicious cases in London and one or two English harbor towns than desirable.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- There was a fair attendance at the races here to-day. The chief event on the programme was the Kenner Stakes, for three-year-olds, one mile and three-quarters. It was won by Ronald.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- It was announced, this morning that another passenger who landed at Gravesend on the steamship Gemma, which arrived Thursday from Hamburg, had died from cholera at the Gravesend Hospital.

Samuel Gladding, at the age of forty, was one of the most promising young men or Aberdeen. So he had been, when, a lad of twelve, he had "accepted a position" (i. e. dusted and swept out) in his father's store, and so in all likelihood he would be even when senility quavered a contradiction; for a promising young man in a small city, like an evergreen, may wither, but he never grows old.
READING, Penn., Aug. 27. -- Venomous snakes are very common in the Schuylkill Valley this Summer. Rattlesnakes and copperheads especially appear to be even more plentiful than last season.

From the San Francisco Call. A Sew days ago mention was made of the disappearance in an earthquake of the principal island of the Sangir group, in longitude 125, midway between the Islands of Mindanao and Celebes. News now comes that a Dutch skipper, sailing along the northwest coast of Australia, reports the disappearance of Expedition Island, at the mouth of Collier Bay, in Western Australia.

Mr. Parkin has taken up the advocacy of British federation in response to many requests from friends. There was need for a collection of facts and arguments set down in connected and popular form. Mr. Parkin has considered the whole subject, as it affects not only Canada, but Australia, New-Zealand, South Africa, India, and the West Indies.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 27. -- This afternoon 'Gen. Adlal E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for the Vice Presidency, delivered his opening speech of the campaign here before an immense gathering. This is Gen. Stevenson's home, and the reception accorded his utterances upon the leading party issues shows well how his home city feels toward him and the party he represents.

From the New-Orleans Times-Democrat. When the Mississippi first began to fall and the engineers bad a chance to investigate the banks, they expressed the opinion that there would be no more cavings than usual this year. This appears to be a mistake, at least for the country immediately around New-Orleans, where the caving has been phenomenally bad, although the river has not yet reached low owater.

To the series known as the Chandos Classics, which embraces a noble collection of literature that is classical, the Messrs. Warne have added "The Diary and Letters of Mme. D'Arblay." It is the first popular edition that has been brought out, and this fact, considering the eminence of the work, is one to awaken surprise.

The steamer Gellert, which arrived yesterday, brought along the following members of the Arion Society, whose singers made a triumphal tour through Germany and Austria: Jacob Ahrens and wife, Henry Ahl and wife, Emil Ams, Morris Baer, Richard Dehnhoff, C.A. Daut, Otto A. Graff, Jacob Germann, Gustav, Hollweg, William Herzog, Carl Mann, Mrs. W. B. Powell, Miss Maud Powell, Dr. Paul Schoeaemann, Andrew Schaefer, and Carl Sohaefer.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 27. -- The end of the season is rapidly approaching. Every outgoing train is crowded with tourists en route to their city homes or the mountain resorts. In another week the hotel keepers will be thinking of putting up storm doors and closing their houses until next Summer. The cottagers, of course, will remain until Oct. 1, but the hotels will be depopulated long before that time.

Copyrighted, 1893, by the N.Y. Associated Press. BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- Delegates from all the Federal States held a conference at the Home Office to-day on the subject of cholera. The President of Police reported that not a single case of Asiatic cholera had yet been certified to in Berlin. Statements were read from Prof. Koch and Counselor Rahts, together with a general report covering the whole health condition of Germany.

Is it necessary to go into paroxysms of grief because certain animals are extinct, or as Mr. Frederic A. Lucas of the United States National Museum expresses it are "threatened with extermination" There are more men and fewer wild animals. Mankind does not interfere so much with the survival of the fittest as it hastens the destruction of the entire fauna.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Vice President Morton left to-day for New-York. Mrs. Morton will remain for another week at the residence of George P. Bliss.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The cottagers have now nearly all returned to Lenox, and while the season will not be as gay as in some previous years, yet the Summer residents will have about all they can attend to during the next two months.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 27. -- The greatest fire in the history ot Augusta in recent years occurred this morning in the heart of the city. Over a quarter million dollars went up in flames. The fire was discovered about 3 o'clock in the large three-story building occupied by Fleming Bowles, furniture dealers, and the Alexander Seed and Drug Company.

Whether the destruction of the Metropolitan Opera House is to be a loss or a gain to the public will depend wholly on its rebuilding. If it is not rebuilt at all there will be a distinct public loss; if it is rebuilt according to its former plan, there will certainly be no gain. From the beginning the Metropolitan Opera House was confessedly a failure as a structure.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 27. -- A few days ago a grand barbecue was given at Leland, Washington County. Miss., by the planters of the vicinity to the negroes living on their lands. The reason was the faithful services rendered by the latter during the recent high water, when the whole of that fertile alluvial region was threatened with a disastrous overflow.

From the Chicago Western Electrician. Ozone was first discovered by Van Marum a century or more ago, but it was first investigated and brought prominently to the notice of medical and scientific men by Sohonbein of Germany in 1845. From that date to the present it has been a subject of active study by scientists, sanitarians, and medical men generally.

Peekskill, Westchester County, will be filled with veterans next Friday at the third annual reunion of the survivors of the Sixth New-York Heavy Artillery. Company A of this regiment was organized in that city.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27. -- The local club won three straight games from Brooklyn, and now has a good lead in the race for championship honors. To-day's contest was marked by heavy batting on the part of the Clevelands. In the second inning they hit Haddock's pitching hard enough to score 5 runs. After that he was taken out of the box and Foutz was substituted, but it was too late.

NEW-ORLEANS, Ang. 27. -- The arrangements for the Olympic triple events are progressing smoothly and satisfactorily. Now that the poolrooms have posted odds, there is a little betting, mostly on combinations, but there have been no sensational bets to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The storm to-day put a stop to all outdoor entertainments. The cold was keenly felt, so that overcoats and wood fires were in general demand. The Narragansett Pler and Block Island boats both attempted to make their regular trips, but were obliged to return on account of the heavy sea. Under the circumstances Mrs. George Peabody Wetmore's entertainment was a delightful success and the dinner one to be long remembered.

From Good Words. But how can invisible particles be brought within the range of our vision? That was one of the first of the many marvelous discoveries of Mr. John Aitken, F.R.S., Falkirk, a distinguished physicist, whose remarkable work has revolutionized a branch of meteorology. He showed that without dust in the air there could be no fogs, no mist, no cloud, and probably no rain.

Washington Letter to the Bochester Post-Express. Statuary Hall was for many years occupied by the House of Representatives previous to the completion of the great south wing of the Capitol where the Representatives now meet annually. It is a Semi-Circular room, is this old Hall of Representatives, and a very peculiar place. For some reason, which no one has been able to explain, it is an echo hall, possessed of remarkably acoustic properties.

Wallace and Poulton have written much in regard to color from the point of view of natural selection, and, as Mr. Beddard states it, the literature relating to animal coloration is enormous. In fact, an exhaustive work upon the entire subject would require a naturalist of a kind hardly existing -- a specialist in every group.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- The new steel passenger steamers which the Globe Iron Works of this city have just contracted to build for a company in which President J.J. Hill of the Manitoba Railroad and Great Northern Steamship Company is heavily interested will surpass anything on the lakes in speed, beauty, and accommodations.

The appearance of ex-Senator PLATT at the Republican Headquarters on Friday, his participation in a formal and solemn conference with the powers that would be, his subsequent intimate confabulation with Mr. ex-Land Commissioner CARTER -- this series of interesting incidents in the Harrison campaign in this State are regarded with satisfaction by a considerable number of eager and avid Republicans.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 27. -- In an interview today, speaking of cholera, Dr. Wickwire, Dominion Health Officer of this port, said the quarantine accommodations were inadequate, especially during the Winter months. In case of cholera coming, temporary buildings would have to be erected.

There is not much of hero worship in Mr. Leland. The translator of Heine might have satisfied, himself with simply transforming Heine's German into English, with such explanatory notes as might have been deemed useful to the text. We fail to see why Mr. Leland should have given so much of Mr. Leland in the notes.

-- The final abandonment of the plan to have an international exhibition at Berlin in 1900 has called forth bitter remarks on Chancellor Caprivi from some German papers. The North German Gazette argues that there is no need of trying to impress the world with Germany's progress, since the world knows her greatness, insinuating that other countries may try for advertisement by expositions if they like, but Germany is above such things.

Stephen B. Elkins, Secretary of War, walked up the brownstone steps of the National Republican Headquarters, 518 Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning. His face was ruddy, and he had a coating of tan on his neck and hands that could not have been improved upon if he had been cultivating a farm in a strong Alliance Congressional district.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27. -- City Judge William R. Coddington is at Lake Hopatcong.

MAYSVILLE, Ky., Aug. 27. -- Squire Massie Beasley of Aberdeen died at 7:30 o'clock this morning. The squire was elected Magistrate in 1869, and has hold the office continuously ever since. The squire was born in Adams County, Ohio, in 1811. At seventeen he left school and became deputy surveyor of his native county, and held public offices all his life.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The Democrats of the Oranges are preparing to open the campaign and push the work of recruiting voters for Cleveland and Stevenson in dead earnest. Thus far not a Republican banner has been seen, although the East Orange Tariff Reform Club's handsome standard has floated in the air for over three weeks in a township where a Democratic banner has never before been seen.

The third supplementary practice shoot was hold yesterday. On account of the trouble at Buffalo and the consequent absence or late return of many of the regiments, the match was not as well attended as usual. The weather was cloudy, with a light "one o'clock" wind blowing, the gray light making a good shooting day.

September has a gift entirely its own and it is called the Autumnal equinox. This occurs when the sun enters the sign Libra, at which time astronomical Autumn begins. This belt of the earth's domain reaches its fruition. The flowers take on their deepest hues, the trees that bear fruit are most heavily limbed, and rich harvests reward the husbandman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The programme for the Colombian dedicatory ceremonies Oct. 21 next is to be revised and cut down by the Council of Administration. As outlined at present, the ceremonies that day would last for five hours. This the council decided was too long a time, and the desire was manifested to reduce it to four hours.
LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Thomas Neill, indicted for the murder of Matilda Clover, was again arraigned before Sir John Bridge in the Bow Street Police Court to-day.

"AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS." "Around the World in Eighty Days" has heretofore been classed as a spectacular drama, | but a performance at the opening of the season at Niblo's Garden last night disclosed the fact that it may be presented as a pantomime. That was substantially what an uncontrolled mob of young hoodlums in the gallery and balcony made it, and there was no protest from the lower part of the house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- It is reported here today that a memorial will be submitted to the President from New-York and other ports, urging the prohibition of all immigration from countries where the cholera now has a foothold.

HEADING, Penn., Aug. 27. -- Among the farmyard oddities hereabout are a six-legged pig, owned by Elias Seaman of Naftzingerstown and a four-legged duckling, treasured for luck by John Smithinger of Union Township, near Birdsborough. Jacob Loeb, also of Naftzingerstown, owns a male guinea that has just hatched out a brood of nine young guineas, which he takes care of with the same pride and attention that a well-regulated guinea hen would manifest.

The Hoboken Evening News shell regatta took place yesterday afternoon. The course was straightaway from Shadyside to the Atlantic House at Guttenberg. There were twenty-one gold medals as prizes. The contesting boat clubs were the Atlantic, Valencia, Active, Rosedale, and Germania. Owing to the lateness of the hour at which the races finished -- It was after 9 o'clock when the party reached Hoboken -- the time was not taken for the last races.

From Good Words. As the evidence of the earth's crust proves that our globe has lasted for incalculable ages, it becomes of interest to think how far the gradual elongation of the day may have attained significant proportions since very early times. It may be that even in a thousand years the effect or the tides is not sufficient to alter the length of the day by so much as a single second.

In the first section of the Metropolitan District Cricket League the Berkeley Athletic Club eleven played its final game of the season yesterday, defeating the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Bayonne, N.J. The Berkeleys won the match before six of their wickets were down. This victory gives the Berkeleys the championship. While the New-Jersey Athletic Club has two more games to play, it cannot even tie the Berkeleys.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Aug. 27. -- John M. Burke, the Democratic candidate for Governor, nominated Thursday, is about forty-eight years old, and is a Virginian by birth. At the breaking out of the war he was in college near Richmond, Va., and became a member of Gen. Lee's staff. After the war he went first to Omaha, where he was a bunker, and afterward to Utah, where he invested in raining property.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- All night long the volunteer rescuing parties kept up their work at the Parkslip pit, the scene of the disastrous explosion at Bridgend, Wales, yesterday. They worked with a will, and removed an enormous quantity of debris from the mine. At 6 o'clock this morning they had penetrated 900 yards into the main shaft.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Aug. 27 -- P.M. To-day's stock market was a very uninteresting affair. There were only about 95,000 shares handed in and 28,000 were in the unlisted department. Sugar and Reading made up nearly half of the market. The former closed 1/2 and the latter 1/8 higher.

SARATOGA, Aug. 27. -- The severe downpour of Thursday and Friday was most depressing to Summer loiterers here. Some one has found out that a long rain has a most soothing effect upon one's nerves, but not, it may be added, if one is at a watering-place hotel.

Our happy grandmothers, who enjoyed the seasons in their regular order, were not called upon to consider new furs in midsummer, but in this topsy-turvy age August is the month when the first new furs appear. The advance specimens this year are small triangular collarettes. They are pointed back and front, so that when opened and laid flat they make a perfect triangle.

MALONE, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Gov. Flower, accompanied by Mrs. Flower and his son-in-law, Mr. Taylor, and Mrs. Taylor of Watertown, arrived at Malone at noon to-day, en route to Paul Smith's, for a fortnight's rest and pleasure. He was met at Norwood by a non-partisan delegation of citizens of Malone, who arranged with him to accept a citizens' reception here.

PAUL E. THEARD. The Hon. Paul E. Theard died in New-Orleans yesterday in his sixty-seventh year. He was born in the Parish of St. Bernard, below New-Orleans, and was educated as an accountant. He served in the Mexican war and afterward in the war of the rebellion, when he commanded the Twenty-third Louisiana Regiment.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the World, of the 16th inst. was published a letter on the encroachments on the Battery, signed by "H.B.," in which he says that the movement engineered by the "Vesey Street Grocer" was farcical and ended because he declared that he could not get a citizen or resident of the ward next the Battery to bring the necessary suit.

What the future of the Metropolitan Opera House will be is a pretty hard matter to decide. Adrian C. Iselin, one of the Directors of the company, as soon as he heard of the fire hurried down to the city from his Summer home at New-Rochelle. He made a careful inspection of the house. After he had completed, this tour, and while gazing down, upon the wrecked auditorium, he said:

From the Philadelphia Times, Aug. 21. The movement which has for its end the collection of all the weather proverbs of the United States is, in this section of the country, in charge of L.M. Dey, the good-natured and genial weather prophet on the top story of the Post Office Building. The work is undertaken under orders issued from Washington by Prof. Mark W. Hurrington, the Chief of the Weather Bureau.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Cooler weather increased the business at the theatres this week. One new play was presented to the public. The company at the Grand which last season played "Incog" was seen in "Divorce Day," which was adapted from the German, by Kirke Lashelle. It was put on to take the place of Nothing but Money," written by the author of Incog."

The statement has been made that the present imbarrassment of the Danville and Terminal Companies is due to the leases made by the Danville Company. Mr. Pat Calhoun has something to say on that point which will be read with attention. When asked in regard to it, he replied:

While it was possible at the beginning of this century for an Alexander von Humboldt "to take a survey of the entire domain of the them extant science," such a birdlike flight to-day, says the author of this volume, would be quite out of the question. There is no specialist who is "master of all the work which has been done in a comparatively small field."

At the meeting of the Transcontinental Association in the Windsor Hotel yesterday. Chairman Vining was directed to send notice to all of the railroad companies in the association that the Canadian Pacific Road proposes, on and after Sept. 10, to apply the same rates to domestic as to imported freight, and all the roads are at liberty to apply the same rates after giving three months' notice to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

From the Baltimore American. A Maine man criticises Baltimore cooking. He is a good judge, of course. He comes from a State where they know nothing better than lobster salad and clam stews, which bear about the same relation to our erabs and oyster and terrapin as a yellow pumpkin does to an Anne Arundel watermelon. The Maine man means well, but he does not know.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- Another theatre opened its season an Monday -- the Howard Athenaeum -- the attraction being Tony Pastor's company. Next week Lily Clay's Gaiety Company will be there. The new plan of having matinees on Tuesdays. Thursdays, and Saturdays, and none on Wednesdays, promises to work well.

With eyes heavy from loss of sleep, unshaven faces, and soiled uniforms the New-York regiments that were in Buffalo during the strike came home yesterday, and of all the crowd that reached here there wasn't a man who didn't long for a bath and a clean shave.

No other disease known to the medical world has been the subject of such deep and exhaustive study during the past twenty-five years as cholera. Koch spent nearly ten years in constant search after the source and action of the disease, and the best minds of the medical world have grappled with the subject.

The close of August will find the Democratic national canvass advanced to a stage where all those who are to be active in the campaign will find their work carefully laid out for them. The preliminary work -- the business of organizing for the fight -- has occupied the attention of the gentlemen at the Democratic National Headquarters up to this time.

Less than one hour after the firemen had been summoned to combat the Metropolitan Opera House fire yesterday they were called out to fight a fresh and perhaps fiercer outburst of flames in the five-story brick building at 124 Wooster Street, just at the junction of that street with Prince Street.

It is an open question as to whether the regiments which went to Buffalo from this city and Brooklyn or those which were held in reserve profited the more from the experiences of the last week or during the period covered by the railroad strike campaign.

The Manhattan Athletic Club team won easily from the Orange Athletic Club nine on the latter's grounds yesterday. Wilson pitched another good game for the Manhattans, only one bit being charged against him.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 27. -- Racing at Rush Park to-day was for the most part tame. In the 2:19 trot a great contest developed between the California stallion Steve Whipple and the Michigan horse St. Vincent. The latter was favorite at odds; and at the end of five heats the race was awarded to him. But the majority of horsemen were of the opinion that the race should have gone to Steve Whipple.

A decided and healthy impetus was given to cycling in this city by the meet held in the Manhattan Field, One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, by the Manhattan Athletic Club yesterday afternoon. Nothing held in this vicinity, touching this sport, has exceeded or even reached the magnitude of the tournament as regards quality of racing or attendance.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The first week of the Borden murder trial closed at noon to-day, and after half the Government witnesses have testified there is not the slightest change in the divided opinions of the people here as to the guilt or Innocence of the young woman who is accused of having brutally murdered her father and stepmother.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The first week of the Borden murder trial closed at noon to-day, and after half the Government witnesses have testified there is not the slightest change in the divided opinions of the people here as to the guilt or Innocence of the young woman who is accused of having brutally murdered her father and stepmother.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 27. -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of the American Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb will be held here tomorrow. The eighteenth biennial convention of the New-England Gallaudet Association will be held here next week. Four days will be devoted to the anniversary.

INFLUENZA. -- In Pasewalk, a small place in Pomerania, where there had previously not been a single case of grip, an officer arrived from Berlin gripped. The staff surgeon who attended on him, and his orderly, next fell ill. Then followed the wife and child of the surgeon, and a friend of theirs, who was generally with them.

From Good Words. We have read how the coffin of Mohammed was poised without support in the mosque of the faithful, from which all unbelievers were so rigidity excluded; no material support was necessary to sustain the remains of the prophet the body itself seemed ever on the point of following the departed spirit to the reaims of bliss A perennial miracle was indeed neceesary to sustain the revered sarcophagus in space.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The City of Boston is supposed to be phenomenally self-satisfied, but tills is by no means true. Relatively speaking, her merits may be considered superlative, but no city can harbor more restless aspirations for improving upon herself. She has righteous longings to make her crooked paths straight, and any plans tending to that end possess an immediate fascination to the Boston ear.

From Electricity, Aug. 24. From common experience we are apt to hold exaggerated notions of the power of gravity. Not until we compare it with other attractive forces, such as magnetism or electicity, do we appreciate how trivial it really is.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 27. -- It was learned, on the arrival of the steamship City of Dallas last night, that the revolution in Spanish Honduras is ended. Nothing is known of the whereabouts of Nuilla or Bonilla, the leaders of the revolutionists, but it is believed that they escaped and are now hiding in some other community. The natives are rejoicing over the news, and the soldiers, having been disbanded, are going to their homes.

The handful of politicians who are trying to steal the sum of $1,1200,000 from the taxpayers of Brooklyn, and give in exchange the bankrupt Long Island Water Supply Company, are getting into deeper water every day. Their great difficulty just now is to find men of such low moral standard as will sorve on the commission to condemn the property of this company.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The Gaiety Theatre closed on Saturday last and will not open again until October. When the theatre is reopened, "Cinder Ellen Up Too Late" will be again presented. Fred Leslie will return to his original role, but it is reported that he aspires to management and high comedy. It is likely, it is said, that he will retire from burlesque and leave his place to Arthur Roberts.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Harry E. Thompson of Main Street is at Newport.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- While the gay season is the Catskills will practically end in about ten days, yet should favorable weather continue many people will remain in the mountains until late in September, At many of the resorts the late bookings exceed those of any previous year.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In THE TIMES of the 24th inst. appears an article embodying, in part, Mr. John Bigelow's plan for the Tilden trust as amplified in Scribner's Magazine for September. I think it proper to correct a misapprehension into which Mr. Bigelow appears to have fallen in claiming that Mr. Tilden gave no encouragement to the project or a public library, which was contemplated a few months before his death.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 28 -- Since the war the State of Maine, with one brief exception, and that in Greenback days, has been one of the solid factors in the Republican organization. It has ever had the iron clutch of the Republican politicians upon it He who worked and voted for them has always found favor; he who differed from them was ostracized whenever it was possible.

A more beautiful exhibition of lacrosse playing is seldom given in this country than that soon at the Polo Grounds Saturday afternoon in the championship match between the New-York and Staten Island Athletic Clubs. The team work of both sides, and especially of the Staten Island players, was exceptionally good, and the Canadian players on the New-York Athletic Club's "twelve" exhibited some marvelous feats of dodging and shooting.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- Emperor William has had presented to him exhaustive reports on the progress of the cholera and the measures taken to combat it. He devotes several hours daily to studying the epidemic. He has ordered that vigorous measures be taken to insure the safety of the troops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- There is undoubtedly a Widespread feeling that immigration from countries where cholera is now raging ought to cease. Government officials who declare that the present quarantine regulations should result in Keeping the scourge out of the country acknowledge in the same breath that absolute prohibition would be the best possible means of Stopping the westward march of the disease.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The New's Paris correspondent says: "A lady called at the Mairie at Montmartre to register the death of her child from cholera. The persons in the office drew away in terror, when suddenly the lady fell to the floor writhing with pain. She was at once removed to the cholera barracks, where her husband had been taken on the previous day.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- Emperor William has had presented to him exhaustive reports on the progress of the cholera and the measures taken to combat it. He devotes several hours daily to studying the epidemic. He has ordered that vigorous measures be taken to insure the safety of the troops.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Preparations for the two Hundred and fiftieth anniversary of this jumping-off place had a tender interest for the class of outing rooters known as "old stagers" From vacation years beyond which man counteth not, Gloucester has been to "old stagers" a blessed haven. The flannel shirt had away hero generations before fashion hit upon that happy device for comfort.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The annual rifle meeting of the New-Jersey State Bide Association will take place here from Sept. 5 to 10 inclusive. The indications are that it will be the best rifle meeting ever held in this country. Five teams will enter the matches for the International and Hilton Trophies, which used to be held at Creedmoor. FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 28 -- It was a quiet Sunday in Full River, as far as new developments in the Lizzie Borden case were concerned, and the vicinity or the police station was one of the most quiet of the many particularly quiet sections.

The racing at Saratoga will be brought to a close this week, the stake events being the Albany Handicap, which is to be run this afternoon, the Grand Union Hotel Stakes, for two-year-olds, and the Merchants' Stakes, a handicap at a mile and a quarter, to be run on Wednesday, and the Spencer Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, to be ran on Saturday.
