AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 24 -- A ballot wholly in favor of one party-the Republican -- and non-secret is what the Maine voters will be obliged to case under the Australian ballot system.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Cadet Arnold A. Kester of Indiana died at the Cadet Hospital at West Point this morning. His death will cause a postponement of the furlough hop of the cadets, which was to be held in Grant Hall tonight. The affair will probably be abandoned altogether.

Don M. Dickinson, E.C. Wall, and B.T. Cable, the three members of the Democratic National Committee's Campaign Committee having the branch headquarters in Chicago in charge, will hold their first meeting in that city at 2 o'clock Thursday afternoon and begin the work of laying out a systematic plan upon which the business of the branch headquarters will be conducted.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- Once more a great surprise is recorded in the twelfth annual tennis tournament of the United States Rational Lawn Tennis Association. First it was Robert D. Wrenn of Harvard who distinguished himself, then "Ed" Hall of New-York jumped into prominence by his victory over Clarence Hobart, and to-night, when both of these players have met defeat, William A. Larned of Cornell stands forth as the hero of the hour.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 29 -- With a threatening storm holding off until nearly nightfall, the kiteshaped track was last to-day, and almost every heat winner in the four races on the programme scored a new record. In the five-thousand-dollar stake for 2:30 trotters, the New-York stallion Geneva, bred by Charles Baokman, started favorite at odds on, but John Goldsmith's California four-year-old Muta Wilkes beat him in straight heats, taking a now record in the first.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 29 -- The Republicans are preparing for a tin-plate rally at Elwood Sept. 13 to rejoice over the establishment of a small tin-plate factory in the natural-gas town of Elwood. The State Committee proposes to make it the largest meeting of the campaign and paid delegations will be taken from every county to witness the dipping of roofing tin by imported Welshmen.

FRESNO, Cal., Aug. 29 -- The bitter political fight between the Democratic factions in this county culminated this morning in the cold-blooded and dastardly assassination of Louis B. McWhirter, a prominent and reputable lawyer and politician.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 29 -- The sub-committee of the Republican State Committee having in charge the calling of Congressional Conventions in districts whose boundaries were changed by the reapportionment met at the Powers Hotel this morning, all the members being present except Chairman Brookfield.

The census bulletin on the woolen manufactures of the United States shows some interesting facts. The value at the factory of the goods manufactured is $338,231,109. The cost of manufacturing is classified in the bulletin as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 --The provision market attracted less attention than anything else on the floor, but the feeling was firm and closing prices were higher. The market received the support of such traders as Wright and the Cudahys, some of the packers, and Counselman Day. Offerings were small and the range of prices comparatively small. Cash pork was quoted at $10.60@$10.65.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The weather was clear and warm at the races to-day and the track dry. There was a good-sized crowd to see the five races run off. The Albany Handicap was won by Saunterer. It was not a good day for favorites.

WOLCOTT, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The terrible tragedy briefly reported in to-day's TIMES, and which occurred near Ira, continues to excite the horror of the people of this neighborhood. Young Foster was a favorite, and his murderer was a brutal fellow who had for years done threshing for a living. An eye witness who saw the awful deed in the barn told THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day the following story:

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 29 -- President Charles Noel of the Olympic Club to-day spoke his mind upon the absurd, stories of intorferences and disturbances at the ring side which had been going the rounds. Anybody who knows anything about the Olympic Club and its methods knows that there is no chance for any foul play or any interruption of the peace.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 29 -- Up to the last halt of the seventh inning the Louisvilles looked like winners to-day. After that however, the Brooklyns won with ease. They got in a streak of heavy batting and sent the curves of Clausen in all directions.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 29 -- The primary election for delegates to the Democratic Convention for the nomination of State and county officers, members of the Legislature, and Presidential Electors will take place to-morrow, and will be one of the most momentous in the history of the State, for the nomination practically amounts to an election.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Chairman Edward Murphy, Jr., of the Democratic State Committee made public to-day the following correspondence through the Troy Press, which explains itself:

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- If all the reports of deaths from Asiatic cholera are true, there is no doubt of Great Britain's having a visitation of the dreaded scourge. From Gravesend, Swansea, Glasgow, and Dundee, towns in England. Scotland, and Wales, reports come of death from the disease, showing that the efforts of the health officials to keep it out of the country have proved fruitless.

Nellie McCarthy, a single woman, forty-five years old, who lived at 1,642 Lexington Avenue, while attempting to cross Broadway at Great Jones Street at 5:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was Knocked down by the horses attached to Car No. 32 of the Broadway Line, and was crushed to death by the car.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 29 -- The Carnegie Steel Company resumed its legal action against the looked-out Homestead mill men this evening by having five of them arrested. The men were taken without trouble by Constables Farrell and Stewart and brought here, where they had an immediate hearing before Alderman McMasters, and all were released on bail.

HARTFORD, Aug. 29 -- Though the final meeting of the Grand Circuit, which began here last Tuesday, was stopped alter two days of lively sport because of rain, and the remaining five class events declared off, the Hartford Purse, for foals of 1889, had to be competed for, and this important event came off this afternoon. The tract was quite dry, and the weather, while uncertain, clear enough to warrant calling out the yonug trotters.

The Marquis DE MORES, who is now on trial in Paris for killing Capt. MAYER in a duel, is known to two disgusted continents as a gasconading swashbuckler. It may be because of the personal aversion that he has contrived to excite that he has been put upon trial for being the victor in a duel, although his own seconds and the seconds of his victim are included in the prosecution.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 29 -- A great crowd gathered at the exposition grounds to-day to witness the championship games of the Central Amateur Athletic Union. There were present and participating many prominent amateur athletes from clubs of this and other States, and a very interesting programme of events was given. The events ware as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- A group of Washington officials some time ago formed what is called the John Brown Fort Museum Company here for the purpose of exhibiting John Brown's old brick fort, which was moved from Harper's Ferry. The financiering or the project presents some unique features.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 30. -- The feature of the seventh day's harness racing at Rush Park was the performance of the three-year-old filly Kentucky Union in the 2:25 trotting race. After having won a live heat, race in the mud last week, the daughter of Aberdeen started against twelve aged trotters. She won the heat trotted last evening, hut it was thought that Mary Mac would land the postponed race to-day.

Mr. Whitelaw Raid has been gunning of late And has brought down his bird. It is a crow. It has been dressed and cooked with savory sauces, and to-day will be served on the party table at Ophir Farm. President Harrison will be there, and Thomas C. Platt, who has been exploited as the prodigal, is also expected to be there and partake of a large portion.

The gunboat Concord was made out coming through the haze that covered the East River at an early hour yesterday forenoon, and, steaming up to the navy yard, she made fast along-side the coal wharf, where she began at once to fill her bunkers.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Aug. 30 -- P.M. There was a considerable falling off in to-day's business, but prices were quite firm. Reading was the feature in point of activity, but New-England scored the greatest advance. St. Paul was the only other stock which was even fairly active and it closed at a fractional advance.
A full-sail easterly breeze made the first annual regatta of the Old Mill Yacht Club, held in Canarsie Bay yeateraay afternoon, a decided success.
BURLINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Two trains on the Camden and Amboy Branch of the United Railroad of New-Jersey crashed together at White Hill to-night, and three of the train hands were killed.

The complaint In the attachment proceedings against the Bullock Wilder Company, railroad contractors of 40 Wall Street, for $450,000 brought by Isaac and Leopold Seligman, who compose the firm of Selifraian Brothers of London, was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office. It says that on June 30, 1890, at Now-York City, Seligman Brothers agreed to lend the company u300,000, with interest at the rate of 10 per cent, per annum.

John L. Sullivan's training quarters, until his departure for New-Orleans, will be at Philip Casey'a, on Degraw Street, Brooklyn, where the handball and racquet court can be used. Up one flight and at the head of the stairs is a bright, cheerful room in which Sullivan sleeps, and adjoining it is another, occupied by lus trainer. His food is carefully prepared by Casey's sister.

The September number of the North American is divided, between English topics and the Homestead strike. Mr. H.W. Lucy, in "Electioneering Methods in England," explains the legislation which, within the memory of young men, has swept away a great part of the corruption that used to make English politics infamous.

Mr. CRIMMINES, as he was reported in yesterday's TIMES, talked very reasonably about the present condition and the prospects of surface transit in New-York. It is gratifying to note that he is by no means so fully committed to the scheme of introducing the trolley as he appeared to be when the question was first broached.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The Roma correspondent of the News says: "Sporadic cases of cholera have occurred la Naples, Venice, and Genoa. The patients have been isolated, and the public has not become alarmed. There has been improved sanitation is the various Italian towns since the epidemic of 1887, and it is hoped that this will have the effect of staying off the disease."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- Oliver S. Campoell of Brooklyn, the present holder of the singles tennis championship of the United States will tomorrow morning defend his title and trophy against Frederick H. Hovey of Harvard, Who, by his victory to-day over W.A. Lamed of Cornell in the finals of the All-Comers, has earned the right to challenge him for the national supremacy.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 30. -- The programme of the dedioatory ceremonies of the World's Fair has been completed. It is subject to approval by the Council or Administration, but it is not thought many changes will be made in the arrangements.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The attendance at the races to-day was remarkably large for the last week of the Saratoga meeting. The weather was all that could be desired and the track was fine. Favorites won in most of the events.

F.N. GISBOENE. F.N. Gisborne, who was largely instruments in the construction of the first Atlantic cable died yesterday in Ottawa, Ontario. It is doubtful if the cable would have been laid when it was, or that Cyrus W. Field would ever have had anything to do with the undertaking, had it not been for Mr. Gisborne.
Tammany has trouble on hand in the Board of Aldermen. Some of that body have taken It Into their Heads to object to the orders given thorn by their district leaders as to how they should vote.

G.C. Matthews, editor of the Appeal-Avalanche, Memphis, Tenn., at the Sturtevant House last night, speaking of the political outlook in his State, said: "This talk aoout a political revolution in the South, and about the Electoral votes of certain States there being in jeopardy, is simply the idle vaporings of calamity shriekers, who always abound when a close Presidential campaign is on.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- A serious riot occurred last night at Weissensee, a northern suburb of this city, where was located the encampment of a traveling show. Among the members of the troupe was a woman named Bruhn, who left Hamburg three months ago. Yesterday her son arrived from Hamburg, and the authorities, fearing that he would bring the cholera contagion to the camp, ordered him and his mother immediately to return to Hamburg.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Actual starvation now stares in the face the Hebrew settlers of Ziontown, who have been on a strike for over six weeks, unless substantial aid is soon obtained in some unforeseen way.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- From an advance copy of Truth, Mr. Labouchere's paper, the correspondence between Mr. Gladstone and Mr. Labouchere in regard to the latter's taking office in the new Ministry has been obtained. The correspondence is published in Truth, with the consent of Mr. Gladstone.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 30. -- The indications are that the most bitter politioal fight in South Carolina for many years was settled at the Democratic primary to-day. Contrary to expectations, the vote was exceedingly light. No difficulties are reported from any part of the State and it appears that the election was very quite.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The first suspicious case of disease in London was made public to-day. Ida Samyan, the four-year old daughter of a couple of Russian Jews who arrived here from Hamburg on Saturday, was admitted to the London Hospital on Sunday suffering with symptoms of Asiatic cholera. She died to-night, and a post-mortem examination showed that her death, was not due to cholera.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- If the United States possessed a National Board of Health, with absolute jurisdiction over the quarantine system of the country, or immigration from pestilence-stricken countries could he prohibited for two or three months, the Treasury and Marine Hospital Service officials would undoubtedly have lighter hearts than they carry to-day.

The stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House have been criticised often in their direction of the house, and if they rebuild it they will doubtless be criticised again. Nevertheless, it is to them that the great music-loving public and the friends of art and culture in general must turn with an earnest appeal for the restoration of our most influential place of amusement.

HAMBURG, Aug. 31. -- There is no questioning the fact that the present cholera epidemic is the worst that has ever visited this city, and every hour the situation becomes worse. The people are dying off like sheep, and the plague is spreading.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 31. -- An almost perfect Autumn day dawned upon the kite-shaped track to favor the race of Nancy Hanks against her record of 2:07 1/4. It was cool enough for overcoats, and a tracing northwest wind blew up the long home stretch. Aside from these slight drawbacks the conditions of the weather and track were as fine as ever favored a Queen of the tnrf in lowering the trotting record.

HAMBURG, Aug. 31. -- There is no questioning the fact that the present cholera epidemic is the worst that has ever visited this city, and every hour the situation becomes worse. The people are dying off like sheep, and the plague is spreading.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 31. -- The tournament of the Standard Keystone Target Company was continued here to-day, with an attendance far beyond expectations. In some of the events the entries ran over forty, shooters were present from all sections of Connecticut, and a very large contingent from New-Jersey and New-York is on hand.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 31. -- Unless released by his friends, Talt Hall, the border outlaw, will be hanged at Wise Court House Friday next. Gov. McKinney to-day refused to commute the doomed man's sentence to life imprisonment. This conclusion of the Executive has been communicated to Hall.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 31. -- Latonia track was a trifle lumpy and dusty to-day. About 8,500 people were present. Summaries:

President Harrison spent yesterday at Ophir Farm, the guest of Mr. Whitelaw Reid. The visit had been anticipated, and every preparation had been made to make it an event in the history of the campaign of 1892. Its social features were conducted in most elegant fashion.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31. -- The Connecticut State Board of Health will act without hesitation in adopting measures to prevent the cholera invasion. The circular prescribing rules and regulations, which is to be sent to the Health Board in every town in the State, will be issued by Dr. Lindsley, Secretary of the board, to-morrow morning. It will be a long document, occupying three newspaper columns.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 31. -- A party of gentlemen, supposed to be good judges of clever boxers, saw Skelly to-day spar with "Kid" Hogan. They expressed satisfaction at the showing he made and declared that Dixon would meet the Hardest game he has yet faced. When through with Hogan, by special request of his backer. "Billy" Reynolds, Skelly and Griffin sparred three rounds.

The Constitution of the State of Mississippi, which went into effect on the 1st of November, 1890, provides that on and after Jan. 1, 1892, in addition to other qualifications for the suffrage, every elector shall be "able to read any section of the Constitution of this State, or he shall be able to understand the same when read to him.

The scourge which has been alarming Europe has reached this port at last. Its advent was by no means unexpected, and the wonder is that it has been delayed so long. It reached here Tuesday night on board the Hamburg-American steamship Moravia, which vessel came into port with her passenger list or 280 persons depleted by 22 deaths during the voyage from Hamburg.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- Miss Leary gave the largest dinner party to-night ever given by one of the four hundred, either in this city or New-York. An immense ballroom was built out over the beautiful lawn, the interior decorations being superb. The walls were lined with red silk plush and hung with lace curtains and valuable tapestries.

NEWPORT, R.L., Aug. 31. -- Oliver S. Campbell of Brooklyn is happy to-night. For the third time he holds the tennis championship of America, and the great silver cup at last is his. This morning at the Newport Casino, before many thousand spectators, who filled every nook and corner of the clubhouses and grounds, he defeated Frederick H. Hovey of Harvard, the winner of the "All-Comers," by a score of 7-5, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5.

VIENNA, Aug. 31. -- A well-known physician of this city who is visiting Hamburg, has written to the Neue Frie Presse regarding the situation in that city. He says that the sanitary machinery of the municipality is in the greatest disorder. No preparations for a possible visit of the infection had been made, and now that the scource is sweeping the city everything has to be improvised.

A very important responsibility will be added to Mayor GRANT'S official duties to-day, when the Stein act, passed by the Legislature last Winter, goes into effect, and the power of licensing children to act in public on the stage will be vested in the Mayor. This is a new power, created by the Legislature, and not the mere transferring of an existing power, as seems to be a widespread notion.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 31. -- The physicians who have been watching the cases of the four Russian emigrants who were attacked yesterday with a suspicions sickness while waiting to go on board a steamer for the United States have officially declared that the disease from which they are suffering is true Asiatic cholera.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Prof. Jean Roemer, Vice President of the College of the City of New-York, was found dead in his room at the Curtis Hotel this morning. The discovery was made by his valet, who knocked at the door a little before 10 o'clock and found it locked.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 31. -- The physicians who have been watching the cases of the four Russian emigrants who were attacked yesterday with a suspicions sickness while waiting to go on board a steamer for the United States have officially declared that the disease from which they are suffering is true Asiatic cholera.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31. -- The Now-Yorks were considerably crippled to-day and put up a miserable game in the field. On this account they dropped their third consecutive game to the Pittsburgs. The score:

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31. -- The Connecticut State Board of Health will act without hesitation in adopting measures to prevent the cholera invasion. The circular prescribing rules and regulations, which is to be sent to the Health Board in every town in the State, will be issued by Dr. Lindsley, Secretary of the board, to-morrow morning. It will be a long document, occupying three newspaper columns.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- A finer day for light harness racing or better sport no one could desire than Point Breeze Bad this afternoon. Out of twelve beats trotted or paced records wore reduced in seven. Fascination dropping from 2:26 1/4 to 2:24 1/2. Rachel B. lowered her record three times, Saladin chipped off two seconds, and Queen Gothard got a new mark, with odds of 5 to 3 on him.

The Coney Island Jockey Club offers a very at tractive card at its trace to-day, three fixtures being on for decision. The track should be in prime condition, as it was rapidly drying out under the harrows yesterday, so that some rare good sport may be expected. The entries to the several races are as follow:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- This has been an uncomfortable day for the Government officials most interested in the work or waging war against cholera. They have been obliged to answer many questions relating to the pestilence, and the news they have received from New-York and foreign ports has been of a character to make them doubt whether the precautions already taken will produce the desired result.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- John and Lou Howard of San Francisco, who started from Seattle on March 10 last on a tramp for Chicago for a five-thouaand-dollar purse, have arrived bore having sixteen days to spare, their time limit ending Sept. 15. Both looked very dilapidated when they reached the city. Howard having lost forty pounds and his wife twenty-two and a half pounds.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- A light rain ten during the races to-day, bat the attendance was fair. There were no special features. Following are the summaries:

Mr. CURTIS occupied a place wholly his own, and quite apart, in the intellectual and political life of his country. He had all, or nearly all, the qualities to give him both eminence and prominence. Eminent he surely was, but not, in the usua sense of the word, prominent. His natural bent was to literature, and for this calling he was richly gifted.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 31. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Downingtown, Chester County, says: "Senator Quay is in the fight in this county to win instructions for his re-election, and he will succeed by a large majority. He is now more closely related to this county than ever before, as he has recently bought an ancestral estate in this section and is likely to make it his home.

The Republican National Committee issued a "bayonet" bulletin yesterday. It was a statement with reference to Southern/elections, Which was said by some to embody an attempt to manufacture sentiment favorable to the Force bill, and to be intended for a "feeler" on that issue. That it was issued the day following the conference between members of the committee and President Harrison, was said by Republicans to have no signifcance.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- There was an unusal degree of activity manifested at the Custom House this forenoon in consequence of the advent of the cholera. Every department which has to do with the arrival and departure of vessels was busy, but there was a degree of secretiveness shown when pointed questions were asked about what "the House" was doing on the cholera business.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1 -- The quarterly meeting of the Rhode Island Medical Society was held at the rooms of the Business Men's Association here to-day, with a very large attendance from all parts or the State. Dr. W.H. Palmer of Pro vidence presided. On motion of Dr. H.R. Storer the following resolutions were adopted, the first one being telegraphed at once to President Harrison.

The beginning of a test case which shall decide the relative authority of President Gerry of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and the theatrical managers employing children was observed, by the audience at the Broadway Theatre last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept 1 -- The factional fight among Onondaga Republicans has come to such a pass that any coming together of the clans means a pitched battle. All efforts on the part of the State Committee in the interest of harmony have proved futile.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 1 -- The fish tug E.M.B.A. arrived down to-night, having as a passenger Harry Stewart of Algonac, a wheelman, the only survivor from the great steel steamer Western Keservo, which foundered on Tuesday evening about 9 o'clock, sixty miles above White Fish Point, on the course to Keeweenaw.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 1 -- It is not often that a big card such as Point Breeze bad to-day is disposed of in heats. Only one favorite got the verdict, the other events going to a second choice and an outsider. Paul had a tough fight to dispose of Saladin in the deciding heat for the 2:16 pace, the black stallion losing a length by a break when near the wire.
Mayor Grant issued the following circular to the public late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Action has at last been taken by the Federal Government which will go far toward keeping cholera out of this country. All vessels hereafter arriving at United States ports with immigrants on board will be detained at quarantine at least twenty days, and longer if farther detention is thought best for the public good.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 1 -- The Louisvilles ran away from the crippled Giants to-day. Brown's all-around play and Bassett's and Jennings's fielding were features.

PLAINFIELD, N.J. Sept. 1 -- A large force of men are at work cleaning the streets and removing garbage. French's mills have boon inspected and the stagnant raceway in the business portion of the city has been cleaned.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1 -- The quarterly meeting of the Rhode Island Medical Society was held at the rooms of the Business Men's Association here to-day, with a very large attendance from all parts or the State. Dr. W.H. Palmer of Pro vidence presided. On motion of Dr. H.R. Storer the following resolutions were adopted, the first one being telegraphed at once to President Harrison.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 1 -- "Bob" Fitzsimmons, the middle weight, was in the city to-day to look after his suit with Carroll. Fitzsimmons has decided that Sullivan will win. Corbett, he said, is without doubt one of the cleverest men in the business and will keep away from Sullivan for a time, but Sullivan would get to him eventually, and science will not count for so much.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Sept. 1 -- Patrick Moran, a non-union heater, was assaulted and roobed early this morning, and his condition is such as to excite alarm. Moran staggered into the provost guard tent hatless, shoeless, and with his coat torn. His nose was broken, his eyes were blackened, and he was bleeding from several wounds on his head.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- It was a great day on the Stock Exchange, the like of which has not been Been since the Baring Brothers' failure. Everybody was nervous, oven the moat conservative, and just before the close the feeling approached dangerously near a panic.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 1 -- The two wings of the Republican Party met in separate conventions to-day. The Harrison faction, headed by Chairman Strother of the State Central Committee, comprised about one-third of the delegates. They nominated Presidential Electors, a Regent of the State University, adopted resolutions indorsing the Administration, and then adjourned for the day.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 1 -- The Board of Health at its meeting to-night decided to adopt stringent measures to prevent the introduction of cholera, and all vessels from foreign countries likely to be infected will be detained and disinfected. All steerage passengers from New-York will be subjected to critical examination.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Sept. 1 -- Sunol is now the third fastest trotter in the world. To-day her record of 2:08 1/4 was beaten by Martha Wilkes, the Boston mare that set the race record at 2:09 1/2 last week.

NEW-LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The third day's shoot at the keystone target tournament was a model one so far as the weather went, but the wind made the shooting rather difficult at times. Shooting on the scheduled events was delayed until nearly 11 o'clock this morning by sweepstake shooting, two events being shot to limber the sportsmen up before trying their skill in the regular events. The result of today's shooting was as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept., 1 -- The terrific northwester which swept down the chain of great lakes on Tuesday afternoon claimed for its prey one of the finest steel steamers that ply these inland seas, and the broken shell of the splendid Western Reserve is now at the bottom of Lake Superior. The details of the awful disaster are as yet meagre, and it is impossible to account for it satisfactorily.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 1 -- The fish tug E.M.B.A. arrived down to-night, having as a passenger Harry Stewart of Algonac, a wheelman, the only survivor from the great steel steamer Western Keservo, which foundered on Tuesday evening about 9 o'clock, sixty miles above White Fish Point, on the course to Keeweenaw.

STETTIN, Sept. 1 -- Hundreds of Russian Jews arrive here by sea from Memel or by rail from Eidtkuhnen. On their arrival here they are quarantined on an island under supervision of the medical authorities until the sailing of the steamers for America.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 1 -- With half the people in the court in tears and with the faces of the others white with nervous excitement. Lizzie Borden stood in the Second District Court room to-day and listened to her father's old friend as, in his judicial capacity, he adjudged her probably guilty of the brutal murder of her parents.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The Amenia Fair closed to-day. The receipts were larger than last year, and all the old officers were re-elected.

Hamburg authorities have not displayed new traits in their unwillingness, first, to admit the prevalence of an epidemic in their city, and second, when the fact that it was there could no longer be concealed to reveal how extensive its ravages were. That sort of thing is an old story with Hamburg. It is a business town, and the truth about epidemics is likely to hurt trade.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 1 -- City Health Officer Duffield says that it is almost certain that the Asiatic cholera will reach Detroit before next Spring. In an interview he said:

It would be premature, probably, to aver that the glory of Creedmoor has departed; but it is quite certain that, with the transfer of this year's annual matches of the National Rifle Association to Sea Girt, the famous parent range temporarily loses its old importance for all riflemen except those of the New-York National Guard.

JEAN ROEMER Jean Roemer, whose death was announced in yesterday's TIMES, was born in England about 1815. TaKen in infancy to Hanover, and afterward to Holland, his early education was conducted under the charge and supervision of private tutors provided by his guardians, William I., King of the Netherlands, and the Princess of Orange, Frederica Louisa Wilhelmina, the wife of Charles George Augustus, heir apparent of the crown of Brunswick.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 1 -- The Board of Health at its meeting to-night decided to adopt stringent measures to prevent the introduction of cholera, and all vessels from foreign countries likely to be infected will be detained and disinfected. All steerage passengers from New-York will be subjected to critical examination.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept 1 -- David Lynoh, William T. Roberts, H.W. Sarvey, William McConeghan, and Hugh O'Donnell were called up for a bearing before Alderman McMasters this afternoon, charged by Secretary Lovejoy of the Carnegie Company with conspiracy. Attorney Brennen raised the point that under the act of 1891 the defendants could not be convicted of conspiracy for acts done in the capacity of a labor organization.

PLAINFIELD, N.J. Sept. 1 -- A large force of men are at work cleaning the streets and removing garbage. French's mills have boon inspected and the stagnant raceway in the business portion of the city has been cleaned.

HAMBURG, Sept. 1 -- There has been a considerable change in the panicky feeling prevailing here in consequence of the ravages of cholera, and to-day more confidence is expressed in the ability of the physicians to cope with the disease.

While Gov. TILLMAN'S possession of the Democratic organization in South Carolina enabled him to carry the recent primaries in most of the counties, and therefore to control the coming State Convention, there is something encouraging for the future of the Democratic Party in that State in the strength displayed by the "conservatives."

The September number of the Century Magazine is distinctly given over to art and literature, with travel and adventure a good third. Mr. E.J. Clave advances with "Pioneer Pack, horses in Alaska," assisted by the draughtsmen Tabor, De Cost Smith, M. and J.A. Fraser, and II. D. Nichols, who have worked out the writer's sketches.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- There was an unusal degree of activity manifested at the Custom House this forenoon in consequence of the advent of the cholera. Every department which has to do with the arrival and departure of vessels was busy, but there was a degree of secretiveness shown when pointed questions were asked about what "the House" was doing on the cholera business.

The people of Verplanck's Point, about three miles from Peeksklll, Westchester County, are in a high state of excitement over an outrageous assault made Wednesday evening about 6 o'clock upon the ten-year-old daughter of Thomas Smith of that place. The child is now in a very precarious condition. This is the third similar occurrence in the vicinity within a month.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 1 -- At the reopening of the famous Andover case, at Andover this forenoon, Prof. Smythe's counsel argued for dismissal, because the case had once been decided, and by the Supreme Court, and that the decision was in Prof. Smythe's favor.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 1 -- The Alliance has won even a more sweeping victory in South Carolina than was supposed. The returns show that Brawley and Moise are the only anti-Alliance men elected. George D. Tillman will have to enter a second race, and if the full Alliance vote, which was somewhat scattered in the first primary.

STETTIN, Sept. 1 -- Hundreds of Russian Jews arrive here by sea from Memel or by rail from Eidtkuhnen. On their arrival here they are quarantined on an island under supervision of the medical authorities until the sailing of the steamers for America.
HEALTH DEPARTMENT, NEW-YORK, Aug. 30, 1892. PREVENTION OF CHOLERA EASIER THAN CURE. HOW CAUGHT.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 2. -- Secretary Tracy arrived here at 10 A.M. to-day aboard the Dolphin, the usual salute being fired from the training ship Richmond. He soon went ashore and was received on Coaster's Harbor Island by a guard ot apprentices, headed by the band, which played "Hall to the Chief " as the Secretary passed along the line.

From the Boston Commonwealth of To-day. Dr. Holmes has the pleasure of knowing what is thought of some of his work by the generations after that for which it was written. It is hard to think of a man still as young as he is, born seventeen years after Shelley. This generation is celebrating Shelley's centennial as if be belonged to the past.

"I do not see a single break now in the horizon. Everything is working together for Democratic success," said Congressman W. Bourke Cookran when he called at the Democratic National Headquarters yesterday afternoon in search of Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Sept, 2. -- President Clifford of the Chamber of Commerce called the first session of the International Reciprocity Convention to order yesterday and welcomed the visitors in a brief address.

Copyrighted, 1832 by the N. Y. Associated Press. LONDON, Sept. 2. -- President Harrison's circular relative to the quarantining of vessels cerrying immigrants finds general approval and even admiration here There is some feeling of envy also that the American law enables the Government to take such prompt and thorough steps to stop the importation of cholera.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 2. -- There will be a big "shake-up" in the management of the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Railroad within the next few days which will create a surprise in railroad circles. L.F. Day, who has been Traffic Manager of the Louisville. New-Orleans. and Texas Railroad, to-day assumed the position of Traffic Manager of the Newport News and Mississippi Valley.

BAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept, 2. -- John Dilke, a mining expert, arrived this afternoon from the much-hoasted Temescal tin mines. The gentleman has had ample opportunity to examine the property thoroughly and avers that the expose or the swindle that was recently made public is correct in every respect.

It is plain that Mr. GLADSTONE'S task is very far from easy and his position very far from enviable. The bulk of his supporters will no doubt acquiesce in any programme he is likely to frame, but there are two factions of them, each of which insists that its demands shall not only be complied with, but shall take precedence over the demands of the other.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 2. -- The telegraph operators who are in the city to form a new fraternal organization, that is called "The Brother-hood of Telegraphers," met this morning. There were only a few operators present, as most of those expected will not arrive until to-night. The morning was taken up mainly in an informal discussion.

The Southern Republican contingent is still pounding away upon the doors of the boodle vaults of the National Campaign Committee. Subtle orators from that section are pouring fairy stories by the yard into the ears of Chairman Carter and Treasurer Bliss.

The funeral of ex-Mayor James Millward of Yonters, Westchester County, took place yesterday morning from the First Presbyterian Church in that city, and was very largely attended. In accordance with the recommendation of the Common Council, business was almost entirely suspended during the time of the service and flags were displayed at half-mast all over the city and on the public buildings.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- Miss Mary E. Dissette, a sister or Capt T.D. Dissette of this city, and who for the past four years has been in charge of the mission school which the Presbyterian Board of Home Missions maintains an the pueblo of Zuni, in New-Mexico, is now visiting here. She tells many very interesting details of the work of attempting to civilize these Indians.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 2. -- Never in the history of Texas as a State has the condition of political affairs been as badly mixed as at present; and not since the famous Houston-Runnels contest for Governor in 1859, when "old Sam" ran against and defeated the Democratic nominee, has there been so much bitterness injected into a campaign.

We hardly know whether Mr. HARRISON fully understands the service he has rendered to the cause of decent politics in the State of New-York, and in the Union, by his abatement of that most uncommon nuisance, Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT. It cannot, unfortunately, be said that the abatement is complete and absolute, but it is at least perceptible and valuable.
LONDON, Sept. 3. -- The Berlin correspondent of the News says:

It was thirty years ago to a day, yesterday, that the Sixth New-York Heavy Artillery mustered at Yonkers, Westchester County, to await orders to go to the battlefield. Its ranks were then fall and a lustier set of men could not be found.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 2. -- Two games were played here to-day. In the first King pitched in good form and won his first victory of the second series. Boyle caught him in good shape and the boys all played good ball. Ewing's leg was too sore, and McMahon was placed at first. The New-Yorks hit Sanders hard and often.
L.H. Manning of Arizona is at the Astor House.

Gen. Luis Bogran, ex-President of the Republic of Honduras, who was reported to have been killed in the revolution about two months ago, arrived in New-York last night from San Francisco. Gen. Bogran left Amapala on July 15 to travel for his health. He is now at the Hotel Imperial, and intends to remain in this city about two months.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 2. -- Betting was very light to-day on the three fights, spectators evidently deciding to wait fur the arrival of the pugilists. The largest bets are being stolen in on Skelly. One bet of $100 against $300 was made yesterday on the Brooklyn amateur. A couple at hundred dollars was also bet on McAuliffe. About $300 went in on the combination of Sullivan, Dixon, and Myer.

In pursuance of a call sent out yesterday by Mayor Boody of Brooklyn to the beads of city departments to confer with him as to the test methods to be adopted to Keep the cholera out of the city. Police Commissioner Hayden and Health Commissioner Griffin met with him in his office in the City Hall yesterday. City Works Commissioner Adams absented himself from the city.
The following is a copy of a letter which was last evening sent by Dr. Donovan, house surgeon of Gouyerneur Hospital, to the Board of Health:

Henry B. Herts, the Columbia student whoso design for the Columbus arch at Fifty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue was successful in a competition which included over fifty arohitects, spent some time at the office of the Committee of One Hundred, yesterday afternoon. In conversation with a reporter he said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The President, having disposed of the task of issuing a Treasury circular ordering a twenty-day quarantine of immigrants -- a task, by the way, that Secretary of the Treasury Foster could have performed without Presidential assistance -- left the capital this evening for Loon Lake.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 2 -- The Western Headquarters of the National Democratic Campaign Committee will be in charge of B.T. Cable, National Committeeman from Illinois. This has been definitely settled by the committee, and Mr. Cable formally took possession of the headquarters to-day. The Secretary for the Western Headquarters has not yet been selected.

LONDON, Sept 2. -- Serious labor disturbances, arising from the employment of non-union watermen to replace the strikers at the Salt Union Works near Northwich, a town seventeen and one-half miles from Cheater, have been occurring during the last few days.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 2. -- Taltoa Hall, the Kentucky desperado, was banged at Wise Court Bouse, Va., shortly after noon to-day. For weeks past, grave apprehensions have been felt that an attempt at rescue by his friends would be made, and the jail has been guarded by fifty or more men for some time past, but no such attempt was made.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- One of the most noisome nuisances in Newark is the Morris Canal. It is a sluggish stream, which those residing along its banks turn into a sewer stealthily whenever occasion demands and opportunity offers. The menace of cholera has admonished the local authorities that the nuisance should be abated, and the Health Board has ordered the Lehiph Valley Railroad Company to Hush it.

CINCINNATI, Sept 2. -- The Sullivan special arrived hero to-night. There was a large crowd at the station anxious to catch a glimpse of the Boston "slugger," but they went away disappointed. Sullivan did not leave the train to go to the restaurant, but had his supper brought to the car. He has not left the car since it started from Weekawken last night.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept 2. -- It is now apparent that somebody has been using the machinery of the Democratic Party to break it up and then fly the third party banner. J.H. Bowden, manager of the Cotton Plant, the officiair ogan of the State Alliance, said, in an interview this evening:

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The cholerine epidemic shows a slight increase. At the Hotel Dien to-day eleven new oases were received and two deaths occurred, while the hospital at St. Antoine reports six new cases and three deaths.

WELLS, Me., Sept. 2. -- Somebody is engaged in An attempt to persuade the farmers of this neighborhood that the McKinley tariff is doing crest things for them; he is sending out to all the Postmasters copies of a little book called, "The Farmers' New Poor Richard Almanao for 1892," in which, the indispensableness of "protection" to men who live by the soil is told in a variety of ways.

Mayor Patritk J. Gleason of Long Island City has already taken steps for the prevention of cholera in his bailiwick. Yesterday morning he employed the fire horses and carts and a large force or men to carry disinfectants from house to house. He also appointed Patrick J. Hunt Deputy Sanitary Inspector at Large in charge of the disinfecting corps.

To the Editor of the New York Times: A. "Yankee Cook," in taking exceptions to Bishop Williams's recipe in rhyme for corn cake, proposes in its pixce what might more properly be called a recipe for wheat cake, since it is composed of two-thirds wheat flour and one-third cornmeal "Yankee Cook" has evidently never eaten "pone " as it was made in the South by the cooks of the olden time.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The cholerine epidemic shows a slight increase. At the Hotel Dien to-day eleven new oases were received and two deaths occurred, while the hospital at St. Antoine reports six new cases and three deaths.

WELLS, Me., Sept. 2. -- Somebody is engaged in An attempt to persuade the farmers of this neighborhood that the McKinley tariff is doing crest things for them; he is sending out to all the Postmasters copies of a little book called, "The Farmers' New Poor Richard Almanao for 1892," in which, the indispensableness of "protection" to men who live by the soil is told in a variety of ways.

Poor fishing has been the word mostly, during the west, from the resorts where anglers are accustomed to seek for the game fish. At the celebrated old fishing ground, Barnegat, the game report is made, and at places of lesser repate little has been done. Usually at this time in the season there is a spurt of good fishing, and the fishermen have hopes of success.

Chief Naval Constructor Alexander Diederich of Germany, who is on a flying official tour of inspection of the principal shipyards of the United States, yesterday completed a two days' detailed observation of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He was the guest of Commodore Erben and the Captain of the yard, and was given every facility for observing the work on the new battle ship and on the other war vessels constructed and under course of construction.

CORSICA. -- The history of Corsica and its steady social retrogression since it has become a Department of France is an interesting study for the upholder of a republican form of government. It is just 100 years since Paoli, the liberator of his countrymen from their Genoese oppressors, was welcomed in Paris as the Washington of Europe and was invited by the National Assembly to take supreme command of the new Department of France.

From the London Daily News. A keen struggle has been commenced here between the brewers and the Socialists. It appears that the Socialists had boycotted the Warmbecker Brewery. The masters have consequently combined and have dismissed all the union workmen, to the number of 1,200, until the boycott is removed.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the N.Y. Associated Press. BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- The public alarm occasioned by the cholera is fast dying out, owing to the limitation of the disease in an epidemic form to the Hamburg district, and the confidence that is felt in the vigilance of the authorities. Cool weather and abundant rainstorms are keeping down diseases simulating cholera, and all influences are restoring a general sense of security.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 3. -- The annual carriage parade of the Summer cottagers at Seabright and Rumson is now an established social event, and every season it is looked forward to anxiously by old and young alike. The parade ends the social period along the shore, and it also marks the close of the Summer season.

INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Sept. 3. -- There was a light attendance at the closing day of the great fortnight meeting. The few in attendance were breeders and owners. The two events billed were won in straight heats. The first race was between the Kentucky and California horses, and as California has been walking away with a large portion of the money held up this meeting, general rejoicing was had when Silicon carried off the five-thousand-dollar stake.

Correspondance Garden and Forest. I am advised by friends to out down a huge pound sweet apple tree, which stands among the shade trees on my lawn, but in my judgment none of the rare and beautiful trees which are called ornamentals surpass this one when in flower, with its exquisite shades of white and red.
The Central Railroad or New-Jersey offers superior attractions to the home-seeker who desires a home in the suburbs with the greatest advantage for rapid transit to and from NewYork.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 3. -- Marshal William McChesney of the Orange Police Department has instituted a novel feature in the working of the police system of this city which bids fair to prove a success and be worthy of emuistion.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 3. -- A marked revival in rowing was shown this afternoon at the fifteenth annual regatta of the crack Bayonne Rowing and Athletic Association on New-York Bay. Only club members could compete, but there was plenty of material and good boats. Three hundred people, including many ladies, took an interest in the events. Nearly all started and finished in front of the boathouse.

NEW-HAVEN,' Sept. 3. -- Despite the fact that Connecticut is regarded this year as a pivotal state, the campaign thus far has been dull, so far as the surface indications may be accepted. The Republicans hope to enliven it on their nide next week, when Gov. McKinley will attend the State Convention of the party in this city.

Carl Richter, a Swiss tailor, thirty-four years old, who was arrested on Friday night, charged with having criminally assaulted his sixteenyear-old stepdaughter, Clara Kuba, hanged himself early yesterday morning in a cell at the East Fifty-first Street Police Station. Richter was a woman's tailor, and kept a shop at 76 West Fitty-fifth Street, and lived in rooms in the rear of the shop with his wife and her daughter.

Senator Carlisle of Kentucky reached this city yesterday from Buzzard's Bay. where he had been the guest of Ex-President Cleveland at Gray Gables. Soon after his arrival at the Fifth Avenue Hotel he went down to the Democratic Headquarters at 139 Fifth Avenue and spent some time in conversation with Chairman Harrity or the National Committee, Bradley B. Smalley, Chairman of the Committee on Speakers, and Simon P. Sheerin, Secretary of the National Committee.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Sept. 3 -- P.M. The cholera scare has exhausted itself if the course of the stock market means anything. To-day, with two additional steamships with the disease on board at Quarantine, prices advanced almost from the opening until the close.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 3. -- Two thousand persons witnessed the races and athletic sports on the new Groton Driving Park at PoquonnocK this afternoon. In the 2:40 class there were three starters. Stoneridge, See H. See, and Daudy. Stoneridge won in three straight heats. Time -- 2:41; 2:40; 2:39; Dandy second, See H. See third.

Greatly to the surprise of the average American inventor of small-arm mechanism, the board of army experts, appointed for the selection of a new weapon for rearming the infantry regiments of the army, decided upon adopting a weapon of foreign design rather than a child of their own creation. For the last two years -- ever since the board has been in session -- it has not been at all unusual to hear inventors say.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- During the early stages of the Borden case, and before Miss Lizzie Borden had been actually arrested, although then practically charged with the crime, a letter of sympathy was sent her by Mrs. Mary A. Livermore, to whom the Borden family has long been well known.

WASHINGTON, Sept 3. -- Official and public interest in the cholera was manifested to day in about an equal discussion of Dr. Jenkins and the arrival of the Rugia and Normannia at NewYork, with new cases of the dreaded disease. As the most active officer. Assistant Secretary Spaulding may be most properly quoted in his remarks concerning Dr. Jenkins. He said:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- In an address here to-day President Harriaon spoke of the reason for his hurried visit to Washington, the threatened coming of cholera, and said that he could not quite accept that view of constitutional law, which he had seen in some quarters, that the power to "repel invasion" extended to the invasion of plague and pestilence.

From the Manchetter (N.H.) Mirror and Farmer. New-Hampshire has played the fool's part in disposing of the magnificent stretches of forest, which but a few years ago clothed and beautified her northern mountains and valleys, and were the unfailing reservoirs for her streams, the haunts of her fish and game and the sanitariums to which people came from far and near for rest, recreation, and recuperation.

Since the dread of an impending evil is usually more acutely painful than battling with it, it is not surprising that the stock market had a sudden drop when it was announced that the cholera had come into port. The way prices fell on Thursday, after the official announcements in respect to the Moravia, has been too fully described in the papers to need repetition here.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 3. -- "Billy" Myer reached hero at 11:50 last night from Chicago accompanied by his backer, "Alf" Kennedy, his seconds and bottle holder, "Eddie" Myer, Frank Hoxie, and John Eckhart, in a special coach containing about twenty men prominent in Chicago sporting circles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3. -- The time has arrived for the quadrennial discussion of the question whether it is possible for the Democracy to pick up any Electoral votes on the Pacific coast. The discussion this year appears to have been exclusively local, for there have been no indications of the faintest expectation on the part of Eastern Democrats of breaking, or even straining, the Republican lines in this part of the country.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 3. -- The Grampus, which came here as part of the anniversary flotilla, reports hopeful prospects for the cruise ordered by Fish Commissioner McDonald in search of the habitat of the tile fish. This news is of interest here because, if profitable fishing grounds near home can be definitely established, Gloucester boats will swarm there no other port having the fleet or equipment to compete with trips from Gloucester.

Condensed from All the Year Round. The best clarets are grown in the district called the Medoe, which is divided into the Haut Medoc and the Bas Medoc, and again subdivided into localities such as Pauillac, Margaux, St. Julien, and St. Estephe. These names are applied to the growths of the respective localities -- and to a good deal besides.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- With the beginning of this week dated the opening of the regular dramatic season of 1892-3. There is every prospect of a highly interesting as well as profitable year. It seems rather early for the season's opening, but managers believe that there will not be much profit during the political campaign, and that it is beat to "make hay while the sun shines."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- About 3,500 people witnessed the seven races ran at Latonia to-day. The track was good, but not fast. In every one of the events there were two nearly even favorites. Prime choice horses won in three races and second choices won in the others except the seventh, in which Viola Ea, a 20 to 1 nag, took the purse. There were very few winnings on place horses.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- The first class ordered to the gray stone building on Coasters' Harbor Island, officially Known as the War College, will report for duty Tuesday to Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, who has been ordered as President of the college. The officers number about a score, and their names have already appeared in THE TIMES.
In the lines that follows a mere sketch of Caleb Cushing as he appeared to the writer toward the close of a life full of triumphs, not unmixed with defeats, is all that is intended.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Sept. 3. -- The first Fall guests are mingling with those of the Summer, and the Water Gap is in one of the gayest conditions of its experience. The Fall season is evidently destined to be a notable one, and the hotel people are preparing for a continuous rush.

If the appearance of the real estate auction rooms were to be taken as an index of the market, the situation in respect to activity in dealings in this class of property would be far from encouraging. There has been no sale of importance lately in strictly city property, and such as was offered excited but feeble interest among the buyers who went to the auction room to witness its sale.

The new millinery goods show a decided partiality for the illuminated coloring, the iridescent dragonfly tints. Quills, wings, and aigrettes are in all variations of this coloring. While there is scarcely the high carnival of feathers that was held last Autumn, yet it is evident that much ingenuity has been devoted to their arrangement.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 3. -- The forty-six-footera Harpoon, Gloriana, and Barbara had a rattling race off this port to-day in a fresh southerly breeze and a bit of a sea, and the Harpoon won from the Gloriana by 4 minutes 6 seconds corrected time. The Barbara was a close third. The race was the Autumn one of the Eastern Yacht Club, and was a successful close to a most successful season.

A correspondent of the Tribune, writing from Danbury, Conn., and speaking of the condition of the hat trade in that city and other places in the United States, gave a glowing account of the "prosperity of Danbury, saved from ruin by the McKinley act." He talked about increased wages and the fresh impetus which had been given to every branch of the business by this great measure of Republican wisdom.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Sept. 3. -- A week of perfect days has served to keep departing visitors for longer periods and to attract a regiment of new ones. Pocono's September delightfulness has been noised abroad in previous seasons and the result is apparent in this.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 3. -- The Common Council last night decided, in view of the threatening advent of the cholera, to appropriate $12,000 to the Board of Health for the construction of a disinfecting station for the care of infectious or contagious diseases, and $8,000 for the equipment of the station, and authorized the City Controller to issue temporary loan bonds to meet the expenditure.

-- About 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire originated in the four-story brick building 46 Decatur Street. New-Orleans, owned by Mrs. Lonis Moller and occupied by the New-Orieans Auction and Commission Company as an office, by Messrs. Cuccio Mocen, steamship agents and importers, and the upper floors by Max Fraenkel, tailor. The building was partially destroyed.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 3. -- The details of Secretary Hester's New-Orleans Cotton Exchange report on the cotton crop for the year 1892 were completed to-day. It covers not only the details of the cotton crop movement, but takes up the question of acreage as put forth by the United States census for 1889-90, and the acreage of each year since according to reports of the United States Agricultural Department.

Flora (Ill.) Letter to the St. Louis Globs-Democrat. Some years ago it occurred to a few restless pirits in Southern Illinois that opulence might be found in apple orchards, and they began to experiment. Most people were incredulous. Everybody knew that "Egypt" would grow good apples, but few supposed it possessed peculiar advantages for that industry.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 3. -- An illustration of the ignorance and superstition of the peasantry of certain parts of Hungary is given to-day in a dispatch from Neusatz, a town on the Danube. The dispatch states that a patient suffering with a choleraic disorder died at Kiszach, a village a short distance from Neusatz, and the authorities desired that a post-mortem examination be held to determine whether or not death had been caused by Asiatic cholera.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Mrs. L.B. Paig left her home in Binghamton yesterday morning, came to Newburg, went to the Riverside Hotel, and registered under the name of Mrs. R.M. Starr of Elmira, and was shown to a room. Soon afterward a man came to the hotel, and, on saying he was the woman's husband, was shown to her room.
Judge George T. Werts of the Hudson County Circuit put an end yesterday to the use of his name in connection with the Gubernatorial nomination by making the following letter public:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The first run of the Fall season of the Ballston Hunt Club took place this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The start was made at Dunning Street, the place where, fifty years ago, the State militia met on general training day. The course lay north, circling to the east, then north and west to the finish at Collamer's farm, a distance of five miles.

The naphtha launch race of the Horse shoe Harb or Club of Larchmont took place yesterday. The race was over a course nine miles in length. The launch Kraken, belonging to Harry Van Liew, was the first to reach the stakeboat in 1:15:10. Mr. Irwin C. Case's launch Susie finished second. There were thirty launches entered in the contest, and the prizes were solid silver cups.

From Garden and Forest. The foe of natural grace and beauty is the Road Commissioner, whoso mistaken zeal is allowed annually to remove the grass which seeks to soften the dusty outline of the road along its untrodden borders and gutters. This is an expensive process and wholly unnecessary, since adding to the dust capacity of the street is the only service it accomplishes, the short, thick turf affording no obstruction to carriage wheels.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Andrew B. Humphrey, Secretary of the National Republican League, and Col. McAlpin, President of the State League, arrived here to-day and gave out the programme for the National League Convention to be held on Sept. 15 and 16.

YANKTON, S.D., Sept. 3. -- The desire on the part of the Democratic leaders or South Dakota, Judge Bartlett Tripp, who was Chief Justice of the Territory under Mr. Cleveland; Otto Peemiller of the State Central Committee; W.R. Steel of Deadwood, and others to bring about a fusion with the Independents upon the Electoral part of the Independent ticket was entertained, so that South Dakota's Electoral vote might go to Weaver and not to Harrison.

As stated in a previous article in THE TIMES, the old hulk of a coal barge, with pork barrels for a smoke stack, having run the blockade of Vicksburg without being sunk, although shot through, showed the Mississippi Navy that certainly iron-clad gunboats and transports protected by coal barges on each side and cotton bales on the decks to save the machinery and boilers could also run around the point.

From Blackwood's Magazine. The influence of the provision trade on the development of the countries of production does not concern us directly, but in considering the subject as a whole some allusion must be made to it. The preparation of food for exportation has been a source of prosperity wherever it has been able to establish itself, but among the many regions that have made money by it the United States have profited the most.

Republicans in Brooklyn who realize the futility of prolonging the fight against the manner in which the local Board of Supervisors apportioned the Assembly districts of the city are ready to call it a "draw" and shide by Justice Bartlett's decision that the said apportionment is legal.

From Fraser's Magazine. Mix boiled hog's lard and milk with thick gruel. Stir it well together with fresh cheese, yolks of eggs, and brains. Wrap it in fragrant figleaf and boil in the gravy of a chicken or a kid. When taken out, remove the leaf and souse it in a potful of boiling honey.

Judging from the preparations made by the officers of the Central Labor Union for the Labor Day parade to-morrow the demonstration promises to be a good one, as fully 10,000 men are expected to be in line. The various unions will be divided into four divisions, which will assemble in the cross streets along Fourth Avenue from Astor Place to Thirteenth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- J.C. Stubbs, Traffic Manager of the Southern Pacific, arrived here to-day. He declined to be interviewed on any of the troubles that have recently shaken the Transcontinental Association to its foundation. Later several transcontinental railway officials, including Mr. Stubbs, had an informal conference, in which the condition of the Pacific coast railroads was discussed.

In what consists the crowning excellence of our Monte Generoso? In its position, rising more than 5,000 feet sheer out of the Italian plains? From the Hotel Pasta terrace you look down upon those plains, sometimes through a torn curtain of soft cloud, and they seem like a sea, the brown towns and villages and the little hills looking like waves.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 3. -- The Carvallis petition of the Oregon Pacific Railroad Company for an extension of time to complete the purchase and pay money under the foreclosure sale was presented yesterday, but on the application of the plaintiff, the Farmer's Loan and Trust Company, the Judge adjourned the hearing until Sept. 14, with power for the petitioners to complete the purchase at any time up to and including that day.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- Mayor Matthews came down from Jefferson, N.H., post haste to direct the Board of Health and the heads of departments in dealing with the threatening cholera. From 9 o'clock until noon to-day he was busy at the City Hall in consultation. Among those who were summoned to his office this morning were Police Commissioner Whiting, Superintendent of Streets Carter.

Perhaps no one is better qualified than Prof. WILLIAM JAMES for the task to which he has addressed himself in an article in the Forum, which is to give an account of what up to this time has been accomplished by psychical research. His article is largely occupied with an account of the Society for Psychical Research and its proceedings.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, Sept. 3. -- The last month of Summer has slipped away, and Autumn finds thousands of people at these resorts enjoying the pleasures of the river and admiring the scenery.

A pretty and quiet wedding occurred yesterday at the little church at Pelham Manor, adjoining Bolton Priory. The bride was Ethel Huyck, daughter of the late Leonard Huyck, the Washington banker. The bridegroom was the Hon. Reginald Pelham-Bolton. The church and priory are ivy-covered English-looking buildings on the road to the Country Club.

CHARLESTON, Sept 3. -- A careful estimate given to THE TIMES'S correspondent by prominent merchants of Charleston of the number of blockade runners engaged during the last war in running between British and Confederate ports shows that between the years 1861 and 1865 there were no less than 250 vessels employed from first to last in this service.

BUFFALO, Sept 3. -- The people of this city are thoroughly aroused on the question of the cholera, and the precautions that have been and are to be taken exceed any previous sanitary measures within the last half century or the city's history. The popular interest awakened in relation to the Asiatic cholera far exceeds in intensity the excitement caused by the recent railroad strike here.

Three transatlantic steamships arrived in this port yesterday from cholera-stricken Hamburg. They formed the advance guard of the many steamships now on their way here from European cities in which cholera is raging. They were sent down the bay to anchor off Swinburne Island with the plague ship Moravia, which first brought the cholera to the city's gates.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- The season is fully at its height and is being made the most of, not only by society, known as the Four Hundred, but by that class of well-to-do people who are now thronging Newport hotels and private boarding houses.

MERIDIAN, Miss., sept. 3. -- There were several stoppages of the Sullivan special during the afternoon travel southward from Birmingham. After one of these stoppings of the train, there was a rumor that the last halt had been occasioned by the discovery of a log on the rails. Instantly active minds construed the rumor into a story of an attempt to wreck the Sullivan train.

From "Thompson's Tombstone." We dined in a little Parisian restaurant where Americans are in the habit of going to obtain those truly French delicacies, pork and beans, buckwheat cakes, corned beef, apple pie, and oysters. I knew a man from Chicago who dined at this restaurant every day during the entire month spent by him in Paris, and who, at the end of that time, said that he was heartily sick of French cookery.
John Good, the rope manufacturer, referring to the recent labor troubles which have attracted so great a share of public attention, said to a TIMES reporter yesterday:

From Chambers's Journal. As exemplifying the pitch to which Roman epicureanism was carried, and indicative of a truly barbaric nature, a dish consisting of the tongues alone of some thousands of the favorite songsters of the air was requisitioned at immense cost to satisfy the inordinate cravings of one of the Emperors.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 3. -- The "Sullivan Special," with the champion, his trainers, friends, and backers is on its way to the fighting ground, and will roach the scene of the battle to-morrow morning in time for breakfasts. It was expected that New-Orleans would see the New-York sporting men to-night, but there were some unlooked-for delays, and in consequence the train is about twelve hours behind schedule time.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3. -- Allan W. Paige of Huntington will be the temporary and Congressman Charles A. Russell of Killingly, the permanent Chairman of the Republican State Convention, which will be held in New-Haven, Wednesday, Sept. 7. The delegate roll has been completed, the list embracing a larger proportion than has been known to be the case in years past of members of the Legislature.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 3. -- The Clothing Cutters' Union were given a place in the Labor Day parade by Grand Marshal Beckmeyer, who is also a prominent Knight of Labor. The union has notified the Essex Trade Council, who are managing the demonstration, that they will parade as guests of the clothing salesmen, but object to the leadership of a Knight of Labor, and will not recognize him officially.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- Arrangements are being perfected for what should be a brilliant and interesting social event at the dedication of the World's Fair buildings. A grand reception will be tendered to the President of the United States, the Vice President, ex-Presidents, Justices of the Supreme Court, Ministers of foreign Governments, the Governors of all the States and Territories, Senators and Representatives in Congress, and other distinguished guests on the evening of Oct. 19.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- There was little change in the condition controlling the action of the provision market. The bull combine gave a little more action to January staff that had been neglected, and a firmer feeling at once developed. There was not a great deal of product for sale for the earlier deliveries, and the changes shown for the day were slight. Pork held within a twenty-cent range.

From the Garden, London. The species of willows are numerous, and much confusion exists in their classification. There are however, only about six species, with their numerous varieties, that are of any commercial value or worth cultivating with a view to profit. Three of those species are essentially basket willows.

MAY'S LANDING, N. J., Sept. 3. -- Four prisoners, three of whom were held for the September term of court next week on serious charges, escaped from the county prison here last night, and have not yet been caught, although a posse of Deputy Sheriffs is scouring the country in every direction in search of them. Their description has been telegraphed to all points.

WASHINGTON, Sept 3. -- The War Department has received the report of an inspection of the New-York National Guard encampment held at Peekskill, N.Y., from June 18 to Aug. 5. The inspection was made by First Lieut. J.T. French, Jr., Fourth Artillery.
GREENOCK, Sept. 3. -- The people of this city and vicinity were startied this morning by a deafening roar that was subsequently ascertained to have been caused by a powder explosion.

Next to the championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, at which the amateur athletes of America strive annually for national honors at track and field athletics, those given by the various associations of the union possess the greatest interest. In these contests people are enabled to see what the athletes of their own locality can do among themselves and what men are the most eligible to represent the local clubs at the national championships.

From the Saturday Review. South Africa may sometimes be nearly as hot as India, but there the hunter, though a sybarite by temperment, must be a Spartan by training, and almost necessarily he must be in tiptop condition. He does his severe exorcise in the saddle or on his own shoe leather; he cuts his communications with the camping place for the day, and knows nothing of soda water or sandwiches.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The race meeting closed here to-day with bright weather, a fast track, and good attendance. Under the new management it has been most successful. Badge won the stake event of the day, the Spencer Handicap, running a mile and a quarter in 2:07, the best record made for that distance on the track here.

Gustav Guillot, a Frenchman, is lodged in Jefferson Market Prison, under suspicion that he is a clever and experienced, but heretofore untrapped, stateroom thief. Complaints of robbery have frequently been made by passengers on ocean steamships, the money having usually been missed just before sailing. Steamship men set an extra watch for thieves, and officers of the steamboat squad were detailed to the ocean piers.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- No theatrical event of the year in Boston is more certain to draw an audience that includes the fashion and intelligence of the city than the opening of a season at the Boston Museum. This evening, when the fiftysecond season began at this house, the rule held good. Aside from purely local notabilities one box was occupied by John B. Schoeffel and Mrs. Agnes Booth-Schoeffel.
The two Staten Island clubs played a tie game yesterday. After eleven innings darkness ended the contest. The score:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Corbett was advertised in the morning papers here to appear at Albaugh's Opera House this evening in a sparring exhibition with his trainer. Although strongly protesting against it, he was finally prevailed upon to make his appearance upon the stage. He was dressed in an evening suit and bowed his acknowledgments for the applause with which he was received.

From the St. Louis Globe-Democrat. In warm weather, if there is any dish which will tempt a wavering appetite it is certainly a well-made, prettily-decorated, ice-cold salad. It requires art to make a good salad. Perhaps genius is necessary to the preparation of a perfect one. Sidney Smith prided himself upon the excellence of his salads and wrote a rhymed recipe for the mayonnaise.

From the Saturday Review. South Africa may sometimes be nearly as hot as India, but there the hunter, though a sybarite by temperment, must be a Spartan by training, and almost necessarily he must be in tiptop condition. He does his severe exorcise in the saddle or on his own shoe leather; he cuts his communications with the camping place for the day, and knows nothing of soda water or sandwiches.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3. -- The annual county fair has come off rather earlier this year than usual. So many of the Summer travelers having returned home, and the weather having been very good, each day Timonium has been thronged, not only by the country people who own the fine horses, useful cows, and well-fed pigs, but also by those who hardly know any of the domestic animals by sight.

BAR HARBOR, Sept 3. -- Scarcely a day goes by that there is not a report of some new robbery, but when one goes to investigate it proves unfounded. From those that have actually occurred there are no new developments. Several Pinkerton guards are here. Everybody believes the robbers are still lurking about here, quite at largo, yet no clue that could warrant an arrest has been found.

In a recent paper on "Education in the Treatment of Nervous Girls," the author urged the value of cultivating a love of good books. "First should come the nursery classics, 'Mother Goose,' 'Cinderella, 'Prince Fortunatus,' , to be followed later by Gwimm, Hans Andersen, 'Alice in Wonderland,' Howard Pyle's 'Wonder Clock,' and others equally fascinating.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 3. -- Some years ago when Gen. Mahone's bolting readjuster party had thrown off all disguise and fallen bodily into the lap of the Republicans, the late Senator Riddleberger, at that time one of Mahone's moat trusted lieutenants, exultantly exclaimed: "At last we have a party in Virginia that is 'all wool and a yard wide.' "

TIEN-TSIN, China, July 20. -- Two years ago, when the Peiho River overflowed its banks, inundating the surrounding country, completely flooding and partly washing away this among many other large cities, causing the loss of thousands of lives and millions of dollars of property, large sums of money and other necessaries were raised by foreign subscriptions and sent to China to alleviate the sufferings of the unfortunate Chinese.
