Three men called at the Coroner's office in the Brooklyn Court House yesterday at noon and requested permission to remove the body of the murdered man Lazarus Eisenstadt, whose body was found on Monday in a clump of bushes on Fort Hamilton Avenue, just outside of Brooklyn, in the town of New-Utrecht.

CONCORD, N. H. Sept. 8. -- The Democratic State Convention, which met in this city to-day, was the largest political gathering of the kind ever held in the State and also one of the most earnest and enthusiastic.
The Hamburg-American Packet Company appears to have added misrepresentation and falsehood to the other offenses of which it has been guilty in connection with the outbreak of cholera.

GENOA, Sept. 9 -- The United States steamer Newark arrived here several days ago to take part in the Columbus fetes here. Among her crew was a sailor named Frank Reilly. He was a liberty man yesterday, and in the course of his journeyings about the city he visited a lodging house last night and was killed.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The fight for the delegates to the Democratic Convention was made here this afternoon, and it resulted in Quartermaster Gen. Donnelly securing a majority of delegates. His opponent is Gen. G. D. W. Vroom, President of the Trenton Board of Public Works. Gen. Donnelly is himself a candidate, but Gen. Vroom is in the contest in the interest of E. F. C. Young of Hudson County.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9. -- The international Commission of the State Boards of Health, in conjunction with the Congressional Investigating Board, left here on the 11 P. M. train for Halifax, where they will inspect the quarantine.

The rumor that several paper bag manufacturers were trying to form a trust was denied yesterday by H.J. Howlett, the New-York agent for the firm of E.J. Hewlett Son of Philadelphia, one of the firms said to be interested in the movement.

The Democratic workers from all sections of the State who were in the city yesterday made calls at the National and State Headquarters and all gave gratifying accounts of the condi tion of the work in their respective localities John F. Carlisle of Watertown, which is in Gov. Flower's county, said:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 9 -- Corbett boxed with Daly, his sparring partner and trainer, at O'Brien's Opera House, this city, to-night. The house has seating accommodations for 1,8OO people. Even standing room could not be had, and an angry mob of disappointed men struggled with each other outside. The champion was received with tumuitnous applanse. Corbett and Daly boxed three tame rounds.

AMESBURY, Mass., Sept. 9 -- The arrangements for the funeral of the late John G. Whittier have been completed. The body was conveyed to this town from Hampton Falls this morning and taken to the poet's former home, on Friend Street. The body will lie in state between the hours of 12 and 2 to-morrow afternoon, that the public may have an opportunity to view all that remains of the honored dead.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday to tender to the authorities co-operation in all matters relating to quarantine, and especially to emphasize the importance of the prompt removal of all passengers from the cholera-stricken ships. The attendance was representative of the business interests of the city and overflowed the main meeting room.

The meeting of the stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday took no decisive action, but there is no reason to doubt that they will take decisive action, nor what that action will be. They have all found that they have assumed public responsibilities by the mere fact of taking stock in an operahouse.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The Argus of Thursday printed this item: "United States Senator David B. Hill, accompanied by Gen. and Mrs. Farnsworth, passed through Greenbush yesterday to enjoy a carriage ride in the country east of the village."

Horace A. Taylor. United States Commissioner of Railroads, who has just returned from a trip across the continent, was at headquarters yesterday. He submitted a report on the political situation and of course, the bulletin for publication showed Republican prospects as bright as the sunshine in every State from California eastward.

At 1:3O o'clock this morning Health Officer Jenkins reported that there had been thirty-two deaths from cholera on the steamship Scandia of the Hamburg-American Packet Company, which reached lower Quarantine about 8 o'clock last night.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Republican primaries in this city and throughout Union County to-night, so far as heard from, resulted in the selection of a solid delegation for John Kean, Jr., for Governor. An attempt was made here early in the week to put a ticket in the field in some wards that would, if elected, support Gen. Grubb's candidacy, out the scheme came to nothing.

CHICAGO, III., Sept. 9 -- By a vote of 8 to 2 the associated cycling clubs of this city have decided not to admit the Chicago colored cycling club to the privileges of the association. It means virtually that they are opposed to the admission of colored cyclists to the League of American Wheelmen.

Tammany nailed its battle flag to the mast last night, threw its opening broadside square nto the Republican camp, and sent out a message to the Democratic hosts in every State that its fighting campaign was open and that it would be found in the thick of battle until the standard of Cleveland and Stevenson floated in triumph on election night.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 9. -- It begins to look as if the Grosse Isle quarantine system was a farce, if not worse. Passengers who have been quarantined and afterward released tell strange stories of the way things are conducted and the manner in which they were treated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Acting Secretary Spaulding has informed the War Department that the action of Col O. M. Poe, engineer officer at Detroit, in requiring certificates from the customs officers showing compliance with the regulations relative to the tolls on vessels passing through St. Mary's Falls Canal, meets with the full approval of the Treasury Department.

E.V. Skinner, General Eastern Agent of the Canadian Pacific, announced yesterday that his road had reconsidered its decision to apply as low rates on domestic goods as those charged on imported traffic. According to the notice given by the Canadian Pacific these rates were to go into effect to-day, and a general disorganization of business was expected.

Save only for the new cases brought by the Scandia, the reports from the lower bay published this morning are very encouraging. There were no deaths and no new cases of the dreaded disease yesterday among those immigrants who entered the harbor on board those infected ships to which public attention has been especially directed.

DURANGO, Mexico, Sept. 9 -- Another crime was committed Wednesday on the train which leads through the Sierra Madre Mountains. Celas Martes, the agent of the State Bank of this city, was on his way to Mazatlan with $10,000 in gold coin, which was to be transported to Guaymas, in the State of Sonora. The gold was being transported in baogs on the backs of burros.

An interesting and impressive ceremony took place yesterday afternoon from 4 to 6 o'clock at the new synagogue. Shaarai Berocho, in Fiftieth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues. The occasion was the dedication of the new temple by the congregation, which was organized thirty-four years ago by the Frenchspeaking natives of Alsace of the Hebrew faith.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The North Star was photographed this evening through the largest lenses ever made for photographing stars. The work was done in the garden surrounding the telescope works of Alvan J. Clark at the foot of Brookline Street, Cambridge, and the results are awaited by astronomers with the greatest curiosity.

GENOA, Sept. 9 -- King Humbert and Queen Margherita, accompanied by the royal party that came with them to this city, among whom are the Ministers of State, visited the Columbus Exhibition to-day. A large crowd was present in and about the exhibition building, and the King and Queen received an ovation.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- The Evening Times of this city published on Wednesday an article from its special correspondent at Hornellsville, in which a good, deal of light is shed upon the career of Charles F. Peck, State Commissioner of Labor Statistics, whose recent report has been so widely discredited. Hornellsville is Peck's old home, and the tale which his former neighbors have to tell is by no means creditable to him.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Sept. 9 -- P. M. The stock market was much less active to-day, but the tone was fairly firm. The features o the day were New-England, Reading, Sugar St. Paul, and Whisky. The mystery surround ing New-England was still unsolved, but the stock scored a very material advance. Whisky crossed 50 and closed at a gain of 3/4.

MlDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 9 -- Capt. Gordon of the Wesleyan football team came back to this city from Newport to-day. He spoke in the highest terms of the work of "Billy" Bull, who has been giving the Wesleyan players a week of apecial training. The reat of the team will come here on Monday. Capt. Gordon thinks that with Bull's coaching the Wealeyan eleven will make an excellent record this year.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- The Latonia track was very fast to-day, and good time, as a rule, was made. The attendance was good, and the sport throughout was interesting. In the fifth race, Porter's first mount, Pearl N., fell in the stretch, but neither horse nor Jockey was hurt. Favorites won half the races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- One of the novel and attractive features of the approaching Grand Army encampment upon which little stress has been laid will be the exercises on Monday, the 19th inst. in connection with the dedication of the vast ellipse known as the White Lot to the use of the Grand Army Corps.

Chamberlain pitched a good game against the New-Yorks yesterday. In one inning, however, they managed to bunch their hits and secure enough runs to win. It was the fourth. At that point they took kindly to the curves of the Cincinnati pitcher and sent five men around the bases.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Monmouth County Democratic primaries to elect delegates to the State Convention at Trenton on Wednesday, Sept. 14, will be held in all the townships to-morrow. It is thought that the factional fights that characterized the Democratic primaries last Spring will not be repeated to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Sept 9 -- The provisions did better to-day in the matter of price, though there was not much business. The firmness came more from the lack of offerings than from the big demand. The combination took care of all the ribs that came out, and lard and pork were bought by scalpers and some of the packers. There was quite an active shipping demand, with moderate receipts of product.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. Sept. 9 -- There was great speed at the Driving Park to-day. The tract was in good condition and the time in all the events was very fast. In the free-for-all trot Evangeline created a sensation by winning the last two heats and race. She went the last mile in 2:11 3/4, beating the world's race record on a regulation track. Records were lowered in all the classes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The Great Northern has made a cut of 12 1/2 cents per 100 pounds on canned goods, wines, borax, and beans from San Francisco to the Atlantic seaboard. This is in direct violation of the traffic agreement and scarcely one-third of the period necessary to release the company from the Transcontinental Association has expired since President Hill gave formal notice of withdrawal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The hotels are beginning to fill up with Odd Fellows from all over the country, who are on their way to Portland, Oregon, to attend the sixty-fifth annual gathering of the order beginning Sept. 19. Grand Secretary Charles M. Busby of Raleigh, N.C., reached Chicago to-day and was met by Lieut. Gen. John C. Underwood, commander of the military forces of the order.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- The Trades League of Philadelphia, in conjunction with the Quaker City Association of Railroad Men, is making extensive preparations for the accommodation and entertainment of the 700 members of the ticket sellers' convention who will hold the annual meeting in this city during the next two weeks.

GDTHRIE, Oklahoma, Sept. 9 -- The 1:10 south-bound passenger train on the Santa Fe was late in arriving, owing to the fact that It was held up by train robbers at Wharton, in the Cherokee Strip, a station twenty miles north of this city. The robbers had their horses hitched near the station, and after attempting to rob the train remained for some time.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- It was learned to-night that Senator Hill had accepted an invitation to formally open the Democratic State campaign in Brooklyn the latter part of next week. He is now at work on his speech in his rooms at the Delavan House.

Ex-President Cleveland left this city via the Fall River Line at 5:3O yesterday afternoon, having concluded the business that brought him here. He was unaccompanied on the return trip except by his stenographer, Mr. O'Brien. He left the Victoria Hotel at 4:30 in a closed carriage with ex-Secretary Whitney, who went down to the pier to see him off.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9. -- Chauncey I. Filley has not been placated, notwithstanding the reports to that effect given out by Major William Warner and his campaign managers. There is reason to believe that Mr. Filley led Mr. Warner and Chairman Bathwell to think that he was willing to be placated, but he did it only that he might have fun with them.
John B. Riley of Plattsburg, the Chief Inspector of the State Civil Service Commission, was in the city yesterday. To a TIMES reporter he said:
ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Gov. Flower returned to the city this afternoon unexpectedly. His motive was to do what lay in his power for the imprisoned well people on the infected steamers in quarantine.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- In the Supreme Court, Chambers, in this city this morning, Judge Martin granted an order appointing the Binghamton Trust Company State Receiver to take charge of the Iron Hall funds.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9 -- The arrest of ex-Assemblyman Frank M. McDermitt at the primaries here last night on a charge of having attempted to bribe election officers to stuff their ballot boxes in his Interest promises to develop into a first-class sensation.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Sept. 9. -- The Democrats in Vermont are jubilant over the results of the State election, while the Republicans are trying hard to break the force of the blow they have received by persistent lying. They started Wednesday with a claim of 23,OOO majority but the figures have kept falling until now they admit that It Is not over 19,00O.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Official reports show that the cholera has been absolutely stamped out of the United Kingdom. The Local Government Board officers, the authorities at the chief ports, and the greatest populous centres concur in the statement that no cases of real cholera, but only a few choleraic cases, have occurred. Experts say that, though the disease was brought to England at a dozen different points.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9 -- The railroads claim to have had a great deal to do with the success of the recent fistic event, and all of them were kept busy handling the crowd which gathered from all over the country. None of them have as yet compiled exact figures, but from the number of trains and other signs they are highly pleased with the result.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The trotting meeting which ended to-day has been the most successful in the history of the track. Three new-comers in the 2:8O list, a new track race record at both gaits, and a faster exhibition record, together with a good balance in the hands of the Treasurer, are among the results.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9 -- When, in urging his plea for the nomination of Judge Worts for the Governorship in spite of Judge Worts's declination, Mr. James Smith, Jr. called attention in this morning's TIMES to what he considers the paralel case of Joel Parker's nomination several years ago after repeated declinations, he failed to lay bare the circumstances that destroy the paralel," said a conspicuous Democratic leader to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9 -- When, in urging his plea for the nomination of Judge Worts for the Governorship in spite of Judge Worts's declination, Mr. James Smith, Jr. called attention in this morning's TIMES to what he considers the paralel case of Joel Parker's nomination several years ago after repeated declinations, he failed to lay bare the circumstances that destroy the paralel," said a conspicuous Democratic leader to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- The two rival bodies claiming to be the legal Ohio Conference of the Evangelical Association, are in session here. The majority, or Esher adherents, having secured possession of the church in this city, are holding their sessions therein. Bishop S.C. Breyfogel of Reading, Penn., is presiding at the latter conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- The committee of employes of the Reading Railroad, representing the engineers, firemen, conductors, brakemen, and telegraph operators, called on President McLeod at the Fourth Street office of the company to-day. The committee numbered twenty-four men, headed by Engineer Clapp, who is an employe of the Jersey Central Road.
ROME, Sept. 9. -- The Italie announces the resignation of Mr. Albert G. Porter, the United States Minister to Italy.

CAMP ABBETT, SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 9 -- The teams from New-York, Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, and the District of Columbia, who commenced at 9:30 this morning to shoot for the possession of the Inter-State and Hilton Trophies, did so under very fair conditions. The wind was blowing steadily at a moderate pace, straight up the range, and the light was good.

From Goldthwaite's Geographical Magazins. It would be untrue to say that we do not know how to make roads in the United States. We do, but we are careful rarely to put our knowledge into practice. The magnificent pavement of Broadway -- not made for a driveway, but for commercial traffic -- shows what the road engineer can accomplish when not hampered by political pulls.

There has been a large number of State politicians at the Democratic National Headquarters at 139 Fifth Avenue this week. Among those who called yesterday was ex-Congressman John M. Wiley of Buffalo. He thinks everything is in flrst-rate condition for the Democracy. He has been traveling in the West recently, and knows much, too, about the situation in this State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Admiral Walker was instructed this afternoon by Secretary Tracy to sail in his flagship Chicago at daylight tomorrow morning for La Guayra, Venezuela, to look after American interests in that country.

As cholera talk seems to be in order, an incident related the other day on a hotel piazza by a venerable woman emphasizes the great advance made in the knowledge of the disease and the value of quarantine measures during the last fifty years over previous centuries of time. "In the visitation of "41" she said. "I was living with an aunt in Brooton, near Buffalo.
Westervelt pitched a strong game of ball against the nine of the Englewood Field Club yesterday. On the other hand, the New-Jersey boys hit Brown's pitching hard at times. The score:

QUENTIN MATSYS. -- Germany in the fifteenth century produced much wroughtiron work of a rather special character, such as the grave crosses and sepulchral monuments to be seen in the cemeteries of Nuremberg. Iron was also employed for well canopies, such as that at Antwerp attributed to Quentin Matsys.

From a Paper by Prof. F.M. Neff. To-day we and in France three distinct classes of roads -- national highways, department highways, and vicinal or county highways. The third class is again divided into three classes, according as the roads are a means of communication between several large communes, join small ones only, or a part of those belonging to a single commune.

AYNNE, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Essex Yacht Club of Newark, whose headquarters are on the Bayonne shore of Newark Bay, held its fifth annual open regatta this afternoon, thirteen boats competing. They sailed twice around a ten-mile triangular course on Newark Bay. Both water and wind were favorable.
To the Editor or the New York Times: AS an American citizen of German birth I beg leave to offer you these lines for publication in your valuable newspaper.

HOW COLUMBUS WAS WRECKED. -- Guacanagari was eager to see more of the Spaniards, and sent numbers of his light-hearted people to welcome them and bring them gifts of every sort. Their enthusiasm was unbounded, their generosity unstinted. The land was gay with festivities, the sea swarmed with canoes.

NEW-YORK, Sept. 10 -- 4, P.M. No cases of cholera have appeared in the city. The number of deaths during the week ending at noon to-day was 731. For the corresponding week last year the number was 747. The deaths from diarrheal diseases (92) were less than in any corresponding week since 1870. although the population of the city has nearly doubled since that year.

LENOX, Sept. 1O -- The season is now fairly open and a great many well-known people are here, having come up this week. There have been a number of entertainments and the first assembly is taking place this evening in the assembly rooms. Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes has opened her house and gave a dance on Friday night, at which about sixty people were present, mostly of the young dancing set.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The opening of the new Trafalgar Square Theatre occurred to-night. A full description of this new London place of amusement has already been given in this series of cable letters. "The Wedding Eve," an adaptation of the French comic opera "La Veillee des Noces," was produced for the first time in England.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- I forget how many new and wonderful plays are promised to Parisians this Winter, but the inviting list is unusually long. It is safe to add that not one-half could possibly be produced, even with the certain failure of one-quarter; and as the managers cleverly choose, accordiug to time, opportunity, and nenecessity, it is wise for the critic to follow suit and await events.

DANVERS, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Whittier memorial exercises were held in the Town Hall this afternoon. There was a large attendance. Addresses were made by A. P. White and the Rev. W. H. Trickey. Whittier's poems were read and the schoolchildren took part with songs and exercises. Appropriate resolutions were adopted. The bells of the town were tolled during the exercises.

In an analysis of the political events that have taken place in this city and elsewhere during the week just passed neither Chairman Carter of the Republican National Committee nor Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Committee's Executive Committee can find anything to be joyful over. In fact, they see in these events much to occasion fear and apprehension, much to destroy the delusive dreams of a week ago.
Robert B. Maclay, Assistant Principal of Grammar School No. 75, in Norfolk Street, died on Friday at his home, 168 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, of nervous prostration and gastritis.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Pateraon'a Cricket Club eleven was beaten here this afternoon by the New-Jersey Athletic Club's first eleven, the score being 67 to 51. This was the last game in the first section of the Metropolitan District Cricket League. Second place is obtained by the New-Jersey Athletic Club, the staten Island Cricket Club being third. The Berleys won the first prize.

The old steamer Caroline Miller of blookaderunning notoriety has turned up with a new name, South Portland, and lies at anchor off Ellis Island with a Custom House officer on board. She is detained under suspicion of attempted violation of the neutrality law. On board of her are 1,391,000 cartridges, 2OO,OOO caps, 4,000 muskets, 90 rifles, 5 Gatling guns and a carriage.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A few years ago, while living in a Long Island cottage, I discovered my writing desk was inhabited by a colony of large black ants. This discovery gave me great pleasure at the time, for I was dull and headachy from overwork, and was thankful for any amusing or interesting diversion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- A strike on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad in consequence of the determined attitude of opposition to labor organizations seems now to be inevitable. The committee of employes who held an unsuccessful conference with President McLeod yesterday are still in the city at the St. Charles Hotel. That is, all the members of it except the representatives of the brakemen, who have gone home.

From the Davenport (Iowa) Democrat. An important meeting for Iowa was the Road Improvement Convention held at Des Moines. It was called to take action in a direction in which all Iowa is materially interested. If it accomplishes anything, it will accomplish a great deal toward making this a better and more valuable state.

RESPECT FOR WOMEN. -- It is a question that depends a good deal upon the point of view, whether consideration for women in public places be not vanishing as a characteristic of American men. There are those who insist that it is not, but I fear that their point of view is not that of the passenger in the conveyances or on the streets of our large cities.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The Southern Central Railroad Company to-day filed a bill in equity here against the Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia and Reading, and Pennsylvania and New-York Canal and Railroad Company.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A telegram has been received here from the Liverpool office of the Guion Line stating that, in consequence of President Harrison's circular relative to the quarantining of emigrants, that company has stopped the booking of all emigrants on its vessels. The telegram adds that no emigrants will be taken after the sailing of the steamer Nevada, on Wednesday next.

There is a similarity in the sporting tastes of the two principal candidates for Presidency, though Mr. Cleveland likes fishing better than shooting, whereas President Harrison prefers shooting to fishing. The latter is happiest when he is down on the Chesapeake, blazing away at canvasback ducks late In the Fall, and there is no doubt that his successes with the shotgun afford him Keener delight than he experiences from political affairs.

CLIMATE AND MOVEMENT. -- The most important physical factor in determining lines of movement has, however, been cli mate. Speaking broadly, migration follows the parallels of latitude, or, more precisely, the lines of equal mean temperature, and not so much, I think, of mean annual heat as of mean winter heat.

Richard Mansfield's boldness in coming before this public in this hour of the triumph on the local stage of the purely "serpentins" and "Ta-ra-ra" varieties of theatrical art, with a wholly serious play, is litttle short of heroic. Whatever the result of his venture with a dramatization of "The Scarlet Letter" may be, it will certainly command the thoughtful respect of intelligent persons.

HACKNEYED QUOTATIONS. -- Ardently, but in vain, do you wish that every rose you see might indeed be "the last rose of Summer," so weary are you of hearing them declare it. Make a remark about a name, and they are panting to put the question, "What's in a name?" with an air of conscious and original wit.

From Good Roads. Our wagon roads throughout the country are generally a disgrace to civilization, and before we undertake to supply Jaeger underwear and sealskin covered Bibles with flexible backs to the African it might be well to put a few dollars into the relief of gailed and broken-down horses that have lost their health on our miserable highways.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 10. -- The attendance at the Latonia races to-day was about 3,000. The track was fast and good time was made. It was bookmakers' day. Favorites lost in every race.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me to appeal through the columns of your excellent paper to the generous public, especially to that portion most in sympathy with the woes and tribulations which attend the "heads of families." By "heads of families" I mean the women, of course. Men may call themselves by that name, if it pleases them, but we women know better.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Marine Hospital Service has notified the officers at the Delaware Breakwater Quarantine station that the steamer Lock Etive, from Germany, with a cargo of rags, will not be admitted at any port in the United States.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- The dramatic novelties for the present week are the two plays that had their first presentations in America last Saturday night -- "Agatha" at the Boston Museum and "The New Wing" at the Columbia Theatre. Each has been distinctly successful and each undoubtedly has started upon a long run.

MACARONIC LATIN. -- Certain Latin phrases of the style known as Macaronic have had some circulation of late, as "I sabilli haeres ago, fortibus es in aro." This stands for, "I say, Billy! Here's ago, forty buses in a row."

ANTWERP, Sept 10 -- The Bed Star Line steamer Westornland, Capt. Jamison, which sailed hence to-day for New-York, had 21O cabin passengers on board. According, to the decision of the company to refuse passage to immigrants during the present prevalence of cholera in Europe, no steerage passengers were booked for this trip.

The fifth supplementary practice was held at Creedmoor yesterday. The weather was fair, but cloudy at times, with a very light 5 o'clock wind blowing in the forenoon, which shifted to 7 o'clock in the afternoon.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 10 -- Returns have been received from 238 towns out of a total of 243. These towns give Fuller, (Rep.,) for Governor, 38,842; Smalley, (Dem.,) 19,400; scattering, 1,635; Fuller's plurality, 19,442; Fuller's majority, 17,807.

The annual session of the National Guard Association of the State of New-York is appointed to convene at the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment in the forenoon of Tuesday next. President William J. Harding, Colonel and Assistant Inspector General, is then to read an address which is expected to contain a wealth of suggestions in respect to the best methods of administering the affairs of the National Guard.

Despite the demoralizing effect of the cholera scare on the public mind, the stock market the past week was generally strong. If this strength be attributed to the closing out of a large short interest, and much of it undoubtedly was due to that, it yet remains that there must have been a comparative scarcity of floating stock in the market available for covering.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Alfred Mueller, son of a well-known Newark physician, was jailed to-day on charges of forgery and obtaining money under false pretenses. Mueller has been following the races, and the sure tips he got proved to be delusive.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 10. -- Montgomery H. Lewis, late Auditor, and H. W. Lee Russell, late Treasurer of the local office of the Lombard Investment Company, which had offices in this city, in New-York, Chicago, Philadelphia, and London, are in the City of Mexico with more than $100,000 of the company's money.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Sept. 10 -- P.M. The stocK market was very dull and prices were irregular. Reading and Sugar were the only stocks in which more than 10,000 shares were traded. The former declined 7 8 and the latter gained 3 8. The general list was only fractionally chanced.

The real estate market begins to show signs of life after its quiet Summer. The number of sales is not yet very large, but every one seems to be busy and sanguine. It seems already certain that, beginning with the latter part of this month, there will be a rush of business both at the auction rooms and through brokers' offices, which will continue unless all signs fail, until the Columbus celebration.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Ring methods were never more forcibly exhibited than in the circumstances attending the arrest of Frank M. McDermitt, the loudest of the anti-ring men in this county, at the primary at which he sought election as a delegate to the Democratic State Convention the other night, and its sequel.

WIDOWS FOR SALE. -- Of all the matrimonial trafficking -- in the age of chivalry -- the ways of widows ate at once the boldest and most comprehensive. As a rule their methods seldom resort to blandishment; it is remarkable when tenderness is an item in their bargain. Speed was their maxim; it was one King John honored, for he profited by it.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The one hundred and fifteenth anniversary of the organization of the Government of the State of New-York was celebrated on the grounds of the old Senate House here this evening under the auspices of the Daughters of the American Revolution.Mayor Kennedy presided. A brass band was present, and the exercises were patriotic and interesting to a high degree.

LIVERPOOL. Sept. 10 -- Mr. Thomas Sherman, the United States Consul here, was asked to-day about the liability of the steamship companies who refuse to carry the steerage passengers who have engaged their passage and now find themselves unable to proceed in consequence of President Harrison's circular regarding the quarantining of emigrant vessels.

It was officially announced yesterday for the second or third time that the President would not be placed on exhibition at the opening of the campaign in this city. The Madison Square demonstration will have to be carried on without the President's assistance.

From the Buffalo Times. New-Jersey has just cause to feel proud of the advance that she has made in roadmaking. The experiments made eight or ten years ago in Essex County proved so successful that an extension of the system was desired, and three years ago, under the celebrated New-Jersey road law, Union County took up the work and laid the famous Union County roads that are now considered models of roadmaklng.

CHIVALRY AND MATRIMONY. -- With all its fine expressions of ardent devotion to the fair sex, and the multitude of its exquisite pretensions, chivalry was the degradation of the highest and tenderest human instincts, the veritable curse of the course of true love. Such a statement presents itself to the romantic believer as a terrible counterblast; but it is true nevertheless.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Secretary Balch of the State Board of Health to-night sent out 1,400 copies of the following circular for the general guidance of the health officers in this State, in addition to the precautions published in his previous circulars:

CAMP ABBETT, SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The second annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Rule Association, which opened on Monday, came to a close this afternoon at 3:30. From start to finish the shoot was an unqualified success, and the attendance was excellent. The shooting in all the matches was of a high order.

Many of the delegates who are to sit in the two New-Jersey State Conventions -- the Republican Convention of Tuesday and the Democratic Convention of Wednesday -- were elected Thursday and Friday night. The Hudson County delegates to the Democratic Convention were chosen Friday night, and there is no doubt that Edward F.C. Young has the vast majority of them -- they are practically a unit for him.

MOUNT POCONO. Penn., Sept. 1O -- The first days of September at Pocono have been most delightful and the signs portend an entire Fall of the same sort. The hotels have been giving a series of very lively evenings, and there are plenty of people here to enjoy them. Arrivals of the last few days include the following:
Bradley B. Smalley, who was the Democratic candidate for Governor of Vermont, received many letters congratulatory and explanatory yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 10 -- At the Dracut grounds of the Lowell Cricket and Athletic Association, the Irish Gentlemen scored the first victory of their cricket tour in this country, defeating an all-NewEngland team by five wickets. The score on Friday night left New-England 86 runs behind, with one wicket to fall, the Irishmen having played a first innings of 156.

Early in the morning of Aug. 21 the schooner Elmira and Ruby of Bath, Me., two days out from Casco Bay, reached a point about fifteen miles south of Seguin Light, where the skipper ordered all hands aloft to look for swordfish. That finny Ishmaelite, having breakfasted on small fry which he is careful to carve in advance with his "sword."

WATERTOWN. N.Y., Sept. 1O -- The dead-look in the Twenty-second District Republican Convention was broken this morning by the nomination of Charles A. Chickering of Lewis County on the seventy-second ballot.

Liebig Zweig, the proprietors of the eggoil factory that used to stoken the residents of that section of Brooklyn which borders on Newtown Creek, make strange off oils of the Brooklyn Health department. Their charges also include the Queens County health authorities. No names are mentioned and no proof can be produced, yet the firm declare that they have paid blackmail to officials, and, moreover, are willing to make affidavit to it.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 10. -- At the bicycle races at Franklin Park, Saughus, this afternoon, G. F. Taylor of the Manhattan Athletic Club was king. He won every race he was entered in, beating out the fast cracks -- Windle, Berlo, Tyler, and McDuffle. Zimmerman, the cycle wonder, was expected to race, but at the last minute he sent word that he would not be present.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 1O -- Now that the nominations on the Republican State ticket have been made, the campaign in this part of the State has opened in earnest. The nomination of Stiles Judson, Jr., of this city for Secretary of State will make the struggle all the more interesting, inasmuch as the Democrats will again nominate John J. Phelan of this city.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- That the twenty-one-foot class has been the most interesting one in Eastern waters is beyond question and in spite of the small size of the boats there has been a most widespread desire among yachtsmen to know the result of each race and to see which boat would win the class championship. There has also been no little eagerness to see how the various types represented would compare with one another.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 -- The famous stallion Nelson, owned by C.H. Nelson of Watarville, Me., will arrive in this city next Tuesday, where he will be put in quarters at Hampden Park.
"Whenever there is a race to be run at a long distance I always play a horse that is sired by Longfellow, because Longfellow means endurance, you know, and I almost always win money that way."

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- All that was mortal of ex-senator Francis Kernan was laid at rest in St. Agnes's Cemetery this forenoon after one of the most impressive funeral services ever witnessed in this city.

Probably the pictorial exhibition of the shameless woman on the New-York theatrical stage was never bolder or more common than it is in this hour when a civilized community might be expected to have no humor for trifling, and to take life seriously. For several years the tendency to view exhibitions with complacency that would once have been publicly hissed has been growing.

GENOA, Sept. 10 -- A banquet was given at the palace to-night, at which ninety-two prominent persons were present. The guests included the Archbishop of Genoa, the Ministers of State who accompanied the King and Queen to this city, and the members of the foreign Diplomatic Corps.

The total amount of life insurance in force in the various countries of the world at the present time is, in round numbers, $12,000,000,000, of which $5,500,000,000 are in force in the United State. In 1860 there was five times as much insurance in force in Great Britiain as in the United States, the scheme of life underwriting being then a comparatively novel on in America.

THE SPIDER AND THE WASP. -- I have no great sympathy with wasps -- they've done me so many bad turns in my time that I don't pretend to regard them as deserving of exceptional pity -- but I must say Eliza's way of going at them was unduly barbaric. She treated them for all the world as if they were entirely devoid of a nervous system.

COLUMBUS OR VESPUCCI. -- Every schoolboy, of course, knows that, if Columbus had never lived, America would have been discovered all the same, when Pedro Alvarez Cabral, the Portuguese Admiral, was carried by the trade winds over to the coast of Brazil, in 1500. But in that case it would not have been discovered by Spain, and the whole course of the inevitable European settlement on the continent must have been modified.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The closing of the Grand Union Hotel on Tuesday after breakfast was the first official notice that the season of 1892 was over. Since then the town has rapidly cleared of its crowds, though what would be termed such in any place save Saratoga remains. To such as know and love Saratoga this is the cream of the year here.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- Newport's municipal election should take place next Wednesday, but the usual notice required by law has not been published. Recently a State commission altered the ward boundaries and made their report at the last meeting of the City Council. At a special Aldermanic meeting this afternoon Mayor Honey presented a striking document.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The immense plant of the old United States Rolling Stock Company at Hegewich, Ill., was to-day turned over to the United States Car Company, a New-Jersey corporation. Work at the Hegeswich plant, which has been suspended since the failure of the United States Rolling Stock Company, over a year ago, will be resumed within thirty days, or as soon as the property can be put in good working order.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Sept. 10. -- The Water Gap's Fall season is fairly under way. There are new faces at the hotels, new traps on the road, and even gayer happenings than those of Summer. It is evident that the season is to be an exceptional one. Engagements at the Kittatinny House indicate a full list of guests up to December, and the other establishments will be open nearly us long.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- In temperate zones September has always been the most favorable month for the spread of cholera. The fact has been demonstrated many times, yet on each new occasion it has to be learned all over again. Probably in former ages, when life was long and facts were few, people remembered things better.

POPULATION IN INDIA. -- The population, of the Indian Empire has risen within the memory of the present generation from 220,000,000 to 289,000,000; it has been increasing at the rate of 2,500,000 annually, and is now rising at the rate of 3,000,000. If no large famines occur it will considerably exceed 300,000,000 at the end of the century now drawing to a close.

From the Norwich (Conn.) Bulletin. In the proceedings of the Connecticut State Board of Trade, at its meeting in Waterbury last Winter, appears a valuable paper by Mr. McKenzie of Southington on the improvement of country roads, drawn out by the resolutions of the Norwich and New-London boards concerning highway improvement.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- The Berlin authorities consider that the foreign press exaggerates the condition of affairs in Hamburg. Cholera is bad enough in the poorer and older quarters of the city, but the middle and upper class residents would not have known of the existence of the epidemic except for the information gleaned through the newspapers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 -- This has been a week of picnics andd other outdoor amusements, with weather absolutely perfect, both night, and day. The sound of horns both musical and harsh has been heard, and the ocean drive has been crowded with teams, fourin-hands with cottagers, busses with parties of citizens and carriages of all descriptions.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- At Oakland Garden to-day the Dorchester Athletic Club held its first open handicap athletic meet. There was a splendid field of competitors. The winners in the different events are as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- The steamer Weatherby, from Hamburg, arrived this morning at the Quarantine station, after a voyage of twentyfive days. There is no sickness reported on board the steamer, and there has been none among the twenty-five sailors during the trip. The men, with their effects, were removed to Gallup's Island.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- W.D. Foulke of Indiana was a guest of the Massachusetts Reform Club at its dinner at Young's to-night, and was the chief speaker. After declaring that he voted for Harrison in 1888, he said:

WOODSDALE ISLAND PARK, Ohio, Sept. 10 -- The anniversary of Perry's victory on Lake Erie was chosen by the Ohio League of Republican Clubs to open the Presidential campaign in Ohio, and this town was selected as the place for the annual mass meeting of the Ohio Republican League.

The indications continue to be of the most encouraging character as to the Democratic campaign. There is now no feeling anywhere -- and there has been no reason for any for a long time -- that the Democrafts of New-York City and Brooklyn will not do their full share in the work of the canvass.

ORANGE, Sept. 10 -- The Oranges are beginning to show signs of reviving social life. A great many people have returned from the various Summer resorts, and rumors are current of a gay season ahead. The tennis courts of all the clubs are in great demand, and the Orange Athletic Club, Orange Lawn Tennis Club, and East Orange Tennis Club are preparing for tournaments which they expect will eclipse all past events.

From the Lancaster (Penn.) Examiner. Conventions in the interest of good country roads have just been held in Iowa and Missouri. They were both well attended and much enthusiasm was exhibited. It now seems certain that the movement in favor of good country roads will not end in talk. People at last appear to be in earnest about the matter.

E.P. Powell in the New-England Magazine. Our present road system, as we term it, was never intended by our fathers to be anything more than a makeshift to cover the immediate necessities of pioneer life. There was far more tendency to experiment with an aim to improvement in ordinary roads before the advent of railroads.

FIRST ARTICLE. This volume, the first of the author's ambitious "History of the New World," leads the student in a novel direction. The reasons which brought about the Discovery, the first speculations indulged in by the Greeks relative to an unknown continent, the gropings of men nearer to our day, the wonderful deeds of those hardy mariners, have all been told separately or conjointly.

"THE WIZARD." -- Crosse, who was perpetually playing tricks and frightening the small boys with electric shocks, was always called "the wizard," it seems. He was much addicted to making fireworks, and one day, when pursuing the two-fold business of learning his Virgil and pounding some rocket mixture, he was discovered by Seyer, who in great wrath carried off the mixture.

LOON LAKE HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The President passed the day very quietly, not even taking a drive. After breakfast he had a few minutes' conversation with Marshal Jacobus of Brooklyn, who was here for a day, and alter dinner saw Mr. Martyn, President of the St. Lawrence County Agricultural Society, who came to invite the President to stop off at Canton on his way out of the mountains to Washington next week.

Apparently without any trouble the Cincinnati players won from the New-Yorks yesterday. It was too one-sided a game to be interesting. In the opening inning the visitors scored 4 runs, and held the lead throughout the game. As a matter of fact, the New-Yorks failed to tally a run throughout the game. Several times they made noble efforts, but the Cincinnati players were ever on the alert and balked them.

QUEBEC, Sept. 10 -- The steamships Wandrahm from Hamburg and Labrador from Liverpool arrived at Quarantine early this morning. Dr. Montisambert boarded both steamers and examined the passengers, after which they were landed to receive a bath and in order that their clothing and effects might be fumigated. No symptoms of cholera have been discovered.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 1O -- The most profitable business in Richfield these bright Autumn days is selling flowers. It has become a regular custom to load down each departing guest with, roses, asters, and sweet peas until to leave town without at least a half dozen bouquets is to proclaim one's self unknown, and the amount of flowers seen at the station is taken as a sort of local barometer of popularity.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York Concert Company, Limited, for the election of Directors to serve for the ensuing year began at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and continued until 7 o'clock, and it was not until 9:30 o'clock that the result of the balloting was made public.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Ex-Assemblyman James K. O'Connor who was the Republican member of Assembly from the first Onelda District in 1889 and is a member of the Onelda County Republican Committee and several party organizations, has resigned his various posttions in the Republican Party and declared himself for Cleveland. O'Connor was an antiPlatt Assemblyman and gives as one reason for his change the control of the Republican Party by platt.

With a most successful day of sport the Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday afternoon. There was a good crowd on hand to see the decision of the six races, which included the race for the Great Eastern Handicap and the Old Time race, which was a dash of four miles, the kind of race that has not been seen hereabout for several years.
From the Boston Herald. Aug. 2. -- Set out on vacation trip to Cape Breton, via steamer to Halifax.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The Saratoga County Republican Convention to select delegates to the convention to be held at Johnstown on the 14th inst. to nominate candidates for the new Twenty-second Congressional Distriot met in the Town Hall at noon to-day. C. A. Waldron of Waterford presided.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1O -- An emergency such as that which arose at Buffalo a month ago was all that was necessary to bring to light the defects in the organization of the New-York National Guard. Show rather than service, to teach the men to look pretty instead of teaching them the art of taking care of themselves, have been the dominating influences in the National Guard for the last decade.

The annual meeting of the Hudson River Baptist Association will be held in Peekskill, Westchester County, this week, at the First Baptist Church. From 200 to 300 delegates, laymen, and pastors, from about forty churches, representing seven counties, are expected to attend. The meetings will begin on Tuesday and close Thursday noon.

Man should surely be classed as a ruminant, for alter abundance he attains the calm satisfaction of that species. My hostess was pouring the coffee. Her husband, my old school friend. Robert Danton, was reaching the cigars. We were thoroughly contented, and with such content often comes reminiscence.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10 -- The Corbett special train left Birmingham, Ala., at 5 A.M., and at every station along the line Corbett was given a great ovation. It was not until the train reached Tallapoosa that the discovery was made that Manager Brady had been left behind. Corbett was eating his breakfast at the time Brady's dispatch was handed to him, stating that he would follow in another train.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 10 -- A terrible accident occurred about 10:10 o'clock to-night at the Watertown Junction, near West Cambridge station, on the Fitchburg Railroad, caused by a westward bound express freight telescoping the rear car of the 10:15 Waltham passenger train from Boston. Fifteen killed and wounded have already been taken from the wreck and it is believed that more are beneath the debris.

While at work in the shop of E. F. Keating, 33 Gold Street, on Tuesday. Frank Cowey, a lad of fifteen, had his right hand caught and crushed in a pipe-cutting machine. Three of his fingers were badly mashed, and, accompanied by Charles Cannon, foreman of the shop, he walked to the Chambers Street Hospital.

The sun was up and attending to business when a jolly party of New-Yorkers reached the shore of Lower Saranao Lake last Sunday morning. Warm rays of light sifted through the overhanging fohage and danced in fantastic forms on the glistening water, as if mocking the cautious pleasure seekers who had provided themselves with heavy flannels and Winter wraps.

KEYPORT, N.J., Kept. 1O -- This town is situated on Raritan Bay, and refuse is being constantly washed up on the shore. As a precaution against a visitation of the cholera, the perms of which might possibly be brought to the town by the floating matter, the citizens of Keyport called the attention of the State Board of Health to the subject.
An old man leaning over a gate at sunset. In the background a farmhouse and buildings surrounded by meadows; in the foreground a white, dnsty country road.

News from the arctic steamer Kite, which sailed early in July with the expedition sent out from Philadelphia to carry relief to Lieut. Peary and his associates in Greenland, is now anxiously awaited. It is some months above a year since the explorers entered upon their period of voluntary exiie in that region of ice and snow.

Mr. CHARLES F. PECK, Commissioner of the State Bureau of Labor Statistics, is likely to find out, before he is done with the National Democratic Committee, that he cannot prostitute his office to his personal ends without incurring a grave responsibility which the law defines and will enforce.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- It was a splendid scene at the Casino Theatre to-night, on the occasion of the last concert of the season, when the pretty theatre was packed with society people and citizens, who gave Mullally's Oychestra a grand reception as the national hymn was played at the conclusion. Among the party were guests of Prince Ponitowski, who gave a large dinner party to-night in the Grill rooms.

Mr. E.B. LANIN begins his article in the Fortnightly Review on the relation between cholera and uncleanliness in Russia with an anecdote. Some time ago one Russian gentleman inquired of another: "Your roof leaks, I hear?" "It does, abominably," was the answer. "Why not have it repaired?"

SPARTANBURG. S.C., Sept. 11 -- Corbett and his party did not leave Atlanta till the middle of the day, and several thousand people gathered around the station to see him off. As the Washington vestibuled limited of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, to which Corbett's special car was attached, pulled out of Atlanta, the great champion was cheered to the echo.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Allan L. McDermott, the brainy chieftain of the Abbett clan in Democratic polities, walked into the office of a glibtongued lawyer one day last week and notified him that his services would be required as a delegate in the State House interest to the Democratic State Convention of Wednesday next.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Cunard Line steamer Servia, from New-York Sept. 3 for Liverpool, which arrived at Queenstown at 8:15 o'clock this morning, had a narrow escape from serious disaster last Tuesday.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- To-morrow morning artisans will be placed at work to repair and put into condition for occupation the villa residence on Van Rensselner Boulevard built twelve years ago by the late Joseph K. Emmet, the actor, and which passed to the ownership of David B. Hill yesterday, when a deed recording that fact was filed with the County Clerk.

GENOA, Sept. 11 -- The King and Queen, and member of the royal family, together with the Cabinet Ministers, attended a popular fete and ball given at the Raggio Castle, in Cornigliano, this evening. The castle was lavishly decorated and illuminated for the occasion.

John L. Sullivan, the former idol of the fistic fraternity, arrived here yesterday from the soone of his Waterloo. He was accompanied by his backers, Charley Johnston and James Wakely, and the trio looked like mourners at a funeral. Sullivan's nose was peeled, his eye was slightly discolored, and his left jaw showed the effects of Corbett's right-hand blows.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 -- The Democratic campaign was formally opened yesterday with meetings in every county seat except where Mr. Stevenson had previously spoken. The speakers were mostly Indianians. Mr. Stevenson spoke in three places -- Bloomington at 10 o'clock. Greencastle at 2 o'clock, and Terre Haute at night.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- In the Winter of 1888-9 some Tammany men decided that a Summer home for the braves of the Wigwam was needed at Saratoga, then as now a favorite resort for them. The matter was talked up and ended in the purchase of the Sehuyler place, on the west shore of Saratoga Lake, about one mile south of Moon's. This was the beginning of the Kayaderosseros Club.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 11 -- About a year ago a female saint arose at Tomasachio in the State of Sonora. She was a reformer, and charged that the clergy, from priest to Pope, were corrupt, and failed in their duty. During the Winter a priest preached against her, which so excited the people that he would have been killed but for Government interference.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Sept. 12 -- A.M. The industrial stocks were the features of the week's speculation and all of them scored material gains. In railway stocks. Reading and New-England led in point of activity. Reading and the other coal stocks were attacked on rumors that there is to be further litigation looking toward the breaKing of the combination.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Driven to madness by excruciating pain, and unwilling that the daughter whom she loved should be parted from her even in death, Mrs. Cora Levis Torgette retired to her room last night in which her child was already sleeping, and turning on four gas jets to their full head, calmly lay down to die.
Ex-Register John Reilly, who is the Tammany leader of the Tenth Assembly District, had a few words to say yesterday about the situation in this city. The ex-Register is an old campaigner.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The reported flop of a Democratic Polish Club to the Republican Party last week has caused much excitement in the Ninth (Polish) Ward. Last night a meeting of over 400 Poles was held, which lasted until a late hour.

For the coming three weeks racegoers will find their enjoyment at the race track at the Brooklyn Jockey Club, where a programme lasting seventeen days has been prepared by Secretary McIntyre. Large fields and a fine lot of racing is a certainty, for Mr. MoIntyre has thoroughly mastered the art of preparing racing programmes that the owners and trainers like, the conditions being plain and such as can be understood by every one.

The American Protective Tariff League is still trying to "fool the farmers" by reports about the benign influence of the McKinley tariff. In the latest issue of its weekly journal, the American Economist, it publishes a short table purporting to "show clearly the benefits of the new law to agriculture."

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 11 -- The State campaign continues to grow warmer and the breach between the Clark and Hogg factions of the Democracy is widening every day. The San Antonio Daily Express, the leading Democratic paper of Western Texas, and a pronounced supporter of the candidacy of Clark, speaks of Hogg as responsible for all of Texas's financial ills.

Record smashing on the bicycle by amateurs still continues. Only a few days ago Zimmerman broke the time for a mile, and news from England informs us of a wonderful performance by Adams, another amateur. In a 100-mile scratch invitation race, under the auspices of the Surrey Bicycle Club, he created new records from 64 to 100 miles.

Records recently made up by the army authorities show that the desertions for the year ending June 30 numbered 1,382. At first glance this may seem to be a very great number in a total force of 25,000 enlisted men, especially as over 4,000 of these are non-commissioned officers, while of the private soldiers many, in consequence of long-service pay, or the approach of the end of their enlistments, have no temptation to desert.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The information sent here of the discovery in Chicago of a fraudulent two-dollar note is such as to prove conclusively that, whatever it is, it was not printed from a plate stolen from the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.

It is a feature of progressive science that it raises problems as well as solves them. The Hittite question is an example. Prior to the decipherment of the Egyptian hieroglyphics and the cuneiform inscriptions the Hittites were simply regarded as one of a large number of petty principalities that divided Palestine between them, and differing in no essential particular from the Amorites.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., Sept. 11 -- At the State Fair races yesterday the Palo Alto filly Rowena broke the two-year-old trotting race record, going a mile in 2:19 1/2".
A piping son'-son' west breeze was blowing across Jamaica Bay yesterday morning when the starting gun for the annual Fall regatta of the Ocean Yacht Club was tired shortly after 10 o'clock.
NEW-YORK, Sept. 11 -- 4 P.M. No cases of cholera have appeared in this city. By order of the Board of Health.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The Republican convention to nominate candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Secretary of State, Treasurer, Auditor, and Attorney-General will assemble next Wednesday, Sept. 14, in this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Nearly all the leaders of the railroad labor organizations came to town to-day, in response to the telegrams sent them on Friday and Saturday, and last night there were gathered in the little St. Charles Hotel the most important representation of organized labor that was ever in Philadelphia.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Discount rates continue easier with no prospect of a betterment. Continental demands are met by the American supply. Austria avoids touching the Bank of England's gold, as, having fresh loans in view, she desires to maintain the ease of the European markets. The usual home Autumnal demands will probably be a mere fleabite in view of the unwieldy resources of the market, and everything points to an Autumn of exceptional case.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Etruria took 554, saloon and 7O second-class passengers, and the Wisconsin 78 saloon and 257 second-class passengers.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 11 -- The great Quincy accident was recalled last night when a through freight express train, west bound, on the Fitchburg Railroad, ran into a passenger train standing on the out-bound track at West Cambridge Junction, telescoping the rear car, killing six persons outright and injuring nearly forty others, three of whom have since died.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 -- The schooner Benjamin A. Van Brunt from New-Jersey, with 1,328 tons of coal for Fall River. was run down and sunk near the latter port this morning, having first been struck by the steamer Pilgrim and then by the Providence. Capt. Davis of the Pilgrim says, when within four minutes of his dock, going into Fall River this morning, he sighted a schooner directly in the channel.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11 -- The Directors of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad yesterday considered the proposition to lease the Housatonic system. The details having been arranged satisfactorily and the roads comprising the Housatonic system being willing to be leased, the Directors of the Consolidated voted to accept the same.

DOVER, N.H., Sept. 11 -- It does not seem to be fully settled in the minds of the expert politicians of the lower district of New-Hampshire whether the Hon. Henry W. Blair, just nominated for Congress by the Republican Party, is a strong candidate or a weak one, and really nobody can send out from this State to an anxious world a prognostication as to the matter that may be relied on.

The bridge Trustees were unable to get a quorum to transact business yesterday, and adjourned until Monday next. The committee to consider and determine the location and arrangement of the new terminal stations, however, did meet, and completed its report, which was handed to the President of the Board of Trustees.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 12. -- The result of the election in this State to-day, as in the case of Vermont, shows an extraordinary falling off in the Republican vote of Maine, beside which the result in the Green Mountain State falls into shadow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- Chief P.M. Arthur of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, who is here with Chief Wilkins of the Order of Railway Conductors and P.H. Morrissey, representing Chief Wilkinson of the order of Trainmen, and a Grievance Committee of Heading employes, to-day said that a conference would be held with President McLeod of the Reading on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A meeting of the Commission, ers of the Western Traffic Association was held today at Chairman Walker's office to consider an application from the Northern Pacific Railroad for relief against the competition of the Great Northern. It appears that the Great Northern Road has voluntarily reduced the rate on grain 1 1/2 to 2 cents per 100 pounds from North Dakota points to St. Paul.

So far as we know, the managers of the Columbian Exposition have not yet indicated what they are going to do with the appropriation of half what they asked by Congress, coupled with the condition that the fair should not be opened on Sunday. This is indeed a matter for very serious consideration, supposing that the managers have no views of their own that will interfere with their duty as managers.

All the railroads have refused to carry immigrants West unless each has a certificate from a surgeon in the employ of the Federal Government. This action was due to the firm stand taken by the Illinois State Board of Health.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 12. -- Four favorites and two second-choice horses won at Latonia to-day. The weather was fair and the track fast. The attendance was about 2,500, the smallest of the meeting.

The Baptist Ministers' Conference resumed its weekly sessions for the coming Winter yesterday moraine in the church house of the Baptist Taberuacie, Second Avenue and Ninth Street. The Rev. Samuel B. Alman, pastor of the Emannel Baptist Church, of this city, presided. Resolutions of regret at the death of the Rev. Mr. Schuite of the Baptise Home Mission Society were adopted.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The hearing on the order issued by Judge Edwards, on the application of E. Ellery Anderson and Norton Chase, requiring Labor Commissioner Charles F. Peek to show cause why he should not be compelled to snow the original blanks upon which he based his recent report, came before Judge Fursman at the Special Term held at the Court House here to-day.

A rumor was afloat in the Board of Education Building yesterday to the effect that the four evening high school of the city would not open on Oct. 1, that there would be no registration of scholars, and that there would be a thorough investigation of the evening high schools.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- At all the Catholic churches in Illinois, the priests read from the altar a long pastoral letter yesterday morning, signed by the Archbishop of Chicago and the Bishop of Peoria, Belleville, and Alton, strongly denouncing the Edwards compulsory education law, and calling upon Catholic voters to enforce the demand for its repeal.

The engines of the new triple-screw ship Columbia, now nearing completion at the yards of William H. Cramp Sons, Philadelphia, Penn., are of the same dimensions and design as the engines of the new armored cruiser No. 6, building at the Union Iron Works, San Francisco, Cal. The Columbia will be provided with three engines and Cruiser No. 6 with two engines.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 12. -- At the State Convention of the colored voters, to-day, the first or its kind ever held in the State, the police had to be called in to quell a small riot that broke out between the warring factions. Pistols were drawn, and had it not been for the interference of the police there would have been a general fight.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Two-thirds of the delegates in the Democratic State Convention, which will be held here to-morrow, are in town at present, and the unanimous feeling is in favor of renominating Judge Morris of New-Haven for Governor. His associates on the ticket of two years ago, with the exception of Dr. Alsop of Middletown, deceased, will also he renominated by acclamation.

The Methodist preachers of New-York began their usual weekly sessions for the coming year yesterday morning at their hall, corner of Twentieth Street and Fifth Avenue. There was a full attendance at the meeting, and the Rev. S.L. Seiler of Brooklyn, the newly-elected President, was in the chair.

Unless Albert L. Adatte, fifteen years of age, changes his ways to a very considerable extent during the enforced confinement which is in store for him, the criminal profession is certain to be enriched sooner or later by the most promising kind of recruit. Until Aug. 20 Albert was employed as errand boy by John H. Johnston, a jeweler at 17 Union Square.

Yesterday was the second day of the thirtietic Harvest-Home Festival of the Cannstatter Volksfest Yerain, new being celebrated at Sulzer's Hartem River Park, and dating the afternoon and evening thousands of Swabiana were present to witness and take part in the festivitles.

ST. LOUIS, Sept 12. -- The National Executive Committee of the People's Party held a called session here to-day. Chairman Taubeneck, Messrs. Davis of Texas, Rankin of Tennessee, Turner of Washington, D.C.; Strickler of Nebraska, and Washburne of Massachusetts were present. The session was secret, but it was given out that nothing was done except to talk over future appointments of the party's orators.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn did not write the letter he intended to send to Gov. Flower in regard to the Newtown Creek nuisances. Learning that the Governor had come to New-York, the Mayor decided that a personal statement of the facts would unravel the legal complications in the matter.

President Harrison yesterday telegraphed Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Executive Committee that he could not make the trip he had expected to make through this State. He was to have visited Herkimer, Watertown, and possibly one or two other places this week and make some short speeches. The President telegraphed that he was sorry he could not fill these engagements, but Mrs. Harrison's health was such that it was impossible.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The great building and bank society which was announced Friday as being involved in the failure of the London and General Bank, the Liberator Permanent Building and Investment Society, and the House and Land Investment Trust, is the Birkbeck Bank, the offices of which are at 29 and 30 Southampton Buildings, Chancery Lane.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 12. -- When the press cholera corps reached Camp Low on Sandy Hook this afternoon with their camp stoves prepared for a siege, they found that the quarters to be assigned them were not near ready to be occupied. They stowed their baggage in an open house, and Capt. Mercer of the Marine Guard kindly furnished them with a guard to watch it.

A meeting of the grammar school Principals was held yesterday afternoon for the purpose of making plans for the parade of the public school children in the coming Columbian celebration in this city. Sixty-three out of the sixty-five Principals were present.

ELWOOD, Ill., Sept. 12. -- The Republicans will make the greatest effort of the campaign in this new natural gas town of 5,000 people. The American Tin-Plate (so-called) Works, situated here, will be dedicated by the Republican State Committee with a State rally, and speeches will be made by Gov. MoKinley of Ohio and Gov. Chase of Indianapolis.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 12. -- The following dispatch explains itself:

A special meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine was held yesterday to take some action on the present quarantine laws. The meeting resulted in the adoption of a resolution offered by Dr. Thompson providing for the appointment of a committee to "consider the feasibility of urging legislation providing for a national quarantine system, and to consider any possible improvement in the present quarantine system of this State."

Corbett, the fighter, exhibited himself at the Martison Square Garden last night, and 3,000 persons went there to look at him. They saw and cheered and came away after the listic champion had shown his quickness at ducking. There was no pretense of work with any fire in it on the champion's part. He love-patted his opposite and was love-patted in retarn, with some balancing to partners sand wiched in.

The steamer Pilgrim of the Fall River Line was at her dock in this city yesterday with a large gang of carpenters on board repairing the damage done by her collision with the coal schooner Van Brunt at Fall River. It was stated by the agents of the vessel that there was nothing serious the matter with her and that she would go out as usual.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept 12. -- New-York State started into the hotel business on Sunday, out the welcome given to her guests, at least on the part of some who should have figured as hosts, was far from cordial.

Dr. Henry B. Baker or Michigan, Dr. J.N. McCormack of Kentucky, and Dr. P.H. Bryce of Toronto, three members of the International Quarantine Inspection Commission, were at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. They had just returned from a visit to the principal ports along the North Atlantic coast, where they examined the facilities for preventing contagious or infectious diseases from entering this country.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Lasker has beat Bird in the set match of fire games up at Newcastle-on-Tyne by a score of 5 to 0, no game being drawn.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- "Prof. Barnard has earned a niche for himself beside Galileo and Herschel, and the permanency of his fame is as secure." S.W. Burnham, the well-known astronomer who recently resigned from the staff at the Lick Observatory to accept the position of Clerk of the United States Circuit Court in this city, made that remark to-day and showed the following telegram:

The Republican national managers have made tremendous efforts to increase their usual vote in Maine. They have flooded the State with their ablest speakers. They have used the letter of James G. Blaine, issued on Sept. 6, as their chief campaign document in the wind-up of the contest.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 12. -- Of the 602 steerage passengers on the steamer Indiana, 350 are from various parts of Great Britain and the remainder are from the Continent. The alien emigrants include a dozen Russian and Polish Jews. They were twelve flays in Liverpool, where their bedding and baggage were disinfected.

Controller Myers returned yesterday from his vacation, and, in company with John A. Sullivan, Superintendent of Markets, begun an inspection of the city's markets to see if the recently-promulgated rules in reference to the cleanliness of the buildings and stands were being complied with. They visited Washington and Fulton Markets and were satisfied with, the condition in which they found them.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 12. -- Judge Edward D. Cutler, State Committeeman and County Judge, who has lately returned from New-York, spoke to favorable terms of an internew he had with ex-President Cleveland in that city. Mr. Cutler was one of the few who was received by him then. The interview lasted thirty minutes.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- Mr. William Steinway's interview with Emperor William, which took place yesterday, was originally fixed for a day in June, but the illness of Mr. Steinway at that time prevented his accepting the Emperor's invitation.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- It is said here that because of the persistency of the Abbett party in pushing his name before the coming Democratic Convention for their own purposes, in spite of his repeated declinations, Judge Werts has written another letter declaring that under no circumstances can he accept.

The Woman's Hospital in the State of NewYork yesterday recorded in the Register's office three contracts of the terms of which it will, on the payment of $331,000, become the owner of land on Eighth Avenue, between Ninety-second and Ninety-third Streets. The property, which fronts Central Park, extends westwardly on Ninety-third Street 250 feet and on Ninetysecond Street 259 feet.

The steamboat Captains, pilots, and officers plying in the waters in and about New-York harbor have formed a strong Cleveland and Stevenson Club. The organization meeting was held on Saturday at 40 Bowling Slip, with 200 persons in attendance. It was resolved to arrange for a ratification meeting at an early date, and Congressmen Cummings, Fellows, and Cockran have been invited to make addresses on the occasion.

The revival or Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "Iolanthe" at Palmer's Theatre last evening was a performance or uneven character. It had some pronounced merits and some painful defects, and the juxtaposition of the two produced an effect of formlessness. The presentation of the operetta was, on the whole, lacking in delicacy of touch.

The entries for most of the races to be run at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track to-day having proved so few in number, the third race, which had received seventeen entries, was divided, thus making on extra race. The entries are as follows:

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 12. -- The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Ireland and the Gentlemen of Canada opened here to-day in perfect cricket weather. The Irishmen won the toss and went to the bat. The innings closed in two hours for 131. of which 105 had been made at the fall of the third wicket. The fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh fell for 123.

On Thursday afternoon the children of the stage will, by Mayor Grant's permission, contribute their share toward the erection of the new Press Club Building by giving the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet" and by acting "Pygmalion and Galatea." The matinee will be held in the Broadway Theatre at 2 o'clock.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- A citizens' meeting was held to-night, under the auspices of the Republican City Committee, at Republican Hall, to "protest against the willful neglect on the part of toe Mayor and Board of Aldermen to fix the new polling places in accordance with the law."

To the Editor of the New York Times: On Sunday, Sept. 4, the dispatches from Berlin contained an attack upon me in connection with the confinement of my husband in a German insane asylum. It is true that I wrote to the high personages mentioned in the cablegram, tout the subject upon which I addressed those seemingly unapproachable gentlemen was entirely misrepresented.

The American (Sugar Refining Company has fitted up one of its buildings at Washington and Essex Streets, Jersey City, for a cholera hosptial. The company employs over 700 men in its refinery in Jersey City. The refinery is on the Morris Street dock, near the piers used by foreign freight steamships.
