Special Agents were busy yesterday in the seizure room of the Custom House examining nine trunks that bad been taken within a few days from passengers on the steamships Britannic and La Bourgogne. The trunks seized from the Britannia belonged to a Philadelphia woman who is said to stand high in society in that city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- During the greater part of the session the provision market ruled steady. Several small lots came out and, in connection with the easy hog market and decline in grain, this was enough to put the market down. The range was narrow, and as lard received the best support it closed at a slight advance, while pork and ribs were a little lower.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12. -- The Hon. Mr. Foster will accompany Sir John Abbott to England on important business in connection with the financial management of Canadian loans in London. There is also a question which came up in the House of Commons last year as to the betterment of Canadian diplomatic relations with Washington and other countries.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- A letter was received here to-day by the family of Mrs. Jesse Tyson, who, with her husband, was a passenger on the Normannia, quarantined in New-York Bay. The letter was written on Sunday, on board the steamer Stonington, to which boat the cabin passengers of the Normannia had been transferred.

The fathers and mothers among the passengers on the Desbrosses Street Ferry early yesterday morning saw a sight that none of them will probably ever forget. The New-York Orthopedic Hospital, thanks to the generosity of its Lady Supervisors, had emptied its wards or its crippled, child patients and sent the whole of them to enjoy the crisp September air of the country for three weeks.
A sewer accident, which cost the lives of three men, occurred in Jersey City yesterday.

A letter was received yesterday by THE TIMES from the cabin passengers on the steamship Rugia, now detained at Quarantine. Inclosed in the letter were two other communications, one of which was sent by the cabin passengers to Emil Boas, agent of the Hamburg-American Packet Company, and the other addressed to Health Officer Jenkins.

QUEBEC, Sept. 12.-- The steamer Brothers arrived up from Grosse Isle to-day, having on board the immigrant and intermediate passengers from the steamship Labrador. Dr. Beaudry, the Chief Inspector of the Provincial Board of Health, after an examination, allowed the customs officers and others to embark, and the passengers were immediately landed.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 12. -- The fact that Augusta gave the Republican candidate for Governor only 180 plurality caused great rejoicing among the Democrats, because the last Presidential year the Republicans had a majority of nearly 500, and this reduction of the Republican vote is significant from the further fact that this is the home of Blaine and of many of the city, State, and Federal office holders.

Four fragments of paper, which, when pieced together, form a will executed by Paymaster George W. Long, lacking only as regards the signature, of which only two letters are left, are on file in the Surrogate's office, having been offered for probate by Booraem, Hamilton Beckett, representing one of the executors. The fragments were sent to the Surrogate by W. W. Godding, Superintendent of the Government Hospital for Insane at Washington.

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 13. -- The Journal has returns from 263 towns, which root up as follows: Cleaves, (Rep.,) 51,772; Johnson, (Dem.,) 41,745; Hussey, (Proh.,) 2,308: Bateman, (Peo.,) 1,495. Republican plurality, 10,027. These towns two years ago gave the Republicans 49,096; Democrats, 33,679; Prohibition, 2,037; Republican plurality, 15,417.

CAMP Low, SANDT HOOK, Sept. 13. -- Surgeon Hutton is of the opinion that no cholera refugees will be received here before Friday or Saturday, He says that the camp must and shall be in perfect order for the accommodation of refugees before any are permitted to land.

E. Ellery Anderson, one of the committee which is seeking an opportunity to investigate the data that Labor Commissioner Peek claims to have used in making up his claptrap report on wages and the tariff, said in reference to Peck's letter published yesterday:

About half a dozen young women will take up the studies of the sophomore year at the opening of the Fall term at Brown University. Of special and graduate students there are twelve or thirteen, and the entering class numbers about the same, making in all about forty women who will bo ranked students of Brown for 1892-3.
LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The Vienna correspondent of the News telegraphs to his paper as follows:

Two letters signed by the passengers on board the Scandia -- one by the cabin and the other by the steerage passengers -- wore Bent to the office of the Hamburg-American Packet Company yesterday morning. Both letters dealt with the reports published last Sunday in certain of the morning papers regarding the state, of health of the passengers aboard the vessel and declared these reports to be absolutely unrounded on fact.

LINCOLN, Ill., Sept. 13. -- Part of an accommodation train on the Champaign and Havana Division of the Illinois Central was thrown from the track near here last night. Twelve persons were injured, several of whom may die. The list of the badly injured is as follows:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- On the opening of the General Term of the Third Department this morning the matter of the application of the People ex rel. George C. Carter against Frank Rice, Secretary of state, was heard. This is an application for a mandamus that the Secretary be commanded to issue election notices under the apportionmentlaw of 1879 instead of that of 1892, on the ground that the latter is unconstitutional and void.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- A conference was this morning arranged between President McLeod or the Reading Railroad and the Grievance Committee of employes, together with Chiefs Arthur of the Brotherhood or Locomotive Engineers, Wilkins of the Railway Conductors, and P.H. Morrisey of the trainmen. At 1:30 the delegation assembled at the St. Charles Hotel.
Capt. Ewing is batting in great form just now and is leading all the League players. Of the New-York men, Doyle, O'Rourke, Puller, and Burke have done very good work. The record is appended:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13. -- The stockholders of the Wabash Railway held their annual meeting here this forenoon, and elected the following Board of Directors: Francis Pavy, C.C. MacRae, Edgar T. Weller, George J. Gould, Russell Sage, John T. Terry, S.C. Reynolds, P.B. Wyekoff, Jay Gould, and O.D. Ashley. The new Directors elected were Messrs. Jay Gould, MacRae, and Pavy, the two latter of London, England.

The gallant Democracy of New-Hampshire has chosen a leader worthy of highest honors in nominating for Governor the Hon. Luther F. McKinney. Congressman McKinney has done excellent service for his party and for the cause which it represents in the halls of national legislation. His aggressiveness and ability, with the marked personal popularity which he enjoys, will all count for gain in the Presidential battle up among the granite hills.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Birds of a feather flock together, and so it was not a surprising thing to see that repudiated and discredited head of the Hudson County ring. Orestes Cleveland, consorting with the chiefs of the equally infamous Essex ring in Parlor 16 of the Trenton Houae to-night. They are against Young, and of course he is against Young.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- One or the most notorious dives in Newark is located at 153 South Canal Street, in the Italian quarter. It is the resort or the worst Italian element. A party of Italians, among whom were several women, were carousing there early yesterday morning when a quarrel broke out.

Despite the heavy wind and high seas which prevailed off Rockaway Beach yesterday afternoon, the annual, sweepstakes ocean swimming contest of swimmers from far and near was held. The seas were running very high, and the orginal idea of a ten mile coarse was changed to four miles. It was from the Iron Pier to a lifeboat anchored two miles out to sea and return.
For a month past there have been rumors of irregularities in the administration of the Stapleton (S.I.) public school funds, but the exact nature of the trouble has been carefully guarded.

The Health Commissioners said yesterday that their preparations to meet cholera were made, and that all they could now do was to wait for its appearance in the city. At the meeting of the Board of Health, in the afternoon the following resolutions were adopted:

The application which John H. Starin recently made to the Board of Aldermen for permission to tear down old Piers 18 and 19. between Dey and Cortlandt Streets, on the North River, and to build a new cue suffered another set-back yesterday. Two weeks ago it was "hung up" because, as some of the Aldermen said, they were tired "taking orders from Fourteenth Street.''
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 13. -- The elements conspired against the Republicans to-day and the dedication of the American Tin-Plate Works at Elwood by Gov. McKinley to high protection was a failure.

LARAMIE, Wyoming, Sept. 13. -- The Republican Convention will be called to order here at 10 o'clock in the morning by Senator Joseph McCarry, Chairman of the Central Committee. About seventy of the one hundred and three delegates are already in the city. The candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination have opened headquarters and are canvassing actively.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 13. -- A caucus of Republican leaders was in session here last night. It was stormy. Cnney and Web Flanagan, office holders, and near the Administration, favor the indorsement or Georgo Clark, a Cleveland Democrat. Another wing desires fusion with the Populists and the indorsement of Nugent for Governor.

Police Justice Walsh of the Adams Street Court, Brooklyn, yesterday issued a warrant for the arrest of Joseph Rosenberg, proprietor of a fat-rendering establishment oil Newtown Creek. The warrant was executed last night.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 13. -- The weaver sympathizers gained control of the Democratic State Convention at 10 o'clock last night, and the straight-out Cleveland men, about 200 in number, withdrew from the hall, and later organized the regular convention. To-day they nominated the following ticket:

The owner of the cargo of the South Portland, which lies at anchor off Ellis Island loaded with munitions of war consigned to Trinidad, but intended ultimately for the use of the insurgents in Venezuela, returned from Washington yesterday with his attorney, the trip having accomplished nothing toward the release of the vessel.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept 13. -- Two thousand persone assembled at Cornwall to-day to witness the boat race between the Ward brothers in celebration of their victory over the world's four-oared crews at Saratoga Lake twenty-one years ago. It was also the forty-sixth birthday of the younger brother. Ellis, who is trainer for the Manhattan Athletic Club crew.

LOON LAKE HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- President Harrison makes no effort to conceal his great anxiety over the condition of Mrs. Harrison, and has been at her bedside during nearly the entire day. The whole family share his deep concern and all are evidently apprehensive of a continuance of the present unfavorable symptons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The law officers or the Government are looking up the legal powers of the President in the matter of a temporary suspension or prohibition of immigration.

When Gov. Flower determined to send State troops to Fire Island, Adjt. Gen. Porter advised the calling out of 250 men from the Sixty-ninth Regiment and the entire force of the Naval Reserve, and this was done.

The quarantined passengers of the Normannia must some days ago have reached the conclusion that it was the intention of the City and State of New-York to kill them. The treatment to which they have been subjected, first and last, was admirably calculated not only to load to the conclusion, but to the actual result.

The fifteenth annual session of the convention of the National Guard Association, of the State of New-York was held in the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment yesterday. The representation of organizations of the State force included one brigade, the Second, Brig. Gen. James McLeer: one troop of cavalry, that commanded by Capt. Charles F. Roe: four batteries of artillery, and twelve regiments and eight separate companies of infantry.

WASHINGTON, Sept 13. -- Is there really a seriously-inclined third party in the Fourth District of Mississippi? One would be inclined to doubt it, seeing what the regular Democrats have done in providing a candidate. Clarke Lewis, now the Representative of the district, fell into disfavor, possibly because he ran for Senator against Gen. Walthall, and he was set aside.

HARTFORD, Sept. 13. -- The Democratic State Convention, which was held here to-day, has done the best day's work of any convention that has been held in the State since the war. It has declared for a constitutional convention, to be initiated by an act of the General Assembly first, submitting to the electors the question whether a convention for the revision of the present Constitution of the State should be held or not.
The quarantine station at Fire Island will be under the immediate jurisdiction of the State Board of Health.

The New-York Committee of the Board of Woman Managers of the World's Fair hold a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Bureau of Applied Arts, 1,122 Broadway. The following members were present: Mrs. H. Walter Webb, (presiding,) Mrs. F.P. Bellamy, Mrs. Arthur M. Dodge, Mrs. F.R. Halsey, Miss A. Hennstraught, Miss Imogene Howard, Mrs. Stranahan, Mrs. Oscar Strauss, Mrs. George Waddington, and Miss A. Roosevelt.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept. 13. -- All the passengers from the Normannia who had been held like prisoners aboard the excursion steamer Cepheus came ashore at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, happy at the relief brought to them, but thoroughly aroused and indignant over the treatment to which they had been subjected.

One of the prettiest yacht races seen this year was sailed on the Sound yesterday under the management of the Larchmont Yacht Club. The race was exciting, because a stiff breeze blew up from the southeast and sent lee rails under nearly all the way.

Walter S. Hicks, formerly an active politician of this State, but now of Ann Arbor, Mich., was in this city Monday. He said he thought it safe to say that more than one-half of the Electoral votes of Michigan would be given to Mr. Cleveland.

CINCINNATI, Sept 13. -- The track at Latonia to-day looked more like a small lake than a race course. The ground was deep in slippery mud covered with little shining pools of water. The attendance, in consequence of the bad weather, was very slim.

MITCHELL, Ind., Sept. 13. -- At last Henry Low, a Township Trustee of Lawrence County, who has been made a target in the last three years for more bullets than any other man in the country, perhaps, has been shot dead, and has left no one but the man who shot him to tell the circumstances of his death.

CADDO, Indian Territory, Sept. 13. -- News has reached, here that seven men nave been murdered since yesterday morning in the Choctaw Nation incidental to the political war. It is thought that the worst has not come yet.

NEW-BRUKSWICK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- The 4 P. M. express from Philadelphia on the Pennsylvania Railroad, while passing through Deans Station, seven miles from this city, at 5:15 this afternoon, at a speed of nearly sixty miles an hour, jumped the track and crushed against a freight train standing on a siding. Two of the three day coaches were wrecked and the parlor car badly damaged.

The second and last day's session of the sixth annual convention of the National Harnessmakers' Protective Union was held yesterday at the Hotel Metropolo. The following officers of the union were chosen for the coining year: President -- J.J. Stillings of New-York; Vice President -- J. Schellenberger of New-York; Secretary -- Andrew Halliday of New-York; Treasurer -- J. Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The efforts of the friends of the Administration here to derive consolation from the returns from Maine, or at least to explain away their significance, are grimly humorous.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 13. -- Ever since A.C. Latimer was nominated for Congress against Congressman George Johnstone, he has been strongly suspected of third partyism. To-day he published a card in which he says:

The followers of McKINLEY have a good deal to say about the tariff plank in the Minneapolis platform, but they do not attempt to answer the charge that this plank is utterly at variance with the practice of the Republican Party in tariff legislation. They know that a tariff bill framed in accordance with the principle laid down in their platform would impose duties far below those of the Democratic Mills bill.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 13. -- A guard of ten men, armed with Winchester rifles and shotguns, are on duty at the Lexington jail. The jailer got word about 10 o'clock last night that a mob was coming from Mount Sterling to lynch Alonzo Brookshire, the murderer of Jailer Tipton and Deputy Sheriff Howard of Montgomery County.

Gov. Flower called out a thousand of the State troops early yesterday morning "to protect the property of the State on Fire Island." Before the order was given he had telegraphic advices which told him of the mob's resistance to the landing of the passenger of the Normannia, and emphatically declared that the outrageous proceedings would be stopped.
The steamship Columbia of the Hamburg-American Line, which was allowed to come up to her dock on a clean bill or health Monday, barely escaped detention at Quarantine.

WASHOUGAL, Washington, Sept. 13. -- Fires still rage fiercely in the timber belt south of Bear Prairie. Two women, one with children, who made their way here last night tell of terrible danger to settlers on the timber claims. They had to leave their homes and take the quickest way out.

At a meeting of the Trunk Line Association yesterday it was unanimously decided to refuse to carry any immigrants unless each one was provided with a clean bill of health signed by a surgeon in the Marine Hospital Service. Nearly all the roads had already taken this action singly.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Sept. 13. -- The first steps were taken yesterday and to-day looking toward an active aggressive campaign from now until election day on the part of the organized opposition to the Republican Party in this State.

The following communication was sent yesterday afternoon to Vernon H. Brown of the Cunard Line and Gustav H. Schwab of the North German Lloyd Line, as representing the committee of the steamship companies:

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept 13. -- John Rowercliffe, a mason, who lived one and one-half miles east of Elba, died yesterday of a disease which the physicians who attended him, Drs. Warner of Elba and Jackson of Oakfleld, pronounce to be almost identical with Asiatic cholera. Rowercliffe was taken sick last Thursday. The local Board of Health has quarantined the house, and the funeral, which is to be held to-morrow afternoon, will be private.
HEALTH - BOARD BULLETIN. [OFFICIAL] NEW-YORK, Sept. 13 -- 4 P.M. No cases of cholera have appeared in this city. No suspected or reported cases have been verified.

John P. Sanborn and Henry Howard of Michigan and John A. Farwell of Chicago sent a protest to Gov. Flower last night against the quarantine which has been enforced against the Normanuia's passengers. They have relatives among the passengers. In their protest they review the history of the Normannia's treatment, and add:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 13. -- All the little booms have been "laid away in camphor," as ex-Candidate Frank Murphy said this afternoon, and John Kean is the nominee of the Republican Party for Governor of the State of New-Jersey.

The State authorities lost no time in applying or an order vacating the injunction order which Justice Barnard granted on Monday, restraining Gov. Flower, Health Officer Jenkins, and others from using Fire Island as a quarantine station.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club continued to appear as a bookmaker at its race track yesterday, and brazenly asked that the women at the track should step up to the book that it is running and not only bet their money at such odds as it chooses to offer them, but submit to she petty imposition of a ten-cent commission for the privilege of advertising themselves to the world at large as gamblers.

Adrian Van Sinderen, who at one time occupied a high position in this city as a lawyer, died on Monday at his residence in New-Lots, L.I. Mr. Van Sinderen came of an excellent family, and was prominent socially as well as professionally until he met with a series of misfortunes which led him to use certain trust funds which had been placed in his hands.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The seventy-ninth annual conclave of the Knights Templars began here to-day. Commanderies are here from Brooklyn, Binghamton, New-York, Hornellsville, Rome, Rochester, Norwich, Watertown, Auburn, Syracuse, Cortland, and other places, besides thousands of visiting Masons. There were 1,500 Knights and eleven bands in the parade.

There was a meeting yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce of the committee appointed last week to co-operate with the State and national authorities in relation to quarantine affairs. A letter was submitted to the committee from William E. Dodge, in which he begged that immediate attention might be given to the wants of the passengers on vessels detained at Quarantine.

The frequent complaints made by passengers quarantined on the ships in the lower bay, regarding an inadequate water supply, is a matter which the agents of the vessels yesterday expressed themselves as being unable to understand.

Mr. Isidor Jacobs, who is at the head of one of the largest establishments in the world shipping California canned fruits, President of the San Francisco World's Fair Association, and Chairman of the Merchants' Traffic Association of California, and who has hitherto been prominently identified with the Republican Party on the Pacific slope, one is now an enthusiastic supporter of Grover Cleveland for President, said yesterday, in respect of the political situation in California:

The Republicans have suffered another very serious set-back. Maine has fallen, and fallen heavily, in its vote. In 1890, the year of the "tidal wave" of Democracy, the State gave a plurality of nearly 19,000, (18,883.) That year, also, the First District re-elected Mr. REED by nearly 5,000 plurality, (4,777.)

BOSTON, Sept. 13. -- Were it not for the sensational contest which now overshadows all other features of the Republican campaign, and for the scramble for the nomination for Lieutenant Governor, the ante-convention gathering at the Tremont House this evening might be regarded as a meeting called to pass suitable resolutions on disasters in Maine and Vermont.
The following statement was made yesterday at the Democratic State Committee's Headquarters:

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Immigrants from two Hamburg ships reached Chicago to-day. A rigid investigation railed to disclose evidence of cholera infection and the passengers were allowed to proceed to their destinations. They carried a bill of health signed by United States Marine Surgeon Wheeler, certifying that an inspection in New-York Harbor had satisfied the authorities that cholera was not among the passengers.

A sorry lot of Inspectors returned to the Custom House yesterday from the pier of the French Liue of steamers after the arrival of La Champagne. They had been detailed to the pier for the purpose of looking out for trunks belonging to about thirty-five or forty dressmakers who were reported to be on that vessel, coming home iaden with the latest designs in gowns and other costly wear from Paris.
The following address relative to the recent elections in Vermont, Arkansas, and Maine was issued yesterday by the Democratic National Committee:

To understand the recent deplorable proceedings at Fire Island one must have some acquaintance with the natives of the south side of Long Island. With homes on sandy soil and a great shallow bay lying between them and the ocean these people are poor farmers and poor fishermen. Their lives are generally sad and sordid, they are far removed from the bustling world, they lack ambition and industry.

Fifty veterans and members of the Ninth Regiment, the organization which served throughout the war of the rebellion as the Eighty-third New-York Volunteers, started yesterday on a pilgrimage to the battlefields of Pennsylvania and Maryland, terminating at Gettysburg. En route the pilgrims will visit the scenes of the battles of Antietam and South Mountain, in which the Ninth Regiment participated in 1862-3, and also the cities and towns of Hagerstown, Sharpsburg, Keedysville, Boonsborough, and Frederick.

It is a great pity that the weather yesterday should have interfered with the pageant projected for the laying of the cornerstone of the monument to COLUMBUS. Our Italian citizens are not very numerous in comparison, but they known more about getting up processions than all the rest of us put together, whatever our origin may be.

-- The roof garden of the Casino will close for the season on next Saturday night. In all it will have been open sixteen weeks this Summer, and its prospority has been exceptional. This week's programme of the entertainment given on its stage is made up of clever specialties toy the Girards, May and Cleaver; Hamilton and Glynn, Mile. Ottillie, Mabel Stephenson, La Granadina, and serpentine dancing by Lizzie Derious Daly.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14. -- John Davis, seventy years old, is lying at his home in a precarious condition, with chances all against his recovery. Tice Hutsell, twenty years younger, is at the City Hospital suffering intensely, but improving gradually, with, chances in favor of recovery after a long siege.
ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 14. -- A gang of burglars entered three houses in East Orange early this morning, secured considerable plunder, and escaped undetected, stealing a horse and driving off with it.

OTTAWA, Sept 14. -- There have been rumors for some time that the Government intended to reimpose an export duty on logs. As a consequence of this the United States lumbermen in the Saginaw district, who import a large number of logs from Canada, are agitated. They have been making inquiries as to the truth of the rumor from the Ottawa lumbermen and others.

At 768 Eleventh Avenue, where the old couple William and Sophie Wiegmann died, everything was in disorder yesterday. The Wiegmanns lived on the top floor of the house and had a reputation in the neighborhood for being rather Shiftiless. Besides the parents, there were three sons and a daughter. William, the father, was a tripe cleaner n Dow S. Kitties's meat shop, on Eleventh Avenue, near Fifty-tifth Street.

The National Board of Steam Navigation, which has been in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel since Tuesday morning, closed its annual meeting yesterday afternoon. Reports were read from the sub-committees which have charge of various branches of the board's work, and there were long discussions of recommendations made by these committees.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 14. -- Cohanzie, a suburb of this town, is excited to-day over the elopement of Ada Snow, a fifteen-year-old girl, not yet out of short dresses, and Miles B. Rogers, twenty-five years old, a stonecutter, boarding at her parents' home.

During the past six months many names have been suggested as having been engaged by Manager Augustus Pitou to replace W.J. Scanlan in "Mavourneen." Yesterday Mr. Pitou announced that he had engaged Mr. Chauncey Olcott, who will take Mr. Seanlan's part in the play, and, although he will not be starred, he trill receive a large salary.

Mexicans will to-day celebrate the eighty-second anniversary of Mexican independence, and the Mexican colony in this city, numbering over 100 representative business men, will to-night honor the memory of the monk Hidalgo, who struck the first blow for Mexico's freedom, by giving an elaborate banquet and ball in the rooms of the Colonial Club, at Seventy-second Street and Boulevard.

The funeral of James A. Gill, an old member of the Herald staff and a Trustee of the New-York Press Club, took place yesterday from his late residence, 659 Warren Street, Brooklyn. A large number of his associates in journalism were in attendance, including the special delegation from the Press Club, among whom were William G. McLaughlin, Thomas Evans, Robert Vaughan, John C. Henuessy, James J. Clancey, R.W. Walton, and I. Weston.
For Governor -- GEORGE T. WERTS of Hudson. For Presidential Electors at Large -- PHILIP P. BAKER of Cumberland and MILLARD F. Ross of Middlesex.
LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The steamer Holderness, from Cronstadt, has arrived at Hull, and reports that two of her crew had died of the cholera.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The Republican Congressional Convention for the new Twenty-second District, comprising the Counties of Fulton, Hamilton, Saratoga, and St. Laurence, met at Johnstown this afternoon.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 14. -- The Republican State Convention was in session all the afternoon and is still in session. At 10 o'clock to-night, by a vote of 579 to 167, George Clark, a Cleveland Democrat, was recommended to the Republicans for Governor.

Two deaths were reported yesterday on board the oil-tank steamer Heligoland, Capt. Duiklage, which left Altoua, near Hamburg, on Aug. 29, and which arrived at this port yesterday. She carried a crew of thirty-five men and no passengers. The two unfortunates were Michael Ballendes and Ship Carpenter Ali Eafmann. both or whom died within twenty-four hours after being taken sick.

Western Union furnished some excitement to Wall Street yesterday when the Directors issued as part of the report of their meeting a recommendation that originated with the Executive Committee for an increase of $13,800,000 in the capital stock of the company, making the aggregate capital stock $100,000,000. This was about all the news that proceeded at first from the Directors' meeting.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 14. -- Complete returns from every town in Vermont give Fuller, (Rep.,) 39,190; Smalley, (Dem.,) 19,526; Allen, (Proh.,) 1650. Fuller's plurality is 19,664 and his majority 18,014. Compared, with 1888, this shows a Republican loss of 9,262, a Democratic loss of 1, and a Prohibitionist gain of 278.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Senator Erwin, who was on his way to Johnstown as a delegate to the convention in the new Twenty-second Congressional District, to-day said he was greatly pleased over the decision of Justices Lewis and Dwight of the General Term at Buffalo pronouncing the reapportionment of the State by the last Legislature unconstitutional.

On Saturday next the Manhattan Athletic Club will give its second annual carnival at Manhattan Field, and it is thought that the event will surpass all other efforts. The 200-yard swimming race will bring together each experts as Alexander Meffert of the Manhattan and T. Carey of the Cathedral Athletic Club. They are both speedy, and are bound to make a good race.

ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- Bleak House. D.B. Hill, proprietor, will be open for the reception of a small number of favored guests on Saturday. On that day the new owner of the Fritz Emmet villa on the Van Rensselaer Boulevard will take actual possession of the hostelry and start in business.

Cholera news knocked the stock market all to pieces yesterday. The market opened with a show of strength, being helped by a settlement of the threatened strike on the Reading and by the official promise of a scrip dividend on Western Union. But the opening prices were generally the highest of the day.

The estate of the late Walter S. Hobart of San Francisco, Cal. whose noted stock farm is at San Mateo, has perfected arrangements to sell out its entire trotting stud in New-York on Dec. 20 and 21, under the auction management of Peter C. Kellogg Co.
The following resolutions were adopted yesterday by the Board of Education:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Postmaster General Wanamaker to-day opened a number of proposals, submitted under the act authorizing him "To examine into the subject of a more rapid dispatch of mail matter between large cities, and Post Offices and transportation terminals in large cities, by means of pneumatic tubes or other systems."

NEW-YORK. New members of the Maritime Exchange Association were elected yesterday as follows: J.M. Adams, William H. Bale, Louis L. Browne, Thomas M. Carson, Alexander L. Cochran, John Dowd. Gates D. Fabnestock, L.G. Flitz, Warren A. Fuller, Benjamin F. Hall. Jr., Henry A. Kessel, John S. Kitching, E.W. MoRea, Thomas J. Montgomery, Edgar V. Murtha, John J. O'Brien, John W. Peale, Joseph H. Seaman, Timothy Shannon, Jr., John W. Sheldrake, and James Stanfield.

YANKTON, S.D., Sept. 14. -- The Executive Committee of the Democratic State Central Committee and the candidates on the Democratic State ticket held a conference in this city last night for the purpose of planning a campaign and discussing matters of importance to the party.

There was a large meeting of the Association of Southern Democrats in New-York at the Reform Club last night. Col. Paul presided, and it was decided to affiliate the association with the National Association of Democratic Clubs. Edward Owen was selected to represent the Southern Democrats' Association as a delegate in the National Convention of Clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The Navy Depart- ment people think they may have another job on hand, with the information which comes to them from the Republic of Costa Rica that President Rodriguez has made the usual declaration of himself as Dictator, and that political arrests have been made.

NEW-YORK, Sept. 14, 1892 -- 2 P.M. Appended to this bulletin are the reports of the bacteriologists who have made biological examinations of all cases of suspected cholera in this city. The cases referred to in their reports have been treated with the same precautionary measures as would have characterized the action of the board if they had been immediately and positively recognized.

The General Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday heard the appeal of United States District Attorney Jesse Johnson, on behalf of Andrew D. Baird and other Republicans, from Justice Bartlett's recent adverse decision in the matter of the application for a mandamus to compel the Board of Supervisors to reapportion the Assembly districts in the city and county.

Gov. Flower remained at his headquarters in the Windsor Hotel all day yesterday. He was not in a mood to be trilled with in discussing the recent developments at Fire Island. He received a basketful or telegrams and other communications thanking him for his action.

Those members of the Republican National Committee who have had experience in the devious ways of Republican politics smiled quietly to themselves when they saw the figures from Maine and Vermont. The loss of several thousand in the Republican majority in Maine did not dishearten such men as R.C. Kerens, James S. Clarkson, and Samuel Fessenden, but seemed rather to put them into good spirits.

In only one inning did the Brooklyns score yesterday. It was the first. At that point they gauged the curves of Dwyer with apparent ease and earned 2 runs. After that, however, Dwyer appeared to be invincible and Ward's players failed to send another man around the bases.

The statement was published in THE TIMES recently that J. Rogers Maxwell was figuring on an eighty-foot schooner yacht for next season. H.C. Wintringham, who has worked with Mr. Maxwell for years in yachting, has been at work on a design, and had it all made nearly two weeks ago. William Gardner also made a model and set of plans for an eighty-footer, but Mr. Maxwell decided to have Mr. Wintringham design the yacht.
The Catholic Bishops of the various dioceses included in the metropolitan province of New-York met yesterday in conference at the residence of Archbishop Corrigan, in Madison Avenue.

On the calendar in the Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge Beach, yesterday were several cases arising oat of the new law as to appearance of children on the stage. They were taken up by Judge Beach after he had finished hearing the other cases on his calendar. After arguments lasting over two hours decision was reserved.
McALISTER, Indian Territory, Sept. 14. -- The reports adding to the original list of fatalities in the Choctaw vendetta are incorrect, only four men having been killed at McAlister and Hartshorn.

The exact terms of the compromise that has been reached between the Reading Railroad Company and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the other unions of the employe's of the company have not been made public and, perhaps, will not be. It is not very important what they are.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The correspondent of the Times at Rome sends to that paper an article on brigandage in Italy, in which he says it is an undeniable fact that brigandage is on the increase, not only in Sicily, but upon the mainland.

RICHMOND, Ind., Sept. 14. -- This week the Southwestern Circuit is having a hard battle with the weather, and, after losing yesterday, the track was not fit to start the horses until late this afternoon. The drop in the temperature added to the discomfort and the attendance was much below what it usually is here.

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club will commence its first annual open handicap tennis tournament this afternoon at 3:30 on the courts of the club at One Hundred and Fortieth street and Brook Avenue. The entry list was closed yesterday afternoon, and a meeting of the Handicapping Committee, consisting of John F. Hobart, New-York Tennis Club; J.P. Paret, Leuox Tennis Club, and Alfred C. Clark, Knickerbocker Tennis Club, was held and the entries handicapped and drawn.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14. -- On receipt of the cholera news from New-York Dr. Pelletier, Sec- rotary of the Central Board of Health, called a meeting for to-morrow, when it is more than likely that a quarantine will be declared against New-York, and all passengers on trains from there will be stopped at the lines.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 14. -- Orders have been received by the trainmasters in charge of the mining region branches of the Reading and Lehigh Railroad Companies not to accept anymore empty coal cars from the Pennsylvania Company at any of the transfer points, and the only coal now being transferred to the Pennsylvania is contained in a few stray cars that were loaded before Sept. 12 and which are just reaching the transfers.

The meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners yeaterday was the first held in some time and the Mayor and the Controller made it interesting by one of their old-time tilts. A resolution was offered giving permission to John H. Starin to tear down Piers 18 and 19 North River and erect a new one. The Aldermen have been squabbling about this matter to considerable extent.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 14. -- It was just after supper that Dr. Vought received a telegram from Dr. Jenkins directing him to examine all the detained passengers of the Normannia. This fact, taken in connection with a message from Quarantine saying the embargo would be removed to-morrow, was interpreted to mean that the imprisonment was ended.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 14. -- Garrett F. Frankland, a prominent citizen, who has just arrived here from London by way of the St. Lawrence, writes to the local press complaining of the scandalous state of the Dominion quarantine at Grosse Isle on the St. Lawrence. He says, in reference to the Canadian quarantine arrangements:

LOON LAKE HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- The best that can be said of Mrs. Harrison's condition to-night is that it is no worse than it was this morning. She rested quietly during the day and had several short naps, which failed, however, to refresh her to any noticeable extent. She seems to suffer principally from exhaustion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- The Spreckels Line steamship Loch Flive, which sailed from Hamberg on Aug. 23, having on board rags, glassware, , is now detained at the Federal Quarantine at the Delaware Breakwater. The Catania of the same line, with sugar, toys, cement, burnt clay, , is also detained under similar circumstances.

-- Ex-Congressman William H. Sowden of Pennsylvania, who has been stamping for the Democracy in Maine, says that personalities were entirely ignored in the campaign there, and that it was fought on national issues. He adds: "Republicans are vainly trying to break the force of the Maine result by saying that the Democrats carried Maine in September. 1880, while Hancock was badly beaten in November.

Pitcher Crane of the New-Yorks was married on Sunday last to Miss Nellie Dolan of Chicago. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Corr of St. Bridget's Church in Jersey City. There is a little romance connected with the roarriage. Crauo knew Miss Dolan from childhood. She lived in South Boston, near the residence of the pitcher, and at an early age they showed affection for one another.

VISALIA, Cal., Sept. 14. -- The Coroner of Fresno County arrived here this morning and held an inquest on the bodies of Wilson and McGinness, the detectives killed by Evans and Sontag yesterday. An Englishman named Meering, the principal witness, was made prisoner by Evans and Sontag, and forced to get breakfast for them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Provisions were almost as much neglected as wheat. Receipts of hogs at the yards were a little over the estimates, and the feeling was easy early. Later there was a rally of 5c in the hog market, and the speculative produce market improved, but the closing figures showed a loss for the day. Receipts of product were fair and shipments liberal.
Capt. Evan P. Howell of the Atlanta (Ga.) Constitution and his son, Clark Howell, who is the Democratic National Committeeman from Georgia, were both in town yesterday. Capt. Howell said:
To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been drawn to a paragraph in the news columns of your issue of this morning in which this statement is made:

This has been a red-letter week in the history of the reconstructed Giants. They have not lost a game and are playing grand ball. Batting like champions, running the bases like sprinters, and fielding in a manner calculated to surprise their most ardent admirers, they have made the clubs of St. Louis and Louisville lower their colors.

A queer story was disclosed yesterday in the Superior Court before Justice Dugro, on the application for alimony made by Flora Weinberg in the suit for divorce brought against her by Abraham Weinberg. The argument on the application was adjourned to Monday. Weinberg, according to his wife's story, is a Jew, while she is a Christian, and their marriage was never sanctioned by his parents, who are wealthy residents of Brooklyn.

Several New-England athletic clubs have applied to the National Cross Country Association of America for permission to organize a New-England Cross Country Association. If permission is given, as it doubtless will be, the now association will hold its first championship meeting on Thanksgiving Day. The constitution, with slight changes, to make the rules applicable to New-England, will be the same as the one which governs the national body.

The heavy windstorm of Tuesday night came near playing havoc with the yachts anchored at City Island and at Larchmont. It was expected that more than one anchor chain would part. Luckily most of the yachts rode the waves well.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The result of the consultation of physicians held at Loon Lake this morning to determine the exact nature of Mrs. Harrison's illness has proved a source of genuine sorrow not only to her immediate family, but to every one with whom she had come in contact during the three and a half years of her life here.
London, Sept. 15. -- White star Line SS Germanic, Capt. Cameron, from Liverpool, aid from Queenstown for New-York at 2 30 P M to-day.

LOON LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 15. -- Contrary to expectation. Dr. Doughty, the New-York specialist, made another call on Mrs. Harrison this afternoon. He arrived at the Loon Lake railroad station, three miles from the village of Loon Lake, about 5 o'clock, on his way to NewYork, and was joined there by Dr. Gardner, the attending physician.

RICHMOND, Ind., Sept 15. -- On a lightning track the trotters and pacers put in some lively heats here to-day, and the pleasant, weather brought a profitable crowd to the driving park, with four classes on. The horses were called early and kept at it for over five hours before everything was decided.

The elections in Vermont and Maine have one peculiar features this year which is worth studying. They were more clearly and completely the expression of public opinion than any like elections have been for years, because the reformed ballot more completely freed the voter from other influences than his own preference.

There can be very little doubt that, in the Summer of 1893, Chicago will be thronged, not alone by visitors from foreign shores, but also by citizens of our own Republic, whose ideas as to the vastness and infinite variety of their country are limited and whose opportunity for seeing how great a people we are is confined within equally narrow boundaries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- A member of the National Committee who was sent out to Bar Harbor to see Mr. Blaine and to sound him as to his intentions just before the late election in Maine, which is now found to need so much "explanation " from Republican Headquarters, gives a curious report or his experience.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept. 15. -- The passengers from the Normannia will pass just one more night at the Surf House, unless all predictions fail. It is rather an uncertain factor, however, when predictions are made respecting any disposition that is to be made where these people are concerned.

DETROIT, Sept. 15. -- To-night the Democrats opened the Michigan campaign with a rousting meeting at the Auditorium Hall. The hall, with a seating capacity of 8,000, was comfortably filled by an enthusiastic audience, which cheered itself hoarse before the evening was over.

Although excitement ruled in the down-town markets yesterday, there were also reassuring signs in certain quarters. For the first time in ten days shippers felt justified in making engagements for grain to go to European ports. They were made for ships to sail to Antwerp, Liverpool, and Genoa, and altogether about 250,000 bushels of grain were positively engaged for shipment.

STONINGTON, Conn., Sept. 15. -- 'Longshore sportsmen had plenty of exciting and unusual sport this week. A few days ago immense schools of porpoises came rushing on the coast and several hundred of them drove into narrow and shallow Watch Hill Bay. Unable to get out of the bay, they floundered about in its waters like an army of toppling carboys, and at times came almost under the windows of the bayside Summer hotels.

Dr. Jenkins did not visit the quarantined fleet in the lower bay yesterday. In company with the, Advisory Medical Board of the Chamber of Commerce he made a flying visit, however, to Camp Low on Sandy Hook in the yacht Vamoose, which has been placed at the disposition of the Advisory Board by Mr. Hearst of California.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The following consular appointments were announced to-day by the State Department: William R. Estes, Consul at Nuremberg; Louis A. Dent, Consul at Kingston, Jamaica; C.M. Barre, Consul at Valparaiso, to succeed Mr. McCreary, who has resigned; Charles H. Cowan, Consul at Manila, Phillipine Islands.

The Board of Street Openings and Improvement held a special meeting yesterday for the purpose of discussing the new map which Commissioner Heintz of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards has had prepared for the extensive improvement of the street system in the annexed district.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 15. -- In the Orange Lawn Tennis Club's tournament to-day, play was only in the men's doubles. There was sharp and exciting work all around. The scores were the following:

The Committee on Evening Schools of the Board of Education held a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Board Building. Every member of the committee was present, in addition to President Hunt and Commissioner Thaddeus Moriarty.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 15. -- Major R. B. Rentfro, President Harrison's appointee as Collector of Customs for the District of Brownsville, Texas, is in bad odor with the Republicans at that point. Recently a convention was held, presided over by H. M. Field, at which resolutions indorsing the present Administration were adopted.

The New York Yacht Club closed another successful season of yachting yesterday with a sweep-stakes schooner race, open to yachts in the ninety-foot class. Only three yachts started, but they made a good race and a profitable one for the winner. The entrance fee was $200, with half forfeit. There were live entries, but the Alcara and Alert did not start.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16. -- The Princeton Theological Seminary entered upon its eighty-flrst year to-day. The matriculation of new students took place in Stuart Hall at 11 o'clock this morning. Ovar 100 new students have applied for admission -- more than over before.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 15. -- The threatened rebellion in the Democratic Party in Kansas has become a reality, and a State Convention has been called to meet Oct. 7 for the purpose of outlining a policy for such Democrats as do not intend to support the fusion ticket.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15. -- The Rev. Dr. Leonard. Bishop of Ohio; the Rev. Dr. Nicholson, Bishop of Milwaukee; the Rev. Dr. Elliott of Washington, and Archdeacon Curley of Saratoga, the delegates from the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, were heard to-day before the Provincial Synod of the Church of England in Canada, now in session in Montreal.
All the star performers among the children of stageland united in a salary yesterday afternoon at the Broadway Theatre to aid the building fund of the Press Club with a testimonial performance.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 15. -- An adjourned meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond Terminal Company was held at the Exchange Hotel to-day. Shortly after noon, the meeting being called to order by W.G. Oakham of New-York, Secretary Crump read the proceedings of the last meeting. On motion of George F. Stone of New-York, representing $400,000 worth of stock, William P. Clyde of Philadelphia was elected Chairman.

Yesterday afternoon was the first day of the open handicap tournament of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club, and the opening matches of the gentlemen's singles attracted a considerable number of spectators to watch the play. No less than twenty-two men were entered in the event, and the presence of a number of players from out of the city added considerably to the interest in the match.

The Thespian Cricketers, an eleven composed of actors from the theatres in this city, played their second game this season with the Staten Island Cricket Club's eleven at Levingston, S.I., yesterday afternoon. Robert B. Mantell, who organized the Thespians two years ago and captains the team, was detained in the city, and several of the strongest players could not go down.

Senator William B. Allison of Iowa ran up the steps of the brownstone building 518 Fifth Avenue, where the Republican National Committee has headquarters, yesterday afternoon, and as soon as he explained to the guard at the iron door who he was he was at once shown to Chairman Carter's private room. He had just come from Maine, and his face was somewhat sad and his brow was wrinkled as if he were unhappy.

LOON LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The President to-day sent a telegram to the Secretary of the Treasury, saying that the Attorney General had sent him an opinion to the effect that he had full power, under the law, to prevent the landing in this country of all immigrants coming from ports infected with cholera or any other contagious disease.

Every man who met Judge George T. Werts yesterday wanted to know of him whether he intended to accept the nomination for Governor offered to him by the Democratic State Convention at Trenton Wednesday. To all the Judge said he had not yet mude up his mind.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15. -- A special meeting of shareholders of the Hawaiian Commercial Company was held to-day for the purpose of hearing from Claus Spreckels, who has just returned from the islands, about the condition of the plantations, and to discuss the financial status of the company.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 15. -- There is considerable alarm throughout Canada over the reported outbreak of cholera in New-York. The situation was considered so grave here that a Cabinet meeting was hastily summoned this afternoon. It was decided to inaugurate tomorrow a rigid medical inspection of all trains crossing into Canada at the international boundary.

There appears to be no doubt that within the last few days four or five cases of Asiatic cholera have appeared in New-York. As THE TIMES said yesterday, this is not unexpected news. The development of modern methods of communication, which is the main triumph of our material civilization, carries with it this power of transporting the germs of disease.

CAMP LOW, Sandy Hook, Sept. 15. -- The largest quarantine station in the United States is Camp Low. Instead of the long-deserted, rickety freight house and sheds which marked the sandy beach on Sunday last, a village of tents, long pavilions, and other structures now cover several acres and are ready for the accommodation of over 1,000 persons.

Certain Republican papers in the West are still attacking "the Reading coal monopoly," and their desire to make a little political capital out of the discussion of this subject leads them to overlook some interesting facts. The Cleveland Leader is one of these journals. Last Saturday it published these remarks:
To the Public: The dreaded cholera has appeared in this city and the Health Department has so far shown its ability to arrest the disease promptly.

The fight in the courts to determine whether the Mayor is entitled, under the act of the Legislature amending the section of the Penal Code relating to the licensing of children in theatrical exhibitions, to grant licenses allowing children to sing and dance on the stage has resulted in a preliminary victory for Mr. Gerry and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

The Brooklyn Board of Health was stirred up yesterday afternoon by reports of two suspected cases. One was the death of a young Russian Pole named Josepha Maleckar, twenty years old, employed as domestic at 526 State Street. Inspectors Convery and Moore were sent to the house and made a post-mortem examination.

Sheriff McPhillips of Hudson County, N.J., went to State Prison yesterday with the last batch of sentenced ballot-box stuffers. He had them driven in coaches to the Pennsylvania Railroad station. They were Lawrence Costigan, John Tarrant, Juhn Nelson, Micheal Hughes, James Scanlan, Michael Cassldy, Charles Carr, William Sweetingham, Rapheal De Buyretter, and George Belier.

The Chamber of Commerce Quarantine Emergency Fund has been increased to $155,885, yesterday's subscriptions amounting to $63,655, to be added to the $92,230 subscribed Wednesday. Wednesday'n list was corrected by changing the $5,000 placed opposite the name of Charles Lamer to the credit of Winslow, Lanier Co.

Ouly the expected arrival of the Bohemia of the Hamburg-American, Packet Company's line gave even an excuse for activity at the Quarantine boarding station yesterday. Dr. JenKins and his assistants expect to find in the Bohemia a worse state of affairs than they have found on any of the ships that have come in from Hamburg so far.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 15. -- At least twenty-five hundred people assembled in the Farmers' Tobacco Warehouse at noon to-day to hear the Hon. Adlai E. Stevenson's speech. He was escorted from his hotel by distinguished citizens of North Carolina, in carriages and a large procession of mounted men from the country adjacent to Asheville.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15. -- The weather improved a little to-day and the attendance at Latonia was considerably larger than it had been for several days. The favorites were regular losers throughout the day.

--Detective Geyer of the Philadelphia police force, who went to Brazil four months ago in search of Gideon Marsh, the rugitive President of the Keystone Bank, has returned to Philadelphia. He reports that he found no trace of Marsh. Geyer was sent, at the instance of Bondsman William H. Wanamaker, who said he had information that. Marsh was in Brazil.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 14. -- The departure from Brooklyn last Sunday morning of the cruisers Chicago and Philadelphia, under the pennant of Rear Admiral John G. Walker, under sealed orders for La Guayra, Venezuela, has given rise to much speculation concerning the mission of these two vessels of war.

PEEKSKILL, Sept. 15. -- The Depew Opera House was opened this evening very auapiciously under the management of Frederick M. Taylor of Newburg, the theatrical manager. This is the first theatre or hall of any size which Peekskill has had, and, in consequence, its opening was a gala event for the town.

An instance of Knavery is furnished by a report which was sent to THE NEW-YORK TIMES office on Wednesday night. It shows that there are evil-minded persons who are desirous of contributing to the cholera scare. A letter addressed to THE NEW-YORK TIMES, bearing a special-delivery stamp, was received at this office which read as follows:

Chairman Harrity of the Democratic National Committee, Chairman Don M. Dickinson of the National Committee's Campaign Committee, ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, Josiah Quincy, Senator Calvin S. Brice, Lieut. Gov. W.F. Sheehan, and Robert B. Roosevelt. Treasurer of the National Committee, all spent a considerable portion of yesterday at the National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue.

SPRINGFIELD, Sept. 15. -- The Springfield Bicycle Club was favored by an almost perfect day for cycle racing at this place to-day, and the postponed races of yesterday were run off on the Hampden Park track before an audience of 7,000 spectators. All the old-time faces in cycling were seen among the spectators, and it demonstrated that to Springfield belongs the palm for successful bicycle meets, as in the old days of 1885 and 1886.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a bulletin on the color, sex. and general nativity of the population of the States of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota. The total populations of these States are given as follows: Ohio, 3,672,316; Indiana, 2,192,404; Illinois, 3,826,351; Michigan, 2093,889; Wisconsin, 1,686,880 and Minnesota, 1,301,826.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 15. -- President Charles Noel of the Olympic Club said to-day that the club had done absolutely nothing toward farther pugilistic contests, and would do nothing for some time to come. The only contest now in mind was a match between Hall and Fitzsimmons. There has been no thought of offering a purse for Carroll and Bowen. A. match spoken of was a meeting between Corbett and Jackson.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 15. -- The first day's meeting of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland took place at Chickamauga to-day. At 10 o'clock the first meeting of the society was called to order at the Park Hotel. Gen. W. K. Rosecrans presided. No business except of a routine nature was transacted. It is understood that the meeting to be held in 1893 will be at Cleveland, Ohio, in December.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 15. -- Soon after the opening of Congress, which will take place tomorrow, Senor Romero, Minister of Finance, will present a measure declaring the titles to lands formerly belonging to the Church, but now owned by private citizens, to be good. This measure, if adopted, will greatly enhance the value of the property in question and thus increase largely the amount of taxes.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 15 -- Sealing schooner Triumph has arrived here from Copper Island. She brings news that further confirms the reports that additional seizures have been made by the Russians. She sighted the Russian cruiser Zadiaka south of Copper Islands, about forty miles off shore. A short distance away were four schooners, off their guard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The recently-issued statement of exports and imports of the United States for the month of July and the seven preceding mouths, with its usual bulletins of the achievements of the "reciprocity" trade, pre- sents some interesting figures that are strangely at variance with the claims of the champions of the much-vaunted new departure.

State Detective James Jackson of Sing Sing Prison, Westchester County, yesterday after- noon brought to this city from Sing Sing Charles Williamson, the forger whom he recently brought East from Missouri to serve out a fifteen-year sentence, in response to a writ of habeas corpus obtained by Lawyer William F. Howe, to show cause why he is held in custody by Warden Brown, the time for the expiration of his sentence having passed.

ANTWERP, Sept. 15. -- The measures taken to repress the cholera are totally insufficient, and the ostrich-like policy of the municipal authorities, who, despite the fact that cholera vicums are daily taken to the hospitals, continue to deny the existence of the disease, has caused the general public to forego personal precautions that no doubt would tend greatly toward checking the disease.

An application made by residents and business men near the dumping grounds of the Street-Cleaning Department and the Board of Health at Pier 60 North River, at the foot of West Tnirtieth Street, for an injunction to have the departments restrained from continuing the dumps, on the ground that they are injurious to the public health, was argued before Judge Beach in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday.

CARROLL, Iowa, Sept. 15. -- Gov. Horace Boies opened the national campaign in Iowa to-day in the most vigorous fashion for Cleveland and Stevenson. The Governor had an immense audience, and his appearance on the speaker's stand was the signal for a remarkable outburst of cheering.

It is about time for sensible citizens to consign all talk of a cholera epidemic to the realm of bugaboos. Such a calamity is not only not to be feared, bat it is practically impossible in this city. Whatever may have happened in history, cholera cannot now overcome the safeguards which have been reared against it.

Secretary of the Interior John W. Noble has just reached New-York after a trip across the country, on which, he devoted considerable time to the investigation of matters connected with his department of the Government. He was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, his face brown with a coat of tan which, he acquired on the Indian reservations of the Northwest.

George Drake Smith, dealer in lace curtains and uphoistery fabrics at 339 Broadway made an individual assignment yesterday to John G. Hyatt, giving preferences for $10,190 as folows: W. T. Smith Son, $4,300; Bromley Manufacturing company, $2,000; Hyndman Moore, $1,700; W. Rogers Co., $1,250, all of Philadelphia, and D. V. Smith. $940.

BUFFALO, Sept. 15. -- The fifth annnal Convention of the National League of Republican Clubs began at Music Hall at 11:20 o'clock today. It was called to order by John N. Scatcherd of this city. The Rev. Dr. Hubbell made a prayer, after which Judge Albert Haight was introduced and made an address of welcome.

For a couple of weeks to come, at least, the coal consumers of Now-York City will not have to pay any increase over present prices for domestic sizes. On and after Oct. 1. nowover, the price will be raised 25 cents, and perhaps 50 cents, a ton. This was decided last evening at a meeting of the Retail Coal Exchange.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The telegram from Montreal published in this morning's papers to the effect that quarantine had been declared by the health authorities of that city against New-York, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania has had the effect of alarming a number of persons who had intended visiting Canada on business or pleasure in the near future.

There was considerable activity at the Democratic State Headquarters yesterday -- the sort of activity that does not please Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Committee's Executive Committee, whose place of business is in Twentieth Street, just across from the Democratic State Headquarters.

The following challenge, which tells its own story, was sent yesterday by the Reform Club through E. Ellery Andersen, Chairman of the Committee on Tariff Reform, to the American Protective Tariff League, 23 West Twenty-third Street:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The officers of the Marine Corps are a good deal elated over the prominent part that arm of the service has been called to play in the operations against the encroachment of cholera in New-York.

The flatting in the vicinity or this city continues poor. While the number of parties that have gone out for the weakfish and the bluefish, have been few. owing to the cholera scare and the fact that a part of the Staten Island, weakfish grounds are within sight of the cholera ships. yet apparently there are few flan to catch.

The ranks of women anxious to establish common-law marriages have been added to in the person of Annette L. Madden, or, as she is known on the stage. Blanche Siegrist, who has sued in the Court of Common Pleas for an absolute divorce from William Madden, the sporting man and manager of theatrical exhibitions and pugilists.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 16. -- There has been an increase in the rates of river insurance on cotton. A leading insurance man said last night:

Speaker Crisp reached the city yesterday and spent the day looking over the political situation. He called at the Democratic National Headquarters and had a conference with Chairman Harrity. ex-Secretary William C. Whitnoy. Bradley B. Smalley, Don M. Dickinson. and the other managers. He also went to the Democratic State Headquarters and had a talk with Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan.
At last the Normannia's prisoners nave been Get free, all having been landed at the HamburgAmerican Company's dock in Hoboken yesterday alteraoon.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- For to-day Brussels reports 4 oases of cholera, Rotterdam 2 new cases and 1 death, and Dordreont 5 new cases and 2 deaths.

RICHMOND, Ind., Sept. 16. -- The track here was at its best this afternoon, and was probably faster than any regulation course in the world. When the horses were called for the third day of the circuit meeting only one of the fourteen heats was slower than 2:15.

The ferryboat South Brooklyn of the line plying between New-York and the foot of Thirty-ninth Street, South Brooklyn, had a narrow escape yesterday morning from sinking in midstream with 800 passengers on board.
The new freight steamer of the Fall River Line, the City of Taunton, arrived from Fall River this morning on her maiden voyage.

SPRINGFILED, Mass., Sept. 16. -- The second day of the bicycle races here, despite the postponement, has fully realized all the hopes of the promotors of the meet. Over 10,000 persons were present and the wildest enthusiasm prevailed at times. Zimmerman is the hero of the bicycle world and fully proved it by his riding to-day.

Fifth Avenue was treated to such a color display yesterday as it had not seen in many a long month. All Little Italy swarmed out of Mulberry Bend and tie streets south of Washington Square to see the great procession of the Italian societies march up the avenue and to Fifty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, where the cornerstone of the statue to Christopher Columbus was to be laid.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- L.F. Thoma, representing the German-American Cleveland Union, on a tour of the State organizing German clubs in the interest of Mr. Cleveland, paid a visit to the Young Men's German Democratic Club here tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- From dispatches received here it is learned that the Ameer of Afghanistan has consented to meet, at Jellalabad, Gen. Sir Frederick Roberta, who, with a large detachment of troops, was dispatched last month by the Indian Government to meet the Ameer.

The carnival of sports on Manhattan Field and the Harlem River to-day under the auspices of the Manhattan Athletic Club promises to eclipse all past efforts. In the athletic and aquatic contests firstclass men are entered, and some of the events ought to prove interesting. Handicapper Carter has done his work in good shape.

SOUTH MCALISTER, Indian Territory, Sept. 16. -- Intense excitement prevails in the Choctaw Nation. The agreement which was signed by prominent leaders of both parties has been rescinded, and war is liable to break out at a moment's notice. Both parties are continually receiving reinforcement despite agreements to disarm and disperse.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16. -- Favorites tared little better to-day at Latonia than they have done for the past three days. Dock Wick, at 5 to 1, beat the favorite, Critic, in the first race, and Roseboy and Diana, both rank outsiders, captured the second and fourth races, respectively. There was no betting possible on Prince Deceiver, and Dixie V. and Annie Bramble were the only well-backed favorites to win during the day.
ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 16. -- Fifty-nine new cases of cholera were reported in this city yesterday, against 55 the day before. The deaths yesterday were 8,9 less than occured Wednesday.

The will of Dr. Antoine Ruppaner has been filed for probate in the Court of Common Pleas. It was executed July 26, and John S. Keyes of Concord and Theodore E. Smith of this city are the executors. The estate, consisting of bonds and securities, books, oil paintings, water colors, and brio-a-brao, of which Dr. Ruppaner was a collector, is estimated as worth $250,000.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- Already Bleak House has taken on the air of habitation, and within a week there will be entertainment for man and beast. The irregular rooms and passageways which make up this "Dream of Fritz" are fast being put into condition for the bachelor junior Senator from New-York.

-- Charles Price of Salem, Mass., died Thursday night, aged eighty-three. He was a member of the firm of Pease Price, who carried on their business on High street for forty-two years. The two men were the closest of friends during their minority, went into partnership on attaining their majority, married sisters, all made one family and lived together in one household, which they shared in common.

Some Republicans who have been studying the situation in certain Western States have urged on members of the Republican National Committee a system of fusion which is quite sweeping in its extent it covers Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Nebraska, and South Dakota.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 16. -- A wedding celebration was in progress at 416 Court Street last night, the contracting parties being Herman Axelrod and Miss Nellie Singer, when Miss Emma Brown or 431 Wall Street rushed in brandishing a knife and made for the bridegroom, whom she tried to stab to the heart.

Gov. Flower, the State Fish Commissioners, and a party of friends returned yesterday from a trip on Lone Island Sound, where the oyster industries were inspected and the Governor had a chance to learn something about the methods of planting, propagating, and preparing the shellfish for the market.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16. -- Capt. George N. Stone, General Manager of the telephone lines of this city, has given official notice to the Police and Fire Departments that the subways for telephone wires are now completed in the central portion of the city, extending from Third to Court Street and from Broadway to Central Avenue.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 16. -- L. McKinney, a promoter of various schemes to got rich quickly, has left town and is being anxiously sought for by many creditors.

HONOLULU, Sept. 10. -- The Louisiana Lottery has presented itself for public favor here, and a bill was read in the Legislature Aug. 30 granting an exclusive franchise to D.H. Cross of Chicago, W.B. Davenport of St. Louis, and John Phillips, J.J. Williams, and Dr. Gilbert Foote of Honolulu to establish a lottery in Honolulu for a term of twenty-five years.

Reverdy Johnson, a guard employed by the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company in Brooklyn, was adjusting the bell rope from the first car of his train to the engine as the train was moving out of the Fulton Ferry station about 6 o'clock last night, when his cap was blown from his head by a gust of wind.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Inclosed find my check ($10) in renewal of my subscription to your paper for another year. I cannot say too much in praise of your paper as a model newsgather and for its cleanly, fair, and impartial comment on all questions, except one.

LOON LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 16. -- Drs. Gardner and Donghty visited Mrs. Harrison at 10 o'clock this morning, and again resorted to tapping to draw the fluid from the pleuric cavity. The physicians returned to the hotel from Mrs. Harrison's cottage about 1 o'clock, and each expressed himself as gratified at the result of the morning's operation.

There are no oases of cholera in Brooklyn and no suspected cases, according to the report of the Health Commissioner. The house 526 State Street, where a servant girl died of cholera morbas on Thursday, was quarantined all day yesterday, and will continue to be until the report of Dr. Steruberg's bacteriological examination of the dejecta of the deceased is made known.

The stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House held an important meeting yesterday afternoon in the Mutual Life Insurance Building. Nassau Street, to consider the question of rebuilding the parts destroyed by fire. The meeting was called at noon and remained in session about two hours. Instead of voting to rebuild, it was voted to sell the Opera House at auction.

Mr. John L. Andorson, whose home is in Flainfield, S.J., but who docs business in this city, spent fifteen years in China and has some interesting recollections of a cholera epidemic through, which he passed in that country. Mr. Anderson says:

Among the New-York State Democrats who have called at the Democratic National Headquarters. 139 Firth Avenue, within a day or two have been State Committeeman Alexander C. Eustace of Elmira, John J. Soannell, the Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District; John O'Brien, formerly Chairman of the State Committee, and Col. James E. Jones, who has often been hoard of in State politics and who is now a Port Warden.

CAMP LOW, SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- No cholera refugees were received at Camp Low to-day, though everything has seemingly been ready for them since 6 P.M. yesterday. The reason given for the non-arrival of the passengers by the surgeons in charge is that the supply of disinfectants and fumigatives had not been received.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 16. -- One of the most successful meetings ever held by the Riverside Gun Club took place here this afternoon. The club has recently inclosed its new grounds and otherwise improved them, and to properly celebrate their opening a number of the gun clubs in New-Jersey-were invited to be present. Invitations were accepted by the Newark, Hollywood, Long Branch, and Central Clubs.
The Chamber of Commerce Emergency Fund was increased yesterday by $24,886.94, raising the total for three days to $180,771.94.

-- An instance which illustrates the foresight of the English bluejackel and his conndence to the Admiralty is recorded in British service journals. One of the functions or the Accountant General of the Admiralty is to act as custodian of the wills made by seamen in the Royal Navy. These documents were all stored in a room sat apart for the purpose. About six years ago.
Arrangements for the Westchester County Fair, to be opened at White Plains on Monday, Sept. 26, closing Saturday, Oct. 1, are rapidly being completed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 16. -- The joint debates between Tom Watson and his Democratic competitor, Major J.C.C. Black, is at an end. Now the voters of the Tenth Congressional District will be left to study over what they have heard until election. The result of the joint debate does not come up to the expectation of either of the principals.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Fire Island is now a deserted strip of sandy beach. Only a few soldiers and hotel employes are loft there. Babylon and Islip redeemed themselves at the last moment, and offered no opposition to the landing of the Ripple, witn her long-delayed ocean voyagers.

Patrolman Florence J. Sullivan, who was accused some time ago of extorting money from excursionists while on duty on the police boat Patrol and was transferred to the West Sixtyeighth Street Station, aunt in his resignation from the force at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board. The resignation was accepted by the Commissioners without comment.

There was nothing specially attractive about the card at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday, and the attendance was only fair. But the racing was about the best of the meeting thus far, and the favorites or strong second choices won all the races, so that the players of form had a good day of it and made quite a bit of money.

As everybody knows, the word quarantine implies a detention of forty days. The term was probably derived from the nature of the forty days' fast of Lent. When the observance of quarantine came into use, in the fourteenth century, some mystical significance of sanitation was doubtless attached to the suffering of suspected travelers.

The Republicans of Brooklyn have prepared an elaborate programme for the Reid reception to-night in the Union League Club on Bedford Avenue. There will be a torchlight procession of which Augustus C. Tate will be Grand Marshal and Warren C. Tredwell Adjutant and chief of staff. The parade will be divided into lour divisions, viz., South Brooklyn, Western Brooklyn, Williarasburg, and Eastern campaigns. All the ward organizations and many campaign clubs will take part.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 16. -- There were 3,000 people here to-day to greet Mr. Stevenson, A large number were on horseback, and clubs from all parts of the State were well represented. The speaking was in the grove at St. Mary's School. An unusually large number of women were present. Senator Ransom, Gov. Jarvis, and a number of other prominent Democrats occupied seats on the platform.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 16. -- Charles W. Havemeyer, the millionaire son of the President of the Havemeyer Sugar Refinery of New-York, walked into the Bingham House to-night. He was considerably excited. In his hand was a copy of a newspaper of to-day relating the sale at Mr. Havemeyer's private offices in the Sibley Building, at 1218 and 1220 Filbert Street, whereby Mr. Havemeyer's private effects wore disposed of by a constable to the best bidders.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept, 16. -- The sub-committee on speakers of the Democratic State Committee has been arranging this week for a flood of oratory, to begin in earnest next week.
