Among those who are to expound Democratic doctrine from the rostrum are Gov. Russell of Massachusetts, ex-Congressman McAdoo of New-Jersey, and ex-Gov. Waller.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 16. -- Referring to the report from Sandy Hook that Dr. Hutton has resigned, Burgeon General Wyman says that he has not resigned, but that Dr. Button is worn oat and has asked to be relieved on that, account. Another man will be put in charge temporarily, but no one has been selected as yet.

In reply to Collector Hendneks a communication concerning immigrant traffic during the present cholera trouble, Messrs, Vernon H. Brown and Gustav Schwab, as a committee representing the steamship companies, have written as follows:

-- The London Monday Popular Concerts will this year start on a Tuesday. It has rightly been considered desirable that Mr. Paderewski should, if in any way it were possible, be secured to open the thirty-fifth season of these entertainments. The popular planist had, however, already accepted an invitation to give a recital at Cheltenham on Oct.24, and he is not the man to throw over any engagement for a more important one.

The cholera saare was pretty well dissipated yesterday in the down-town markets. Evidences of returning confidence appeared everywhere. The stock market was strong and active, with, recoveries throughout the list. Sugar was subject to some fluctuations, but closed steady at a substantial advance above Thursday's figures.

The Association of Democratic Voters of the Seventh Ward of Brooklyn at an enthusiastic meeting in Haviland Hall. 399 Classon Avenue. Thursday evening, were reorganized as a Cleveland and Stevenson Campaign Clab. C. Augustus Haviland called the meeting to order, and said that the association had as members 1,150 party workers.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 16 -- Thomas Linton, a ranchman, living near Ogo de Veranda, a few miles north of Presidio, in what is known as the Bloody Peninsula, has arrived here. He brings the news of a conflict between cowboys and a band of Mexican smugglers which occurred Monday night, fifteen miles north of Presidio.

An overzealous police officer last Thursday was the cause of an erroneous report sent to headquarters about a so-called "suspected" case of cholera. The case was that of Mrs. Jane White of 316 East Thirty-ninth Street, who was taken sick while visiting a friend at 1,442 Second Avenue. Dr. Herman Kahn of 158 East Seventy-fourth Street, who attended the case.

Yesterday was the second day of the open handicap tournament of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club, and the grounds at One Hundred and Fortieth Street and Brook Avenue presented a gay appearance, for the many pretty girls who eagerly applauded the clever strokes of the players wore gayly-colored costumes. This afternoon the gentlemen's singles and doubles will be played to the final round, and the final match of the ladies' singles will also take place.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A movement is on foot among the manufacturers of water works, pumping engines, and machinery to consolidate all the large plants in this country into a syndicate headed by the Crane Brothers of Chicago. Negotiations are now pending with the Holly Manufacturing Company, one of the most successful water works manufacturers, to secure a large block of stock and the ownership of its valuable patents.

The victory achieved by the Clevelands yesterday over the New-Yorks was something of a gift on the part of the latter. They should have won the game easily. The defeat, however, was due to the unsteady work of Crane. He appeared to have an off day. Just, at times, when it would have been good policy for him to put the ball over the plate, he pitched it out of Ewing's reach.

The latest " item" in the cholera scare is the announcement that Indianapolis proposes to quarantine New-York. All passengers from this town who visit the capital of Indiana are to be subjected to some examination in order to assure the sanitary authorities that; they are not of a contaminating kind.

An important conference was held in the Mayor's office yesterday forenoon between the Mayor, President E.P. Barker of the Tax Department, Commissioner Thomas P. Gilroy of the Department of Public Works, President Wilson of the Health Board, and President Martin of the Police Board. It was understood that the advisability of the proposition that the Mayor should request the President to prohibit immigration to this port until the cholera scare was over was discussed.

A telephone company, says the Electrical World, which for several weeks permits its wire to remain suspended across a public highway, a few feet from the ground, is liable to a traveler who comes in contact therewith during an electrical storm and is injured by a discharge of electricity. The duty on the part or the telephone company was clear to prevent its wire from becoming an obstruction on the highway.

There was not a new case of cholera in this city yesterday, as the official bulletins show The case of Edward Hoppe developed on Thursday. There is every reason to believe the max died from cholera, although the bacteriologies examinations have not yet so proved. Mary Conerty, who was stricken with the disease on Thursday, is still the only patient under treat ment.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: I hope that for the sake of justice you will not refuse to publish the following letter in the columns of your paper.

The Jeannette Gun Club, which probably has a larger membership than any other New-York City Gun Club, had its regular monthly shoot at Dexter Park, Long Island, yesterday. The club shoot is at ten live birds, modified Long Island rules, gun below the elbow, the use of both barrels, but the bird to be on the wine. There are three medals in the club for Classes A, B, and C.

Dr. W.T. Van Vredenbnrgh of the Medical Board of the New-York Life Insurance Company visited Spain in 1885 for the purpose of studying the cholera then prevalent in that country. So spent several months in Madrid, Toledo, Aranjuez, and Valencia, and subsequently made an official report to the United States Government touching the causes and effects of the disease.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- While Commissioner of Labor Statistics Charles F. Peck was acting in an unofficial and ungentlemanly manner this afternoon to the special committee of the National Democratic Committee, sent here to look over the data on which Mr. Peck based his high wages report, District Attorney James W. Eaton was weaving a chain of evidence about him that may possibly send him to State prison.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- Mayor Honey has taken the wind completely out of the sails of the so-called citizens' meeting held the other night by fowarding to Gov. Brown an official letter on the situation.

Some weeks ago the New-York Tribune sought to discredit the Aldrich report on prices in some remarks about carpets. Now the Cleveland Leader gives that report another kick. In its issue of the 12th inst., the Leader said:
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 16. -- The following explains itself:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The Committee on Sanitary Supervision of Passenger Traffic met this afternoon at the office of Dr. Benjamin Lee. Secretary of the State Board, of Health, to arrange the details on inspection work on the State board, especially the inspection of immigrants. It was found that there was a quorum of the hoard present, and a special meeting of the hoard was held.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Sept. 16 -- P.M. The stock market was weak in the early trading, but subsequently become firmer, and late in the day was very strong. The improvement, however, was at the expanse of activity, the total sales to-day being only 329,650 shares, against 466,341 shares yesterday. The strength was due to the taking of profits on the short side, and the market was almost wholly professional.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The following opinion has been given out for publication:

The investigation by the United States authorities in regard to the charge of the Venezuelan Minister that the steamer South Portland, now in this port, has aboard arms and ammunition intended for the Venezuelan insurgents, resulted yesterday in the arrest of Francisco Gonzales, the consignor and consignee of the alleged contraband goods.
"How much do you ask for beans?" inquired a small boy of the baker's wife.

B. Altman Co. of Eighteenth Street and Sixth Avenue have just received one of the most complete lines of imported Fall downs ever seen in this city. Among the makers are Felix, Raudnitz, Doueet, Honet, La Ferrlere, Savoye, and other fashionable Parisian makers. The gowns are to serve as models from which the firm's skilled dressmakers make up costumes for the customers of the house, or they may be purchased outright.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The following yachts passed Here to-day: Bound west -- Steam yacht Lorna. Passed East -- Steam yachts Isolene. Orienta, Helvetia, Tillie, Empress, Corsair, Vision, Vivienne, and Linta; side-wheel steam yacht Clermout; schooner yachts Avalon, Alcaea, Carlotta, Ramona, and Fenolla; sloop yachts Wizard.

BOSTON, Sept 17. -- The City Fathers were called upon last week to accept the official extinguishment of the plan recently advanced for opening up a vista from Washington Street to the Post Office. The plan would involve an outlay of something like $700,000, as land along Water Street is held at about $150 a foot, and the street thus widened would be only about 150 feet in length.

For the fifteenth, time in its history the National Guard Association of the State of New-York met in convention the last week. The meeting was held in the armory of the Twenty-second Regiment, and, although the attendance so far as the representation of organizations went was not so great as had been hoped for, the few hours covered by the session proved eminently productive.

Of the numerous Summer schools which have been organized, that of Glenmore in Keene Valley in the Adirondacks is the only one, so far as known, that continues its course well into the Autumn. The lecturers, who remain from the beginning to the end of this session, are chiefly from the Faculties of the great universities.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Four thousand spectators witnessed the bicycle tournament at the Hudson River Driving Park this afternoon. More interest was shown in the team race between the Poughkeepsie Bicycle Club and the Wappinger's Falls Club than in any of the rest of the contests. There were thirteen entries in the one-mile novice contest.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17. -- Several families have left for town or other places, but in almost every case have ordered their cottages kept open till Oct. 1. This is the case at the Travers cottage, which the Whitney family have occupied this Summer. Also at Mr. John Jacob Astor's cottage, he and his wife having left for Rhinebeck-on-the-Hudson.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- There have been no novelties at any of the down-town theatres this week, and but few at the up-town houses. "The Grey Mare," at Hooley's, has had a "very successful run, but will be withdrawn after to-night's performance, to make way for the new plays promised by Manager Daniel Frohman. "The Counciler's Wife," at the Columbia, has done very well.

The Association of Southern Democrats in New-York, which was organized for the special purpose or getting all Southerners who now reside here to go to the polls on election day, is likely to prove a very important factor in the Democratic campaign. Nothing like it has ever been organized here in a campaign before. Speaking of its plans and aims.

CAMP LOW, SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The passengers, either cabin or steerage, who are to be quarantined in the quarters here which have been prepared at such expense by Austin Corbin, will finally, it is now expected, be brought here to-morrow between the hours of 10 A.M. and 4 P.M.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 17. -- The fact that a few cases of cholera have appeared in New-York has made considerable impression upon some of the cottagers here. Several of them who were seen by a TIMES correspondent yesterday said that they should not return to New-York until they ascertained whether the cholera was to become epidemic or not.

From the London Telegraph. M. Robert Mitchell corroborates the testimony of his old comrade in arms, M. Paul de Cassagnac, relative to the personal appearance and demeanor of Napoleon III, at Sedan. In "The Debacle" M. Zola describes the Emperor as having glowing cheeks. The author adds: "Assuredly he had his face painted."

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept 17. -- A.M. Palmer, his wife, and child arrived safely at their country borne at Stamford, Conn., Friday morning. When Been by a TIMES correspondent today Mrs. Palmer was beaming with, delight at being safe and sound once more in her own home. She said:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17. -- Society in this city has no brighter ornaments than Charles Randall Garrison and William Snyder. The former is a son of the late Charles Garrison and a grandson of the late Commodore Garrison. Snyder is a son of the Rev. John Snyder, pastor of the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, the highest salaried preacher in St. Louis.

The wise historian rejects no document relating to his subject, without careful examination, no matter how trivial it may seem to be. He knows that small things often count for much in the making of States and the establishment of dynasties, and that information concerning the petty details of private and domestic life may often reveal to him the existence of rarely manifested traits of character in great personages.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 17. -- Oae of the most amusing incidents of the present national campaign is the Republican pretension that they have a chance or carrying West Virginia for Harrison. As a matter of fact, there is scarcely a chance that the Democratic majority for Cleveland for President or for Col. MacCorkle for Governor will fall below 3,000, and it is probable that it may go 2,000 higher.

One of the newest developers that has appeared is called amidol, and is of the same class as eikonogen and rodinal, but with the difference that it requires no aikali solution to accelerate development. Reports of its working in English journals say that it is put up in yellow bottles and resembles in appearance epsom salts. Its action is quicker when neutral sodium sulphite is added.

A very successful tennis tournament was hold yesterday afternoon on the courts of the Kings County Tennis Club, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn. The contests were men's singles and doubles, ladles' singles, and mixed doubles. The most interesting matches were the finals in the mixed doubles and men's singles. In the mixed doubles Miss Brush and Mr. Payne defeated Miss Hell wig and Mr. McGrath after a sharp contest.

It may be true that the doctrines of evolution have brought the lower animals up many pegs in the world -- or lowered man to a more modest rung on the ladder of perfection -- but we are still far from according to beasts, birds, and insects, reptiles and fishes, the position they once held in man's estimate of the universe.
NEW-YORK, Sept. 17 -- 4 P.M. No cases or suspected cases of cholera have appeared in this city since the last bulletin.

Novelties crowd so fast this Fall that they must be presented as they appear without regard to arrangement. Millinery, especially, is prolitle of new ideas, though many of the hat shapes are a season old. A new use of an old idea is the adaptation of the rosette to lines of hat trimming other than silk, velvet, and ribbon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The twenty-sixth annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic will he a great gathering. Its success from a spectacular point of view is already assured. It will also be, in regard to numbers and in many other respects, by far the most notable gathering that has ever been held at the national capital.

"Our Lady of Loretto," the new Italian church on Elizabeth Street, will be opened Sunday, Sept. 25, with a solemn high mass in the presence of Archbishop Corrigan and other distinguished clergy of the dlocese.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The alleged offer of $50,000 to Chief of Police McClaughrey by representatives of the Hawthorne race track for a political campaign fond if the rival track at Garfield was suppressed had a counter-bribery sensation to-day, with Garfield as the alleged, bribe offerer.

Who has not asked himself what is in a dog's mind, and how the animal so familiar to us regards himself? CUVIER said that the dog regards his human associates of the family to which he belongs as members of his pack, and that ingenious writer, Dr. LOUIS ROBINSON, expresses the same opinion in the Contemporary Review.

An evening paper yesterday quoted Gov. Flower as saying the State need not buy the Surf Hotel at Fire Island, because offers had already been made for it. "One Gentlemen paid he would make good my check for $50,000 on one day's notice the assume the balance," the Governor is represented as saying. The statement was further pubished that the man who made this offer was believed to be E.S. Stokes of the Hofman House.

Last Spring THE TIMES in this column made mention of a beautiful service to which two young women of birth and culture have devoted themselves -- that of establishing a school home for the children of families of a good class who, through death or other misfortune, have been deprived of the environment to which they are accustomed and entitled by blood.

Some of the high hopes which Chairman Thomas Henry Carter of the Republican National Committee has been entertaining that South Carolina was one of the States where Republican success was possible were put to a severe strain yesterday, when ex-Congressman Thomas E. Miller of that State called to see Mr. Carter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The contemplated transfer to the World's Fair grounds in this city of the bronze figure of Diana, which has graced the pinnacle of the dome on Madison Square Garden, New-York, has been a matter of earnest solicitude on the part of a number of wellknown and well-meaning women connected with several organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $164,201,350, as follows: Currency sixes, $11,828,000; 4 per cents, $130,335,700; 2 per cents, $22,037,850.

After a remarkably pretty game, the New-Yorks won from the Clevelands yesterday. From start to finish both nines put up a hard, earnest game of ball, and some of the plays executed were of the giltedge order. Rusie, who was so effective against the coming champions on Friday, was again put in the box and he gave satisfaction from a New-York standpoint.

The more sober and cautions, not to say the more honest, of the Republicans have pretty well concluded that the weapons of which Mr. HARRISON made so much in his letter of acceptance -- the charge of "freetrade Democracy" and of "wild-cat currency" -- are not available for serious use in this canvass.

Brooklyn Republicans had an opportunity last night to look upon Whitelaw Reid, grasp his hand, burn red lights, shoot off bombs, and tramp about the streets in his honor. The Union League Club planned a public reception for the Vice Presidential candidate and took extra pains to have a big hurrah in celebrating the real opening of the campaign for the Kings County Republicans.

The Republican County Executive Committee is not happy over the way in which its campaign is starting out. Several meetings have been held and long discussions have taken place, with the net result of an announcement yesterday that the campaign will be formally opened on Sept. 28 at Cooper Union. A mass meeting, at which "at least two speakers of national prominence" will be present, will then be held.
BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- Considerably excitement was caused here to-day by the actions of Mrs. Clothilde Fliess, who is said to be the widow of a prominent New-York physician.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The event of the season with the Summer colony at the picturesque resort of Millbrook, Dutchess County, this State, was the marriage to-day of Miss L. Grovene Vail. ("Daisy," as she is best known,) daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Vail of New-York, to James Converse of Boston.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 17. -- Arthur Frothingham of this city has undertaken the task of obliterating the minstrel "gag" from the provincial stage, especially the personal "gag," usually aimed at individuals who are much better known than appreciated by their fellow-citizens. Mr. Frothingham is a man of considerable tenacity, and when he has once set his mind to a thing he does not surrender his position easily.

LOS ANGELS, Cal., Sept. 17. -- Gervaise Purcell, manager of the Temesoal tin mines, was asked by an Evening Express reporter to-day regarding the report from Riverside that the tin mines had shut down because of lack of funds.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17. -- The first reunion of the Naval Veterans was held here to-day. In the parade were veteran sailors and marines, militia, the Grand Army of the Republic, Sons of Veterans, firemen, exempt firemen, letter carriers. Women's Relief Corps, and the members of Naval Veteran associations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17. -- Sir Edwin Arnold has, according to reports from several sources, acted in such a manner that the tongues of the people are wagging about him in a very lively manner in Mikado land, Joseph A. Gosser, an Australian, who has been sojourning in Tokio for the past year, arrived yesterday morning on the steamer China, and, in an interview, said:

BOSTON, Sept 17. -- The Glasgow steamship Prussian was released from quarantine this morning, after being for three days under observation. The Prussian reached her dock about noon, and by 1 o'clock her 234 passengers had all been landed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The weather for the past week has been that of June. Most of the cottage colony remain till after Sept. 20, and many or them till Oct. 1, to enjoy the Fall days after the jostling crowd has disappeared. September is usually active in real estate transfers, and in the past week there have been several sales.

These two big volumes, full of anecdote, cause the writer be called reminiscences, because the writer gives, besides his own personal recollections, of which, indeed, he has an abundant store, such traditions and stories as may from time to time have come in his way. However, when he has not known personally the subjects of his discourse, he has been usually able to get pretty near to them.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept 17. -- The Republican and Democratic State Conventions have now been held and their work has materially changed the political aspect by making a local issue the chief one in the campaign.
The second cabin passengers of the Guion Line steamship Wyoming, who have been held in quarantine since Sept. 6, have issued the following appeals to the public:

From the New-York Staats-Zeitung. Sept. 17. If a Republican President and Republican House should be elected this year the country would again be threatened by the Force bill and a further increase of the tariff, not to mention other baneful measures. The election of a Democratic House would protect the country against the worst, because it would act as a check upon Republican arrogance.

The tennis season of 1892 is practically over. The conclusion of the Newport championships really marks the end of the campaign, as the cooler weather brings with it the attractions of football. Only one tournament of importance yet remains to be decided, the intercollegiate meeting in October, which is held just after the beginning of the college year.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The fair season has fairly set in at the Water Gap. People who are to stay right through the Autumn are becoming established, and for two or three weeks there will still be a constant influx of others.

The Paris correspondent of the Vossische Zeitung relates a comic incident which took place during some cheap trips on the ParisHavre Railway. The pleasure-seekers found only half the necessary quantity of carriages at their disposal, and at the station Harfleur the overplus was put into a number of cattle cars, which were quickly provided with seats made of boards set upon blocks of wood.

From Garden and Forest. Recent issues of German horticultural journals report wide and active interest in the proposed displays at the Chicago World's Fair. Meetings called in various places to awaken such interest and make practical arrangements for contributing have boon largely attended, and at one held in Berlin, where not only local horticulturists but also those from distant towns were present, almost every person announced his intention of exhibiting.

HAMBURG, Sept. 17. -- The official cholera statistics for yesterday place the number of new cases at 276 and the deaths at 136. This is an apparent increase of 54 new cases and 38 deaths, compared with the figures for Thursday, but the increase is not actually as large as that for yesterday's, returns include 39 new cases and 36 deaths that occurred previously, and were not mentioned in former returns.

"I am very well satisfied with the situation in this State," said Lieut. Gov. Sheehan yesterday at the Democratic State Headquarters, 11 West Twenty-fourth Street. Mr. Sheehan was very busy during the latter part of last week, conferring with many prominent Democrats from up the State about the details of the vigorous campaign that is to be conducted above the Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The War Department people who are interested in the Division of Military Information, in which Secretary Elkins has taken a special interest, are a good deal wrought up over the continued failure to provide sufficient quarters for this growing branch of the department.

In these days most persons are more or less familiar with military drills, and through military schools even thousands of boys know as much about ordinary drills as the adult members of a crack regiment. But when naval drills are spoken of most persons wear a blank look. "How can sailors drill? What do they drill at?" are the questions usually asked.

This will be an eventful week in Brooklyn politics. The campaign is booming and both great parties have begun the battle. Kings County can be relied upon, the leaders say, to give Cleveland and Stevenson between 15,000 and 20,000 majority.

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- The theatrical season hero is beginning very badly. In Brussels -- that little Paris -- thanks to Bernhardt, Queen Cleopatra has opened the ball with great eclat. This actress begins now her Continental Winter campaign, and its promise seems everywhere brilliant.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Chicago proposes to be resplendent during the dedicatory ceremontes of the World's Columbian Exposition Oct. 20 to 23. Meetings of prominent citizens have been held, the Common Council has been interested, committees have been appointed, and schemes of decoration devised to beautify the smoke-begrimed city or hide the ugly contours of the "sky scrapers."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Secretary John W. Foster will leave here to-night for Loon Lake, to confer with the President in regard to the letter of Mayor Grant requesting the President to take some steps to restrict immigration during the cholera epidemic.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept 17. -- Gen. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, was in Charlotte to-day, accompanied by Mr. C. A. Ewing. Both made speeches. There was a great gathering of Democrats a horseback parade a mile in length being the feature. Old residents say it was the greatest political demonstration ever known here.

An important and interesting meeting or the Reception Committee of the General Committee of Arrangements having in charge the National Convention of Democratic Clubs and of the two monster parades of Democratic clubmen to take place here Oct. 3 and 4 was held in the banquet hall of the Hoffman House, Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 17. -- The dismal failure of the Republican opening after weeks of extensive preparation and much cheap advertising is the quiet talk of the party, and there is much evident disappointment over the matter. It was there that the lion and the lamb were to lie down together in the presence of an admiring populace, but the spectacle was not assuring.

"The Making of a Man," by the Rev.J. W. Lee, (New-York: Cassell Publishing Company,) takes for a theme that line of Pope, "The proper study of mankind is man." The author is fully abreast of the generalizations of scientific thought of to-day, and in a series of chapters leads the reader up to the spiritual nature of man.

From the Jacksonville (Fla.) Times-Union, Sept. 14. George W. Wilson of the Democratic State and Campaign Committees has been in charge of the headquarters for a month, and receives more political information, both National and State, than any other one man in Florida. Yesterday he said: "The political situation is all that could be desired, and the State has not been so thoroughly aroused since 1876.
The Orange Athletic Club nine failed to score a run against the Montclair Club on the former's grounds yesterday. Welch did not have a hit charged against him. The score:

Nathaniel Cleveland Moak died at his home in Albany, N.Y., yesterday morning. Mr. Moak was one of the most eminent lawyers of our times and a striking example of what may be accomplished by hard study and unyielding perseverance.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- The only dramatic entertainment entirely new to Boston that has been offered this week is that given by the ManolaMason Company at the Tremont Theatre. The audiences have been very large, for Boston claims as its own some of the leading people engaged in the performance, notably Mr. Mason, Mr. Booth, and Miss Annie Slarke.

From the Garden, London. The scarlet-flowered horse chestnut (Esculus rubicunda) has flowered unusually well this season, and it is unquestionably one of the handsomest of our rather limited number of flowering trees. Being of small growth, rarely exceeding twenty-six feet in height, it is peculiarly suitable for planting where ground space is rather limited and where one has to be careful in choosing trees of small and compact growth.
The I co d' Italia has received the following cable dispatch dated at Rome, Sept. 17:

Among the hills of New-Hampshire, near the old town of Gilmantown, a place famous for its theological seminary in stage-coach, times, stands a building which has been named by visitors the "Worsted Curch." In passing, one would not give a second thought to the little, yellow, box-like edifiee standing on the bare hilltop where two straggling country roads cross.

FIRE ISLAND, Sept. 17. -- The town of Islip flung a thunderbolt to-day on this island, which, forged paper though it was sent a nervous shock through the small settlement still here, consisting of soldiers, reporters, special policemen, telegraph operators, and what may be termed general camp sutlers.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17. -- A member of the Government said to-night that Sir John Abbott, the Premier of Canada, had tendered his resignation, and although Lord Stanley, the Governor General, did not wish to accept it, Sir John pressed the matter and it had been accepted.

The carnival of sports held at Manhattan Field and on the Harlem River yesterday under the auspices of the Manhattan Athletic Club was a grand success. No records were broken, and the performances of the winners were not of a remarkable character, but the sport was good, and the 6,000 ladies and gentlemen who witnessed the different events appeared to be satisfied, if hearty and frequent outbursts of applause are any criterion.

"The Scarlet Letter" seems to please the public, for it has drawn good houses since the first performance, and althougn its success will not increase Mr. Mansfield's artistic stature, yet it is not to be regretted. Everything that Mansfield does is done well, and his acting in this narrow and almost lifeless play is as good as possible. He is picturesque, dignified, and forcible.

From London Truth. The Empress Eugenie, says Truth, was by no means a bad woman, but she was a singularly foolish one. Brought up by a mother who was little more than an adventuress, occasionally living in Spain, and often roaming about Europe, she became strongheaded and narrowminded, with all the superstition of a Spaniard, and with all the tolerance of a lady who has lived much at Continental watering places.

That is the story of the Wyoming's cabin passengers in quarantine in the lower bay yesterday.

"Abiit, cxcessit, crasil, crupil." -- Cicero. On chaste Diana! scattered is the spell That bound thee to us; so a long farewell. Westward the star of virtue takes her way; Her empty spindle scars the dome or day. No Herostratos, hungering for fame. Assails her temple with devouring flame; But Seidl stops his ears against the yell, That greets young Corbett and the late John L. Al, ai: the temple and you towering void.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17. -- The attendance was very large and betting was heavy at Latonia track to-day. Goodale was the hero of the hour in the fourth race. He started last in a field of nine, but came out at the finish, and won by a head. Goodale was on four successive mounts. The track was very fast. Favorites won everything save in one race.
OGUNQUIT, Me., Sept. 17. -- "Why, haow to dew! Tur'ble glad to see ye; kinder feared you'd took sick or suthin'. Walk right into the haouse an' set daown."

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- At the International Orientalist Congress in this city a most interesting document was submitted by Prof. Hechler, Chaplain of the British Embassy at Vienna, a distinguished Orientalist.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept 17. -- Labor Commissioner Peck and his stenographer, Elbert Rodgers, appeared before Police Justice Gutmann this morning and each was held in $1,000 bail and the case adjourned until 10 A.M. Sept. 29.

BUFFALO, Sept. 17. -- Daniel Morgenstern, the Superintendent of Police, has gone to New York to arrest the men accused of killing the boy Broderick. He has warrants for the arrest of the parties and a stock of subpoenaes for witnesses. The prisoners, as soon as apprehended, will be brought to Buffalo.

Uncle Sam's section of Brooklyn furnished a lively blaze early yesterday morning and, besides consuming buildings valued at $30,000, scorched and twisted a lot of machinery and the costly engines for the cruiser Cincinnati. The amount of damage has been put at high figures but the navy-yard authorities say that it will not be more than $60,000.

An English journal devoted to education has been giving selections from papers submitted by girls in an examination on domestic economy. Some of these, remarks the Pall Mall Gazette, could, in unconscious humor, scarcely have been rivaled by a professional joker.
Cornelius Vanderbilt yesterday sent the following additional list of subscribers to the Columbus Celebration Fund to the Secretary of the Columbus Committee of One Hundred:
"New-York State will go for Cleveland by 50,000." This statement was made by Gov. Roswell P. Flower at the Democratic National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, yesterday forenoon.

The tennis tournament of the Brooklyn Lawn Tennis Club, which was held yesterday afternoon on the club's courts, at Throop Avenue, near Pulaski Street, demonstrated the good judgment of the Handicapping Committee. Very few matches have been won in straight sets, and most of them have had one or more deuce sets. Of the three class tournaments in the singles but one was finished yesterday, Mr. Rainstord winning in class C.

The Banks family were flushed with the feeling of coming victory, but they tried to stifle it. At least to outsiders they did not wish to appear vainglorious. Yet when one is at the very door of success it is hard to be cool and collected, and perhaps unnecessary in the privacy of home life.

A large number of spectators visited the grounds of the Knickerbocker Tennis Club, at One Hundred and Fortieth Street and Brook Avenue, yesterday afternoon, and applauded enthusiastically the many clever strokes of the players. Throughout the day the play was of a high order, and the final matches in the two gentlemen's events promise to be closely contested and very interesting.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 17. -- The club tennis tournament of the Orange Athletic Club opened on the grounds at the Orange Oval yesterday afternoon write a large attendance. The play was spirited, and good scores were made.

E.A. Stevens, President of the Democratic Society of New-Jersey, has issued a call for the convention of the society, which will be held at Camden, N.J., Tuesday, Sept. 27. The convention will open for business at 10 A.M. and officers to serve for a term of three years will be elected.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 17. -- The scholastic term at Yale will not open until the 29th inst., but the coarse in football will begin on the 20th. Candidates for the eleven have been requested to report on that day for work, and many of them are expected to be on time. The training at Newport during the Summer has done much for the men who are to fill the places back of the line.

Not a word need be said of Mrs. Oliphant's productiveness, or that, through long usage, there has been mental blunting. "Diana" is as fresh, as graceful, and as natural as is the first effort of the romancer, who, having at the outset given himself away, has nothing to give afterward. Would it be complimentary to say that Mrs. Oliphant understands Italy as Howells and James know it?

The police are investigating a cheap and clumsy infernal machine which was sent in a cheap and clumsy way to Gov. Flower at the Windsor Hotel on Wednesday night. To give it an added interest, the novel feature of an anonymous letter of warning preceded it by mail.

NEWPORT, R.L, Sept. 17. -- Politically, the week has been full of excitement in consequence of the municipal election, which should have taken place on Wednesday, going by default. The question is one over which even lawyers are puzzled and raises entirely now questions in State law.

Almost every New-Yorker of mature age and of the male sex discounted before its breaking out the news of the cholera in New-York. It was a matter of absolute certainty that, given the cholera in Europe and in Quarantine, the cholera would make its appearance in the city. To most people who were both experienced and observant the actual appearance of the disease was a relief.

"The Republican National Committee will confine its work chiefly to the National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic for the next week," said a Republican at headquarters yesterday. "It will send a good many workers to Washington to labor with the voterans with all the vigor they can command. The war will be fought over again, for political purposes, in the camp-fire reminiscences which the veterans always enjoy."
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- A.J. Nichols, an inmate of the Soldiers' Home, and G.W. Stevenson, a trunkmaker living on Lum Street, met awful deaths on the Jersey Central Railroad here this morning.

An alleged cable telegram recently appeared in a religious evening newspaper stating that M. Willot, the inspector of French telegraphs, had invented a system which promised greatly to accelerate ocean telegraphy, and if as fully successful as claimed would be of great benefit to the press and the business public generally, "from the fact," as the dispatch naively said, "that the new system will cause a reduction of tolls."

There may be more self-satisfied people than the Grahams of Armway, just as there may be suns more resplendent than Arcturus, but with-in the scope of their orbit they were the most abundant in beaming qualities.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- The British Consul at Palermo, in his report to the Foreign Office, gives startling details restarting brigandage. The whole island of Sicily, he says, is infested with bands of robbers, who capture large landed proprietors and rich merchants and hide them in caves in the mountains until they are ransomed. Farmers are plundered of horses and cattle, while peasants who are suspected of being informers are persecuted, tortured, or murdered outright.

DETROIT, Sept. 17. -- Eleven immigrants crossed the river at Wyandotte Wednesday night under cover of the darkness in two email rowboats, and left Wyandotte on the 10 o' clock train. The Custom House officials learned of the stolen march after the birds had flown, and reported the case to the Wyandotte health officers.

COMBER, Ontario, Sept. 17. -- A terrible boiler explosion occurred this morning in Force Dickinson's stave mill at Staples, a small village on the Leamington and St. Clair Railway, four miles from here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The War Department authorities have been hanging on with great tenacity to the report of the board which recommended a magazine arm for the army. It was known when the report was handed in, and as published in these dispatches, that the board had recommended an improvement on the Kreg-Jorgensen gun. Gen. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance, and Gen. Schofield both indorsed this recommendation.

LOON LAKE, N.Y., Sept 17. -- This has been the most favorable day Mrs. Harrison has had since she was stricken down with pleurisy, nearly ten days ago, and her physicians express confidence this evening of her recovery from that particular complication. They gravely admit, however, that the terrible seeds of consumption are still present, and are apt to continue their steady inroad on her constitution.

Judge George T. Werts has decided to accept the nomination for Governor tendered him by the New-Jersey Democratic State Convention at Trenton last Wednesday. He will not, however, make his determination public till he receives the committee appointed by the convention to notify him of his nomination. He will, in some way, arrange with the committee today for a formal meeting later in the week.

From the Portland (Me.) Argus. The veteran legislator, the Hon. William Dicker of Fort Kent, now eighty-one years of age, is among the members-elect to the next Legislature. Major Dickey has served thirteen terms as a member of the House of Representatives, his first year of service being in 1842, fifty years ago, while John Fairfield was Governor, as Representative from Strong, Franklin County.

The new Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Councel, on Ninetieth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, will be formally dedicated this morning by Archbishop Corrigan. The office of matins and lands was recited last evening by Bishop O'Farrell of Trenton, assisted by nine clergymen.

That distinguished Boston citizen and ex-champion "slugger" of the world, John Lawrence Sullivan, is many dollars better off this morning than he was yesterday, as the result of the benefit tendered him last night at Madison Square Garden. Mr. Sullivan sparred with his late antagonist, Mr. James J. Corbett, three rounds with gloves as big as feather pillows, making about as stupid and uninteresting an exhibition as one could well hope to see.

Our real estate contemporary, the Record and Guide, which has a habit of discussing the public interests of the city with information and good sense, is inclined to be skeptical about the ability of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners to find a purchaser for the franchise which they will presently offer for sale.

Every housekeeper in this community should be impressed with her responsibility at the present time. It almost seems as if each one held in her hands the preservation of the health of her household. Certainly she can largely contribute to that end by her care and fidelity the next few weeks. The trouble lies in the confidence born of taking perhaps one precaution.

An effort is being made to revive the old fight of the trades and labor organizations against the beer pool. The Journeymen Brewers, who have returned to the Central Labor Union, asked that organization to impose a special boycott upon Brewer George Ehret, on the allegation that he refused to employ onion men and discharged every employe who was known to read a labor paper.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 18. -- The construction work on the new United States torpedo boat No. 2. building at the Iowa Iron Works of this place, the first vessel of the new navy to be attempted on the Mississippi River, is fast nearing completion, and but for several unforeseen contingencies which have arisen since the contract for her building was signed, the vessel would be ready for launching to-day.

NORWICH, Sept. 18. -- The Republicans of Eastern Connecticut are evidently out for a still hunt in the national campaign. It has just come to light that the leaders lately arranged with the Home Market Club of Boston to supply them with several cords of protection tracts in Italian and the French-Canadian patois, to be distributed mainly in the mill villages of this part of the State.

TRENTON, Sept. 18. -- THE NEW-YORK TIMES may fairly claim the credit of having forced a plank into the platforms of both of the great party conventions that met here last week. It has saved the State school fund, the most sacred of the public reserves, from further spoliation.

CAMP LOW, SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- There are 700 cholera refugees at Camp Low tonight. All are from Hoffman Island. They are the steerage passengers of the ships Normannia and Rugia of the Hamburg-American Line. They were brought here on the boat William Fletcher. The first shipload, composed entirely of Normannia passengers, numbering 325, arrived at 12:55 P.M.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18. -- A distressing accident occurred yesterday afternoon on the cruiser Philadelphia during the bombardment, which considerably shortened the sham battle. The entire starboard complement of guns had been fired without any hitch, and everything pointed to a successful trial of the big breechloaders, as well as the small sixpound rapid-firing Hotchkies guns.

Nothing official has been heard by the officers of the Twenty-second Regiment concerning the arrival in this city of Superintendent of Police Morgenstern or Buffalo, with pockets full of warrants of arrest for everybody who was connected with the shooting of Michal Broderick at the time of the strike of the switchmen last month.

More than ten years have passed since the first volume in this Thoreau series was issued. That volume pertained to early Spring, and it came as a delightful addition to the works of one who, in Emerson's words, had in a short life "exhausted the capabilities of this world." Some years later came the other volumes, on Summer and Winter, and now we have a fourth, completing the series.

BEAVER, Penn., Sept. 18. -- The neighbors and political friends of United States Senator M.S. Quay are beginning to wonder how soon he intends to take hold in the campaign, and when he proposes to take up his canvass for the United States Senatorship.

Two young men working themselves through the crowd in front of the Union League Club in Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, during the reception to Whitelaw Reid on Saturday night attracted the notice of Detectives Reynolds and Moran of the Grand Avenue Station. As the crowd began to move away about midnight Reynolds made up his mind to get close to the suspected pair and took up a position in front of them.

The new synagogue of the Congregation of Kol Israel Anshi Poland, at 20 Forsyth Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon according to the ancient rites of the Jewish faith. The keys of the temple were presented to the President of the Congregation by Miss Annie Morris, acting on behalf of the Building Committee. The dedicatory address was delivered by M. Jachas.
-- Mr. Symonds's biography of Michael Angelo will be brought out this Fall by the Scribners.

READING, Penn., Sept. 18. -- Shortly after mid-night last night the residents in the vicinity of the Court House were startled by a mighty cheer, which continued for fully tea minutes. The jury in the case of Pietro Buccieri, charged with the murder of Sister Hildaberta at St. Joseph's Hospital, this city, last June, had reached a verdict. It was murder in the first degree.

Henry J. Mowry of Syracuse, a member of the Democratic State Campaign Committee, has been sit headquarters for the last few days. He reported that the Democrats of his part of the State were beginning the campaign with unusual activity.

Senator William D. Washburn of Minnesota and Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Each has been in his own State since Congress adjourned. Each asked the other yesterday for news.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 18. -- A pastoral letter from Archbishop Duhamel was react to-day in all the Roman Catholic churches of the Archdiocese of Ottawa urging the faithful to co-operate with the authorities in preventing an outbreak of cholera, and enjoining fasting and self-mortification, with the hope that the epidemic may be staid.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept 18. -- The reports which, have emanated from El l'aso to the effect that a revolution had broken out in Chihuahua or Sonora are untrue. The facts of the matter are as follows:

Dr. Jenkins said yesterday that all danger of cholera getting into New-York City was practically at an end. The danger of infection from steerage passengers was over, he thought, as there were no more ships coming from infected ports with steerage passengers on board. The only real danger, in his judgment, now lay in the handling of cargoes from infected ships, and particularly of goods put up in woven fabrics.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: The arrival in this harbor of vessels with cholera on board brings to my mind a sad remembrance of the last visit of the disease.

Congressman T.L. Bunting, in the National Provisioner, Sept. 17. Mr. Harrison in his letter of acceptance reiterates the exploded arguments of his party in defense of the tin-plato industry, so called, which has been born under the midwifery of his Administration.

-- The State County, and Municipal Governments of the South are now in Democratic bands, and there they should remain. The South has prospered under Democratic rule, and she would be still more prosperous if the National Government were in Democratic hands. It will be unfortunate for the Southern people if the solidity of the South is not maintained.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 18. -- The town was greatly excited yesterday over the reported discovery of a case of cholera, Lena Longes, a German woman who arrived here two weeks ago from Germany. A rigid examination was made for the cause of her stomach disorder, and it was promptly located. The woman had been in quarantine before she left the steamship, and all her baggage had been disinfected.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The invasion of New-York by the cholera scourge has a stirring significance for people here. Three times within the last sixty years has the Asiatic plague found a foothold in this county, and each time it has left a trail of death and terror behind it.

DUBLIN, Sept. 18. -- At a meeting in Limerick to-day a resolution was passed urging the Government to release Daly and the other Irish-Americans now imprisoned in English jails for political offenses.

From tne Portland (Me.) Press, Sept. 16. The outlook for the packing of Maine canned corn was never more promising, both for quality and for sales, for it is now problematical whether the packers can nil their orders. If, as it now seems, the packer and farmer are to go on harmoniously, Maine can double its output with profit to both.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Great excitement prevails in this city over the supposed discovery of a case of cholera, and the Mayor, police, Judge Rice, and the Board of Health are very active in sending out notices to all houses in the city, containing rules similar to those of the New-York board. Indeed, the Board of Health for a week has been making a house-to-house canvass of the city.

From the San Francisco Chronicle. The most successful beast tamers are generally email, wiry fellows, with plenty of nerve and a good stock of trade secrets, derived from toe close study of wild animals. In the latter respect savages, with their outdoor mode of life, have a considerable advantage over their civilized rivals.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 18. -- After the commutation by Gov. Buchanan of the sentence of Col. H. Clay King, condemned to death for the murder of David H. Poston, the brother of King's victim, Frank P. Poston, addressed a letter to Grover Cleveland, strongly deprecating the letter he had written to King's niece, Mrs, E.K. White.

From the Montreal (Canada) Gazette. When Mr. W. W. Ogilvie purchased Somerville farm at Lachine he came into possession of a deed that would make an antiquarian's eyes glisten with delight. It is written in the quaint, crabbed hand of the seventeenth century, in a curious old French that puzzles many of our archaeologists.

There is one feature of the recent cholera ex citement which should commend itself to the general public. That is the revelation of the utter absurdity of that useless institution the State Quarantine Commission.
