An early report to Health Officer Jenkins from Dr. Byron on Swinburne Island contained the intelligence that two patients had been transferred there yesterday morning from the steamer Bohemia, and had died of Asiatic cholera two hours after the transfer. Later came the report of three more cases, which were promptly transferred.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The third annual convention of the State Society of Democratic Clubs opened its first session in the Sixth Regiment Armory at 12 o'clock. Over 100 clubs were represented, and the armory building was well filled with delegates and guests of the society. The big hall was elaborately decorated with flags and bunting, and hundreds of Chinese lanterns adorned the walls.
In consequence of false and misleading reports which are being promulgated to injure the Associated Press, it has become necessary to make the following statement:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Dave Martin came to town yesterday and returned to New-York to-day. He frequented his favorite haunts on Monday night, and tried his best to laugh away the exposure which THE TIMES made of him. "It don't hurt me," he said to a party of his heelers. "It shows the other fellows that I must be a great fellow.

The unusual demand for buntings and red, white, and blue decorating stuffs has practically exhausted the supply, and as a result the figures on buntings to wholesalers have been advanced 15 per cent, and upward. This to regular customers. Occasional buyers have not been dealt with so leniently, and for them prices have ranged from 50 to 100 per cent, above the ordinary rates.

Gen. Martin T. McMahon, Grand Marshal of the Columbian celebration, issued yeaterday an order relative to the military parade of Oct. 12, giving the following corrected list of appointments on the Grand Marshal's staff:
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 27. -- Yale football men have a good piece of news. Hinkey, the phenomenal end rusher, who was reported to be too ill to return to college, will come back and will play football.

The body of Bandmaster Patrick Sarsfield Gilmore arrived at the Grand Central Station from St. Louis, accompanied by his widow and daughter, and Messrs. Schultz, Cilm, and O'Reilly of his band, just before 8 o'clock yesterday. A large concourse of his comrades in the Musical Mutual Protective Union, Musical Post, No. 452, G.A.R., and other organizations, together with many friends, was present to pay honor to the dead leader.

-- The father of Carter, the catcher and first baseman of Yale, inquired into the financial condition of the baseball association, and learning that it is not overburdened with wealth, has made a very generous offer. Mr. Carter told Capt. Lauri Bliss of the nine that, he would pay the salary of a professional player through the college season to coach the ball players in pitching and batting.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The Life and Reserve Association of Buffalo, a life insurance company which has 5,000 members in NewYork, Ohio, and Pennsylvania, will probably go into the hands of a receiver this week. A motion to that effect was made in Special Term yesterday afternoon, and a hearing was granted this morning.

BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- Nobody expected that Tremont Temple would be crowded to its utmost capacity to-day. Nobody anticipated the presence of 1,200 or 1,400 enthusiastic delegates to the Democratic Convention. There was no contest. Every candidate for office was nominated by acclamation and general consent. Why did all these workers pour in from every nook and corner of the State?

Alderman Patriot J. O'Beirne of the old Third Assembly District gave a performance at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen that will entitle him to retirement to private life. He has been endeavoring to distinguish himself ever since he got into the board, and he apparently succeeded in doing so yesterday.

Alderman Patriot J. O'Beirne of the old Third Assembly District gave a performance at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen that will entitle him to retirement to private life. He has been endeavoring to distinguish himself ever since he got into the board, and he apparently succeeded in doing so yesterday.

The Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad met in this city yesterday and voted to withdraw from the Western Traffic Association for the avowed reason that that organization "appears to have outgrown its usefulness." The action of the Directors was unanimous.

Major Arthur Morris, United States Army, (retired,) died of heart disease at his residence, 106 East Seventy-fourth Street, Monday night. He had been a sufferer from heart failure and Bright's disease for many years.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27. -- The West Virginia Central Railroad is preparing for another effort to gobble up the Western Maryland, and the fight is expected to be lively and interesting. Behind the West Virginia Central is the Pennsylvania, and secretly assisting the Western Maryland are the Baltimore and Ohio and the Reading.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The signs of mourning for Gen. James W. Husted continue to grow in Peekskill. Not since the body of Gen. Grant passed through this city on its journey to its last resting place have the emblems of mourning adorned the stores and residences of Peekskill. Never before has this been done for one of its citizens.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 27. -- For the first of the Western Southern Circuit meetings hero to-day the fine weather, smooth track, and lively sport assured a better patronage. All the heat winners improved their records. Winslow Wilkes scoring 2:09 3/4 in the pace.

Yesterday the Democratic Convention in Boston unanimously renominated Gov. WILLIAM E. RUSSELL, and took an advanced position upon the issues involved in the national campaign. It is the fifth time that Mr. RUSSELL, still a young man, has been the candidate of his party for Governor of Massachusetts, and twice he has been elected in the State which was formerly the stronghold of New-England Republicanism.

Let me mention one further illustration. Under the Administration or President Arthur a lady named Isabefla De La Hunt was appointed Postmistress at Cannelton, in this State, on the recommendation of Senator Harrison. She was the widow of a soldier who died of wounds received in the service. I think it was on some complaint of offensive partisanship that she was removed under Cleveland's Administration and a Democratic politician and editor appointed in her place.

Henry Gillis, a former employe of the London Portrait Studio Company of 105 Fourth Avenue, was arraigned before Justice White in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning and held in $50O bail for practicing a uniqe swindling scheme.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind, Sept. 28. -- Nothing that Nancy Hanks can do in the way of speed seems to be so surprising as when she placed the world's rec- ord at 2.04 this afternoon. The big crowd was quite prepared for the feat. The day was the warm- est of the week, bright and clear, and the track re- ceived a careful preparation last night for the queen's supreme efforts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The attend- ance at the Westchester County Fair was some- what smaller to-day than it was yesterday, owing to there being no pony racing. There is hardly a member of the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association who would not travel many miles to see the game little ponies ridden by gentlemen jockeys, and on Tuesday every member who could possibly get there was at the county fair.

The Banquet Committee of the Columbian celebration met at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the Stewart Building, with George C. Clausen in the chair. Gen. Horace Porter and John A. Cockerill were appointed a subcommittee to select a list of speakers for the banquet to be given in the Lenox Lyceum, with instruction to report at the next meeting of the committee.

One of the finest political, clubhouses in America was formally dedicated last evening in the Eastern District of Brooklyn as the home of the Bushwick Democratic Club. As Mayor Boody, who was a speaker at the dedication exercises, pointed out the event had a peculiar and unusual significance, indicating as it did in the most unmistakable manner the remarkable wave of enthusiasm that is sweeping over the Democratic Party.

RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The Democrats of Union County have discovered, and have taken official means to block, what is believed by many of them to have been a scheme on the part of the Republicans to colonize a large number of colored persons in and around Rahway and at various points in the county, and poll fraudulent votes at the Presidential election in November.

BALTIMORE, Sept 28. -- The death ot Mrs. H. Newell Martin, wife or Prof. Martin of the Johns Hopkins University, takes away one of the most remarkable and brilliant women who have given Baltimore its reputation for beauty. Mrs. Martin had been in falling health for some time, and the improvement which began at her cottage at Bar Harbor was only temporary She died of nervous prostration.

MADRID, Sept. 28. -- The monastery at Azpeitin, the town in the Province of Guipuzcoa near which Ignatius Loyoln, founder of the Society of Jesus, was born, is the scene to-day of a great meeting of members of that order. Provincials of the society from all parts of the world have assembled to-elect a successor to the late Father Anderledy, the General of the Jesuits.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Sept. 28 -- P.M. The stock market is rapidly dropping back into the condition of apathy which prevailed in the early Summer. The transactions to-day were considerably less than 200,000 shares, and not one of the stocks on the active list was changed as much as a point. As is natural under such circumstances the drift of the market was toward lower prices.

CAMP LOW, SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The authorities here are in the dark as to when another shipment of passengers will be received. The camp was cleared yesterday of all cholera suspects except Mrs. Gutel Domiz. convalescent from cholera, and her four children.

The annual meeting of the New-York, Ontario and Western Road was held at the offices of the company. 56 Beaver Street, yesterday. The number of shares represented was nearly 400,000 out of a total of 580,000, and the total vote was the largest in the history of the company, being 337,316 shares.

Creedmoor wore somewhat of its old-time look yes- terday, the matches between teams of the several regiments of New-York, and Brooklyn for the State and Brigade prize, drawing out a large number of spectators, conspicuous among whom were Gov. Flower and the members of his staff, who had come down to the range in a special train of the Long Island Railroad, provided by the Chief of Ordnance, Brig. Gen. Joshua M. Varian.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Labor Commission- er Peck and his stenographer, Elbert Rodgers, appeared in the Court of Sessions this afternoon at 3 o'clock, the time set for them to plead to the indictments found against them for destroying public records.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday gave a public hearing on the nine applications of the Metropolitan Traction Company for franchises for extensions of their system of street railroads in this city. The most important of these are to be sold at public auction if granted, but there is no question, as to the purchaser.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- William S. Williams of New-York began suit in the Circuit Court today against Robert Lindbloom of this city and N.S. Miller of New-York on a judgment for $63,705.16, recently obtained against them in New-York on an accounting between them as partners of the firm of Robert Lindbloom Co., doing business on the Board of Trade from July, 1883 to April, 1884.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept 28. -- The Democrats are elated over the unprecedented success of the Shelbyville barbecue to-day. The attendance is estimated from 35,000 to 50,000. The fair grounds were not large enough to hold the crowd, and it took twenty roast beeves and a great number of sheep to feed the people attending from all directions.
ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The Republican campaign is now in full blast, and from every county in the State but one report comes -- that the wheels of the machine are abundantly well oiled with money.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Under the authority conferred by the last naval appropriation bill, providing for the construction of two new vessels for the navy, one a sea-going battle ship of 9,000 tons' displacement and one an armored cruiser of 8,000 tons' displacement, proposals were to-day issued by the Navy Department for their construction.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- The statement of the business of all lines of the Pensylvania Railroad Company shows that all lines east of Pittsburg and Erie for August, 1892, as compared with the same month in 1891, show an increase in gross earnings of $14,232; an increase in expenses of $240,749; a decrease in net earnings of $226,517.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Charles Peshall, the attorney for the ballot-box stuffers, made a successful effort in their behalf to-day before Judges Green and Acheson of the United States Circuit Court.

On the evening of Sept 29, 1842, sixteen men met in Teetotalers' Hall, in Division Street, this city, and organized a society for the promotion of temperance. That meeting was the nucleus from which has grown the Sons of Temperance, an organization with nearly 70,000 members. This evening the Sons of Temperance will celebrate the semi-centennial of their society with a mass meeting in Carnegie Music Hall.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept 28. -- The Mexican railway pool recently formed in London has been completely knocked oat by an official communication issued by G. Costa, a Secretary of the Department of Communications of the Mexican Government. A copy of this document was received by shippers here to-day.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28. -- The New-Yorks by their work here during the past few days proved that they are in great shape. They won three straight games from the Orioles, and are now ahead of the Brook- lyns in the pennant race. This fact seemed to please President Day, as well as the members of the team, and all han is left for home to-night in a very jubi- lant mood.

THE CURRENCY ISSUE. It is not an unusual device for a sharp lawyer with a poor case to ignore, and to try to make the jury ignore, the chief point at issue by spending a great deal of time and energy upon a minor point. The device is equally prevalent in politics. The friends of the present Administration are resorting to it in this campaign with reference to the financial issue.

NEW-YORK. -- On Monday evening there will be a rally of Bible teachers of the city in the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. The Rev. Dr. Arthur T. Pierson, who is to succeed Charles H. Spurgeon in London, will deliver an address.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The last of the jack- ets was yesterday slipped over the breech of the great thirteen-inch gun at the Washington Navy Yard and the immense piece of ordnance is now Hearing completion. The work is one of more than usual interest, and every step is being carefully watched by Capt. Sampson, the inspector in charge at the yard.

Patrick Sarsfield Gilmore the great bandmaster who for more than a quarter of a century centred in himself and his incomparable Twenty-second Regiment Band the attention and the applause of the people of this country, was yesterday borne to his rest in Calvary Cemetery amid a great display of honor and love from those who knew him as a friend and those to whom his music had given hour upon hour of pleasure.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28. -- "Harry" Jewett of the Detroit Athletic Club, who made a world's record at the Canadian games last Saturday; Theodore Luce of the same club, world's champion in the pole vaults, and James McGee, Western champion in the mile walk, have been in this city since Tuesday. They are on their way to New-York, where they will take part in the games Saturday.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- There was a big crowd at Mystic Park to-day at the trotting meeting, and it indicated that the races of the Trotting Horse Breeders' Association are growing in popular favor. There was some of the prettiest trotting ever seen on the track in the 2:15 and three-year-old races, although Star light won the latter in three straight heats and Nightingale the former in the same manner.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept 28. -- Howard L. Emerson of Central Avenue, a prominent young New-York lawyer, a member of the Seventh Regiment and a club man, disappeared early last Summer. He was an executor of the estate or Mrs. Susannah Stillman and was short $8,000 in his accounts.

BOSTON, Sept 28. -- The steamer Watertown, Capt. Alley, which left here about 12:20 to-day for Lynn, took fire before site reached Shirley Gut, and will be a total loss. Her passengers and crew were taken off by the tug Chase and landed at Point Shirley. The Watertown was owned by John E. Cassidy of Boston and is fully insured.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The Syracuse Athletic Association had its Fall race meet at Kirkwood Driving Park yesterday in the presence at a large crowd of people, who were attracted chielly by the Central New-York championship bicycle races between teams of three men from Oneida and Syracuse. The rivalry between the men has been intense all Summer long.

Thomas C. Platt, repentant and willing to be forgiven for ever having fought against President Harrison, made an effort to smother the bitterness that followed the President's broken promises and bring forth works meet for repentance at Cooper Union last night.
BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- In the platform of princi- ples adopted by the Democratic Convention yesterday was this suggestion:

BOSTON, Sept 28. -- The steamship H.M. Whitney of the Metropolitan Steamship Company was run into and sunk about 7 o'clock this evening just abreast of Gas Buoy No. 9, Boston Harbor, by the Warren Line steamship Ottoman. The Whitney now lies in an uncomfortable position in midchannel, between East and South Boston, near the Bird Island Flats.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept 28. -- The solemn chant of that ancient piece of Roman liturgy, the requiem for the dead, filled the Catholic Church of St. Mary's, on High Street, on the opening of this the third day of the sixth annual convention of the German Catholics of the United States. Mgr. Schroeder delivered a sermon and Bishop Messmer of Green Bay was the celebrant.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 28. -- A destructive fire broke out at 2:10 o'clock this morning in the cabinet shop of the Singer Sewing Machine Works, Elizabethport, and rapidly extended to the carpenter's shop, roundhouse, paint shop, lower engine room, and pattern shop. It required four hours' hard fighting on the part of the Elizabeth Fire Department, aided by the steam lighter Advance from Bayonne, to get the names under control.

Although the Cooper Union meeting held to denounce the Geary registration law was very spirited, and although the Six Companies in San Francisco and the Chinese Civil Eights League in this city are thoroughly aroused, it yet remains to be seen whether the hundred thousand Chinamen in this country can be brought to disobey that law.
BALTIMORE, Sept 28. -- A clergyman in this city says of "Vatican influence" upon the election of the Superior General of the Jesuits:

Fifty-three residents of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn marched Into Mayor Boody's office yesterday, headed by the Rev. C.K. Cressy, and made one more and very distinct and emphatic demand upon the Mayor to put a stop to the stench nuisance.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Livery of the City of London met to-day in the Guildhall to elect a successor to Lord Mayor Evans. The Guildhall was crowded, and unusual interest was taken in the proceedings, owing to the fact that strenuous opposition had developed against Mr. Stuart Knill, Alderman for the Bridgewithin Ward, who stood next in rotation for the Lord Mayoralty, because of his religious faith, be being a Roman Catholic.

Efforts are again being made to put in circulation counterfeit two-dollar bills, but it is probable that all the "shovers" of the bad money will be arrested before many of the bills have been unloaded upon the public. Five Italians have already been arrested for passing the counterfeits, and are now awaiting indictment by the Grand Juries of Brooklyn and New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29. -- The first National German-American Union to be formed in Connecticut was organized in this city to-night. A large delegation of representatives, including a delegation from every ward in the city, met at the invitation or L.F. Thoma of New-York and had the details of the great organization explained to them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- There was a little more interest in provisions all around. October ribs led the interest,, naturally, but there was a more general demand for other product. The receipts of hogs at the yards were under the estimates, but there was not a good demand and prices were off. This had no apparent effect on the speculative market. Cash sales were again large, with moderate receipts.

The decision recently rendered by Judge Bartlett in the Supreme Court, Special Term. Brooklyn, upholding the reapportionment of Kings County under the act of the Legislature of 1892, was sustained yesterday in an opinion handed down by the General Term, consisting of Judges Barnard, Pratt, and Dykman. The latter wrote the opinion, the others concurring.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29. -- Above 3,000 people witnessed the Latonia races to-day. The track was fast and the time made was fair. Prince Deceiver, the winner of the Edgewater Handicap in the fourth race, took $1,950 as his share. Delays in making the starts caused toe last race to be ran by moonlight. There were very close finishes in every race except the second and fourth.

The magnificent scale on which Repeater "Dave" Martin is to conduct his shady politics in the effort to elect Benjamin Harrison has never been equaled -- so it is said. Even in the campaign of 1888, when "Dave" had a hand in carrying out Quay's schemes with John Wanamaker's four-hundred-thousand-dollar fund, Martin was not in a position where he could go into the business of corruption in such a wholesale way.
NEW-YORK. -- Michael J. Butler was reinstated as assistant weigher at the Custom House yesterday at $4 per diem, not including Sundays, and Patrick J. Leahy was appointed clerk, at $1,000 per annum.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 29. -- Wesleyan University opened to-day with the largest attendance in the history of the institution. The freshman class numbers an even hundred, about twenty more than ever before.

PEERSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The body of Gen. James William Husted was to-day laid to rest on a shady knoll in Hillside Cemetery in a grave which overlooks his late home and the village of Peekskill, and commands a beautiful and extensive view of the Hudson River.

-- Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, was asked to commit Lazarus Wolff for contempt of court in failing to pay alimony to his wife. Henrietta Woff, who is suing for divorce Wolff's lawyer said his client would have paid the alimony of $10 per week had Mrs. Wolff not broken into his house and taken deeds and diamonds worth a large amount of money.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- The Evening Record says: "It is learned on the best authority that every railroad corporation operating in Massachusetts and doing an extensive business will not comply with the law passed by the last Legislature requiring them to have on sale mileage books representing 1,000 miles for $20 and interchangeable on all railroad lines in the State.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Gen. Plume, commanding the National Guard of New-Jersey, today issued a special order for the participation or a provisional brigade of the guard in the Columbian celebration in New-York City on Oct. 12. The brigade will be constituted of the First and Third Regiments and Gatling Gun Company B. Brigadier and Brevet Major Gun. Company J. Sewell is to be in command.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The committee appointed by the Postmaster General to examine into the subject of a more rapid dispatch of mall matter between large cities and Post office stations in large cities by means of pneumatic tubes or other devices has submitted its preliminary report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- About the 15th of next month the new return postal card will be placed on sale at all Post Offices. The two designs, one for the domestic and the other for the International Postal Union service, have been approved by Postmaster General Wanamater, and the work of printing and distributing the cards will be pushed with vigor.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., Sept. 29. -- The Windham County Bank of Brooklyn, Conn., has attached the interest of Thomas C. Peckham of Coventry in the Oneco Manufacturing Company for $15,000. The attachment was placed to secure to the bank payment of the alleged forged notes of Mr. Peokham, which it holds and which fell due on the 18th inst.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 29. -- "Has Chris Magee come to town?" was a common inquiry here to-day among politicians. It had been announced upon the best Republican authority that Magee would to-day make his third visit to this State to consult with the Republicans, who have made an alliance with the Kolb party, with the common object of taking Alabama out of the Democratic column.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- M. Camille Krantz, Commissioner of the French section for the World's Columbian Exposition, will leave Paris on Saturday next to be present at the dedication ceremonies that are to take place at Hampton Roads and Chicago. None of his staff accompany him, as he inten is returning soon.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Proceedings by virtue of a writ or inquiry in the case of Fred G. Wethy against half a dozen young men of Pavilion, in this county, ended to-day when the jury, after two hours' deliberation, rendered a verdict of $300 in favor of the plaintiff. One of the jurors was in favor of a verdict of $1,500, the lowest figure considered being $30.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- The beautiful new Schiller Theatre on the north side of Randolph Street, between Dearborn and Clark, was formally dedicated this evening with appropriate ceremouies. Cards of invitation were issued to the stockholders, and, as the house seats but 1,300 people, but few outsiders were permitted to attend.

What was considered an important gathering of Republicans was held yesterday in one of the rooms on the third floor of the National Republican Headquarters, 518 Fifth Avenue. There were present Chairman Carter, ex-Chairman Clarkson. Treasurer Bliss, and Secretary Charles Foster of the Treasury Department. This was Mr. Foster's second visit to headqurters since his arrival in this city Wednesday.

Things Democratic are lively in the Twentyninth Assembly District, and they promise to be extremely active during the remaining weeks of the campaign. Jacob Seahold, the new district leader, has perfected his organization, and promises a majority for Cleveland which will nearly equal the regular Democratic majority of the whole of the old Twenty-fourth District.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept 29. -- Coroner Everett and a jury held an inquest to-day in the case of seventeen-month-old Katie Richter, daughter of George Richter of Jamaica Bay Meadow, whose head was actually shot off on Wednesday morning.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Yorkshire Post says that, as a result of the recent outbreak of C Squadron of the First Regiment of the Life Guards at Windsor, the War Office has decided that the Guards shall henceforth be treated the same as other soldiers, and shall take foreign service the same as other regiments.

PRICETON, N.J., Sept 29. -- Several hundred students and alumni witnessed the regular football practice on the university field to-day. Some changes were made in the composition or the eleven. Lee, '96, played left end and Andersen, '96, full back. Homans, '92, and Bartels. '96, doing excellent work as halt backs. King took Bartels's place in the second half. Poe played quarter.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Another large crowd saw the races of the Horse Breeders' Meeting at Mystic Park this afternoon. The 2:20 stallion race was the drawing card, but it proved far too one-sided to be very interesting, although in the second heat Kremlin lowered the track record for trotting from 2:13 3/4, made by him two weeks ago, to 2:13. Kremlin was driven by F. Bithers, and Orrin Hickok sat behind Constantine.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 29. -- Though the People's Party has gone through the form of holding a State Convention, and has nominated a fall State and Electoral ticket, it will not figure to any appreciable extent in the Connecticut returns.

Mr. JOHN D. CRIMMINS, President of the Metropolitan Traction Company, at last openly avows that it is the purpose of that company in completing its lines of surface road under the west side elevated structures, connecting the Sixth and Ninth Avenue lines through West Fifty-third Street, and extending the latter to One Hundred and Tenth Street, to adopt the trolley electrical system for propelling the cars.

Almost all of the Democratic campaign, managers were at the National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. Chairman Harrity of the National Committee, Chairman Don M. Dickinson of the Campaign Committee, Bradley B. Smalley, Lieut. Gov. Sheehan, S.P. Sheerin, Senator Arthur P. Gorman, ex-Secretary of the Navy William C. Whitney, and Josiah Quincy wore all on duty.

Union Theological Seminary has opened its doors for another year, and with no uncertain sound has it proclaimed its position in the world of religion. At least, it is fair to infer that there need be no question as to the policy of the institution, judging from the remarks made at the opening exercises yesterday.

In one of his bilious and amusing "Latter Day Pamphlets" the late THOMAS CARLYLE remarked: "The Bishop of our diocese is to me an incredible man. Mankind does not even read those charges of his, preferring speech which is articulate." There may be American Bishops to whom this description still applies, but the Bishop of New-York is not one of them.
The Democratic Club opened the doors of its clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue, last night to welcome home its President, J.H.V. Arnold, President of the Board of Aldermen.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The returning Americans on board the steamer Marathon will not be landed, as was ordered by the Board of Health a few days ago, as Collector Beard has raised another point which forbids it.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 29. -- A grand wedding took place to-night at the residence of Oliver S. Carter, on Mountain Side, West Orange. Miss Alice Grifling Carter, Mr. Carter's daughter, was married to Frank Halsted Ballard of New-York.

An atrocious and, so far as police investigation has determined, motiveless assassination was perpetrated a little after 7 o'clock last night on the top floor of the four-story tenement 139 Hester Street.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29. -- Baltimore continued the cricket match to-day with the Gentlemen of All Ireland. The score yesterday was: All Ireland, 247. To-day Baltimore went to the bat. In the first inning Baltimore scored 158, and in the second inning 62, making a total of 210, All Ireland winning by an inning and 37 runs. Summary of to-day's play:

A general call has been issued for a meeting to be held in Chicago from Oct. 19 to 22 to take stops toward the formation of a National League of Road Improvement. All local road societies, boards of trade, wheelmen's organizations, and private individuals interested in the subject are invited to take part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- An unreasonable quarantine is being enforced upon American ships by the authorities at Havana, Cuba, according to advices received in this city. A desire on the part of the Havana officials to "get even" for a ruling by the United States Collector at Key West is thought to be the cause of the rigid and annoying quarantine.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29. -- The entire lot of animals composing the Spendthrift stud were sold here at auction this afternoon. The bidding was spirited, and prices ruled high. Spendthrift was the first offered, and he brought $13,500, going to J.N. Camden, Jr., of Versailles, Ky. Kinzea Stone. C.B. Chenault, "Gus" Easton, and Col. Bruce also bid on him.

DUBLIN, Sept. 29. -- A meeting of the National Federation was held to-day at which Mr. Justin McCarthy, the leader of the anti-Parnellite section or the Irish Parliamentary party, presided. The federation approved the issue of a manifesto addressed to Irishmen in America and Australia. This manifesto says:
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 30. -- George Fergus, twenty-six years old, is a prisoner here this evening at Police Headquarters, accused of arson and grand larceny.

Josiah Quiney, Democratic National Committeeman from Massachusetts and Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of Massachusetts, is very hopeful over the outlook in his State. To a TIMES reporter who met him at the National Democratic Headquarters yesterday, he said in reviewing the situation there:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 30. -- Lately the Republican papers outside of Indiana have been referring to an alleged report made by State Statistician Peele showing an advance in wages since the enactment of the McKinley tariff. The Republican papers of this State are not referring to it, because no such report has ever been made. In order to disprove this Republican falsehood, Statistician Peele makes the following statement for publication:

CINCINNATI, Sept 30. -- Beautiful weather, a fast tract, and an attendance of 3,000 people were the accompaniments of the thirtieth day's racing of the Latonia Jockey Club's Fall meeting to-day. There were thirty-nine starters out of forty-eight entries in the six races. Favorites won in the second, third, and sixth races and non-favorites in the others.

The order just issued by Secretary TRACY concerning the employment of pilots will be welcomed by naval officers. It revokes all existing regulations on the subject and Substitutes the simple rule that "commanding officers will employ pilots "whenever in their judgment such employment is necessary."

-- Judge Pryor, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday with great promptness stamped with the court's disapproval the attempt of a woman calling herself Mrs. Mary E. Gallagher to have herself declared the wife of James H. Gallagher, a bookmaker at 22 Cortlandt Street. The woman is suing for limited divorce in order to establish the existence of a common-law marriage.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- A misapprehension seems to exist as to the nature of the proposed amendment to the Constitution of New-York State providing for the sale of the Onondaga salt reservation, or, rather, giving the legislature permission to do so. For many years the local industry has been a constant drain upon the State Treasury.

NEW-YORK. -- Postmaster Van Cott has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Alameda arrived at that port Thursday with mails from Melbourne, Sept 3: Sydney, Sept. 5; Auckland, Sept 10, and Honolulu, Sept 22. These malls are due to arrive in NewYork next Tuesday morning.

LAURENS, S.C., Sept 30. -- The article which appeared in THE TIMES some three weeks ago, entitled "It Was a Social Revolt," and dated from Charleston, this State, has been widely read throughout South Carolina, and has been the subject of much comment, particularly among intelligent farmers. The article purports to give what is characterized as the "true inwardness and spirit of Tillmanism."

The arrival of the United States ship Philadelphia at this port has brought to light a number of statements regarding the recent accident on board the vessel while storming Fort Henry, near Baltimore, and, while it is the policy of the Philadelphia's officers to treat the affair with the utmost secrecy, enough has been divulged to make it appear that there is work ahead for the court of inquiry appointed to look into the mishap.

Ex-President Grover Cleveland arrived in this city from Buzzard's Bay just after 7 o'clock yesterday morning on the Fall River Line steamboat Pilgrim. With him came Richard Watson Gilder, Daniel G. Griffin of Watertown, who was Chairman of the Democratic State Committee's Executive Committee last year, and Charles F. Chichester.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 30. -- The second match between the Gentlemen of Ireland and Philadelphia was began to-day at Manheim and was witnessed by about 4,000 people. The wicket prepared for the occasion appeared perfect, and yet twenty-two wickets fell in five hours for a total ou 279 runs, a most unexpected result.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 30. -- Chairman Frick went through the Homestead mills to-day and on his return declared everything running nicely, and that the strike or look-out was certainly a thing of the past.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 30. -- J. W. Breidenthal. Chairman of the People's Party State Central Committee, was arrested at Enterprise to-day on a complaint of the State Bank Examiner for doing an illegal banking business. There are other prominent men Implicated whose arrests will follow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- The whaling steamer Mary G. Hume, Capt. Tilton, some details of whose remarkable voyage in the arctic have already been telegraphed, arrived in port to-day, fourteen days from Unalaska. The steamer has been gone over two years and a half, and for two Winters was housed in the ice.

The authorities at Barbados have been looking industriously for cholera on ships from New-York, and the steamer El Calloa, according to letters which nave reached this city in the last day or two, had a rather checkered experience in consequence.

The protectionist says, with strange inconsistency: "We do not wish protection against all countries; we do think that some things may be cheapened without much harm, sugar, perhaps; and so we will pass a law giving the President power to declare reciprocity with some nations and under some conditions."

All was bustle and activity about the Columbus Celebration Committee's rooms in the stewart Building yesterday. The committee met at 11 o'clock to revise the work of its subdivisions and to approve of plans already outlined. In all 1,250 special invitations to attend the celebration have been sent out, and 410 of these included tickets to the banquet to be given at the Lenox Lyceum.

CAMP LOW, SANDY HOOK, Sept. 30. -- Com mandant Sawtelle has received no instructions as to the future of this camp, and, unless the Bohemia's passengers are sent here, quarantine will most probably be raised Monday next. None of the employes were sent away to-day, as had been intended. Another pavilion is being built, and it is believed that the Bohemia suspects will eventually be sent here.

-- George Reese of Centralia, Penn., the well-known Lehigh and Cape May pitcher, has entered the medical department of the University of Pennsylvania. Reese pitched the season through at Cape May without losing a name. He was in demand by Princeton, Capt. King doing all in his power to induce the big left bander to enter "Old Nassau," but-to no purpose, Reese preferring the red and blue.

There was a meeting of the Campaign Commitee of the New-York State League of Democratic Clubs at the Hoffman House last night, at which the arrangements for the State Contention of clubs to be held in Chickering Hall Monday next were made.

UTICA, N, Y., Sept. 30. -- Attention has been called by some of the Republican papers in this section to the cotton and woolen Industries of this city as furnishing examples of great prosparity under the Harrison Administration, and word comes that Republican stamp speakers at distant points are making-claims of inareased wages and additional workmen in these manufactories.
Under the provisions of the act of Congress approved Oct. 1, 1890, the following assignments to regiments of officers recently promoted are ordered.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- The Cunard steamer Marathon, with all her passengers, was released from quarantine and admitted, to entry by orders from Washington received by Collector Beard at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The fine weather draw a large crowd to the Westchester County Fair near White Plains to-day. There were not as many visitors as on Thursday, for there was no pony racing on the card, but the trots and the gentlemen's running race proved good attractions, so that the 5,000 visitors had an enjoyable day.

William S. Hurley, a flour merchant at 36 Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, is the plaintiff in a suit, soon to come up in the Supreme Court, this city, in which be demands $350,000 from William Miles, his uncle, formerly the head of the Sixpenny Savings Bank. The action has grown out of an alleged forgery to a contract of the name of Mr. Hurley's father, now dead.

The reputation, of the Board of Aldermen of this city and the manner in which the privileges asked for by the Metropolitan Traction Company were granted on Thursday raise the suspicion that there was some motive poorer behind the action of the board besides a desire to increase the surface railroad facilities of New-York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sent 30. -- Within the last two weeks a complete change has come over the spirits of the Democrats of Westchester County, and the gloom and despondency of a fortnight ago have been supplanted by a feeling of encouragement and a display of energy that give promise of producing the best of results on election day.

The seventeen days' meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was brought to close yesterday afternoon, the attendance being light, for the card offered was a very commonplace one, the fields being small and the class of horses that ran poor, as a whole. Midgely and Doggett divided the honors of the day between them, the former riding three winners, Crotchet, White Rose, and Uncle Jim, and the latter two.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Another Cabinet council was held to-day. Upon the conclusion of the Ministers' deliberations Mr. Gladstone left Downing Street and started for Hawarden, where he will remain until the end of October.

DE KALB, Ill., Sept. 30. -- Representative Springer or Illinois, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, addressed a large audience at this place to-day. He replied to the interview of Mr. Justice, a member of the firm of Justice, Bateman Co., wool dealers, of Philadelphia. Mr. Springer said:

The temperance people of Philadelphia and Pennsylvania have some vivid recollections of Mr. "Dave" Martin's peculiar activities. It was a fearful shock to the trustful temperance and morality element of the Republican Party in the Quaker City when President Harrison appointed Mr. Martin Collector of Internal Revenue.

To-day at 2 o'clock the biggest American athletic event of the year the Amatuer Athletto Union channionships,a III take place at manhattan Field. One Hundred and Fifty-Fifth Street and Eighth Avenue. This meeting will decide who are American champions for the year at sunning, jumping, and weight throwing. The events are open to the amateur athletes of the world.

On the Polo Grounds yesterday the contest between the New-York and Philadelphia Gluts was a very lively one. At one stage the New-Yorks looked like sure winners. Then the visitors went to the front and secured enough runs to win the game by a single ran. On both aides the fielding was of a most brilliant character, and the New-Yorks made over twice as many base hits as their opponents.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept 30. -- The famous broodmare Eophronia, ten years old, by Ten Broeck, dam imp. Lady Stock-well, by Knowsley, has been sold by Major John S. Clark, this city, to Pierre Lorillard. New-York City, for 95,000. She is the dam of Locohatohee and others.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Preparations are actively in progress in all of the executive departments for the Government exhibit at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, and it is now evident that this exhibit will be finer and better, fuller and more scientifically arranged than any one ever heretofore made.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- The Supreme Court was crowded this morning when the petition of Maud Ledyard Newbold for divorce from her husband, Frederick R. Newbold, was heard. The petitioner's brother, Lewis Cass Ledyard, said that Mrs. Newbold had been entirely supported by their mother for the last three years, and that while his sister had an interest in the Ledyard estate she had as yet no income from it.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 30. -- The annual Fall baseball game between Williams's sophomores and freshmen took place this afternoon and ended In a rush after the second inning. The score was 40 to 0 in favor of the sophomores.

The Fabre Line steamship Massilia, which arrived yesterday from Mediterranean ports, was in collision with a derelict in mid-Atlantic. A glance at the last pilot chart of the North Atlantic will show that what mariners call the "Western Ocean" is pretty thickly strewn with these drifting menaces to navigation, and the wonder is that such reports as was brought by the Massilia are not more frequent.

The salient point in the management of Indian affairs for the last year, as presented by Commissioner MORGAN'S annual report, is perhaps the continued reduction of reservations by purchase and opening to settlement. This involves the gradual extension of the severalty-allotment system, which is one of the chief means now resorted to for effecting progress among the red men.

The Public School Trustees for the Twenty-second Ward opened bids yesterday morning for erecting the, new grammar school building on the south side of Forty-sixth Street, 200 feet west of Sixth Avenue. The bids, fifteen in number, were as follows:

All Souls' Universalist Church, on South Ninth Street, near Bedford Avenue, (Greenpoint,) Brooklyn, was well filled last night with school children and their parents and relatives to witness the award of prizes, offered by All Souls' Historical Lecture Course, for the best essays on "The Story of Brooklyn, from Hendrik Hudson to Mayor Boody."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 1. -- The second day's cricket in the big international match at Manheim was witnessed by upward of 7,000 spectators and left the match in a most interesting condition, the Irishmen now needing 142 runs to win and having seven wickets in hand for the purpose, although three of their most consistent scorers have been disposed of in Meldon, Green, and Johnson.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Music and musicians will have a prominent place at the World's Fair. The Bureau of Music, of which Theodore Thomas is Director and William L. Tomlins is Choral Director, has arranged a splendid programme of musical events. An appropriation of $175,000 for a permanent orchestra of 120 was made on June 30.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The Williams College football team made a creditable showing against the Laureates of Troy in the first game of the season to-day. The score was 24 to 0 in favor of Williams. The college boys played with snap and pluck, though lacking in science and concerted action. Half Backs Garfield and Manning played the best game for the team, running well and blocking finely for each other.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1. -- Col. Cuthbert Bullitt and Mrs. Mary E.S. Ransom are to be married Monday at noon at the residence of the bride-elect, on the southeast corner of Floyd Street and Broadway. It was intended that the matter should be kept private, and the few invitations that have been sent are marked "Confidential."

BALIMORE, Md., Oct. 1. -- Another week of perfect Autumn weather has made the country entertainments and outdoor sports flourish in all perfection. The "Gentlemen or Ireland" "came and saw and conquered." They were here Wednesday and Thursday and played at Mount Washington, where are the grounds of the Baltimore Cricket Club.

Jewbaiting in Germany and France, together with the expulsion of Hebrews from Russia and the renewal of the scheme of LAURENCE OLIPHANT to repeople. Palestine with the Jews, combine to keep a race ever famous for deism and finance before the world. HEINRICH HEINE is in some respects their greatest modern literary figure.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 1 -- At 11:20 last night a wreck occurred on the Eastern and Amboy Railroad at Hamden aiding, caused by a train of empty coal cars palling out from the siding, contrary to orders. A fast freight going west stuck it on the switch, ripping the coal cars in splinters, stripping the engine of the fast freight on the engineer's side, and killing the engineer, Jorden Wertheiser of South Easton.

The Rev. Edward Peele, curate of St. Mark's, Shelburn, hardly realized the modern ideal of a model clergyman. As most of our modern ideals are founded on nothing more material than a novelist's conception of man as he ought to be, it would have been strange if he had. Even detectives, amateur or professional, find it hard to give up to the standard set before them by writers of fiction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Oct. 1. -- Spurred to emulation by the recent baby show at Poughkeepsie, and strong in the consciousness that Westchester County has had a good year for babies, the managers of the Westchester County Fair gave notice that all Westchester babies would be welcomed and judged on the closing day of the county fair, which was to-day.

The New-York State League of Democratic Clubs will hold its convention in Chickering Hall to-morrow. Yesterday the hall was beautifully decorated, and the Sixty-ninth Regiment Band was secured to furnish the music.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The Republican Club held its first meeting for the term Wednesday evening, Sept. 31, choosing the following officers: Presdent -- W.C. Breed. '93: First Vice President -- H.F. Stone, '94; Second Vice President -- H.T. Noyes. '94; Secretary -- J.A. Rawson, Jr., '95; Treasurer -- G.B. Brouks, '93; member of Executive Committee -- D. W. Morrow. '95.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Overwhelmed with debts and threatened with criminal prosecution, ex-Mayor William B. Smith suddenly shook the dust of Philadelphia from his feet this week and started for the West, leaving behind him a legacy of bogus checks, protested notes, and broken contracts.

There is an article in the October number of Fetter's Southern Maganine, a comparatively new periodical published in Louisville, about WHITTIER -- an "appreciation" of him, as Mr. PATER would say -- that arrests the attention. It is of course, merely one man's opinion of another man's work, but all criticism is that; and this is, in a certain way.

Certain Republican leaders in Kings County have been trying studiously for the past few weeks to circulate a story to the effect that several well-known Democrats, beaded by William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn, who have been opposed to the local organization in reference to local matters, were going to bolt the ticket this Fall. The idea was to get that impression abroad without actually stating it as a fact.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The Princeton eleven to-day played their first match game of football this season with the Rutgers College team on the university field. The Princetonians had anticipated a hard tussle, and the Rutgers men, with last year's close score of 12 to 0 fresh in their minds, expected at least to score on the Princeton team.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 1. -- Senator D.M. Read, President of the Senate in this State, is the President of the Read Carpet Company of this city. He has made a careful study of the carpet industry in this country and the effect of the present tariff laws upon the American carpet industry. To a reporter Senator Read said:
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The Proprietary House and Land Corporation. Limited, doing business at 29 New Bridge Street, suspended to-day.

The most conspicuous design of the season, one which meets the eye in every line of goods, is the palm leaf. It is wrought in silks, ribbons, wools, velvets, feathers, and everything else. Often it is in the cashmere colors, that seem, through long association, to belong to it, and often in colors and materials that have no Oriental flavor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Yachts which sail into the harnor during the World's Fair or at any other time will not be compelled, to have the name on the bow. This is the result of a protest made by Major Wetmore of the regular army and owner of the New-York yacht Lurline, which made a cruise to this port.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The yachting season on the North Shrewabury River closed to-day with a race at Fair Haven. Much Interest centred in the contest as three of the fastest catboats in this section were matched, namely: Superintendent of Police Byrnes's Jessie. Fred Oakes's Enigma, and Clinton R. James's Undine. The race was for a stake of $300.

At the sessions of the second annual meeting of the American Electro-Therapeutic Association, which will be held at the New-York Academy of Medicine in West Forty-third Street on Oct. 4, 5, and 6, a number of important papers on the use of electricity in medicine will be presented.

The sporting gentlemen who are wont to gather at a cate on Columbus Avenue near Eighty-first Street are a little sore in mind and somewhat squeezed in pooket these days. They do not openly mourn. The instinct of a sporting life is too strong within them for that. When the matter of, their being "done" is mentioned they laugh it off as a good joke.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 1. -- President Dwight's opening prayer Thursday morning was to the largest number of students ever gathered in Battell Chapel. Last year there were very few vacant seats in the chapel, either on the floor or in the galleries, and with the increase in the number of students there has been a question as to whether the chapel could accommodate all.

The Schenk Building had been the Schenk Mansion in those good old days of Aberdeen, when Main Street had been a winding lane, overshadowed by spreading elms, and when the broad houses had sat back in retirement with long courtyards begirt with quaint plants on guard before them. But Main Street had been straightened and widened.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- CoL. Charies J. Murphy, special representative in Europe of the United States Agricultural Department, has written a letter from Berlin to Mr. J. C. New, the American Consul here, stating that Charles Scholvin will open his new Indian-corn mill this month. He will grind only American corn. He has the, latest improved American, machinery.

The German Catholic congress that has been in session in Newark within the last week was one of the most remarkable assemblages that the country has seen. We do not recall any other body of American residents, and presumably of American citizens, which has shown itself so completely out of tonch with American institutions.

The "confidential-circular" business of the Republican managers is on the increase daily. The brazen tactics of Carter and Hackett in their confidential circulars were outdone yesterday by one sent out by the American Protective Tariff League to certain Post Offices.

Mr. Rudolph Aronson's experiment at the Casino is interesting entirely apart from its very slight connection with the dramatic art, to which, however, it bears as close a relation as many other theatrical shows that are now crowding the poor drama in the background. Without commending the kind of exhibition Mr. Aronson seeks to make popular here, we may admire the boldness and liberality with which he has gone into the scheme.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 1. -- A special to the Dispatch from Ironwood, Mich., says: "The work of dislodging the bodies of the entombed miners is going on as rapidly as possible. Sand Sutton, the pit boss, came up the shaft at 10:45 o'clock this morning. He says five bodies can be seen piled together among the heavy timbers, and work is delayed on account of the lack of air.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- But little heed appears to be paid to the civil service law. It requires the heads or departments to make report quarterly to the Civil Service Commissioners. Whether their time has been too much occupied of late or through neglect, not more than half of the heads of departments have reported for the quarter ended June 30.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Oct. 1. -- The month of crimson foliage and Indian Summer days was ushered in by an elaborate dance at the Kittatinny House this evening. Prof. Kirsch is still leading the orchestra, and the musical arrangements for the evening are notably brilliant.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- There was not much doing in provisions. The hog market ruled about steady, and exerted no influence on the speculative market. Trading was light in all products, but most of the buying done was of the near futures. Receipts of product were moderate and shipments quite large. The rib deal attracted no special attention, and the demand for the cornered stuff was light.

Manager Gustave Amberg, who sailed from this city for Europe on Jane 30, returned yesterday morning on the steamer Columbia, accompanied by his wife, known on the opera stage as Marie Engle. The Columbia was detained at Quarantine about four hours for inspection, which made it late before the passengers reached their hotels.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- The stage has given to Boston theatregoers this week nothing that has proved to be of intense interest, although it has presented two or three plays that are new here. One of these possesses a sort of home interest because one of its authors is a Boston man -- Mr. John J. McNally, dramatic critic of the Herald. This is "A Mad Bargain," which has crowded the Hollis Street Theatre nightly.

UNDER PRESSURE. -- Yeast placed in a saccharine solution at ordinary pressures gives rise to the well-known, vinous fermentation. Under a pressure of 600 atmospheres, however, this did not occur, the yeast falling to the bottom of the liquid, while the solution of sugar was unchanged. After removing the pressure the yeast remained inactive for some time, and then, resuming its activity, set up fermentation in the ordinary way and carried it on to completion.

In a narrow and therefore professional market like the present, speculation is necessarily concentrated, a few stocks being active and the general list remaining dull. In the past week, the active speculation died out in the coal stocks and Northern Pacific, and sprang up in New-England, Chicago Gas, and, with less force, in two or three other stocks.

The Italian cruiser Giovanni Bausan arrived in this port yesterday. She was boarded at Quarantine by Lieut. Tremont of the Philadelphia, United States Navy, who represented Commodore Erben. The Philadelphia, Dolphin, aid Vesuvius escorted the Bausan to anchorage off the foot of West Twenty-third Street. As the four vessels passed Governors Island salutes were tired.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Candidates for the Williams football team began practice a week ago yesterday. Since that time they have put in an hour's hard work every afternoon, and the interior material is now pretty well sifted out. The team has not yet begun training, as it has not been definitely selected, but in the course of the coming week the Captain and trainers will have the men in good working order.

Writers of books on the French Revolution have made the world better acquainted with effects than with causes. It has not been wholly their fault. It was natural that readers should most readily become absorbed in contemplating the tremendous spectacles which that wild drama afforded, and yet it remains true that writers have commonly passed over in haste the equally fertile field in which grew the plants that produced the revolutionary fruit.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The football team has practiced diligently all the week. Captain Trafford has been materially assisted in his coaching by Cranston, who was centre rush in 1891, and who has the record of being the test centre-rush Harvard over had. Several new candidates for the team have appeared H. F. Sheldon, a man weighing 195 pounds, who came here from the University of Wisconsin.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- A big throng of society people attended the third and closing day of the Autumn race meeting of the Country Club, held at Clyde Park. The races were, on the whole, good, seven events being on the card. Little Friend, Brandy, and HappyHappy, in the half-mile dash to beat the track record, made an interesting struggle. The record was not broken, however.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United states bonds to secure national bank circulation $164,498.650. as follows: Currency sixes, $11,847.000; 4 per cents, $130,513.700; 2 per cents, $22.137,850.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- This afternoon Harvard played her first game of football and beat Dartmonth by a score of 50 to 0. From the beginning to the end there was no occasion for any particular enthusiasm. Harvard had everything her own way, and Dartmouth made no progress, except for the few minutes when she held the ball after Harvard had made a touch-down or kicked a goal.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1. -- At 2:30 o'clock this afternoon a terrible hailstorm visited this city, doing much damage to vegetation and buildings. The hailstones were fully one inch in diameter, and a great many pedestrians were injured before they found shelter.

NEWPORT, R.L, Oct. 1. -- Newport practically begins its Winter season to-day, though a large majority of the cottagers are still at their residences and likely to remain some time. Social entertainments during the week have constated of email dinner parties, the only affair to draw out a large attendance being Miss Leary's "at home" on Thursday afternoon.

PRINCETON, Oct 1. -- The management of the Princeton Track Athletic Association has decided to hold its annual Fall handicap games on the University Field Oct. 29. The following events will be contested: One-hundred-yard dash, 220-yard dash, quarter-mile run, (for freshmen,) half-mile run, onemile run, 220-yard hurdle, one-mile walk, two-mile bicycle race.

The opening of October ushers in a new epoch in astronomical annals. When the sun crossed the equinox on its apparent journey around the earth, the shortening day and the lengthening night reached an equality in duration, and the sun was directly over the heads of those from whom he never does wholly retire his golden ray; so that nights are longer than days.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- The Court of Appeals, Sec- ond Division, to-day handed down a decision in the celebrated case of George Rico against the Trustees of the Standard Oil Trust. In 1886 Mr. Rice bought some of the stock of the trust in open market, but was never able to obtain a transfer on the books, the allegation being made that he was hostile to the trust.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- This noon, after lying at her dock all night, the steamer Marathon was unceremoniously ordered back to Quarantine by the Board of Health. The reason given was that she did not conform to the Quarantine regulations as ordered by the board. At 10 o'clock this morning Dr. Durgin telephoned for Dr. Cogswell to come immediately to the Board of Health office.
ORANGE, Oct 1. -- So far in the season all the social interests of Orange people have been centred, in weddings, leaving little time for aught else.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The Navy Department has issued a new table of cable rates of the world. A chart of the world is published, on which the submarine cables are indicated, with the principal communicating land lines and the seacoast stations. Detailed maps are also given of the telegraphic accommodations in Central America and the West Indies, in Eastern Europe, and in the Mediterranean countries.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- While the brilliant send-off of Sullivan and Grundy's new opera, "Haddon Hall," has served to crowd the Savoy Theatre all the week, there is no doubt that the opera 13 a disappointment, and the belief is strengthened that Sullivan and Gilbert are indispensable to each other.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 1 -- Between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning four mashed men entered the railroad station at Nicholas Junction, four miles from here, and with drawn revolvers demanded that Night Telegraph Operator Robinson should open the safe. This he could not do, not knowing the combination. They then knocked him down with a coupling pin and bound and gagged him while they ransacked the place.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The opening game of the Orange Athletic Club's football season, played on the Orange Oval this afternoon with the Stevens Institute eleven, resulted in a tie in two twenty-minute halfs. One thousand spectators watched the game. The teams did little but bucking at the centre. Orange showed evidence of having good material, but a painful lack of training.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Oct 1-P.M. The four stocks, New-England, Chicago Gas, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Reading again overshadowed the general market, the trading in them amounting to more than 75 per cent. of the day's total transactions. New-England and Distilling and Cattle Feeding advanced, the former and the latter 1 1/2 points. Chicago Gas gained 1/4 and Reading 1/8. The rest of the market was only slightly changed.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 1 -- To many it will be a matter of surprise to learn that in Canada there is tolerated a system of landlordism. Happily, however, it is confined to a very small portion of the country, known as the Magdalen Islands. These slands, seven in number, are Amherst, Grindstone, Allright, Coffin, Groase Isle, Entry, and Bryon.

The disaffection among the so-called Republican leaders grows more conspicuous every day, and predictions are being made on every side to the effect that there will be an open revolt before the campaign is over.
From the London Standard. The outery which has been raised against the destruction of Nelson's old flagship, the Foudroyant, makes it interesting to trace the end of other famous vessels.

At the meeting yesterday of the Executive Committee of the General Committee having in charge the Columbus celebration in this city it was decided to have at least one stand in Riverside Park, near Grant's tomb, to be used on the night of the naval parade. The stand will seat 5,000 and two-fifths of the sittings will be reserved for the Committee of One Hundred and invited guests.

WASHINGTON, Oct 1. -- The Navy Department has discovered how it can save 13 cents on each copy of its useful monthly hydrographic chart. A general distribution of this publication, which gives the condition of the North Atlantic Ocean, so far as icebergs, derelicts, and storms past and future are concerned, has been prevented by the expense of issuing this lithographic map.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Considerable fault finding has been indulged in because of the apparent delay in printing and issuing the session, laws of 1892. Most of the complaint has come from practising attorneys who do not appreciate the magnitude of the work. Commissioner Charles A. Collin of the Statutory Revision Commission, speaking of the matter, said that, if any delay had been occasioned, the Statutory Commissioners and the Legislature alone were to blame.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The annual tennis tour nament of the college was began on Tuesday. Great interest was manifested in the event, the entries being more numerous than for several years. Nearly all the matches have been closely contested, and it is not possible as yet to pick the winner.

NEW-YORK. -- The report of the Central Park Meteorological Observatory for the week ending yesterday shows that the average temperature for the last seven days was 63.9. At 4 P.M. Sept. 25 the thermometer reached 81, and at 6 A.M. Sept. 30 it fell to 49. The distance traveled by the wind during the week was 1,252 miles.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- There has been a perceptible falling off in the entering class at Syracuse in both the Liberal Art and Fine Art Colleges. This is held to be due to a great extent to the changes which the Faculty has undergone in the last two years. In 1891, Dr. C.J. Little, History, and Dr. L. M. Underwood, Biology, left, the former for Northwestern and the latter for De Pauw.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The long-distance ride of army officers from this city to Vienna began at 6 o'clock this morning from the Custom House in the Tempelhof Field. Herr Koeler of the Union Club officiated as starter

Ex-President Grover Cleveland breakfasted alone in the dining room of the Victoria Hotel yesterday morning. Afterward he went out for a walk. He strolled down Broadway and reached a prominent jewelry store very soon after it had opened for business. He entered and asked to be shown something suitable for a present for a little girl who would be just one year old on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- "The American" tin works at Ernest Station, near Norristown, have been "shutdown" for the past four or five days, for the reason that there were no plates to work on. There are sixty workmen employed in the mill, of whom about twenty work at the tinning pots. All that could be found around the establishment to-day was a few laborers.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 1. -- To-day the application of Judge James O. Bauman for a writ of habeas corpus was heard in Chambers. Judge Bauman was arrested last Saturday night, charged with being an accessory to the attempted assassination of Judge Long. He was lodged in the Gretna jail, but as public sentiment was against him there.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Last night saw the opening of the Schiller Theatre, the new German temple of dramatic art, in Randolph, near Clark Street. Three one-act plays, all chosen because of their special application to the event and to the name the new theatre has been baptized were performed.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Fishing for pleasure and for business are very different things, as any one may suppose. Here it is done mainly for business. A more perilous, daredevil life is not led anywhere in the world than by the Gloucester fishermen. It is said that a soldier at the front has seven chances of escape against one of the man who goes to the fishing banks for a living.

-- President Frank De H. Robison will leave Cleveland Monday for New-York, where he will attend the special meeting of the League. Mr. Robison will then try to make arrangements with Boston for the championship series of games. He said: "If we are fortunate enough, to win the right to play off with Boston. I will bet any Boston official $1,000 that we will win the championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Gen. Flagler, the army Chief of Ordnance, has not yet completed his negotiations with the owners of the new magazine arm which has been recommended, for adoption in the army. An effort is being made to have the owners, Krag and Jorgensen, agree to a royalty on each weapon issued. They are represented in this country by a man named Petersen, a retired Norwegian naval officer.

The prayer of the Kolb crowd in Alabama to Chairman Carter of the National Republican Committee that boodle might be sent them in abundant quantities is likely to be answered. Possibly it may not be dealt out with that liberality which the Kolb crowd wishes, but still boodle will go to Alabama.

With unlimited enthusiasm the Arion Society last night celebrated the return of its singers, who recently made a triumphal tour of Europe. There was a brave display of German and American flags upon the society's building at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, fireworks were burned, speeches were made, songs were sung, and the evening was given to good-fellowship and good cheer.

LENOX, Oct. 1. -- This has been a gay week. House parties have been large, the weather has been fine, the mountain tops are beginning to be tipped, with the golden glory of early Autumn, and all are enjoying themselves. The noose parties will begin to break up this week.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Oct. 1. -- The borough has not yet recovered from the shock of last night's bombshell. To-day business has been practically suspended, and anxious groups stood at every corner discussing this latest coup. "What does it mean?" That is the query on every tongue. The thought of the State of Pennsylvania interfering in the struggle is frightening the sturdy workers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The University Dramatic Association held a meeting this week to take some decisive step in reference to the presentation of a play in the course of the year. A play called "Julius Caesar," written toy Mr. George P. Wheeler of the class of '91, was unanimously adopted. A trial of ail men who are desirous of a place in the caste and chorus will be held at an early date.

Now that the purpose of the railroad syndicate of which John D. Crimmins is the spokesman is unmasked and no secret is made that the trolley system is to be employed in this city, unless plans miscarry, there is a strong probability that publio indignation will soon find vent.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 1. -- In this, the thirty-first and, closing day of the Latonia. Ky., Fall meeting, about 3.000 people attended the races. The track was fast, and the weather perfect. Fast time was made in the second, fourth, and fifth races. Favorites won in the second and fourth races and non-favorites in the others. The betting was lively.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the N. Y. Associated Press. BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The Reichstag will reopen on Oct. 22, and immediately the sessions begin there will get in a period of the greatest danger of a Ministerial crisis. The Government has determined not to delay the presentation of the budget, which includes the credits arising on account of the army bills.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1 -- The Republican State Central Committee, which has been, organized in the interest of Gov. Bulkeley as a candidate for the United States Senatorship, succeeding Gen. Hawley, has considered plans for shelving the General during the campaign in this State by assigning him unimportant fields for the customary campaign rallies.

Ten innings were required to decide the game on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Philadelphia Clubs. At the outset it looked like a New-York game. The Philadelphias, howover, overhauled their opponents inning after inning, and finally won the contest by a single run. The visitors led in the batting and fielding and deserved a victory.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1. -- Johns Hopkins University will enter upon its sixteenth year next Monday. The coming week will be devoted to matriculation examinations, the organization of classes, and the reception to students Friday. The Winter's routine will begin Monday, Oct. 10. President Oilman arrived this week from a European trip. Prof. Ira Remson has returned from Deer Island, Me., where he spent the Summer months.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore of the Amerinan Museum of Natural History, who returned last weak from his annual trip abroad, gave an interesting account of his travels yesterday. The professor crosses to the Old World nearly every year in search of material for the illustrated lectures which he delivers during the Winter at the museum.

The letters of our correspondent who has been studying the political situation in Virginia, North Carolina, and Alabama have thrown a great deal of light upon the agitation that is going on in those States and to a less extent in other parts of the South where the Farmers' movement has attained strength.

BALTIMORE, Oct 1. -- Everything is now ready for the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which is to meet at Emmanuel Church Wednesday. Bishops Williams of Connecticut, Potter of New-York. Doane of Albany, and Whipple of Minnesota, and the Rev. W.S. Rainsford, St. George's Church, New-York, will be entertained by J. Plerpont Morgan, who has rented one of the largest residences in the city for the month of October.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 1 -- This afternoon an informal discussion was held by Justice Paxson and the attorneys for both sides in the charges of high treason against the Homestead Advisory Board.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your very interesting article about "Dave" Martin's work in the campaign against the prohibitory amendment in this city in 1889, you say very properly that his procurement of 90,000 majority for his liquor saloon employers was one of the greatest masterpieces of his outrageous political methods, and perhaps the most remarkable masterpiece of all.

PARIS, Sept.20. -- The new Odeon managers, Messrs. Marok Desbeaux, have shown proper spirit and determination in bringing out two original plays from almost unknown authors, instead of going back to familiar programmes. M.Brieux had only given thus far two plays, and both of these at the Theatre Libre The last one, "Blanchette," was a great success, and it forms a part of Antoine's programme for his provincial representations.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct.2. -- The public announcement that Judge Gresham would vote for Grover Cleveland created a sensation in this city to-day. The rank and file of the Republican Party believed that Gresham would remain loyal to the cause of that party. The leaders, however, have known for a long time that the most they could expect from him was silence.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 2. -- Gen. Mahone's visit to Washington a day or two ago is understood to have been for a twofold purpose. The first was to urge the Administration to use its influence to induce the Republican candidates for Congress in Virginia to withdraw and leave the field open to the third-party people, and the other was to give the leaders some "tips" about dealing with the situation in West Virginia and Alabama.

At a meeting of representative Irish-Americans held in this city Sept. 28, the IrishAmerican Democratic Union was organized, and an address issued setting forth the objects for which it was formed. It has opened headquarters at 853 Broadway. The address is as follows:

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 2. -- There is some little romance and considerable mystery connected with the death of Frank Mezick, the young man who committed suicide by taking morphine Saturday afternoon while in the company of Mrs. Hathaway. The woman in the case is not quite twenty years old, and is the wife of a wealthy contractor in Cleveland.

The near approach of the General Convention brings many subjects of pressing importance to the front, and yet Churchmen are perhaps slower than other denominations in making radical changes in their system of worship or belief, and usually their conventions produce a great amount of smoke and very little fire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The charge has often been made that John Wanamaker collected in 1888 the sum of $4,000,000 and turned it over to the Republican National Campaign Committee to be used in buying votes. It is well known that he has frequently admitted raising the money, and in a recent interview he exulted in his act, and boasted of the successful placing of the funds, and what was accomplished.

Mrs. Langtry and Miss Marie Linden will divide the honors in the new play with which the Haymarket opens its doors to-morrow evening. Mrs. Langtry, as an irresistible Beile Dame sans Merci, who draws all mon on to their doom, in to wear some marvelous dresses made for her by Worth. As three of these are evening costumes, the artist has had great opportunities.

LONDON, Oct.3. -- The Paris correspondent of the News says: "M.Renan may be said to have died from the results of influenza, aggravated by a weak heart and chronic arthritic rheumatism, often rendered acute by his natural aversion to physical exercise.
