NEW-HAVEN, Oct .14 -- The recent but just-announced resignation of ex-Judge Lynde Harrison from the Republican League in this city is the current topic of political discussion. The league was organized nearly eight years ago, as a means of helping to retrieve Repuplican fortunes after the defeat of Blai ne, and Mr. Harrison was conspicuous in this organization.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The first ball of the Orange social season was given this evening at the picturesque and historical old house of the Essex County Country Club. The ball was a great success and a fit opening for the brilliant social season promised for the Winter.

Immigration statistics show that 17,474 Steerage passengers were landed on Ellis Island in September. Of this number, 16,036 were aliens and 1,436 were citizens returning to their homes in this country.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 15. -- A special train arrived at the Illinois Central Station last evening bearing the chiefs on their annual inspection tour. The party is composed of President Fish, First Vice President J.C. Welling, Second Vice President and General Manager J.T. Harahan, and Directors E.H. Harriman and C.A. Peabody, Jr. The party came down over the Illinois Central and will return over the recently-acquired Mississippi Valley lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The united States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $164,561,500, as follows: Currency sixes, $11,847,000: 4 per cents, $130,740,900; 2 per cents, $21,966,600.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- The light receipts of hogs and strong market at the yards led to the development of considerable strength in the speculative market, and on the advance there was fair realizing by the buyers of the last fair days. Buyers preferred January product to anything else. At the close everything but lard showed a gain. Receipts of product were moderate and shipments of meats and lard heavy.

BRUNSWICK, Oct. 15. -- The college opened this Fall with an entering class of sixty men, besides several from the Bangor Theological Seminary. Prof. Houghton occupies the "Winckley Chair of Latin in place of Prof. Lawton, resigned. Mr. Farnsworth holds the position of instructor in German, occupied last year by Mr. Wheeler. Mr. Files, who was elected to the Chair of German, is still in London.

The naval parade of the past week, while in some respects an interesting affair, will be dwarfed into obscurity by the one to be held in New-York Harbor next Spring. The invitations have been sent broadcast, and while only a few official acceptances have yet been received, unofficial information shows that the representation both from Enrope and South America will be most gratifying.

NONCONFORMISTS AND MUSIC. -- For more than two centuries it has been a fundamental principle of the Nonconformist conscience that all instrumental music on Sundays is sinful, even when used for a "religious purpose." Bishop Earle, in his portrait of a rich "Nonconformist" lady in 1628, says that "she suffered not her daughters to learn on the virginals, because of their affinity with organs."

Matinee Kills reigned supreme yesterday afternoon at the Food Exposition in Madison Square Garden. The quaintly-sttired maids in attendance on the various booths, the demure country damsels rounding out the festivities of Columbian week by a visit to the food show, and the society dames in their swell costumes, all looked their prettiest and smiled their sweetest, but the matinee girls outdid them all.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- EX-GOV. James E. Campbell of Ohio delivered his first political speech before a New-York State audience la this city to-night. He spoke in Washington Rink to an audience of 4,000 people, and made a winning and effective presentation, of the tariff question, which was the only issue he discussed.

The Executive Committee of the Columbian celebration, composed of the Chairmen of the various sub-committees, will meet Tuesday, when reports will be due upon the several features of the celebration, and when possibly a financial statement may be given out. It seems probable that the showing will be a fairly good one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- The Cincinnati Daily Morning Tribune Company has filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State, the capital stock to be $200,000. Archer Brown, James N. Gamble, Jonathan D. Hearne, William Doepke, and Aaron F. Ferris, prominent and wealthy Republicans, are the incorporators, and the paper is to be stalwart Republican.

The Board of Walking Delegates of the building trades la not trying to assert its authority in a very aggressive manner just now, it having come out of the right with the employers not only second best, hut badly beaten. It is not likely to precipitate another war with the builders and contractors and manufacturers of ail kinds of building materials for some time to come.

The political events of the week just past indicate with extraordinary clearness that the Republican managers have become completely convinced that their cause is desperate, and that even the big fund that Chairman Carter now has at his command cannot be depended on to carry this election.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Henry W. Jaehne, the first to be punished and the last to be released of the New-York "boodle" Board of Aldermen of 1884, walked out of Sing Sing Prison at 6:55 o'clock this morning a free man.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- One of the largest political meetings of the campaign was held in the Academy of Music to-night under the auspices of the Young Men's Democratic Association of this city, which had invited Wayne MacVeagh, formerly Attorney General under President Garfield's Administration, to address the public in reply to Senator Sherman's recent speech, and to explain his reasons for abandoning the Republican Party.

The dangers of riding over a rough country in pursuit of a tame animal in a cage, at the risk of the lives of riders and horses, are provoking much discussion in the city. Tha accident which resulted in Charles L. Cottenet's death on Thursday has again called attention to this silly and absurd following of an English custom in a country adapted in no particular to indulgence in this sport.

One Autumn -- never mind how many years ago -- I, Basil Ogilvy, then junior attache to the British Embassy at St. Petersburg, was spending a week or two at the house of a cousin of mine who was married to a Russian General.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Oct. 15. -- The opening leeture before the Art Association was given to-night by Prof. Rice, who has recently returned from Europe. The subject was: "The Functions of Art in Modern Life."

ORANGE. N.J., Oct. 15. -- The football eleven of the Orange Athletic Club met and vanquished the Lehigh University team on the Orange Oval this afternoon. The attendance was not large, the impression having gone out that the Lehigh team would be a picked eleven. Consequently the Orangeites and spectators were surprised when the regular university, minus only three players, showed up for play.

Mr. JAMES MACKENZIE, a subject of Queen VICTORIA, dwelling temporarily and, we fear, much against his will in this country, complains to the British Minister at Washington that the rough but patriotic quarrymen of Tuckahoe who tore down the British flag he hoisted in his dooryard at Bronxville before he went to the races Wednesday "made asses of themselves."

The present week opens this morning with a sense of relief in the social world. The long-expected and upsetting Columbian celebration is happily over, and matrons and housekeepers can now joyfully contemplate a brief period at least of comparative quiet in which to set their houses in order for the Winter.

NICE, Sept. 26. -- I have just left the International literary and Artistic Congress of Milan. It concluded its proceedings on Saturday, the 24th inst., after a week of sessions full of value and interest, varied with pleasant excursions and other social gayeties, under the auspices of the Italian Authors Society and the City of Milan.

Delay in issuing the medals expressly designed for Columbus week in New-York is explained by the breaking of the original in clay, "which will necessitate a remodeling of the work. It is proposed, as before, to cast the medals in gold, silver, bronze, and white metal, the bronze to cost but $1 and the white metal 25 cents.

Appreciation of Dr. Doyle's "Adventures of Shorlock Holmes" has to do with one's personal zest for the marvelous. You may care for one detective story, but when there is a round dozen you may got a fit of indigestion. This volume of Dr. Doyle's is entirely different from his other spirited work, and scarcely the better on that account.

Following the regular monthly meeting of the Art Students' League last night the members and their guests, to the number of several hundred were afforded an opportunity of inspecting the elegant quarters of that flourishing institution in the new club building at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Baltimore dropped the last two games of the season to Brooklyn. In the first the field did not Rive Vickory proper support, and in the second John Ward's lucky double brought in the only two runs scored. Tho scores:

RUSSIANS AT HOME. -- It is generally well known that the Russians live more indoors than we do and are very partial to closed windows. The houses are kept surprisingly warm all through the long, severe Winter by stoves built usually into the wall, and running from floor to ceiling, and often some of the windows are never opened till the Summer comes round again.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- The Presbyterian Synod of New-York, which embraces churches in this and several New-England States, will meet here in annual session next Tuesday. The session will last several days. About 270 delegates are expected to be present.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Sunday morning Bible study will consist during the first semester of a course of lectures by Dr. True of Rochester on "The History of the Early Christian Church as Seen in the Acts of the Apostles and in the Epistles." The Young Women's Christian Association held its first monthly missionary meeting on Wednesday and was addressed by Mr. J.U. Forman, a prime mover of the student volunteer movement.

The festival interfered sadly with the attendance at the theatres, and the managers and actors are perhaps the only folks who are glad it is all over. An unsophisticated person might imagine that the presence in town of half a million strangers would greatly improve the theatrical business, but the experience of the managers in the Washington Centennial festival or 1889 taught them the contrary.

PARIS, Sept 29. -- Another play taken from a novel. M. Ernest Baudet, the brother or Alphouse, is the author of the extremely entertaining, highly dramatic novel the "Defroque." This story is reputed to have been suggested by facts familiar to the writer and to the old imperial world. In any case, the play comes from this source, and, like all stories turned into comedy or drama, the book remains the best.

Miss Euphemia Perkins had been graduated summa oum laude at Matthews University. Her thesis subject, "Psychical Sociology," had won for her the Blue Ribbon and the encomium of the President that perseverance would surely place her statue in the literary pantheon. And Euphemia bolieved him as she believed in her career.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 15. -- The university celebrated the beginning of its seventeenth academic year Monday in the large hall of the Peabody Institute, with an address on "Christopher Columbia and the Discovery of America." by Prof. Herbert B. Adams. The audience taxed to the utmost the seating capacity of the hall.

-- Demetrius Phalareus was commanded by Ptolemy to collect all the writings in the world, and so great was the success of his patient and laborious exertions that two great libraries were collected -- the just pride and boast of antiquity.

Yesterday morning three active stocks were quoted ex dividend; 2 per cent for the quarter came off General Electric stock; 3 per cent. for the same period came off National Cordage common; 6 per cent. for the half year came off American Tobacco common; and at the same time it was announced that the Directors of the Chicago Gas Company had decided to advance the dividend rate from 5 to 6 per cent.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Oct. 15 -- P.M. New-Yort and New-England and Reading were the features of to-day's speculation, in railway stocks, and both were strong. Reading closed 1/2 higher and New-England 1 1/4. All the old stories were revived, and, notwithstanding reiterated denials, the mystery was still maintained.

ITHACA, Oct. 15. -- Track athletics, never flourishing at Cornell, are still in an unsatisfactory condition. Instructor Lannigan, is on Percy Field every day coaching the men, but the number of athletes in training is discouragingly small, the freshman, class especially showing poor spirit. Football, on the other hand, is undergoing a steady, healthy boom.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 15. -- In athletic sports at Bowdoin the customary, sophomore-freshman football game was won after a considerable struggle by the sophomores, Fairbanks finally souring the goal. In the tug-of-war the freshmen won easily. The ball game was won by '96 by a score of 11 to 9. The sophomore football rush lacked its usual characteristics of a free fight this year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Frank Bishop, Chairman of the Grievance Committee of the Big Four strikers, was arrested to-day by Detective Dickson for a crime committed in Illinois. Bishop, alias Patsey Curren, alias Birchoff, is a fugitive from Mount Carmel, Ill., where he was bound over in $200 for breaking into a freight car in the night time.

STUDYING STORMS. -- In the year 1821 a severe storm prevailed along the eastern coast, which for many years was known as the "great September gale." It held that title until September, 1869, when another and more remarkable one occurred, which rather disturbed its claim to the honor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Society is still looking to the country for its amusements, and this week the record of Autumnal gayety has been well kept up. There has been a succession of pleasant entertainments, ending with the Elkridge Club races and the "hunt ball" last evening at the Kennels. The races, as well as the ball were a pronounced success.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Amherst and the School of Technology teams played a well-contested game of football this afternoon on Pratt Field. Technology had out a very strong team while Amherst was semewhat weakened by the absence of Capt. Pratt at full back. Ellis, who took his place, kicked beautifully, but was not very successful in gaining ground.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct 15. -- Dartmouth presented a very light eleven against the Boston Athletic Association team here to-day, and consequently met defeat by a score of 30 to 8. The Unicorn rush line was much too beefy for the collegians. Dartmouth was weak at left end and left tackle, and the playing of banning at left end was the vulnerable spot on the Athletic team.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- After a month's practice, the chances for a winning football team seem better than for two years. Ever since the championship team of 1889. Princeton has had up-hill work in organizing a football team that would make even a fair showing against Yale. Nearly all the members of the '89 team were graduated the next Spring, and in the Fall of 1890 Capt.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Public attention hero is directed to the Military bill, which no journals except the Government organs support. The recent pretty general nelief that a crisis was impending in the Prussian Cabinet, arising from the divergence of views in regard to the bill, has become greatly modified.

ROME, Oct. 15. -- Lake Come has overflowed its banks. The lower part of the City of Como is inundated, and the towns of Bellagio, Cadenabbia, Tremezzo, Monaggio, Varenna, and other Iskeside towns are all sufferers by the flood. The weather is now improving.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 16. -- One of the most successful athletic meets which Williams has held for several years took place on the campus this afternoon. There wore more than the usual number of contestants, particularly from the freshman class. Patterson, '96, proved himself the best man on the field, breaking two records, although one will not go down as otlicial.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Richard Mansfield's production of a dramatization of Hawthorne's romance, "The Scarlet Letter," has been the only novelty at the down-town theatres this week. The actor has added to his high reputation as an artist, though the play is not dramatic. Hawthorne's writings were not designed for the stage.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The storm that set in over Northern England, Scotland, and Wales night before last threatens to cause as much damage as some of the phenomenal gales and rains that passed over the country last Autumn. The telegraph lines are down in every direction, and communication with some of the coast towns is greatly interrupted.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 15. -- The wonderful "boom" in athletics at the University of Pennsylvania grows every day. Not content with providing the football team for the first time in its history with a fine training house, the Athletic Association has arranged to build a rowing tank for the 'Varaity crew, and, if the undergraduates will give their support, contemplates also the erection of a large baseball cage.

The Republican managers who were with Mr. Blaine at Whitelaw Hold's palsoe Friday night came to the city yesterday morning in no every happy frame of mind. They had learned little to encourage them at their midnight conference, apparently, and each counsel as the once "Plumed Knight" Had given them did not put them into that buoyant frame of mind which had been expected.

The labors performed at the Court of Charles II. by the Comte de Cominges in the last half of the seventeenth century were not of world-wide importance. In those times the duties of an ambassador from France wore apt to be as much of a social kind as political Louis XIV. was fond of small gossip no less than of war and glory.

The big celebration is over, but the city still trembles from its throes, and it is almost impossible to stop writing about it. Such a pageant is history, and everybody who tools part in it, either as active participant or as more or loss passive onlooker, feels that he has put himself on record.

THACKKRAY'S HEAD. -- Thackeray, like most Anglo-Indian infants, was sent, when no was about five years of ago, to the mother country for mental and physical nourishment. An aunt, with whom he lived, discovered the child one morning parading about in his uncle's hat, which exactly fitted him.

In this volume a series of jolly trips in Provence are described by Mrs. Pennell, while her husband supplies the sketches. And if the lady would use her pen alone and Mr. Pennell restrict himself to pencils the partnership would always be so much more satisfactory, for it is not always possible to have the dual faculty; that is, as far as the artist is concerned.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- Two or throe plays never seen in Boston until tills week are on the boards. One is "The Grey Mare," in which Daniel Frohman's Lyceum Theatre Company began a three weeks' engagement Monday at the Hollis Street Theatre. This and "White Roses" have proved so successful that the bill will continue to be the attraction next week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The new freshman class contains 407, contributed by the following schools: Hopkinson, 35; Boston Latin, 28; Phillips Exeter, 25; Phillips Andover, 13: St. Paul's 12; Cambridge Latin. Roxbury Latin, and Dalzell's, (Worcester,) 10 each; Groton. 9; Belmont School, 7; Browne and Nichols and Somerville High, 9 cach; Newton High, Adams Academy, Noble's School, and St. Paul's School, (Long Island,) 6 each; St. Mark's, Berkeley School.

HONGKONG, China, Sept. 12. -- Li Hung Chang, the foremost figure in the Chinese Empire, recently celebrated his seventieth birthday, and the great age of this important personage, together with his declining strength, has caused the imperial Cabinet much concern as to who will succeed him and lead the empire during the coming years, now apparently so fraught with dissensions within and mutterings of foreign wars and reprisals without the celestial dominions.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The work done by the football team the last week has been erratic, yet considerable improvement is noticeable. The fine game which Amherst played against Harvard last Saturday brightened the outlook considerably, but when she allowed Trinity to make two touch-downs and only scored 21 herself on Wednesday, there seemed to be something wrong with the team.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct 15. -- This morning cleared up the long programme of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders Association, when Sternberg captured two more, beats of the 2:27 trot, the only event left unfinished at dark last evening.

Gloves show daring transgressions of conventional ideas. Gauntlet gloves ore brought out in visiting tints and ornamentings, and the derby glove, Iap-stitched and with the regulation big buttons, is to be soon in the most delicate shades. Think of it -- a derby glove in pale blue, pink, !
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- At 10 o'clock to-night, Mrs. Harrison was resting quietly. The only noticeable difference in her condition since yesterday is that she is less drowsy to-day.

I have received permission to tell the Kekoskee fish story, provided that I do so in a careful and temperate manner. I do not know how to obey this injunction better than by giving it in the words of Dr. Clark of Mayville, Wis., from whom we first heard it.

Francis Parkman's "Oregon Trail," which comprises old-time sketches of prairie and Rocky Mountain life, has been brought out by Little, Brown Co. in illustrated holiday form. Printed on fine calendered paper, it is profusely illustrated from drawings by Frederic Remington, and is bound in undressed tun-colored leather, with designs representing Indian pipes, bows, arrows, hatchets, c.

SIR CHARLES WHEATSTONE. -- In London I had generally heard Wheatstone speak on his own special subject; he was very accessible to visitors who desired to see his wonderfully ingenious applications of electricity. In the Autumn of 1871 we chanced to be staying in the same hotel at Lucerne, and it was then a revelation to his listeners to find that Sir Charles was a man of very wide culture outside his own subjects.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Law School Building is the latest addition to the campus. It is situated just east of the library, and is of a style of architecture much the same. It is a handsome, whites sandstone structare, with complete appointments, well-stocked library, and, besides many smaller apartments, has three large lecture rooms now in active use.

It is promised now that storage-battery electric cars will be running on the Second Avenue street-car line before the Winter is over. They may be put on before the Broadway cable ears are. The storage battery to be used possesses some points that are peculiarly its own, and if what the inventors claim is true, it will be nothing short of a success -- the trolley will be regarded as utterly valueless beside it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15. -- The Examiner has a long account or the cruise of the steamer Montserrat, which arrived here Thursday from San Jose de Guatemala after having landed in Guatemalan ports 388 natives of the Gilbert Islands, who were delivered to wealthy plantation owners of Central America under contract to become laborers there for a term of five years.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- At a mooting of the University Cleveland Club this week the question of a joint debate with the Republican Club was considered, and it was voted to hold a preliminary debate to select the men who will represent the club in the joint debate.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- The theses prepared by the students at the University of Pennsylvania this year will be worth decidedly more than the value of the paper upon which thay are written. The senior class in the Wharton School of Finance and Economy will be engaged during the whole of the coming year in collecting statistics and making observations of industrial, political, and social Philadelphia.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 15. -- The naval cadets played a same or football here to-day with the Princeton College team. The visitors won easily by a score of 28 to 0.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Democratic County Convention for the nomination of county officers in Westchester County will be held in St. John's Hall, this village, on Monday.

"We must not expect too much for a shilling," writes Mr. Edward Eggleston in his preface explanatory of Chistopher Columbus. He was neither a Copernicus nor a Las Casas, but he had courage and fortitude and was a master of navigation. He had, in fact, those wonderful qualities which kept him long enough at sea to cross the Atlantic, and so he reached the islands which stood along the American coast.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 15. -- District Master Workman Dempsey of the Knights of Labor returned to-day from New-York where he has been working in behalf of the locked-out men at Homestead. Speaking of the proposed investigation into the quality of armor plate furnished the Government by the Carnegies, Mr. Dempsey said: ...

Many Knights of Labor are very indignant at the attacks made by General Master Workman Powderly upon the Democratic Party. While they concede to him the right to support any party he prefers as a private citizen, they object to his making himself prominent as a partisan in the official organ of the Knights, the Journal of the Knights of Labor, in his capacity as chief of the order.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Where mackerel go for the Winter is one of the fish mysteries. When the first snow flies in the Bay of Fundy, mackerel disappear. They are abundant in the Gulf of St. Lawrence and off New-foundland until that time, plump and juicy and very toothsome, the result of having fed well on their migration northward.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- On Tuesday and Wednesday there was a college "bolt" to allow the Faculty and undergraduates to attend the Columbian exercises in New-York and to ride on the steamer Laura M. Starin, generously furnished to view the fireworks and take port in the naval parade by the Hon. John H. StarIn of the Board of Trustees.

The one important fact that has bean forced upon the minds of all Brooklyn Republicans by the primaries and conventions of the week just ended is that Ernst Nathan is once more the supreme local boss of his party.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The Wesleyan football team has never had a harder-working Captain than Gordon, who leads the men this year. He is himself probably the best all-around player on the team. As a Captain, his playing is an example and an inspiration to his men, and he succeeds in getting out of them all the work possible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The football practice game on Monday atternoon was by far the most promising one of the season. Two elevens were formed as follows from among the candidates for the university team:

HAMBURG, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The men, women, and children who annually add materially to their income in this locality by gathering chestnuts are now busy. The vast forests of chestnut trees that cover the mountains in the central part of the State render this occupation very profitable when the yield of nuts is large.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- There is comparatively little new to chronicle this week in the London dramatic world. On Thursday it was reported that Mrs. Langtry was suffering with pneumonia and that she was being treated by Sir Andrew Clark. On investigation the report proved untrue, and on Thursday night she played, in "The Queen of Manoa" at the Hay-market Theatre as usual.

Amateur photographers have not had a busier week since the craze for picture taking started, than during the Columbian week. There was a constant snap of the shutter from the time the decorations went up on Saturday until experiments were tried at getting some kind of views of the night procession, a hard thing to accomplish and only attempted by the bravest of the young men.

A subject that is more and more becoming a matter of inquiry among thoughtful persons is, How shall the children of the thousands of immigrants who have lately landed upon our shores and who are yet to come in almost countless numbers be speedily brought under educational and moral influences, be taught our language, and be led to respect and honor our flag?

The new United States armored cruiser No. 6, now building at the Union Iron Works. San Francisco, will be named Olympia. She will be launched on Nov. 5 next. When completed the Olympia will possess many of the structural elements found in the New-York. She is a smaller vessel than the New-York, her displacement measuring 5.500 tons, whereas the New-York measures over 8,200 tons.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 15. -- A great many persons have been in New-York this week from Lenox, to attend the Columbus celebration. Consequently there have been but few entertainments. Among those who went down to town were George G. Haven, William D. Sloane, Dr. Greenleaf, Joseph Burden, Morris K. Jesup, Capt. Barnes, Mr. Davis, George W. Folsom, Henri Braem, and Mr. Beckwith.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- This afternoon Harvard beat Williams by a score of 55 to 0. The game was of special interest, because on Oct. 11 Yale had beaten Williams 32 to 0, and an opportunity for making rough comparison between Yale and Harvard was thus afforded. Williams had the same team with which she opposed Yale and arranged in the same way.

Some members of the National Committee who are bending all their energies to the election of the good Mr. Harrison did not keep Sunday as a day of rest yesterday, but gathered in a closely-guarded room in the Fifth Avenue Hotel and held a political conference which lasted for an hour or two.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Another Philadelphian who has long been identified with the Republican Party has come to the conclusion that the interests of the country demand a change, and that, in his judgment, the election of Grover Cleveland to the Presidency of the United States is desirable in every respect.

Every day we see fresh evidence of the desire of our high-tariff friends to discredit, repudiate, and get away from the Aldrich report on prices. The Republican Magazine is a now monthly publication, edited by an ardent follower of McKINLEY who was recently employed by the Protective Tariff League in editing the weekly journal of that organization.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 16 -- The Republican fat-frying work has been gone through with here, and has panned out pretty well, all things considered.

The United States torpedo boat Cashing is the first vessel of the new navy to put in an appearance with a coat of lead-colored paint. The coat which the Cushing is now carrying will be subjected to a test aboard that craft for its wearing qualities and effect under search lights and varying phases of natural light.

-- Prof. Hubert Vos has come to New-York on his way to Chicago as Commissioner of Art for Holland. Mr. Vos is not only an artist of high rank in the sturdy little kingdom at the mouths of the Rhine, but has conquered for himself a very notable place in London. Six years ago he went to London almost unacquainted with English.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct 16 -- Joseph Dodson, colored, twenty-three years old, was shot in the bead and almost instantly killed this afternoon on Sycamore Street by John Hill, also colored.

William Dudley Foulke of Indiana, who has been making campaign speeches in Massachusetts in the interests of Cleveland and Stevenson, was in this city yesterday. He left last night for his own State, where he will continue the work.

It was free day at the Loan Exhibition in the Academy of Design. Usually one has to part with a quarter before being admitted. Yesterday, however, the bars were let down, and all, both, quartered and quarterless, could enter.

WASHINGTON, OCt. 16 -- The army and navy officers who frequent the Army and Navy Club in this city are discussing the ill feeling which apparently exists between the Marine Corps and the Army Ordnance Corps. It all grew out of the attitude of ordnance officers stationed at Sandy Hook toward the officers of the Marine Corps who had been ordered to Camp Erben during the cholera scare.

BOSTON, Oct 16 -- Repeated and continued storms have broken up Mr. Vanderbilt's yacht, the Alva, and the attempt which has been in progress for some months to raise her has been abandoned. Among those engaged was Capt. John Stone, a diver of this city, who returned home to-day with this story:

On Saturday night, the 1st inst., or early on the following Sunday morning, the jewelry store of A.T. Jammes, at 909 Broadway, was burglariously entered and watches and jewelry valued at $l,500 were carried off. There was a mystery about the affair which puzzled the police for a while. The store was securely closed at 11 P.M. on Saturday and the gas was left burning aa usual.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Suppress the truth and fool the people," is the watchword at Mr. Harrison's Pension Bureau. Truth has no foothold there. The sole aim of the heads of the department at this stage of the political canvass is to make votes for Harrison. To do this, deliberate misrepresentation is resorted to.

Union Theological Seminary has broken away from the control of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church. Its Directors have terminated the compact of 1870, which did more than anything else to unite the then divided Church. The supervisory powers given to the General Assembly over the theological seminaries of the Church are absolutely withdrawn, so far as Union is concerned, and that wealthy and influential institution stands independent.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 16 -- The trainmen's strike on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, begun yesterday, is still unsettled, and from the present outlook promises to extend over the entire system of some 1,700 miles. Half of the road is now tied up, and not a oar west of Salida is moving:

Charles A. white, who describes Himself as a journalist, was arrested in the Potter Building, on Park Row, on Saturday afternoon, by Detectives Valelly and Evanhoe of the Central Office, and looked up at Police Headquarters, charged with embezzlement ana Kidnapping. The complaint against him is made by his wife, who is a wealthy woman living at Cheyenne.

There were some new and interesting disclosures yesterday in the case of Domingo L. Ruiz, the septuagenarian Consul General of Ecuador in this city, who was arrested on Friday night charged vita having negotiated two one-thousand-dollar promissory notes draws by him on Gustavo Preston, commission merchant at 35 Grand Street, Boston, and on which the indorsement of Preston was forged.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- No General in chief ever made greater consternation than did Felix, a few days ago, when he or some one familiar with his authority, hinted that a great dress revolution had come, and that its limits had been given by the secret manufacturing of some new and wonderful goods, all of which -- for this season, at all events -- must belong to Felix and to has patrons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Chief Naval Constructor T.D. Wilson was at Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday inspecting the practice cruiser George Bancroft, under construction at that place. He found the work advancing satisfactorily. The vessel is nearly completed. Steam has been made in the boilers. It is expected that the vessel will be ready to be taken away from the builders' wharf by the first of the new year.
Such of the horses as have been raced during the Summer over the Board of Control tracks as will not be given a rest were shipped yesterday either to Washington or to the Western tracks.

Henry W. Fisher, the European correspondent who lately returned to New-York, has received interesting replies from Dr. C. Birgfeld, the Hamburg dentist and writer on medical topics. They are in answer to a number of pointed questions on the cholera epidemic, its immediate consequences, and its ultimate bearing on the fortunes of the Free City and State of Hamburg.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- "I really believe," said Chairman Allan L. McDermott of the Democratic State Committee to THE TIMES'S correspondent yesterday, "that Grover Cleveland will carry New-Jersey by over 12,000 majority, and I should not be surprised to see his lead attain the phenomenal mark of 14,000. All around where I live I find Republicans who are going to help swell his vote.

BUFFALO, Oct. 16 -- In the schoolroom of St. James's Episcopal Church was held last night one of the most unique political meetings in the history of Buffalo. The assembly was silent as the tomb, yet enthusiastic to the extreme. When the demonstration was at its height all that was perceptible to the ear was on occasional sigh or groan, as if some one was trying to burst the bonds of silence.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 16 -- There is trouble brewing among the baseball clement at Williams College. In compliance with the order of the Advisory Committee, J. Lynch, '94, has resigned the Captaincy of the team. The committee's action was based on the request of Ennis, '93, manager of the team. In defiance of the wishes of the management the team has elected Beach, '94, first baseman, to the Captaincy.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 17 -- A.M. The Columbus celebration interfered in some degree with the week's speculation, but the stock market was by no means stagnant. The specialties which have been the feature for many weeks were still prominent. New-England fluctuated rather widely, but closed 1 1/4 higher than on the previous Saturday.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 16. -- The strike of telegraph operators and station agents on the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe system is on. Promptly at 7 o'clock to-night almost every man from Purcell, Indian Territory, to Galveston, Temple to San Angelo, Cleburne to Paris, and Oleburne to Weatherford left his post, and the struggle between the management of the road and this branch of the service commenced.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 16 -- Distressing, indeed, is the political situation in Nebraska as it appears to the Republicans of this State, and as it probably appears to the Republicans at the headquarters of the National Committee. For Chairman Carter must know, as every Republican here knows, that nothing short of a political miracle can prevent the election in Nebraska of eight Electors who will vote in the Electoral College for Weaver and Field.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Alden Fales, the boy murderer, who was recently convicted of killing Thomas Haydon while robbing him, and who is under sentence of death, preserves his remarkable equanimity in the Essex County Jail. He was to have been hanged on Aug. 11, but his counsel appealed his case to the United States courts.

Notwithstanding much has been written concerning what really took place in Britain after the Romans left it, the events of that time remain conjectural. Mr. Besant tells us that Gildas and the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" give some little information of occurrences during the fifth and sixth centuries; that Richard of Cirencester is valuable for topographical indications, but added nothing to English history, while Bede, "The Venerable," sheds on events a light that is faint.

There is no sense at all in placing the responsibility for the recent uproar in this city anywhere but upon the shoulders of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS. He must carry it. He was not a bad man at heart, but, like so many other "good-hearted" persons, he was a most colossal bore, and he has been to blame for the personal inconvenience suffered by thousands of citizens of quiet habits.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, California, Oct. 16 -- The annual report of the Acting Superintendent of this park, Capt. A.E. Wood, Fourth United States Cavalry, to the Secretary of the Interior, has Just been made. Capt. Wood, besides being the Acting Superintendent of the park, is in command of the troop of cavalry kept here during six months of the year, for the purpose of guarding the park.

NEW-YORK. -- The University Magazine for October is particularly rich in illustration. There are pages of pictures of alumni of leading colleges, and some of the university athletic teams of to-day are also given. The articles are contributed by E. C. Cranson, Bayard Holmes, George Donaldson, Herbert A. Weeks, George G. Munger, Ruford Franklin, George D. Rice, Jr., Eugene B. Beaumont, Prof. Burt G. Wilder, and Dr. J. Madison Taylor.
AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The number of students enrolled at the opening of the year at Wells College is greater than that of any previous year. The freshman class is also larger than ever before.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Republican candidate for Congress in this (the Twenty-sixth) district is Theodore L. Flood, D.D., editor of the Chautauquan, a monthly of wide circulation. The Democrats, Prohibitionists, and People's Party have united on Joseph C. Sibley of the firm of Miller Sibley, owners of a fine stock farm as Franklin, also of the kito track at Meadville, where Sunol has been summering.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Mr. Eugene Jones has recently purchased several pieces of property on Broadway in this village surrounding the stone marking the spot where Major Andre was captured.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Reports of damage by floods continue to come from many different parts of Great Britain and Ireland.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- The Administration Republicans, led by Collector or Customs John M. Bailey, carried their fight into the County Convention to-day and succeeded in defeating State Committeeman William Barnes. Jr.

During the present campaign the representatives of the crockery, glass and brass ware, and lamp trades will shout lustily for Cleveland and Stevenson, and in the great parade on Saturday, Nov. 5, the Crockery Business Men's Cleveland and Stevenson Club will cut no small figure.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Secretary Lindsley has just issued his September bulletin on the work of the State Board of Health for that month. There were 1,064 deaths reported in the State during the month. This was 360 less than in August; it was 41 less than in September, 1891, and 26 more than the average number of deaths in September for the five years preceding the present.

One hundred and fifty marines left the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning for Chicago, to take part in this week's celebration there. The battalion is commanded by Major R.W. Huntington, United States Marine Corps. The command left the Brooklyn Navy Yard at 5:30 o'clock and an hour later was on route West on a special train furnished by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The general condition of Mrs. Harrison to-day was more gratifying to the Presidential household, than it has been for several days past, and the day closed without any incident to increase the sad feelings of the family circle.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Thomas Dolan of this city, a Director of the Reading Railroad, whom rumor has credited with manoeuvring a deal by which the New-York and New-England Railroad was to be greatly benefited, was seen here to-night on his return from New-York City, where he had been in company with President McLeod of the Reading.

The New-York delegates to the convention called to meet at Chicago to-morrow and Thursday for the purpose of organizing a league for the improvement of country roads left here yesterday. This movement has already proved of wide interest, and it is believed that a national organization can be formed without trouble and will be able to exercise enough influence on Congress to insure action by the Government favorable to this project.
The nomination of the local candidates has aroused a great deal of enthusiasm among Brooklyn candidates, and from now until election day they propose to do a prodigious amount of work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- With a view to securing uniformity in the observations to be made of the partial solar eclipse next Thursday, the Naval Observatory has issued some instructions. The first contact will occur on the western limb of the sun, about 28 degrees from the north point, and the last contact on the eastern limb, about 103 degrees from the north point.

-- Millions of dollars are being expended by the railroads centring in Chicago in preparation for the expected increased business during the World's Fair. Upward of 1,600 new passenger coaches and over 400 new engines have been entered constructed and delivered prior to May 1, 1893, and all the car works and locomotive shops in the country are running overtime to till the orders.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Grover Cleveland, Mrs. Cleveland, and Baby Rutch will not come to Chicago after all. In a letter received to-day by Secretary Culp of the Committee on Ceremonies, Mr. Cleveland declined the invitation which the exposition officials sent him to take part in the various festivities of the week. He had been expected to participate in all the official and social events, and his coming was awaited by thousands of friends.

Orders reached the Brooklyn Navy yard yesterday from the Navy Department to prepare one of the dry docks for the receiving of the Italian cruiser Glovanni Bausan, now in this port. The orders were received by Capt. Theodore F. Kane, United States Navy, who is at present acting as Commandant, of the navy yard during the absence of Commodore Henry Erben in Washington.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The Rome correspondent of the Chronicle says:

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 17 -- Joint discussions between Republicans and Independents, chiefly, are a feature of the campaign in Nebraska Ex-Senator Van Wyok, the Independent candidate for Governor, has been dividing time with Judge Crounse, the Republican candidate for the same office, and fifteen engagements of that sort have been kept in as many towns in the State.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 17. -- Major Alexander Shaw's fight against Henry G. Davia and Stephen B. Elkins began in earnest to-day. The case is before Judge Dennis, and it will last the rest of the week. Major Shaw is a millionaire. He was the reform candidate for Mayor of Baltimore four years ago. His charges against Secretary of War Elkins and ex-Senator Davis are sensational.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17. -- This promises to be a great week for the young harness racers, the meeting of the Weatern-Southern Circuit which began at Cumberland Park to-day, starting off well with two new records for age. The track is in superb condition, and the juvenile trotters were able to perform some remarkable feats in the contests for the two stakes.

MACON, Mo., Oct. 17. -- Twenty-five thousand Missourians listened to Gov. Boies of Iowa here to-day. Such a gathering was never before assembled in Northeast Missouri. They came from every direction and by every possible means of conveyance.

HONGKONG, Oct. 17. -- The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company's steamer Bokhara has been lost in a typhoon. She sailed from Shanghai Oct. 8 for Hongkong, and should have arrived here Oct. 12 at the latest. When fears were aroused by the delay in her arrival, the steamer Bombay and the British cruiser Porpoise were sent to search for her.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 17. -- A special to the Enquirer-Sun from Opelika, Ala., says: "The Presidential campaign was formally opened in Alabama at the fair Grounds in this city today with a speech from Gen. A.E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for Vice President.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 17. -- "Gus" Yost, who is charged with murdering his wife Marie last night, was committed to the Queens County Jail to-day by Justice Crandall to await the result of the Coroner's inquest, which will be held tomorrow night.

James M. Waterbury, President of the National Cordage Trust, was a witness yesterday before Commissioner Williams in the suit brought by E.B. Balch for an examination of the trust's books. Mr. Waterbury said that the reason why the trust objected to an examination of its books was that it was feared that such an examination would give a olne to a number of valuable secret processes used by the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Despite persistent Republican effort, the United States Supreme Court has affirmed the decision of the Supreme Court of Michigan that the Miner law, providing for the election of Presidential Electors by Congressional districts instead of by the State as a whole, is constitutional.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 17 -- All the telegraph operators on the Santa Fe system, about 900 in all, struck at 10 o'clock to-day. In response to an order from Chief Ramsay of the Order of Railway Telegraphers. The trouble is on the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway in Texas, which is operated by the Santa Fe.

The utterances of Mr. SCHURZ and Mr. MACVEAGH in this canvass have a particular interest and value because they undoubtedly express a feeling that is very general among intelligent Republicans, a feeling of weariness and disgust at the manner in which the party has been betrayed with reference to the tariff.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 17. -- A steam pipe set fire to some shavings in one of John Henderson's greenhouses, near Flushing, L.I., last evening. Six greenhouses containing choice plants were destroyed. The loss is estimated at $4,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- The Boston admirers of the work of Charles Frohman's comedians filled the Columbia Theatre to-night to witness the first production on any stage of William Lestooq's new comedy, "The Sportsman," an adaptation of "Monsieur Chasse," by Georges Feydeau, first presented at the Palais Boyal in Paris.

Col. A.L. CONGER of Ohio, the promoter of certain tin-plate projects in connection with real estate speculation, and the organizer of two or three Trust combinations which have escaped the attention of his friend Mr. JOHN SHERMAN, has recently given to the public in Liverpool some remarks about the McKinley tariff.

Ex-Gov. Campbell of Ohio mode his second speech of the campaign in this State at Tottenville. S.L, last night, and he was given an enthusiastic reception by the Democrats of Richmond County and the neighboring towns of New-Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Indian Commissioner Morgan, with the assistance of his man Friday, the Rev. Mr. Dorchester, has turned the Indian Office into a reservoir of Republican misinformation. He spends his days just now in giving out a fifteen-page pamphlet, which is a conglomeration of politics and religion designed to assist President Harrison. Secretary Noble, and Commissioner Morgan.
The Republicans have resorted to another trick in spreading broadcast a circular with the name of George Blair, packing-box maker, attached, attacking Cleveland for not having favored labor.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Two bulldogs belonging to "Joe" Little and "Jimmy" Lynch the prize-fighter, attacked William Burdge early yesterday morning at the Lower Highlands. Burdge is employed in the Navesink House, opposite the Eastview Annex, from which the dogs had escaped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The San Francisco dispatch reciting the trouble experienced by American merchants on the Gilbert Islands was shown to Secretary J.W. Foster to-day. The United States has a commercial agent on the island, but up to the present time he has made no representations of this kind to the Department of State.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The trial of Thomas Neill on charges of willful murder in connection with what are known as the Lambeth poisoning cases opened before Justice Hawkins this morning in the Old Bailey. The Attorney General, Sir Charles Russell, Q.C., M.P.; the Hon. Bernard Coleridge, Q.C., M.P.; Mr. H. Sutton, and Mr. Gill appeared on behalf of the Treasury, and the prisoner was defended by Mr. Geoghegan and Mr. H. Warburton.

Consul General of Ecuador, Domingo L. Ruiz, who was arrested on Saturday on a charge made by Simon Epstein of 83 East One Hundred, and Seventh Street of forging two notes for $1,000 each, was released from the Jefferson Market Prison yesterday, his son having deposited $2,000 with the City Chamberlain as security for his appearance for examination in the Jefferson Market Police Court to-morrow.
Grand Marshal Catlin, who is arranging the Brooklyn Columbus parade for Friday next, announced his staff yesterday. It consists of the following:
Tammany conventions held last night for the nomination of candidates for Congress resulted as follows:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The will of Samuel S. Sands, late of New-Hamburg, was admitted to probate in the Dutchess County Surrogate's Court this morning. The instrument was drawn May 11, 1891, and was executed in the presence of F.W. Rhinelander, 289 Madison Avenue, New-York; J.H. Bond, Hempstead, L.I, and Henry de Peyster, 137 West Fourteenth Street, New-York.

The County Convention of the County Democracy was called to order in Nilsson Hall, on East Fifteenth Street, near Third Avenue, at 8:30 o'clock last night by Charles A. Jackson, Chairman of the County Committee. Although the details had all been arranged, it was nearly three hours later before the business of the convention was disposed of and the nominations for city and county offices made.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Peter Jackson, the colored pugilist, will sail for New-York to-morrow. The object of his visit is to arrange for a tight with Corbett.

It was announced yesterday at the offices of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company that two new steel steamers would shortly be turned out from the yard of that establishment for the Morgan Steamship Line. One of the two new vessels has been designated El Rio. The second vessel is still known as No. 6. The speed of the new ships still be a maintained sea speed of sixteen knots per hour.

CARACAS, Oct. 8 -- The last few days have been filled with great excitement, the streets have been alive with troops, the surrounding districts have been the scene of numerous battles, and Pulido, the President, has fled to La Guayra, where he is to embark for Curasao. All of this has taken place since the 4th, and it has struck those here like a thunderbolt from a clear sky.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 -- The second championship game between Cleveland and Boston was witnessed by 6,700 spectators. The contest was more of a slugging match than yesterday's game, but the work of the pitchers was very evenly balanced. The crowd was enthusiastic and everybody staid until the last man was out.

Edward Divins, the young man who shot and killed Max Clerget on June 27 in Part I., Court of General Sessions, to avenge an outrage which had been committed upon his half-witted sister, was placed on trial for murder in the first degree before Recorder smyth yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Three superblyequipped trains moved out of me Pennsylvania Railroad Station this morning conveying the highest officials of the executive branch of the Government, the members of the United States Supreme Court, and diplomats and representatives of foreign countries to Chicago to attend the dedicatory ceremonies of the Columbus Exposition.

Police Justice John R. Voorhis had a nice little pony convention of the New-York Democracy in Webster Hall last night, which got to work about 9:30 o'clock. The usual formalities were quickly gotten through with, the hall was well filled, and the people cheered everything in sight and did as they were told.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The following dispatch was received to-day by Chairman Fillip of the Democratic County Committee:

When the new Canard racer Campania puts in an appearance next Spring she will be found to possess engines arranged in a novel fashion, and yet designed to develop 28,000 horse power. The arrangement of these engines was learned yesterday from Mr. Thomas Sewall, the Commodore Engineer of the White Star Line. Mr. Sewall says that the Campania's engines are worked on the triple-expansion system, but that the forward, and after cylinders are tandem.

In 1890 the Democrats elected twenty-three of the thirty-four Representatives in Congress from this State under the old apportionment. On the vote for Governor last year they had a plurality in twenty-two of the districts as now constituted under the reapportionment. Two years ago the first fourteen districts included Long Island, Staten Island, the City of New-York, and the County of Westchester.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- At a meeting of all the bicycle men in college to-day it was decided to organize a club to be known as the Princeton University Bicycle Club. The officers were elected as follows: President -- William J. Reid. '93; Secretary and Treasurer -- Walter B. Ferris, '94.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 -- A special meeting of the Corn Exchange was hold to-day for the purpose of considering the proposed United States inspection of Canadian grain exported via New-York. The following resolution was passed:
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 -- The Right Rev. Davis Lessums, Bishop of Louisiana, conducted the religious exercises opening the twelfth day's session of the Episcopal General Convention.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The Chamber of Deputies opened to-aay after the recess. Nearly all the members were present, as it was expected that an attempt would be made to overthrow the Government on the question of the labor troubles at Carmaux. All the members of the Ministry were present. The public galleries were crowded.

At Bidgefleld, Conn., Saturday night, the local Democratic club had a rally. The Rev. Dr. Rainsford of St. George's Church, this city, was asked to make an address, and he did so. Speaking of this yesterday, he said:

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Oct. 18 -- P.M. The specialties which led the business on yesterday's stock market were again the centres of activity to-day. New-England, Chicago Gas, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Reading accounted for over half of the 272,000 shares dealt in on the Exchange. The balance of the business was fairly well distributed.

The announcement from Albany that Gov. Flower had expressed the opinion that Friday should not be a legal holiday because it had not been expressly set aside by the President as a day of religious observance excited a good deal of interest down town. All the Exchanges had decided to close Friday, and some of them were likely to close also on Saturday.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 18 -- The gamblers are now being "held up" by the boodle combine which is running the Harrison campaign, to the disgust of all decent people. The levy made on each of the larger houses is $500, and several of them have paid. The money will be used, of course, to secure an "honest and fair count."

Whitelaw Reld has sent the following letter of acceptance to W.T. Durbin of Anderson, Ind., Chairman of the committee appointed to notify him of his nomination as Republican candidate for the Vice Presidency of the United States:
The Mayor of Chicago said to the Mayor of New-York: "Hollo! The City of Chicago greets --"

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Lawyer Peshall, the irrepressible counsel for the Jersey City ballotbox stuffers now in the State prison, found himself in an embarrassing position this afternoon in the United States Circuit Court at the argument on his new application for a writ of habeas corpus for Mosohell, Fallon, and Hart, the three principal ballot-box staffers who are making a test case.

Mathllde Sabail, a Frenchwoman in the employ of Redfern, the London costumer, was taken to the Custom House yesterday under arrest on a charge or smuggling. She arrived hero Sept. S on the City of New-York. Her trunks contained very valuable dresses of the latest fashion. One of them was removed to the Public Stores for examination and she went to the Hotel Martin.

Tammany has put up as its candidate for May or the ablest administrative officer belonging to the organization now in the public service, Commissioner THOMAS F. GILROY of the Department of Public Works. Of Mr. GILROY'S capacity for the duties of the office there is no doubt, and we are not aware that his personal integrity has ever been brought in question.

Matthew Stanley Quay, whose presence in this city has been awaited with interest for some days at Republican Headquarters, had not put in an appearance yesterday. From Republican sources it was learned yesterday that Mr. Quay might not come to New-York for some days, and some gave it out flat that the Pennsylvanian had gone to his home in Beaver and would stay there the remainder of this week.
District Attorney Nicoll yesterday issued the following proclamation in regard to elections and election frauds:

HONGKONG, Oct. 18 -- The chief officer of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company's steamer Bokhara, which was lost during a typhoon on Sand Island, between the Island of Formosa and the mainland of China, hat arrived here. He reports that of the crew 102 are missing, and little, if any doubt is entertained that they were drowned.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The National Harrow Company, composed of twenty-three of the leading firms manufacturing harrows la the United. States and representing a capitalization of $500,000, opened a two days' meeting at the Hotel Broozal this morning and elected these officers for the coming year: President -- Charles H. Childa, Utice; Vice President -- A.O. Bennett, Lansing, Mich.; Secretary -- William Brinkerhoff, Auburn; Treasurer -- Edward Norria, Utica; Attorney -- C.H. Dernell, Syracuse.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Republican County Convention, to nominate county officers, was held in Lafayette Hall, this village, this afternoon. M.D. Raymond of Tarrytown was the Chairman.

It is now believed by many that Otis Greye, the promoter, who disappeared from the Fall River steamer Pilgrim some time on Saturday, Oct. 8, is alive. The theory is advanced that he had some reason for getting out of the way and that he neither met with foul play nor oommitted suicide. Those who hold to this theory laugh at the idea of the man walking off the boat in his sleep.

NASHVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18 -- With weather like mid-summer and a track like a billiard table, the trotters and pacers furnisned plenty of sensations at the circuit meetinghere this afternoon. Belle Archer began with a heat in 2:12 3/4 for the class left unfinished last evening, and two more rapid miles landed her a winner.

One cause for the disaffection of intelligent and self-respecting Republicans from their party is the deep disgust at the tyranny on the one hand and the corruption on the other of the Republican machine. This is an influence necessarily rather quiet in its operation, and the extent to which it is felt is only shown at the polls.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Attorney W.E. Hartex of this city announces to-day in a letter to the Observer that he will no longer vote the Republican ticket. Mr. Harter is a citizen and a lawyer of high standing in this county. He has been a Republican ever since he became a voter, about twenty years ago, and has been a prominent worker in that party during all that time.

Two weeks ago the College of Pharmacy of the City of New-York secured the famous Canby collection of botanical specimens, after several weeks of negotiation with the owner. Mr. Canby, the well-known botanist of Baltimore.
Tammany Hall placed its local ticket in the Field last night at the biggest local convention ever held in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam, in circumstances that warranted the great enthusiasm displayed.

Our high-tariff friends are again disturbed by evidence that protected manufacturers sell their goods in foreign countries at prices considerably lower than those which consumers in this country are required to pay. From the McKinley press comes a chorus of denials, with the additional assertion that the evidence is manufactured by wicked persons.

The Special Committee, Controller Myers and President Barker of the Tax Department, appointed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to report some plan for the final disposition of material of the Street-Cleaning Department, yesterday submitted a report. It was laid over without discussion. The report in part is as follows:

CHICAGO, Oct 18 -- Vice President Levi P. Morton and party and ex-President Hayes and party arrived in Chicago this morning. Vice President Morton was accompanied by Mrs. Redmond and Miss Morton, and his private secretary, H.N. Higginbotham, escorted the party to his home, where they will remain during the sojourn.

Very few of the people who cast ballots at the coming election will realize what a tremendous amount of paper, type, ink, and labor is involved in their production. Martin B. Brown of 49 and 51 Park Place has the contract for making the ballots and doing the official election printing of all kinds for this city, and has been at work on the job for about three weeks.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Even the Judges of the Court of Appeals are in doubt as to whether Friday, Oct. 21, is a legal holiday. The court had intended to hold a regular session on that day until late this afternoon.

Edwin Einstein, who was nominated as the Republican candidate for Mayor Thursday night, began the work for which he was chosen yesterday. He started in on his campaign just as had been expected. He went early in the day to the headquarters of the National Committe. It is by the National Committee that his contribution will be used.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles is having a hard time with Chicagoans in reference to the much-wanted military parade. He has hit upon a scheme, however, which he thinks will quiet all feelings of resentment because of his decision preventing the military from taking part in the parade next Friday. Gen. Miles proposes to have a grand spectacular display of military tactics at night.

The will of Miss Maria, known as "Midy," Morgan was admitted to probate by Surrogate Stephen D. Stephens of Richmond County at New-Brighton, S.I., Tuesday morning. William W. Niles, one of the executors, appeared for the probate, and James A. McKenuell and Frederick B. Lange, two young men of this city, witnesses to the will, were present to prove the document.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 19. -- The Princeton football eleven made their largest score of the season to-day. Defeating the Lehigh University team by the score el 50 to 0. The Harvard eleven is the only team that has scored a larger number of points this season against a college team, havlmr made in one game 52 points against the Williams College eleven.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 19 -- Although Nebraska has a Democratic Governor, elected in 1890 by a very slight lead over the Independents, and a larger lead, over the Republicans, it is still far from being a Democratic State. Gov. Boyd received, not only the straight Democratic vote but, in addition, the vote of that part or the Republican Party in the cities, and notably in this city, that approved his outspoken opposition to prohibition.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The annual Fall meeting of the Amherst College Athletic Association took place on Pratt Field this afternoon. The events were well contested, but spectators and enthusiasm were lacking. The class or '95 won the greatest number of points, '96 was second, and '94 third. The victorious class is having a celebration to-night.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- The regular monthly meeting of the Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company took place to-day. The President, Mr. Charles F. Mayor, presided. Mr. Andrew Anderson, Secretary, read the statement of earnings and expenses for the month of September and for the three months of the fiscal year, with comparisons with the corresponding periods of the previous year.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Wesleyan played the second game on the campus this afternoon with the Tufts College team. As they expected to meet a weak team a number of substitutes were tried, and the result was one of the poorest exhibitions of football ever seen here. The game lasted only forty minutes, as the Tufts team had to take an early train for Boston.
The following business was transacted at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom yesterday, Wednesday, Oct. 19:

In the forecast of the programme for the Brooklyn Columbus celebration that is to take place to-morrow nothing appears to indicate that the one great industry of the city is to have part in the festal doings. There is no place assigned in the parade to a body representative of this industry, nor has any recognition of the industry been made up to date in the arrangements for the other functions of the day.
THE BROOKLYN PROGRAMME. To-day -- 1 P.M. -- Parade of children in Roman Catholic parochial schools.

WEST WINSTED, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Six hundred school children were seated on temporary seats 15 feet high, this afternoon, rehearsing for the Columbus Day celebration on Friday, when the benches collapsed and 300 children fell to the floor. Many received broken limbs, but none were killed. All the doctors in town are in attendance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The dedicatory ceremonies of the World's Columbian Exposition were begun to-day with the reception and entertainment of distinguished visitors by the various committees on their arrival in the city, and followed this evening by the formal opening reception by the citizens of Chicago to the guests of honor.

"Dave" Martin, who has charge of the colonization of voters for the Republican National Committee, was one of the men most deeply concerned about the registration yesterday of any in the city. He was one of the busiest, too. Nearly all day, in company with "Charlie" Voorhees, who is assisting him, he was at his headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, constantly receiving information and giving directions with reference to the work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The annual report of Major Gen. Schofield, submitted to the War Department to-day, shows the discipline and state of military instruction throughout the service to be in a highly-satisfactory condition. The drill regulations have proved satisfactory and justify the belief that, with corrections in minor details, they will fully meet the necessities of modern drill regulations.

MADRID, Oct. 19. -- The Official Gazette states that King Alfonso, whose illness at Seville has already been announced, suffered a slight relapse yesterday. Late in the day his fever subsided and he is now making good progress toward convalescence.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19 -- The twenty first annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, which was held here to-day, was by far the liveliest one held in the history of the company. About 300 shareholders were present, among whom were the following named: William Rockefeller, J. Pierpont Morgan, George MacCulloch Miller, Joseph Park, and Henry S. Lee of New-York.

The efforts of the Whitelaw Reid manipulators in Typographical Union No. 6, and of Mr. Reid's labor lieutenant, Mr. Milholland, to get up a grand mass meeting of Republican printers at Checkering Hall last evening resulted in a grand failure. A brass band "tooted" on the sidewalk in front of the hall for over half an hour before a score of people found their way in.

During the Gubernatorial campaign in this State last year, THE TIMES had frequent occasion to call public attention to the levying by Republican campaign managers of assessments upon poorly-paid Government clerks. The same tactics are now being indulged in under the direction of Chairman Carter. Men who have to work hard all day to earn just about enough to keep themselves and families from hunger and other privations are being taxed heavily.

Congressmen Fitch, Geissenhainer, De Forest, Harmer, and Ray of the committee appointed to investigate John I. Davenport, met for the third time in the Federal Building yesterday morning, and for the third time, also, Mr. Davenport was missing, in spite of the fact that he had been served with two subpoenas.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 19. -- A good track and fair, bright weather aided the sulkies to-day at Belmont. Three trotters dropped into the "twenty" list, two made their first appearance in the "thirty" list, two pacers beat 2:20, and one went into the free for all.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Union County Democratic Convention held here this afternoon for the nomination of candidates for County Clerk. Surrogate, and Coroner, was a lively occasion, and the climax was capped when the Rah way delegation bolted because their choice. County Clerk John L. Crowell, was refused a renomination.

Chairman Carter has been sending out from the Republican Campaign Document Bureau at 32 East Thirteenth Street and from the Document Bureau in Washington a campaign pamphlet, entitled "Wildcat and Bluedog Money as National Currency." It contains the stock arguments and misrepresentations which Republican orators have been using with reference to the plank in the Chicago platform which deals with the tax on State banks.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 19 -- It is understood that S.E. Halberstadt, formerly General Agent of the New-York Life Insurance Company of New-York City, is an embezzler. He has disappeared, and it is generally believed here that ho has fled to the United States.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The delegates to the Presbyterian Synod were mostly on hand this morning at 9 o'clock, when Moderator Parsons called them to order. The reports on the work of the post year were submitted from the different Presbyteries, as well as reports from the several committees. The Moderator then announced the standing committees.

Fleet City of Paris, the pride of the Inman Line and champion of the transatiantic racers, has again broken all records from Queenstown to this port. Capt Watkins, her commander, come very near malting good his boast of crossing the ocean within five days and a half. His vessel accomplished, the voyage in 5 days 14 hours 24 minutes.

Otis Greye, the "promoter," who was due in this city on Oct. 11 with about $750,000 of syndicate money to purchase various pieces of property, and who, it is said, mysteriously disappeared from the steamer Pilgrim on Saturday, Oct. 8, is still among the missing.

Spencer Trask, head of the widely-known Wall Street banking house of Spencer Trask Co., and heretofore conspicuously identified with the Republican Party, has made up his mind, after careful deliberation, to cast his vote this year for Grover Cleveland.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- A glorious Autumn night it is. Town filled with people, a city brilliant with light; a metropolis alive with the impulse of the Columbian anniversary

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Princeton University Track Athletic Association held its Fall handicap games this afternoon on the University Field. The track was in excellent condition and favored record breaking. The moat exciting events were the two-mile bicycle race and the one-mile run. In the two-mile bicyle race, Banker, '96, lowered the Princeton record and the collegiate and intercollegiate records.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- The thirteenth day's session of the General Protestant Episcopal Convention was opened tills morning with religious exercises, conducted by the Right Rev. J.H. Wingfield, Bishop or Northern California, and the Rev. F.W. Smith, D.D., of Vermont.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Miss Charlotte Lewis, daughter of Robert Lewis of New-York, was married yesterday in Christ Church to Harry Heminway, son of M. Heminway, the silk manufacturer, of this town. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Lewis of Point Pleasant, N.J., assisted by the Rev. William Lewis of Bridgeport, Conn., uncles of the bride.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 19 -- Capt. A.O. Macdonell, the General Passenger and Ticket Agent of the Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad Company, had arranged with Otis Greye, the man missing in New-York, for the sale of a large and valuable tract of phosphate land in this State.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The centennial Canal Convention met at Music Hall in this city at 11:30 o'clock to-day. It was a larger gathering than had been expected. George Clinton, President of the Canal Improvement Union, called the meeting to order. Thomas G. Alvord of Syracuse, who heads the delegation from that city, and who is widely known as a friend of the canals, was given a seat upon the stage.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Charles H. Houston and Miss Ella Case wore married by the Rev. J. Scott King of Little Britain at the house of the bride's guardian, Squire James Patton, at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The bride was given away by the venerable Squire, who is ninety years of age, yet hale and hearty as a man of sixty.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Oct. 19 -- P.M. There was not a great deal of novelty in today's business in the stock market. In the specialties trading was active. For most of the session the greater part of the list was weak, but a rally just before the close put about everything except New-England at top prices for the day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 19 -- It is proposed to test the legality of the Baker ballot law, and this morning the long threatened proceedings were instituted in the State Supreme Court, in the shape of a bill in equity to restrain the County Commissioners from distributing to election officers the ballots which have been agreed upon by them as the official ballots.

The tot contest between Gen. Martin T. McMahon and Gen. Daniel E. Sickles for the Congressional nomination in the Tenth Congressional District toot on new complications yesterday by reason of the withdrawal of Gen. Isaac B. Catliu, who was nominated for Congress by the Democrats of the Third Congressional District of Kings County, on the ground of his ineligibility, he being a retired officer of the army and drawing pay.

All honest citizens of whatever party must desire to have every public election the fair and unbiased expression of the popular will. They naturally wish their own party to succeed, but they cannot wish to have it succeed by unfair or corrupt means. They cannot approve of bribery to induce persons to vote for their party ticket or to refrain from voting for that of the other party.
Chairman William F. Harrity received the following letter yesterday from Starr Hoyt Nichols of the Social Economist, who is widely known on account of his trade and tariff writings:

It is the opinion of Mr. WHITELAW REID that the election of Mr. CLEVELAND as President will carry with it a Democratic majority in both houses of Congress. Mr. REID'S authority is considerable. He used to be a journalist, he is an active politician, and he aspires to be Vice President. He ought to be fairly well informed, and he has the greatest inducement to make no mistakes in his calculations.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Every train brings hundreds of visitors to the World's Fair city, and many of the most important participants in the official ceremonies are already on the grounds.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 19 -- I want to see if the United States Government has any rights in Arkansas on the occasion of an election in which a President and Vice President and six Congressman are being voted for. It not, then the four years of war, the spilling of a vast quantity of blood, and the expenditure of millions of dollars amounted to nothing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Visitors to the fair grounds were well repaid to-day by a scene of color, activity, and animation.
