PARIS, Oct 24 -- Prof. R.H. Thurston, Director of Sibley College, Cornell University, has called the attention of the Associated Press correspondent here to a so-called "Parisian Inventors' Academy," remarking: "I assume, as a matter of course, that it is a most insolent humbug and swindle."

It was not to be expected that Mr. EGAN would enjoy the remarks made about him by Mr. MACVEAGH before a New-York audience in which were many well-known Irishmen. And it was natural that he should be prompted to attack the orator of the occasion, who is not a citizen of New-York, and to one not familiar with him might be supposed to be a safe person to assail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Mrs. Harrison is no more. At 1:40 A.M. came the end. For the second time in the history of the White House a President's wife has died within its walls. Mrs. Harrison met death with the patience and resignation of a devout Christian, and her last days were comparatively free from pain.

Allen Brewer, a Grand Army man whose home is in Warsaw, N.Y., and who has been a Republican all his life, has left his party to support Cleveland. In a letter to Thomas F. Reed, Secretary of the National Veterans' Tariff Reform League, Mr. Brewer said:

A small sensation was created in official circles on Staten Island yesterday by the arrest of James Scott, Jr., the defaulting collector of the Stapleton public school district, and Michael F. Donnelly, who is both Clerk of the school district and Clerk of the town of Middletown.

The leading feature of the meeting of Baptist ministers at their conference yesterday the Tabernacle, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, was a discussion as to the best means of providing for the family of the late Rev. J.F. Avery of the Mariner's Baptist Temple on Oliver Street in this city.

The air of serenity which usually pervades United States Commissioner Shields's office was rudely disturbed yesterday afternoon by a personal encounter which took place there between two well-known lawyers.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 24. -- The last of the Consolation Stakes and the only event left over in the programme at Cumberland Park at dark on Saturday came off this afternoon. This was open to four-year-olds and ten started. Geraldine, the favorite, drew the pole and was not headed in the first heat. In the second she made a break and was laid up, while Broomal outfooted Elsie S. on the home stretch.

Thomas F. Gilroy, Tammany's candidate for Mayor, was enthusiastically greeted last evening at a mass meeting of Democrats of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District in Sulzer'a Harlem River Park. In his speech Mr. Gilroy said:

Brooklyn Republican leaders have become involved in a row with Naval Officer Willis and Franklin Woodruff on one side, and the Campaign Committee, through Chairman Wilson, on the other. It all grew out of the desire of Mr. Woodruff to boom the new but invisible, Brooklyn Republican Club.

"DIPLOMACY." People who were of the playgoing public fourteen years ago went to see "Diplomacy" at the Star Theatre last evening with some sort of misgiving. They liked the capital English version of Sardou's "Dora" so well in 1878, their memory of it was so precious -- for we have had few better plays than "Diplomacy" in a whole century -- that they were naturally afraid of disappointment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Last night passed slowly for the grief-stricken watchers by the bedside of Mrs. Harrison. The patient was restless and nervous, with small fluctuations in condition that did not range far on either side from the general average of extreme depression and exhaustion.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 -- The eighteenth day's session of the triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church was held today.

QUAY is in town, and not a moment too soon. They need him at Republican Headquarters, and they need him as the Bishop in a well-remembered hypothetical case needed his revolver when journeying in the State of Mississippi. Chairman CARTER is amiable, but not bold, not constructive. The Republican campaign is going to the dogs in his hands.

Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday rendered decision for the plaintiff in the suit brought by Henry K. Isham to recover $25,000, with interest from Jan. 13, 1890, from the estate of the late Augustus T. Post.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- The Phoenix Iron Company won a verdict against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad to-day for the delay in delivering the Northwest Seal Root Lighthouse, which was erected near San Francisco. In October, 1890, the Government gave a contract to the Phoenix Iron Company for the erection of the lighthouse. The company contracted with the Philadelphia and Beading Railroad to carry the iron to the Pacific coast.

The hearing in the petition for a writ of habeas corpus brought by Eleanor Doughty or 228 West Seventeenth Street, to compel S.S. Vreeland of 150 Nassau Street. Mrs. May Bradford of 181 West Sixty-third Street, and Drs. Shaw and Sweeny of 147 Greenwich Avenue to produce her unnamed infant, in possession of Mrs. Bradford, in court, was called before Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 24 -- P.M. After the second Columbian holidays the stock market opened higher this morning and from the start a brisk business was done on the Exchange. The industrials, New-England, and the other specialties were strong and active, while there were evidences of a tendency toward a broader market than has prevailed several weeks.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct 24 -- Local issues in this city and strong candidates on the Democratic Assembly tickets in Dutchess County will, if signs have merit in this campaign, do much to help the cause of Cleveland and Stevenson in this Republican section of New-York State.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The publication of the names of eighteen members of the Faculty of Amherst College, out of a total number of thirty-four, openly avowing their intent to cast their voted for Mr. Cleveland in the next election has aroused great excitement in the college. Prof. Grosvenor, an old-time Democrat, has been the chief agent in obtaining the signatures of the Faculty, and for two weeks he was busied with the task.

The adjourned annual meeting of the New-York Law Institute was held yesterday afternoon at the library in the Post Office Building to consider the report of the committee appointed to revise the by-laws of the association, also to elect officers under the same. An unusually large number of members was present, indicating, as it was thought, a revival of interest in the old and "very respectable institution," as one said.
"Devote your time and energy to getting out the vote for Cleveland and Stevenson. The local ticket will take care of itself."

A good example of the deceit and trickery depended upon by the Republican managers to secure success is found in the circulation in great numbers of cards purporting to give extracts from Mr. Cleveland's messages. One of the fraudulent statements printed on these cards is this: ...

The work of making the provisional estimates for the year was practically completed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday. A few miscellaneous items and the appropriations for the various charitable institutions remain to be passed upon.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 25 -- There was a small attendance to-day at the football game between the Manhattan Athletic Club of New-York and the Rutgers College team of this city. The teams were almost equally matched in weight and lined up as follows:

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- "You can say with emphasis and with truth that the laboring man whose wages have been increased by the McKinley bill cannot be found in Amsterdam," said Judge Z.S. Westbrook, formerly Deputy State Controller, this atternoon. "And you can go further and say that many workingmen in this county who voted in 1888 for the Republican candidates will vote this year for Cleveland and Stevenson, thanks to the ballot-reform law."

Dr. William J. Doyle, a respectable physician 55 Windsor Place, Brooklyn, was found inconscious in the gutter at 2 o'clock yesterday morning at Norman and Kingsland Avenues, Brooklyn. The region is a very bad one, and is infested by a gang of young toughs with whom the police have had several encounters.

This year thirty members of the Assembly are elected in this city, against twenty-four for thirteen years past. Six different organizations have made nominations in most of the districts, Tammany Hall, County Democracy, Republican, New-York Democracy, Prohibition, and Socialist-Labor. Besides these there are People's Party nominations in twelve districts and there are independent candidates in two or three.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I would like to call your attention to a clipping from the Herald of Sunday, Oct. 23, which shows that five leading general salesmen in the jobbing dry goods trade, engaged in one of the large jobbing dry goods houses, desire an engagement with manufacturers or importers. The advertisement is as follows:

By long odds the most comprehensive guidebook to New-York City, among the excellent ones lately issued, is "King's Handbook of New-York City," just published by Moses King of Boston, Mass., who has brought to the work the experience gained in a number of similar enterprises, notably his handbooks of Boston and Springfield, Mass., and a volume treating of the whole United States.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Oct. 25 -- Within the past two days several non-union men have been assaulted toy strikers and severely injured. Last night Charles Mitchell, on his way to work, was set upon and probably fatally injured. John Gilder, who was with Mitchell, was also severely beaten. Another man, whose name could not be learned, was also assaulted.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Gov. Flower has postponed until 11 A.M. to-morrow at the Windsor Hotel, New-York, the hearing on the application of the Governor of Wyoming for the surrender of Charles A. White, who is wanted in Wyoming for an alleged theft of $100,000 from his wife, whom he recently married.

ASHTON--COWLES. The wedding last evening in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn, of Miss Ella Y. Cowles, daughter of Mrs. E.L. Cowles of 110 Park Place, Brooklyn, and John D. Ashton was largely attended.

Announcements of the changes that are being made every day from the Republican to the Democratic Party among veteran soldiers are annoying Mr. Carter very much. He doesn't like it a bit. None of the announcements can be contradicted, and that adds to Mr. Carter's worry. He has frequently shown that the activity displayed in this canvass in behalf of Cleveland and Stevenson by the National Veterans' Tariff Reform League is mighty displeasing to him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The general rules governing the conduct of the Columbian Exposition have been issued. The gates will be open to employes at 6 A.M. and to the public at 8 A.M. They will be closed at 7 P.M., unless in case of some special exhibition or event, when they will close not later than 11 P.M.

The frontiers of the Eden Musee are of such a character that large attendance is always assured. Those who go once are sure to go again, and on the second visit they are almost certain to find that some new attraction has been added since the first visit.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Sir James Stirling, one of the Judges of the Chancery Division of her Majesty's High Court of Justice, to-day dismissed the application of Lord Henry Bruce to have invalidated the sale of the Savernake estate to Lord Iveagh.

The only way in which it can be determined whether an organization belongs to either of the political parties is by ascertaining whether that organization has been recognized as such by the State Committee and State Convention of that party."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The All Chicago football eleven played the University of Rochestor team yesterday at Culver Park, and a large crowd went out to see Heffelfinger and the other past great champions of the field. The visiting team was not as strong as had been anticipated, several of the men expected not being with the eleven.

Mr. Quay yesterday surveyed the political battlefield which Chairman Carter has mapped out, and, with the air of an old Commander in Chief, promptly got ready to deploy the forces in several quarters which, had boon neglected. To his superior craftiness and great sagacity the committee gave good heed. For an "invalid" Mr. Quay did a substantial day's work.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 25 -- "Minnesota will choose Harrison and Reid Electors, elect Knute Nelson Governor, regain nearly all and possibly all of the Congressional districts, and we hope it will secure the Legislature." That is Chairman Jamison's prediction for the Republicans.

The Electoral College will this year contain 444 members, and a majority is, therefore, 223. The candidates who can get that number will be elected. If none of the candidates can do so, the election will go to the House of Representatives, which, as at present constituted, would elect Mr. CLEVELAND.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Mr. Wayne MacVeagh came from Philadelphia to-day to make an argument before the Supreme Court in a case in which he is counsel. He was asked to-night if he intended to reply to Patrick Egan's statement which appeared this morning.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 25 -- The Schuylkill coal region is threatened with, a complete cessation of work and distress generally among its inhabitants resulting from the small water supply, in all this county Minersville is the only town that has its regular normal supply. Here in Pottsville the Water Superintendent stated to-day that the service can hardly be kept up a week longer.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 -- This was the eighteenth and last day's session of the General Episcopal Convention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Active competition for hogs at the yards, with a good speculative demand for January product, resulted in a general advance in the list pork leading. Lard was rather neglected, and not much interest was shown in ribs; packers, as rule, were buyers, especially of pork, while selling lard and ribs. Scaipers were showing more partiality for January pork, and commission houses seemed to be well supplied with buying orders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Col. William Ludlow of the army engineers will probably not get on lighthouse duty, despite the great amount of personal and political influence he is bringing to bear upon Secretary Foster for a reversal of the action of the Lighthouse Board in detaching Ludlow from duty as engineer of the Eleventh Lighthouse District.

With the transfer of the buildings of the World's Fair from the Chicago board, under the supervision of which they have been erected, to the commission appointed by the General Government comes the first formidable danger that the enterprise has thus far had to encounter. It is not disputed that the work done by the board that represents Chicago has been, in every respect, done most admirably.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- All night long telegrams of condolence with the President and his family in their affliction arrived, and in the early hours after dawn messenger boy after messenger boy passed through the gates bearing telegrams of this nature. Many of those which came last night were predicated on a premature report that death had taken place at 6 o'clock in the evening.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The funeral arrangements have teen completed by Private Secretary Halford, assisted by Lieut Parker and Mr. McKee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, dwells at length upon the value to the country of the 900 miles of military telegraph lines which have been successfully maintained in operation during the year by the Signal Corps.

The organs of McKinleyism persist in dishonoring and repudiating their own mannal of prices. With one accord they virtually assert that the figures of the Aldrich report concerning the prices of tinware, carpets, woolen goods, glassware, and linen goods are misleading and untrustworthy.

The Manhattan Athletic Club's second ladies' day entertainment of the season was held at the clubhouse, Forty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon. It was estimated that 4,000 visitors were packed into the gymnasium, theatre, bowling alleys, and around the water polo tank to witness the various sports.

With nearly a hundred speeches, with brass bands and fireworks, and marching clubs and an abundance of enthusiasm, tne Tammany Hall political organization ratified the Democratic national ticket last night, cheered Grover Cleveland and Adlai E. Stevenson to the echo, and incidentally started its local campaign off with a great hurrah.

WILLIAM SWINTON. William Swinton, the author of many series of school text books, died about 9 o'clock on Monday evening, in an apartment which he had recently hired in the Neufville flats, 254 West Eighty-fourth Street. Mr. Swinton had suffered for several years with kidney trouble, complicated with rheumatism and a tending to dropsy.

Senator Hill in his speech followed closely his manuscript and frequently referred to it. The main portion of the address dealt with the tariff. He went extensively into the unconstitutionality of excessive taxation. He was attentively listened to, and received the greatest amount of applause when he spoke of ex-Presi dent Cleveland.

There has been a vague rumor in Brooklyn for weeks to the effect that there was to be a sensation in high life, in which a well-known lawyer and politician was mixed up, and yesterday the rumor developed into fact.

At this stage of the campaign in this city it is interesting to note the method that the Tammany organization is employing to set out the vote. It does not difier materially in general from the plan employed in Tammany's recent campaigns, but it has blossomed out into greater perfection. Its details are more complete.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- As a result of the quarrels between national and local officers at the fair two sets of rules have boon issued for the government of the exposition. The set prepared by the local Directors is incomplete, while those prepared by the national commission cover the field thoroughly. These are what have come to be known as the St. Clair rules.

Adlai E. Stevenson last evening visited Brooklyn for the first time in his life, and a right royal welcome did the Democracy of Kings County give their party's candidate for the Vice-Presidency. He went to Brooklyn on the invitation of the county's Democratic Committee to address a mass meeting in the Academy of Music.

The hearing in the contest over the will of Mrs. Elizabeth Underhill Coles was begun yesterday before Surrogate Ransom. There is involved in the contest, which is made by a brother, Edward Coles, an estate valued between $ 2,000,000 and $ 3,000,000.

The city, county, and judicial nominees of the County Democracy were last night withdrawn in the interest of the National Democratic ticket, and there are now only one set of nominees before the Democratic voters of New-York -- those of Tammany Hall. The nominees of the County Democracy were:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26 -- Capt. McCormack, with L. Bliss and Graves, were in Cambridge watching the Harvard game to-day, but Acting Capt. Winter led the Yale team well, defeating the Young Men's Christian Association Training School team eleven 60 to 0 in thirty-miunte halves. About 400 people watched critically the Yale men who are to meet Harvard here in November.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 26 -- Every Republican manager in Minnesota knows that the only hope the Harrison people have of carrying this State is in their recovery of men who have deserted the party of the Administration to join the party of the farmers. So it is that the efforts of most of the speakers are directed toward those "erring brothers."

CHICAGO. Oct. 26 -- Larger receipts of hogs at the yards and lower prices there induced rather general liquidation in the speculative market, and the selling of the list was general, shorts being the best buyers. Outside markets were firm and cables showed an advanco in Cumberland sides and lard. Outside trade was light. Packers were buyers of lard and ribs and sellers of pork. Scalpers bought ribs and sold pork against their purchase.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Mr. Josiah Quincy, the Massachusetts member of the Democratic National Committee, has given to the press his views in detail upon the national political outlook. New-York, New-Jersey, Connecticut, and Indiana he considers reasonably sure for Cleveland. He says:

Major John Byrne of 54 Wall Street, this city, was formerly a resident of Cincinnati. He has watched with considerable interest the effort of R.C. Kerens of the Republican National Committee to pose as a "professional" Irishman in this campaign for the purpose of securing IrishAmerican votes for the Republican ticket.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Oct. 26 -- Lawlessness continues on the increase. Several non-unionists were assaulted in daylight, and crowds which defied the force of Deputy Sheriffs to-day gathered in astonishingly short time and carried matters with a high hand. It has about been decided to increase the force of night deputies by fifty.

It is too early yet to make confident predictions as to the results of the present football season. The indications at present are that Harvard will maintain her supremacy, though, owing to the unlikelihood of her meeting Princeton, she may not be able to establish an indisputable claim to the first place.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 19. -- The Government of Crespo can now be considered as quite firmly established, and the quietness with which matters have settled down reflects a great deal of credit upon the ability and forbearance of the party in power.

Benjamin C. Wetmore, lawyer, of 7 Nassau Street, made an assignment yesterday to Augustus L. Hayes, his managing clerk. Mr. Wetmore was not at his office yesterday, and Mr. Hayes said he knew nothing whatever about the particulars of the assignment.

The Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., pastor of the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church of this city, has acquired prominence by his attacks from his pulpit upon lawlessness generally and the administrators of the law in this city in particular. Tuesday evening he was arrested as a violator or the law.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 26. -- The grain blockade and car famine which the railroads of Iowa, the Dakotas, and Nebraska have taken every precaution to prevent has set in.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 26 -- Jerry Simpson has been warned that a conspiracy to kill him has been unearthed, and from now until he has completed the tour of his district he will be accompanied by a body guard.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- A smaller crowd than usual witnessed the football game to-day between the Princeton University team and the Manhattan Athletic Club eleven. This was undoubtedly due to the poor exhibition of football the 'Varsity men have recently given in their practice games, and as a consequence the students, for the time being, have lost their enthusiasm.

The new twenty-knot protected cruiser Olympia, to be launched at 11:25 A.M. on Saturday, Nov. 5, is the largest war ship constructed on the Pacific coast. The Olympia is the work of the Union Iron Works of San Francisco, Cat., the same establishment which built the new cruisers Charleston and Sau Francisco, and the coast-defense battle ship Monterey.

Francis C. Hewitt, the City Weigher who was arrested Oct. 14 charged with bribing Custom House Weigher Edward W. Simonds to underweigh certain importations of sugar received at the port of New-York, was brought before Judge Benedict, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, for pleading. He was represented by Lawyers Charles A. Hesa and Charles P. McClelland.

Whatever apprehensions were felt concerning the safety of the White Star liner Teutonic and the welfare of her half-thousand cabin passengers were set at rest last night when the late champion of the ocean race-course was reported off Fire Island. She reached that point many hours too late to regain her lost prestige, and her admirers will have to wait for more auspicious circumstances before the White Star is again ascendant.

Among the amusing literary productions of the campaign is a small lithograph picture of a good, stont, greenish-black bottle, such as many patent medicines are sold in, the printed labels of which constitute the campaign document. The front label shows the following words, in big black letters:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The body of Mrs. Harrison was placed in the coffin this afternoon amid a profusion of flowers and taken to the library to await the funeral services to-morrow. The body allows the effects of the long, wasting illness of eight months that reduced her large, matronly figure to a thin, frail form. But her face in death has the same kindly expression that it had in life.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- A great railroad combination, rumors of which have been in the air for several weeks, was consummated to-day. Parties largely interested in the Boston and Maine and Philadelphia and Reading Railroads have made a friendly alliance.

The special Congressional committee continued yesterday its work of weaving a net of evidence around Chief Supervisor of Elections for the Southern District of New-York John I. Davenport. As on previous occasions, the subject of investigation was absent, but his handiwork was there, and it was almost as satisfactory to the Democratic majority of the committee as the person of Davenport would have been.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Eighty thousand voters registered to-day in Chicago, and on Nov. 8 not lees than 270,000 citizens will be qualified to vote here. This tremendous registration is the most sensational feature of the Presidential campaign of 1892. It exceeds the highest expectation of the most sanguine politician and no man in Chicago is bold enough to say, "I told you so."

Ex-President Cleveland was the guest of the Buffalonians' Cleveland Club at the Hotel Imperial last night, and the occasion was one of most enjoyable sociability and good-fellowship. The recaption was of an informal character, and Mr. Cleveland found, himself surrounded by nearly 150 old Buffalo friends. He had a cordial handshake for each, and there were many pleasant reminiscences of the old Buffalo days.

Against the protests of many decent Repub- licans the general direction of Mr. Harrison's campaign has been placed in the hands of "Matt" Quay, the notorious ex-Chairman whose manipulation of voters and judicious expenditure of the corruption land resulted in the election of Mr. Harrison four years ago.

BRISTOL, R.I., Oct. 26 -- One of the most interesting figures in the yachting world at the present time is Royal Phelps Carroll, who has placed with the Herreschoffs the order for the eighty-four-foot cutter, which they are now building. He was at the works to-day, coming from Newport in the steam yacht Nantilus, and had a long chat with the members of the firm concerning his order.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 26. -- The Right Hon. Alexander Stavely Hill, member of Parliament for the Kingswinborn Division of Staffordshire, England, is here on business with the Dominion Government. At the time the first Canada sealing vessels were seized by the United States for taking seals in the Bering Sea. Mr. Hill went to the Pacific coast and made a thorough investigation of the matter.

Two New-Hampshire men, both Republicans, met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and, in course of time, fell to talking politics. One of the men had been West for several months, and was not posted as to the political situation, in his own State.

The police are making search for Joseph Wolf, who is said to be insane, and who ran away from his home in Morrisania on Tuesday night in peculiar circumstances. He had with him a sword and $700 in cash. Wolf and his brother Frank keep a lager beer saloon on the ground floor of the three-story frame house at Tinton Avenue and One Hundred and Fortyfifth Street.

Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Executive Committee yesterday sent out several hundred circular letters to his lieutenants in all parts of the State, giving them some final instructions as to how to handle the men whom he expects may be "induced" to vote for Mr. Harrison.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Harry Vane Milbank, who became prominent through his connection with the Borrowe-Drayton affair, died Monday at Davos Platz, the capital of the district of that name in the canton or Grisons, Switzerland.

All the trouble that has been caused by the new ballot laws that have been adopted in this country since 1888 has been due to departures from the simplicity of the Australian system. The prolonged dispute which followed the election of two years ago in Connecticut was caused by the practice of furnishing separate ballots for the different parties making nominations, to be inclosed in official envelopes at the polling places.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 26. -- Twenty-one persons, nearly all firemen, were injured in a fire here to-day, many of them by inhaling smoke. The flames were in D. Chestnut's leather establishment on First Street and were hard to get at. The following is the list of the injured:

Before the Park Commissioners yesterday morning Jacob F. Miller, representing citizens of the west side, asked for a new opening into Central Park in the neighborhood of Nintieth Street, on the ground that the Eighty-sixth Street and the Ninety-fifth Street entrances are inconveniently rar apart.

Eugene Delmar shared the ill fate of his chess brethren when he played his second game with Laaker yesterday. The veteran was visibly suffering from a severe cold, which may account for his rather ignominious defeat. Delmar selected the English, opening for his debut, and had a good position when his temper got the upper hand by prompting him to do some attacking with his queen.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 -- At the annual meeting of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company, held here to-day, about 70 per cent of the stock was voted. There were 194,570 shares of common stock and 69,227 of preferred. The vote was unanimous for the following-named Directors to serve for three years: Amos Townsead, James Barnett, Benjamin S. Brown, A. McDonald, and George A. Farlow.
ATHENS, Oct. 27 -- Twenty-five years ago King George and the Grand Duchess Olga, eldest daughter of Grand Duke Constantine of Russia, were married, and their silver wedding was celebrated to-day.

AMHERST, Oct. 27 -- The students and alumni of Amherst College are still much excited over the recent statement of the eighteen professors who intend to support Grover Cleveland in the campaign. The professors still hold to their opinions, notwithstanding the reports of the Republican newspapers to the contrary. Several of them have published statements in which they explain their position.

President A.A. McLeod of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad spent a few hours in this city yesterday on his way from Boston to Philadelphia. He was not disposed to discuss the transactions by which the Boston and Maine and the New-York and New-England Railroads have been made parts of the great Beading combination beyond expressing satisfaction at what had been accomplished.

An order was issued by Judge Patterson in the Supreme Court on Oct. 20 in the cases of the three companies of the Broadway Street Railway syndicate against the Tax Commissioners, by which the basis of taxation of those companies will be materially changed.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- A decided, change for the better has appeared within the past forty-eight hours in the prospects of the Democratic Party. Even the Republicans, who a week ago were most confident of Harrison's success, now exhibit signs of uneasiness and apprehension when questioned as to the final result.

The latest combination of railroad interests effected by the adroit financiers who control the great Philadelphia and Reading system sets at rest, for the time being, the long prevailing doubts regarding the exact status of the New-York and New-England Railroad in its relations to other Eastern lines.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- Major William McKinley, on his tour through this section, took in St. Louis, and spoke his little piece Tuesday night. It was expected that he would visit the Niedringhaus tin-plate plant, and that there would be a great blow-out. He did not make the visit, and THE TIMES'S correspondent set out to find out the reason.

All the frames for the new United States revenue stoamer Calumet have been laid down in the shops of the Union Dry Dock Company of Buffalo, N.Y. The contract for the construction of this vessel is in the hands of the David Bell shipbuilding establishment of Buffalo. The Union Dry Dock people are doing sub-let work for David Bell.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The News to-day quotes a story that comes from Bombay respecting the piano prodigy, Josef Hofmann. According to this story young Hofmann, who was visiting a relative at Cardiff some time ago, disappeared, and the next known of him he appeared as a stowaway on a vessel that had arrived at Calcutta.

PORTLAND, Ind., Oct. 27 -- This city has to-day been the scene of the greatest political demonstration eastern Indiana has seen for years, and the enthusiasm manifested on every side was boundless. Fifteen thousand Democrats were here and the walks and pavements were a mass of humanity. They came in from early morning in great crowds, interspersed with big delegation wagons loaded down and drawn by horses and traction engines.

When the several candidates of the County Democracy folded up their letters of withdrawal Wednesday evening, shot a parting and contemptuous glance at Judge POWER, and stole home through the night, they eased the troubled mind of Mr. CROKER, restored, the status que, and won the approval of all good Democrats. It was a sensible proceeding.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 27. -- All arrangements for the National Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union have been completed, and about 600 delegates are already here to be present at the opening session to-morrow. The convention will be called to order by Miss Frances Willard of Illinois, President of the National Association.

Neither the crowd nor the enthusiasm at the big meeting were confined to the hall. Both overflowed into the street. The crowd blocked traffic and yelled itself hoarse at every mention of Mr. Cleveland's name. Between 9,000 and 10,000 persons were packed in the square in front of the building. Detachments of the German-American Cleveland Union, with their attendant bands, gave a melodious turn to the enthusiasm and furnished an appreciable part of the crowd.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- "Steve" Elkins is seeking to justify his appointment as Secretary of War by working night and day for the success of the national Republican ticket in West Virginia. Since Mr. Harrison was nominated Elkins has spent but little time at the War Department, and about every matter of importance there is left pending.

The stockholders of the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets Railroad Company, of the Thirty-fourth Street Railroad Company, and of the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry and Eleventh Avenue Railroad Company were to have met yesterday for the election of Directors at the office of their joint Secretary, 45 William Street. For various reasons, however, the meetings were not held.

Edwin Einstein, the Republican candidate for Mayor, is making a unique campaign. He has opened, largely as a matter of form, some rooms for headquarters, which are fitted up with comfortable chairs and an open coal stove which makes the place as cheerful and comfortable as a clubhouse sitting room.

COLUMBIA, Tenn., Oct. 27 -- The last meeting of the Western-Southern Circuit began here this afternoon and has a programme for nine days. Owing to lack of water the kite-shaped track was very dusty, and it was late before the horses were started. So many breeders have sent their stock that there is not stabling room, and considerable confusion attended the opening.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The French Art Jury for the Chicago exhibition, composed of twenty-eight of the leading painters and sculptors of France, has already passed on over 350 pictures destined for the World's Fair. Through the courtesy of the secretary of the jury the Associated Press correspondent here is able to give the following information, which has not heretofore been made public:

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 27 -- Three more Demacratic officers of registration were arrested this afternoon on charges of refusing to show the tax receipts or applicants for registration to Federal Supervisors, and held in $3,000 bail each by Chief Supervisor Macallister. This makes a total of twenty-four thus arrested and held to bail to date.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 27. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Atchison. Topeka and Santa F6 Railway Company was held here to-day, and a Board of Directors elected, as follows: G.C. Magoun. A. A. Manvel, Thomas Baring, B.C. Cheny, C.K. Holliday, Alden Speare, William Libbey, Robert Harris, J.J. McCook, G.R. Peck, George A. Nickerson, E. B. Purcell and L. Severy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- In the Fifty-first Congress there was a spirited rivalry between Representatives Tracy and Quackenbush over an appropriation for a survey of the upper Hudson River. The former was willing that the deep channel should end at Albany, but Mr. Quackenbush was determined that the northern terminus should be the State dam at Troy.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 27. -- B.T. Yoakum, joint receiver of the San Antonio and Aransas Pass Road, was on the stand all of to-day in the investigation that is being conducted for Judge J.R. Fleming, the Master in Chancery, in the accounts of the receivership. His testimony was of a sensational nature. He testified that, during the election of 1890, he and his co-receivers.

The Messrs. Knoedler have hung on the wall of honor in their gallery a large naval engagement by Mr. J.O. Davidson, painted for the Plaza Hotel. It is to hang in the main hall near the elevators, and, with its broad frame, will nearly cover a space twenty feet wide. Like several other paintings by this artist, it recalls a feat of naval arms in the war with Great Britain -- 1812 to 1815.

Mr. PATRICK EGAN is receiving an amount of attention grossly out of proportion to his cosmical significance and assessable political valuation. This is because Mr. MACVEAGH, who is an incurable wag, turned aside from his serious work at Cooper Union the other night to have a little fun with the Hon. WHITELAW REID, who is a very solemn personage, devoid of humor himself, and for that reason the frequent cause of mirth in others.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 27 -- Senator Hill made an address this evening to an enthusiastic crowd of Democrats, who filled to overflowing the largo tobacco warehouse in which the meetins was held. On the tariff and Force bill issues the Senator's speech was in the line of those recently delivered in New-York and Brooklyn.

The meeting between Postmaster General John Wanamaker and H.C. Frick, Chairman or the Carnegie Steel Company, was intended to be a secret affair, but it was duly reported by a Pittsburg Republican paper, which evidently was not advised of the necessity of keeping it quiet for party reasons. The conference has made no end of trouble for the Republicans.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 27 -- During the last week in October voters are "made," as it is called, in Connecticut. Citizens who have become of age, or who, having been electors elsewhere, have changed their residence, and allens who have been naturalized, appear before the Board of Registration in each town and have their names placed upon the voting list.

As a matter of principle, "fusion" by either of the regular political parties with the People's Party is not to be commended. Neither of them is in sympathy with the demands and purposes of that organization, and cannot give it encouragement by supporting its candidate without a sacrifice of principle.

Nobody who has followed the career of Mr. JAY GOULD from its petty to its grand stage can entertain any doubt that he will seize any property that is desirable to him without payment, unless he is compelled to make payment. This compulsion he will resist and evade as long as it is practicable.

At a meeting of the New-York Yacht Club held last evening the letter which the recently-appointed America's Cup Committee sent to Lord Dunraven a week ago was read to the members and Given out for publication.
The attention of Shelby M. Cullom, United States Senator from Illinois, is likely to be called to Section 5,440 of the Revised Statutes of the United States, which reads as follows:
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 27 -- In his annual message to the Legislature to-day Gov. Northen had this to say on the subject of lynch law:

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Under the orders of Sir Andrew Clark, his physician, Mr. Gladstone has decided to limit his presence in the House of Commons daring the coming session. He will attend the sittings only on the days when important measures are under consideration.
Mr. Wilson Barrett, the distinguished English actor, who arrived on the steamer Teutonic from Liverpool yesterday morning, is staying at the Marlborough.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 27 -- The last detail of the arrangements for the funeral of Mrs. Harrison was completed to-day by Major Ransdell and Chapin C. Foster.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 23 -- Sitting at dinner with a faithful but gloomy Republican in the pretentious but imperfectly lighted dining hall of the Hotel Ryan, and while we were discussing the Minnesota conditions that are giving the Republicans so much concern just now for the future, the electric lights all popped out and the guests of the house were left in utter darkness.

The business men of this city who have taken their stand under Democratic banners in this campaign mustered around the Sub-Treasury Building, on Wall Street, yesterday afternoon. A grand army they were, standing shoulder to shoulder up and down Wall Street, and spreading down Broad Street and up Nassau Street to a much greater distance than the orators who addressed them could make their voices carry.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 27. -- Judge Gillett of Porter County has rendered a decision upholding the constitutionality of the Indiana tax law. The suit was one in which the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railroad was resisting the collection of taxes in sixty-five counties. The case will go to the Supreme Court.
BOSTON, Oct. 27. -- The following letter is self-explanatory: ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- As the campaign draws to a close the Administration redoubles its efforts to falsify Mr. Cleveland's record regarding pensions. The charge that while President he persistently ill treated the old soldiers is being industriously circulated in every State. The dispatch from Topeka, printed in THE TIMES, shows that the Republican managers in Kansas are making the best possible use of this lie.

"Here are fifty letters from Congressmen in all parts of the Union," said Representative Amos J. Cummings yesterday at Democratic National Headquarters, 139 Fifth Avenue. "The views of the situation expressed in these letters are made on the battle ground in each State, and are worthy of careful consideration. All are very encouraging.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A heavy gale swept over the Channel all day yesterday and during the night. The storm was particularly severe on the southeast coast of Ireland. The Channel steamers are greatly delayed. The steamer Jessie of Dundalk was driven on the Cleopatra Rocks and seriously damaged.

"FELLOW CITIZENS: When I address yon as my "fellow-citizens," I use the salutation common on occasions like this, and one which ordinarily carries with it no greater meaning than a customary greeting.
Upon the request of Josiah Quincy, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee on Campaign Literature, Mr. S.H. Angell has prepared the following reply to Senator Aldrloh's article in the Forum:

-- Thirty thousand shares of New-York and New-England stock were traded in the first ten minutes of business on the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday. Two or three prices were quoted for the stock at the same time. Nearly every firm in the Street seemed to have an order in the stock.

STOCKTOK, Cal., Oct. 27 -- Rowena the two-year-old Palo Alto filly, made a mile against time in 2:18 1/4 this morning, the fastest mile ever made by a two-year-old fily. True half mile was made in 1:08 1/2 and the last quarter in 33 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Funeral services over the remains of Mrs. Harrison took place at the White House this morning. They were impressive, but were characterized by the simplicity which was so dear to her. Except the sable rosette of crape at the doorway, there was no sign of mourning about the exterior of the mansion.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- The following letter from Wayne MacVeagh was given out hero today for publication:
All the States will elect Presidential Electors, and all the States, except Maine, Oregon, and Vermont, will elect Representatives in Congress on Tuesday, Nov. 8.

The advent of Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, the millionaire candidate, into active politics after a lapse of many years has been halled with delight by the "boys" in the Tenth Congressional District, in which he is to run for Congress.
Ex-Gov. Waller of Connecticut devoted himself to exposing Republican bugaboos. He said:
The Journal of the Knights of Labor in the issue of Oct. 20 contains the following upon Judge Gresham's position:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 27 -- The Evening Scimitar publishes a story, on the authority of a well-known Republican, which adds a new and interesting phase to the sale of the People's Party in this State to the Republicans by John H. McDowell, the manager of Gov. Buchanan's candidacy and Coal Oil Inspector at Nashville.

For a third play the Emil Thomas companyat the Amberg Theatre gave last night a Ger man version of Alexander Bisson's farce under the title "Der Verdachtiger Sohwiegersohn." It brought on the stage only a portion of what is called in Germanized French the "Berliner Ensemble," but that portion, aside from Herr Thomas, Was composed of weak brethron and sisters.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- This has been Yale's Fall field day. The records made were not of a high order, owing to the cold weather, but the freshmen material which was exhibited promises well for Yale at the intercollegiate meeting next year. It was "Freshmen's Day" in earnest, that class taking three-quarters of all the first prizes.
Richard Dorney, the polished and able business manager of Daly's Theatre, is the owner of a pet pug dog, which he holds as the apple of his eye.

Mrs. John Sherwood gave a lecture yesterday afternooon in Sherry's lower ballroom, and as a result the treasury of the Workingwomen's Society is better off by nearly $500. The ballroom was crowded almost to discomfort with well-known ladies. At 3 o'clock the reading was prefaced with some piano solos.

The Tribune published two or three days ago an account of what it called "one of the most brilliant engagements of the brilliant campaign which is being fought to restore New-Jersey to Republican rule." In this engagement Mr. ELIJAH R. KENNEDY of this city" was in command of the Republican forces, which were intrenched, behind breastworks of American tinware."

Ample evidence of Mr. Cleveland's great popularity with the German-Americana of this city was given last night at the mass meeting held under the management of the United German Democracy in the large hall of Cooper Institute.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 28 -- President Harrison and the grief-stricken members or his family arrived tiers tills morning at 9:30 o'clock on the special tram which also bore the body of Mrs. Harrison, brought hare for burial. At the station thousands of sympathetic friends or the Nation's Chief Magistrate had gathered, and when the train drew in heads were bared and a most respectful appreciation was manifested of the sadness of the occasion.

The Presidential campaign of 1892 is remarkable and will be memorable for the great number of defections noted in its course of prominent Republicans from the party to which they have been attached ever since its beginning, and which they desert, reluctantly it may be, for reasons of principle and conscience.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 28. -- Ex-Surgeon General Hamilton of the United States Marine Hospital Service spoke with the wisdom of experience when he recommended that all quarantine stations throughout the country be operated by the General Government and all expenditures therefor appropriated annually by Congress.

Tie handsome five-story brownstone-front house that was built by the late Edmund C. Schermerhorn, and owned by him until his death, will be torn down before long, and will be replaced by a large and imposing mercantile building. This property is now owned by William C. Schermerhorn, the brother of Edmund, who inherited it.

Lasker completed the second round in his series of matches at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday by defeating J.W. Baird after a prolonged struggle. The Berlin master didn't allow his opponents to escape with a single draw in this round. Altogether he won ten games in succession.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct 28. -- The Republican hubbub over firing at Fort Sumter is the biggest farce of the campaign. Gala week is the annual celebration of the earthquake of 1886 and the restoration of Charleston by the money and good-will of its friends, mainly of the North. It is the crazy makeshift of a sinking cause to try to give political significance to the attack on Fort Sumter.

BINGILAMTON, Oct. 28 -- The Delaware and Hudson train No. 3, which leaves Albany at 4:25 P.M., narrowly escaped a wreck this afternoon near the Cobleskill Station. Engineer Whitaker Had just pulled out of the station on time as a mixed freight and coal train bound east was drawing in. The freight, however, had broken in three sections.

PHILADELPHIA, Ponn., Oct. 28 -- Isaac Woodruff, older brother to Hiram, the old-time Long Island driver, and himself a reinsman of more than fifty years' standing, was given a benefit at Belmont Park to-day, the proceeds of which will amount to about $1,000. In addition to three other events a veterans' race to road wagons was arranged for, in which Woodruff was to take part, but his road mare, Sentress.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 28 -- If the eminent men who are conducting affairs at the National Headquarters of the Republican Party will only continue to give their undivided attention to the other New-England States and the West, the prospects are that Rhode Island will out an active figure in the surprise party which is to greet Mr. Carter and his co-laborers on the morning of Nov. 9.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Col. A.K. McClure, editor of the Times, telegraphs from New-York a long review of the present political outlook in which he says:

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 28. -- Communication had this afternoon with the principal Democrats of the State at headquarters in this city induces the belief that the withdrawal of the Democratic nominees for Electors will result in the success of the Weaver or third-party ticket. No one would have doubted it from the first, were it not that half the people of the State are disfranchised.

There have been many inquiries on the part of Democrats as to the political situation in Long Island City, and suspicion has been expressed in some quarters that Major Gleason would trade off votes for the National Democratic ticket in return for the support of the Republicans and opposition Democrats in his fight for re-election.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The fashionable event of the Autumn at Newburg was the wedding yesterday of Miss Margaret A. Wilson, daughter of Arthur Wilson, cashier of the Highland National Bank, and Frederic W. Banks, both of Newburg. The ceremony took place at 5:30 o'clock at St. George's Church, followed by a reception from 6 to 9 o'clock, at the residence of the bride's parents, on the bank of the Hudson.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Congressional contest in the Twenty-sixth Pennsylvania District is what they call a "rattler." This is in the main the district represented in Congress by the late W.L. Scott. Mr. Scott, as is well known, always made a hot campaign. In his day the politicians along the lakeshore "picked up their feat lively" on both sides.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- At to-day's meeting of the American Humane Association the question of vivisection was discussed, and a vote on a resolution condemning the practice as commonly performed resulted in a tie, whereupon the President voted against it.
DUBLIN, Oct. 28 -- The Queenstown Commissioners and many other public boards in Ireland have passed resolutions condoling with President Harrison in the loss of his wife.

NEW-YORK, Friday, Oct 28 -- P.M. There was less activity in stock trading to-day and the market was generally heavy. Distilling and Cattle Feeding was the feature, the attack on this stock continuing to push the price down. Just after the opening at 65 considerable strength, was shown and an advance of a point was scored, but then a slump began which carried the quotation as low as 6314.

NEW-YORK. -- Postmaster Van Cott has been informed by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Mariposa arrived at that port Thursday with mails from Melbourne, Oct. 1; Sydney, Oct. 3; Auckland, Oct. 8, and Honolulu, Oct. 20. These mails are due to arrive in this city next Tuesday.

QUEENSTOWN, Oct. 28 -- The Cunarder Etruria, from New-York, which passed Brow Head at 7 o'clock to-night, has experienced violent weather. Owing to the severity of the storm she was unable to disembark either passengers or mails here, and proceeded almost directly for Liverpool. A tender was damaged in attempting to fasten alongside her, and the Etruria's master at arms was drowned while the effort was being made.

The new American steel etearner El Rio, built for the Morgan Line of steamships, was launched Wednesday afternoon from, the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company. The El Rio is the first steal steamer built for the Morgan Line and the largest all-steel merchant steamer now under the American flag.

Shelby M. Cullom of Illinois is a Senator of the United States. As such be must be well posted upon the law relative to the use of his poatal frank and that it permits him only to use it for public documents. The Rapublican managers ore using his frank, as shown in yesterday's TIMES, to send out campaign literature. With Senator Cullom these managers are violating the laws of the United States.

HELENA, Mon., Oct. 23 -- In Montana is waging the fiercest battle for ballots ever known in the Western country. It is a struggle of all forces in the business and political life of the State, and is breeding jealousies and bitterness that will not be forgotten in years. Not a preciuct, even among those 200 miles from a railroad, lacks an interest never before known.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- The announcement in to-day's newspapers that Agnes Huntington, the American actress, is engaged to be married to Paul D. Cravath, a New-York lawyer and a member of the firm of Cravath Houston, brought a sign of roller from a well-known member of the Philadelphia bar, who is also a millionaire.

There is no denying that the English Liberals have no great reason for jubilation in the present condition of British politics. Their leader is a very old man and not exempt from the infirmities of old age, while there is nobody who would by common consent be chosen either as his lieutenant or his successor.

The first football game in the intercollegiate championship series will be clayed between Princeton and Wesleyan Universities at Manhattan Field. One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, this afternoon.

Col. Daniel S. Lament, formerly President Cleveland's secretary, who arrived on Thursday from Europe vastly improved in health, went yesterday to the registry place in the Third Election District of the Twenty-third Assembly District, at 296 Boulevard, and got his name down upon the lists. Col. Lament spent Thursday evening with Mr. Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who have been inspecting the Pennsylvania system since Oct. 11, came back to town to-day in their elaborate special train, reaching Broad Street Station at 2 o'clock. During the trip they took in the dedicatory ceremonies of the Columbian Exposition at Chicago, and they went as far as St. Louis, covering nearly every mile of the company's tracks west or Pittsburg.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28 -- Trinity Methodist Church was crowded with delegates to the nineteenth annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union this morning long before the hour announced for the meeting to convene. The building was decorated with bunting and banners, the most prominent of which was hung over the stage and bore the words: "No Sex in Citizenship."

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Chief Sweenie remained in his office during the evening, receiving telegrams giving the progress of the conflagration in Milwaukee, and holding himself in readiness to order additional companies to Milwaukee it necessary.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 28 -- This city was visited by a great conflagration to-night. It did millions of dollars' worth of damage and was the most serious fire in the West since the great Chicago conflagration. The fire started at 5:30 o'clock this evening in the Union Oil Company's store on east Water Street, and soon threatened to destroy the entire wholesale business section of Milwaukee, east of the Milwaukee River, below Huron Street.

There was a peculiar significance in the great meeting of German-American citizens at the Cooper Union on Thursday night, because it plainly indicated that the great mass of these sober and thinking people among us are arrayed in the ponding political contest on the side of rational tariff reform, sound money, and honest government.

The Dock Commissioners yesterday announced that the city had purchased the wharf property situated between Murray and Warren Streets, and that as soon as practicable West Street in that vicinity would be widened sufficiently to meet the demands of traffic. Frequent complaints have been made concerning the narrowness of that thoroughfare at that particular point, and blockades frequently occur there.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Daniel H. Chamberlain or New-York was the principal speaker at a big Democratic meeting held at the Academy of Music to-night, under the auspices of the Tariff Reform Association. His address was an elaborate and exhaustive review of the issues of the present campaign considered from the point of view of the independent voter.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28 -- Two fires, which occurred to-day within an hour in the heart of the city, caused a property loss of at least $250,000, the loss of one life, and the serious injury of half a dozen persons. Shortly before 11 o'clock an alarm called the Fire Department to the works of the Cleveland Window Glass Company, on Champlain Street, between Seneca and Ontario Streets.

Senator Quay did not go home yesterday, but remained in his hotel most of the day and entertained such callers as came to see him. He is said to have told a friend that he thought this campaign, from the Republican standpoint, had not been "set up" in the strongest manner possible, and he was not over-sanguine of the result.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 28 -- The local Democracy opened the national campaign to-night with a grand parade assembling on the Mall at 7 o'clock and marching to Wakehurst, the residence or Mr. J.J. Van Alen amid a blaze of red fire and fireworks. The streets were crowded and the long line was given a great cheer as it passed along Thames Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The annual report of the Adjutant General of the Army, submitted to the War Department yesterday, shows that the average number of students over fifteen years of age attending the several universities and colleges was 18,484, an increase of 2,767 over the number reported last year, and over 6,000 more than the number reported for the scholastic year 1889-90.
Commissioner Gilroy sent his formal acceptance or the Democratic nomination for Mayor to Chairman Weeks yesterday. It was as follows:
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The following open letter to Patrick Egan is made public to-night:

BUFFALO, Oct. 28. -- It is now generally believed that Erie County will go Democratic by from 5,000 to 6,000 majority; that the entire city and county Democratic tickets will be elected; that surely five, and possibly all six, of the Assemblymen from Erie in the next Legislature will be Democratic, and that Congressman Lockwood (Dem.) will be returned from the Thirty-second District.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The United States Nurseries, at Short Hills, are crowded every afternoon with visitors to the annual exhibition of plants, chief of which are the chrysanthemums. The display includes orchids and palms, and is oven finer and larger than the past exhibitions of these nurseries.

The report of Capt. L.G. Shepard, United States Revenue Marine, chief of the United States revenue cutter service, shows that for the past fiscal year the vessels of the Revenue Marine cruised as an aggregate 335,512 miles, and that during the same period officers of the Revenue Marine boarded and examined 37,521 merchant vessels.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 28 -- The Republicans in Williams College at a rally Saturday night voted to make the professors of protectionist opinions honorary members of the Republican Club. Only two members of the Facculty, however, desired this honor, the others, excepting, Dr. Basoomb, the well-known Prohibitionist, having declared in favor of Cleveland.

The entire fitness of "Dave" Martin as a professor in the Firth Avenue school of political knavery presided over by Mr. Carter was demonstrated yesterday in the arrest of a Bleecker Street "floater" of the ordinary type for illegal registration. The confession of this "floater" shows the sham work of John I. Davenport and his horde of satellites, who as Supervisors of Elections, are supposed to detect and prevent all false registry of voters.

C. Oliver Iselin, former owner of the seventy-foot sloop Titania, told a friend in this city a few days ago that in case Lord Dunraven should challenge for the America's Cup with a yacht in the ninety-foot class he -- Mr. Iselin -- will build a boat and try defend the cup. Mr. Iselin would not build a seventy-looter, as he wants a boas he can convert into a schooner in the ninety-foot class.

Yesterday was a lively day in the wheat pit at the Produce Exchange, and when the day's business was over it footed up sales of 10,505,000 bushels of wheat. This was the largest day's business of the present year. The spirit of the brokers was bearish, and from the moment business opened until the closing gong sounded, the tendency of the market was downward.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The case of the Yonkers Supervisors, who were denied admission to the County Board of Westchester County, was before Justice J.O. Dykman, holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court here, to-day.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The intense interest roused throughout England by the controversy over vivisection started at the Church Congress has made the subject of experimental research on living animals an all-absorbing topic. During the current week every newspaper has treated the question more or less exhaustively, and the chief contending parties have daily filled the correspondence journals with a constant stream of reiterated assertion.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Frod E. Ackerman, attorney for the Dutohess County Republican Committee, presented affidavits to the Inspectors of Electlon in the Second District of the Fourth Ward this afternoon, purporting to allow that Edward B. Osborne, Senator from the Fifteenth District, was not a resident of that district, and demanding that his name be stricken from the registry lists.

Pageants and ceremonies of one kind and another have occupied a great part of the attention of the home squadron this year. Sometimes they have come so near together that the vessels have had to hurry from one scene of public festivity to another. And the Pacific station has been busy in this occupation like the Atlantic.

POLISH CATHOLICS AND RUSSIA -- Polish Catholics are at this moment the object of a bitter persecution at the hands of Russia. Their Church is degraded to the level of a mere department of State, their Bishops are deposed and exiled without the right of appeal or complaint to Czar or Pope. Parish priests and curates are treated like fellows of an inferior caste, snubbed, cuffed, and hustled about by every Ispravnik.

The United States Rubber Company is abont to join the ranks of the industrial combinations. Twelve of the fifteen companies in which are centred the rubber boot and shoe business of the country have organized under the above corporate title, and their trade marks, patents, secret processes, plants, and good-will are to come under one management.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 29 -- A slight reaction after the celebrations of last week and the breaking up on Tuesday night of the convention has made these last few days rather quiet. Still, there have been one or two notable events, among them the wedding on Tuesday at noon of Miss Minnie Jenkins and George W. Curtis, which, although a very small one, was unusually interesting.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 29 -- Building will be active during the entire Winter. The tendency is to build on the shores of Mahkeenac Lake. Leonard C. Beckwith has had a large and expensive cottage built on the west shore this season. H.H. Cooke of New-York, who has bought the Gideon Smith place, will build a huge cottage on the east side of the lake.

READING, Penn., Oct. 29 -- There are rumors in railroad circles here which are being very generally discussed in business centres along the Reading Railroad that at no distant day the company will make its entire road four tracks wide, where it is not of that width already, in order to accommodate its rapidly-increasing traffic.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The Vassar Miscellany, a monthly publication by the students, has opened its twenty-second volume with the October number, and announces as its board of editors: '93 -- E.K. Adams, literary miscellany; M.V. Clark, de temporibus et moribus; E. Wilkinson, home matters; E.B. Cutting, business manager. '94 -- M.L. Boynton, exchange notes; E.L. Wells, college notes and personals; M.M. Macauley, assistant business manager.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 29 -- Nothing in the way of a political excitement that ever occurred in this State equaled that occasioned hero this afternoon upon the publication, in two afternoon papers, of a story of attempted bribery in connection with the approaching election, in which United States Senator Anthony Higgins is personally involved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Stockholders of three companies connected with the operation of the Atchison Railway system held their annual meetings in this city to-day. They were the Chicago, Santa Fe and California, the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe in Chicago, and the Mississippi River Railroad and Toll Bridge Company. Of the first-named company four Directors were elected, to wit: Abram Poole, E.O. Faulkener, Alden speare, and Benjamin P. Chase.

The art of conducting pomps, in which New-York and later Chicago have shown themselves somewhat lacking, is not one to be learned in a day, nor to be attained by the mere expenditure of money. The eagerness with which these cities and Brooklyn, during her recent celebration seized on the military to help them out is a confession of weakness.

Chester D. Burrows, a wealthy Brooklyn provision dealer, is the latest prominent convert in that city to Democracy and tariff reform. He was one of the Harrison Electors in 1888 and was President of the Republican League.

The Young Republican Club of Brooklyn has always boasted of the fact that it never lost any of its members, and that the wholesale desertions of the Republican Party by men "who could no longer submit to the prohibitive tariff party had never made any inroads on their organization.

The meanest feature of McKinleyism is its hypocritical profession of regard for the workingman and its cynical injustice and oppression toward him. The burdens of the McKinley tariff fall far more heavily on him than on his employer, because the proportion of things taxed used by him is larger, and because the taxes are relatively heavier.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Yachtsmen in this city are stil hoping for a favorable outcome of the cup match negotiations, but it is generally conceded that if Dunraven adheres to his opposition to holding the cup, under the new deed of gift no match is possible Pending the settlement of the cup matters yachting is at somewhat of a standstill, and only a few orders for boats, most of them small ones, are being placed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The University of Pennsylvania football team had a close call with the Chicago Athletic Club eleven to-day, but succeeded in winning by the score of 12 to 10. The umpiring, especially in the second half, was of such a nature that the "red and blue" representatives really had no opportunity to show the excellence of their aggressive play.

NICE, Sept. 30 -- On Tuesday M. Sonohon endeavored, in the interest of musical works, to obtain the modification of Paragraph 3. Article IL, of the Convention of Berne, which considers "the country of origin" of a work that in which it is first published, or, if it be published simultaneously in several, then that one of them in which the term of protection accorded is shortest.

St. Bartholomew's Mission, 209 East Forty-second Street, has opened a free night dispensary for the poor for the treatment of diseases of the eye, ear, nose, and throat. The mission is one of the charities of Mrs. W.H. Vanderbilt and her son, Mr. Cornelius Vanderbilt, undertaken to forward good work on the part of members of St. Bartholomew's Church, Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, where they attend divine service.

THE OLDEST OF TRADES -- There are in all twenty-three different kinds of flint made, but it requires some ingenuity to stretch them out so far. For instance, to make up the list, you have gray muskets and black muskets, where difference is not at all in the workmanship, but in the alleged quality of the flint.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Among the various new buildings which are in the process of erection there is probably none which win supply a long-felt need more than the Princeton Inn. The building is being erected by a stock company composed of the alumni and students of the college, and is designed o afford suitable accommodation to the alumni and guests of the students on their visits to the university.
A young woman recounting some recent European experiences the other evening told, among other things, of an episode in the French capital.

The social movement is a still confined to the country and the suburbs, and of the suburbs Tuxedo continues to be the gayest. There have been dinners at Tuxedo every evening at almost all the cottages and at the clubhouse, while the days have been devoted to driving, riding, rowing, and sailing on the lake, and to shooting parties, in some of which some of the belles of the place have participated.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 29 -- Last June, while Bowdoin was still rejoicing over the gift of the Walker Art Building, costing over $100,000. Gen. Hubbard of New-York City, in behalf of Mr. Searles, who has figured conspicuously in the Searles-Hopkins will contest, presented to the college a laboratory which will, when finished, be superior to anything of its kind in the country.

At 6 o'clock on the morning of July 6, 1851, old Martin, the janitor, emerged from the basement of the seminary and plodded along the path to the belfry. There he grasped the rope with the swing of a quarter century's habit, and the bell responded with the same peal which had aroused sleepy theological students every morning during that period.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Daniel Frohman's New-York Lyceum Theatre company closed to-night a successful engagement of three weeks at the Hollis Street Theatre with a performance of "The Charity Ball." The only play new to Boston that has been offered this week was "Squire Kate," which was given by this company on Monday night and was twice repeated later on.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29 -- The largest and most enthusiastic meeting of the campaign in New-Haven was the one hero to-night and addressed by Bourke Cookran. Though the meeting began at 7:3O o'clock, in older to accommodate the speaker, every seat in the Grand Opera House, even to the last row in the second gallery, was occupied, and many had to be content with, standing room.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The question which everybody in Orange is asking everybody else at this time is, "When is the social season to begin?" Tho Country Club ball two weeks ago was the formal opening of what at that time was prophesied to be a gay Winter, but since then there have been no announcements of any other events to transpire.

JAIL: GAOL -- These are now ear and eye forms, respectively, of one and the same word. In earlier days each, had its own distinct pronunciation, as is attested by the family name Gayler. Gaol, our oldest sound form, owes its survival to the influence of the French geole, though the anomaly of g sounded soft before a has been vigorously protested against.

LISBON, Oct. 29 -- Of the 122 persons -- passengers and crew -- who were on the Anchor Line Steamer Roumania, wrecked Thursday night on the Portuguese coast, only seven survive. These are Capt. George Hamilton of the British Indian Army, Lieut. Roohe, and seven Lascars.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 29 -- Editor Benjamin Feigenbaum of the New-York Arbeiter Zeitung and Nathan Saggen, a Russian Socialist of this city, were held in $600 and $500 bail, respectively, by Magistrate Kane this morning on charges of inciting to riot, assaulting an officer, and breach of the peace. This action was the result of a small riot last night which was quelled by a squad of police.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- As already briefly stated In last night's dispatches, politics has brought trouble to the Union Veteran's Union, and W.H. Michael, Commander of the Department of the Potomco, is suspended in consequence.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The Glenridge seniors and the Stevens Institute freshmen played a sharply-contested football came here to-day. The Glenridge's proved superior back of the rush line, and won by a score of 10 to 0.

NIAGARA FALLS, Oct. 29 -- As If by magic the cataract here about 4 o'clock this morning took on a heavier roar and in two hours the river below the falls in the gorge began steadily to rise until it showed an increase of from ten to twelve feet. The waves were soon rushing over the docks of the Maid of the Mist Company on both the American and Canadian sides of the river.

The week just closed, the next to the last of the great Presidential campaign of 1892, brought abundant hope to the Democrats on the one hand and brought out more of the tricky tactics of the Republican managers on the other hand.

GREAT PROCESSORS OF THE PAST -- Among the most famous physicians of the University of Alexandria were Cleombrotus, Herophilus, and Erasistratus, and among the subordinate physicians was Philostephanus, who had charge of the natural history department of the museum and who wrote a book on fishes.

Rumors have teen current for some weeks that the Staten Island Athletic Club was to be reorganized and that the club's finances were not in a satisfactory shape, but very few outside of the club and many of its members do not know that the preliminary steps for the reorganization have already been taken and that all of the club's property is to-day in the hands of the Sheriff of Richmond County.

In their desperation the managers of the Republican campaign, are now doing things quite unworthy of what -- until these breaches -- has been a campaign of education as well as of dignity. Worse than disgraceful is the attempt to deceive voters by unsupported statements that as Governor at New-York Grover Cleveland lent his support to legislation intended to oppose labor reform, sad embarrass the workingman's position.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29 -- "I am known in this community as a Republican, but I am a Democrat," wore the words spoken by N.W. Guernsey at a public meeting at Hansen's hall to-night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- This afternoon Harvard played her second game with Amherst, winning by a score of 34 to 10. In the first game, Oct. 8, Harvard had made 26 points, but had played so much better than Amherst that the latter never camo anywhere near scoring. Within the three weeks Amherst has improved much more than Harvard, for the playing of the "crimson" team was weak and uncertain.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The failing or the Autumn-tinted leaves and the cool, bracing northwest wind are signs of Lakewood's season. Judging from present indications, this Wintel will be one of profit to the hotel and boardinghouse proprietors and a season of social enjoyment to the sojourners from the city.

In May last a fourteen-ton block of North River bluestone, quarrled in Maiden Township, in the CatsKills, near Saugerties, arrived at the marble yards of R.C. Fisher Co., at Corlears Hook. Since then the stone has been out into a monument in the form of a Celto-Runic cross, which will soon be erected in Trinity Cemetery over the tomb of Audubon, the naturalist, artist, and ornithologist.

We take leave to defend the Census Office against a base imputation. Bulletins regarding manufactures in cities are now falling upon editorial desks thicker than snowflakes in an old-fashioned Winter, and it has been charged that their issue has been timed with a view to making votes on election day.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- John Thomas Doyle, Special Agent of the Civil Service Commission, has just completed an investigation of the methods of the Republican Committee in levying campaign assessments on Government employes in Jefferson County. His investigations were confined to the Watertown Post Office and the Cape Vincent Custom House, where he found ample proof that assessments had been levied as stated in dispatches printed in THE TIMES a few days ago.

The first game of the American Intercollegiate Football Association's championship series was played yesterday afternoon on Manhattan Field, at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth street and Eighth Avenue. The competing teams were those of Princeton and Wesleyan. Princeton won the match by a score at 60 to 0.
ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- The head of the Commerce Insurance Company here estimates that the loss to the company by the Milwaukee fire will not exceed $30,000.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- One of the most desperate and underhanded, schemes of Republican managers to secure false registration has been revealed to-day. Every effort has been made to carry it out; even the aid of United States authorities was evoked to consummate the plans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Judge Thomas M. Cooley of Michigan has openly declared for Mr. Cleveland.
