His positive announcement in favor of the Democratic national ticket puts an end to conflicting newspaper comments and gives the lie to certain Republican organs which have persistently denied that Judge Cooley, had announced himself in favor of Cleveland and Stevenson.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 29 -- Joseph Courtney of Portsmouth, England, beat Peter Priddy in a two-mile race to-day at Exposition Park, and he beat him easily. Priddy collapsed entirely at a mile and a quarter. The race was a very one-sided affair. The betting was tame.

A great far cape, that looks warm enough to suit an Esquimau, has one or two points worth noting. The cape proper, which is a little, very little, less than three-quarter length, begins at the shoulders. Above is a plain, smoothly-fitting pointed yoke, to which the cape is gathered into slight fullness, The junction is hidden by a roll of furas large around as a blacksmith's wrist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation $164,778,000, as follows: Currency sixes, $11,847,000; 4 per cents, $131,033,150; 2 per cents, $21,897,850.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- The practice of the Harvard football team this week has not been wholly gratifying, for Capt. Trafford has been trying the men in new positions, and as a result the playing has been as poor as it was at the beginning of the season. As only three weeks remain before the Harvard-Yale game, the Harvard men are beginning to grow anxious.

Ex-Congressman John E. Russell of Massachusetts and District Attorney James W. Ridgway of Brooklyn spoko yesterday at the noon meeting of the Wholesale Dry Goods Men's Oleveland and Stevenson Club. The meeting was held, in the headquarters, 384 Broadway. More than 2,500 were present.

To the Editor of the New-YorK Times: A paragraph in this morning's TIMES in regard to the relations between the Brooklyn Art Association and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences is so inaccurate that I feel it due to all concerned that the facts should be correctly stated.

New-York is admirably equipped with schools for students of the fine arts, from beginners up to the point when a pupil feels himself strong enough to trust his own wings. But the higher education of the artist does not exist, that further study in his profession which has a parallel in the post-graduate courses of universities and the curriculum of Johns Hopkins University.

Five rascals were arrested and locked up at Police Headquarters last evening on the charge or instigating illegal registration. They had the evidence on them to show that they were acting as agents for such worthy employers as "Dave" Martin and "King of Colonizers" Quay.

The Board of Engineers, United States Army, consisting of Brig. Gen. Henry L. Abbot, President; Col. C.B. ComstocK, CoL D.C. Houston, and Lieut. Col. E.L. Gillespie, met yesterday at the Army Building to hear views expressed on the location of the two bridges that the East River Bridge Company purposes to erect across the East River, and upon the clear height of the bridges above high water.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The Lecture Association of the University of Pennsylvania will not begin its work this year until January. Dr. S. Weir Mitchell will open the sixth year of the association on Jan. 7: he will deliver one lecture and will be followed by two from Mr. Talcott Williams. Mr. Hudson Shaw, Fellow of Balliot College, Oxford, is to give six lectures on "English Social Reforms."
As the campaign draws to a close it is seen, in Kings County at least, to resemble in many respects the interesting canvass of one year ago.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 29 -- C.L. Magee, who is conducting the Republican campaign in Alabama, could evidently find no printer in that State whom he could trust to print the tickets for those whom he hopes to be able to induce to vote for Republican Electors and the Kolb State ticket, for he had 1,500,000 such tickets printed in this city.

Here are some startling facts about the way the McKinley high-tariff law has affected the working classes in this city. It is a sorry showing for the law, bat it is a sorrier showing for the people who suffer under it. It is the result of a careful investigation made during the past few days.

Residents along the South Shore line of the Staten Island Railway have been visited by underground fires which are peculiarly hard to fight. They have thus far proved exceedingly annoying, and may soon endanger property. Several valuable pieces of woods have been destroyed.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Shortly after 12 o'clock this morning John McElmeel, accompanied by James Smith, went into William Jones's saloon at 142 Riverdale Avenue, this city. Soon after, Jones and Smith got into a controversy over politics, in which McElmeel also joined, siding with his friend Smith. Smith drew a knife.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The President and the members of his private and official family who accompanied him to Indianapolis to pay the last earthly tribute to the late mistress of the White House returned to the national capital at 5 o'clock this afternoon.
On no day of this campaign has there been so much talk of a campaign corruption fund for use by the Republican National Committee as was heard yesterday.

Judged by the amount of business done, the two events of the week in the stock market were the movements of New-England and Distillers' Trust, or Whisky Trust, whichever you like. Two more highly speculative stocks than these, in their respective departments, it would be hard to find. Each can show in its varied history, equally sensational movements; but New-England stock, being a much older acquaintance than the other stock, scores more of them.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the N.Y. Associated Press. BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- Emperor William will open the Reichstag in person Nov. 22. While the Imperial Parliament is wrestling over the Army bill the Prussian Landtag, which has been summoned to meet Nov. 9, will be involved in an eager party fight on the fiscal reforms proposed by Dr. Miquel, Minister of Finance.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 29 -- The students from North Carolina met Thursday night to agitate the formation of a social organization of the students from that State. Addresses were made by Dr. A.M. Elliott and Prof. E.G. Davis. Thirteen students were present.

Cotton receded somewhat yesterday from the high prices that had lately prevailed, on a dispatch received at the Cotton Exchange and believed to have been sent out by Neill, the authority on cotton statistics at New-Orleans and Liverpool, in which the crop now making was estimated at 8,000.000 bales. Dealings in the cotton market of late have been based upon estimates of from 6,000,000 to 7,000,000 bales.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29 -- The feature of the football gossip at Yale the current week has been the coming to town of Heffelfinger and the speculation as to whether he would re-enter college and play football. He came East with the football team of the Chicago Athletic Club, and naturally improved the opportunity to come to New-Haven and see how the Yale boys were playing the game.

All Hallow Even or Halloween, which is to-morrow night, is undoubtedly a relic of pagan times. The Druids were accustomed to Kindling sacred fires on the eve of Nov. 1, possibly to ward off evil spirits, as in the popular imagination this has always been considered the high carnival season for witches, fairies, and the immaterial principle in humanity to wander abroad.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The theatrical season, which opened so well that managers were highly elated at the prospects of making up the losses they incurred last season, is scarcely fulfilling the promises of its earlier days. Yet it is proving fairly satisfactory, and the best evidence of prosperity has been the gradual reopening of all the theatres.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 29 -- Recently a number of remarkably well-executed Aztec idols have been received here from a village near Volcano Ajusco, which, it will be remembered, was once the most active volcano in Mexico.

The eleventh supplementary practice was held, yesterday at Creedmoor. The weather was cloudy early in the morning, but soon cleared up. There was a brisk 7 to 10 o'clock "fish-tail" wind blowing in the forenoon, but in the afternoon it increased and blew a gale, making shooting very difficult.

There was a large congregation in St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, yesterday afternoon to participate in the musical service that was held there in memory of Mrs. Henry Dale, who died at her Tarrytown home about a month ago. Friends and members of St. James's parish were present by invitation, but strangers were admitted as well.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- The Swiss Democratic Club organization is taking an active part in national politics. At a meeting held some weeks ago, it authorized the officers to prepare an address to Grover Cleveland, of which the following is a copy:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 30 -- "Nothing but apathy and overconfidence," say the Wisconsin Republicans, "will give this State to Cleveland. We were beaten two years ago by stay-at-home Republicans; if those who then refrained from voting can be induced to come out we shall carry the State by something like our former majori ties."
Another sad boating accident occurred last night, resulting in the death of one man and injuries to three other members of the party. The Sound steamer Puritan of the Fall River Line was the cause.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Dispatches from this point which have heretofore appeared in THE TIMES have made public the fact that for weeks the Republican managers in the State nave abandoned all hope of winning her Electoral vote for the Republican national ticket.

William M. Harnett, one or the best known still-life painters in the country, died Saturday of uraemia at the New-York Hospital, whither he had been taken on Thursday from his studio 42 West Thirtieth Street, where he was found unconsciens. He was attended during his last hours by his sister, who came on from Philadelphia.

The best promise of Democratic success in this State is found in the registration in this city -- 309,759. It is about 24,000 heavier than ever before. It is decidedly a Democratic registration -- the gains are all Democratic, the decreases are all Republican. It is a great registration for Cleveland and Stevens on. All the Democratic managers are sincerely satisfied with it.

The Printers' Cleveland League held another large and enthusiastic meeting yesterday afternoon at Military Hall, 193 Bowery. Thomas F. Bradley asked what good the McKinley high tariff had done the workingmen, and answered by quoting statistics which showed that wages had not been raised, although prices of necessaries had increased, and consequently the workman got less now for his money than formerly.

It was in August that the story of a new project for making a canal on the Panama Isthmus came from France. The receiver of the bankrupt Panama Canal Company had induced M. HIELAND, Vice President of the Paris Chamber of Commerce, it was said, to join him in promoting a new company, or syndicate, which should finish the canal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- By making particularly rocky the road to the pockets of Governmen employes, the Civil Service Commission has incurred the deadly enmity of the Republican campaign managers.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 30 -- There are four tickets in the Held in Nevada for Presidential Electors, Representatives in Congress, and Regents of the State University.

The published accounts of the appearance in this city of H.C. Frick, manager of the Carnegie Steel Company, and of his conferences with prominent Republicans on Saturday, was discussed by the politicians all day yesterday. The belief that he had brought an immense corruption fund from the Pensyivania millionaires, who are willing to pay liberally for a continuance of protective legislation, was one of the prominent facts of the discussion.

Timothy Cole's engravings from the old Italian masters, which have been appearing in the Century during several years, as now collected in a volume by the same publishers make an impressive and beautiful art volume. It is of large octavo size, and printed by the De Vinne Press. Mr. Cole's full-page engravings are sixty-seven in number, and represent all the most famous Italians of the great art period.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- In Oewego the manufacturer is happy, the farmer gloomy, the Democrats are cheerful, and the Republicans despondent. The reasons are apparent on the face of things. Oswego for the first time in many years is experiencing the delightful sensations of a boom.

"Now, I wonder how much you have forgotten since the last time?" said Frank Damrosch yesterday afternoon, as he came before the singing class at Cooper Union. It was the People's Singing Class, and 2,500 members laughed at Mr. Damrosch for hinting at forgetting. They came there to learn and they went away to remember.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The Canadian paper manufacturers are about to combine to protect their interests. It is said that unlimited English capital is back or this movement, and a syndicate of all the large mills of Canada will be formed this week. If this is accomplished it will mean the closing up of quite a number of smaller mills, and a new stimulus to trade prices.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Oct. 30 -- The worst fire that St. Johnsbury has ever known broke out about 7 o'clock this evening and raged fiercely for two hours before it was brought under control. In that time several business blocks and a large number of stores were destroyed.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30 -- The scene of Milwaukee's great fire was visited to-day by fully 150,000 people. Not only was more than half the population of the city there during the day, but thousands came from neighboring towns.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 30 -- The strike of the wrarehousemen, draymen, packers, and sugar salestnen still continues. No attempt to bring about a conference has been made, the strikers taking their stand behind the American Federation of Labor and refusing to treat unless the unions are first recognized and a committee from the labor loaders allowed to join in the arbitration.

Since the meeting of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, held at Chicago last week, much speculation has been indulged in as to the decision arrived at regarding the amateur question. There has been preserved a decided silence by all the members of the board bearing on this subject, which is of such vital importance to the membership of the organization at large.

THE ARION CHARITY CONCERT. The Arion Male Chorus Society should congratulate itself upon its own existence as an institution, upon its admirably-trained body of singers, and upon its energetic conductor, Frank van der Stucken. The society gave a most delightful concert last night at Music Hall, and the large audience which assembled to hear the music and contribute its dollars toward the Arion's charitable enterprises, dispersed in a happy frame of mind.

In his campaign tour through the country Mr. McKINLEY finds it necessary to discredit and repudiate his party's official handbook concerning the prices of protected products -- that ponderous report upon which Senators ALDRICH, ALLISON, and HISCOCK, Commissioner CARROLL D. WRIGHT, the New-York Tribune's partisan, economist, and a considerable number of Government employes, were engaged for several months.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Oct. 30. -- Trouble has come upon the People's Party in Ohio. State Chairman Barnes has been deposed as the effect of a controversy in the first subdivision of the Tenth Judicial District.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Lord Dunraven has given to the Associated Press, in an interview, a statement of his position in connection with the challenge he recently sent to the New-York Yacht Club for a race for the America's Cup.
BOSTON, Oct 30 -- The British steamer Oramore, which arrived here this morning, had on board the crew of the wrecked bark Supreme, picked up at son. Capt. Bartlett of the Oranmore reports:
POTTSTOWN, Penn., Oct. 30 -- The unusual spectacle of a uniformed policeman patroling the aisles of a church during religions services was witnessed here to-day at the Stephens Re- formed Church.

William M.F. Round, Corresponding Secretary of the Prison Association of New-York, addressed the congregation of the University Place Presbyterian Church last night on the subject of the need of prison reform in tills State. It coat more, be declared, to support the criminal clauses and to protect good citizens against thorn than it cost Great Britain to support her army.

There has not been a Presidential election within the average lifetime of a generation in which business has been so little affected as in this campaign. Usually there is a considerable interruption to business, either from excitement, which takes men's minds off, or from uncertainty as to the effect of a victory by one or another party.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 30 -- Late in the day yesterday, Gov. Fleming signed office papers removing J.E. Johnson from the office of Tax Collector in this (Duval) county.

A glance at the totals of the completed registration tables shows that the City of New-York has fallen short of the figures she was expected to reach, while Brooklyn, more patriotic or more thoroughly aroused, actually exhibits a larger increase in registered voters as compared with 1888 than our own city.

ALEXANDER KNOX. Alexander Knox died at his home, 38 West Seventeenth Street, this city, Saturday noon, in his eighty-sixth year. An injury to his foot had made him a sufferer for nearly a year. He was much better during the Summer while at his country home at Cottage City, Martha's Vineyard, but grew worse on his return to the city five weeks ago.

Tennyson memorial services were held yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. The singing was of a special nature to conform to the purposes of the occasion. Two sermons were delivered, one by the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke, pastor of the church, and the other by the Rev. Dr. Hall.
"I've been a tariff reformer for four years in a theoretical way, but it's only since this morning that I've felt a personal interest in the matter," said a New-York newapaper man to his desk fellow.

The new chapel of the Nostrand Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, on Quincy Street, Brooklyn, was dedicated and opened for services yesterday. The new structure is situated in the rear of the main church building, and has just been completed at a cost of $50,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- The old Shawmut Congregational Church has come to the end of the long lane where there must be a turning, but whether it shall be to the right or the left, the congregation stands in divided sections at the crossroads debating.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 31 -- A.M. A fair amount of activity prevailed in the stock trading last week, but the market remained almost as narrow as ever. The few specialists still represented the bulk of the business, although, signs of life were exhibited at times at other points on the list.

PENICHE, Portugal, Oct. 30 -- The coast of this region is strewn for miles with wreckage and goods from the cargo or the steamer Roumania, which was wrecked Thursday night off the fishing village of Grono, near here. Everything that comes ashore is rapidly becoming covered with sand. Coast guards are protecting goods thrown ashore by the waves.

BANGOR, Me., Oct 30 -- By the end of this month the steam and water mills from which comes the creator part of the long lumber manufactured in Maine will have been closed for the Winter, and therefore an accurate estimate can be made of the output The operations along the Penobscot River are the heaviest in the State, and here 198,000,000 feet of long lumber have been manufactured.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Shortly after 4 o'clock this morning, and but a few minutes after the fireman at the pumping station of the Point Breeze Gas Works had replenished his fires, the people in the vicinity were startled by the sound of an explosion. A moment later the flames shot up from the river and a pall of dense black smoke began to gather over the wharves and shipping in the harbor.

From the semi-annual report on savings banks of this State, issued by the Superintendent of the Banking Department last July, the Tribune has attempted to show that there has bean an extraordinary growth in deposits in the savings banks, the increase being attributed to the Harrison Administration by the Republican organ.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for the Vice Presidency, has sent the following letter of acceptance to the President of the National Democratic Convention:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Kenna of West Virginia expressed the opinion this evening that his State would be counted in the Democratic column on election day, despite the efforts of "Steve" Elkins.

The old John Street Methodist Church celebrated two anniversaries yesterday, one being the one hundred and twenty-fourth of its dedication and the other the one hundred and twenty-sixth of the establishment of Methodism in America. There were five services during the day, and all were well attended, many persons who had never visited the oldest Methodist Episcopal Church in America being present.

WASHINGTO, Oct. 31 -- The Civil Service Commission has reported to the Attorney General for criminal prosecution, under the law against soliciting political contributions, the case of Samuel Thomas, Treasurer of the Republican State Committee of New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 31 -- The dispatches from New-York announce that Mr. Charles Noel, President or the Olympic Club, was negotiating for some big pugilistic events on behalf of the Crescent City Athletic Club. The name is a now one here, and the telegram was the first intimation the general public received that such a club was in existence.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 31 -- The fusion of the Democratic and the People's Party in Colorado almost insures Republican defeat. For the first time in its history in a Presidential year will Colorado's vote be taken out of the Republican column.

The second annual chrysanthemum show under the management of the New-York Florist's Club will open in the Madison Square Garden to-day at 2 o'clock. The judges will be at work from noon until the opening hour.

Correspondents, who are naturally puzzled by the fact, having watched the course of public opinion since the opening of the campaign, write to THE TIMES to ask us to explain the cause of the recent accession of confidence shown by the Republican politicians. That there is a manifestation of such a feeling more or less sincere, and that it has shown itself in a somewhat marked manner within the last week, is plain enough.
Coutributions to the Democratic Campaign Fund should be sent to Robert B. Roosevelt, Treasurer of the National Democratic Committee, 139 Fifth Avenue, New-York.
Otto Kempner, the Tammany candidate for Assembly in the Seventh District, is making a thorough canvass, and his election is assured.

The careful inquiries made two or three years ago by certain State officers in Massachusetts concerning the prevalence of tuberculosis in dairy herds situated within twenty or thirty miles of Boston revealed a great many cases of the disease and stimulated inquiry of the same kind in neighboring States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- First reports from the yards indicated large receipts of hogs, and prices were 10@ 15c lower. Later the figures were revised and an advance was scored. The speculative market, which opened weak, eased off early, reacted on the second reports from the yards, but finally sagged off under the liberal offerings of January stuff from the packers.

The provisional estimates for the appropriations for 1893 were completed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday by passing on the allowances for the various charitable institutions. The fact that the total is considerably in excess of the figures for 1892 was explained by Mayor Grant as due to the increase in the State taxes.

The Republican platform of this year and all the Republican speakers and papers profess adhesion to that degree of "protection" in the form of tariff duties which shall offset the difference in wages here and in foreign countries. The words of the platform are very explicit. They are as follows:

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 31. -- Wayne MacVeagh addressed a large and enthusiastic meeting here to-night. It was in many respects a Yale rally, conducted under the direction of the Cleveland battalion of students, which escorted Mr. MacVeagh to the Hyperion.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- A Republican plot to buy Indiana, notwithstanding the Australian ballot law, has boon discovered. The Republican State Committee has issued a letter of instructions to precinct committeemen which is far more sweeping in scope than the famous Dudley blooks-of-five letter.

Never since the civil service law was adopted have there been such persistent efforts to violate or evade the provisions which forbid the solicitation of contributions for political purposes from Government employes as have been made during the present campaign by Republican committees.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Mrs. Annie L. Brownlee, eighty years of ago, was Killed this morning by her daughter, Mrs. Mary Marean, fifty years old, at her home, 66 Dana Street, Cambridge. Mrs. Marean was evidently temporarily insane. After committing the deed she went to the door and called Miss Caroline Fuller, and conducted her through the Hallway on the first floor.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 31 -- Amherst easily defeated Troy Polytechnic at football this afternoon on Pratt Field. The visitors' rush line, with the exception of McPherson at left guard, was very weak and made scarcely any headway against Amherst. Amherst's team work has improved wonderfully during the past few days, and to-day her interference was of the best.

The important question discussed at the monthly meeting of the Executive Committee of the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon was whether the museum should be closed on Sundays. Some of tne Trustees, who had hitherto been supporters of the Sunday-opening movement, were of the opinion that it would be necessary to discontinue that movement for lack of means.

The influence of Federal office holders should not be felt in the manipulation of political primary meetings and nominating conventions. The use by these officials of their positions to compass their selection as delegates to political conventions is indecent and unfair; and proper regard for the proprieties and requirements of official place will also prevent their assuming the active conduct of political campaigns.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Shall Mr. Cornish of Washington, N.J., be transformed into Mr. Cornish of Washington, D.C.? That's the point around which the Warren County politicians are making the State canvass revolve.

John T. McKane, King of Coney Island, has had his rapacious maw in many a good thing, but nothing quite so pleasing as the fighting club by the sea. It is turning out a veritable gold mine, and many Brooklyn politicians are this morning shaking hands with themselves for coming in on the ground floor. Unquestionably, politics has its remuneration, but successful fighting clubs are bonanzas.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Oct. 31 -- P.M. The stock market was generally strong to-day, with an increase in activity in the Vanderbilt securities and the Grangers, which showed substantial advances. The close was firm in the case of most of the list, although some of the cheaper stocks were weaker than they had been early in the day.

The United States training ship Portsmouth, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, is the only remaining sloop-of-war of the number once carried on the naval lists. She is the last of the three vessels -- Saratoga, Jamestown, and Portsmouth -- which in recent years constituted the training squadron.

PENICHE, Portugal, Oct. 31 -- The bodies of several persons who perished through, the wrecking of the Anchor Line steamer Roumania were burled in the village of Obidos to-day. The chaplain of the British Legation at Lisbon road the services tor the dead and offered a prayer beside the graves. Several members of the British Legation attended as mourners.

Next month the terms of seven members of the Board of Education will expire, and Mayor Grant will make the appointments of their successors. Amons: the members of the board whose terms thus expire is Mrs. Clara M. Williams, who is now the only woman Commissioner on the board.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 -- The Germania Maennerchor, and probably the Baltimore Liederkranz, the Arion Society, and the Arbeiter Maennerchor, four of the five leading German singing organizations in Baltimore, are said to be considering the advisability of withdrawing from the Baltimore Saengerbund, or the United Singers of Baltimore.

The striking wiremen held a mass meeting yesterday morning and appointed pickets to watch the offices of the members of the Electric Contractors' Association and try to prevent non-union workmen from applying for work. The meeting also gratefully accepted the offer of the Board of Walking Delegates to order general strikes in all buildings where non-union wiremen shall be found at work this morning.

WITTENBERG, Oct. 31 -- This old town of pointed gables, quaint towers, and narrow streets to-day presented a unique aspect. Everywhere bright banners and floral festoons were seen, the streets were crowded with sight-seers, and the whole town bore a holiday appearance.

The new bill at the Standard Theatre comprises two plays -- a one-act sketch founded on Dickens's "Boots at the Holly Tree Inn," and a three-net farce taken from the French of Bisson by Sydney Rosenfeld. Neither Mrs. Burnett, whoso idea it was to make a stage play out of one of the slightest and least probable of all Dicken's occasional pieces, nor Mr. Rosenfeld seems to owe very much to the original author.
Since it was announced that Judge Walter Q. Gresham intended to vote for Mr. Cleveland, the Republicans have been persistently denying the truth of the statement.

In no other part of the public discussion of the tariff by the defenders of McKinleyism has there been shown so much quibbling, evasion, and downright dishonesty as in that part which relates to the comparative prices of tin plate. Special Agent AYER of the Treasury Department says in his report, issued two or three days ago:

To Americans the marked and emphatic refusal of the members of the British Ministry to attend the Lord Mayor's dinner will be matter of pure wonder. Mr. GLADSTONE had a perfectly good excuse in his age, his infirmities, and his occupations, although the absence of the Prime Minister from the inaugural banquet of the Lord Mayor of London is said to be without precedent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- A thoughless act cost one life and much suffering to two men and destroyed $15,000 worth of property this evening at Point Breeze, the extreme southern point of the city. The Schuylkill River at Point Breeze is always covered with a thin scum of oil from adjacent oil works, and since the oil fire there on Sunday more than the usual quantity has been floating on the surface.

The first football match of the interscholastic championship series was played at Berkeley Oval, Morris Heights, yesterday afternoon, between the teams of the Berkeley School and Columbia Grammar School.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- Several days ago Henry M. Cleveland or Brooklyn, this State, addressed a letter to ex-Judge S. Lynde Harrison of this city, asking his reasons for resigning from the Republican League. Judge Harrison's letter in reply bears date of Oct. 28. The full text is as follows :

The sealed proposals for the construction of the new battle ship and armored cruiser authorized by Congress on July 19 of the present year will be opened at the Navy Department on Dec. 15 next The proposals call for the building of one sea-going battle ship of about 9,000 tons displacement and one armored cruiser of about 8,000 tons displacement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Beginning to-day, passenger rates were raised as follows: Chicago to Kansas City, from $10 to $12.50; Chicago to St. Joseph, from $10 to $12.50; Chicago to Leavenworth, from $10 to $12.50; Chicago to St. Louis, from $6 to $7.50; St. Louis to Kansas City, from $5 to $7.50; St. Louis to Leavenworth, from $5.50 to $81 St. Louis to Atchison and St. Joseph, from $6 to $8.50.

It is surprising that a reputable lawyer like Mr. JAMES W. HAWKS should be willing to lend the support of his professional opinion and counsel to such a stupid and sinful proposition as that made by "BARNEY" BIGLIN'S henchman BARRON before the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- District Attorney Quinby of Eric County has received the official report of the shooting of the boy Michael Broderiok by soldiers of the Twenty-second Regiment during the railroad strike last August.

John P. Button of Lincoln, Neb., for many years, under President Fitzgerald, Secretary of the Irish National League, and always an ardent Republican, has written and made public a letter in which he gives the reasons that have caused him to change his political faith. Mr. Sutton is widely known among Irish-Americans as one who devoted himself to the cause of the National league from patriotic, not commercial, reasons.

Oliver O. Gardiner, who died at the residence of his daughter, 29 West Ninety-third Street, on Monday last of heart failure, was born in the town of North Berwick, Me., in 1813. He received his preliminary education in the South Berwick Academy, and was graduated from the Colby University, formerly known as the Waterville College, in 1838.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., NOV. 1. -- Just as Cornish is the disturbing factor in Warren County politics, young Mr. O'Brien is a disturbing factor in Morris County politics.

While the tally-ho coach Republic was preparing yesterday morning for its usual trip from the Plaza Hotel to Tuxedo at King's stables, Fifty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, the four horses attached became restive and ran out of the stable. They swerved as they went out and caught the door with the hub of a wheel, damaging the door.

Republican Inspector of Election Thomas F. Barren, a confessed henchman of " Barney" Biglin, was on trial yesterday before the Police Commissioners for refusing to register a duly-qualified voter who presented himself for that purpose at the place of registry of the Ninth Election District of the Fourteenth Assembly District, because all the three Inspectors were not present at the time.

BATH, N. Y., Nov. 1. -- Residents of New-York and Brooklyn have wondered this year why grapes have been so abundant and so cheap. The flavor has never been finer, the grade never higner. The grape grower of this section of the State can answer the question to his own sorrow and to his pecuniary discomfiture. He charges it all to the McKinley bill.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 1. -- The greatest strike that has ever taken place in New-Orleans will be begun to-morrow morning. The teamsters, loaders, and warehousemen who struck on Monday of last week to enforce a demand that the merchants sign the tariff which they presented to them and that they recognize the union have failed to accomplish their object.

A self-confessed forger with a peculiar history, who, according to his own admissions, has been engaged during the past eighteen months in scattering forged drafts varying in amounts from $25 to $700 broadcast over the country, was captured yesterday by Detective Sergeants Shoridan and Hanley, and is locked up at Police Headquarters.

Judge Thomas M. Cooley of Michigan has openly declared for Mr. Cleveland. His positive announcement in favor of the Democratic national ticket puts an end to conflicting newspaper comments and gives the lie to certain Republican organs which have persistently denied that Judge Cooley had announced himself in favor of Cleveland and Stevenson.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The announcement was officially made this afternoon that Mr. Gladstone had declined to attend the inaugural banquet of Lord Mayor-elect Stuart Knill on Nov. 9. His declination is especially significant, as it has been the custom in past years tat the Prime Minister, in his response to a toast at this banquet, to review the work of the Government and speak or its plans for the future.

The letter of ex-Judge LYNDE HARRISON of Connecticut announcing his reasons for voting for Mr. CLEVELAND this year will be found in our columns this morning. It is a very frank and interesting statement. Mr. HARRISON, like so many men of prominence who have followed the same course, has been always a Republican.

A special meeting of the Trunk Line Executive Committee has been called for Tuesday, the 15th inst., to consider the subject of World's Pair rates. It is not expected that the General Passenger Agents will do anything further in the matter until after the Executive Committee has acted. The point to be settled first is the kind of ticket to be issued for the vise of World's Fair excursionists.

With every hour in these final days of the canvass the assurance that Cleveland and Stevenson will carry the State by a splendid plurality and be elected President and Vice President of the United States increases. All indications point to it. All conservative judges in both parties concede the State to the Democrats.

Joseph H. Manley, the member of the Republican National Committee from Maine, yesterday felt it necessary to tell the Republicans of his State to come to the polls next Tuesday and save the six Electoral votes for Harrison. He sent a telegram urging them to do so, which was spoken of as "Joe Manley's joke."
PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 1. -- "Can Weaver carry Oregon if the Democratic Electoral ticket is withdrawn?"

"News from Indiana," said Congressman Cummings at National Democratic Headquarters yesterday, "is inspiriting. If the election were held to-day in that State I am assured by Democrats of prominence on the ground that they would carry it by at least 10,000 plurality. We have the Republicans at a standstill there. They are flooding too State with boodle, but are having a hard time to secure results with it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Early reports from the yards called the hog market, firm, and quoted an advance of 5c for desirable lots. On this the speculative market opened moderately firm, but on a later report that shippers were out of the market, selling became more general. Commission men joined the packers and prices fell off. There was a slight reaction at the close, but the list closed lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The powder barges will stay on the Jersey City flats. The inhabitants of that shore and Ellis Island recently complained that the storage of powder at the adjacent anchorage threatened life and property. An official inquiry was instituted.

If there be any weak-kneed Democrats, or any supporters of the Democratic Presidential ticket who fail to appreciate the extraordinary hold that Grover Cleveland has upon the affections of the people, such persons should have been in the Lenox Lyceum last night. They would have taken into their systems a most invigorating tonic.

If old General Apathy, whom the managers of Mr. Harrison's campaign would have the people believe is the most conspicuous character in this election, would visit the headquarters of the Wholesale Dry Goods Men's Cleveland and Stevenson Club, 384 Broadway, at noon any day he would find that his enemy, General Enthusiasm, was in complete possession of that field.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The Democrats held a largely-attended meeting in the Academy of Music to-night. Arthur A. McLean presided, and John J. Delaney of New-York made the first speech. Senator Carlisle was the principal speaker. He spoke about one hour.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Damaging statements against the New-York and New-England Railroad wore made before Judge Prentice to-day in the Superior Court, affecting the road's claim to register $2,000,000 of the proposed issue of $25,000,000-bonds. The suit is to restrain the road from issuing the $2,000,000 bonds for registration. The hearing to-day was on a motion to compel the road to produce its books in court.

BUFFALO, Nov. 1. -- The Republicans were beaten to tie last ditch to-day, before a Judge of their own political stripo, in their efforts to prove illegal registration. This is the third futile attempt to score a point against the Democracy.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1. -- Indiana is no more doubtful for Cleveland than is Kentucky. This is so because the Democrats have 18.000 more votes than, the Republicans. The Democratic organization is the most perfect political machinery ever put to work in this State, and all safeguards necessary to protect the ballot box from the repetition of the boodle frauds of 1888 have been provided for.

The Brooklyn Democratic leaders took hold of the revolt in the Fourteenth Ward yesterday and chopped off the political head of its leader, "Lorry" Carroll He is the man who has been trying to build up a personal following in the ward, and for that reason nominated Edward Olark for Assembly and "Pat" Ralph for Supervisor.

From the Albany Argus, (Dam.,) Nov. 1. In another column the Argus publishes the total number of personally registered voters in the cities of the State compared with the number last year. As the personally registry law did not go into effect until 1890, no comparison with 1888 is possible, and in 1890 there was no State contest.

The funeral of Alexander Knox, the merchant and philanthropist who died at his home, 38 West Seventeenth Street, on Saturday, in his eighty-sixth year, took place yesterday morning from the South Reformed Church, at Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, of which Mr. Knox was an elder. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Roderick Terry and the Rev. Dr. Willer.

The Special Congressional Committee which is investigating the doings of Chief Supervisor of Elections John I. Davenport was to have met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in Room 135 of the Federal Building. But only two Democratic members of the committee appeared. They were Congressmen Fitch, the Chairman, and Geissenhainer.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Attorney General Rosendale has prepared the following in regard to questions most frequently arising under the new ballot law, as he has been in constant receipt of communications concerning the construction of the law as amended by the last Legislature:

The Park Board is developing a tendency to speak with authority on matters of art. At yesterday's meeting there was quite a discussion concerning the value of the various statues that are presumed to adorn the public squares and parks, and the view was advanced that as a rule New-York's attempts at the sculpturesque were a disgrace to the city.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 2. -- Lieut. Frederick Schwatka of Alaskan exploration fame died here at 4:50 this morning. He was found at 3 o'clock lying on First Street, near Morrison, by an officer. By his aide was a bottle half empty, which contained laudanum. He was in a comatose condition and was immediately removed to St. Charles Hotel, where he was placed in a chair.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 2. -- A dispatch from Ottawa to the Empire (Government organ) saya: "A dispatch from Washington undertakes to give reasons which have led to the reciprocal wrecking agreement arrived at between the two Governments last Winter not going into effect. The real reason, however, has not been given.

CLINTON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The visits THE TIMES'S correspondent made to Lambertville and Flemington last night disclosed some peculiarities as to ex-Congressman James N. Pidcock's relations to the State canvass and the Democratic candidates that seemed to need explanation, and this morning the explanation was sought with some startling results.

Every patriotic heart responds to a tender consideration for those who, having served their country long and well, are reduced to destitution and dependence, not as an incident of their service, but with advancing ago or through sickness or misfortune. We are all tempted by the contemptation of such a condition to supply relief, and are often impatient of the limitations of public duty. -- Annual Message, 1886.

Inspector MCLAUGHIN and his subordinates deserve particular praise for their successful efforts to detect and expose cases of illegal and fraudulent registration. The police force is now, for the first time in a good many years, able to undertake such a work without laying itself open to the suspicion of a one-sided and partisan enforcement of the law.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Nov. 2. -- There is an air of weariness and apprehension about the headquarters of the Republican General County Committee here and the party in Niagara County is in bad straights. Deserted by the partyorgan, the Journal, which is fighting Harrison and Hiscock, the party managers hardly know what to do.

The North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II. reached port yesterday morning looking somewhat the worse for her long struggle with adverse gales encountered during the voyage from Bremen. In enumerating the casualties at Quarantine it was found that two of the crew were in hospital with broken legs and a third had been severely injured by a wave that came tumbling over the bow.

Although there is to be a convention next year to revise the Constitution of this State, it is desirable that the three amendments to be submitted to the people at the coming election should he ratified. It will be a direct notice to the convention that these provisions must be permanently incorporated in that instrument.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 2. -- The Republican leaders of Minnesota are in a panic. No less than twelve prominent men of the party here in the last forty-eight hours declared their intention to vote for Cleveland, and the tide is running so strongly in favor of the Democrats that hope is now expressed that not only the four indorsed Weaver Electors, but the five straight Democratic Electors, will have a majority in the State.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 2 -- Joseph W. Kay, Chairman or the Executive Committee of the Veterans' Rights Union, wrote Judge John P. Rao, exCommander of the Grand Army of the Republic, last week a letter of congratulation upon his stand in favor ot Grover Cleveland, in which he said:

Mme. Modjeske acted Beatrlee at the Garden Theatre last evening to the manifest pleasure of a numerous audience. This is not, indeed, one of her best roles. There is a touch of the virago in the sharp-tongued lady of Messina which the poet expresses frankly, and the actress but faintly suggests, and there is more passion in her feeling toward Claudio, after the brutal renunciation of Hero, than Mme. Modjeska chooses to discover.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- By far the largest crowd that has been on the University Field this season witnessed the football game to-day between the Varsity eleven and the Chicago athletic team. According to the expectation of all the Chicagos put their strongest team in the field, far surpassing any that has met the various college elevens during their Eastern trip.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 2 -- The contest in Michigan is between the Republicans and the Democrats. There is a People's Party organization; they have certified nominations for all the leading offices, and they will poll votes enough to make a respectable column in the returns; but it will not be a large vote, and Republicans and Democrats regard it as probable that it will not exceed 10,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- J. H. Clark, the silk manu facturer of Argusville, is still being named as a deserter from Democracy on the tariff question. It has been shown by his own confession that he never was a Democrat. It was only within the past five or six weeks that he became a citizen. Previous to 1889 he was the Superintendent in the FultonviUe silkmill.

SALEM, Oregon, Nov. 2. -- Lieut. Schwatka was well known in this city, where his early life was spent. He came here from Galena, Ill., with his parents in 1859, receiving his education at Williams University. He then learned the printer's trade, at which, he worked until 1867, when he received appointment to West Point. His father, Frederick Sohwatka, was a cooper, and worked at the trade while living here.

Strange as it may seem to the Republican of prohibition proolivities, the managers of his party in this State have been making strenuous efforts to capture the votes of the organized liquor dealers. In return for votes for Harrison and Reid these party managers have promised not only financial aid to the liquor-dealers' organization, but also legislative votes for an excise bill which will permit saloon Keepers to do business during certain hours on Sundays.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Provisions apparently had no friends during the early part of the session. Receipts of hogs were liberal, prices at the yards were lower, and most of the prominent operators wore sellers in the speculative market. Cudahy offered the best support to pork, while Wright took November lard, and the Anglo-American and Sohwartz, Dupee McCormick were moderate buyers of January pork.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- In no part of the State is the Democratic Party in better shape for a contest than in the northeastern corner, where Smith Weed of this city is looked upon as manager, The organization is excellent, the spirits of the rank and file superb. The work accomplished by Mr. Weed and his energetic lieutenants has bean unexcelled in its thoroughness, intelligence, and vigor.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 2. -- The local Republicans are greatly stirred up over the publication of the following letter:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- In the rain and fog this afternoon Harvard played football with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and won by a score of 34 to 0. The ground and the ball were so wet and the field was so dark toward the end that a slip or chance often counted more than strength or skill.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- To-day's practice of the Yale eleven was the most valuable the team has indulged in for weeks, as it was the only afternoon of the season thus far when the players have had an opportunity to handle a slippery ball. The small amount of fumbling done was an agreeable surprise to the coaches in attendance, ex-Capt. Rhodes and Walter Camp.

When the question is generally understood there will, we are confident, be no objection to the proposition that the Board of Estimate shall appropriate the maximum amount allowed by law to the maintenance of the Metropolitan Museum, or so much of that sum as may be needed for the running expenses of the institution.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2. -- In the recent grounding of the United States steamer Mohican in the Pacific 20 feet of that vessel's keel were torn off. The Mohican is now in dry dock at the Mare Island Navy Yard, California.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Nov. 2 -- P.M. As election day approaches it becomes apparent that Stock Exchange circles are not to be altogether unaffected by political excitement. Until now speculation has not been interfered with by the campaign, but to-day it was plainly evident that the minds of the majority of professional operators were distracted from stocks to politics.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Edwin Booth, the great American actor, who has been here for several weeks, hoping for the improvement of his health, has at last decided to return to New-York, and he will go from here to-morrow.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- An appalling railway accident occurred early this morning near Thirsk, in Yorkshire, by which ten persons were killed and a large number injured.

President Merrill E. Gates, LD.D., of Amherst College delivered an address last night before the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences at Association Hall, Bond and Fulton Streets, on "Patriotism in Times of Peace: or, the Duty of Educated Citizens to the State." The speaker was heard by a large and more than ordinarily intellectual audience, and his scholarly deductions received the closest attention.

The third came between Lasker and D.G. Baird, which was played yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club, was one of the moat exciting ever contested over the chess board. At a critical juncture the New-Yorker could have escaped with a draw, although a rook behind, but was naturally afraid to enter upon so seemingly hazardous a course. The result was that Lasker won.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 2 -- Another chapter in the Republican plot to corrupt the vote of Sussex County is given in an affidavit made by Cyrus Ward, the Democratic nominee for Treasurer of that county, a man who is well known and whose reputation stands indorsed by hundreds, if not thousands, who have heretofore recommended him for official appointment at the hands of the Governor.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 2. -- The circulation in New-York of a rumor that the famous "lake front" case of the Illinois Central Railroad Company against the State of Illinois and the City of Chicago (in which many million dollars are involved) had been decided by the Supremo Court in favor of the railroad company caused considerable talk here to-day.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 2. -- The Dayton Coal and Iron Company, operating blast furnaces and coal mines at Dayton, Tenn., gave notice to-day of a 5 per dent, reduction in wages, being a reduction of 15 per cent, since Jan. 1. It affects 500 men.
To the Editor of the New York Times: In the New-York morning papers of this date appeared the following "news" paragraph:

Vote as early in the day as possible and thereby avoid all possibility of accident. Remember that the polls are open in this city from 6 A. M. to 4 P. M.; in Brooklyn and elsewhere throughout the State from sunrise until sunset. In order to avoid delay at the polling place you will do well to prepare your ballot before leaving home.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- A great Democratic mass meeting was held in Now-Milford, Southern Litchfield County, this afternoon, which was attended by over 2,000 voters, including many farmers from the surrounding towns. The occasion was a notable one in at leas tone respect it was the first time Governor-elect Morris has appeared in public during the present campaign.
During this weak the final distribution of Republican "boodle" is being made, and some of he States have not been able to secure as much as the State Committees have thought necessary.

With the betting at $1,000 to $700 on Indiana and $1,000 to $500 on New-York in favor of Cleveland, it is evident that popular confidence is with the Democracy this year. Bets of that sort on both States were made yesterday, and will continue to be made as long as the Republicans are willing to take them.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 2 -- Fraud and forgery have been again resorted to by the campaign managers who are trying to carry, this State for Harrison. They are sending out tons of pamphlets containing as palpable a forgery as ever caused a twenty years' sentence. It is addressed to laboring men, particularly miners and railroad employes.

OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 2.J.F. Barkelow of Brooklyn, N.Y., who with Frank K. Conroy, also of Brooklyn, left here two weeks ago to examine the territory of the extinct cliff dwellers along Nine Mile Creek, returned here yesterday. He tells a horrible story of Conroy's falling down a precipice and landing on a projecting rock, where he was attacked by two eagles and clawed to death.
The October Grand Jury has just sent in a most tavorable report on the progress and success of the treatment employed at this city's Farm for the Insane at Central Islip, L. I.
The October Grand Jury has just sent in a most tavorable report on the progress and success of the treatment employed at this city's Farm for the Insane at Central Islip, L. I.

OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 2.J.F. Barkelow of Brooklyn, N.Y., who with Frank K. Conroy, also of Brooklyn, left here two weeks ago to examine the territory of the extinct cliff dwellers along Nine Mile Creek, returned here yesterday. He tells a horrible story of Conroy's falling down a precipice and landing on a projecting rock, where he was attacked by two eagles and clawed to death.

Every one must be struck with one note that runs through the numerous statements by Republicans of their reasons for voting for Mr. CLEVELAND this year. It is the declaration that the party has changed and that they have not and will not. Judge GRESHAM, in the terse letter published by us yesterday, put this fact in a very clear fashion.

Dr. William Everett, the distinguished Massachusetts educator who is fighting against Henry Cabot Lodge, the author of the Force bill, for the Congressional seat of the Seventh Massachusetts District, talked to the Wholesale Dry Goods Men's Cleveland and Stevenson Club yesterday noon at the headquarters, 384 Broadway.

Col. SHEPARD has called out the Federal troops on Governors Island for service on election day. "Somebody will get hurt," he says, "and it won't be the Federal officials." It is his opinion as a Republican and a Colonel that "the Tammany bullies will be the first to run from the smell of powder."

CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The average campaign orator is usually able to distinguish a Prohibition crowd from a Democratic crowd; but the penetration necessary in order to distinguish between the two was not possessed by a young Demosthenes who was sent up into the wilds of Putnam County the other evening by the Democratic Committee.

In Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, Miss Elizabeth Wyman Aldrich, daughter of the late William Aldrich, was mar ried yesterday afternoon to Jacob Berry Underhill, son of Edward B. Underhill. Owing to the recent death of Mr. Aldrich, the wedding was strictly a family affair. While several friends were invited to the church, only the immediate families attended the reception, which was given at the home of Mrs. Aldrich, 200 Madison Avenue.

The Republican National Committee issued its first threat of violent interference in the election in this city yesterday. When Chairman Carter awoke yesterday morning to find that heavy odds were being laid that Cleveland would carry this State he came to the conclusion that something must be done about it.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 2 -- Chris Magee has been in Alabama since Sunday night. One night he spent in Decatur and one in Montgomery, returning here to-night.

The chief business of the managers at the Republican Headquarters this week seems to be the distribution of "boodle" for the purchase of votes. The supply appears to be practically unlimited. The Pennsylvania manufacturers have yielded "fat" even more freely than heretofore, being induced thereto by a fear that they may lose the advantage afforded by the McKinley tariff to accumulate the substance of the people upon their own ribs.

The efforts of the walking delegates to cripple the building trades by ordering all the men in them on strike in order to help the Wiremen's Union in its fight against the Electrical Contractors' Association do not seem very effectual. There were but two strikes ordered yesterday, one at Terrace Garden, and the other at Miss Veltin's school in East Seventy-fourth Street.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Nov. 3 -- P.M. Quotations of election bets were not sent out on the tape, but, nevertheless, betting on the result of next Tuesday's polling formed a large part of to-day's business on the Stock Exchange.

Compared with the exuberance of three days ago, the Republican National Committeemen sat in a cave of gloom yesterday, because of information which came to them in various ways indicating that the wave of enthusiasm was rolling in the direction of the Democrats. Their troubles multiplied during the day, although they did their best to appear cheerful and Keep up the Harrison talk which they have been pouring out so lavishly.

With victory in sight the serried hosts of Tammany Hall paused again last night in their steady march toward Tuesday's battlefield, and, with a shout that brought back echoes from the skies, rallied around the Wigwam to reassert their adherence to Grover Cleveland and to declare anew their ardent purpose to carry the great principle of tariff reform to victory at the polls.
LEIPSIC, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Blum Has recently had a long interview with Prince Bismarck at Varzin, an account of which is published in the Neueste Nachrichten of this city.

Gen. Martin T. McMahon, Grand Marshal of the great parade of Business Men's Cleveland and Stevenson Clubs to-morrow, issued his fianl orders for the management of the demonstration yesterday. As nearly as can be estimated from the figures reported by the various organizations which are to participate in the march there will be from 35,000 to 40,000 men in line, and the demonstration will be the greatest political feature of the campaign.

The Executive Committee of Tammany Hall, made up of the leaders or the thirty Assembly districts in this city, held an important meeting late yesterday afternoon, at which measures were taken to prevent any intimidation at the polls by John L Davenport and his men.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Gov. Flower said to-day he expected to speak at Peskskill Saturday night as well as at Poughkeepsie to-morrow night. The Governor will vote in New-York City and return here by Tuesday night. He and Senator Hill will receive the election returns by special wire at the Executive Chamber Tuesday night.
Contributions to the Democratic Campaign Fund should be sent to Robert B. Roosevelt, Treasurer of the National Democratic Committee, 139 Filth Avenue, New-York.
The Bed Star Liner Noordland, which yesterday arrived from Antwerp, brought the Captain and crew of the Norwegian bark Konig Oscar II., which was abandoned at sea in a sinking condition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The country hop at White Plains to-night was the last effort of the Summer colony of Westchester County for this season and through the usual co-operation of Westchester Society, the affair was made a success. There were about 300 guests present from the different centres in the county and a few from Stamford and Greenwich, Conn.

The Society for the Belief of Destitute Children of Seamen hold its forty-fifth annual meeting and exorcises at the children's home, New-Brighton, S.I., yesterday at noon. There were a large number of well-known Staten Island and New-York people assembled in the chapel when the children or the school, numbering abont 100, entered.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- "Tell me who will last catch the floater vote here and I will tell you about what the result will be in Middlesex," said the gentlemen of both political parties whose judgments THE TIMES'S correspondent sought last night as to the local aspects of the political situation.

Wayne MacVeagh and ex-Gov. James E. Campbell spoke to an assemblage of great size and extraordinary enthusiasm in Brooklyn lost night. There was not an inch of space to spare in the Academy of Music, watch was profusely and patriotically decorated for the occasion.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- In no Presidential campaign since the close of the war have so many prominent Virginia Republicans deserted their candidates as in this one. The list includes a member of the Supreme Court of Appeals, an ex-Attorney General, a member of the Legislature, a member of the State Board of Agriculture, and many others.

The new nickel-steel Harveyized American armor plate adopted for the new American battle ships will be tested by the Russian Government on Nov. 15 in competition with armor plates submitted by Sohneider Co. of Creusot, France; Brown Son, and Messrs. Cammell. both of England. The trial will take place at the Russian proving grounds at Okhta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- After a dry spell of many weeks Washington caught a light rainfall last aight, as the alleged result of the series of explosions which the experts of the Agricultural Department have been causing across the river. Bat the cost of the experiments has been too great in the sacrifice of nerves and comfort to make the plan entirely popular with Washington people.

JAMESTOWN, Nov. 3. -- In no section of the State outside of the big cities has Democracy made such steady gains, in proportion to the increase of population, as in the Thirty-fourth Congressional District, which includes the Counties of Allegany, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua. Especially does this hold good in the County of Chautauqua, where, in spite of a few local differences, the party has progressed with strides that at times have surprised the Republican managers.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 3 -- The damage suits filed in the United States Circuit Court by the relatives and friends of the eleven Italians who were lynched in the Parish Prison on March 14, 1891, will be called for trial in the next few days, papers material to the conduct of the plaintiffs' case having been received from Rome to-day.

Central Office Detective John J. Carey was shot dead last night by James De Blanche, alias David Wheeler, a Chicago all-around crook, whom he was trying to arrest at Seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.
DENVER, Col., Nov, 3. -- The "gang" forces of the Republican Party in Colorado are broken and the white flag offering a half surrender has been raised.
MADRID, Nov. 3. -- The populace of Granada were greatly disappointed at Queen Regent Christina's refusal to visit the city with King Alfonso after great preparations had been made to receive them.

The leaders of the Republican Party assert in their public speeches that the present tariff was made in accordance with the doctrine of their national platform that the "duties should be equal to the difference between wages abroad and at home." Some of them -- Mr. JOHN SHERMAN, for example -- say that they would not have voted for duties exceeding this difference.

The three big liners which came up to their piers yesterday had the same old story of rough seas and high gales on the steamship route. All three came into port considerably overdue. Two of the vessels, the Spreo and City of New-York, reached the bar Wednesday night, but could proceed no further on account of a dense fog which rendered objects invisible a score of yards away.

KINGSTON, Nov. 3 -- Bears are unusually plentiful in the Catskill Mountains this year. A large number have been seen, and in several instances hunters have been successful in capturing them. Bruin dies hard. Since the advent of the Wagner parlor car into the very heart of the mountains all largo game has become exceedingly scarce, and only once in two or three years is a deer captured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Harrison and Secretary John W. Foster are the only members of the Administration now left in Washington. All the others have gone away to fight for their retention in office.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- A dispatch received to-night from Ferrol states that the British war ship Howe has been floated. The Portuguese Minister of Marine will allow her to be repaired at the State dock yard at Ferrol.

The Department of Justice at Washington holds that United States Deputy Marshals have the right on election day to be in any part of a polling place, and Marshal JACOBUS instructs his deputies that they may go behind the guard rails that inclose the booths in which voters prepare their ballots.

Both the Park Commissioners and the members of the Board of Estimate have shown a disposition to make liberal appropriations for the Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. One of these gentlemen, however, declared that he was not in favor of the city assuming the whole expense of maintaining the museums.

The howl that has been get up at the Republican Headquarters and echoed through the party organs about election frauds in this city is intended merely to cover the disreputable efforts of the managers to buy the election, and to prepare the way for an explanation of their inevitable defeat.

The alleged enthusiasm of the Republican managers which has been kept up with so much noise for the last two or three days has begun to die down. There is not one-half as much talk of Republican success as there was and the confident claims of Republicans who have already carried New-York by 20,000 plurality for Harrison are not made so loudly.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Increasing interest is manifested in the slander case ot Mrs. Leader, wife of Lieut Leader, against Mrs. Gibbons Smyth, wife of Major Gen. Smyth, and to-day the courtroom was not only packed, but many persons desirous of gaining admission found it utterly Impossible to do so.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.,Nov. 3. -- The mandamus proceedings to compel the Board of Registry of the Second District of the Fourth Ward of this city to strike Senator Osborne's name from the registration lists came before Judge Barnard this morning, and was sent by him to the Circuit Court, which convenes in December, for trial as to the question of fact involved.

The Executive Committee of the National League for Good Roads, which was organized in Chicago, Oct. 20 and 21, held its first meeting at the temporary headquarters in the office of Gen. Roy Stone, 45 Broadway, yesterday afternoon. The object of the meeting was to take steps to further the work of the league and extend its usefulness.
The Irish Democratic Union, having headquarters at 853 Broadway, issue the following statement:

The marriage of Miss Fannie Irving Pittman, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Pittman, to Edmund Paulson Browne was celebrated last evening at St. Chrysostom's Church. The Rev. Thomas H. Sill officiated. The best man was Dr. Charles Wood, and the ushers were Clark B. Ferry, Thomas Daniel, Arthur A. Carpenter, and John Johnston.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 3 -- The Republican politicians of this city are chagrined and disheartened by the declaration of Dr. I. De Ver Warner, the millionaire corset manufacturer, that he can no longer support the policy of the Republican Party, of which he has always been an active member.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- The Iroqnois Club, the leading Democratic organization of Chicago, bold a great demonstration at the Auditorium to-night. It was the biggest event or the kind which the club has held in four years.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Mr. Herbert Gardner, President of the Board of Agriculture, is not satisfied with the reports of the veterinary surgeons of the board that the disease that has appeared among cattle landed from Canada is undoubtedly pleuro-pneumonia. He is inclined to wait and ascertain whether more cases develop before ordering he slaughter of all Canadian cattle at the ports which they are landed.

GLOVERSVILLE, Nov. 3 -- Daniel B. Judson is the largest glove manufacturer in the United States, whose entire business interests are located in this country and whose capital is entirely invested in American industries. His output amounts to $500,000 per year, and not one dollar does he spend in importing gloves, as is the case with one or two leading Harrison manufacturers in the county.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Nov. 3 -- The Democratic State Committee has issued to Arkansas election officers a circular defining the rights of United States Supervisors and Deputy Marshals at elections, which, after a clear exposition of those rights and duties, continues:

Children who read the "Arabian Nights" consider as one of the most delightful stories the account of how Aladdin and the African magician went down into the cave of rubies, and how, with a wave of his wand, the magician made a thousand lights to spring from the roof of the cave, illuminating the place with a rosy glow.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- In reply to the circular issued by William P. Sheehan of the Democratic Executive Committee regarding the rights and duties of United States Deputy Marshals at the polls on election day, the following letter of definite instructions has been issued by United States Marshal Archie E. Baxter of this city.

DES MODES, Nov. 3 -- The Grand Opera House was crowded to-night with voters who had come out to hear several goading citizens all of whom voted for Harrison four years ago, but who will vote for Cleveland this year.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Throughout the night men were working upon the debris of the wrecks of the express and goods trains that were in collision near Thirsk early yesterday morning. The tender of the express train has not yet been lifted from the mass of wreckage. It is suspected that when it is removed several bodies will be found beneath it.

The Executive Committee of Tammany Hall, made up of the leaders or the thirty Assembly districts in this city, held an important meeting late yesterday afternoon, at which measures were taken to prevent any intimidation at the polls by John L Davenport and his men.

The Republicans held a mass meeting yesterday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury, in Wall Street. They had the same chairs that were used at the Cleveland demonstration on that spot a week before and the decorations were practically the same, except that portraits of Harrison and Reid were substituted for pictures of Cleveland and Stevenson.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of the Times says that the Russian ironclad cruiser Rurik, the largest vessel of the kind ever built in Russia, was launched yesterday in the presence of the Czar and Czarina.

PARIS, NOV. 3. -- Col. Dodds, commanding the French forces operating against the Dahomeyans, has telegraphed details or the fighting that took place on Oct. 20 and 21. His dispatch says that the French were attacked at Akas by the whole strength of the Dahomeyans. The natives were repulsed with heavy loss after two days' fighting.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3. -- The Democratic State Central Committee claims to have received dispatches from various points in the State confirming the reports received yesterday of the distribution of mixed tickets. These tickets, it is claimed, can be thrown out under the election law of 1887, and considerable excitement prevails about the various headquarters in consequence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Acting Attorney General Aldrich to-day made an important statement with reference to the authority of United States Deputy Marshals to supervise elections, in which he announces that all persons who attempt to interfere with those officers bring themselves within the scope of the criminal statutes of the United States, regardless of whether or not they apt under any State or municipal statute.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- The contest between George Fred Williams (Dem.) and Gen. William T. Draper for Congress in the new Eleventh District is close and exciting. The cities and towns of the district gave a Republican plurality of 2,646 on the vote for Congressman in 1883. In 1890 they gave a Democratic plurality of 213, but that was the year of the tidal wave, and the district is regarded as Republican.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 4. -- Pittsburg Republicans have given up all hope of carrying New York. They admit this reluctantly, but non the less certainly. They won't bet on the Empire State, even at odds of 10 to 6, but the exhibit any amount of confidence on the general result, and their reason therefor leake out to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- A conference of Managers Maffitt and Moore of the Harvard and Yale football elevens was held this afternoon at Springfield relative to the arrangements for the Harvard-Yale game at Hamden Park on the 19th. The two managers inspected the grand stand and field and found the work on the former progressing finely and the latter in first-class condition for playing.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- There appeared in a late issue of the New-York World a statement that there were twenty-seven Republicans and only thirteen Democrats in the Faculty of Cornell University. THE TIMES'S correspondent has made a careful canvass of the members of the Faculty, (consisting of professors, associate professors, and assistant professors,) seeing each member personally and ascertaining from him his preference in regard to the two candidates for President.

TAHLEQUAH, Indian Territory, Nov. 4. -- Ned Christie, the notorious outlaw, who killed Dan Maples, a United States officer, has been shot. His cabin was surrounded, about daylight yesterday morning, by sixteen of the bravest men of Col. Yoe's command. They were led by Heck Bruno and A.G.W. White.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 4. -- Registration is closed in Minnesota and the committees of the three parties are to-day conning the figures with a view of extracting some comfort from them. The total is more than 20,000 greater than ever before and the vote of the State will reach 280,000, an excess of 18,000 over the vote of four years ago and at least 40,000 more than two years ago.

Patrick Walsh, editor of the Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle, (Dem.,) and one of the best-known Democrats in the South, is in the city. To a TIMES reporter he said that after carefully looking over the situation he was confident that the desperate efforts the Republicans have been making to curry Alabama and West Virginia would avail them nothing, and that both these States were sure to go for Cleveland.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 4. -- To-day the Westchester Democratic Committee began a crusade against false registration, which has been perpetrated in Westchester County. Evidence has been placed in the hands of the committee showing that false registration has been carried on extensively in, North Salem and Ossining by the colonization of colored men.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Dr.C.H.W. Stocking, rector of the Church of the Holy Innocents of St. Cloud, West Orange, and Principal of the, Orange Academy, has come out for Grover Cleveland and Democracy. At his home this evening, to a TIMES representative. Dr. Stocking frankly said that he unhesitatingly gave his support to Grover Cleveland.

QUEBEC, Nov. 4. -- The trial or Ex-Premier Meroler was concluded to-day. He and M. Pacaud were charged with having defrauded the Province of $60,000 and savings bank of a like sum. The jury retired at 5:45 P.M. On their return, ten minutes later, the Clerk of the court first challenged the jury in French. "Non coupable," replied the spokesman. Then the Clerk challenged the jury in English, the spokesman replying, "Not guilty."
The conditions of Republican success in the State of New-York are Democratic factional quarrels in this city and great Republican enthusiasm and a full vote in the interior counties.

Mr. Cleveland had s rousing reception last night in Jersey City. He went over there to keep his promise to meet the people of the State of his birth before the close of the campaign, and he enjoyed a welcome that came straight from the people.

Yesterday's bad weather did not keep the crowds away from the flower show. There were more professional gardeners in attendance than heretofore, the main attraction of the day lying in the show of new seedling chrysanthemums. First premiums of $25 each were awarded as follows:

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Charles M. Dennison, Chief Supervisor of Elections for the Northern District of New-York, issues the following final instructions to Supervisors of Elections appointed to serve at the election, Nov. 8.
So the People of the United States: The Presidential campaign will soon end. It is right and necessary that we should now say a few words to you.
