After carefully examining the stock of fine Winter Suits and Overcoats made by a large Milwaukee clothing concern the companies' insurance appraisers decided that the goods were not damaged to any extent, and, failing to agree with the owners as to the actual loss, the entire stock of Men's Fine Suits and Overcoats has been sent here to be turned into cash during the next fifteen days, in order to make a settlement.

Bradish Johnson died Thursday night at his Summer home at Bayshore. L. I., aged eightytwo years. His death was attributed to general decline, due to old age. He was born April 22, 1811, on Woodland Plantation, forty miles south of New-Orleans. This plantation was the property of his father, William M. Johnson, and is one of the famous sugar plantations of Lonisi cna. At the time of Bradish Johnson's death it belonged to him.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- A dispatch to the Times from Ferrol, Spain, says that the force of the spring tides causes so much vibration in the stranfled Howe, English war ship, that the cables and anchors securing her are strained severely. The work of lightening the big battle ship continues rapidly.

BUFFALO, Nov. 4. -- D.S. Alexander, United States District Attorney for the Northern District of New-York in this city, has written a letter to W.H. Watts, Deputy United States Marshal in Buffalo, in which he says:

There is not the least occasion for any conflict between the State and Federal authorities in the condnct of the election next Tuesday, and there will be none if both confine themselves to their legitimate duty in protecting qualified electors in their right to vote and preventing any illegal voting.

The Western farmer is now contemplating with some signs of disapproval and annoyance the prices of wheat, corn, and rye. McKINLEY and his associates sought to deceive the farmer by increasing the duties on certain farm products. For example, they increased the duty on wheat from 20 to 25 cents a bushel.

There was a meeting of the Advisory Committee of the Theatre of Arts and Letters yesterday afternoon, to appoint sub-committees and discuss generally the scope of the institution. The meeting was held at the Berkeley Lyceum, and there were about fifty of the incorporators present. Edmund Clarence Stedman was appointed Chairman and Henry B. McDowell Secretary.

ALBANY, Nov. 4. -- Under the provisions of the amended insurance law, which went into effect Oct. 1, radical changes are made in the provisions governing assessment companies. By the law of 1883, life and casualty insurance corporations upon the co-operative or assessment plan made out their policies so as to provide for the payment of beneficiaries in proportion to the amount of the money paid in upon a certain claim.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- Deputy United States Marshal Williams of Cincinnati has removed James Brown, a deranged United States prisoner, from the Ohio Penitentiary to the National Asylum at Washington, D.C. The prisoner fought like a tiger against being removed.

The action of the British "Board of Agriculture " in excluding Canadian cattle from Great Britain will operate to strengthen whatever feeling there may already be in the Dominion in favor of annexation to the Union. One of the privileges that Canadians have enjoyed is to have the "sanitary" precautions of the Privy Council, or of its successor, the Board of Agriculture, much mitigated when the question was of Canadian and not of "American" imports.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 4. -- Some of the details of the new railroad federation, mention of which have been made in these dispatches, were obtained from a gentleman who seemed thoroughly posted as to the plans upon which the new organization will be based.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 4. -- Over one hundred of the leading merchants and firms of this city, including representatives of all the banks, have signed and promulgated an address to the business men of the North. It reads as follows:

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- The Redistricting act of 1891, by which the State of Massachusetts was subdivided into thirteen Congressional districts, has rendered exceedingly difficult a reliable forecast of the results to be reached next Tuesday with respect to representation in the national Legislature. Communities which had acted together hitherto have been divorced and thrown suddenly into now relationships.

ELIMIRA, Nov. 4. -- A number of complications exist to-day in the County of Chemung that render the Presidential contest not only interesting, out amusing. Between the floater and the factions in both of the great parties the result in the county is very problematical, although the more hopeful Democrats are positive that Mr. Cleveland will carry it by at least 500 plurality.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Gov. Flower this afternoon issued the following proclamation:

The experiences of Mrs. Simon Pooy of Whitestone, L.I., who had to pay the Willcox Gibbs Sewing Machine Company $100 for a sewing machine which was listed to foreign buyers at $45, as related in Tuesday's TIMES, caused much agitation, among the different sewing-machine companies in this city.

SODUS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The Hon. Lewis H. Clark of this village, who has been a Republican all his life, to-day publishes a long letter in the county seat Democratic organ, announcing that he will vote for Mr. Cleveland, as a matter of conscience. Mr. Clark is one of the best known educators in Wayne County, being now Principal of Sodus Academy.

The mass meeting of genuine workingmen, held last evening in and about Webster Hall, Eleventh Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, to advocate tariff reform and to in dorse the nomination of Grover Cleveland and Adlai E. Stevenson was a great success.

Verily, "they do these things differently in France." An American observer must bo convinced of the truth of the time-honored saying when he studies the history of the miners' strike in the little town of Carmaux. In its origin, in its conduct, in the way in which it has been taken up by the politicians and forced upon the National Government it is, from first to last, almost unimaginable to the American mind.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 4. -- The Democratic Party, through a singular muddle, has lost what chance it had to carry Oregon at the election next Tuesday.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Candidate Reid tells us that the Republicans are standing on their platform, but the Democrats have been trying to get away from theirs. The Minneapolis platform declares that "on all imports coming into competition with the products of American labor there should be levied duties equal to the difference between wages at home and abroad."
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4. -- Arkansas is in the last week of one of the most exciting campaigns held in the State since the war. The fight opened on July 16 and has grown hotter ever since.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The anxious inquiry among the public men all over the State concerns the attitude of the great Counties of Hudson and Essex. Hudson embraces the populous cities of Jersey City and Hobokon.

Hard work is the order of the day with the Democrats in these final days of the campaign. Backed by absolute confidence that this is a great Democratic year, they are working night and day to pile up the plurality for Cleveland and Stevenson.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 4. -- The general strike situation is somewhat complicated to-night. The warehousemen, sugar-scales men, and the teamsters and loaders have been out for nearly two weeks, and they have dealt a heavy blow to the wholesale grocers and the sugar and rice industries, very little freight having been moved.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. McKinley said in his speech at the Clermont Avenue Rink. in Brookyn, Oct. 31: "When Europe came to settle with as the year's business, she paid us $230,000,000 in gold to settle the balance of trade in our favor, and we have got that money now."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. McKinley said in his speech at the Clermont Avenue Rink. in Brookyn, Oct. 31: "When Europe came to settle with as the year's business, she paid us $230,000,000 in gold to settle the balance of trade in our favor, and we have got that money now."

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- About the only exhibition of strength in any market was shown by provisions. This was largely due to the fact that hog receipts were light and prices at the yards were advanced. Shorts were induced to cover, and prices all around moved up a peg. While the high prices of the day were not maintained, the undertone of the close was strong.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Difficult as it is to take the very sanguine expectations of the Democrats of Illinois, there is everywhere in this State so much of Democratic confidence as to apparently justify the opinion expressed to-day by Representative Benjamin T. Cable or the Westen branch of the National Democratic Committee that Illinois will not only elect Judge Altgeld as Governor, but will give Cleveland and Stevenson the twenty-four Electors from this State.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- The following are some particulars of the damage done by the cyclone which passed over Old Providence and Ban Andres, in the Caribbean Sea:

At a large and enthusiastic meeting of the Kurtz Association held at 414 Sixth Avenue last evening, Dr. Samuel Wesley Smith, Democratic candidate for Alderman in the Eleventh District, was the principal speaker. Dr. Smith, who made an enviable record for himself as State Commissioner of Lunacy in 1888 and 1889, has the indorsement in his canvass of the best known men in his district, irrespective of party.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Actor Wilson Barrett, whose scenery and costumes arrived from England on the British Prince on Wednesday, appeared at the Custom House to-day and made oath that the articles, which are detained for customs duties, comprise professional implements of trade, intended for use in his occupation. Mr. Barrett claims that his property is entitled to entry free of duty under the McKinley tariff law.

After twenty-four hours' reflection over the Treasury Department's unexpected resurrection of the order to hold all ships having "immigrants" on board in Quarantine for twenty days, the steamship agents were still at a loss to fathom its motive or to see any reason for it in ins present circumstances.

The exhibit of table decorations was the overwhelming attraction at the flower show yesterday. Six tables were placed in competition by Thomas H. Spaulding, George Stumpp, Warendorff Brothers, J.H. Small Sons, Siebrecht Wadley, and William Dihm. The judges were Ward McAllister, F.T. Underhill, and Prince Poniatowski.
The following address by Chairman McDermott of the New-Jersey State Democratic Committee was issued yesterday from the committee's headquarters:

It may safely be said that New-York has acquired a taste for great spectacles which it will not cease to cultivate. The Washington Centennial of April, 1889, the Columbus Quadro-Centennial of October, 1892, have been of a very solid value as well as of a universal interest to the city. They have been, in the first place, of a great commercial value.

BABBAGE -- I do not remember in my whole life a more curious and noteworthy evening than the one I am now describing. Mr. Babbage had reached his anecdotage, was in the mood to be communicative, and my friend Miss Kinglake, claiming the privilege of age, asked. without reserve such questions as induced our host to be autobiographical.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The Democrats are not willing to concede the accuracy of Chairman Dick's extravagant estimate that Mr. Harrison will win in Ohio with 20,000 votes to spare. The facts, however, do not justify the hope that the Democrats will carry Ohio; only that the majority will be much smaller than Chairman Dick has assumed to think probable.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 5. -- After five weeks' trial the commons at Yale is pronounced a success. At its tables there are accommodations for 466 students, and the popularity of the institution is attested by a waiting list of 200. The food is of excellent quality, well cooked, and satisfactorily served by a corps of thirty-six student waiters and ten colored waiters.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The collapse of Signer Lago's opera season at the New Olympic Theatre has been received with general regret, as Signer Lago deserved well of the public. He it was who out down the prices of admission to operatic performances and who showed in former seasons that it was quite possible to produce operas adequately rendered and staged at moderate prices.

Considerable use is being made of chamois this Autumn. Blue and green wool dresses have chamois Tests, collars, and cuffs. There are chamois bonnets, and toe chamois gloves are in greater variety and better made than usual. A derby glove made of bright yellow chamois has trimmings and large buttons of black. White chamois gloves are made now with cable seams, like the finest kid gloves.

HAVANA, Oct. 29 -- Preparations for the next sugar season are being actively pushed all over the island, and it is now generally believed that next year's production will be fully equal to the last crop. The recent showers of rain have been beneficial to the growing cane, especially to the sprouts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Chairman Carter has sent here and to other States a buncombe circular charging that the Democrats intend at the last moment to flood close States with money to help carry them for Mr. Cleveland.
The people of Hudson County, N. J., were shocked at noon yesterday by the announcement that Congressman Edward F. McDonald had died at his home in Harrison.

Col. Ward, C.M.G., Commissioner from Jamaica, British West Indies, to the Chicago exhibition, is in the city on his return from the October celebration in Chicago. He has arranged that Jamaica shall have a collective exhibit, and has secured five thousand feet in the Manufacturers' Building, which will he known as the Jamaica Court.

It was a natural piece of Revolution that to Mr. Symonds should come the task of writing a biography of Michael Angelo. His studies of the Renaissance period of Italian history fitted him for the task as no one else probably has been fitted by such or by any other studies in that most attractive field.

ORANGE, Nov. 5. -- In the second of the championship games at the Orange Oval to-day the Orange Athletic Club football team vanquished the NewYork Athletic Club eleven by a score of 18 to 6. The cold wind blow over the field during the game, and at times was almost a hurricane. It soon froze out the majority of the spectators, so that the game was finished almost without witnesses.

Toward the close of the last century there was a strange crisis in the industrial world. English enterprise and ingenuity had produced the spinning jenny and the power loom, and the improved methods of cotton manufacture had been established in face of the stubborn opposition, of the hand weavers, who had fought long and bitterly for the preservation of their antiques industry.

CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 5. -- It has always been the policy of the Republican managers in this State to "claim everything" when an election is pending, and the present year furnishes no exception to the rule in this respect. At the Republican Headquarters in this city entire confidence in a complete victory for their party is expressed.

CHAPTER I. Valentine Forsyth was Commissioner of Police at the Diamond Fields, and he had just returned from a visit to Graham's Town, bringing a young wife back with him, greatly to the astonishment of his numerous friends and acquaintances.

The Iron and Kindred Trades Cleveland and Stevenson Campaign Club, 1,300 strong, formed in front of the clubhouse, at 66 John Street, and behind a band of forty pieces, marched up Willlam Street, to Beekman, to Park Row, to Centre Street, to Leonard Street and Broadway, where 200 hardware men from Chambers Street were waiting to join them, with another large band.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 5. -- The Republican club, which began its career a month ago under the best at auspices, has not been much of a success. It was promised that the club would join in the large parades in Boston, Springfield, Worcester, and in other cities, but on account of a lack of interest among the members the trip to Boston and Worcester had to be abandoned.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 5. -- About thirty unions, representing every industry, quit work to-day and the street cars stopped running. Hundreds of stores had no clerks, more or less tumult existed at railroad freight depots, and the retail trade of the city was badly crippled.

According to the men in charge of the local Weather Bureau yesterday's blustering gale will probably have blown itself away to some other locality by to-day. In the city it reached a maximum velocity of forty miles an hour. The Sandy Hook observer says it had a speed of forty-five miles an hour at that point.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 5. -- In dismantling the old Soovill homestead, at the corner of Prospect and Grove Streets, in this city, recently, there was found in a massive old secretary built into the library wall a secret drawer, containing a bundle of ancient title doeds. The even lines of round, scholarly writing had faded and the soft creased linen paper had darkened, until both were fast reaching the same neutral brown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- It is the talk here that if the Administration had given any thought to the probable effect upon the people of the proclamation to Supervisors of Election and United States Marshals, which Attorney General Miller issued just before he took the stump for Harrison, its evident intention to put Republican deputies behind the guard rails at the polling places next Tuesday would have been concealed rather than made conspicuous.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the the New-York Times. HONOLULU, Oct 1. -- Sailing for six days due Southwest from San Francisco, the steamers or the Union Steamsnip Company reach Honolulu, distant 2,100 miles. If you will glance at a map of the Pacific, you will be struck with the fact that the Sandwich Island group looks to be a half-way house of call for the three great continents of North America, Australia, and Asia.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 5. -- Two weeks from to-day Yale mut face Harvard in football, and yet there is uncertainty about the centre of Yale's eleven. Still man has been shifted from centre, pat back again and again displaced, this time to give place to McCrea. There is much experimenting. McCrea appeared to be steadier and quicker than Stillman, but he is hampered by inexperience, although he has been learning the game rapidly.

A well-authenticated statement comes from Washington that Republicans high in the councils of the party are casting about for some expedient by which the choice of President and Vice President may be wrested from the people in case the Electoral votes of the country, as determined in the several States, should be given to CLEVELAND and STEVENSON by a narrow majority.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- Nine philanthropic young women are preparing to spend the Winter in the South Cove in the interest of the poor women who live in that region. They are not simply to visit and labor in that malodorous quarter, but they are to live there. They have rented their house.

A big fire visited Brooklyn lost evening, rendering sixty or seventy families homeless, destroying about $300,000 worth or property, and causing the severe injury of a young laborer. who had to jump from a fourth-story window to save his life.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- A watch once owned by John Milton, the poet, is now in the possession or Frank Morris, proprietor of the "Old Book Shop," in this city. The proofs of its genuineness are almost indisputable. Last year a seedy-looking individual entered the pawnshop of B. Zuokerman in St. Louis. He took from a package a handsomely-embossed ease of leather, upon the cover of which was a coronet of gold.

A large part of the corruption fund of $400,000 collected by Mr. JOHN WANAMAKER in the last days of the campaign of 1888 was contributed by the Manufacturers' Club, a high-tariff association of which he is a prominent member. This club afterward boasted in its weekly paper of the powerful influence exerted by the use of this money.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- Barnes Compton, Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, issued to-day an address to the officers of election and the Democratic voters regarding the power conferred upon the Supervisors of Election by the Federal statute. It refers to Acting Attorney General Aldrich's Instruction, and to the decision of Judge Morris delivered in tue United States Court for this district.

One of the most unique meetings of the campaign was hold last night at Webster Hall. It was a meeting of deaf-mutes, presided over by a deaf-mate, with deaf-mutes for speakers, and all in the interests of the Democratic ticket.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 5. -- The contest scheduled for the Yale field this afternoon as a championship intercollegiate football game proved unworthy of the title. Both Yale and Wesleyan presented substitute teams, and both used their plainest and most inferior style of play in the hope that none of the representatives of rival colleges who were present could be able to obtain pointers on the tricks which may prove serviceable in winning later champion, ship games.

J. M. Mason of West Virginia is in New-York for a few days on legal business. He has been connected with, the recent successful undertaking by the General Trust Company in behalf of the Virginia State debt. Mr. Mason is the son of the ante-bellum United States Senator from Virginia, and for several years has been familiarly known in Wall Street as the "son of Mason and Slidell."
There may be a lively time at the polls in Brooklyn on Tuesday, for both political parties are determined to have enough officials on hand to prevent any illegal ballots from being cast.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- There was an immense gathering in Faneuil Hall this afternoon for the Democratic business men's meeting. Henry L. Pierce presided and made the opening address, the other speakers being John O. Carlisle of Kentucky and George Fred Williams. Upon the platform with the speakers was an influential array of well-known Bostouians, and the gathering generally was distinctively a collection of business men.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- For the first time in the history of intercollegiate football the red and the blue to-night floats above the orange and black. After a magnificent straggle of nearly two hours and a half Princeton was defeated this afternoon in the opening game of the intercollegiate championship season by the University of Pennsylvania by a score of 6 to 4.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- There are a great many funny things in Paris, but among the most remarkable is the press influence. Without discordant note, the new play at the Cluny, the "Tournee Ernostin," has been written of as a wonderful success, and the theatre is crowded nightly. I doubt that a more stupid, leas laughable play was over produced.

There is unusual interest am one the Catholics of the country regarding the annual meeting of the Archbishops of the Catholic Church which is to be held in this city this month. The meeting has no legislative powers. It is entirely for review and consultation, but its discussions and conclusions will have a potent influence with the government and general tendencies of the Church.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 5. -- There is a new drift of traffic at the head of the great lakes. Duluth, Minneapolis, and St. Paul are sensible of it and its cause -- the movement of wheat through new channels. It is a gravitation to the shortest rail and longest water hauls.

There was something of a reaction in the society world during the last week from the suburban gayety of the week preceding, due doubtless to the absorption of the masculine portion of the community in the coming elections and to the dreary weather which for the most part of the week inflicted the land, following directly the beautiful Autumn days which so long delighted the country.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- During the coming week several important meetings of party leaders will be held in Berlin, preliminary to the opening of the Reichstag. The general drift of political developments points to the Government's securing a majority for the Army bill, through a coalition of Conservatives, Centrists, and members of the Reichspartei.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 5. -- The hastily-arranged breeders' meeting, organized to fill dates left vacant by the collapse at Columbia last week, began to-day at Cumberland Park. The weather was too cold for extreme speed and the heavy rain which fell on Thursday rendered the track a trifle soft and slow. Notwithstanding these handicaps, two world's records were broken by the trotters and other important records were made.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Teams of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of this city and Columbia College freshmen broke even here this afternoon in an exciting football match. There was a terrific gale blowing from the shores of Newark Bay, adjoining the oval. In the first halt 6 points were scored by the Columbia freshmen. Joseph made a goal and McConway a touch-down.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 5. -- Dartmouth defeated Williams at football here to-day in a game which was close and exciting up to the second half, when Williams weakened and Dartmouth had things practically her own way. A light frozen snow rendered the field and hall extremely slippery. Dartmouth was especially weak in goal kicking as of all her five trials, which were right in front of the goal, she only secured two goals.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- The campaign in Maryland is ending with more enthusiasm than was expected. Mr. Cleveland will probably have a plurality of about 20,000 in this State. The .Republicans openly concede 6,000 and the Democrats place their lowest figures at 15,000. Good judges believe that the real figures will be near the twenty-thousand mark.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 5 -- Henry F. Debardeleben, the richest of Alabama's ironmasters, the largest individual stockholder of the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company, and General manager of its affairs, was an open advocate of Harrison four years ago, and voted for him on the ground of protection. To-night in an interview he says:

It was when they were homeward bound, in mid-Atlantic, that Mary Denning first began to doubt. She had been so happy in her love; for ever since childhood Major Herbert Knox had been her hero. His ten years' seniority had only served to shield him from the criticism of companionship. Her judgment was thus nurtured by inference, not by knowledge, and the Major's gallant bearing had been an agreeable stimulant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5. -- The poll to determine the Presidential preferences of the Harvard Faculty and students has resulted: Harrison, 1,114; Cleveland, 851; Bidwell, 31. This is for the students. The Faculty stands: Cleveland, 62; Harrison, 6. As may be seen, only about two-thirds of the college has voted, but it may be concluded that the proportion would have held had it been possible to obtain the expression of preference from the whole university.

With absolute confidence that the Democratic issues and the Democratic candidates will win a magnificent victory the Democratic national managers will submit their cause to the people on Tuesday. With nervous reliance on the power or money to corrupt voters and to debauch franchises the Republican managers will send their cause to the people.

It is now generally admitted, even by candid Republicans, that there is no chance of the election of Mr. HARRISON by honorable means. There is absolutely no evidence of any reaction from the vote of 1890 and 1891 in this State, and without this State Mr. HARRISON canaot hope to win.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 5. -- The jury in the Iams case came into court this morning at 10 o'clock and in writing asked some special instructions from Judge Porter, who said:

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The indications to-day are that the Democrats will make almost a clean sweep in Monmouth County next Tuesday, although the Republicans are confident that they will elect a majority of their candidates for local offices. This campaign has been one of the hottest political battles in the history of the county.

In spite of tie political excitement there will be four new plays this week, including one at Daly's called "A Test Case; or, Grass versus Granite," founded on a German play by Herren Blumenthal and Kadelburg. This will be produced next Thursday night. It is said to be comedy, not farce, of much the same quality as "Dollars and Sense," and it playfully contrasts city wisdom with rural simplicity.

POTTSVILEE, Penn., Nov. 5. -- The long drought continues throughout Eastern Pennsylvania and the mountain, fires which have raged for more than a week, despite the passing showers of the last few days, are still devastating immense tracts of timber in this and adjoining counties. One of the interesting features of these fires is the fact that they have been the means of revealing and dislodging undreamed-of numbers of snakes infesting the mountain fastnesses.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- England to-day saw the beginning of what seems lately to prove the greatest industrial war between capital and labor that the country has ever known. Cotton mills employing, all told, about 14,000,000 spindles were shut down to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Happy America, who next Tuesday night will wait for the counting of votes without any dream of concern as to what armed and embittered neighbors on her frontiers may think of the result, and who sees involved in the issue of her great election only economic, commercial, and social questions.

Richard Bell, who died at his home, 251 Lexington Avenue, on Friday, aged ninety-six years, was the oldest banker in Wall Street. For a number of years Mr. Bell was agent of the Bank of British North America. Then he became a private banker, and after the war he was agent of the Bank of Montreal. From this post he retired in 1876.

ORANGE, Nov. 5. -- The sad accident to William Brown Lord, the polo player who was seriously injured by being thrown from his pony while playing at Morristown last week in a game with the Essex County Country Club, has had a depressing effect upon the polo enthusiasts of the Oranges, among whom Lord is well known and very popular.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 5. -- The oldest resident of this State is Mrs, Emily Talcott of West Hartford, who will be 102 years of age in December. She was born at Wolcott Hill, in the town of Wethersfield, Christmas Day, 1790 her maiden name being Robbins. She is still in possession of all her faculties, and has four children living.

Lysander Thompson, who has been for over twenty years connected with one or another of A.M. Palmer's companies, was removed to Bellevue Hospital on Friday night for examination as to his sanity. For over a year Thompson has been eccentric, but it is only within the last five weeks that his insanity has been very noticeable.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- A big audience gathered in the Opera House tills afternoon to hear ex-Gov. James Campbell of Ohio discuss the issues of the campaign. Ex-Mayor Barnert presided.

Twenty thousand men passed in review before Grover Cleveland in this city yesterday afternoon. Undeterred by the cold, searching wind that blew through the streets and whistled around the corners, these men -- citizens of high character and influential stations in life -- marched from Wall Street to Thirty-fourth Street and made Broadway and Fifth Avenue glow with enthusiasm.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Our reciprocity reminds me of the story of how the Arabs managed first to get the best of the devil himself, but finally lost his services by their duplicity. Listening to their prayers, the devil lent his aid to irrigate the barren fields of the desert, on condition that he should have half of the crops. He chose what would grow above ground, and the Arabs planted turnips.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The weekly sporting papers continue to be filled with long discussions over the rating role. Among the letters published in the Field is a long one from Lord Dunraven opposing any change unless it be the object to accomplish an international agreement. "To arrive at that end," the letter says, "any amount of trouble and considerable sacrifice on our part are warranted.

KANAKAS -- The aboriginal belief of the Kanakas can hardly be dignified by the name of a religion, being little more than a superstitious regard for the spirits of the dead, whom they imagine to be transformed into malevolent demons. When any one dies, his near relations envelop their thick woolly locks in a cap, which, must not be removed for two years.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- The class of '98 has voted to adopt the Oxford cap and gown for its exercises in Commencement Week. This will be the first time in the history of the university that caps and gowns are worn.
The campaign closed in Brooklyn as it began and as it continued all along-quietly and thoughtfully. This latter quality has been the most peculiar and most satisfactory feature of the entire affair.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- More interest has been manifested by the undergraduate students of the university this year in the political campaign than in any previous Presidential election. A club has been organized in each of the three leading parties, and prominent speakers have responded to invitation to address the students and several parades have been held.

OLD ENGLISH MONOPOLIES -- Monopolies were quite common in England long before the days of the Stuarts, while it was under a Stuart, Jaimes I., that an act was passed declaring void all monopolies for the sole buying, selling, and making of goods, excepting patents for fourteeen years for any new process or new manufacture.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 5 -- The present exciting campaign for Governor of Texas recalls to the older inhabitants of the State the memorable race between Sam Houston and Hardin R. Runnels just before the civil war. Recently THE TIMES'S correspondent met Capt. Edward Sharp, who accompanied Gen. Houston during his first campaign, and who is possessed of an almost inexhaustible store of reminiscences concerning the General.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- Among the first of the luncheons this Fall was a handsome one given lately by Mrs. Charles F. Rhett, in honor of her cousin, Mrs. Coster of New-York. Some of the invited guests were Mrs. Morton Stewart, Mrs. von Kapff, Mrs. Ward, Mrs. Samuel Johnston, Mre. Thomas Buckeer, and Mrs. Dobbin.

A King's Daughter was relating one of her last Winter's experiences. "With my aunt," she said. "I was passing through a street in a tenement district in this city, when a crowd of children, struggling for the possession of a poor half-starved-looking kitten, attracted oar notice. There were six boys and three girls, and the former were raining blows upon the latter, who in turn pulled hair, kicked, and scratched the faces of their adversaries.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- Physicians who have heard the story of Philadelphia's woman leper pronounce her case unique in its development. The condition of the woman was first brought to the attention of the health authorities of this city in August last. She was examined by a well-known specialist in skin diseases. Ho expressed the opinion that she was a leper.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5. -- Cruiser No. 6 was successfully launched at the Union Iron Works at high tide, 11:25, this morning. The cruiser was christened "Olympia" by Miss Bella Dickie, daughter of George W. Dickie, manager of the Iron works.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The Civil Service Commission has sent to the Attorney General copies of a circular sent to C.K. Kotoham, the Postmaster at Ditney, Ind., and of a letter written by this Postmaster to the editor of the Non-Conformist. In its letter to the Attorney General the commission says:
Popular confidence in the election of Cleveland and Stevenson is piling up with every hour.

ALBANY, Nov. 6. -- The campaign just closed will go down in history as a fit rival to that of 1820, when the era of good feeling prevailed. The feeling of depression that began in this State in the Republican Party the day that Gen. Harrison's renomination was secured has not been entirely removed. In certain counties it is manifest to-day.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 6. -- The campaign now closing has been less exciting and demonstrative than any other Presidential struggle for a long series of years, yet there has evidently been a great deal of thinking done by the people. Generally Democratic meetings have been largely attended throughout the State, and more newspapers have been circulated and road than ever before.

That opera bouffe order of the Treasury Department recording the detention of incoming steamships at this port, and which was at first regarded as a sort of a delayed April-fool proceeding, was still in force yesterday. It will seriously inconvenience a number of people for the next few days, but there are few who have the effrontery to predict that it will continue in force after next Tuesday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- A decided sensation was sprung last midnight by the secret distribution, to Catholic voters of a twenty-four-page circular purporting to give a complete exposure of the purposes of the "American Protective Association," with its ritual and a long list of members who are prominent Protestant citizens.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 6. -- For the first time since Nebraska became a State the result of the vote for Presidential Electors is in doubt. There are three Electoral tickets in the field, but the Democrats have abandoned theirs to all intents and will vote for the Weaver Electors in order to take the State from Harrison. It now looks as if the move will be successful.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- There is no longer any doubt in the minds of the Democratic managers that Connecticut will to-morrow choose six Electors who will vote for Grover Cleveland for President. They are confident that at least three Democratic Congressmen will be elected, and that the Legislature will be such as to insure the election of a Democratic Senator to succeed Joseph R. Hawley.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 6. -- The Electric Light Union, composed of the trimmers, engineers, and other workmen about the electric-light plant, have decided to join in the strike, but in order to make their decision effective it was necessary that they should obtain the approval of the International Union of Electric Light Workers, of which they are members.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 6. -- There are four tickets in the field in Nevada -- Republican, Democratic, Silver, and Prohibition. The Silver, or People's Party, is for Weaver for President, William M. Stewart for United States Senator, and Francis G. Newlands for Congressional Representative. The State is conceded to Weaver by from 2,000 to 3,000 majority over Cleveland and Harrison combined.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 6. -- United States District Attorney Marion Irwin, in a letter to Supervisor of Elections Alexander, Democratic Supervisor for one of the voting precincts in Augusta, explains his views of the duty of Supervisors as follows: "It Is the duty of local managers of elections appointed under the State laws not to attempt to apply the registration test to anybody offering to vote."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The Carnegie people have a great "pull" with Secretary Tracy and the Republican Administration. There was evidence of this yesterday, when Secretary Tracy misapplied the authority with which he is vested to pay tribute to the corrupting generosity which gave a huge sum of money to the Republican cause.
The Republican managers have attempted to deceive voters and discredit ballots to be cast to-morrow by distributing in this oity pasters which do not comply with the law.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- At 10:30 P.M. Saturday fire was discovered in the stop of H.S. Robinson Co., boilermakers, on Border Street, East Boston, and by the time the fire apparatus reached the place a lively blaze was in progress. The whole building was soon a mass of flames which, driven by a strong westerly wind, soon spread to H. Murray's planing mill adjoining.

From the Tacama ( Washington) News. The way that costs are run up in a civil suit is appalling to one not familiar with litigation in Pierce County courts. The case of H.S. Holcomb against John D. Knox is a fair example. Holcomb had a chattel mortgage upon a boom of logs owned by Knox for $315, which it became necessary to foreclose.

Mr. Cleveland will have at least 232 votes in the Electoral College, or 9 more than are neces- sary to elect him. Where these votes are to come from is clearly shown in the following special dispatches to THE TIMES from its corre- spondents in every State that is now consid- ered doubtful or has been so classed by intelligent observers:

"If I live long enough I may strike upon an invention after a while that will make people open their eyes in amazement," said Thomas A. Edison the other day. Mr. Edison has great hopes that he will live to a ripe old age, because he has a thick, healthy head of hair. He says bald-headed people die young and people with plenty of hair live long and have good health.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6. -- Wisconsin is a doubtful State. Both parties claim it to-night, but neither claim more than 10,000 majority. The chances are that the Republicans will carry it, but they are very much frightened. Ex-Senator Spoonar, the Republican candidate for Governor, has made such a campaign as was never before known in the State.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 6. -- The campaign in Indiana closed Saturday. Both parties are now working to poll a full vote. Carriages are being hired for every precinct in the State, and if the weather is favorable 95 per cent of the vote now on the poll books will be cast.

Fair-minded voters throughout the length and breadth of the United States have for weeks been applying the Shibboleth tost to the two nominees of the Republican Party and the cause they represent. Each candidate has struggled to pronounce correctly the magic word and failed utterly, and BENJAMIN HARRISON and WHITELAW REID must meet their fate at the polls for this signal shortcoming.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 6. -- While interest in the State and National elections has been overshadowed by a fierce struggle for the permanent capital, both campaigns have been conducted with great energy. The People's Party opened with a showing of considerable strength, but has steadily grown, weaker, and will not seriously affect either party.

TRENTON, Nov. 6. -- The revelations made in Chairman Allan L. McDermott's letter, published in this morning's TIMES, concerning the insidious methods the Republican campaign managers are employing to cheat New-Jersey out of her Democratic Electoral vote, give new force and application to the political axiom that "Eternal vigilance is the price of liberty."

YANKTON, S.D., Nov. 6. -- Two days before the election the political situation in South Dakota seems to be indicative of a Republican victory so far as State and National tickets are concerned. The campaign has been a triangular affair, with the Republicans, the Democrats, and the independents in the field, each with a strong ticket, sufficient money, and numerous speakers.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Discount closed yesterday at 2 1/2 for three months and 1 3/4 for short. In the middle of the past week the rate in the open market advanced to equal the Bank of England rate, owing to expectation that the Bank of England would raise its rate to at least 3 1/4. But when, the Bank of England's decision against an advance was announced rates relapsed.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- The following letter has been sent by the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the New-England Tariff Reform League to the Home Market Club, not only accepting the letter's challenge, but exposing the insincerity of its offers:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- A wave of excitement swept over this town to-day as the result of a report that United States District Attorney Jesse Johnson of Brooklyn had been here in consultation with the President and Acting At- torney General Aldrich relative to the employ- ment of Deputy Marshals and United States troops at the polls in Brooklyn on election day.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 6. -- Never before have Kansas Republicans been compelled to fight for existence. Two years ago the strength of the opposition was not realized, and the Republicans were rudely awakened from their stupid security on election day. This year they had a most perfect organization with telling results.

Late, but with a start and an awful yell, our esteemed contemporary, the Herald, has awakened to the dangers to which this country is exposed from the coming of "English cheap laborers"; just as a heavy sleeper roused toward midday jumps in utmost disorder out of bed and loudly calls on Death and Apollyon in his wrath at having missed his breakfast and all the trains.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Nov. 6. -- The condition or affairs in North Dakota is somewhat mixed, with the chances in favor of the Democratic-Independent ticket at the first State election, in 1889, the Republicans had 14,000 majority In 1890, at the second State election, the Republicans had only 6,500 plurality, and a majority of only 1,700 over the Democrats and Independents.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6. -- Virginia will go Democratic in Tuesday's election by a majority, it is thought, of not less than 10,000. It is more likely to exceed these figures. The Hon. Basil B. Gordon, the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who is always extremely conservative in his estimates, confirms the claim here made.

" Thank God, I'm saved, I'm saved!" He was a small man and thin that stood in his place at the anniversary services of the Bowery Mission and Young Men's Home yesterday afternoon and gave his testimony for the good of the mission and the strengthening of his brothers there.

MR. SEIDL'S CONCERTS. Anton Seidl'a first popular concert at the Lenox Lyceum took place last evening. The house was crowded and there was an abundance of applause, which, however, was not always of a discriminating nature. The walls of the building have been covered in parts with additional hangings, and the sounding board over the stage has been wholly sheathed with flannel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 6. -- The refusal of Commander Henry L. Johnson, United States Navy, commanding the United States steamer Mohican, to go to the assistance of a mail steamer in distress off the coast of Alaska has resulted in the arraignment of that officer before the Secretary of the Navy by the citizens of Sitka, Alaska.

ALBANY, Nov. 6. -- Mr. L.F. Thoma, the organizer of the German-American Democrats, who has just completed his work, reports very flattering results. Regarding the outlook in the State, he said that the Germans had organizations in nearly every city and in many of the large villages. He said:

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6. -- All indications now point to the complete success of the Dem- ocratic Party at the election in this State on Tuesday. The Democratic situation has been steadily improving for the past month, and now the promise is that that party will win one of its old-time victories.

It was Sunday yesterday in Chrystie Street. A young woman who had once been pretty leaned against the house wall and grasped uncertainly at the rail to secure her balance. She reeled and grimaced and swore shocking oaths under the influence of drink. Her hair hung in strings over her face and she was dirty. In one hand she clutched a torn handkerchief that had knots in the corners.

DES MOISES, Iowa, Nov. 6. The people of Iowa on next Tuesday will choose thirteen Presidential Electors and the following State officers: Secretary of State, Auditor, Treasurer, Attorney General, and one Railroad Commissioner. No legislative candidates are to be voted for, except in one or two districts where vacancies have occurred by resignations.

Prof. N.S. Shaler, Dean of the Lawrence Scientific School of Harvard University and one of the most prominent of the college Faculty, tells with considerable pleasure of the great political change which has taken place in the body of Harvard instructors since he first became connected with the university.

BUFFALO, Nov. 6. -- The boodle received at this end of the State by the Republican County Com- mittees last week is now being distributed. Tidings come from various rural districts of overtures made by Republican leaders whose pockets bulge with bundles of "stuff."

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- A short time after the passage of the McKinley bill the Republicans in this section found occupation in holding up to the public the fact that an old cotton mill, previously used for the manufacture of knit goods, at Clark's Mills, near this city, had been purchased by an English firm, Messrs.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The cause of local self-government has received some now recruits here. The people of this city are in revolt against the Street and Water Board which Gov. Abbett imposed upon the city several months ago. The act creating the board destroyed all representative functions in the management of city affairs and placed the control of things in the hands of a board appointed by Mayor Haynes.
The following sanguine and roseate view of Democratic prospects in Illinois and the Northwest is in many respects corroborated by other information received by the Democratic Na- tional Committee:

From the Fall Mall Gazette. Mr. Beerbohm Tree, in a farewell speech delivered at the Theatre Royal, Glasgow, took occasion to refer to an address recently delivered in Edinburgh by the Rev. Dr. Rainy, head of the Free Church, on " Betting and Theatre Going." He had remarked. " There are three things that stick to the theatre -- they are orange peel, sawdust, and vice."

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 7 -- A.M. Like all weeks immediately preceding a Presidential election, the past one was not marked by much activity. Brokers have devoted much attention to the political campaign, and the bulk of the little business that was transacted was in the industrial stocks. Chicago Gas, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, Consolidated Gas, Cotton Oil, and American Tobacco were the leaders in the group.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- New-Jersey elects on Tuesday a Governor, eight Congressmen, six new State Senators, and an entire new Assembly. The Republicans concede Cleveland the Electoral vote by 3,000, but insist that because of the sins of the State Administration they will elect Kean Governor by 5,000. The Democrats expect to carry the State for Cleveland by 10,000 or 12,000 and for Werts for Governor by 6,000 or 7,000.

The flower show looked its prettiest -- and that is extraordinarily pretty, too -- for the benefit of its thousands of visitors yesterday afternoon and evening. The number of children in the Garden in the afternoon was very noticeable. They were of all dimensions and ages. They took everything in with open-mouthed delight and then literally cried for more.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 6. -- The contest in Colo- rado is between Republicans and lusionists, and both aides are claiming the victory for Presidential Electors. The State ticket, in best-informed circles, is conceded to the Republicans. The Democrats and People's Party have fused on Electors, but they failed to come together on a State ticket, and hence the Republicans have the best of this part of the contest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- The steam whaler Beluga, which arrived from the Arctic Ocean to-day, brings the news of the destruction of the whaling bark Helen Mac, Capt. Thaxter, and the loss of thirty-five of her crew. Only five of the vessel's men were saved.

To one who spent yesterday around the Federal Building it seemed as though all the tramps and toughs in town had business with the Government. They thronged the corridors, the Marshal's office, the office of the United Stated. Commissioner, and several of the courtrooms. Altogether a more disreputable looking lot of white men and negroes -- and there were nearly as many negroes as white men -- could not be brought together.
The most remarkable Presidential canvass ever made closed last night with popular confidence in the election of Cleveland and Stovenson by the people to-day.

Everybody must have been startled by the announcement that the proclamation of a quarantine-of twenty days against the vessels carrying emigrants was about to be "re-enforced." When the proclamation was issued, the issue of it seemed to be decidedly the right thing to do. The cholera was really "raging," as the sensational reporters said it was, in several European cities, and in one that formed the point of departure of two great transatlantic lines.

At midnight last night Mr. Harrison's managers made their last bluff of the campaign. Cyrus Clarkson, Carter, and Kerens walked into the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel at Twenty-third Street and Broadway and announced that they were ready to wager all the money Democrats cared to take at odds of 10 to 9 that Mr. Harrison would be elected.

Local steamship men are of the opinion that whoever is responsible for the present absurd condition of affairs needs an extended vacation. What the Federal authorities expect to accomplish by subjecting every incoming passenger vessel to a vexatious and needless delay, no one has yet been found to explain. Nonsense of this sort is not by any means harmless nonsense, as the steamship people, whose patrons have Buttered unwarranted detention, are willing to testify.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Bronson Howard's now play, ''Aristocracy," was produced to-night for the first time at the National Theatre, Washington. The audience was not made up of society "first-nighters," such as are acoustomed, to greet a new play in New-York. The author probably desired, for good reasons, that it should not be so. But the theatre was crowded by a fairly critical audience, and the piece achieved success.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- George F. Sanford, the big left guard of the Yale University football eleven, broke one of the bones of his ankle at the regular practice of the team this afternoon. He will be unable to play any more this year.

The French Government has in contemplation the sending to the United States next April of one of the most powerful cruising fleets ever dispatched from France. The occasion will be the naval rendezvous in Hampton Roads, Virginia of representative war ships from nearly every country in honor of the Columbian celebration.

Testimony was taken a few days ago in the suit by which the Government questions the legality of the transfer of the Philadelphia refineries to the Sugar Trust. This is one of the suits by which the Department of Justice has sought to excite contempt for the Anti-Trust law.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The case of the score or more of men, nearly all negroes, whom the Democratic County Committee of Westchester County had caused to be arrested, or had warrants issued for, in the town of North Salem, for illegal registration, was before Justice J.O. Dykman, holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court here to-day.

The campaign that will close with sunset to-day has been very remarkable in many ways, for the extreme calm that has prevailed in the public mind from beginning to end, for the absence of personalities on both sides, for the steadiness with which business has moved apparently uninfluenced by the course of the canvass.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 7. -- South Carolina can be classed among the most certain of Democratic States. There is not a shadow of a chance for the Electoral votes to be cast for any excepting Mr. Cleveland. The white Democratic vote will be about 70,000 and the Republican vote about 40,000, and the third-party strength between 2,500 and 4,000.

Every election in this State under the present ballot law is an object lesson to teach the voter the need of a more complete reform. If we had the Australian ballot, with the patty group arrangement and the party symbol device for the benefit of the illiterate, the task of the voter would be much simpler and easier than it is now.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- This morning the latest "boodle" scheme of the Republican managers in this county came to the surface. Out of a vote of 1,300 in the town of Minden the Republican County Committee has laid a plan to capture 200 floaters at $10 a head and farm them out to the farmers.

H. Maitland Kersey of the White Star Line received a cablegram from Lord Danraven yesterday, in which Dunraven said he is satisfied with the concessions made to Mr. Kersey by the America's Cup Committee at the New York Club in their conference last Friday, and will proceed to formally answer the committee's recent letter at once.

Sorosis gave its second "social day" at Sherry's yesterday afternoon. At 1 o'clock 200 ladies sat down to lunch, which was served in the lover ballroom. The tables were beautifully decorated with chrysanthemums and lighted with pink-shaded candles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- The provision pit was lively from the start, Receipts of hogs were away under the estimates and prices at the yards were materially higher. Aside from this naturally bullish fact, influential traders like Wright, Cudahy, Singer, and Fairbank took the buying side, and the list was advanced. Perhaps the greatest advance was November lard, which closed Saturday at $8.55 1/2, sold yesterday at $9.25, and cloned at $9.10.

From the Philadelphia Press. Two thousand letter boxes a day will be turned out by a factory which begins Dec. 1 to manufacture those articles for the private use of householders all over the Union. They are designed for attachment to the doors of dwellings and other buildings, being of the patterns selected by the Post Office Department from 1,600 models offered.

Cool evenings the chafing dish and the amateur cook unite forces with wonderful results. Men particularly love this dainty style of cooking, and they employ their talents with pleasure on Welsh rarebits, oysters, terrapin, and even candy.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- At 8 o'clock this morning 1,200 people assembled in the Town Hall in Provincetown to see and hear Gov. Russell. He arrived, at that extremely bleak spot last night on a special train. This morning, after speeches by his Excellency and a few others, the special train started for Boston. It was then 9:20 o'clock.
The launch of the new United States cruiser Cincinnati from the stocks of the Brooklyn Navy Yard has teen deferred until 1:45 o'clock next Thursday.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 7. -- A conference of leading Democrats was held to-day, and the unanimous decision reached was that Oregon must be carried for Weaver, and it will be done if individual work and personal effort will do it.

Edwin J. Freedman, receiver of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company, appeared before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Superior Court yesterday, in sequestration proceedings against the Western Union Telegraph Company to recover $2,000,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 7. -- The Secretary of State has received from the Roman Catholic minority of Manitoba a petition asking that under the provisions of Manitoba and the British North America act his Excellency the Governor General in Council make an order to the effect that the right to separate schools possessed by them both at the time when Manitoba became part of Canada and afterward, by virtue of provincial legislation, be restored.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- A special dispatch to the Times from Teheran, Persia, says it is reported that Mr. Theodore Child of Harper Brothers, the well-known publishing house in New-York, baa died from cholera at Ispahan. Mr. Child was making a tour of the East.

When it was discovered at Tammany Hall yesterday morning that the Tammany paster ballot was four inches and a half wide, while the law requires the paster to be only four Inches wide, an investigation was at once set afoot.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- In a political quarrel last night at Pelham Bridge, Westchester County, John Hiney was fatally shot by John Elliott.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Arrangements are being made to carry a largo delegation of University of Pennsylvania students to the Yale-Pennsylvania game in New-York next Saturday. On Wednesday tickets for the game will be put on sale, and the Pennsylvania Railroad is to run a special train for the students on the day of the game.

In every State, it may be assumed, the voters have some time ago made up their minds for whom they will vote for President, and in a very few States only will it be possible for the Republicans, even with an unexampled corruption fond in hand and applied to change the resolution of the people, to escape the defeat that seems about to overtake and, perhaps, overwhelm them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- The general Fall athletic names of Harvard University, postponed from saturday on account of the weatner, were held this afternoon. The sky was overcast, the air was, a little chilly, and the ground was extremely soft, conditions by no means favorable to the making of good records. The time on the track was however, fair, and in the mile run even fast.

In the four events at Fleetwood yesterday two additions were made to the 2:30 list -- Cambridge Girl and Cartridge. The latter was bred by Robert Bonner. Cartridge's dam was the famous Lady Stout, the first three-year-old to trot below 2:30. Summaries follow:

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Another meeting of the unemployed workingmen was held at Tower Hill to-day, and the speeches made showed increased violence in their tone. The speeches to-day was more pregnant with promise of violent results than any beard recently at Tower Hill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- No one not a member of his personal or official family could get near President Harrison to-night. Not many porsons made the attempt, for nobody had good news to carry to the defeated Republican candidate.

CAMBRIDE, Mass., Nov. 8. -- This afternoon Harvard played her last football before the great Yale game at Springfield, Nov. 19. The opposing team was from the Boston Athletic Association. The score was 16 to 12 in favor of Harvard. The general playing of the Harvard men did not inspire the supporters of the crimson with enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Illinois may safely be put in the Democratic column from all indications at midnight. Cleveland's plurality in the State will certainly not fall below 5,000, and may exceed that considerably. His gains all through the city show this.
From the Atlanta Constitution, Nov 7. "Do you see that gentleman sitting at the further end of that long seat?" said Mr. Matlock to a Constitution reporter yesterday.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Nov. 8. -- A numerous band of Vaqui Indians attacked the hacienda of Alexander Lacy, throe leagues from Cortez Station, Sonora, Mexico. At the time of the attack Mr. and Mrs. Lacy and child were seated at the sapper table. The Indians fired twice into the room, hitting Mrs. Lacy. The lights were extinguished and dishes shattered.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Mr. Eugene O'Neill, a passenger on the Cunard Line steamer Pavonia, Capt. McKay, which arrived at Queenstown yesterday from Boston, in describing his experiences on the voyage, says that he has crossed the Atlantic at all seasons and in different classes of vessels, but he never met with weather that approached in violence that which prevailed on Wednesday and Thursday last.

Lady Peg. W.T. Hunter, and Onward, O.W. Ames; Bois Fauat, Rudolph Schmidt, and Earl of Kent, A.R. Gilham; Croxie O'Shannon, R.I. Shannon, and Biz, W.P. Smith; Lad of Russ, J.L. Adams, and David C., Joseph Cruse; Pomme de Terre, T.G. Bastos, and Kent Elgin, T.L. Ashford of Birmingham.

The following table shows the pluralities in the several counties of the State of the Republican and Democratic candidates for President this year, and also the pluralities of the candidates for President in 1888:

According to a telegram from Rome the Republic of Colombia has petitioned the Pope asking that the 12th of October be declared a perpetual religious holiday in that country in commemoration of the discovery of America.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- 11:30 P.M. -- Never in the recent history of political effort in this State have the returns of an election come in so slowly as they are coming to-night. At this hour twenty precincts in Boston are missing, but it is safe to put the total plurality for Russell at 14,000 or 14,500. The national ticket will fall below these figures.

Everything is Democratic in New-Jersey. Perfect weather all over the State brought the Cleveland voters to do their part in giving the Republicans their Waterloo. The polls remained open until 7 o'clock, and other States had considerable headway before New-Jersey started to count. Returns were thus late in coming in, but they repaid waiting.

Democratic New-York enjoyed Its triumph last night. Factions had disappeared, and men who had fought shoulder to shoulder in the day's tattle of the party for Cleveland and Stevenson joined heartily in the evening's celebration of the utter rout of the enemy. It had been a groat day, and It was a great night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Cornell defeated Michigan to-day in a sharp game before a large and enthusiaslic crowd. Thirty-minute halves were played, when the score stood 44 to 0. Cornell outplayed Michigan in offensive work, but the visitors made good gains through her centre and used the wedge effectively. Michigan also tackled hard, but guarded poorly and tumbled continually.

In the last weeks of the campaign the leading organs of the McKinley party sought to disturb what the New-York Tribune called the "overconfidence" of Republicans by warning them that the loss of the Presidency would carry with it the loss of the Senate, which had been regarded as an impregnable stronghold of McKinleyism.
The following table shows how the votes in the Electoral College will be cast, as shown by the returns thus far received:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The third annual members' games of the Montclair Athletic Club were held on the club grounds at Montclair, N.J., yesterday afternoon. As usual, there was a large attendance, and the events were well contested. Summary:

CHARLESTON, West Va., Nov. 8. -- Chairman W.E. Chilton of the Democratic State Committee says to-night that Cleveland has a majority of fully 3,000 over Harrison. It will be a day at least before the exact figures of the election in West Virginia will be known. Some of the voting precincts are fifty miles or more from railroad or telegraph facilities and the returns will have to be carried by men on horseback.

From London Truth. A dim. dingy, cockpit-looking hall, dear Lady Betty, with a raised bench running along one end, an ample dock, and an overhanging gallery at the other, and progressive pens to the left Opposite to these, and beneath the only windows through which struggles the light of day, an antiquated jury box, containing twelve men, the very image of the waxworks in Mme.

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Albany Democrats are not rejoicing in the glorious result. They feel aggrieved over the treachery that was practiced by the followers of David B. Hill, which cut down Cleveland's majority from 1,600 four years ago to about 500, resulting in the election of three of the four Assemblymen by the Republicans, and the probable election of James D. Walsh Republican County Clerk and the Republican County ticket.

To say that the supporters of HARRISON and REID had no expectation of winning the election except by overriding the evident will of the people of the United States is to declare what has for some weeks been a self-evident truth. It has been equally evident to all New-Yorkers that the means upon which they relied were two -- bribery and intimidation.

OHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- If Martin Knutzen, keeper of the lighthouse on Pilot Island, at Death's Door entrance to Green Bay, floes not get a gold medal it will not be because he does not deserve one, for he saved two entire crews of vessels which stranded on Pilot Island during the recent gales. The first was the schooner J. R. Gilmore and the second the schooaer A.P. Nichols.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 8. -- Since 4 o'clock this morning bands of workmen have been parading the streets, singing revolutionary songs and shouting "Long live universal suffrage!" The action of the Constitution Revision Committee in rejecting the proposition to grant universal suffrage and adopting the proposition to grant the franchise only to householders is the cause of the demonstration.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Mrs. Catherine Parnell, widow of Charles Stewart Parnell, has obtained, under her own petition, a receiving order from the Brighton Bankruptcy Court. She will the a lull statement of her affairs on Thursday.

The people's trust in Grover Cleveland, the moral revolt from the Republican Party, and the hearty union of the Democracy upon the great issue of tariff reform produced a Democratic landslide in the election of yesterday. Cleveland and Stevenson have been chosen to the highest offices in the gift of the American people by a majority in the Electoral College so large that the meaning is unmistakable.

Letters received from Singapore give particulars of an explosion which occurred on board the cruiser Mercury, one of the ships of the China squadron, on the 21st of September. The spirit room, which opens into a narrow and ill-ventilated space on the starboard side of the main magazine, was being opened by the Captain of the hold, the ship's steward and several other men standing by to render him any necessary assistance.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Whitelaw Reid returned to his country place, Ophir Farm, immediately after he had voted in New-York. He dined at 7 with Mrs. Reid and D.O. Mills, his father-in law.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 8. -- There were scarcely any developments in the strike situation to-day. There was a sort of general understanding that the election would be allowed to pass off quietly so as to furnish no excuse for nullifying any part of the result. Both sides are very quiet as to future movements, but the impression is that to-morrow will bring forth decisive action.

With all his bluffing and all his talk, John I. Davenport, as an intimidator, out a small figure in the election in this city. His more than 5,000 special Deputy Marshals arrested altogether less than 200 men at the polls. It was nothing like as good a record as Davenport had made in previous elections, when he had not had more than 1,000 or 1,500 plug-uglies enlisted as Deputy Marshals.
Kings County redeemed its old reputation for steadfastness in the Democratic ranks yesterday by rolling up the biggest plurality for Grover Cleveland that any Democratic candidate ever obtained.

The vessels of the North Atlantic squadron are at present stationed as follows: The flagship Chicago is at St. Thomas, West Indies. The Concord is en route from Colon to Key West, Fle. The Kearsargo is on the Venezuela coast and about to make a cruise up the Orinoco River. The Atlanta and Miantpnomoh are at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

From the Shoe and Leather Reporter. That the profits of the men who make shoes have been small for years, and continually getting smaller, is universally conceded. But we do not think it is anything like as generally known that these same shoes, originally sold at a trifle above cost, frequently find their way into the hands of dealers who dispose of them at retail at figures which yield them immense profits.

The construction work on the new United States Torpedo Boat No. 2, building at the shops of the Iowa iron Works, Dabuque, Iowa, will be completed about Dec. 1. This statement is made by Mr. William Hopklns, Superintendent of the Iowa Iron Works.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- The Union Pacific will have to decide before Nov. 17 one of the most perplexing questions in its history. Should its decision not be satisfactory it will lead to a finish fight between it and the Atchison, Burlington, Burlington and Missouri, Rock Island, Rio Grande Western, Colorado Midland and Denver and Rio Grande.

The House of Representatives of the Fifty-third Congress will consist of 356 members, the membership having been increased by the apportionment of 1891. The Fifty-second Congress consists of 232 Democrats, 86 Republicans, and 9 Farmers' Alliance men, who do not affiliate with either party. Of the Fifty-third Congress there will be 231 Democrats, 86 Republicans, and 12 members representing only the People's Party, The Democratic majority will be 110; Democrats over Republicans, 120.

At the present writing the returns give Mr. CLEVELAND the Electoral votes of the South -- 159 in all -- 36 in New-York, 10 in New-Jersey, 6 in Connecticut, 7 in Michigan, 12 in Wisconsin, and 24 in Illinois. This is a total of 254. The early returns from Indiana were favorable to CLEVELAND, but were insufficient to justify a conclusion.

The work of voting in this city was accomplished with much less friction than was anticipated or than has bean the case at other elections of importance for a number of years. There were, of course, arrests and differences of opinion, but as a rule the day in all districts was exceptionally quiet.

From the Milwaukee Sentinel, Nov. 6. The history of a century does not record many such fires as the one which recently burned away a portion of Milwaukee. A great billow of flame, that leaped from an oil house, was carried on the wings of a tempest, laying waste 150 acres of buildings, making 3,000 people homeless, destroying 465 structures, and causing a loss approximated at $6,000,000.

FARGO, N.D., Nov. 8. -- It the Republicans have carried the State it will be by means of Indian voters driven to the polls by the agent and voted for the straight Republican ticket, like a flock of sheep. On Devil's Lake Reservation there are from eight to ten hundred Indians about twenty-one years of age, who, a few months ago, were given land in severalty.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- An explosion occurred in this city this morning by which two policemen and two other men lost their lives, and another was latally injured. The affair was undoubtedly the worte of Anarchists, \vlio were Booking revenge against the Carinaus Mining Company, whose long-continued straggle with their employes was amicably settled a few days ago.
GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 8. -- The vote will probably not exceed that of 1888, when Cleveland's plurality was 146,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8. -- All the lines of the Columbus Street Railway Company are tied up this morning on account of a strike of the conductors and motor men. The cause of the strike was the discharge of Conductor Clarence Alexander, who declined to receive a mutilated dime from a passenger. The rules of the company make the conductors stand good for mutilated coins.

At the election in this city yesterday more than 286,000 citizens voted, out of the 309,625 registered. Of these the Cleveland Electors received 168,964, and the Harrison Electors 94,495, giving the former a plurality of 74,469. The People's Party candidates received 1,702 votes, the Socialist 5,600, and the Prohibitionists 1,617.

The Democracy of Richmond County (Staten Island) were jubilant yesterday over having polled the largest vote and given the largest majorities for the whole ticket ever known in the history of the county.

The explosion in a Parisian police office of the dynamite intended, as the French have it, to "make jump" the offices of an unpopular corporation, does not seem to have been, from the Anarchist point of view, a very successful performance. Nevertheless the French Anarchists declare themselves to be delighted with it.

The new United States cruiser Cincinnati will be launched to-day from the Brooklyn Navy Yard at 12:45 o'clock. Miss Mo sby, daughter of the Mayor of Cincinnati, will christen the new cruiser as she is about to take her initial plunge.

The confidence in the intelligence and the moral worth of the people has in this campaign been rewarded in a brilliant manner. Such a campaign as the young Democracy conducted this year had perhaps never before been carried on by a party in the United States. It consisted throughout of the noblest appeals to the understanding of the people upon the economical, political, and moral significance of tariff reform.

Three new Directors were elected by the st ockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company yesterday. They are G.P. Morosini, one of the largest holders of the company's stock; George Bliss of Morton, Bliss Co., and Donald Mackay of Vermilye Co. The Directors re-elected were Jay Gould, George J. Gould, Edwin Gould, Russell Sage, Samuel Sloan, J. Pierpont Morgan, R.M. Gallaway, Frank K. Hain, Simon Wormser, and T.C. Eastman.
LONG ISLAND CITY, Nov. 9. -- The defeat of Mayor Patrick J. Gleason for a third term as Mayor of Long Island City is the absorbing topic.

Later reports of Tuesday's election extend tie lines of the Democratic conquest Mr. Cleveland's majority in the Electoral College will be at least 156 votes, and it is possible that it may be still greater.

FARGO, Nov. 9. -- North Dakota will be very close on Electors, Congressman, and State ticket. It will be Thursday night before the full returns will be received. The Republican State Committee claims the Electors by 1,000, Johnson for Congress by 500, and Burke for Governor. The Democrats claim Electors by 1,500, the Governor by 3,000, and the Congressman by 1,000.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Nov. 9. -- The boast and the boodle of Steve Elkins have come to naught. He has failed to deliver West Virginia to Harrison as the price of his admission to the Cabinet.

Few men have been able to describe a storm at sea, and fewer yet have told of the horrors of a blizzard on the plains. So strong are the unchecked elements of nature that language falls short of telling the story. An avalanche of fire, sweeping everything before it, is one of the world's happenings that never will be properly described in a newspaper.

The St. Louis Game and Fish Association, commonly known as the King's Lake Club, enjoyed its seventh annual coon hunt on Saturday night. The triumphant sportsmen returned last night. The event has been discussed among the members of the club for some time, and the largest number that has ever attended the famous coon hunts gathered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Beginning with snow and hall and ending with such as downpour of rain as Washington usually reserves for the days when New-England excursion parties are in town, this has seemed to the Republicans at the capital a very fitting sort of day to follow such news as came to them last night and this morning, and which they continue to receive at a most disheartening rate.
The following table shows how the rotes in the Electoral College will be cast, as shown by the retains thus far received:

Prof. Charles A. Briggs, oooapant of the Chair of Biblical Theology at the Union Theological Seminary in this city, whose written and expressed opinions have divided his Church against itself, is on the rack again. The case of "The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America against the Rev. Charles A. Briggs, D.D.," was called yesterday afternoon before the court of the Presbytery of New York.

"The people did it," was the universal opinion in Kings County yesterday when the astonishing result of Tuesday's voting became generally known.
