Detective Sergeants O'Brien and John Taylor of the Central Office, after shadowing two men three or four days, made the arrests in the case on Friday night, but the matter was not made public until the prisoners were arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Additional affidavits were filed to-day in the coal combine suits between John P. Stockton, informant, and the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey and others. Theaflidavits are those of A.A. MoLeod, President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad; C.E. Henderson, General Manager of the Philadelphia and Reading Company, and Charles Hartshorne, Second Vice President of the same road.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- The will of the late Charles E. Powers, the wealthy ex-street railway President, contains some clauses that are interesting in view of the statement published this morning that Mr. Powers's former wife is in Denver seeking to set aside the divorce obtained in the State of Colorado by Mr. Powers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 14 -- The Orthodox Presbyterians of Ohio were recently shocked by the declarations of the Rev. Henry Preserved Smith, a professor of Hebrew in the Lane Theological Seminary, against whom charges were made and whose trial was began here to-day. The declarations were made in a pamphlet entitled, "Biblical Scholarship and Inspirations."

"The Republican Party will be in better shape in 1896 than it would have been if Harrison had been elected," Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota said yesterday, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broadway and Twenty third Street.

The Autumnal meeting and dinner of the Unitarian Club of New-York took place at the St. Denis Hotel, Broadway and Eleventh Street, last evening, and was followed by exercises in memory of George William Curtia. Two hundred gentlemen and ladles sat down to dinner.

The question whether there ought to be an extra session of the now Congress for the consideration of tariff bills is discussed by many of our contemporaries. We find the following in Mr. McCLURE's Philadelphia Times, a Well-known advocate of tariff reform:

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 14 -- Mayor-elect Gilroy of New-York City arrived here this morning and took quarters for a few days at the St. Charles Hotel. He gave THE TIMES'S correspondent a cordial reception. Naturally he was asked as to the Democratic victory, and responded readily and rapidly.

JOSEPH H. MACK. Joseph H. Mack, the theatrical manager, died yesterday at his place, Summit Hill Farm, near Hewitt, N.J. His death was rather sudden, though he had been in ill health for the last three years.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The funeral of the Duke of Marlborough took place to-day at Blenheim Palace, the Marlborough seat at Woodstook, Oxfordshire.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 14 -- At a political demonstration to-night Vice President-elect Stevenson said:

To all appearances the proposed match between Herr Lasker and Mr. S. Lipschutz is well under way and will probably take place early in the Spring. Recently the project of a match between W. Steinitz, who has hold the chess championship of the world for the past twenty-five years, and Herr Lasker has also been under consideration in chess circles.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The present week is likely to be a momentous one for the French Cabinet. There is a growing opinion that the Ministry is only awaiting a chance to die gracefully. The Chamber of Deputies has already abolished the duties on certain drinkables, against the advice of the Ministers, thus dlminishing the revenue by 88,000,000f, and upsetting the Finance Minister's budget schemes.

Two matters out of the ordinary routine had to be considered by the New-York Presbytery at its regular session yesterday, held in the Scotch Church, on Fourteenth Street. Immediately after the devotional exercises Stated Clerk Alexander read this somewhat remarkable letter:

The Adirondack of the Atlas Line arrived in this port yesterday from Haitian ports and Jamaica. She had official dispatches from President Hippolyte to the Haitian Consulate in this city, believed to refer to the threatened revolution.

The United States revenue cutter Dexter, recently ordered to duty on the Massachusetts coast, will take the place of the ill-fated Gallatin, lost in January, 1891, in a blinding snowstorm off Gloucester. The Dexter, of recent years, has been engaged in patrol duty In Long Island Sound, with a cruising ground extending from Whitestone to Edgartown.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Receipts of hogs were larger and prices at the yards were lower. This was reflected in the speculative market, and selling was the rule early, with shorts about the only buyers at the decline. Outside orders were source. At the lower range or prices there was moderate buying, and a slight rally from the lower point of the day followed.

Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin, a member of the Republican National Committee, who with Mr. Campbell of Illinois, had charge of the campaign in several of the Western States, was in this city yesterday. It was his first visit since he was assigned to his work early in the campaign.

Those football experts who quote the rules of the Intercollegiate Football Association to show that a Princeton defeat Nov. 24 means the crowding out of Princeton from the Thanksgiving Day game next year are evidently unfamiliar with college football. Because Section 2. Article IV., of the constitution of the association says that "the two leading colleges of the preceding year shall play in or near New-York," it is taken for granted that Princeton is doomed.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Thomas Neill, the murderer of Matilda Clover and other girls, was hanged in Newgate Prison at 9 o'clock this morning. He made no confession. Death appeared to be instantaneous.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 15 -- Col. Jack Chinn, the well-known horse starter, was probably fatally shot at the East St. Louis track this afternoon by Capt. D.D. Anthony of the track police force. The circumstance are these:

Archic M. Aston, a Custom House clerk, living at 77 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, who is alleged to have boon engaged in a conspiracy to prevent 350 Democrats of Troy, N.Y., from voting by taking them on a free ex cursion on election day, was arrested on Monday night and locked up at Police Headquarters on a warrant issued by Police Magistrate Dono.

"A SOCIETY CLOWN." Mr. George Grossmith made his first appearance in this country last night at Ohickering Hall, presenting, to the evident delight of a large audience which included many persons of note, his platform entertainment, in which song, narrative, and mimicry are pleasingly commingled.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Mrs. Anita McMurrow, alias the Countess de Bettincourt, had a hearing before Magistrate Durham this afternoon, and was hold in $1,000 bail upon the charge of entering into a conspiracy with Elmer M. Billings of New-York to defraud William G. Toplis, a Germantown druggist, out of a large sum of money.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- When the International Marine Conference recommended a system of lights on vessels as the preventive of collisions at sea there became necessary the examination of the power and intensity of lights and the solution of the problem what was the least eandle power at which lights of various colors could be clearly seen at definite distances.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The position of the Ministry was the all-absorbing topic about the Chamber of Deputies this evening. The lobbies were thronged with animated groups discussing the outcome of to-morrow's debate on the bill giving the Government power to suppress violent Anarchist newspapers.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- The Wesleyan Faculty met this evening and awarded the Seney scholarships to the three upper classes. These scholarships are the gift of George I. Senoy of Brooklyn, and vary in amount from $50 to $150. They are given to each class on the basis of the scholarship standing for the preceding year. The successful students this year are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- There are a number of vacancies in the different branches of the Government service at present, and some people have indulged in the belief that, owing to the late popular upheaval, Mr. Harriaon would refrain from filling them, leaving the task to his successor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- There is one name on the tongues of Philadelphia Democrats that possesses a charm to conjure with. That name is Harrity. He is the man whom the expectant Democrat would like to see honored. But Mr. Harrity is not looking to the incoming Administration for any personal reward.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners announce that the franchise for the construction and operation of rapid-transit railroads upon the routes heretofore decided upon and in accordance with the plans and specifications now submitted for inspection will be offered for sale in the rotunda of the City Hall on the 29th of December.

For the one hundred and twenty-fourth time the Chamber of Commerce gave an annual dinner last night. The event toot place at Delmonico's, and there a score of gentlemen who have achieved fame in politics met nearly 250 of the business men of the city. The number in attendance at the dinner was limited only by the capacity of the hall.

"Presidential Campaigns as an Educational Influence" was the Nineteenth Century Club's timely topic for discussion at its meeting last night at Sherry's. It was ably handled by Congressman William L. Wilson of West Virginia and Prof. James Schouler. The two men differed just enough in their views to make what they had to say all the more interesting, and call for more thought on the part of the audience.

The deficit for the Columbian Exhibition in this city promises to range from $50,000 to $70,000, and the wisest financiers of the Committee of One Hundred are not able to see how it can be overcome without legislative aid. Sessions have been held daily at the Mayor's office, and rumors Have been rife that an irrepressible conflict was raging between Controller Myers on one side and the committee on the other.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 15 -- Officer Nard of Fremont County and two assistants reported to have been killed in the Big Horn Mountains by Jim Moore, the fugitive murderer at Constable Byron Smith, have returned to Lander with the report that they could not find Moore, The latter, according to Indian hunters, has a regular fortified citadel and challenges any posse to come and take him.
The inexcusable ignorance of some of our Republican contemporaries is shown by their comments upon the following paragraph, from an editorial article published in THE TIMES of the 11th inst.:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 15 -- The yearling match race run at the Kentucky Association course today, for $100 a side, at one quarter of a mile, was won by Wickliffe. Preston's bay colt, by Glenleg, dam Triangle, dam of Tringle and Champagne Charley, in excellent time, considering the track was muddy. Major John S. Clark's colt, by Springbek, dam The Niece, by Alarm, was the opposition, but ran twenty lengths behind.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 9 -- Advices from Haiti say that another revolution is not far distant in that country. The coffee crop is gathered and this is just the time of year that disturbances usually arise. Hippolyte, however, is extremely watchful, and any one suspected of plotting against him is promptly arrested. An attempted rising at Capo Haitien has just been put down by the arrest of the leaders.

GEN. DE FAILLY. The French General Pierre Louis Charles Achille de Failly is dead. He was born at Rozoysur-Serre, Department of Aisne, on Jan. 21, 1810. He entered the military school of St. Cyr in 1826, and two years later joined the army, where he rose gradually in rank until he became a General of Brigade in 1854.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 15 -- The convention of the National Farmers' Alliance and the Industrial Union was called to order by President H. L. Lonoks at 11 o'clock tills morning in the ball of the Young Men's Hebrew Association.

CRAVATH -- HUNTINGTON. Miss agnes Huntington, the actress, was married yesterdy to Paul Drennan Cravath of this city, the son of the Rev. E.M. Cravath of Nashville, Tenn., President of Fisk University. The wedding took place at St. Thomas's Church at noon, and the Rev. Dr. John Wesley Brown, the rector officiated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Chief of Engineers will ask for over $2,500,000 for continuing the work of defending the coast line of the United States. The report of Gen. Casey to Congress, beyond the estimate for land fortifications, asks for very little money for river and harbor improvements.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- The killing of Charles Doolittle on the night of Oct. 10, within a few hundred feet of his house, and the failure of the police to unearth his assassin, has directed public attention to other mysterious cases of killing, which preceded Doolittle's murder.

It is not at all to be wondered at that the apathy of the French Ministry in the presence of the recent outbreaks of Anarchism should have provoked a very general resentment. A like apathy on the part of the authorities of any State of the Union in like circumstances would have provoked a general resentment here, and our ways of looking at such things are very different from French ways.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- The Wesleyan football men did some lively practicing in the mud this afternoon, with "Billy " Bull and Jordon Wells, '89, as coachers. Wells paid particular attention to Cobb, the freshman centre, who has been showing up so well lately. Cults was out again in his old place at left guard, and seemed to be in better trim than ever before.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- The Socialist Congress resumed its sessions in Concordia Hall to-day. Herr Singer, who was yesterday unanimously elected President of the party, matte a speech in the course of which he referred to the rapid progress of the party. At its first meeting, held twenty-five years ago, the contributions reached the total of 520 thalers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- News reacted washington to-day that "W.H. Howard," who has been in jail in Troy, N.Y., for a week, charged with conspiracy against the elective franchise, is Howard Sutherland, Chief of the Population Division of the United States Census Bureau.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 15 -- The Yale eleven played one hour and a half at the Yale field this afternoon. It was the first practice since the same Saturday, and the players were in fine shape. None is overtrained as yet, and the danger is now practically over, as to-morrow the team indulges in its last hard play before the games, with Harvard and Princeton.

There are several aspects in which the choice of a Democratic Senator from New-York can be viewed in which there is some danger that the persons upon whom that choice will fall may neglect to view it, and which we therefore take the liberty of bringing to their attention.

The Diebold-Mosler-Damon Safe Company, which was incorporated at Trenton, N.J., yesterday, takes in most of the safe manufactories not in the recently-formed Safe Trust. Its capital is $5,000,000, divided into $2,800,000 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock and $2,200,000 common stock. There is no bond issue.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- The trial of Prof. Henry Preserved Smith of Lane Theological Seminary for alleging that the Old Testament contains errors of historic fact and that the inspired authors of Chronicles and other inspired writers of the Old Testament were guilty of suppressing sundry historic truths was resumed in the First Presbyterian Church before the Presbytery of Cincinnati this morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Stiles Judson, Jr., of Stratford, who was defeated on the Republican ticket last week for Secretary of State by Judge Phelan of Bridgeport, added to his blunders in the House this afternoon by leading the Republicans in that body to stand by the socalled "Schedule G" fraud, which was used in keeping the Democratic State officers out of office two years ago.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Battle Akers of Greason, Penn., was placed on trial to-day in the Warren County Court on a charge of attempting last August to kill Patrick Quinn, the night operator in the telegraph office at Delaware, in this county.

Very different from the club days of the colonial settlers on the upper part of this island was the brilliant scene in the new Colonial Club house, at Seventy-second street and the Boulevard, last night. Although the weather was in its most disagreeable mood it failed to check the enthusiastic joyousness of the members of the Colonial Club upon the occasion of the formal opening of their beautiful house.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Nov. 15 -- P.M. To-day's stock market seems to indicate that the short interest has become so large that it cannot be covered without causing a sharp advance in prices. The opening was about steady, but the tendency was downward until the afternoon, when a sharp rally sot in on the covering of short contracts.

Many Republicans of more or less prominence were in this city yesterday, and the corridors of the hotels were livelier than they had been any previous day since election. For the most part the visitors seemed to take the defeat of the party philosophically.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 15 -- The Hon. R.F. Kolb, late candidate for Governor of Alabama, is out in the Evening Journal to-day in an open letter addressed to the Legislature, which convened to-day, charging fraud in the late election for State officers and asking for a thorough investigation. He says:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 -- The General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church completed its work to-day and adjourned to meet in Minneapolis in 1893. It has appropriated $1,275,000 for mission work, the greatest amount in the history of the Church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- During the three months yet to elapse before President-elect Cleveland will be afforded an opportunity to call an extra session of the Fifty-third Congress, it is likely that a good deal of careful consideration will be given to that question, and some good reasons may be urged by earnest tariff-reformers against under taking too much reform work at one time.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Fully two-thirds of the candidates of the Democracy before the people at the last election have filed their expense account with the Secretary of State, while not more than one-half of the Republicans have thus far complied with the law. The ample cor ruption funds which the Republicans in the interior of the State had to debauch the ballot with are shown by the expense accounts filed.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The Government's bill providing for the imposition of severer penalties upon Anarchist papers that incite to violence and generally adding to the stringency of the press laws was introduced in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. An exciting debate followed, but the Chamber adjourned without taking a vote on the measure.

The only comfort Mr. Bauer, temporary manacer of the weather of this vicinity, had to offer to complaining citizens yesterday was that during the twenty-four hours ending at 8 o'clock in the morning more rain had fallen in New-York than ever before in the same length of time during the month of November. The exact amount was 3.65 inches.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 16 -- Nearly four weeks ago the agent of Reuter's Telegram Company telegraphed from St. Petersburg the first of the Russian official statements in reference to the seizure of Canadian sealers in Bering Sea. The contention of the Czar's officers was that the vessels taken near Copper Island had been seen killing seals within the limit.

A conference of Roman Catholic prelates would not ordinarily excite much interest among Americans who do not belong to the communion that it represents. The conference that took place yesterday, however, attracts a wide attention because of the belief that the subject mainly considered at it was one that has come to interest all Americans.

The second annual convention, of the City Evangelization Union of the Methodist Episcopal Church began its sessions yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street. Over one hundred representatives and delegates from the various missionary and church extension societies throughout the country were present.

The politicians who are watching the lists of callers at 12 West Fifty-first Street, where Mr. Cleveland entertains those who call to congratulate him, and who speculate as to the meaning of all the visits, as if each was full of significance, were busier than usual yesterday.

The dispatch of the Alliance to Apia may give strength to the recent rumor that some changes in the tripartite agreement for the government of Samoa are contemplated. The Alliance was sent to Honolulu some time ago to relieve the Boston, but Hawaiian, affairs were so threatening that both vessels were retained there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The navy yards are gradually falling to pieces, according to the showing made by Commodore N.H. Farquhar, Chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy. The yards and stations have been kept in as good condition as the limited appropriations would permit, but the deterioration has been so great that the repairs do not keep pace with it.

The conference of the State Boards of Commissioners for Promoting Uniformity of Law in the United States came to an end yesterday at the rooms of the Bar Association, on East Twenty-ninth Street. As soon as the report of the conference is completed it will be submitted for action to the Legislatures of the different States represented at the meeting.

Great Britain is so situated commercially that the interruption of the movement of shipping by rigid quarantine regulations is a very serious matter, a fact which has led to a pretty thorough study of the best means of dealing with infectious diseases of foreign origin. One result has been the reduction of quarantine to the simplest form, while special attention is given to the sanitary condition of seaports and of cities and towns.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Last Friday Gov. Flower wrote to each of the three Civil Service Commissioners and demanded their resignations. The Commissioners are Alexander C. Eustace of Elmira, William A. Poste of New-York, and John A. Sleicher of Albany. The latter is the only Republican on the board. They were all appointed by Gov. Hill.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16 -- The big freshet in the Raritan River last night broke away the temporary Pennsylvania Railroad structure used for conveying material for its new bridge, and seventy-five feet of the temporary bridge at Albany Street were carried away. In consequence no one from this city or the country on the other side of the river can cross unless he goes two miles above what is called the "landing bridge."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- The New-Jersey Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows was in session today at the Masonic Temple here. All the lodges in the jurisdiction were represented. James W. Trenohard, the Grand Master, presided.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Nov. 16 -- P.M. The bear leaders raided the stock market in the first hour to-day, but their success was very limited. Finding that long stock did not come out, they abandoned their tactics, and then speculation became exceedingly dull. The rainstorm did much toward lessening operations.

Grover Cleveland made no promises to Tammany Hall; he made none to Richard Croker; he made none to Edward Murphy, Jr.; he made none to William F. Sheehan; he made none to anybody, at the time of the dinner at which they and Messrs. Harrity, Whitney, Don M. Dickinson, and others were present, or at any other time.

MONTEREY, Mexico, Nov. 16 -- The particulars of one of the most remarkable and exciting railroad accidents that ever occurred in Mexico have reached here. The catastrophe occurred three days ago on the Mexico national Line, bat only meagre details of it were received here until to-day.

The Advisory Committee of the Theatre of Arts and Letters has decided to revise its determination not to permit the dramatic critics to view the "new plays, chiefly American." which it is proposed to produce the current season. The matter has been referred to a special committee, consisting of George Cary Eggleston, Richard Harding Davis, and Henry B. McDowell.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 -- The trial of Prof. Henry Preserved Smith before the Cincinnati Presbytery was continued this morning. The prosecution began with Dr. McKibben as the first speaker. He said there were two things to be settled: First, the sufficiency of the specifications to sustain the charges, and, secondly, whether the charges constituted an offense.

The trial of Assistant Engineer Danforth of the Philadelphia was resumed in the court-martial room of the Brooklyn Navy Yard at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Naval courts-martials are interesting from a spectacular point of view, but the proceedings of such bodies are distinguished by an absence of haste, or anything that is startling or unexpected.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16 -- "I order you all to leave the hall at once! Leave the hall! Do you hear ?"

Jacob M. Patterson and his friends of the County Executive Committee met at Grand Opera House Hall, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, and held an executive session that lasted about three hours. It was a solemn affair. The committee made an unsuccessful attempt to discover just where the recent political cyclone had left it.

The monthly shoot of the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club was held at Woodlawn Park, Long Island, yesterday. The club shoot is at 7 live birds, modified Hurlingham rules, for a diamond badge and extra prizes. "Jumbo" Murphy won the badge for the second time. He only had to kill 12 straight to win it. The second prize (the sixes) was divided. H. McLaughlin won the third, and the fourth was divided.

The publication yesterday of the terms of sale and specifications for the proposed rapid-transit railway had the effect of sending many inquiries to the rooms of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners, and many requests for the pamphlet issued by the Commissioners in which all these matters were fully set forth. By evening there had been a generous distribution of the pamphlet among persons interested in the project.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- There is a very remote chance that the orders of Commodore Skerrett of the Washington Navy Yard to command the Pacific station may be changed.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The rapid growth of the agitation among the tanning classes, and their demands for legislation which may palliate the depression in agriculture, has precipitated Government action in this direction. Among the Cabinet committees preparing measures for next session of Parliament the latest appointed is that on agrarian bills.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Carlisle, who leaves to-night for Chicago, talked to-day about the proposition for an extra session of the Fifty-third Congress. He could not say that one would be held. All would depend upon circumstances. He was inclined to believe that if an extra session were called it would be to meet late in the Fall.

The College of Pharmacy, now at 209 East Twenty-third Street, has for some time been contemplating moving to an up-town location, for it has outgrown its quarters. It has secured a plot of ground 75 by 100 feet on Sixty-eighth Street, between Ninth Avenue and the Boulevard, and will erect a handsome and suitable building on it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The victory of the Democratic Party in the State surprised nobody so much as it did Judge Lambert Tree, formerly Minister to Belgium; William C. Goudy, who has posed for years as the leader of the party in this State, and Carter H. Harrison.

We suppose that Mr. REID and Mr. DEPEW may fairly be called "leading" Republicans of this State. It is true that in the natural stagnation of their party at the present moment, leadership, if not a sinecure, is a somewhat vague function. But when the party was in motion, and these gentlemen thought that they knew whither it was going, they essayed to lead it and were allowed to do so.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The appeal of Mrs. Deacon from the decision of the Tribunal of the Seine, declaring that the had no right to apply for a divorce from her husband and awarding the custody of the children to Mr. Deacon, came up to-day in the First Chamber of the Court of Appeal. Judge Perivier presided. Mr. Deacon was present, but Mrs. Deacon did not appear.

Audiences at the Amberg Theatre were not up to the usual mark on Monday and Tuesday, though Lachende Gesichter is a taking name and the public is supposed to like a hash of farces and operettas on the same principle that the public is supposed to adore a pot-pourri of favorite airs from the band.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Loading Democrats of the District of Columbia have already taken the preliminary stops toward arranging the ceremonies attendant upon the inauguration of Mr. Cleveland. These ceremonies, with the exception of that part of the programme during which the President-elect is in the Capitol Building, have for many years been entirely arranged by a committee of the citizens of the district.

The body of John Hoey was lying in state yesterday afternoon in the borne of Father Ducey, pastor of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church. The heavy oak casket stood upon pedestals in the darkened room, with lights burning at head and foot, and was strewn with flowers, while about the room were many large floral pieces which had been sent by friends of the dead man.

The annual conference of the Roman Catholic Archbishops of the United States held its first session yesterday at the home of Archbishop Corrigan, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Cardinal Gibbons presided and Archbishop Katzer of Milwaukee acted as Secretary.

Secretary Elmer M. Billings of the Mercantile Safe Deposit Company had a lively time yesterday explaining his connection with the alleged Countess de Bettincourt, otherwise known as Mrs. Anita McMurrow, who was held in $1,000 bail by Magistrate Durham in Philadelphia Tuesday on the charge of conspiring to defraud Druggist William G. Toplis of Germantown out of $2,500.

Commodore Henry Erben, commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, said yesterday that the cruisers Atlanta and Philadelphia were now ready for sea and could leave the yard almost any day. The repair work on the Philadelphi he said, was mostly upon the lead of the ammunition supply tubes.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16 -- The General Assembly of the Knights of Labor met in secret session this forenoon, with General Master Workman Powderly in the chair. After consuming about an hour in finishing preliminary work, Mr. Powderly delivered his annual address, in the course of which he said:

William H. Clark, Counsel to the Corporation, yesterday sent his opinion to the Secretary of the Columbus Celebration Committee of One Hundred as to the obligation of the committee to indemnify the city for the bonds which the city issued to aid in paying the expenses of the celebration. Mr. Clark agrees with Controller Myers that the city should be paid in full.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17 -- The Supreme Court to-day, on the application of an elector of Fayette County, allowed an alternative writ of mandamus, returnable Monday, Nov. 21, at 10 A.M., to compel the County Board of Deputy Supervisors of Elections to complete and certify the abstract of votes cast in that county to the Secretary of State.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Gwyneth Maude, the handsome eighteen-year old girl who was arrested on the charge of swindling Spink Son, the jewelers of 2 Gracechurch Street, out of silver salvers and candelabra, was brought up on remand in the Marlborough Street Police Court to-day. A few minutes before the cage was called the court was informed that the girl's mother had committed suicide this morning.

The old saying that brevity is the soul of wit was appreciated last night at the meeting of the Republican County Committee, held in Grand Opera House Hall. The business that necessarily came before the meeting was disposed of as quickly as possible, and then the committee adjourned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The President to-day appointed Lewis E. McComas of Maryland to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, vice Montgomery, resigned.

Brooklyn is to see a sweeping change of ownership in some of its street-car lines. It was made known yesterday that new interests had secured control of one of the big combinations of surface railways, while gossip was afloat to the effect that the other was being negotiated for.

The Cabinet makers were busy yesterday constructing a Cabinet for Mr. Cleveland, and while there were few new names mentioned, the presence in the city of numerous gentlemen who had been heretofore mentioned and the added fact that they called at 12 West Fifty-first Street to pay their respects to Mr. Cleveland kept the slatemakers in the hotel corridors busy.

LONDON, Nov. 17.--The India Currency Committee, which, it was supposed, was expediting its decisions with the view of influencing the International Monetary Conference, which meets in Brussels on Tuesday next, adjourned to-day until the conference is over. This unexpected step is attributed to a design of the committee to assist the British delegates to the conference in evading a discussion on the position of the currency in India.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Early this morning a storm of rain, snow, and sleet encountered the warm-air currents of "Egypt" and developed three distinct cyclonic storm centres, diverging from a common centre near Red Bud.

If any further illustration was needed of the entire disreputableness of John I. Davenport and his methods, the examination of Capt. Michael Whalen before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday more than supplied what was lacking. The arrest of Whalen was proved yesterday the moat malicious and flagrant of all of Davenport's abuses of Federal authority this year.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- The Wesleyan football players returned from Providence this morning in excellent physical trim, but in very bad temper. They say they could have stood a square defeat at the hands of the Brown team, but they are unsparing in their criticism of Mr. Arnold, the Brown referee. There were no cross lines on the field, and the referee used his own judgment in meas urine distances.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 17 -- On the 12th of last September David Robinson, an old resident of Trinidad, and a man possessed of much wealth, died at the Grand Central Hotel in this city. No heirs to his estate made themselves known for some time after his death. It is now asserted that an attempt has been made to forge a will and divert his estate from its proper course.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- State Dairy Commissioner George McGuire, Prof. J.H. Leeds, State Chemist, and Leon Abbett, Jr., counsel for the State Dairy Commissioner, have begun a movement to improve the supply of milk that comes from the stables and sheds in and around Jersey City, Newark, Paterson, Trenton, and Camden.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 17 -- Sir John Thompson, Minister or Justice, and the Hon. Mackenzie Dowell, Minister of Militia, returned to-night from Halifax, where they were attending the conference with the Newfoundland delegates upon trade and other matters. They anticipate that important results will be accomplished.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17 -- The leaders of the anti-Cleveland wing of the Indiana Democracy held a conference here yesterday with Senator Voorhees and ex-Gov. Gray. The Indianapolis News says that nearly all the prominent Democrats who opposed Mr. Cleveland at Chicago took part in the conference, and that the object was to organize to control the patronage of the State.

After Justice Grady had disposed of his ordinary criminal business yesterday morning, a hearing was held in his little back room in the Tombs. The immediate cause of this slight variation in the usual procedure was furnished by the case of Count di Mitkiewicz, the manipulator of Chinese railway concessions, who is charged by Arthur Lloyd Tomes of Brooklyn with having secured various sums of money from him under false pretenses.

Whatever else may be done at the ap- proaching session of Congress, there is one duty before the House of Representatives of the most urgent and imperative nature. It is the ascertainment and publication of the actual condition of the national finances. This duty falls upon the House at this session with especial force.

It is possible that the Republican politicians of the State of Connecticut may learn from the result of the recent election that it does not pay to steal public offices. Gov. BULEELEY will have held his office for a full term, for which he was not elected and for which he was not even nominated, but when he leaves it he will be politically dead.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 17 -- There has been laid before the Government a petition for the extension of the period for the free entry of corn now on route. The Government has decided the matter unfavorably to the petitioners on the ground that shipments of grain of the new Mexican crop have already been made, and, the Government believes, the supply under present conditions will be sufficient.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- On Oct. 26 last Mr. Labouchere, in Truth, published an article exposing the fraudulent character of the business carried on by an alleged dealer in patents named Wells, who is identical with the man Wells who a short time ago gained world-wide notoriety through reports of heavy winnings made by him at the Casino at Monte Carlo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Chicago millionaire beef packer, G.F. Swift, is to be tried in a United States court. There are cases pending in the Chicago district against Swift and the various members and agents of his firm for violations of the inter-State commerce law, and word has come from the United States District Attorneys office in Chicago that the trial will be begun within a week or ten days.

The Amberg Theatre, in Irving Place, has lost two of its actresses -- Miss Willie Walden, the leading soubrette, and Miss Freda Dahlen, her sister, who was one of the chorus girls -- and Emil Thomas, the German comedian end the manager who brought them out from Germany, is mourning the loss of some $400 or $500 which he advanced them.

The steamship Philadelphia of the Red D Line, from La Guayra, Venezuela, arrived at Quarantine last night. She sailed from La Guayra without clearance papers, and her action is liable to be the subject of international complications between this country and the new Government of Crespo.

The law requiring candidates for office in this State to file itemized statements of the expenses incurred by them in aid of their election cannot be said thus to have served the purpose intended. It is little more than a formality, serving no other end than to gratify curiosity as to the amount of money contributed by candidates for election expenses.

BED BUD, Ill., Nov. 17 -- At 3:30 this morning a cyclone swept over this place destroying thirty-five houses, killing one boy, and injuring many other persons. Two churches, the Town Hall and jail, and the newspaper office were among the buildings leveled. The wind wave came in the midst of a driving rainstorm, and it was daylight before the full extent of the catastrophe was known or the injured could be given attention.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The trial of Andrew George MacRae for the murder of Annie Pritchard began to-day before the Northampton Assizos. After the court was opened and the jury were in their seats, the Public Prosecutor said that the evidence upon which the Government relied to prove its case was wholly circumstantial.

The trial of Assistant Engineer George W. Danforth of the United States Navy, charged with disobeying the lawful orders of his, superior-officer, was resumed in the court-martial room or the Brooklyn Navy Yard at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The trial was concluded with a statement made by the accused officer, who was allowed to testify in his own behalf.

HARTFORD, Nov. 17 -- An analysis of the new General Assembly shows that the Democrats have re-elected thirty-seven members of the dead-lock Legislature, while the Republicans have returned only twenty-two. In the Senate nine members were returned by the Democrats from 1891. The Republicans were not able to re-elect a Senator who was identified with the dead-lock.

It seems safe to say that the Horse Show would be much more useful if it were not so popular. It is popular, evidently, because it is fashionable, and the show is a proof that the two words mean very different things. A small number of people go to see each other and incidentally the horses, and a much larger number of people go to see this small number of people.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. Deacon has hitherto steadfastly refused to give her side of the case, but to-day her friends made what appears to be an authoritative statement in her defense. According to this statement, Mr. Deacon has treated his wife, since the first weeks of their marriage, with brutality, which, Mrs. Deacon eays, she endured, hoping by forbearance to subdue a temper that at times bordered upon insanity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17 -- The Executive Committee of the Ohio League of Republican Clubs met here to-day and received condolences in sufficient quantity to convince the members that the party is only suffering from partial paralysis. It was decided to hold the annual league banquet on Feb. 14 in this city, as the 12th, the anniversary of Lincoln's birth, falls on Sunday.

A notable event in the social world yesterday of equal interest in Philadelphia and in this city was the marriage of Miss Katherine Drexel of this city to Dr. Charles Bingham Penrose of Philadelphia. The bride is the daughter of Mrs Joseph Drexel of 103 Madison Avenue. The groom is of an old and leading Philadelphia family.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Disaster attended the last practice of the Yale football eleven to-day, previous to its departure for Springfield for the annual game with Harvard. All the members of the 'Varsity side were in their places and Capt. McCormick gave directions that the play would consist of just half an hour's brisk work, the last the men would participate in this year.

Loungers in Twenty-eighth Street near Broadway and in Broadway near Twenty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon noticed with some curiosity a young man, whose whole air was decidedly theatrical, walking up and down the street and every now and then entering a barroom, in which he would stay for some time. The young fellow had his hands bandaged so that he was unable to use them, and this provoted numerous inquiries from every one who met him.

A much larger attendance marked yesterday's session of the second annual convention of the City Evangelization Union of the Methodist Episcopal Church than had been present on Wednesday at the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church. Among the visitors were many ladies and several deaconesses of the Church.

Yesterday's session closed the ninth annual meeting of the New-York State Medical Association. The attendance was somewhat larger than on previous days, and the papers road were received with hearty applause. At the morning session the following physicians were elected officers of the association and members of the Council for 1893:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- The reunion of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee came to a close to-night with a banquet at the Lindell Hotel. Over 200 people were seated at the table, the gentlemen of the party being almost entirely composed of ex-officers of the Army of the Tennessee.

We have looked through the pages of the Protective Tariff League's weekly paper, the American Economist, for Nov. 11, expecting to find some comments upon the recent election. The league publishes an account of the distribution of 184,694,819 pages of "tariff literature in the campaign just closed."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Democratic patriots who are already anxious to serve their country abroad under Mr. Cleveland and who ore preparing their applications while there is yet no rush upon the State Department, will do well to scrutinize very carefully the hastily-prepared guiding paragraphs that are published for the information of the eager.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- One more day remains for the candidates at the last election to file their expense accounts. All of the Democratic Electors have made returns, the last certificate received being that of William Steinway. He gave $500 to the Democratic State Committee.
The members of the New-York Presbyterian, Church at Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-eights Street have extended a unanimous call to the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Robinson to become their pastor.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 -- Dr. Fowe's argument on behalf of the Prosecuting Committee at the Smith trial occupied a large part of the afternoon session. Prof. Smith made frequent objection to Dr. Lowe's statements in what seemed to him to be defense of the doctrines and practice of his Church.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Hog receipts were 7,000 head less than expected and there was active competition among shippers for the best lots. One of the results of this was to induce covering in the speculative market by packers who had product sold for January and who saw little chance for manufacturing the stuff at a profit, considering the present price of hogs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- Geraldine, the champion sprinting race mare, who holds the half-mile record in 0:48 and six and a half furlongs in 1:19 3/4, has been sold to L.H. Williams, the proprietor of the Undine Stables. The price paid is not stated.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 17.--It was said this evening that Bishop Wigger of the Catholic Diocese of Newark has sent a letter to Father Corrigan of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Grace in Hoboken suspending him pending an inquiry. The Bishop declined to speak on the subject, saying it was a private matter that concerns the authorities of the Church alone.

At the Cosmos Club last night Prof. James Mooney read an interesting paper before the Anthropological Society upon the biographic nomenclature of the Potomac River. The Indians of this region were a part of the Pow hatan Confederacy, winch claimed all of tidewater Virginia and both shores of the Chesapeake nearly to the entrance of the Suiquehanna.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The advocates of a session of the Fifty-third Congress to be held immediately after the inauguration of the President are supporting their demand for such a session to amend the tariff laws by the argument that the menace of a deficit in the Treasury will also have to be met and considered. The two suggestions together ought at once to indicate objections to a session immediately following the inauguration.

On Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday next the first great sale of American and other furs for the season will take place in London. Dealers in fur and fur manufacturers in this country are looking forward to the event, and will anxiously watch the sales, as they will fix the wholesale prices of furs in this country for the remainder of the year at least, and perhaps for the entire Winter.

We are always hearing that there is much we can learn from the Chinese. Co-operation, however, is one of those things which few of us would hare expected to find among the number; but they can tell as something about this, for they apply it in the most elaborate and ingenious way to many things that elsewhere are done by individual effort.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The last public football practice of the year was held to-day on the Shiver City field, and over 1,000 spectators took advantage of the privilege, and went away when the game was finished feeling more encouraged for the Thanksgiving game than at any time this year. The Varsity gave the best exhibition of football of the season both in defensive and aggressive play.

Ever since the inter-State commerce law went into effect, fire years ago last Spring, prominent railroad men have from time to time expressed their disapproval of the prohibition of pooling contracts. They have maintained that each contracts, or something like them, were necessary to the maintenance of remunerative rates upon through traffic for which several different lines were competing, and to anything like uniformity or stability in freight charges.

That the beneficiaries of the Panama Canal swindle have continued to exert great influence in France since the downfall of the company is shown by the curious delay of the legal proceedings against the Directors of the company and the treatment of the evidence in the French Cabinet a few days ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- In the Pinkerton investigation to-day Senators Peffer and Gallinger quostioned Capt P. Foley, a Chicago Pinkerton official. The Captain was asked whether the Pinkerton agency had a stock of arms. He replied that it had 400 rifles and 2,000 revolvers, but the men had strict orders not to use arms except to defend themselves.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The will of Samuel Pratt King has been filed for probate. Samuel King was one of two prodigal sons, whose father's mansion is now the home of the exclusive Buffalo Club, which, with much other property, amounting to hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars, was left to the three children several years ago, when the boys, Sam and Will, were just coming of age.

There is a very heated discussion going on in various parts of the country among Republicans and in the Republican press, more or loss benevolently aided, of course, by the Democrats, as to who brought about the astonishing defeat of the Republican Party last week. Some of the ardent friends of Mr. BLAINE insist that it was caused by the "ostracizing" of Blaine Republicans.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- For the post thirty-six hours not a click has been beard from the telegraph instruments connecting Chicago with the great Northwest. All that section having St. Paul and Minneapolis as a centre has been practically isolated.
Glass "bangles," according to Mr. C.J. Halllax's interesting monograph on Indian industries, are something very much more important than mere ornaments for the wrists and ankles of Indian women.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The debate on the Press bill was continued in the Chamber of Deputies today. The discussion lasted five hours.
John Decker, the last Chief of the old New-York Volunteer Fire Department, died at 12:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his home 16 Vreeland Street, Port Richmond, S.I.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 18 -- A few weeks ago a young man named Coburn reported at Police Headquarters that his wife had mysteriously disappeared. She had left their lodgings, at Thirtieth and Champa Streets, the previous evening after 10 o'clock to go to the Post Office to mail a letter and had not returned.

The naval court-martial case of Assistant Engineer Danforth, who is on trial before a conrt consisting of nine of his brother officers for alleged "disobedience of the lawful orders of his superior officer," attained its chief interest yesterday when the case was summed up by Mr. W.H. Stayton, the counsel for the defense.
Stephen H. Herriman died at his home, 143 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, a little before midnight on Thursday, after a short illness. His death was caused by a complication of heart and kidney troubles.

Dr. G.W. Teschner of 60 Rivington Street and Dr. I.M. Rottenberg of 280 Second Street, well-known physicians of the east side, may be called upon to answer the serious charge of perjury, if their plea of ignorance of the law is not accepted in extenuation of what they have done.

CHESTER, Ill., Nov. 18 -- The cyclone which did so much damage at Bed Bud destroyed considerable property here. The storm blew down a large tree upon the house of Harman Otteng at New-Palestine, six miles north of here, and crashed it. killing Mrs. Otteng and two children. A great deal of damage was done to barns, orchards, and fences.

Chairman William P. Harrity of the Democratic National Committee said good-bye to the National Headquarters at 139 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, shook hands warmly with Col. John Tracey, who had charge of the Press Bureau, exchanged compliments with genial Sergeant at Arms James Oliver, and left the building to catch a train for Philadelphia.

The conference of Roman Catholic Archbishops, which has been in session here for three days, has completed the only piece of work it had to do that is of great public importance. That work was to define the attitude of the Church toward public education. Everybody knows that there have been in the Church wide differences of opinion upon this question.

The following letter from the officers of the Tilden Trust directed to the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York and dated "Office of the Tilden Trust, 15 Grammeroy Park, Nov. 14, 1892," was read at yes- terday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment:
The ancient disagreement between William W. Kent, formerly of the firm of Heins La Farge, architects, has been settled. Heins La Farge yesterday gave out the following statement for publication:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 18 -- It is widely believed in this city that should the Presbytery of Cincinnati find the Rev. Henry P. Smith guilty of heresy and silence him as a minister, Lane Theological Seminary would continue to retain him in his position as Professor of Hebrew in the institution. This belief is founded on the private utterances or men who have a voice in the control of the seminary.

NEW-OKI.KASS, Nov. 18.-The Cotton Exchange this morning published a strong- letter directed against the insurance compact and making vigorous protest against the rate to which the insurance on cotton in press had been advanced, and protesting against the idea of in- stituting a still further advance.

The biggest wildcat killed in the State for years was shot at Lantern Hill, near Norwich, by Ira Main on Monday afternoon. The animal was really a Canadian Bay lynx, 3 feet tall and 4, feet long. Its fur was thick and beautifully mottled. Its face, almost as large as a man's, wore a ferocious look in death, and its paws and claws were almost as large as those of a panther.

Detectives Holland and Reap of the Central Office pleasesd Inspector McLaughlin yesterday with the sight of one of the shrewdest swindlers who ever fell into the hands of justice. The swindler, who had come in the company of the two detectives all the way from San Antonio, Texas, to Police Headquarters here, is a dapper little fellow, about thirty years of age.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- The Wesleyan team played in a pouring rain, this afternoon, but put up the best aggressive game seen here this Fall. The same quartet of coaches looked after the work of the men as during the last few days, "Billy " Bull, Seward Coffin, George Manchester, and Jordan Wells. They succeeded in getting quick, sharp playing out of both the Varsity and the college side.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 18 -- The annual convention of the National Farmers' Alliance and Industrial Union adjourned last night at midnight after a ballot had been ordered for the election of a President, and with the name of only one candidate -- H.L. Louoks -- before the organization. The adjournment was made necessary on account of the confusion which prevailed.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 18 -- The celebration in Baltimore the other day of the one hundred and eighteenth anniversary of the burning of the Peggy Stewart brings to mind one of the most courageous and patriotic episodes of the anterevolutionary period.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Interest centred in the provision market from the opening, and professionals from all the other pits were gathered there to watch operations. Receipts of hogs, according to the first reports from the yards, were 6,000 higher the estimate, with prices 10@15c higher. Shorts in all lines of product had been getting nervous during the last ten days, and have only been hoping for larger receipts to help them out.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The Elizabeth police at midnight last night surprised in a barn on the outskirts of this city Sebastian Siatterer, the ex-convict who assaulted and robbed Mrs. C.C. Fitzgerald or 613 Madison Avenue, on Nov. 7, in her house, where he was employed as a servant. He escaped with $1,000 worth of diamond earrings and rings.
The reports of the United States naval engineer officers on duty in Boston indicate that the new cruiser Marblehead is likely to be ready for trial even ahead of the Detroit and Montgomery.

RED BUD, Ill., Nov. 18 -- The descent of yesterday's terrible crclone was made two miles south of Rose Bud. When the storm reached the town it first destroyed the two-story residence of Col. B.W. Sharp, and then utterly wrecked the Catholic Church and school, leaving the two-story rectory between them, and higher than either of them, intact.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 18 -- In a drenching rain and a gale that sent hats and umbrellas whirling into the air, the Amherst football team to-day do feated Williams by the phenomenal score of 60 to 0, and won the championship of the New-England Intercollegiate Football Association. Few thought before the game that Williams stood any show of winning, and the result was a surprise to the most sanguine of Amherst's supporters.

The New-York Association for improving the Condition of the Poor has sent out a Thanksgiving appeal to its patrons, which, earnestly requests generous donations in view of the splendid work accomplished in the year which ended Sept. 30, 1892.

The General Term of the Supreme Court administered a severe shook yesterday to William H. Beers, the ex-President of the New-York Life Insurance Company, in the shape of a decision in the case submitted to it as to his right to draw from the company the $37,500 pension which was voted him when he was finally forced from the Presidency by the persistent efforts of THE TIMES.
The conclave of the Archbishops of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States held its last executive session yesterday at the house of Archbishop Corrigan, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

There was a curious wedding at Sherry's last evening when Miss Priscilla Van Der Hoven, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Der Hoven, became the wife of Sir Arthur Cortwright. In spite of the rainy weather a large number of well-known ladies and gentlemen made personal responses to the invitations issued and willingly paid 50 cents admission to witness the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The people about the State and Navy Departments to-day read with interest the account in THE TIMES or the arrival at New-York of the Red D Line steamer Philadelphia, with Gen. Mijares, ex-Governor of Caracas, on board.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 18 -- J.R. Dodge, representing the Department of Agriculture, addressed the National Grange this morning. He recognized the Grange as one or the legitimate children of the Department of Agriculture, claiming that its inception, its organization and first work had been largely due to the inspiration and efforts of the Department officers, three or the seven founders of the order being in that department.

"Society," arrayed in all its glory, was out once more at the horse show last evening, and there was a big crowd on hand to look at society's representatives and their good clothes. The crowd was not so great as it was on Friday night a year ago, as the threatening weather, coupled with the stiff price that the speculators put on the tickets for the evening, kept many people away from the Garden.

At the dinner given by Mr. Henry Villard to President-elect Cleveland and some of his personal and political friends at Sherry's on Thursday evening. Mr. Cleveland responded, when his health was proposed, in the following brief speech:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Capt. Meeker, the Marine Corps officer who was sentenced to a year's suspension by Admiral Walker's courtmartial, is expected, at the Navy Department to-morrow. He has given notice to the department that he leaves New-York to-night. He will bring with him the appeal which he is to make to the Secretary from the decision of the Admiral in ordering his trial after he had already been publicly censured.

The information that we are to have an early, a long, and a cold Winter may not be thoroughly trust-worthy, but it has been spread by somebody with great industry, and it is believed by a large number of people throughout the country. Perhaps the docile chipmunk has stored away more hickory nuts than usual, or that legal song bird, the robin, taken on an unwonted thickness of down.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the New-York Times. LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The circumstances by which France yesterday escaped a Ministerial collapse prompt one to the feeling that French politics belong under the heading of "dramatic canserie" instead of a chronicle of serious events. The Chamber of Deputies was never-more of a playhouse than yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- English newspapers, as a rule, are not given to unstinted praise of "play actors," but in the case of Mr. Henry Irving the rule has been reversed, and nothing too good can be said of his performance of "King Lear." This laudation of the great English actor has aroused a certain degree of protest.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19. -- During the last few days it has been currently reported in this city that if Prof. Henry Preserved Smith should be convicted of heresy by the Cincinnati Presbytery, and silenced as a minister, he would join some other religious denomination.

The social horizon was, as had been predicted, almost entirely bounded last week by the Horse Show, which closed last night and allowed thousands of thoroughly-wearied men and women to repair homeward for a necessary rest of some days. The show was a remarkable proof of how much Dame Fashion can accomplish when she presses any particular button and lets society "do the rest."

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- The Theatre Libre has given us the first programme or its seventh season, for it was in March, 1887, that Andre Antoine organized his representations at the Elysee des Beaux Arts. Daring those seven seasons -- not years -- he has given hospitality to unknown talent of every school. He has made Known to the public a great many names, and among these he has introduced to celebrity Messrs.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 19 -- The Picayune's cable special from Havana say a: "Much-needed rain has fallen within the last few days and the country generally is looking fine, with prospects of good crops of all kinds of vegetables, such as onions, potatoes, tomatoes, okra, and cucumbers, which are shipped in great abundance to New-York in the early months of the year, where they find ready sale at good prices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The attention of the Right Rev. John J. Keane, Rector of the Catholic University of America, was to-day called to the statement sent out from New-York last night concerning an alleged discussion by the conference of Catholic Archbishops in New-York yesterday of the condition of the Catholic university in this city.

A foreigner who visited the World's Fair when the buildings were sufficiently finished to indicate the uncommon grandeur and beauty of their plan remarked: "This is what we expected to find in Paris at the Universal Exposition; the buildings there were such as we might expect from Chicago." This speech has found great favor since it was made because it contains a great compliment.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 19 -- Yesterday the body of the widow of the late Capt. John Wilson was laid to rest beside the remains of her gallant husband, in Girod Street Cemetery.

THE STRATEGIC VALUE OF EGYPT.--To the trained military eye Egypt presents itself as the eastern bastion of the ill-shaped African continent--a bastion naturally strong and capable of resisting attack, whose broad moats are the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, together with the dry moat of the desert.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 19. -- There is much interest in Pittsburg over a telegram from New-York in regard to a legal electric fight affecting, it is claimed, at least $25,000,000 worth of property, which was begun in the United States Circuit Court yesterday before Judge E. Henry Lacombe.

Vernon H. Brown, the New-York manager of the Cunard Steamship Company, returned a few weeks ago from a visit to England. While abroad he made it a point to inspect the two mammoth Cunarders which are building for the company in the Fairfield Shipbuilding Yards on the Clyde. Mr. Brown is enthusiastic about the new additions to the Cunard fleet, and says that they will excel anything of their class now afloat.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 19. -- The naval cadets are in troubled waters. When Cadet A.L. Fairbrother of Rhode Island was tried for hazing, and the courtmartial closed its sessions, the cadets drew a long breath and thought all investigation of the hazing of Oct. 1 and 2 was over. Not so. Cadet Fairbrother was convicted by the court-martial and recommended for dismissal by the Superintendent.
The report of the Health Department of this city for the calendar year 1891, which has just been published in a hound volume, contains the following paragraph:

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 19 -- Alarmed at the strength shown by Mrs. Lease and the determination, shown by many of the Populists to make her United States Senator, if possible to control the Legislature, Senator Peffer and Congressman Simpson have given countenance to a scheme which has for its object the overthrow of ex-Senator Ingalls.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Did United States Express Messenger George T. Bagley steal $100,000? Is Bagley under arrest? Chief Detective John Shea of the Chicago police force, answers "Yes" to both questions. General Manager Shepard of the United States Express Company answers both Questions "No."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Now that the Rapid Transit Commissioners have issued the terms of sale and specification of construction for the underground railroad the opportunity is at last presented to capital to decide whether the road shall be built or not.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The news announcing the result or the Yale-Harvard game when received here to-night created no surprise whatever. Everybody expected Yale to win, and Princeton's sympathies were with the blue. When the news was received, cheers were given for Yale. If Yale succeeds in winning tlio Thanksgiving Day game, Princeton will not consider herself vanquished by Harvard, as she would be compelled to do if Harvard had won the victory to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- The most valuable half dollar ever made in this country, and probably the most valuable coin in existence, the first of the new World's Fair souvenirs, was turned out at the United States Mint hero today, and delivered to James W. Elisworth, Chairman of the Committee on Liberal Arts of the World's Columbian Exposition.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The inaugural address of President Sohurman has been so widely quoted and, so far as it relates to the financial condition and history of the University, has been so generally misunderstood, that it may be well to give the whole situation in a nutshell, if possible. Cornell is a State institution, but receives nothing, and never has received anything, directly from the State.

The market movement the past week has been within very narrow limits, but the close yesterday was strong, on a favorable bank statement, and the weaker tone of foreign exchange. The rise in the fates of exchange had caused much uneasiness. It was rumored on Thursday that there would be shipments of gold on Saturday, and the stock market was quite depressed by the reports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The details of construction of armored cruiser No. 3 and battle ship No. 1, for which the Secretary of the Navy has just invited bids, have been completed. The description of the machinery of these ships has been published in the Washington dispatches of THE TIMES. The hull and ordnance plans are interesting.

IN THE SHAH'S TREASURY. -- Perhaps the objects in this bizarre collection that most attract the stranger are the infinity of gems cut, uncut, or set in every variety of fashion seen behind the glass panels. Here are the enameled and bejeweled arms of the great Sefavi Kings; here the swords of Timur, Shah Ismail, and Agha Mohammed Shah; here the magnificent Abbas coat of mail.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 -- To judge from the numerous teas and evening entertainments this week, one would any that the Winter gayety had fairly begun without waiting for the germans, which hitherto have started the season. The chrysanthemum show at the Cyclorama has been well attended, and several box parties to see Mansfield, followed by suppers, have been the order of the evenings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences is very anxious to send another expedition to the north, and Mr. T.J. Wistar, the President of the academy, in a letter to Secretary Tracy, asking that leave for a term of three years be granted to Lieut Robert E. Peary to head the expedition, says:

The troubles which beset the managers of the Republican county organization, and which some predict will result in a complete overthrow of some of the present managers, are growing thicker every day. Complaints of bad management of the organization on election flay have been hoard on all sides, but until yesterday they were of a general nature, so far as the public is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $166,020,500, as follows: Currency sixes, $11,852,000; 4 per cents, $132,208,150; 2 per cents. $21,960,350.

The latest news in reference to the Long island Water Supply Company scheme to defraud Brooklyn taxpayers is undoubtedly the best that the public has had in a long time. The selection of a lawyer of the calibre of Edward M. Shepard is something upon which the taxpayers can congratulate themselves.

Cashier Theodore M. Banta of the New-York Life Insurance Company is well satisfied with the decision, of the General Term of the Supreme Court, which held that William H. Beers, ex-President of the company, was not entitled to the pension voted to him by the Trustees of the company. He feels this way about it because he believes that simple justice is done the policy-holders by this decision.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 19. -- Gilmore's Band will disband, after playing its Cincinnati engagement to-morrow night. The band played here last night and the box receipts were attached by the Galesburg Opera House for the failure to play at a matinee. The matter was compromised.

The application of the officers of the Tilden Trust to the Board of Estimate is one that concerns every taxpayer and every inhabitant of New-York. It is very desirable, in the interest of the city, that it shall be so acted upon as to increase the desirableness of New-York as a place of residence and to improve its position as a civilized capital.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 19. -- The competition for next year's Student board has become very spirited, although the election of the new men does not take place until the middle of March. One man will be elected from each of the three lower classes. The number at present competing is somewhat over thirty.

The drill season has come around once more, and the First Naval Battalion, numbering 300 officers and men, finds itself in the matter of accommodations for carrying on its drills in precisely the same position as it was three years ago, when it came into existence. Considering what the energetic and patriotic young men of this organization have accomplished under the direction of their competent and devoted officers, this is simply a shame.

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- Another sharp trick of the Republicans developed to-day. Chapter 681, which relates to public officers, amends the former law by placing Assemblymen among the State officers. Every State officer, under the same law, mast file an oath of office with the Secretary of State within fifteen days after election, his failure so to do making the office vacant.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Information gathered today snows that the telegraph system is demoralized. Throughout the Mississippi Valley, from St. Paul to St. Louis, along the Wabash line in Missouri, near Kansas City, a stretch of poles for fifty miles is down, and altogether there are over 100 miles of poles on the system down.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 19. -- A meeting of the newly-elected Executive Board of the National Farmers' Alliance this morning wound up the convention of the order which began here on the 15th inst. From the first, the third-party people of the North and West have carried things with a high hand.

Shall the nude be studied on Sunday? That is the latest phase of the Sabbath question which is being discussed by members of the Art Students' League of New-York. The topic has been brought Into prominence by the fact that the Board of Control has decided to throw open the studios and schools of the league seven days a week.

AFTER RARE BOOKS. -- It has been thought, or, rather, more correctly speaking, only fondly hoped, by the learned men throughout Christendom, that among the rubbishy chronicles of the Kairouin there would some day be found the missing classics, the lost books of Euclid and of Livy among others.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 19.--A cave-in occurred this forenoon at the Hazledell colliery at Centralia, operated by L. A. Riley Co., whereby eight men were imprisoned in the mine for some hours, and two others were quickly taken out very badly injured. This colliery is situated about two miles from Ashland, and is a very large concern, shipping its product over the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Representatives of the Atchison, Burlington, Rock Island. Colorado Midland, Rio Grande Western, and Denver and Rio Grande Roads, after a conference of nearly a week, have at last decided on a method of dealing with the Union Pacific on account of its refusal to divide business with them at Ogden and Denver instead of the Missouri River.

It is safe to say that after all that has been done to prepare the way for rapid transit in this city the plan submitted by the commission will be carried into effect either by private capital or by the municipality itself. The people will not allow all this valuable work to be thrown away. Several things must now be admitted as settled.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Leonard P. Beckwith of New-York will have a pleasant country home on the west shore of Mahkeonac Late. He owns about 1,000 acres and has a frontage on the lake for a long distance. The grounds about the cottage cover over 200 acres, and are being laid oat as a great park, something after the English fashion, with drives in all directions.

For the fourth time the little gallery of Fred erick Keppel Co. at 20 East Sixteenth Street is filled with American water colors of a bright, attractive sort. They are by artists of renown, and also by beginners whose names have scarcely been heard outside some art school. There are but eighty-nine of them in all, and they will be visible for one month, exactly, dating from to-day.

At the last Sunday morning service John Jacob Astor attended in Trinity Church he remarked to his son, William Waldort Astor, as he pointed to the doors about the edifice; "Those have ever been eyesores to me. I may never have them removed, but some time you can perhaps make a change which will tend to beautify the church."

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The London County Council will assail the landlord interest in Parliament through a bill levying a new tax on ground values throughout the metropolis, and also insuring that the tax shall not be shifted on the occupier of the laud by contract or otherwise.

One of the callers yesterday at 12 West Fiftyfirst Street, the home of Grover Cleveland, Was Carter H. Harrison, ex-Mayor of Chicago. Mr. Harrison came to the city on Friday, two days later than certain other Democrats from his State, among whom were Benjamin T. Cable and Editor Walsh of Chicago.

"I've done more lying about domestic after dinner coffee than any other subject under heaven," said the man at the club, as he carefully balanced his spoon on the edge of his demitasse, so that the half-inch cube of white sugar should just touch the surface of the coffee.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Nov. 19 -- The decision of the machine men and day laborers to return to work has put the people of the town in a happier frame of mind than at any time during the look-out, and the business men especially feel that the town will soon resume its former activity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19. -- The freshman football team is still working hard. On Saturday afternoon they beat the Agricultural College eleven from. Amberat by a score of 50 to 12. Wednesday the freshman won another victory, beating the Worcester Polytechnic Institute 22 to 6. This was the last practice game before the struggle with the Yale freshmen, Nov. 26.

Patriot J. Gleaaon, whose autocratic reign as Mayor of Long Island City was summarily ended by his outraged subjects on election day, made yesterday what, in the language of his opponents, is described as "his final dying kick."

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 19. -- "It is very curious that while the election has had a decided effect on the terrapin market and largely restricted the sales, there has been no decrease in the price, and there is no break in the rate of $60 a dozen," said the largest terrapin dealer in the country to THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day. "Most of our stock is from the Chesapeake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Harrison has made a rather significant recognition of good service by a Republican. He has appointed ex-Representative and Representative John H. Gear of Iowa to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in place of Crounse, resigned. Mr. Gear was a member of the Fifty-first Congress and of the Ways and Means Committee that made the McKinley bill.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Nov. 19 -- P.M. The stock market was intensely dull even for a Saturday. The industrials were the feature and in these the trading was light. Distilling and Cattle Feeding was the most active, but it moved between 66 3/8 and 66 3/4, closing unchanged at 66 1/2. Sugar gained 7/8 and Cordage 1.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19.--The annual Autmnal exhibition of the Orange Art Association, which has been in progress since Thursday, has been visited by hundreds of people. The exhibition includes oil paintings, water colors, and architectural designs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the line of your advocacy in to-day's TIMES of the proposed new rapid-transit system attention may be directed to a few of its merits which have perhaps not yet been much spoken of.

Only a very select few of the many who enjoy from the front of the house the artistic performances given at Daly's Theatre have ever been favored with a view of the "workshop" of the energetic manager of that famous playhouse. The rooms in which Mr. Daly works, and his surroundings while preparing for the productions which have given his theatre a world-wide reputation, are deep mysteries to the general public.

The Manhattan Club, the foremost Democratic social organization in the country, gave a brilliant reception to President-elect Grover Cleveland at its splendid clubhouse, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, last night.
