To the Editor or the New-York Times: I noticed in the columns of the newspapers of Friday that Barney Rourke claims the credit of having 2,555 scratched votes, which, he claims, shows the strength of the John J. O'Brien Association in the Third Assembly District.

The ecclesiastical disturbances in the Newark Catholic Diocese that have been revealed by the Rev. Father Corrigan's letters and by the incident at the meeting or the priests in Newark last week, are due to the fact that a German Bishop presides over a priesthood that is mainly Irish-American.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Just now Boston is showing two or three vigorous efforts to better the condition of society. A wave of popular protest broke out all at once against the improper theatrical poster, which in fact has much, offended the public eye of late. No former crusade against this evil has had so influential a backing.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 19. -- Very many of the thousands who to-day saw the game at Springfield know little of the tremendous amount of work and of study necessary to produce a champion football team. Few young men, not influenced by the college spirit, would care to undergo the vigorous training, the hard work, and the restraints to which the candidates for the Yale eleven submitted themselves.

Mr. Concert's speech had been frequently interrupted by applanse and cheers, but the response that was given to his toast was an ovation to the President-elect. Every man in the hall rose, raised his glass, and a call for three cheers for Mr. Cleveland was answered by three times three and a "tiger."

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Miss Hobble's unique love affair with Robert M. Toppin was aired in Judge Conlin'a police court last evening. Miss Hobble is the eighteen-year-old daughter of the Rev. Reeve Hobble of St. Philip's Episcopal Church, in High Street, in the Roseville section of Newark. Toppin is the nineteen-year-old, son of a Roseville real estate agent.

Copyrighted, 1892, by The Associated Press. BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- The Reichstag will open in Tuesday with the party groups in each a state of variance that is would be futile to attempt to predict how they will ultimately rearrange themselves.

"My Irish maid has come out in a new role, that of art critic," said a woman the other day. "I went into the parlor recently where she was dusting and found her standing in apparently rapt attention before an old print after Raphael's "Mars Going to Battle," showing the virile and stalwart god as charioteer of those splendid steeds that are seen only in the clouds.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 19. -- The blue of Yale again waves triumphantly above the crimson of Harvard, and every supporter of the New-Haven college, from the King of American football, Walter Camp, to the smallest boy who wants to be on the winning side when he grows up, is the possessor of joyful heart. Yale won her football game with Harvard by a score of 6 to 0.

Within the last week the annual rumor of a protected reorganization of the National Guard has come to the front -- this time from Brooklyn, and the easternmost section of that city, where the latest victim of disbandment, the Thirty-second Regiment, was quartered. The statement, as it is given out, possesses all the characteristics of a "bogie" story, and has as much foundation in fact, from all accounts.

THE JESUITS. -- The popular idea of the strength of the Society of Jesus, as a grand corporation waging ceaseless war with all modern ideas, and almost equal to that struggle, is an exaggeration born partly of a confusion between Jesuitism and Catholicism, and partly of the incurable fear felt by great numbers of any spiritual power which obvionsly moves.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The fair and loan exhibition to be held in Upper Music Hall, Nov. 29 and 30 and Dec. 1, for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital promises to be an interesting one. The committee having the loan exhibition in charge is actively engaged in securing antiques, articles of historic interest or artistic merit, furniture, laces, embroideries, manuscripts,

At the beginning of the week the vessels of the North Atlantic squadron are stationed as follows: The flagship Chicago is at the man-of-war anchorage in North River off West Twenty-sixth Street. The cruisers Philadelphia and Atlanta are at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh is at the same navy yard.

There was a runaway in Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon which caused great excitement in the neighborhood of Madison Square Garden. A boy was run over and killed and a coach and a cab were overturned.

Inspector McLaughlin and a squad of his detectives made a raid last evening on the premises 428 Sixth Avenue, on the third floor of which was found a fully-equipped and well-furnished establishment for the reception and disposal of stolen goods. The proprietor of the place was captured, as were also twelve thieves, including five women.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 19. -- Ever since Williams won the intercollegiate championship in the Fall of 1890 football has been the all-absorbing feature of athletics here. During the football season baseball, tennis, gymnastics, and field sports claim little or no interest. In fact, the interest in baseball daring its season seems feeble compared with that which football calls forth.

The report of the proceedings of the recent convention of the National League for Good Roads, held at Chicago, has just been published, and copies may be obtained at the headquarters of the temporary organization, 45 Broadway, from Gen. Roy Stone, Secretary of the league.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: One of the most interesting problems now engrossing the attention of the engineers of the City of Paris and of the towns along the Seine is the "Tout a l'Egout" ("All to the Sewer") problem. In former years the sewerage system of Paris only served to carry away the street dirt and sweepings.

The announcement of the finding of the genral court-martial in the case of Assistant Engineer George W. Danforth, United States Navy, is expected to be made public by the Secretary of the Navy during the coming week. The court-martial board completed is session on Friday night and immediately mailed to the Navy Department under cover of seal its finding and sentence.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Facts which have been gleaned from the college records show that previous to the Fall of 1887 Princeton held the Supermacy in her favorite sport -- football -- over any other American college. Since that year the tide has turned -- Yale has taken the lead.

The annual report of the New-York Free Circulating Library for 1892 shows that the expenses of the institution during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 were $27,708.33. All the departments of the library work show a large increase. The usefulness of the library has been greatly extended, and the whole condition improved.

More than 1,500 persons, including a large number of men who ordinarily on Sunday evenings can be found around the hotel cafes and in places where "sacred concerts" are given, went to Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre last evening to witness a Spiritualistic seance. It was a seance of the type which "old residents" remember as having mystified them in their youth.

Stupefying impudence is the chief characteristic of the proposition that EDWARD MURPHY, Jr., shall be elected to the Senate of the United States; and when it is added that this honor is decreed to MURPHY in recognition of his eminent services to Mr. CLEVELAND and the Democratic Party during the recent canvass, the public is affected to loud protest or shouts of laughter according to individual bent.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Nov. 20 -- Dr. W.H. Philio of this place lies at his residence suffering from severe injuries received at the hands of John P. Corning on Saturday evening. The attray is the sensation of thehour, especially as the alleged cause of it was Dr. Philio's attentions to Coming's wife.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- There is no fight between two factions of the Democratic Party in Illinois. The men who are trying to make trouble are not numerous enough or strong enough to be designated by the name of "faction." The party is to all intents and purposes harmonious.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20 -- The great strike at Carnegie's Homestead Steel Works has been declared off. After a flve-months struggle which for bitterness has never been equaled in this country, the strikers finally decided to-day to give up the fight.

Thanks giving Day will be celebrated by shoots all over the country, and every sportsman who does not go off after field gaine will be found at one or another of the trap grounds. In this section very few regular tournaments will be held the members of the various clubs preferring to spend the day by shooting go-as-you-please events on their own grounds.

One of the merriest parties that went over to Springfield, Mass., to see the big Yale-Harvard game was the Exceleior Club of Brooklyn. It was the fifth trip that the club has made to the great college contest, and if anything even more enjoyable than the former journeys. The party occupied Dr. Webb's private car Riva, and a sleeping car of the NewHaven Road.

Mrs. August Belmont died yesterday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock. An hour before death she became unconscious, and did not again rally. She passed away peacefully. At her bedside at her death was her son Perry Belmont, August Belmont, Jr., and wife, S.S. Howland and wife, Oliver H.P. Belmont, and Dr. Barrows. She was attended in her illness by Drs. Barrows, Polk, and Hanlen.

A large crowd was present Saturday evening at the games of the Twenty-third Regiment Athletic Association, held at the armory on Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, and saw the much-prized Point Cup for he company making the most points won by Company A with a total of 21 points. Company K was second, with 17 points.

We commend to the thoughtful attention of Gov. McKINLEY and many other prominent Republicans who profess a desire to make the fight again on the old lines the following-editorial remarks in the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, one of the most influential Republican newspapers in the country, and a journal that supported McKinleyism and the Republican ticket heartily during the recent campaign:
WILLIAM M. TWEED -- "F.J.R.": (1) How and when did William M. Tweed escape from this country? (2) Where and when was he caught and by whom? (3) Where and when did he die?

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 20 -- The steamboat Rosa Lee was turned to the water's edge at her wharf at 6 o'clock this morning. There were about thirty cabin passengers aboard. Among the number were three women. All these, with about forty deck passengers and the officers and crew, were saved.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The report of the Secretary of Agriculture has been submitted to the President.

The beautiful now edifice built by the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church at West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street was dedicated yesterday afternoon with simple but appropriate ceremonies. The group at buildings, comprising church and school, in quaint Flemish architecture, has already been described in THE TIMES.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- One assumption of the speculations that accord Gov. Abbett an easy triumph in his Senatorial struggle is that United States Senator John R. McPherson is to be invited into President Cleveland's new Cabinet, and that with both Blodgett's and McPherson's chairs to fill, the Legislature cannot gracefully decline to let the Governor have one.

A proposition is now under discussion which may result in the consolidation of the Asbury and Central Methodist Episcopal Churches. The Asbury Church is on the east side or Washington Square, at the corner of Washington Place, directly opposite the University Building. Before ground was broken for the University Building, what is now Asbury Church was standing as the old Dutch Reformed Church.

The closely-contested game of football between the Yale and Harvard teams on Saturday may not be decisive of the superiority of the winners. The time limit of the game had been almost reached before the first score was made, and it may be that another contest between the same teams would result differently.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 20.--There has been a campaign of education in progress in Kansas during the last two years that is startling to a man of conservative ideas. It first familiarized the popular mind with Socialistic ideas, and then cautiously paved the way in the prepared mental soil for the more dangerous ideas of the advanced leaders of that branch of society.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 20 -- W.H. Styles, the colored member of the Legislative Committee on Penitentiary, makes public a letter giving a deplorable account of the penitentiary system of the State, Speaking of the Dade Coal Mines, where over 1,000 convicts are employed, he says: "On entering, everything presented apparently a fine appearance, considering where prisoners are generally kept, but on examination we found that their condition was a sad sight to look upon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Yale is making ready for the Princeton Thanksgiving Day game. The eleven is in good condition despite the terrific pounding its youthful members received yesterday. Laurie Bliss strained his bad knee, and Butterworth and Wallia sustained slight cuts, but nothing of a permanent nature was suffered.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- Charles Reed, the comedian, is dead. Prostrated for a week past with an acute affection of the heart, friends feared that the bad turn of yesterday morning would prove fatal. The action of the heart grew weaker as the day wore on. In the early evening as he lay propped up by pillows, his face like marble, friends felt that the end was near.

Police officials are much elated over Inspector McLaughlin's raid of the big thieves' "fence" at 428 Sixth Avenue on Saturday night. The raid was the most successful made in this city in many years. The value of the property recovered is fully $5,000. Besides closing up the dangerous "fence" seventeen well-known shopllfters, pickpockets, and sneak thieves were landed behind the bars.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 20. -- "Assuredly the result of the election determines, without doubt, the fact that the masses of voters are not believers in extreme protection."

The Secretary of the Treasury, as announced in THE TIMES'S Washington dispatches Sunday, has ordered the United States revenue steamer Morrill, stationed at Charleston, S.O., to cruise on the Atlantic coast during the coming Winter between Absecom and Cape Hatteras. The Morrill will take up the duty heretofore performed by the United States revenue steamer Hamilton.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 20. -- Joseph Rosenthal is a thrifty Santa F6 banker and a member of the Legislature-elect from Haskell County. He is a Democrat, and will probably be the leader of his party on the floor, as he is the only member of it elected to the body. He was opposed to fusion and was elected by the aid of Republican votes.

The Jerry McAuley Water Street Mission was twenty years old yesterday, and the birthday services were shared in by a congregation that filled the little chapel. It was a season of song and of rejoicing over the good accomplished during these years, of glad testimony, and of earnest promise of continued good work in the future.
ABRAHAM LINCOLN. The True Story of a Great Life. By William H. Herndon and Jesse W. Welk. With an introduction by Horace White. Illustrated. In 2 vols., 12mo. New-York: D. Appleton Co.

The Board of Education's free-evening lectures for the course of 1892-93 have begun. In view of the fact that the attendance last year reached the enormous number of 125,000 persons. Dr. H.M. Leipziger, the expert in pedagogics in charge, has increased his corps of lecturers to forty. They will deliver plain talks, on topics of daily interest, illustrating them for the most part by stereopticon views or by experiments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Secretary Tracy has all the papers in the case of Capt. Meeker of the Marine Corps on his desk, and is giving the matter careful consideration, looking in to the points of law involved. Capt. Meeker was here yesterday and bad a long talk with Mr. Tracy, without getting from that official any intimation of the action that he proposed to take.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 21 -- A.M. The stock market was under bear pressure most of the week. Less talk, however, has been heard of coming disaster as a result of the Presidential election. The arguments used by those working for a lower level of prices have been the possibility of heavy gold exports and a revival of anti-option legislation at the coming session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Paymaster General Edwin Stewart, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, gives the following resume of the work of the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, with some pertinent recommendations:

The danger to the White Mountain forests is much greater than we stated in our article of the 13th. According to a statement made recently by Mr. HARRISON of the Forestry Commission of New-Hampshire in Boston before a private company of persons interested in preserving the forests of New-Hampshire, the final limit has been reached where the cutting off of these forests cannot be further carried on without serious results.

The Horse Show Association offered $35,000 in prizes for competition during last week's exhibition. The prizes in nearly all the classes were in money, a few, however, were in plate, and one was a Canadian-bred mare, given by W.D. Grand of Toronto, for the best Canadianbred jumper. This prize was valued at $300. Dr. W. Seward Webb won the largest amount of any exhibitor, and had the largest number of horses in the show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The President has remitted the unexecuted port of the sentence of six years' imprisonment, imposed May 26, 1891. In the case of James A. Slmmons of New-York, convicted of aiding and abetting the President of the Sixth National Bank of New-York City in embezzling, abstracting, and willfully misapplying the moneys of that bank.

The Eagle has followed its demonstration of Grover Cleveland's freedom from any pledges to any man, any men, or any organizations of the party, in so far as a monopoly of the patronige ia concerned, with a frank and full discussion of the question of the next United States Senatorship from this State. The latter discussion may now be said to be under way.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 21 -- The Nebraska Legislature contains thirty-three Senators and 100 Representatives. The Republicans have fifteen Senators and forty-seven members of the House, lacking five of a majority on joint ballot. An effort is being made to unseat three or four, Populists, but it will fail. It is doubtful whether all the Democrats, or even all the Populists, can be induced to unite against the Republicans.

Not since the time of the famous raid in the Tenderiein Precinct last Spring have so many cabs been sean about the Jefferson Market Police Court us stood there in the rain yesterday afternoon. This time, however, no ladies were present to lighten the gloom of the criminal proceedings, which proceeded relentlessly within those frowning walls, where Mr. justice Andrew J. White sat upon the bench.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 21 -- The stockholders in the new Crescent City Athletic Club are this morning discussing the matter of purchasing the handsome Litchford residence, at the corner of Bampart and Custom House Streets, for $24,000. The property is one of the handsomest sites and the most convenient in the city, being only one square from Canal Street, and covers 120 feet on Rampart Street by 125 on Custom House Street.

Immediately after the election it was announced from Washington that certain plans that had been considered by Mr. HARRISON for extending the rules governing the civil service under the act of 1883 had been abandoned. It was also said that this was done by the President from motives of delicacy, it being his desire not to restrict his successor as to any "patronage" now at the disposal of the Executive.

Two men, whose clothes were covered with blood, entered the Lower Fulton Street Station House, Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning and reported that there was a dead man on the tugboat R.S. Carter, lying at the foot of Adams Street. The informers were Frederick Johnson, aged thirty-four years, a tugboat fireman, and William Bradley, a trackman.

The action brought by the Board of Health of Islip, L.I., against Health Officer Jenkins and Gov. Flower to restrain them from establishing an annex quarantine station at Fire Island came up for argument before Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Special Term, Brooklyn, yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- After two days of wordy conflict between the Yale students and the football manager, the matter of the disposal of Yale's seats for the Yale-Princeton Thanksgiving Day game has been decided. At 1 o'clock this afternoon Manager Mafitt announced that the postponed sale would commence at 2 o'clock. There was a rush for places, and at the appointed hour half the college had gathered in front of the box office.

The Rev. Father Corrigan of Hoboken said yesterday that he had prepared his reply to Bishop Wigger's letter demanding apologies and retractions from him on account of his fable published in THE TIMES of Sunday morning. He refused, of course, to reveal the nature of its contents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Very little has been published in regard to the use of nickel steel for other purposes than armor plates. Commodore Melville, the Engineer in Chief of the navy, Has been placed ln possession of the results of some very valuable experiments which have been made by the Bethlehem Iron Company, and as a consequence has decided to test the value of nickel steel in connection with machinery.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21 -- Several local conditions raising serious legal questions delay the count in the State, and it may be ten days before the result is officially declared, though all the counties are in.

The Democratic masses of Kings County are not usually consulted about the distribution of the prizes won at a great election, but evidence is given every day that the rank and file propose to have something to say about the selection of the next United States Senator from New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS Nov. 21 -- Theodore Schroeder, allas Theodore Stelgerwald, does not like New-Orleans. He arrived here from Philadelphia on Thursday and on Friday he was arrested, by the police upon information furnished by Eichenberg Co., cotton brokers, to the effect that he was wanted in Germany for defrauding the German Government out of something like 100,000 marks.

The politicians yesterday settled the question of two important local Federal offices to their own satisfaction. They slated for United States District Attorney Henry D. Hotchkiss, as the successor of Edward Mitchell. Mr. Hotchkiss is a lawyer of this city and a member of the General Committee of Tammany Hall. He is only thirty-eight years of age, a native of Albany, and was formerly a Republican.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Word comes from the Southern States that the Democrats, particularly in Alabama and Georgia, are rapidly assigning all the patronage that will be due on March 4, and are finding the demand for places greatly in excess of the visible supply.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 21 -- The Critchlow trial was continued to-day, the first witness toeing John Malley. He said he saw the defendant several times on July 6 with a gun in his hands.

The vote of the State of Pennsylvania at the recent election presents an interesting subject of study. The official returns are not fully made up, but the reports generally agree that there was a falling off in the total vote from that of four years ago, whereas it would have been natural to expect an increase of from 80,000 to 100,000.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21 -- The heresy trial of Prof. Henry P. Smith of Lane Theological Seminary was resumed to-day in the First Presbyterian Church by the Cincinnati Presbytery sitting as an ecclesiastical court.

An interesting exhibition bearing on the question of color photography was given at the rooms or the New-York Camera Club yesterday by Frederick E. Ives of Philadelphia. Mr. Ives is the inventor of the heliochromoscope, a device, as he himself describes it, intended to do for color what the phonograph does for sound and the stereoscope for binocular vision.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The only man who is disposed to make trouble for the Democratic Party in this State is Carter Harrison. He proposes to rule or ruin. This attitude of his is not apparent in the interviews he has given to Eastern newspapers, and which nave been telegraphed back hero. It is not Mr. Harrison's policy to show his hand away from home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Secretary Foster appears to be inviting epithets to describe the attitude of the Treasury Department in the case of the steamship Weimar, which has been at anchor at Cape Henry, quarantine entrance to Chesapeake Bay, for a fortnight, and may be kept there possibly until there is a change in the Treasury Department.

The Rev. Dr. M.C. Harris, Superintendent of the Japanese missions in California, spoke yesterday to the Methodist Episcopal ministers at their weekly meeting on the missionary work among the Japanese on the Pacific coast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Fred Douglass has received so many inquiries since the late election from members of the colored race who are anxious to bear his views as to the probable effect of Democratic accession to power, that he has put his answer in the form of a printed circular to save the labor of replying to each by letter.

The tenth annual meeting of the New-York City Indian Association was held yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle, Mrs. Edward Elliott presiding. The meeting was largely attended, and in addition to routine business transacted earnest addresses were made reporting progress in the work of the association and giving encouraging reviews of the undertakings now well in hand.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., Nov. 21 -- The strike having been officially declared off, a grand rush was made this morning by the strikers to get back to work. As early as 6 o'clock the rush began, and it kept the police busy handling the crowd. By 9 o'clock the rush was over, but the men continued to go in in twos and threes, and this will doubtless be Kept up for days to come.

ST. Louis, Nov. 21 -- Terence V. Powderly, General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, to-day submitted to the first interview he has given on some of the Questions that are agitating workingmon. He was very emphatic in his statements, some of which are herewith given verbatim:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The special report or the Hon. H.A. Taylor, the Commissioner of Railroads, relative to Senate Bill No. 751 providing for the funding of the debts of the Pacific Railroads, which he has made a part of his annual report, has been received by Secretary Noble. The report shows that there were bonds issued in aid of these roads in the following amounts: Union Pacific, $35,139,512; Central Pacific, $27,855,680.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Editor Rosewater of the Omaha Hee, on his way from New-York to his home, blurts out his reasons for the defeat of the Republicans in Nebraska, about as one might have expected who had heard him talk during the progress of the campaign.

NEW-YOKK, Monday, Nov. 21 -- P.M. The stock market was not active to-day, and the bears took advantage of the general indisposition to trade to depress prices. They met with most success in Missouri Pacific and Burlington, and the general list was fractionally lower in sympathy. There were stories current of inside selling in the Gould speciatles.

The dread of a cholera invasion has passed, so far as the popular feeling is concerned. In September last, when the Asiatic scourge was brought to this city's gate, there to be checked by rigid quarantine methods and favorable conditions, foremost among which was the coming of cold weather, the public apprehension was great.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- A special meeting of the New-York and New-England stockholders was hold in this city to-day. Ex-Gov. Howard was elected Chairman on motion of President Charles Parsons. The election was objected to by N.F. Goldsmith, who wanted President Parsons to preside.

The coming international armor test at Ochta, Russia, will be the most severe one to which ship armor has ever boon subjected. This state- ment was made yesterday by an officer recently of the Russian Artillery of the Guard, and now temporarily in this city. Because of his personal disinclination to be quoted his name is withheld.

Additional means of transportation and an increased food supply for the natives are two of the most urgent of the wants of Alaska. The lack of facilities for communication not only retards the growth of trade, but is a great drawback to the proper administration of justice. As to the food question, it has become more serious from the inroads made by whites on sources of sustenance which the natives formerly possessed in abundance.

The great Continental Congress of the United States forces of the Salvation Army opened in this city last evening. The Congress is to continue in session to-day and to-morrow, and judging from the first day's proceedings there is no questioning the fact that it will make itself beard.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- By a unanimous vote and after a most exciting discussion, the Chamber of Deputies to-day agreed that a Parliamentary Inquiry should be instituted into the affairs of the Panama Canal Company.

The trial of the case entitled Sehuyler against Curtis was commenced yesterday in the Supreme Court before Justice Ingraham. This is the case of the relatives of the late Mrs. Mary Morris Hamilton Schuyler against the officers of the Woman's Memorial Fund Association to restrain them from erecting a statue of Mrs. Schnyler at the World's Fair in Chicago.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- The rumors of proposed changes in the Boston Museum company for another season have taken shape recently, and it is now safe to announce that George Wilson, the comedian of the Museum company, will appear next season in comic opera with Marie Jansen, and, perhaps, under the management of Mr. Field.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 21 -- If the South Carolina Legislature at the session which begins to-morrow obeys the will of the people clearly expressed at the polls at the recent election, this will be a prohibition State in the near future. A prohibitory measure was before the last Legislature and passed one branch. It failed in the other by only one vote, and it is openly said that money was used to defeat it.

PANAMA, Nov. 13 -- The question of the day hero is that of the retention of the concession for the completion of the Panama Canal, and it has also occasioned some activity among prominent people in Bogota. The suggestions made by a number of prominent citizens that the executive power should be fully autorized to deal with the matter, seems to have taken root, and will be carried through.

The golden jubilee of Mother Mary Augustine of Compassion, the head of the Little Sisters of the Poor, was yesterday celebrated in an unobtrusive manner at the four houses of the order in this city and Brooklyn. The nun the anniversary of whose reception was commemorated yesterday, and for whom masses were said in every house of the order, is now in her seventy-third year.

The politicians got a surprise yesterday, Mayor Grant officially announced that he would make no more appointments. The places now ready to be filled will be filled by Mayor Gilroy after he takes the office on Jan. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- For the next two weeks President-elect Cleveland hopes to escape the importunities of the swarm of office seekers that have descended on him in person and by mail since his election. Quietly, almost secretly, Mr. Cleveland left New-York to-night at 8 o'clock in the Norfolk express over the Pennsylvania Railroad for the South.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 -- Just prior to the election in the United States a syndicate of American capitalist came into Nova Scotia and bonded all the stock of the coal companies in that province, with the exception of the property of the General Mining Association of Sydney.

A matter of unexpected importance was brought to the attention of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners at their meeting yesterday afternoon. It was nothing less than an application from the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company, backed up by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, for permission to build an extension from the Ninth Avenue Line, through Cortlandt Street to the ferry.

Had the seating capacity of Carnegie Music Hall been one-third greater it could not have accommodated all the men, women, and children who sought to gain admission last night. The Salvation Army had its second public meeting there in connection with the Continental Congress opened Monday.

The Dry Goods Economist, one of the organs of the dry goods trade, has recently interviewed a number of business men upon the question, whehter Mr. Cleveland should call an extraordinary session of Congress immediately upon his inauguration for the special purpose of taking up tariff revision. It has published the result of its inquiries, extending not only to New-York, but to many distant and important trade centres.

The dog show is on in Brooklyn. It is held in the Clermont Avenue Rink, under the direction of the National Greyhound Club. For many weeks men and women having dog lore and dog genealogy at their finger tips, have been going about the surrounding country making their selection of dogs for exhibit That they knew their business is shown by the result.

There is a certain ironic significance in the fact that the International Monetary Conference held its opening session yesterday in the Palace of the Academics, at Brussels, since the civilized world has for many years agreed to give to discussion that leads to nothing the name "academic."

A movement is on foot among a number of prominent citizens that may result in the erection of a magnificent arch at the Fifth Avenue entrance of Central Park. At present those interested are endeavoring chiefly to secure an expression of opinion from those whose cooperation in such an undertaking would be deeired.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- The contest between the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Baltimore and Ohio for the fastest regular time between New-York and Washington goes bravely on.
A fire that was hard to fight occurred yesterday in the five-story brick building 11 and 13 East Fourth Street, just near the corner of Lafayette Place.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 22 -- The following officers were elected by the Trotting Horse Breeders' Association here this afternoon: P.S. Talbert, President; W.C. France. Vice President: R.P. Todhunter, Second Vice President; E.A. Tipton, Secretary; Fayette National Bank, Treasurer.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday at 128 Broadway, and President William A. Rooth, who for thirty-two years has been at the head of the organization, handed in his resignation. He gave his extreme age -- he is eighty-sevan -- as his reason for retiring from active work in connection with the society.

There was an array of counsel before Judge Ingraham in the Special Term of the Supreme Court yesterday to represent a large number of creditors of Burkhalter Co. and move for the appointment of a receiver and the deposition of Assignee Charles H. Fancher. The motion was made by Blumenstiel Hirseh, who represent creditors to the amount of $160,000 and indirectly to the amount of $4,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day transacted the following business :

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22 -- From an unquestionably reliable source the information comes that the United States Express Company has captured, or rather will capture on Jan. 1, supreme control of the express business on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad lines, and by securing the Knoxville, Cumberland Gap and Louisville Railroad express franchise, extend its express business to this city, and thus place itself in competition with the Southern Express Company.

A well-organized effort has been instituted by many of the largest stockholders of the New-York Steam Company to oust President Wallace C. Andrews, who they charge has made himself the sole authority of the company by surrounding himself with a "dummy" Board of Directors. The stock of the company is now worth about $1 a share.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 22 -- A large church wedding took place to-night at the new First Baptist Church of East Orange, the bride being Miss Carrie May Chambliss, daughter of the Rev. John A. Chambliss, pastor of the church, and the groom Emerson Johnson, also of East Orange. Four hundred invitations had been issued for the ceremony and the large church was filled.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- The last field practice of the Yale football team was held this afternoon at the Yale field. It was brief, for the trainers were anxious to take no risks in disabling the players. The eleven lined up exactly as last Saturday, and there is now no doubt that at its composition in the Thanksgiving Day game at New-York will be iden- tical with that against Harvard.

It is not many years since BISMARCK startled the German people, and people outside of Germany, in the famous speech in which he declared that the burdens of Germany must be increased instead of diminished, and that it was not possible to foresee a time when they could safely be lightened.

The Board or Aldermen yesterday granted to the East River Bridge Company the right to construct, operate, and maintain the approaches to the two bridges which the company proposes to build over the East River, under the act of the last Legislature, the passage of which was so generally criticised.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 -- The morning session of the Cincinnati Presbytery was wholly taken up by arguments by members of the court upon the question of the sufficiency of the first charge in the Smith case. The speakers were the Revs. James, Bryan, Roberts, Robertson, Monfort, Pollock, and Francis in favor of the sufficiency of the charge, and the Revs. Gilchrist, McGiffert, Achsman, Dudley, and Riggs and Elders Sproull and Fulton against it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day received a letter from Representative Fitch, Chairman of the special committee investigating election methods, protesting against the payment of any bills of John I. Davenport, Chief Supervisor of Elections at New-York, for services or disbursements at the recent election and requesting that he (Mr. Fitch) be allowed personally to examine such accounts before settlement.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 -- Now that the authoritative announcement has been made that a new Republican morning newspaper is to enter the field here some time next month, independent Democrats and Republicans are earnestly discussing the advisability of starting a morning paper to be conducted on the same lines as THE NEW-YORK TIMES, a paper to be run in the interests of the public, and in pronounced opposition to all political gangs.

Mr. Marcus Mayer must quickly find better plays for his new star, Mrs. Bernard-Beere, or her first American tour will end in disaster. She is a thoroughly-competent actress, with a style that is both vigorous and refined, with few displeasing mannerisms, with a keen sense of the picturesque, and ample power. But Mr. Mayer has doubtless heard the tiresome proverb about making bricks without straw.

The red tape which has attended the distribution of tickets to the Yale-Princeton football game tomorrow among Yale and Princeton graduates of more or leas renown is at last ended, and thousands of persona who have contributed largely to the football fund of both colleges in former years will havo one whole day in which to hustle for whatever is left.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The provision market lost all of the snap that it had shown for four or five days chiefly because of the fact that receipts of hogs at the yards overran the estimates 6,000 and prices were 5 @ 10c lower. Influnential traders, who led the buying during the latter part of last week, were the principal sellers yesterday, and shorts appeared to be about the only buyers of note.
The North German Lioyd steamship Saale, nine days out from Southampton, arrived in port yesterday with a splintered bridge and some remarkable tales of the sea.

Those advocates of tariff reform who urge that there should be an extra session of the Fifty-third Congress in March next to revise the tariff do not say, as we have already pointed out, that this session would or could do more than make a few changes in the present law. They admit that a complete revision would have to be postponed until the regular session.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The lobbies of the Chamber of Deputies, before the beginning of to-day's regular session, were crowded with members discussing the probable composition of the Panama Canal Committee. Many members remarked tht it would be difficult to define the extent of the committee's powers, and that the committee's decisions would have no legal force.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The Eickmeyer-Field Company was incorporated some months since with a capital of $1,000,000. The Secretary of State demanded a tax or one-eighth of 1 per cent. The company claimed exemption under the corporation-tax law, being a consolidation of three corporations whose combined capital was not in excess of the capital of the consolidated company.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 22 -- The Williams sophomores are jubilant to-night, having downed the freshmen in the annual championship football Contest by a score of 20 to 4. The game was more hotly contested than usual, and consequently more exciting to the 300 students who, despite the cold weather, lined up around the field to cheer their favorites.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- The First Chamber of the Court of Appeal to-day banded down its decision in the Deacon case. Judgment was given for Mrs. Deacon, and it was ordered that the child Gladys be returned to a convent, where both Mr. and Mrs. Deacon shall be allowed to visit her. Mr. Deacon was ordered to pay the costs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Secretary of the Navy has before him the three court-martial cases involving Passed Assistant Engineer G. W. Danforth, Paymaster H.R. Sullivan, and Capt. E.P. Meeker of the Marine Corps.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The editorial position of THE TIMES -- -that all changes of the tariff must be delayed until its complete revision can be effected-seems likely to meet dissent among some, at least, of the advocates of tariff reform, and I, for one, though seldom differing widely from THE TIMES, confess to being impressed with the objections to such a course.

Next after the deficit and tariff questions the question of the election of a United States Senator is the one of most interest for our State. It is known that Mr. Murphy of Troy, the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, is working energetically for the post, and that his claims meet with a favorable reception from a large portion of the Democratic machine politicians.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 22 -- The Critchlow trial was concluded to-day. In rebuttal the defendant was called to the witness stand.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22. -- H.M. Neil, the wellknown cotton authority of this city, has prepared a revised estimate of the cotton crop, which will be sent to the Exchanges and published in the morning. On Nov. 2 he estimated the crop at 5,100,000 bales outside of Texas, or 7,100,000 bales including Texas. Referring to that estimate, he says:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov., 22 -- The moat fashionable wedding in Camden for several seasons took place in St. Paul's Episcopal Church at noot to-day. The bride was Miss Holen Sewell, daughter of ex-United States Senator William J. Sewell, Vice President of the West Jersey, Railroad Company. The groom, Charles Louis Borie, is well known in this city.

BENSONHURST, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Burglars have been operating here and hereabout with some success lately. They have entered houses, packed up clothing and silver and disappeared, and the local Hawkshaws have been unable to find any trace of them.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- "The comet now visible near the nebula of Andromeda, instead of approaching the earth, is, in all probability, receding from it," said Professor Young in an interview with a reporter of the Associated Press to-day, "and, furthermore, according to the latest data, it is not a fragment of Biela's comet, as earlier data had led many astronomers to suppose."

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- The ceremony of the session of the Reichstag took place to-day in the Knights' Hall of the royal palace, and was performed with the utmost pomp and splendor. Chancellor von Caprivi, the members of the Bundesrath, and nearly all the members of the Reichstag were present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Before Senator Hill had served one Winter in the Senate he had afforded his colleagues, Democrats and Republicans, opportunity to judge of his qualities as a statesman, legislator, and companion. His reputation as a politician bad been already made, and it was calculated to assure hima warm reception among partisans whose impulses were much stronger for success than for reform.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 22 -- The International Monetary Conference met at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The proceedings were purely formal.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 22. -- The sixty days' session of the Legislature of Alabama saw the introduction of a bill which will do away with the convict lease system in this State. There is no doubt but that the bill will pass in some form or other. That is the opinion of Mr. McQueen of Jefferson County, who introduced the bill.

The annual report of the Children's Aid Society is always interesting and suggestive, and that just made public, which is the fortieth of the series, shows gratifying progress in the society's excellent work. While the work is constantly extending, the field is almost unlimited and there is always need of increased appliances and facilities for carrying it on.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 22 -- The General Assembly of South Carolina convened at the State Capitol at noon to-day. The House consists of 125 members, 87 of whom are new. In the Senate there are 36 members, half of whom are new. The Assembly is overwhelmingly "Tillmanite," the conservatives, or the Democratic element that is recognized as being in opposition to the present administration, being few and far between.

HOMESTEAD, Nov. 22 -- The closing act in the famous strike was performed last night. The Advisory Board, which has been the Gordian knot of the strike, was severed, and the last official gathering is at an end. The board, which, has directed the destinies of the looked-out men throughout the entire struggle, met for the last time in its hall on Eighth Avenue, and, after disposing of the unfinished business, was dissolved.

Judges who have been yelped at and Harked at at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, for the past two days by 577 dogp, and who will now be scolded at and criticised by angry men and women whoso dogs did not scours the prizes that they thought their pets were entitled to, completed their work yesterday afternoon.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 23 -- This afternoon, in the Church of the Redeemer, Miss Mary C. Washburn was married to Elbert Francis Baldwin, a New-York journalist Miss Washburn is the daughter of United States Senator William D. Washburn. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Tuttle, assisted by the Rev. James Wood and the Rev. William Crocker of Boston, friends of Mr. Baldwin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The annual report of Gen. Cyrus Bussey, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior, has been received by Secretary Noble. It deals exclusively with the work of the Board of Pension Appeals, of which the Assistant Secretary has direct charge, and with the purchase of Indian supplies at the Government warehouse in New-York.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Gov. Flower has pardoned George H. Pell, who was serving a sentence of seven years and three months in Sing Sing Prison for the larceny of certain securities from the Lenox Hill Bank, in New-York City. His sentence would have expired May 23, 1895, on account or good behavior. The pardon was granted on Monday.

There was a panic last evening among the tenants of the four-story doable tenement 136 West Seventeenth Street, occupied by eight colored families. It was caused by a fire which started from some unknown cause in the basement of the building and extended to the roof. But for the prompt work of the firemen several Lives would have been sacrificed.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Collins, who lived at the Hotel Dam, have brought salt against George B. De Revere, the proprietor of the hotel, for $8,000, which they allege was the value of a package of jewelry deposited in the hotel safe for safe keeping last year and not delivered when called for.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23 -- The excitement that prevailed among the students of the university to-day has been unprecedented. As the time approached for the game the enthusiasm seems to grow hourly in intensity. A manifest reversal of feeling has taken place in the last few days, and indifference has been supplanted by the most ardent enthusiasm for the "orange and black."

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- George Hamilton Pell, the bank wrecker serving a sentence of seven years and six months, from June 9, 1890, was discharged from Sing Sing Prison this morning, having been pardoned by the Governor.

The most notable social event in The city yesterday was the marriage of Hiss Laura Wallace Buchanan to J. Mayhew Wainwright, both of tills city. The bilde is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Buchanan. The groom is the son of Mrs. William H. Catlin and grandson of the late Bishop Wainwright. Trinity Chapel, where the ceremony was performed at noon, was crowded to discomfort.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 23 -- In the United States Circuit Court here to-day Judge Simonton filed for the court, consisting of Judge Goff of Virginia and himself, a decree ordering the sale of the South Carolina Railway, and appointing ex-Gov. Daniel H. Chamberlain, now receiver of the road, Special Master to conduct the transaction. The sale is to take place at Charleston April 11 next.

The Seventh Triennial Diocesan Synod of the Roman Catholic Clergy of the Diocese of New-York was held yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue, with great pomp and solemnity. Archbishop Corrigan presided, and there were over 200 priests present. The doors were closed at 9:30, and no one except the clergy was admitted to the mass and the deliberations which followed.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 -- From the Atlantic to the Pacific, sporting men will hear with regret of the death of William O'Connor, the champion oarsman of America. The end came at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon from typhoid fever.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 23 -- The trial of Sylvester Critchlow, charged with murder in connection with the Homestead riot, was brought to a close this evening by the lury bringing in a verdict of acquittal. Owing to the hour at which court convened, there was not many persons present when the jury filed in. The prisoner was not released, he having yet to answer the charge of riot.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The star and crescent of Turkey flies from a flagstaff on the scaffolding from which the Turkish pavilion is to rise at the World's Fair grounds. The ceremony of raising the flag took place in the presence of all the Sultan's subjects who have come to take part in the exposition, as well as a number who had come especially from Turkey for the occasion.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22 -- Exmore is almost inaccessible to interviewers. The island of Broadwater, where Mr. Cleveland will spend his time, is eight miles long and can only be reached by a private boat. So without the connivance of the friends or the President-elect visitors will find it impossible to break in upon him.

It is doubtful it ever before since the establishment of the free delivery system there have been so many complaints as are making just now about the service of the local Post Office. Complaints are hoard all over the city of failure to deliver mail, and others of delays of from one to four days.

The feeling with which Mr. CLEVELAND looks forward to the opportunities and the duties awaiting his Administration has been so freely and seriously expressed since the election that there is no possible excuse for misunderstanding in regard to it either by those who sympathize with it or by those who, from difference of aims and difference of character, are opposed to it.

Mr. CLEVELAND did not speak in a whisper when he told EDWARD MURPHY, Jr., that he ought not to seek an election to the United States Senate, that he was not trained for a legislative career, and that his activities might much more profitably be turned to other works. He has made no concealment of his views about Mr. MURPHY'S misdirected aspirations.

It is strange that no American newspaper should have been able to get the news of the recent archiepiscopal conference. It is still stranger that the scope and objects of this conference have been generally misunderstood. The questions which the Archbishops were called to consider are of the utmost importance to the American Republic.

The main significance of the German Chancellor's speech, on the Army bill is the challenge it contains to his predecessor. It is to be hoped, in the interest of Germany and for the sake of the reputation of a great man, which has been a national possession of high value, that BISMARCK will not re-enter the Reichstag to take up the challenge.
ROME, Nov. 23 -- The Italian Parliament was opened to-day by King Humbert in person. The Queen and the ladies of the Court were present in the gallery, and were heartily cheered.

The extensive furniture factory and warerooms of Otis Cornett, successor to Doremus Corbett, on West Twenty-third Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, were destroyed by fire last night, involving a loss of between $150,000 and $200,000.

In Monday's debate in the French Chamber of Deputies on the Panama Canal scandal, M. Joles Delahaye, the Deputy for Chinon, (Rabelais's own country, by the way,) named one Arton as the medium for transactions which consisted in bribing, right and left, to bolster up the "South Sea Bubble" of the nineteenth century.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23 -- The Yale-Harvard freshman game at Cambridge next Saturday is attracting considerable attention, and the lower classmen are anxious to keep up the pace set by the 'Varsity eleven against their crimson rival. Out of the ten games played Yale has won three. Harvard five and two were drawn. Last year Yale beat her opponents 28 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- It is to be hoped that no partisan will be so mean on Thanksgiving Day as to suspect that the following answer to the Hon. Ashbel P. Fitch's request to Secretary of the Treasury Foster to withhold the pay of John T. Davenport and Marshal Jacobus was written by Davenport just because it is like him, and because he arrived here just before Mr. Foster gave it out.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Prices were strong to-day, not only for good to choice shipping steers, but for the poorer sorts as well. The light receipts and the fact that no trading can be done to-morrow stimulated the demand, as did also the colder weather, and there was a brisk movement at an advance on yesterday's prices of 5@10c 100 lb. The quality or the offerings was not very inviting.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23 -- In the Knights of Labor Assembly to-day a resolution advocating the abolition of the militia was voted down, and the following resolution adopted:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- Public attention here has been called to the large number of negroes who are leaving this section of Tennessee in search of work and homes in Northern and particularly Western States. The railroads are carrying away scores of negroes, women and children, every week, and it is said that about 700 colored people have left this city alone within the past month, the greater portion since election day.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 23 -- To-night the City Council has under discussion the subject of differences between the City Government and the County Commissioners over the drainage of Hamar Swamp, a pestilential morass two miles from the city. This swamp has been a source of contention between the county and city officials for years.

The case of Schuyler against the officers of the Woman's Memorial Fund Association, brought to obtain a perpetual injunction restraining the defendant from erecting a statue of Mrs. Mary Morris Hamilton Schuyler and exhibiting it at the World's Fair, was concluded in the Supreme Court, before Justice Ingraham, yesterday afternoon.

Mr. William J. Henderson's locture before the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences last night proved one of the most notable musical events which has transpired in that city in many a year. Association Hall, in which the lecture was delivered, has a seating capacity of close upon 2,500, but not only was every seat occupied and all the standing room pre-empted, but several hundred persons were unable to gain admission to the hall.

In the mind of every graduate of Yale and Princeton to-day is the most important day in the Fall and the one that is looked forward to eagerly from the time that college opens. Judging from the appearance of the people on the streets yesterday and the crowds at the hotels last night, one might almost think that the people of New-York held the day equally important with the collegians.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- The long-looked-for event of the present session of the Reichstag occurred to-day. The Army bill was introduced by Chancellor von Caprivi, who made a most important speech upon the relations existing between France and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Speaker Crisp's floor manager, Representative Caterings of Mississippi, is ont very emphatically for an early session of Congress. Naturally, he thinks there should not be a protracted struggle over the Speakership, "for," he says, "Mr. Crisp will be elected Speaker again beyond any doubt. He has made a good Speaker, and there is no reason why he should not be re-elected to that position."

EXMORE, Va., Nov. 23 -- The train bearing President-elect Cleveland and party arrived here at 5:11 o'clock this morning, and Mr. Cleveland, who had traveled in the private car of General Superintendent Kenney of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad, started, with his companions, on the journey to Hog Island, his destination being the Broadwater Club house.

A large importer of rags said yesterday that it would, not tie surprising if some confusion existed in the public mind, concerning the statement made by Health Officer Jenkins that rags coming from ports where cholera had existed during the past year would not be allowed to land at this port.

After a great deal of speculation whether gold exports would begin again. Wall Street learned late yesterday afternoon that $600,000 in gold coin had been taken at the Sub-Treasury. This news came upon the heels of reports from houses likely to be interested in shipments of the yellow metal that they didn't know whether gold would be sent out on Saturday's steamers or not.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- An ex-member of the Chicago Board of Trade, William C. Lincoln, who is a juror in a special assessment case, was charged in open court to-day with having tried to secure bribes from both the property owners and the city.

The whereabouts of C. Sinclair, cashier and confidential bookkeeper, is a matter of some interest to his former employers just now. These employers are the Armonr Packing Company, and more particularly the local branch of that institution, which has its offices at the foot of West Thirty-fifth Street. Mr. Sinclair has been employed in these offices for some years, it is said.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 -- The North German Lloyd steamer Weimar, from Bremen to Baltimore, with her 1,906 passengers, is still detained at the Cape Charles Quarantine, and the customs officials here say that she will not be released until the full twenty days of quarantine are up, on the 30th of this month.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 24 -- Two more Blount County (Ga.) moonshiners, Joseph Garland and Isham Lake, have come to grief. They were brought here last night by Deputy Marshals MoKenzie and Brodie and admitted to ball. An officer at Maryville station with the prisoners arrested William McNeely, also an aged moonshiner, as he was buying a ticket to Texas.

There was published two or three days ago a long interview with ex-Senator EDMUNDS, of Vermont, concerning Trusts and the Federal Anti-Trust law. Mr. EDMUNDS is not in accord with Senator ALDRICH and other leaders of his party in his opinions on this subject.

The very thing Yale hoped for and Princeton was afraid of happened. Yale worked in one of her brilliant end plays at the outset of the Struggle, before the Princeton players had had a chance to settle down to the battle, and scored a touch-down. The Yale interference, which has been perfected at Yale this year, worked like a charm.

Seven new war ships of the United States, at present in process of construction, have been ordered in commission prior to March 1 next. Six of those chips, according to Commodore George W. Melville, Chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department, could be given their steam trials prior to that date.

The Murphy boomers claim "Boss" Mo Laughlin of Brooklyn among the supporters of their candidate for United States Senator, which would mean nineteen votes from Brooklyn, in addition to the thirty-six New-York votes controlled by "Boss" Croker, and that would secure to Mr. Murphy the nomination in the caucus, and consequently his election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Mr. Ryan, United States Minister to Mexico, left Washington today for New-York to take the steamer for Mexico. "I am," said he, "an earnest protectionist, but I do not think that the principles of protection apply to our intercoure with other countries on this continent. If there were no Custom Houses between tale country and the republics south of us it would be worth hundreds of millions of dollars to us.

Dr. William G. Buddington, a retired physician and a well-known clubman, declared that he was the victim of an utterly unwarranted and outrageously brutal attack by Policeman Samuel L. Magrane early yesterday morning, and his declarations are corroborated by two witnesses. Evidence of the fact that he was roughly handled exists in braises on his nose and in his swollen lips.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Secretary of the Navy is busily engaged on his annual report. This official record of the closing days of the Harrison Administration of the Navy Department will be interesting. It covers a period of great activity in the work of building up the service on the lines originally laid out by Secretary Whitney.

As stated in THE TIMES yesterday, Mrs. Appleton Sturgis disappeared from her stateroom on the Pall River boat Plymouth some time Tuesday night or Wednesday morning. There is now no doubt that she fell overboard and was drowned in the Sound. The best evidence shows that the event was purely an accident.

There appears to be a widespread belief that the trunk-line railroad Presidents wore really sincere in their recent action relating to passenger rates for the World's Fair traffic. The official declaration that a reduction of 20 per cent, from the regular fares would be made only on a few slow trains, and that no reduction whatever would be made on the fast trains, at once evoked pronounced manifestations of disappointment and indignation.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 24 -- It is a far cry from Charleston to Albany, but intelligent interest is taken here in the election of a Senator to succeed Frank Hisoook. In an editorial article headed "Murphy Not the Man," the News and Courier this morning says:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 24 -- Prof. Wiggins, the Canadian astronomer and weather prophet, was interviewed by a TIMES correspondent today regarding the alleged collision of the earth with a comet last night, as was stated by Prof. Snyder of Philadelphia in this morning's telegraphic dispatches.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The North German Gazette. referring to Chancellor von Caprivi's speech in the Reichstag yesterday, expresses the hope that the authentic information furnished by the Chancellor in regard to the Ems dispatch will silence the critics who are basing their attacks on false conceptions.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- Gov. Northen ana thirty-five members of the Georgia Legislature devoted the day to sightseeing in Cincinnati and its vicinity. They were bound for Chicago, where they will inspect the World's Fair buildings, with a view to obtaining information that will insure an appropriation of $100,000 for a Georgia exhibit.

Leopoldo Sanguinetti is an Italian nobleman who, on account of financial reverses, is over in Brooklyn figuring as the proprietor of a "boot-blacking parlor." He used to have a place of business close by the bridge, but they pulled down the building in which he had his parlor, and he packed his belongings and moved up town-up country, a person with a prejudice against Brooklyn, would say.

Forasmuch as on Nov. 25, 109 years ago, the last of the redcoats who had staid in New-York to harass the citizens sailed away forever, leaving Gen. Washington to ride down Broadway at the head of the American Army in a free city, a number or patriotic Americans got up very early yesterday morning to hoist flags in commemoration of Evacuation Day.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, Nov. 25 -- There is much excitement in the western part of the State of Sonora over the recent discovery of a gold mine of fabulous richness. The find was brought about in a remarkable manner, the fortunate discoverer being Arthur O. Corna, a merchant of Altair, this State.

It is some months since there has been an acute outbreak of "the European crisis." The crisis may be said to exist so long as France does not definitely renounce the reconquest of Alsace-Lorraine. BISMAKCK, with that brutality of good sense which is his most distinguishing characteristic, put this point very well and strongly in the famous speech in which he successfully exhorted Germany to add to her military burdens in time of peace.

The Council of the University of the City of New-York decided yesterday to purchase, according to an option which runs out on Dec. 1, all the property on Sedgwick Avenue facing the previously-purchased college grounds. The object of the purchase is to secure the property against possible undesirable tenants, and also to insure convenient approaches from the New-York Central and New-York and Northern Railroads.
HAMBURG, Conn., Nov. 25 -- Harden Gray, School Visitor in the Alder Ridge district, and Alice Griswold, teacher of the school, had an exciting experience with a wildcat a day or two ago.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 25 -- The weather was mild to-day and there was no wind in the middle of the day. The All Age Stake was completed, and, as intimated in last night's report. Lorn, P. Lorillard's dog, came out first. This makes the second prize which has fallen to Lorillard this week, and the trainers are jubilant. Count Gladstone came out second and Harry C. third.

ROBERT BARBOUR. Robert Barbour, President of the Barbour Flax Spinning Company and a member of the firm of Barbour Brothers Company of 218 Church Street in this city, died suddenly of apopiexy yesterday morning, at his residence in Paterson, N.J. Mr. Barbour was sixty-eight years old and a native or Belfast, Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Nothing authentic can be learned to-night, from an official source, as to the actual physical condition of Mr. Blaine, though, naturally, there is much inquiry, and there are widely-conflicting statemeats in circulation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The publication in the Philadelphia Times of the claim advanced by Henry B. Foulke of this city, backed up by a number of his friends, that he is now the head of the Theosophical Society of the World, having become at her death the earthly successor to Mme. Helen P. Blavatsky, has stirred up the Theosophists.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 25 -- There is trouble browing among the Methodists in this State and elsewhere in the South over the action of the Epworth League in regard to negro members of that organization who may visit the Chicago Exhibition next year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- It is generally believed that the action of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Road in threatening to withdraw from the Western Passenger Association unless Southwestern Missouri River business was exempted from the agreement, will have the desired effect. Of course, the desired effect is the reorganization of the association, with all the important roads in the territory as members.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Montgomery is a spoils county. It includes forty miles of canal with places for two dozen look tenders and fifty scowmen and laborers, a Deputy Revenue Collector, a United States Commissioner, forty Post Offices, and several places dependent on them.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Thomas E. Benedict, Deputy Secretary of State, said to-day that he thought some remedial legislation would be necessary in order to have the election for delegates to the Constitutional Convention, who are to be elected Feb. 14 next, not interfere with the town elections, which are to be held in twenty counties in the State on that day.

Capital, as represented by the New-York Steam Company, yesterday had an encounter with labor, as represented by its firemen. The firemen went on a strike because of a reduction in their pay and an increase in their hours of work. For ten hours the service of the company was crippled by the strike, which occurred at midnight Thursday.

The Church of St. Mary Woolnoth, which stands out conspicuously at the King William Street corner of Lombard Street, was closed ten months ago, and it is clear from the stataments of the rector that the step was not premature. It has been his unhappy lot to be often startled in the course of his services by a loud yet muffled sound, evidently issuing from the vaults under the church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- "Corporal" Tanner, fat with prosperity, "rolling in wealth," as he is described in an authorized interview, seems to have been stirred up by recent suggestions about the desirability or scrutinizing the pension lists for fraud. He swaggers, too, and while contemplating, with satisfaction, an increasing list of claimants and fees, practically repeats Tweed's "What are you going to do about it?"

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 25 -- The Olympic Club will not make the match between "Tommy" Byan, the Chicago welter weight, and "Tom" Williams of England. The club offered $3,000 for the match, but the recent forty-thousand-dollar offers have given the pugilists an exaggerated idea of the value of their services, and Ryan promptly replied that the money offered was not enough.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 25 -- The Hon. J.J Abbott has resigned the Premiership of Canada. The official announcement was made this afternoon.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 25 -- A mob of between 75 and 100 men surrounded the jail at Jasper, the county seat of Marion County, forty miles west of here, about midnight last night. They demanded that Sheriff Rogers turn over to them Floyd Woodlee, John Turner, and "Cal" Collins, three negroes, who murdered George Dawson, a white man employed as engineer at the furnace of the Tennessee Coal, Iron, and Railway Company, on Wednesday night.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A report was in circulation here to-day that the North German Lloyd steamer Trave, Capt. Sanders, from New-York Nov. 15, which landed some of her passengers at Southampton yesterday and proceeded for Bremen, had a very narrow escape from running ashore at Start Point, the southern ex- tremity of Devonshire.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- The Atlanta Journal, voicing the wishes of Mr. Cleveland's personal supporters in Georgia, thus speaks editorially of the New-York Senatorial canvas:

MISSISSIPPI CITY, Miss., Nov. 25 -- The details of a strange story are just made public. A double wedding had been arranged in Harrison County, the brides being two sisters named Lott and the bridegrooms two brothers named Slade. The wedding day was set, and the Blades came to Mississippi City and obtained the necessary licenses.

A few minutes after 11 o'clock last evening James Brady, living at 506 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, saw flames in a paint shop in the rear of the carriage factory of J.F. Butler, at 502 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street. He ran into the street and sent out an alarm, but before the firemen reached the place the flames had extended to the two-story frame dwelling at 504, owned by William Nunn.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- The signal-tower and interlocking block system on the New-York Central Railway is in full operation north to Hudson. The bridges are completed to Buffalo, the towers are framed as far west as Utica, and the connecting cable is in place to a point near the village of Oneida, about half way between Syracuse and Utica.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 25 -- "The Breakers," the beautiful Summer residence of Cornelius Vanderbilt, is in ruins. A mass of debris now marks the spot whore it stood.

The remarks of ex-Senator EDMUNDS about Trusts and the Federal Anti-Trust law have been taken by several of our Republican contemporaries as a text for discourses that must give their faithful readers a shock. The interview with Mr. EDMUNDS was procured and published by the Chicago Inter Ocean, which is disturbed by the exactions of the Anthracite Coal Trust.
The special committee of the Brooklyn Aldermen appointed to manage the recent Columbian celebration made its financial report yesterday. It expended $51,226.83, made up of the following items:

Although there is the usual solemn affectation of impenetrable secrecy regarding the proceedings of the International Monetary Conference at Brussels, the situation is clear enough. The policy of hiding everything in mystery in diplomatic matters is an absurdity, as much so as would be in these days the institutions from which it sprung.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 25 -- The published statement that the sum of $30,000 was sent to this State during the recent Presidential campaign, for the purpose of bringing out stay-at-home voters, men who generally work on election days, and do not go to the distant polling places unless taken to them in conveyances, has caused widespread discussion in Ohio.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Premier Loubet and Minister of Justice Ricard appeared before the Panama Canal Investigating Committee at its opening session to-day. They spoke in opposition to the proposal of at Pourquery de Boisserin, that the committed should be invested with the power of an examining magistrate, but they stated that the Government would grant access to papers and documents collected for previous lawsuits.

After losing the beat part of a week in an endeavor to got to work, the Congressional committee which is to investigate the Reading coal combination finally began proceedings yesterday in the Post Office Building. President A.A. McLeod of the Reading system was put through a long examination relating to coal prices, the methods by which the combination of the railroads under his direction was effected, and other matters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The forthcoming report of Mr. A.B. Hepburn, the Controller of the Currency, shows that 163 banks, with an aggregate capital of $15,285,000, were organized during the year; 53 went into voluntary liquidation and 17 became insolvent, leaving a net increase for the year of 93 banks. Nearly 50 per cent, of the new banks are west of the Mississippi River and 35 per cent in the Southern States.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 25 -- The sober reception of the pretensions of Mary Ellen Lease to the United States Senatorship completes the idiocy of the Kansan who has become infected with the new doctrines. When first spoken of this candidncy was the subject of jest, but there soon became apparent an earnestness and the evidences of such a strong following that those who were inclined to smile found reason to become alarmed.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 25 -- Superintendent Fisher of the Southern Express Company has completed a fine-piece of detective work in the arrest of three robbers to-day at Adairsville, Ga., thirty miles south of here. They are Benjamin Morrow, George Green, and Henry Leake. Superintendent Fisher secured strong evidence against them, and one of them has confessed the crime.

Mrs. Abby Hutchinson Patton, wife of Ladlow Patton, died in this city on Thursday evening, Nov. 24, after a brief illness, the immediate cause of which was a rupture of one of the blood vessels of the brain.

HARTFORD, Nov. 25 -- There will be an unprecedented amount of legislation to be attended to by the incoming General Assembly, which will begin its session Jan. 4. Every particle of legislation that has been omitted by the two houses, that have been involved in a hopeless disagreement during the past two years, will have to be shouldered by the Legislature of 1893, practically forcing into one session the legislation of four years.

The orders of the President, as announced in THE TIMES'S Washington dispatches, directing the vessels of the Revenue Marine to take up Winter cruising duties until next April, are orders which are regularly issued to the Atlantic coast vessels of the service every Fall. The vessels included in the recent orders are those at present engaged in patrol work between Eastport, Me., and Charleston, S.C.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Justice Reed, for the Court of Error and Appeals, has rendered an important decision in the liquor case from Cumberland County. When the Worts liqour law was passed Senator P.P. Baker secured the adoption of an amendment which would practically give local option to townships opposed to saloons by fixing at a special election the amount of license to be charged.

CHARLESTON, S.O., Nov. 25 -- An object lesson of the value of trading in futures, which the Hatch Anti-Option bill designed to suppress, is being given to Southern cotton planters to-day, and its effect is likely to be felt when the bill is taken up for consideration in the United States Senate.

The approval of Secretary of the Navy Tracy on the findings of the Danforth court-martial was generally expected in naval circles at this port, but that Secretory Tracy should take occasion in rendering his decision positively hereafter to render the engineer officer of every war ship in the service subservient to untimely calls from the deck was far from being expected in engineering circles.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 25 -- The International Monetary Conference resumed its sitting this morning.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 25 -- The Legislature of Alabama will have to wrestle with three important measures which came before it Wednesday. They are among the most interesting which the human mind in this country is compelled to face -- baseball, rum, and the destructive baggage smasher.
