SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The funeral of the late Daniel Edgar Crouse, the multi-millionaire, who died on this city Monday night, took place at his late residence at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and was conducted by Chancellor Sims of Syraouse University and the Rev. Dr. George B. Spalding of the First Presbyterian Churoli, Chancellor Sims delivered an address.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 -- A Schumacher Co., agents of the North German Lloyd at Baltimore, wera shown the dispatch from Washington about the steamship Weimar, and say: "We are greatly astonished at the assertions made by Treasury officials intimating that the detaining of the Weimar at Quarantine was caused by our not advising them of the character of the passengers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Unofficial reports have been received here of the arrest of John L. Montien, cash clerk in the Sub-Treasury at New-Orleans, for the larceny of silver dollars belonging to the Government. It is said that Montien has confessed to the theft of nearly $500 from the Sub-Treasury, and that he has offered to make complete restitution.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 25 -- It has developed through the investigation held by the Coroner that the killing of two Mexicans in Live Oak County last Monday by the State rangers was a most unfortunate tragedy. The Mexicans were supposed at the time of the killing to be horse thieves, but they have since been identified as Juan and Gabriel Longera, brothers, who were prosperous and honest ranchmen.

NEW-ZEALAND BIRDS. -- The kiwi is a brown night bird, about the size of a guinea fowl, with a long, narrow, curved beak, with which it pierces the gronnd to satisfy its appetite with worms and grubs. It has fine, long, pointed feathers, of which the Maoris make feather rugs by working them together with flaxen threads.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 26 -- This city is experiencing a mild typhold scare, which was to-day intensifled by the announcement that the fever had broken out with great violence in the Ohio Medical College of this city. The announcement was made in the following hysteric manner:

NAPOLEON'S MOTHER. -- Public attention does not seem to have been directed toward Napoleon's mother until her son was proclaimed Emperor in 1804. She then received the title of Mme. Mere and an income of 1,000,000f. was settled upon her. And that she might have a position of political importance, she was made Protectrice Generale of all the charitable institutions of France.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- The football season has closed, with its disappointments and its successes. Cornell certainly never had so good a team nor harder Inck in securing games which could teat its ability. Manager Hanson has struggled with all sorts of difficulties, the chief of which is Cornell's remote location, and at the end of the season no one wonders that football accounts show a deficit.

Miss Dinsmore, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Dinsmore of 7 East Forty-seventh Street, made her debut into the world of society last evening. Miss Dinamoro is the first of the debutantes to make her bow to New-York society this Winter.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you kindly allow me space for a few words in reply to the article in your issue of Nov. 18 in reference to the commitment of Leah Rappaport of this city to the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane?

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The Long Branch nd Asbury Park football teams played an interesting game at their grounds this afternoon. The Long Branch boys won by a score of 12 to 0. Elin Burtis of the Asbury Park team was injured daring the last halt of the game. A return game will be played on New Year's Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The most successful football season the University of Pennsylvania ever had is now closed. Sixteen games were played, a larger number than any other of the larger teams engaged in, and but one defeat, and that at the hands of Yale, marred the record.

The presses of the Publishers Printing Company have lately become the cause of considerable apprehension to the tenants and employes in the buildings adjoining 120 and 122 East Fourteenth Street, where the company has its place of business. The Publishers' Printing Company does the press-work on such publications as Short Stories and the Forum.

OUR MOTHER GLOBE. -- The existence of volcanoes, geysers, and hot springs irregularly scattered over the whole surface of the globe and continually ejecting molten rock, ashes, mud, steam, or hot water is an obvious indication of some very widespread source of heat within the earth, but of the nature or origin of that heat they give little positive information.

A WIFE FOR SALE. -- The first recorded sale after the accession of George III. occurred in the month of March, 1766. In this case a carpenter of Southwark, named Higginson, went into an alehouse for his morning draught; there he met a fellow-carpenter, and their conversation turned on wives.

The portentous calamity of an export of $600,000 gold has fallen on Wall Street at last, and the stock market has naturally been depressed. The shadow or cold shipments has rested on the market for ten days at least; and has been talked about as something which. if it happened, would have consequences indefinite, but dreadful.

With yesterday's games at West Point and Cambridge the football season of 1892 is at an end. There has never been such a season in the history of the game in this country. The attention to football at the leading colleges has had its effect upon smaller institutions of learning, so that this Fall has witnessed an eleven in nearly every school in the East.

Copyrighted, 1892, by the New-York Times. LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Upon that memorable twenty-first birthday of the republic, celebrated with such pomp in Paris a while ago, the world was given to understand that whatever else might happen we would hear no more of monarchical pretenders.

Col. B.H. Richardson, editor of the EnquirerSun of Columbus, Ga., and a member of the Democratic Executive Committee of his State, was talking yesterday at the Coleman House about the election in Georgia and the utter rout of the third party in that State.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- When the debate on the Imperial budget opens in the Reichstag on Wednesday next some indication will be given as to the manner in which the parties are likely to range themselves on the Army bill. The army estimates, that were prepared independently of the increased expenditures involved through the now bill, amount to 585,000,000 marks, being 12,500,000 marks over the amount contained in the last budget.

CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- The new Latin scientific course has now been organized, extending over four years. It is a course parallel to the old clerical one, which will preserve its separate degree of A.B. The new one will end in a B.S. In it natural science, modern languages, and literature replace Greek. In every other respect the courses are identical.

The action of the Vladivostok authorities in the recent seizure and prompt release of a New-Bedford whaler has properly been regarded as another indication that Mr. BLAINE'S "closed sea" theories are not likely to receive much support from the actual practice of Russia. Last Summer it looked as if she had really decided to lend support to the extreme contentions of our State Department by maintaining jurisdiction over the western portion of Bering Sea.

The investigation by the Senate committee of the labor disturbances during the strike at Homestead and the connection therewith of the Pinkerton Detective Agency was taken up yesterday at the offices, at 31 Nassau Street, of Seward, Guthrie Morawetz, counsel for Robert A. Pinkerton. The examination was carried on in the lawyers' office because the rooms at the Pinkerton Detective Agency were too small for the purpose.

There is one result of the late election that must, we should say, be profoundly satisfactory to every good citizen, of whatever party he may he, and that is the evidence that in the reformed ballot we have found a means of freeing the workmen from any serious interference with their voting by their employers.

To fully appreciate the work of the artist modistes it is necessary to note the wonderful creations turned out by modistes who are not artists. These may he seen any day or evening, upon the promenade, at public entertainments, and even, occasionally, at the most exclusive gatherings.
The latest letter in the correspondence between Representative Ashbel P. Fitch and Secretary of the Treasury Foster relative to the accounts of the notorious John L Davenport is as follows:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 26 -- Gov. Tiliman to-day transmitted to the Legislature an important message in regard to the control of the Port Royal and Augusta Railway by the Central Railroad of Georgia and the consequent bottling up of Port Royal, claimed to be the finest harbor on the Atlantic coast. Complaint had been made of the matter, and the last Legislature had directed the Attorney General to investigate it.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- This was the third day of the Manchester Autumn meeting. The event of the day was the Manchester November Handicap of 1,500 sovereigns. It was won by Sir J. Thursby's three-year-old b.c. Paddy. Mr. W.I. Anson's four-year-old b.c. Newcourt, by Highborn, out of Orange Blossom, was second, and Mr. S. Platt's three-year-old br.c. Portland, by Poste Restante, out of Miss York, third.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Nov. 26 -- P.M. There was a fair day's business done for a Saturday, and in view of the universal bearish feeling on the part of brokers prices were firm. New-England was exceptionally weak and lost 1 1/8 points. There was also some pressure on General Electric, which declined 2 points. Cordage also closed 1 point down.
The interest being taken in the question of the successorship to Frank Hiscock in the United States Senate is a thing of constant growth all over the United States.

WHAT WILL BE THE AWAKENING? -- It was of Harriet Martineau (and the saying might apply to all who, like her, have done their best to serve their fellows that the large-souled Florence Nightingale remarked: "What a delightful surprise it will be to her to wake and find herself in heaven!"

HUNTING ZEBRAS. -- After crossing the usual heated yellow plains, looking for all the world like an expanse of overparched hayfields, and dotted hero and there with droves of springbok, we outspanned two and so rode back again across the hot, weary plain for camp. We had not long quitted the forest before we sighted a good troop of Burchell's zebra, feeding quietly.

The wretched condition of the highways in the cities, villages, and country districts of America has always been a weak point in the administration of its communities. It is but very recently that the streets even of New-York have been covered by a reasonably good pavement or have been kept even decently clean, while other great cities are generally unable to show any considerable section of street in fair condition of repair or cleanliness.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26 -- Among football men there has been much discussion of the new wedge that Harvard played once or twice with much success in the game with Yale at Springfield Nov. 19. Curiously enough, this piece of strategy was planned by a man who until a little more than a year ago knew almost nothing about the game of football and, indeed, had hardly seen it played.

To those who were privileged to witness the handsome exhibition given by the Forty-seventh Regiment on Thanksgiving Eve in the Marcy Avenue armory there was no need of the assurance of the Inspector General that the state military authorities had no intention of distributing the eight companies comprising Col. Eddy's command among its companion regimental organizations of the Second Brigade in the City of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Something less than year ago, partly to meet "a long-felt want," but due more directly, perhaps, to the ferment into which the discussion of the Russian persecution everywhere threw the race, a very interesting Jewish club was founded here in London.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Some of Boston's citizens are becoming very unhappy over the shortsighted policy of the City Goverment in leaving Commonwealth Avenue so long uncompleted. A communication has been received by the Board of Aldermen this week sharply arraigning them for indifference to the best interests of the city.

FORKED RIVER, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The few Democrats of this no-matter-what-so-long-as-it-is-Republican community are wearing a variety of smiles in consequence of the election, and a particularly broad one occasioned by a local incident.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- College journalism is receiving a decided revival at the University of Pennsylvania through the establishment within the last two weeks of two new papers devoted entirely to the interests of the university. The most important of the new papers is the Wharton School Bulletin, published with the object of creating a more general knowledge of the work done in the Wharton School of Finance and Economy of Pennsylvania.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26 -- The game played here to-day between the Harvard and the Yale freshmen ended in a tie, the score being 6 to 6. Harvard far outplayed Yale in the first half, when she made her touch down, but the second half brought Yale's turn and a touch-down for the boys in blue. The teams were evenly matched, and considering that they were freshmen played a fine game.

LONG-DISTANCE RIDES. -- Long-distance rides, have always been a favorite subject with poets and the writers of romance. There is something that seizes the imagination in the idea of a solitary horseman spurring on his steed in a race with time, spurred on himself by terror, by hatred, or by devotion to duty.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- A special dispatch from Calcutta to the Times says that Afzul-nl-Mulk, the reigning sovereign of Chitral, together with his younger brother, has been murdered by Sher Afzul Khan, a brother of the late ruler of Chitral.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The boom in matters the atrloal that was expected at the beginning of the season, and which managership since been looking for, has not yet been realized. The depression, however, does not affect the leading houses, but is indicated by a new recourse to revivals amid the abundance of new plays that are awaiting production.

It is a very suggestive fact that the question of restricting immigration should have been taken up in two public places on one evening in this city. On Friday evening the Patria Club held a meeting at which this was the topic of discussion, and at the same time Judge EMORY SPEER of Georgia was urging the importance of it upon his hearers in a speech after the annual dinner of a college society.

Mr. Yates mentions that a correspondent has pointed out to him that the story of Tennyson's saying "Ne laissy pas sortir le foo" was orignally told as occurring during a visit paid to Paris by Tennyson and Lushington, not Browning. This assertion is only an additional Illustration of the seemingly incurable propensity to father the oldest chestnuts on famous people.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Wealth, beauty, and fashion combined to render the opening ball at the Lakewood to-night one of the most brilliant events in the history of the hotel and of the community. About 500 guests, representative of society in New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, Buffalo, Albany, and even Portland, Oregon, took part in the festivities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Gen. Rosecrans, Register of the Treasury, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury, makes the following caustic remarks in regard to the operations of the civil service law:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your statement in THE TIMES of Nov. 15 is so absolutely truthful that I wish I could see it repeated many, many times. The handiwork of a tricky Congress should be shown up so that the public may see the unfortunate, embarrassing predicament the new Congress will be placed in.

PHYSICAL TROUBLES AT GREAT HEIGHTS. -- A far more important factor is the effect of diminished pressure on the portion of the spinal marrow which, is concerned with the nutrition of the locomotive agents, the lower limbs. Greatly increased pressure also produces much the same symptoms. This effect has no relation to the absence of oxygen.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- The effort which has been made during the week to becloud the title of Mr. Russell to the Governorship is worthy of mote than a passing notice. Its springs may be found deeply imbedded in the current history of modern Republican politics in this State.
The total value of city real, estate sold at auction at the Exchanges for the week ending with yesterday, Nov. 26, was $318,975, as against $1,294,694, the figures for the week previous.

OLD FLINT, STEEL, AND LIGHTS. -- We fail to realize the boon conferred upon us by the invention of lucifer matches, not perfected until the present generation. The old strike-a-light, still manufactured at Brandon, in Suffolk, required a flint, a steel, and a tinder box. In Buchan the steel was called the fleurish or fleerish.

It would be a disservice, I think, both to Mr. Irving and to the public, to ignore the fact that the Lear of Thursday night was, to a great extent, a Lear of inarticulate dumb show. A very large -- a much too large -- portion of the text had been out away, and of what remained of the part of Lear, one-half at least was entirely inaudible.

The promised sensation in Richmond Terminal affairs came out yesterday in the form of a notice sent by Receiver W.G. Oakman to the members of the financial combination who four years ago sold a large block of the securities of the Georgia Company to the Richmond Terminal Company, tendering them the said securities and demanding the return of the purchase money with interest.

There has just been launched from the yards of the Craig Ship Building; Company of Toledo. Ohio, a vessel which in two hours time can be converted in all respects into a harbor defense ram, and with a rapid-fire battery well protected by steel shields can justly be expected to silence any craft the British are able to send through the Welland or St. Lawrence River Canals.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 26 -- The six members of the senior class annually chosen to compete for the Class of '68 Prize have been selected. Work done in English composition during the three previous years is the basis of selection. The men are G.S. Chapin, Auburndale, Mass.; M.S. Clifford, Bangor; H.C. Fabyan, Portland; C.H. Howard, South Paris; A. A. Hussey, Honlton; C.W. Peabody, Portland.

Mr. Flagg undertook the preparation of this biography with, some diffidence and in circumstances that were embarrassing, for it was the purpose of the late Richard H. Dana to write it. Mr. Dana had made notes, had actually written some parts of his work, and had collected many valuable letters bearing on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, ,$166,410,000, as follows: Currency sizes, $11,862,000; 4 per cents, $132,597650; 2 per cents, $21,960,350.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Augustus Thomas's new war drama, "Surrender," produced for the first time on any stage at the Columbia Theatre on Monday night by Charles Frohman's new Boston stock company, is a good show. "Surrender" is on for a run.

THE ARMADILLO AND IGUANA. -- The armadillo, as eccentric in his habits as in his appearance, does the duty of the domestic cat among the field mice, which are terribly destructive. Voracious in his appetite, he is sedentary by inclination, but he can find his game with very little trouble. Mice are always more or less abundant, though periodically, and almost punctually, their numbers decline, but in certain years they positively swarm.

The home mission department of the Presbyterian Church of America has undertaken in earnest during the past two years the regeneration of the "mountain whites" of the Southern Atlantic and border States. In an address delivered in the Seventh Presbyterian Church, 134 Broome Street, Miss M. Morrison, one of the Carolinas, missionaries, gave a graphic ac- count of the ignorance and degradation prevailing among the "mountain whites" of Virginia, the Carolinas, Georigia, Tennessee, and Kentucky.

Very great success is attending the National League for Good Roads in its efforts to arouse a widespread and effective interest throughout the United States in the Question of country roads. The practical object of the league was to cause the organization in every county in every State in the Union of local leagues having for their purpose the bettering the roads in their vicinity.

Mr. Willard's return was the single notable theatrical event of last week. That able, sincere, and powerful actor was seen again with genuine pleasure, but his portrayal of Cyrus Blenkarn, the potter, suggests no new comment. It is the same as it was before, except that Cyrus is no longer bearded, and the actor's fine face therefore expresses more clearly and minutely the emotions of the character.

THE "MARSEILLAISE." -- The story that Bucher composed the "Marseillaise," whatever may have been its age when the "Englishman" culled it in Paris, is new, now, only a force d'etre anciennc, and is not true at all. The identity of the author with the composer of the "Marseillaise" was, one would think, decided beyond reasonable question nearly twenty years back.

A good moral is to be found in a little story told at a woman's luncheon a day or two ago. The narrator was a Western woman who came last Spring from a residence of several years in a Western frontier fort. "When we left," she said, "I had to part with a faithful dog friend. who had been a member of our family circle during our entire stay at Fort --.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Judge Dixon disappointed a good many people this morning by his failure to come to Paterson as he had three weeks ago agreed to do.

IN THE LOUVRE. -- "My dear Sir," says the guide, "three francs an hower; show you tings never see at all widout guide." He stands with his hat off, grasping a black-thorn stick, his Eastern countenance wrinkling into innumerable smiles. I look first at him and then at a little man with his hands deep in a bulgy covert coat.

Even the fact that President-elect Cleveland is enjoying a brief vacation far away from the city and the politicians does not prevent the Cabinet speculators from going right on with their business and making up all sorts of Cabinets for the next President of the United States. This is undoubtedly very kind on the part of the Cabinet makers.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- The football eleven of the Naval Academy, attended by some hundreds of onthusiastio men and maidens, all flaunting the Naval Academy, blue and gold, came to West Point to-day and adminis tered a severe drubbing to the eleven of the Military Academy. The navy is accordingly jubilant and happy, and the army is wearing an unbecoming air of humility and nursing a reduced pocket.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- A dispatch from Algiers says that the great French Cardinal Lavigeria is dead.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 26 -- There were a number of blockade runners in the civil war who were Northern men by birth. Many of them hailed from the New-England States, and of this latter number Capt. Edwin Davis, of whom mention has been made cently in THE TIMES, was one. In nearly every instance, though, where a Northern-born man was engaged in running the blockade, his wife was a Southern woman.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 -- The release of the North German Lloyd steamer Weimer has precipitated a lively row in this city. The officials all along held that the 1,800 immigrants on the ship had not engaged passage before the 1st of September, and therefore did not come within the exceptions of the President's order, and, as a consequence, were liable to the twenty days' detention.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- The large number of Cor- nell men working on the new revision of Johnson's Universal Cyclopedia is something of an indication of the reputation the university is acquiring. Ex-President C.K. Adams is editor in chief, and though he has left Ithaca the office of the cyclopedia remains here under the charge of Mr. Thurber, chief editorial assistant.

It was the distinguished Carolinian, William Gilmore Simms -- the same whose life was recently attempted by William Porterfield Trent, Professor of History at the University of the South -- who expressed the opinion that the result of the war which the thoughtful Southerner had most to dread was not the conquest of arms, but the conquest of opinion.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The yearly inventory of the Mont-de-Piete has again discovered that wonderful umbrella, placed there in 1849! Six francs were loaned, and some good and faithful soul has already paid over 30f. interest. What a legend of misery and hope!

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 26 -- Sugar planters all over Louisiana are showering letters upon Mr. Cleveland and the Democratic leaders of Congress. A cry is going up from every parish that the bounty system must go, and that duty on sugar should be restored in a modified form.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 26 -- In athletics the students have done very little this Fall. Football has never had so little support, and the team has never made such a poor showing as it has this season. The 'Varsity team has not won a single game, indeed losing by large scores to teams with whom they need to play for practice, such as St. John's Military Academy and the Syracuse Athletic team.
I'm glad I'm a "thus far," said my friend Smith as he stood before tho window of the smoking room in the club, with his hands behind him.

The public, whose interests the elevated raiload has so much at heart, has been taught by experience to look beneath the surface for the real purpose actuating the road's management in any of its so-called improvements, extensions, and changes.

BAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 26 -- The trial or Juan Antonio Flores, the Mexican who held the commission of Lieutenant Colonel in the revolutionary army of Catarino Garza, was resumed in the Federal court here to-day. The case is attracting wide attention, owing to the prominent part which the prisoner playad in the Rio Grande border troubles of a year ago.

LONDON FOG. -- Over the mighty city, amid certain atmospheric conditions, the particles of carbon form a canopy that obstructs the passage of heat and of chemical rays from the centre of life -- the sun. There is a lowering of the temperature and animal vitality is diminished. Pure fog mist, such as we see in the conntry, does not seriously interfere with solar chemical energy.

LE SUEUR, Minn., Nov. 26 -- St. Henry, a country neighborhood twelve miles distant from this city, is in the throes of a tremendous sensation. Tuesday morning word reached here that Joseph Bounder, a prosperous farmer, had suddenly died of heart disease. On Wednesday the information also reached hare that Miss Agnes Shear, a sister of Hounder's wife, had died in the same manner.

The local political surprise of the week was the announcement made by Mayor Grant that he would make no more appointments before going out of the Mayor's office. He questioned his own right to appoint successors to Police Justices Duffy and Kilbreth, owing to the unsettled questions as to whether their terms expire early in January or did expire early in November.

The Congressional committee which is looking into the Reading combine got to work tardily yesterday. The witnesses were on hand promptly enough, but the members of the committee and the counsel were all late. Chairman Coombs did not attend the hearing at all, being detained at home on account of illness.

Now that brokers are getting the greater part of the real estate business, instead of auctioneers, old disputes about commissions have been revived. When brokers had a hard time to provide for office rent they were glad to split commissions with anybody who could help them to business and to make every concession to owners.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 26 -- Football will now become a reminiscence, and a very agreeable one, at Yale, with the phenomenal record of two seasons in which her opponents have not scored a point against her, and with the splendid stimulus of this record for another season. Yale science and Yale spirit has triumphed again, and this time with an eleven which, individually, was not superior to its opponents.

Phil Daynton was as susceptible as most artists in their twenty-sixth year. Still, it never occurred to him that he might be imperiling his happiness and Beatrice's by just crossing to Capri for a week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Secretary Tracy took up another interesting court-martial case yesterday. The report of the proceedings of the court-martial on board the Chicago has lain on the Secretary's desk for a week, together with Capt. Meeker's appeal from the action of Admiral Walker in publicly reprimanding him and then trying him by court-martial.

It is in large part New-York's affair who shall be chosen by the Democrats to succeed Senator Hiscock to the United States Senate. But this is a national body and the character of its makeup is of national concern. It is of some general consequence whether its members are men of commanding ability or men whose qualifications are their money or their ability in the manipulations of ward politics.

Within the past two months two wealthy members of the congregation attending the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Bartholomew, Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. Greer is pastor, have given handsome presents to the church and church mission.

There were dances last night by the classes organized by Mrs. Philip Sands and Mrs. Henrl Braem. Both classes were successful last Winter and they started off in the new season last night in a thoroughly satisfactory way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Representative Bynum has directed the attention of President Harrison's Attorney General to some queer performances of the United States Marshal in President Harrison's own home, which is also Attorney General Miller's home. Mr. Bynum is impressed, apparently, with the belief that there was disregard of law and great personal thrift in the proceedings in Indianapolis and thereabout on election day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary Tracy has added to the foroolty of the fight between the staff and line officers of the navy. His unqualified approval of the sentence of the general court-martial in the case of Assistant Engineer Danforth will increase the bitterness which has existed for many years, unfortunately, between, line officers and officers of the Engineer Corps.

"I am fully satisfied, from views afforded to the eye, that the comet which made its appearance in the Constellation Andromeda on Nov. 6 is growing dimmer and receding from the earth," said Prof. Rees of Columbia College last night. "I am also thoroughly convinced, from the data furnished by careful computation, that the comet is not Biela's but one not hitherto defined."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- United States Treaserer E.H. Nebeker has submitted to Secretary Charles Foster the annual report on the operations and condition of the Treasury.

Occupying a cell at Police Headquarters yesterday was a slick young Englishman. Capt. Edgar J. Vernell, who was arrested in this city on Saturday evening by Detective Sergeants Hickey and Lanthier. He is charged with forgery and swindling and, in the pursuance of his nefarious designs, personating T. Aubrey Peart, also a young Englishman of good family, who is at present engaged in viticulture at Fresno, Cal.

The members of the Hebrew congregation Shaarai Zedek met yesterday to consider a proposal to remove the bodies from the old burying ground, of the congregation in Eighty-eighth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, to Bay Side Cemetery, near Jamaica, L. L. A new building is being created near the old cemetery and while the foundation was digging the cem etery wall was undermined and partly fell In.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27. -- In an interview yesterday with Prof. Charles A. Young, senior professor of the department of astronomy here, in reference to the recent meteoric shower and the later developments of the much-talked-of comet, he stated that on Wednesday night he, with some of the other professors, witnessed the display of meteors which between 10 and 11 o'clock were fallingat the rate of about 6,000 per hour.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Trafalgar Square was today the scene of another animated gathering of Socialists, Anarchists, and an otherwise motley crowd, which required police supervision, though no serious conflict occurred.

The new United States lighthouse steamer Columbine arrived at Bahia, Brazil, on Nov. 19. She is en route from this port to the Columbia River, Oregon, where she will take up the duty of conveying stores to the several lighthouse stations on the Pacific coast which lie to the north of San Francisco. Portland, Oregon, will he her headquarters.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla,. Nov. 27. -- News at the killing of Charles H. Pratt, editor of the Daily Leader, at Gainesville, late last night by Thornton S. Stririgfellow, was received in this city to-day at noon and created considerable stir. Young Pratt was a rising young newspaper man in the State, and a hard worker in his profession.

If any one still cherishes the illusion that it is possible to find out from the statement of the Treasury Department under its present management what is the condition of the department, he ought to read, ponder, and inwardly digest the report made by United States Treasurer NEBEKER, the substance of which, as given out to the press, will be found in our columns this morning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 27. -- A Helena (Mon.) special to the Pioneer Press, says: Wronged before she was seventeen, assaulted two years later by the man who ruined her, slandered by the same vile creature after she was honorably married, poor Maggie Dowty lies in jail in Kingston, soon to become a mother.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- The shipping in San Francisco Bay had a lively time last night and to-day. The weather has been stormy for the past few days, and last night before midnight a furious gale commenced, which seemed to increase in intensity until nearly noon today, when the wind began to go down but there was still a heavy gale on at 6 P. M.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 27. -- There is no disguising the fact, trotting-horse breeders are getting soared. They are evidently afraid the bottom is going to fall out or the breeding business and they are doing the very thing that will help to bring it about. They are crowding the combination-sale men with consignments; not with culls, as has been largely the custom in the past, but with the very best animals on their farms.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Discount was firm during -- the past week. Quotations yesterday were: Three months, 2 1/4; short, 1 3/4. The firmness of rates was owing to the fact that supplies in the-open market have been, steadlly decreasing. The only marked feature of the week was furnished by New-York's gold shipments to Europe, which, it continued, will, it is thought, tend to counteract the Continental demands still threatened.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- It is announced to-day that the most prominent and influential men in the shipbuilding and shipping interests of the United States have, completed the preliminary organization of a professional society of high standing, to be called. "The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers," whose object shall be to promote the art of shipbuilding in all its branches, both commercial and naval.

The new coast-defense battle ship Monterey will be ready for her official trial trip by Dec. 15. This is the latest information to hand of officials connected with the Bureau of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department. As a consequence every preparation has been made in the matter of details to enable the data for the Government to be collected by that time.

ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- According to the slate prepared toy the politicians, Edward Murphy, Jr., will succeed Frank Hiscock in the United States Senate, and William Sulzer of New-York will preside over the next Assembly as Speaker. The compliment to the latter is said to have been obtained by his political godfather, John Reilly, the ex-Register, who has been training Sulzer for this office for three years.

It is declared at the Navy Department by officers in a position to know that the Lancaster, now on the Asiatic station, will be ordered to return shortly to the United States. The Lancaster is at present the flagship of Rear Admiral D.B. Harmony. The big ship proceeded to the Asiatic Station from this port not two years ago.

The popular demand, for the enactment of the inter-State commerce law was caused mainly by disclosures concerning discrimination in freight rates for the benefit of powerful corporations and firms. There were other evils in the practice of railroad companies for which legislation was desired, but this evil of unjust discrimination was the one which had been most clearly disclosed to the public by many official investigations.

The formal statement by the delegates from the United States to the Brussels Conference says: "It is the unanimous opinion of the people of the United States that the establishment of a fixity of value of gold and silver and the full use of silver as a coin metal upon a ratio fixed by agreement between the great commercial nations of the world will greatly promote the prosperity of all classes of the people."

NEW-YORK, Monday, Nov. 28 -- A.M. The bears were unusually active last week, and they met with a fair amount of success. Their sole argument for a lower level of prices was the possibility of large exports of gold. They predicted that upward of $2,000,000 would go on Saturday, but the amount taken was only $600,000.

Mr. Biela's stars wore either on a strike last night or there was some trouble with the management, for the curtain was not rung up, and the biggest "audience" New-York has turned out in many a day was disappointed. The show has been better advertised than many another with fewer stars but less uncertainty in keeping engagements.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 27. -- Gov. McKinney and other prominent public men in this State believe that Virginia's oyster beds can be made of inestimable value. The revenue now derived from them by the Commonwealth is little more than sufficient to defray the expenses of collecting it. If this industry is made to yield a larger income, it is believed that some new and radical system will have to be adopted.

When formal permission has been obtained from Bishop Potter, from the standing committee of the diocese, and from the Supreme Court, the two Protestant Episcopal Churches of St. John the Baptist and the Epiphany will unite their interests. Already the Wardens and Vestrymen of the two parishes have entered into and sealed an agreement settling the details of the consolidation.

ELIZABETH, K. J., Nov. 27.-The politicians here are much interested in the outcome of the Plainfleld municipal election which occurs Dec. 6. The city is a Republican stronghold and the Republicans have renominated Alexander Gilbert for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- A reporter for the Post has secured several entertaining valedictory statements from members of President Harrison's Cabinet, and the candor of the utterances procured is calculated to make the reader of them regret that all of the Cabinet officers were not interrogated.

There was surprise and anger yesterday in the family of Cigar Dealer John H. Wolters of 282 Sixth Avenue, near Eighteenth Street, over the action of the General Term Saturday in ordering a new trial of the suit of pretty Miss Georgine Wolters against Bedquilt Maker Louis Schultz for breach of promise of marriage. Miss Wolters sued Schultz last Spring in the City Court, before Judge Fitzsimons.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 27. -- There is going to be a bitter contest over the Governorship of Alabama, after all. Koib has been making all the preparations in his power to oust Gov. Jones. It was first supposed that Kolb would attempt to be sworn in on inauguration day, next Tuesday. It is understood that he has abandoned that idea.

At the annual exhibition of lantern slides by members of the Society of Amateur Photographers of this city last week a variety of work was shown by about a dozen members, some of which will be included in the set of slides contributed by the society this season to the American Lantern Slide Inter change.

At this distance from Paris the one thing we can assume to know positively about the Panama Canal scandal is that the affair is immensely interesting. Beyond that we may safely conjecture that M. DELAHAYE is a reckless accuser and that the results of the investigating committee's work will be disappointing to those epicures of sensationalism to whom no scandal is satisfactory if it does not blast every reputation accessible to its ravages.

Next Thursday Trinity Parish will add another chapel to its corporation by the annexation of the old St. Luke's Church on Hudson Street. On that evening the historic old edifice becomes "St. Luke's Chapel, Trinity Parish," by the holding of appropriate services.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 27. -- Nutley can sleep once again. This is more than the little Jersey village has been able to do since H. C. Bunner brought his donkey to town.

The novelty of a play written exclusively for the American stage by Victorien Sardou will be offered next Monday at the Lyceum Theatre, where Daniel Frohman will produce the new comedy, "Americans Abroad," which the great dramatist has written for that theatre. On that night "Americans Abroad " will have its first production on any stage.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 27. -- A special from Spokane, Washington, says: "The series of highway robberies which have taken place at Wenatchee, on the line west of Spokane. resulted last night in two murders by the robbers. Gamblers, thieves, and thugs have made that town their headquarters, reaping a rich harvest from railroad construction men who usually visited the town to get their pay and then proceeded to spend it in saloons and gambling houses.

The Kings County Insane Asylum In Fiatbuah la now the scene of the nightly visits of a ghost, clad in black, and with an annoying habit of swishing suddenly upon unwary attendants in a certain corridor after the usual hour of midnight. The attendants are wrought up over it, and the doctors even say something, they can't tell just what, has happened.

The British Admiralty has launched a third war vessel on the great lakes. The fact or the launch was announced la THE TIMES'S dispatches of Sunday. The new vessel is named the Petrel and is a slater ship of the two British gun vessels Constance and Curlew. Ostensibly, It is announced, the Petrel is designed to cruise on Lakes Superior and Huron and to patrol Goorgian Bay.

The trial of the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs, professor of Biblical Theology in Union Theological Seminary, for heresy, by the New-York Presbytery, was taken up again yesterday afternoon, and will now go on from 2 to 5 o'clock each afternoon until the verdict of the Presbytery is given.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 28. -- A pretty little story has been gaining currency within the last few days, to the effect that Miss Sophonisba Breckinridge, the bright and handsome young daughter of Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge, had just taken a bar examination, and been admitted to the practice of law.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 28. -- The heresy trial of Prof. Henry P. Smith of Lane Theological Seminary was resumed this morning by the Cincinnati Presbytery in the First Presbyterian Church. Prof. Sproull gave notice of a protest against the action of the Presbytery at the last session in voting to sustain the first charge and specifications as proper in form and legal effect.

A bitter passenger-rate war has been waged between Cincinnati and Chicago for several days. At first the only roads concerned were the Pennsylvania, the Louisville. New-Albany and Chicago, (Monon,) and the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, and the points chiefly affected were in the Ohio River and Missouri River territories. AS the fight progressed other roads were dragged into it and the disturbing influence became far reaching.

It is difficult to take seriously the proposition submitted yesterday to the International Monetary Conference by Mr. ALBERT DE ROTHSCHILD of the British delegation, and we should certainly be very reluctant to believe that the American delegates are, as reported, working with the Englishmen to secure the adoption of this most amazing plan.

While there is already a good deal of talk about the choice of Speaker of the Assembly and the election of a United States Senator, there is no sign of anything that can fairly be called a "canvass" of the opinions or preferences of the members of the Legislature with regard to candidates for those places, much less with regard to the opinions or preferences of the people whom those members are supposed to represent.
Brooklyn society crowded into the theatre and assembly rooms of the Academy of Music in Montague Street last evening at the benefit concert and ball for the Brooklyn Homeopathic Hospital.
ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- The Court of Appeals has set down for hearing to-morrow morning a collateral inheritance tax case arising from the bequests of the late Edward D.G. Prime.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The mounted highwayman who created trouble at the north end of the city last week, has transferred himself to Clyde, Bermyn, and Riverside suburbs, in the southwestern part of Chicago.

The engineer officers of the navy in and about New-York City are preparing for a dinner at Delmonico's on the night of Dec. 15 next, when it is proposed to bring together not only the engineer officers of the navy now in active service, but those who at any period did honorable service in the regular or volunteer branch of the Engineer Corps of the navy.
PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The members of the French Cabinet resigned to-day, owing to an adverse vote of 304 to 219.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- With the vote of Vice President Stevenson, even without the assistance of independent or Farmers' Alliance Senators, it seems to be certain that the Democrats will be able to reorganize the next Senate and command a majority vote on all nominations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- East-bound shipments of freight by rail last week, exclusive of live stock, amounted to 61,818 tons, against 71,624 for the preceding week, a decrease of 9,806 tons, and against 73,752 for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of 11,434 tons. By lake the east-bound shipments amounted to 77,253 tons, against 82,150 during the preceding week, a decrease of 4,897 tons.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 28. -- Mr. de Rothschild's proposals on behalf of Great Britain were submitted to the Monetary Conference this afternoon. They cover eleven printed octavo pages.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 28. -- Business men North and South will watch with deep concern the action of the Tillman "reform" Legislature, now in session at Columbia. Several measures have already been introduced which, if they become laws, will, in the opinion of business men here, work serious harm to the State by their effect on men who have money invested in South Carolina.

Prof. Briggs opened by stating that under the Book of Discipline he was privileged to file objections to the regularity of the organization of the Presbytery as a a court, or to the jurisdiction of the judicatory, or to the sufficiency of the charges and specifications in form or in legal effect, or to make any other substantial objection affecting the order or regularity of the proceeding, on which objections the parties should be heard.

The revenue problem is not ignored by certain Democratic members of the Fifty-third Congress who urge that the tariff should be revised in part, at least, by Congress legislating in extra session immediately after the inauguration of Mr. CLEVELAND, but the devices by which these members would solve this problem to their own satisfaction will not be approved by a majority.

One man, two women, and six children sat in the front room of the Pasteur Institute, 178 West Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon and waited patiently for symptoms of hydrophobia to appear. They had been engaged in the same cheerful occupation ever since they reached this city from Danville, Ya., Sunday afternoon.

THE TIMES, in its Trenton dispatch published yesterday morning, made public the fact that there is no use of Leon Abbett trying to get the support of the Hudson delegation in the nest Legislature in his Senatorial fight unless he first releases the convicted and imprisoned ballot-box stuffers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- There was active trading in provisions all the morning, local speculators and outsiders showing much more interest in the market. Receipts of hogs were fairly large with prices for the heavy lots a little higher. Manufacturers Bold a little product, mostly for May, which is attracting more attention, while the selling was done chiefly by one of the traders who have been long and were anxious to realize.

EXMORE, Va., Nov. 28. -- President-elect Cleveland put in the day around the Broad-water Club House reading, listening to, and telling stories. Mr. Cleveland seems to be enjoying his stay greatly, and the quiet and rest are just what he wanted.

L. Bradford Prince, Governor of the Territory of New-Mexico, arrived in this city yesterday, and in a few days will visit Washington on important business. In conversation with a reporter of THE TIMES Gov. Prince said:

The first of the series of "Urania" entertainments, entitled "A Trip to the Moon," wan presented at Daly's Theatre yesterday morning, and the audience which gathered to enjoy it carried away with it a knowledge of the world's satellite which could have been gained otherwise only by the reading of a library of scientific works.

The miserable farce of the arrest by John I. Davenport of State Senator Edward B. Osborne of Poughkeepsie a few days prior to election on the charge of illegal registration was repeated again yesterday in an examination of Mr. Osborne before United States Commissioner Shields.

The Congressional committee which is investigating the Reading combination was at work in this city yesterday. To-day, at 10:30 A.M., it will meet in Philadelphia to pursue the inquiry at the fountain head of the deal, and it is more than probable that some exceedingly interesting facts will be brought out.

BUFFALO, Nov. 28. -- The Democracy of Erie County is nearly evenly divided on the question of the United States Senatorship. The thinking Democrats believe that Mr. Cleveland should be consulted in the matter. The machine Democrats are openly for William F. Sheehan or for any Democrat Mr. Sheehan may advocate. Mr. Murphy is considered a candidate only to the extent of Mr. Sheehan's support.

Probably the most interesting piece of news that has transpired for a long time in connection with the future of Irish home rule was made public yesterday. It is a complete outline of the plan Mr. Gladstone proposes to offer to the British House of Commons as a solution of the problem of Ireland's self-government, which has confronted the English Government for so many years.
DOVER, N.H., Nov. 28. -- A Dover Democrat received a letter two or three days ago from a New-York friend, in which he found this question:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- The annual report of John Hoag, County Treasurer of Westchester County, shows that he had received from all sources during the year ending Oct. 31 $951,979.58, which, added to the balance from last year, $103,468.67, gives a total of receipts of $1,055,448.25 during the past year.

Naval Constructor Frank L. Fernald, United States Navy, Chief of the Department of Construction and Repairs of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, said yesterday that, so far as his department was concerned, the training ship Portsmonth, the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius, and the cruiser Philadelphia were practically ready for sea.

The fight between the Jeffersonian Democrats and the Gleason Democrats to determine whether Horatio S. Sanford or Patrick Jerome Gleason is the Mayor-elect of Long Island City was began in earnest yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Dr. Scott, President Harrison's father-in-law, died at 4:10 o'clock this afternoon.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- The validity of certain Kings County bonds was sustained by a decision of the Court of Appeals to-day, which affirmed the judgment of the lower courts in the case of Henry H. Adams, County Treasurer of Kings County, vs. the East River Savings Institution, appellant.
The Committee of Thirty of Tammany Hall met yesterday afternoon, and the two large silken prize flags were awarded to the district organizations that made the best records at the last election.

News comes from the Mare Island Navy Yard, California, that the United States steamer Thetis was taken from the dry dock at that station on Nov. 23 last. The United States steamer Ranger was floated into the berth, previously occupied by the Thetis on the same day. The Mohican, the same advices state, was being made ready during the past week for duty as flagship of the Pacific squadron.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 29. -- A divorce suit with unusually sensational features was filed hero to-day. The complainant is Lulu Simmons, and her husband is S.C. Simmons, a prominent and wealthy young citizen of Carroll County, Tenn. She seeks absolute divorce on grounds of alleged fraud in the marriage ceremony.

Unless we are greatly mistaken, the beatific frame of mind in which the American delegates to Brussels are said to go about these days will be sadly broken up when they hear from their own country. At present they are said to be enjoying the congratulations of their delightfully-courteous fellow-members of the conference over the "triumph" achieved by them.
Justice Meade, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday tackled the labor question, and with commendable promptness solved the problem presented to him.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad was held in this city yesterday. There was not a very large attendance, but perfect harmony prevailed. Mr. D.O. Mills presided. President John King voted on $22,715,200 of stock and $6,175,200 of bonds, held abroad, and Mr. McCullough, representing the Mills-McCullough Committee for American security holders, voted on $33,738,300 of stock and $25,308,700 of bonds.

For a long time the telegraphers employed by the Central Railroad of New-Jersey have been complaining that they were getting less pay for their services than any other body of railroad telegraphers in this country. Yesterday a conference was held at the railroad company's building in Liberty Street between the officials of the company and a committee of telegrapher headed by D.G. Ramsay, Chief of the Order of Railway Telegraphers.
"In a few years from now New-York City will get all its gas from Long Island."

ALLENTOWN, N.J., Nov. 29. -- One of the most daring bank robberies, with a touch of the Western manner, ever perpetrated in New-Jersey, was attempted in this town this afternoon, and but for the courage of two of the bank officials, backed by a score of townsmen, the robbers would have been successful.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 29. -- An iron-clad, copper-bound prohibition bill was introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday by Mr. Roper of Marlborough, under direction of the State Prohibition Executive Committee. It was the result of a year's steady work by State Chairman L.D. Childs and his lieutenants, who claim that if it is adopted South Carolina will have absolute prohibition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Supervising Special Agent Tingle, in his report to the Secretary of the Treasury of the operations of the Special Hgents of the Treasury Department during the last fiscal year, says that the smuggling of dutiable merchandise upon the Canadian and Mexican frontiers has largely increased since the passage of the Tariff act of 1890 imposing high duties on agricultural products.

The people of St. Louis do not appear to have been enlightened by the experience of Chicago as to the fearful cost of a polluted water supply. They have waited for a similar experience in their own city, where an alarming epidemic of typhoid fever now prevails. This epidemic promises to be much more severe than that which was caused in Chicago by the contaminated water of Lake Michigan.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 29. -- The Brooklyn Coop- erage Company, tired of its long struggle with the cotton interests and the insurance compa- nies, is determined to force matters, and has notified the City Council that it has closed the contracts for the erection of its factory, and that the work will be began in the morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 29. -- At noon to-morrow the last fashionable wedding of the season will take place when Mr. Benjamin Weaver will be married to Miss Eleanor Whipple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Whipple.

LICK OBSERVATORY, Cal., Nov. 29. -- The Holmes comet has been systematically observed here since Nov. 8, but the stormy weather has prevented observations during the past week. Its position has been accurately measured by Prof. Schaeberle with a meridian circle and by Prof. Barnard with a twelve-inch telescope. The latter has also secured a good photograph of the comet.

The latest plan of Mr. Gladstone's looking to home rule for Ireland, as given in yesterday's TIMES, is a fruitful source for conversation among representative Irish-Americans. Opinions have been expressed upon it with great freedom, for the subject is one or the highest importance, and no one who has the slightest care for the future of Ireland can avoid taking an interest in measures affecting it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- There is considerable discussion in football circles at present as to who will be elected Captain of the eleven for next year. Rumor has had it that Capt. King is coming back to college next year to pursue a graduate course of study, but he has not as yet returned from his Thanksgiving recess and has not positively committed himself.

The Yale Alumni Association of New-York had an old-time celebration last night at Sherry's. Over 300 members were present, and it was by all odds the biggest company that has gathered at the regular meetings since the organization of the New-York alumni.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Secretary Noble has received from Gov. Fifer of Illinois a letter asking for the aid of the Government in finding a child which it is believed has been carried into captivity by the Ute Indians. Following is the Governor's letter:

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 29. -- All the arrange- ments for the Nicaraugna Canal Convention have been completed, the sum necessary for the expenses has been raised, and the only local committee which will now have fixed duties to perform is the Reception Committee, which will meet at Odd Fellows' Hall at 9 o'clock to-morrow to receive and seat the delegates.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- The first steps in what promises to be a long and famous legal fight have just been taken in the commencement of an action brought by Frederick Cook, ex-Secretary of State, against the Silver Lake Ice Company to establish the ownership of the lake.

The proposition to suspend all immigration from Europe to this country for a year from the 1st of next March is by far the most radical suggestion that has been made by anybody on the subject. Yet this proposition is favored by the Chairman of the special committee of the Senate, and was by him submitted to that body, and it seems to stand a very fair chance of adoption by the committee.

It is among the possibilities that emigration from European ports to this country may be totally suspended for at least a year by act of Congress. At yesterday's meeting of the Senate Committee on Immigration at the Fifth Avenue Hotel a proposition to this effect was submitted, and, while no definite conclusion was reached, it was unanimously decided to confine the discussion of the immigration problem to this one point.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Formal application was made to-day to the Court of Pardons for the pardon or parole of the thirty-five men now serving terms in the Snake Hill Penitentiary and the State prison for ballot-box stuffing during the Gubernatorial election of 1889. The application wan made in proper form by two petitions.
ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- Gov. Flower to-day made the following statement regarding his action in pardoning Thomas Hayes, who was serving a life sentence in Sing Sing prison for murder:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, Chief Naval Constructor Wilson renews his former recommendations looking to the allowance of an assistant to the Chief and to an increase in the pay of the chief clerk of his office.

The term of revivals of well-tried old plays was begun last night at Daly's Theatre, where a large and fashionable audience assembled, though the wind was blowing a gale out of doors and the flying snow was wet. Sheridan Knowles's five - act sentimental comedy, "The Hunchback," esteemed by that versatile, hard-working, and earnest playmaker his masterpiece, was then presented for the first time on that stage.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- President Carnot has asked M. Brisson to form a Ministry, retaining in the Cabinet M. Ribot and M. do Freyoinet. M. Bris- son promised to communicate his decision to President Carnot to-morrow, after conferring with his friends.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- The Kings County Electric Railway Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $625,000 for constructing about sixteen miles street surface road in Brooklyn. The terminal points of the road are the Thirty-ninth Street Ferry and Union Street and the City Line in the Twenty-sixth Ward: also Cooper Avenue and the City Line to the Eighteenth Ward.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- The Congressional committee to investigate the Reading Railroad Combine met here at 11 o'clock the morning in Room 23 of the Post Office Building. With the exception of Mr. Lind all the members of the committee were present. Charles F. Beach was present as counsel for the committee, and John G. Johnson and J.D. Campbell represented the Reading Company.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 29. -- The application of Hugh Ross and John McLuckie for their release on bail was heard before Judges Kennedy and McClung this afternoon. Capt. Breck resisted the application and W.J. Breunen appeared for Ross and McLuckie. Neither of the prisoners was in court and few persons were present.

At the meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, held in the See House, 29 Lafayette Place, yesterday, it was resolved that the cornerstone of the cathedral should be laid on Tuesday, Dec. 27, which is St. John's Day, according to the calendar of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- The only developments in the Schenck-Masterson matter to-day have been the indignation of the friends of the latter and the condemnation by fair-minded Democrats generally of the arbitrary action of the State Surveyor in demanding Masterson's resignation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- At the meeting of the House Appropriations Committee to-day, Pension Commissioner Raum submitted a statement which, he acknowledged, was incomplete, in that it presumably gave an inadequate showing of the liabilities of the Government in this direction.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- A mild sensation was caused in English political circles to-day by a cablegram from New-York, summarizing an article published in American newspapers purporting to give the details of Mr. Gladstone's latest home rule plan for Ireland.

The New-York Power Company was kindly treated yesterday by the Board of Aldermen, which granted it a franchise that will enable it to tear up the streets, avenues, alleys, lanes and public places of this city, to lay mains and pipes to make sewer connections, and to con struct manholes.

Hearing will be resumed next Thursday in the Superior Court of a case whose turning point is the rignt of a wife, under the so-called "married woman's act" of 1887, to receive real property directly from her husband and to dispose of such property without consulting her husband in regard to the transaction. The parties are Thomas Clarkin, a retired policeman, and his wife, Bridget Clarkin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- A week from to-day and the two Houses of the Fifty-second Con- gress will nave begun the second session of that body. Three months later that Congress will come to an end, and the term of a new one will begin at the same time that Benjamin Harrison surrenders to Grover Cleveland the office which was four years ago surrendered by Cleveland to Harrison.

The prize fight at Coney Island between "Buffalo" Costello and "Alec" Greggains was declared a draw about 4 o'clock yesterday morning. Eighty rounds had been contested and the spectators were disgusted at the feeble efforts of the men. In about fifty rounds not a blow was struck. The alleged fighters took fancy positions, worked their arms like piston rods, glared defiantly at each other, but, to the disgust of the onlookers, refused to fight.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 29. -- The greatest political steal in the history of Wyoming has just been perpetrated. At the recent elections the result was almost overwhelmingly Democratic and Populist. Two years ago on the Statehood issue the Republicans literally swept the State. Thus they had in this campaign absolute control of the election machinery.

The Ninth Notional Bank, at 409 Broadway, has offered a reward or $500 for the arrest of Johann C.K. Davidson, who was until recently employed by A. James Co., commission merchants in the South American trade at 667 Broadway, as a bookkeeper. The bank's interest in Davidsen grows out of the fact that he succeeded in forging his employer's name to checks aggregating $2,700 and in cashing them at the bank.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 29. -- The interest in the selection of a coadjutor to Archbishop Kenrick is growing, and the feeling is becoming intense. When the Rev. Father Brady went to the recent conference of Bishops at New-York he carried in his pocket a letter signed by Archbishop Kenrick asking that Father Brady be recommended by the hierarchy of the United States as Coadjutor Bishop of this province.

WOTHERSPOON -- WILLIAMS. In spite of the driving snowstorm last evening the Central Methodist Episcopal Church on Seventh Avenue, near Fourteenth Street, was crowded with guests to witness the marriage of Miss Louise Castree Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E.C. Williams, to James Wotherspoon. The wedding ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles S. Harrower at 8 o'clock.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- The death or Gen. Richard H. Jackson, Lieutenant Colonel of the Fourth Artillery, at the McPherson Barracks, last night, removes from the army the only offi- cer who filled every position consecutively from private to Brevet Major General.

WELCH -- LINDENSTEIN. At 7:30 o'clock last evening the Mendelssohn Assembly Rooms were the scene of the marriage of Miss Grace Frances Lindenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lindenstein, to David Welch. The ceremony was performed according to the ritual of the Catholic Church by the Rev. Father Skelly.

"No one who is not in the furnace business can have any idea or the amount of heat that is wasted in, a great city like New-York," remarked a furnace dealer to a TIMES reporter. "The leakage of heat is something enormous." "How's that?" inquired the reporter.

The Senate Committee on Immigration held a session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, which was devoted almost entirely to the consideration of the immigration question as bearing on the introduction of cholera into this country next year. The proposition submitted by Senator Chandler on Tuesday to prohibit immigration for one year was the basis of the discussion, and it was found advisable to devote other sessions to the same general line of investigation.

YANKTON, S.D., Nov. 30. -- Herbert Hall Winslow, author of the farce-comedy "The Idea," now being presented by Hallen and Hart, and the older pieces, "A Barrel of Money" and "Birds of a Feather," who resides at 70 West Ninety-third Streetm, New-York City, came to Yankton in June of this year, and entered upon the irksome task of acquiring what is known as a legal residence.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 30. -- The Nicaragua Canal Convention met this morning at 11 o'clock in Odd Fellows' Half with delegates present from every State and Territory in the Union. George L. Converse. President of the convention, took his seat, with Gov. Fostor of Louisiana, Gov. Fleming of Florida, and Gov. MoKinney of Virginia.

It is very fortunate that no partisan issue has thus far been made upon, the question of immigration. The most docile "organ" in the United States is at liberty to take any ground it chooses upon this subject, and the result of this liberty is that very few of the organs have taken any ground at all.
BISGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- A special to the Republican from Hancock, says:

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- Gov. Flower brought the Forest Commissioners up with a sharp turn last week, and followed up his work to-day by having John B. Locke, one of Senator Hill's pets, retired from the eighteen-hundred-dollar position of Inspector in the board and his place filled with Wallace Brooks of Lowville, Lewis County.

The green-goods men are going to eat turkey and plum pudding this Christmas, judging from their unusual activity and from the number of alluring schemes they have adopted for entrapping the unwary ruralists all over the Country.

EXMORE, Va., Nov. 30. -- Broadwater Inlet rang from shore to shore to-day with the centinnous reports of shotguns as Grover Cleveland and his fellow-sportsmen from the Broadwater Club fired at wild duck and brant.

The Conference of Day Nurseries opened its second day's session yesterday moraine at the Young Women's Christian Association Building at 10:30 o'clock, with Mrs. Richard Irvin in the chair. The attendance was large, comprising nearly all the ladies of the city whose names are prominent in charitable work, with delegates from Albany, Brooklyn, Buffalo, Boston, Hartford.

It became known in Wall Street yesterday that Jay Gould was a very sick man, and of all the men in the Street who are intimate with him or have dealings with him none questioned the truth of this statement.

The Park Commissioners adopted a resolution yesterday directing that the drawbridges over the Harlem River, at Third and Madison Avenues, Shall not be opened or operated between the hours of 6 and 10 A.M. and 4 and 7 P.M. alter Dec. 20, except when otherwise ordered, by the War Department at Washington.
The Board of General Appraisers yesterday finished its report to the Secretary of the Treasury for the year ending Oct. 31. It allows that in that time the reappraisements were as follows:

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- The Panama Canal Investigating Committee continued its inquiry to-day, M. Flory, Auditor in Bankruptcy, was called upon to give testimony as to how the money of the company had been expended, but he refused to give the committee the desired information on the ground that to do so would be a violation of professional secrecy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Some of the Democrats who have been watching for several days the dispatches from Wyoming and California are beginning to doubt the talk of Republicans about their delight at the Democratic control of both branches of the Congress, and to wonder whether the Republicans are not getting ready to steal the Senate next March by reversing the elections in States that nave been repotted as electing Democratic Legislatures.

The Building Fund of the New-York Athletic Club gained about $3,000 by an entertainment given last night at the Carnegie Music Hall. It was strictly amateur, and it was strictly burned cork throughout. Young gentlemen with blackened faces sang, danced, and cracked jokes, and as many people as could get into the hall encored everything they did.

JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 30. -- The Stone City Bank, a private institution, suspended payment today on account of a run caused by the shutting down of the Enterprise Company, one of the departments of the big wire-fence industry. The bank is operated by H. Fish Sons, and was thought to he one of the soundest financial institutions in the State.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- James E. Ostrander, for twenty-five years Treasurer of the Ulster County Savings Institution, and Matthew T. Trumpbour, Assistant Treasurer of the same institution for the same period, will be taken to Dannemora Prison to-morrow. Ostrander was found guilty to-day on a charge of perjury in swearing to a false statement as to the condition of the banking department, and Judge Fursman sentenced him to seven years' imprisonment.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 30. -- President-elect Grover Cleveland, who is now enjoying himself gunning at Broadwater Island in this State, may appear in court here Monday. Mr. Cleveland was this afternoon summoned to appear on that day in the Richmond Chancery Court, to answer a bill of complaint against Lawyer Willis B. Smith of this city.

Now that the plans of the Rapid Transit Commissioners are known in detail, interest in the proposed undertaking has greatly increased among all classes. It is conceded that the time has come when something must be done to aid the people of this city to got about with better facilities, and, above all things, to have improved methods in getting back and forth from their homes to their business places.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- The Journal says: "While the report that the Grand Jury suspended its finding against Lizzie A. Bordon in order that site mignt be examined by experts as to her sanity may prove incorrect, still such a thing is within the range of possibility. The law says:

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Nov. 30 -- P.M. To-day's stock market was wholly profession al. In the early trading the industrials, under the lead of Sugar, Lead, and Distilling and Cattle Feeding, were strong. It seems that a new pool has been formed in Sugar, and that yesterday's depression was part of its programme to acquire a line of the stock.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 30. -- Ten years ago Georgia was shocked from one end of the State to the other by the murder of a well-known druggist named Simmons by another well-known man, Samuel Hill. Hill had a beautiful wife, and assorted that Simmons was intimate with her. The murder was a cold-blooded one and occurred in the old National Hotel bar.

Negotiations are being carried on by which all the surface railroads in Brooklyn, representing an investment of about $10,000,000, will soon be controlled by one organization. A syndicate was formed some time ago, with J. W. Seligman Co. at its head, and this syndicate took the first step toward the acquisition of the railroads by purchasing the entire Atlantic Avenue system recently for $3,000,000.

Our readers will remember that during the first months of Mr. FOSTER'S occupation of the Treasury there were various utterances from subordinates in his department, the purport of which was that the $100,000,000 of gold reserve could be used to meet any demands on the Treasury for which current receipts were not sufficient.

The annual report of the Board of Directors of the Berkeley Athletic Association, Limited, to the stockholders has just been issued. It goes into details of the financial troubles that fell upon the association during the Presidency of Dr. White, but closes with the assurance that there will probably be a balance of income over expenditure for the current year of $2,400.
The cornerstone of the new building of the New-York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, at Second Avenue and Seventieth Street, was laid yesterday.

Mrs. Henry Whitman of Boston is a woman of uncommon talents who has accomplished note-worthy things in stained glass, designs for book covers, and paintings in pastel and oils. Very well known in Boston, her pictures appear occasionally at the Society of American Artists here, whore her flower painting has often been commended.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 30. -- The International Monetary Conference did not meet to-day. The next sitting will be on Friday, when it is expected that the committee considering the de Rothschild proposals will make a report.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- Herr Lasker arrived in Baltimore yesterday, where the Chess Club, headed by E.L. Ford, President of the Maryland Chess Association, and Prof. D. Melametas, gave him a hearty reception. Lasker will be the latter's guest during his stay in Baltimore.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The big fair and loan exhibition for the benefit of the Orange Memorial Hospital, which was opened in Music Hall yesterday afternoon and will continue until to-morrow night, is being visited by crowds of people from the Oranges and the neighboring cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The correspondence between Representative Fitch and the Treasury Department on account of John I. Davenport seems to have taken a turn against District Attorney Edward Mitchell.

The Congressional committee which has been examining into the Reading Railroad combine finished its labors in this city yesterday for the time being. There were two sessions, and at the close of the afternoon hearing Chairman Coombs announced that, all the witnesses available at this time having been examined, the committee would stand adjourned until the opening of Congress in Washington on Dec. 5.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- There was some excitement in provisions just at the close. During the morning there had been pretty general liquidation of everything on the list by the large stockholders, and this, in connection with the larger receipts of hogs and lower prices at the yards, gave the market a weak tone. Everything sold off, and it looked as if there was to be a material break all along the line.

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly gave a farawell dinner and dance to seventy-five acquaintances about Madison and Morristown last evening. Early next week they will close their handsome residence here and so to the city for the Winter.

Charles Droher, aged seventeen; Charles Adams, a "crook." and Henry Luens, a sailor of the man-of-war Portsmouth, were yesterday arraigned in Essex Market Police Court on charges of being concerned in a burglary in Red Bant, N.J., on Friday last.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day transacted the following business:

Prof. C.F. Chandler's letter in reference to street cleaning was received by Mayor Grant yesterday, and copies of it were sent by him to the members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, who will soon hare to decide just how much money shall be paid for street cleaning next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov 30. -- The enemies of civil service reform were informed, a few days before the appearance of Register Rosecrans's report, that the Register of the Treasury would "make an attack" on the civil service law. This report contains nothing to justify the rumor, the recommendations regarding the weight to be given in examinations for promotions to efficiency and scholastic merit, respectively, being far from an attack upon the merit system.
