Mr. Carson for absence at the last session received one negative vote. This led Dr. McKibben of the prosecution to give notice that hereafter the strict rule would be applied to the defense that now seemed to be used against the prosecution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Capt. Frank D. Baldwin, Inspector of Small Arms aud Practice, Department of the Missouri, returned yesterday afternoon after an extended tour of the Western posts. His mission was practically to find out what the posts had done on the ranges during the Autumn competition, and to learn something about the Indians and their condition.

The fracas between "Bob" Neville of Washington's exclusive hunting set and "Sam" Howland of this city, son-in-law of the late August Belmont, which began Nov. 17 in Secretary W.F. Wharton's box at the Madison Square Garden Horse Show was brought to a close with judicial solemnity yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in the Tombs.
In the mansion where he had lived and where he died, the solemn words or the funeral service of the Presbyterian Church were spoken yesterday afternoon over the body of Jay Gould.

WASHNGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the judgment of the Circuit Court in the well-Known Chicago lake-front cases. The lower court decided in favor of the local authorities, and hold that the Illinois Central did not have a right to use the submerged lands along the lake front for wharves, piers,

Dr. James Rosebrugh Leaming, one of the most famous specialists on chest diseases of the century, died Monday of slow consumption, aged seventy-three years, at his home, 18 West Thirty-eighth Street. He had been gradually declining for a year, and had not been in active practice for several years. He was born in 1820 at Groveland, Livingston County, this State, and was the son of William Leaming.

BRUSSELS, Dec 5 -- When the International Monetary Conference resumes its sittings tomorrow, the first matter requiring settlement will be whether the report of the committee appointed to consider the Rothschild plan shall be further debated or the proposals of the American delegates proceeded with. Mr. Rothschild, Sir C. Freemantle, and Sir William Houldsworth, all of whom are British delegates, desire some expression of opinion regarding Mr. Rothschild's plan from the full conference.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- The announcement made last night that Mgr. Satolli had been appointed by the Pope with full power to settle, without appeal, all religious questions between Bishops and priests in the United States has caused considerable excitement in Catholic circles here. The announcement was made by Cardinal Gibbons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Every opening of Congress, whether it be first sessions or second sessions, is new and interesting to somebody, and to somebody in great numbers. When it happens that there is to be a contest for the Speakership and a new man is to be elected to preside over the lower branch, partisan interest is added to unintelligent curiosity, and there is a crush.

ROME, Dec. 5 -- M. Clemenceau, in the name of the French political party of the Extreme Left, recently caused the Pope to be informed that if his party attained office, the Church would have nothing to fear from it.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 5 -- The body of a beautiful young woman was found late this afternoon in East Chester Creek, near Webber's Hotel, on the outskirts of the city. The Coroner was notified, and when the body was removed from the creek it was found that a rope was attached to the woman's waist, and that at the end of the rope there wore two stones weighing together about twenty-five pounds.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5 -- President-elect Cleveland, accompanied by Mrs. Cleveland, arrived here on the Lakewood special at 5:30 this afternoon. The train was fifteen minutes late on account of a detention on the Raritan River draw. Although Mr. Cleveland was offered the free use of the special parlor car, he refused to accept it, saying that an ordinary coach was good enough for him.

Charles W. Gardner, Chief Detective or Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, of which the Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst is President, was arrested Sunday night on the charge of being a suspicious person. He appeared in the Tombs Court yesterday morning, and at the request of the officers who accompanied him, and who said he was suspected of blackmail, was remanded until to-day and taken back to headquarters.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5 -- Jacob Gerber is once more in Omaha, having escaped from the Siberian exile to which he was deemed a year and a half ago. He arrived in the city last night after an absence of twenty-one months. After being a resident of this city for six years he returned to Russia to dispose of what property he had there and to bring his family to this country.

The cars of John K. Van Ness, a lawyer at 196 Broadway, whose residence is at Plainfleld, N.J., ought to have tingled yesterday. Judge Ingraham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, was talking about him. The language that he used was clear. He said that if Mr. Van Ness were only in court he might find himself in trouble unless he could explain certain matters.
The French Line steamship La Bretagne, which arrived from Havre Sunday, is still swinging to her anchor off Liberty Island awaiting permission from Washington for her passengers to land.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- From the way the January shorts went after pork and laid yesterday one might have thought that there was not to be any product in existence that month. The bulge started at the opening and had the excuse of light receipts of hogs and higher prices at the yards. Cudahy looked after pork and Hately after lard and saw that it was kept on the jump for a little while.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- Some apprehension is felt among the retail grocers, the hotels, the restaurants, and the housekeepers of the city because of the growing scarcity of the cranberries. For a week past several of the larger firms have had men all over New-Jersey trying to buy up all the berries in sight. In some cases they were successful, but many of them came back empty-handed.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- M. Ribot, at present Minister of Foreign Affairs, was asked this evening to form a Cabinet. Later he informed President Carnot that he had succeeded in forming a Cabinet, which is a reproduction of the Loubet Cabinet, except that M. Bourgeois, formerly Minister of Public Instruction and the Arts, will succeed M. Ricard as Minister of Justice and Public Worship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Engineers' Association of New-York recently made complaint that engineers employed on Bedlow's Island are compelled to work twelve hours a day in violation of the eight-hour law. An investigation was made by the Lighthouse Board, from which it appears that three of the men are regularly employed as keepers of light stations and that three others are Known as firemen, but are keepers just as much as the others.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- Attorney George A. Knight, addressing the jury in the Curtis case to-day, outlined what the defense would attempt to prove, and said it would be shown that much of the testimony of the prosecution is absolutely false. Concerning John Cann of Humboldt County, who testified to seeing the shooting of Officer Grant, counsel said:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 -- Edward Gorman, the Buffalo welter-weight pugilist, was arrested to-day on the charge of arson. German's saloon, at 13 West Broad Street, was partially burned between midnight and 2 o'clock this morning, and an investigation disclosed the fact that a box of straw and other Inflammable material had been piled in the cellar and a match applied.

A fair in aid of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, wag opened yesterday in the Sunday school room, and will be continued to-day and to-morrow, afternoon and evening.

A meeting of the committee appointed by the bondholders of the Yuengling Brewing Company was held yesterday afternoon at the St. Nicliolas Bank. All the members of the committee were present, together with Mr. Yuengling and Samuel Untermyer, the counsel for the company.

Among the passengers on the Canard steamer Aurania, which arrived yesterday, was Augustus T. Kerr. who has engaged the attention of the criminal authorities of this country and Europe since last Spring. Kerr at one time out a considerable figure in Kansas City, Mo., where he was employed as head bookkeeper in the home offices of the Jarvis-Conklin Mortgage and Trust Company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- Bishop McQuaid of the Diocese of Rochester said to an Associated Press reporter to-day, with reference to the powers conferred upon Mgr. Satolli by the Pope: "The appointment simply confers upon Mgr. Satolli the powers or an apostolic delegate. Authority of the same nature, though perhaps not so great in its extent, has been conferred upon American Bishops many times before this.

The Rev. William T. Elsing of the De Witt Memorial City Mission lectured last evening before the Working Women's Society at Cooper Institute on "Tenement-House Life in New-York." He thought down-town workingmen had been often slandered by being talked of as living in slums. Many of them had just as comfortable homes as working people in the country, and neat carpets, pianos, and libraries could be found in many tenement homes below Fourteenth Street.

The body of Jar Gould lies with that of his wife in the mausoleum in Woodlawn Cemetery. It was placed in the catacomb directly opposite that in which Mrs. Gould rests at 12:25 P.M. yesterday, after Chancellor MacCracken had read the brief burial service and offered prayer in the presence of the immediate family, a few relatives, and Dr. and Mrs. John P. Munn.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 6. -- The special committee of the merchants appointed by the Executive Committee in charge daring the recent strike has about completed the plan for the Merchants' Union, and it will he submitted to a special meeting of merchants, manufacturers, boss draymen, and other employers to be called in a few days.

There was a mysterious suicide at the Hotel San Remo, Seventy-fifth Street and Central Park West, yesterday morning. Enrique Bregaro, the head of the firm of Bregaro Co., commission merchants of 135 Pearl Street, this city, and of Ponee and Humacao, Porto Rico, shot himself through the head with a revolver while in his apartments at the hotel a little after 8 o'clock.

The Richmond County Republican General Committee had a lively session at Stapleton, S. I., yesterday afternoon. Only about twenty-five of the members were present, but the majority of them had something to say ahout members who had failed to do their duty on election day or had made deals with the Democrats.

"When the present Secretary of the Navy entered upon his duties," says President HARRISON in his message, "only three modern steel Teasels were in commission. The vessels since put in commission and to be put in commission during the Winter will make a total of nineteen during his administration of the department."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 -- The students who took an active part in the disturbance last Saturday night are Just now passing hours of fear and trembling. That some pretty severe sentences will be passed upon several of the men implicated is certain. Not only will the Faculty take action in the matter, but it is likely to be severe.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- The annual meeting of the Agricultural and Horticultural Society of Westchester County was held here to-day. Vice President Lewis S. Onderdonk presided, owing to the illness of President John B. Tompkins. The society was shown to tie in a flourishing condition. The receipts from the county fair were $34,993.02, and the disbursements $34,592.07, leaving a balance of $400.95 in the treasury.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 6 -- The Directors of the Olympic Club have definitely fixed the date of the triple event which, is to maintain the club's record for high-class sport during the carnival and other seasons. In order to avoid a conflict with the carnival, the dates have been selected on the 1st, 2d, and 3d of March.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- Several big politicians have been in Albany to-day, but they imparted very little information of value. Early in the day Edward Murphy, Jr., with grip in hand, made his appearance. Later on he was joined by Richard Croker, and both proceeded to the Capitol and talked for an hour with Gov. Flower. The conversation, the Governor said later, was simply of a friendly nature, and but little politics was discussed.

Some important testimony as to the value of road improvement to the farming and general industries of the country was brought out at the regular monthly meeting of the Farmers' Club of the American Institute, at 113 West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon.

Just after the election prominent Republicans professed a good deal of satisfaction at the prospect that after the 4th of March next the Democratic Party would control the United States Senate as well as the House and the executive department of the Government. They wished to see the Democrats have full swing and complete responsibility.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Times says: "Mr. Harrison ascribes the drain of gold from America to political movements in Europe. By many of the Republican leaders, however, nothing of the kind is required to explain a phenomenon which everybody acquainted with the first principles of currency legislation could predict with absolute confidence when America first undertook to control the market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The crowds that yesterday filled the galleries of the Senate and the House so comfortably did not return to the Capitol this morning, and the attendance of Senators and Representatives seemed smaller when they were called to order. It had been announced that the President's message would be transmitted to the Congress, but the interest in that communication, as indicated by the attendance upon its reading, was far from absorbing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Senator McPherson speaks very frankly about his position in the approaching Senatorial election in New-Jersey. As already stated in a dispatch to THE TIMES, he not only does not oppose Gov. Abbett's desire to be Senator, but he approves it for reasons of political friendship and because he thinks that Gov. Abbett has won the place by political service.

Dr. E.W. Siemens, the well-Known engineer and electrician, died yesterday at Berlin. He was born at Lenthe, In Hanover, in 1816, and was educated at the Lubec Gymnasium. He joined the Prussian Artillery in 1834, where his eminent talents soon attracted notice, and, having passed through the military schools, gained him the rank of Lieutenant in 1837.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- This was the day fixed for the hearing of the case of Charlie Mitchell, the pugilist, by Judge Sir Peter Edlin, in the Clerkenwell Sessions. Mitchell was sentenced in the Bow Street Police Court on Oct. 7 last to two months' imprisonment at hard labor for brutally assaulting the aged keeper of a lodging house in the Strand.

At the Park Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street last evening Miss Amelia Robertson Hurray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Irvin Murray, was married to Dr. Willard Avery Heacock by the Rev. Anson P. Atterbury, pastor of the church. The best man was the bride's brother, J. Irvin Murray, and Dr. E.A. Tucker, J. Statesbury, F.A. Pattison, I.M. Sutton, C.S. Hilton, and F.S. Coleman served as ushers.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 6. -- The people of this town are very much worked up over an election which will take place on Friday and Saturday of this week, and the only thing the town is talking about is "electric railways" and how the town will be benefited by them.

The work on the building of the new Empire Theatre, at Fortieth Street and Broadway, is now completed, and the house is in the hands of the plasterers and decorators. Charles Frohman and Rich Harris, the lessees, claim that the Empire is thoroughly fire-proof, and that it is the only stock theatre in New-York on the ground floor.

The reports sent out from Paris concerning the discoveries thus far made by the Panama Canal investigating committee are fragmentary and possibly misleading with respect to the disposition of the canal company's money in certain cases, but enough has been disclosed to show a vast scheme of bribery, with members of the Cabinet among the beneficiaries.

The Folios Commissioners began preparations yesterday for the election on Feb. 14 of thirty-two delegates at large and thirty district delegates to the Constitutional Convention. They first read and filed an opinion of Corporation Counsel Clark, who had been asked to say if the election was a general or special one.

MANCHESTER, S.H., Dec. 6. -- Fire broke out in the town of Raymond about 11:30 last night, and this morning twenty-five buildings are in ruins. The town has no Fire Department and not a liydrant, ladder, or apparatus of any kind. The fire, when first started, might have been easily extinguished had there been any means at hand.
ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- The appeal of Carlyle W. Harris from his conviction of causing the death of his wife in New-York City by morphine poisoning came up before the Court of Appeals to-day.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 6. -- The body of the young woman which was found in East Cheater Creek, near hero, yesterday afternoon, was this morning identified by George Newton, a tailor living at 1,787 Amsterdam Avenue, New-York City. After due examination he declared it was that of his step-daughter, Ella Newton. She had been, missing from home since Sunday afternoon.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The members of the Centre Party in the Reichstag have held three conferences to decide upon the course, the party would follow regarding the Army bill. It was generally believed that a split would occur in the party over the measure, and that thirty-four of the Southern members would vote with the Opposition and the seventy-six others with the Government.

The St. Nicholas Society hang its banners on the walls of Delmonieo's dining hall last night, and there its members assembled to pay fitting honor to the memory of their patron saint. It was the fifty-eighth annual reunion of the socity and 240 members and their guests were there to join in the festivity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The victory of the city in the lake-front case gives the most unbounded satisfaction to all members of the City Government, and to the public generally. The Illinois Central officials and attorneys, however, are bitterly disappointed, for it means that they cannot go on making land along the lake shore, and that the right to build wharves and docks in the harbor does not belong to them, but to the city.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The fact that State Senator Barrett and his eight Democratic colleagues in the Assembly got together last night and formally declared for James Smith, Jr., is one of the interesting freaks of the progressing campaign for the United States Senatorship in New-Jersey.

The Navy Department will endeavor to place the new armored cruiser Maine in commission for service in the Columbian naval review at Hampton Roads, Virginia, next April. This action will be in accordance with Secretary Tracy's express desire to have the big-ship present with the fleet. The Maine is at present in dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where she is awaiting the armor plating to be placed on her hull and turrets.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- The Public Ledger Building, at the southwest corner of Birth, and Chestnut Streets, was badly damaged this evening by fire and water. The fire was confined almost entirely to the composing room, situated on the top floor, but a torrent of water poured down through the building, flooding every floor in the structure.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 6. -- This community is just now interested in a new religious sect, the members of which call themselves the "Holy Ones." E. Loney, who came here from Richmond, Va., is the leader. He claims to be sent of God to give the last warning to the saints, and admonishes his hearers to sell all their property and give it to the sustenance of the Gospel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The annual report of Engineer in Chief G.W. Melville of the navy shares with the report of the Chief of Ordnance the distinction of being worth reading. Every one who has followed the course of the conflict between line and staff in the navy has awaited with interest this report of Mr. Melville. Those who looked for any sensational treatment of the controversy by Mr. Melville will be disappointed.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 6 -- The International Monetary Conference resumed its sitting to-day and continued its discussion of the report of the committee which examined into the Rothschild proposals.

It was noticed last week that Police Superintendent Byrnes was very busy during his regular hours of duty, and remained at his office long after the time he usually left Police Headquarters. This was the case on Sunday and yesterday, and at 10 o'clock last night, when he called the newspaper men into his sanctum, he looked so grave that it was evident he was not to tell a story bearing on ordinary police business.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Dec. 6. -- The Hon. W.W. Hart, the Master and examiner appointed in the suit of Matthias H. Arnot against the Philadelphia and Reading and the other corporations interested in the Beading deal, filed his report in the office of the Prothonotary here this afternoon. The report occupies over 200 type-written pages, and is one of the largest documents ever filed in the Prothonotary's office.

The Christmas numbers of foreign illustrated papers have their own line of artistic growth. If one may judge that the pace is slow, one must admit that the course is run only once a year. Yule Tide (Cassell) contains four cartoons in colors, a large colored plate of three faces of women decked with the rose, the shamrock, and the thistle, representing England, Ireland, and Scotland, and illustrations of the text by Harry Furniss.

The first dance of Mrs. John T. Hall's class took place last evening in the large ballroom at Sherry's. There was an attendance of about 250, and all the arrangements were successfully carried out. The entire second floor was used. While dancing was going on under the rotunda the hall and the pink room were turned into drawing rooms.

The farewell annual message of Mr. HARRISON is an unexpectedly entertaining document. Those who had looked forward to a mere dry, businesslike statement of the condition of public affairs, with such recommendations as seemed sufficiently urgent, will be agreeably disappointed. No reader weary with the serious discussion of national politics and policies should fail to study this message.

Plans have been drawn for an eight-story building on the land where the late Edmund H. Schermerhorn had his city home. In Twenty-third Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Arrangements are already in progress for the removal of the present building, and operations upon the new one will begin as early in the Spring as weather will permit.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Dec. 6 -- P.M. The stock market suffered a reaction to-day, the most important declines being in those stocks which have recently advanced sharply. Within a few days a large part of the short interest has been eliminated, and conditions consequently favored a hear attack. The raid was made at the opening, Sugar being the principal object of attack.

A fire which had its origin on the third or fourth floor of 30 Reade Street at 4:40 o' clock yesterday morning was not put out until the building was wrecked and engines, summoned by four alarms, had thrown water on the flames for more than two hours and a half.

The play called "Judah," by Henry Arthur Jones, revived at the Star Theatre Monday night, will be repeated there to-night and Saturday afternoon. "John Needham's Double" will be substituted for it at other performances. The present opportunity, therefore, to see a play justly esteemed as one of the strongest in treatment and most original in subject produced by an English dramatist in recent years, is limited.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The fifth annual boxing and wrestling championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States will be held in this city Thursday and Saturday nights, Jan. 5 and 7, 1893, under the auspices of the Philadelphia Amateur Swimming Club.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 6. -- President-elect Cleveland arose at an early hour this morning. He looked much refreshed after his night's rest and took a sharp walk before breakfast.
Mayor elect Thomas P. Gilroy, who returned from his trip to the Pacific coast Monday, was back at his desk in the Department of Public Works yesterday forenoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- The sale of Washington-Madison papers, coming from the estate of J.C. McGuire of Washington, was began to-day. Historians, litterateurs, autograph gatherers, and book lovers assembled in full force. Among the local buyers present were Simon Gratz, M. Pollock, Frank Marshall, J.H. Lambert, William S. Baker, Charles R. Hildburn, Dr. Edward Moris, and Howard Edwards.

ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- The State canals were officially closed to-day. Last night at midnight was the time set for this event, but Superintendent of Public Works Hannan concluded that he would keep certain sections manned, and get through such boats as were near their destinations or close to tide water.

The Silversmiths' Company is the title of an organization or company which it is proposed to form by a number of the leading silversmiths of the country, including such well-known houses as the Gorham Manufacturing Company, the Whiting Manufacturing Company, the George W. Shiebler Manufacturing Company, and Dominick Haff of this city, and the Towle Manufacturing Company of North Adams, Mass.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 7 -- Ellsworth Wyatt, a member of the Dalton gang, who was arrested in Terre Haute, Ind., was brought to this city at midnight and placed in jail. Sheriff Bonwall of Kiowa County, Kan., and Sheriff Hixson of Guthrie, Oklahoma, both of whom had requisitions for Wyatt. accompanied him, and the dispute as to which State will prosecute him has not been settled.

United States Sub-Treasurer Eills H. Roberts has received a written request from the Treasury Department at Washington to use every effort at his command to gather in all the five-hundred-dollar United States legal-tender notes of the issues prior to that of 1880 outstanding in his bailiwick.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 7 -- Mr. Henry W. Cannon, one of the American delegates and President of the Chase National Bank, has asked the Monetary Conference Committee to discuss the proposals of the American delegates as stated to the plenary conference. Those proposals substantially said:

The stockholders of the Providence and Spring- field Hallroad met in Providence yesterday and elected the following Directors: William Tinkman, William Pope, Fenner H. Peckham, Jr., B.F. Vaughan, Charles L. Vaughan, Providence: Albert L. Sayles, Pascoag; Peter B. Wickoff, New-York; F. H. Prince, C.A. Prince, Boston. The Directors subsequently elected B.F. Vaughan President, William Tinkham Chairman, and William H. Pope Secretary and Treasurer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The management of the Rock Island Railroad has declined to treat with the committee that has been here for a week trying to induce the company to adopt a new schedule of rules and wages for the employes in the telegraph department of that system. The committee was from the Order of Railway Telegraphers, and claimed to represent a majority of the Rock Island operators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Following the example of similar clubs in other cities, the National Capital Press Club of this city is to have a special benefit entertainment at Albaugh's Opera House on Friday, Dec. 16, at noon. Ex-Speaker Reed is expected to deliver an address on "What I Know About. Newspaper Men." "Private" John Allen of Mississippi, of the House, will talk about "What I Don't Know About Newspaper Men."
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Fred Leslie, the well-known and popular burlesque actor, died to-day. His death, has caused the greatest regret among theatregoers and his colleagues.

After a long discussion yesterday, the Board of Education adopted the resolution submitted by Commissioner Hubbell that the board should ask the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to appropriate $8,000 for the purpose of making an exhibit at the World's Fair of what had been accomplished in educational matters in this city.

The annual meeting of the women's National Indian Association was opened yesterday morning at the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, at the corner or Clinton and Lafayette Avenues, Brooklyn. There were about 200 delegates present, who came from nearly every State in the Union.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Gov. Flower to-day pardoned Frank Rhoingold, the cloakmaker, who in May, 1891, was sentenced to five years and eight months for burglary, second degree. Regarding his action in this case, Gov. Flower this afternoon said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Upon the brief and general announcement that the re-election of Mr. Crisp to the Speakership will be disputed, and that he will probably have to face either Breckinridge, Bynum, or Wilson of West Virginia as a candidate, the Crisp men have begun their denials. They characterize the opposition as a "mere whisper," and assume that it will not amount to anything more.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, President of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, busied himself yesterday in preparing an answer to the statements made by Superintendent Byrnes respecting the society and the crusade it is prosecuting against the Police Department.

The first public meeting to consider the project for the consolidation of New-York and Brooklyn drew to the Real Estate Exchange in Brooklyn yesterday an attendance that completely filled the spacious auction room. It was a gathering composed evidently of men capable of understanding the subject and of weighing its merits.

Several members of the Republican National Committee were in the city yesterday. Among them William J. Campbell of Illinois, Person C. Cheney of New-Hampshire, Joseph H. Manley of Maine, M.H. De Young of California, and James S. Clarkson of Iowa, who has been living at the Plaza Hotel since the campaign closed. The members said it was wholly by accident that so many of them were here at the same time.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The Panama Canal Committee to-day reaffirmed its resolution declaring the necessity of an autopsy on the body of Baron de Reinach. It is expected that the Government will to-morrow announce its intention to have an autopsy performed.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The National Agricultural Conference, called for the purpose of directing public attention in an emphatic manner to the present grave condition of agricultural affairs, met at 11 o'clock this morning in St. James's Hall. Fully 1,500 delegates from over 250 agricultural associations were present. The Marquis of Huntly and many members of the House of Commons were also in attendance.

The suit brought by Cassius H. Read to compel Edward S. Stokes of the Hoffman House to reconvey to him land in Suffolk County, valued at over $100,000, came up in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on a motion to make a technical amendment in Stokes's answer.

The application to have continued a temporary injunction restraining the Panama Railroad Company from making any contract with the Chilean line of steamships, the temporary injunction having been obtained by Edward Lauterbach, representing the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was argued yesterday before Judge Ingraham in the Supreme Court, Chambers.

There are a good many politicians of the Hill machine in this State who are growing very nervous over the things that may happen to that machine as a result of the election of Edward Murphy, Jr., of Troy, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, to the United States Senate in place of Frank Hiscock.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- The following letter, with inclosures, was to-day sent by George W. Childs, proprietor of the burned-out Ledger, to Mayor Stuart:

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 7 -- Since last June the mails in the Augusta Post Office have been systematically robbed, and considerable money -- how much cannot be estimated -- has been stolen, and not until last night was the perpetrator detected and captured.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 7 -- The demoralization into which that eminent swashbuckier, Mayor "Pat" Gleason, has succeeded in plunging Long Island City has fired the hearts of his understrappers to emulate his success on a smaller scale. The result is a school war which disgraces the city and again illustrates the methods that characterize the Gleason administration.

Persons with an eye for the picturesque and those who are fond of seeing pretty girls in quaint costumes should take a walk down the "Japanese street" which was thrown open for traffic yesterday at 1,476 and 1,478 Broadway. The "Japanese street" is a new style of church fair, and it is intended to help out the funds of the Central Congregational Church at 309 West Fifty-seventh Street.

An interview with Archbishop Corrigan, in which he is made to say that Dr. McGlynn was coining back to the Church, and that Archbishop Satolli had arranged a settlement satisfactory to both the Anti-Poverty people and to the Archdiocese of New-York, appeared yesterday in a morning paper which is credited with being the Archbishop's official organ.

About twenty years ago an English visitor to this country, in a public address, made what was then a just discrimination in a striking remark: "In England," he said, "a rich man wishes merely to found a family; in America he still aspires to found an institution." The remark could not with equal justice have been made much later.
MADRID, Dec. 7 -- The Government has arranged to ask the coming Chambers for a credit of 750,000 pesetas for the expenses of the Spanish representation at the Chicago Columbian Exhibition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was to be expected that the information printed last west on this side of the Atlantic would be received with dismay and objurgation by sundry slow-witted newspapers who are apt to lose both breath and temper when a contemporary "cuts out the running" at too fast a pace.

The annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury gives the same general figures as to the condition of the finances that were given by Mr. HARRISON in his annual message. They are neither sufficiently full nor sufficiently clear to do away with the need of the inquiry proposed in Mr. DOCKERY'S resolutions, which will doubtless be promptly acted on by the House.

Over fifty paintings from the collection of the late James R. Osgood were sold at executor's sale last night at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The paintings were for the most part unimportant and the prices realized were insignificant. The earlier American landscape school was chiefly represented, although several of the later men were represented by indifferent examples.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- At the annual meeting of the New-York State Trotting Horse Breeders' Association, held here at the Powers Hotel, those officers were elected: President -- Dr. J.W. Day of Waterloo; Vice President -- H.M. Little; Second Vice President -- Leslie W. Russell; Third Vice President -- Jacop Ruppert; Secretary and Treasurer -- M.E. Serviss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The President transmitted to the Senate to-day a letter of Secretary of State Foster, in response to a resolution adopted at the last session, asking for information about the agreement between Great Britain and the United States as to the naval force of each country on the great lakes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Union of American Hebrew Congregations closed its sessions to-day. The financial committee reported that the total receipts were $26,539. The maintenance of the Hebrew Union College for seventeen months amounted to $22,804. A. Bloom of Cincinnati made an appeal for an increase in the endowment of the college.

The short session, with its crowded calendar bequeathed from the session preceding, and augmented by contributions of its own, is rarely favorable either to army or navy measures. The regular appropriations are attended to, and sometimes a bit of general legislation can be smuggled into them.

Members of the Board of Education read with Interest the article in yesterday's TIMES that set forth that a number of the Commissioners had determined to got rid of President Hunt and elect another man who would not be subservient to the ring that exists in the board.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The proposal to abolish the United States Diplomatic Service, stated last month in some American journals, and the fact that President-elect Cleveland will soon be called on to appoint successors to most of the incumbents of the American legations, has directed considerable attention in Europe to the subject.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7 -- Judge Pickett furnished a startling denouement to the Yale freshman disturbance Saturday night. When in the City Police Court this morning he ruled that because of the evidence presented before him the affair must be termed a riot, and was, therefore, to be treated in an entirely different manner from that planned by the Prosecuting Attorney.

BUTTE. Mon., Dec. 7 -- A strikingly suggestive letter was to-day sent to Secretary Foster of the United States Treasury Department at Washington by Superintendent Allen of the Butte and Boston Mining Company of this city. The letter is an offer to make any amount of much better silver dollars for 90 cents apiece than are at present in use.

The Belleflower case came to an unexpected conclusion when the session of the Board of Review opened at about 10 A.M. yesterday morning. When President Johnston took the chair, and before any case was called, Gen. A.C. Harbison entered the room. He was starter at Lexington on Oct. 14 last, when the race in question was trotted.

It was again rumored yesterday that the Metropolitan Traction Company had secured control of the Forty-second Street and Boulevard horse-car lines. According to the story, the present Boulevard cars would be withdrawn early in the new year and transfers made at Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street for the Grand Central Station, and at Forty-fourth Street for the Broadway line.

Wallace Ogden, a well-known Custom House broker, whose office is at 58 Wall Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Special Treasury Agent Charles H. Traitteur, charged with defrauding the United States Government of customs duties. The irregularities with which he is charged cover a period of nearly a year, and, although their extent has not yet been ascertained, the loss to the Government was estimated by Custom House officials yesterday at about $1,200.

Mr. Cleveland reached this city from Lakewood yesterday morning at 10:30 o'clock and went at once to his home, 12 West Fifty-first Street, where he remained nearly all day. He received a few callers and devoted a considerable portion of the day to answering letters.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 7 -- Snow has been falling here since 10 o'clock last night. Street-car traffic has been entirely abandoned. The snow is accompanied by a high wind from the north, and it is growing colder, with a good prospect of a blizzard. Railroads centring in Omaha report all trains greatly delayed, and some have been abandoned.

Arrangements for laying the cornerstone of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on St. John's Day, Tuesday, Dec. 27, are rapidly completing by Thomas P. Browne, sexton of St. Agnes's Chapel, who has been intrusted with, the work by the committee of which Bishop Potter is Chairman.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- The State Forest Commission has found enough surplus to purchase 960 acres of land at $1.50 per acre in Township 14, Essex County. This, the Commissioners declare, is the last purchase they can make this year. They will ask the Legislature for $750,000, the amount denied them last winter, with which to purchase lands within the line of the Adirondack Park.

UNIONVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- This little village, on the New-York and Harlem Railroad, in Westchester County, was shocked yesterday by the suicide, late in the afternoon, of Miss Ida A. Symonds, aged twenty-seven, one of the most popular young ladies of the place. She was a daughter of Malcolm Symonds, a farmer living near the railroad station.

The coming Summer the frugal housewife with a taste for "home decoration" will be able to make card receivers, workboxes, and other attractive articles of household use out of her berry boxes without being troubled by the corner grocer with incessant demands for the return of the cherished fruit receptacles.

Decisions were handed down yesterday by Judge Ingraham in the Supreme Court on two motions made in the suits growing out of the assignment or Charles Burkhalter Co., wholesale grocers, to Charles H. Fancher, President of the Irving National Bank. Mr. Fancher is removed from the position of Trustee, and Henry Winthrop Gray is appointed receiver.

The Board of Electrical Control has recently been making an investigation to ascertain where overhead wires have been strung by the electrical companies without permits from the board. Yesterday the Mayor sent a communication to Commissioner of Public Works Gilroy, inclosing a list of overhead wires reported to him as being up without permits, and directing Mr. Gilroy to remove them as obstructions as soon as possible.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 7 -- Judge Hallett, in the United States Court, yesterday ordered that the replication to the answer of Victor Elliott in the suit of Amy C. Seely against George W. Taylor be stricken out.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 7 -- One stage of the mighty struggle of the Republicans to save Francis E. Warren his place in the United States Senate will culminate in the morning. The vote will be canvassed by the Republican board, with Mr. Barber, who has been acting Governor, at the head. They will pay no attention to Gov. Osborne, who was elected to fill an unexpired term, and who has qualified.

Miss Strong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Strong of 176 Madison Aveuno, made her social debut yesterday afternoon. The reception which was given from 4 to 7 o'clock was one of the largest of the season. Miss Strong was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Strong, Mrs. Burke-Roche, and Mrs. Henry Robbins. Miss Strong's debut gown was a Parisian conception in pale yellow silk striped with white.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 7 -- A valuable feature of the annual report of the Iowa Railroad Commissioners is the fine showing it makes of the prosperity of Iowa railroads. They were never so prosperous as they are now. Their earnings are larger than ever before. They are paying the highest wages they have ever paid, and the number of their employes increased from 27,583 in 1891 to 30,492 in 1892.
Congressman Belden of Syracuse was in the city yesterday. He said he did not expect any important legislation on the tariff or other questions of a party nature at this session of Congress.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 7 -- The Smith heresy trial is nearing its completion of the portion which will be open to the public. Prof. Smith closed his argument to-day, presenting in strictly logical form his view of the case, and summing up with the claim that the committee had failed to show anything in his writing or teaching to justify a verdict of guilty.

NEW-YORK, Wednesday, Dec. 7 -- P.M. The reaction which set in yesterday was short lived. There was some hesitation this morning, but in the afternoon prices became firm and at the close were quite strong. The raid of yesterday failed to dislodge any long stock, and when the shorts endeavored to cover to-day the market moved up on them.

A dinner to Charles Emory Smith, given by ex-Postmaster General Thomas L. James in the famous alcove room of the Union League Club, afforded pleasure to a small party of distinguished gentlemen last night. The diners were seated at a round table, which was attractively decorated with flowers, a large floral mound rising in the centre.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 7 -- The controversy between the Esher and Dubbs factions of the Evangelical Church has got into the Iowa courts and is occupying the attention of Judge Conrad of this district. The case was brought in the form of a petition for an injunction restraining the Esher faction from gaining possession of the church property in Des Moines, and involves the three churches of the Evangelical Association of this city.

The intention, of Commodore George W. Melville, Chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department, as announced in Wednesday's TIMES, to fit out the cruiser Chicago and the dispatch vessel Dolphin with modern high-powered engines met with general approval yesterday among most Engineer officers at this port.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 7 -- The ceremony of swearing in the new Ministry took place this afternoon. The new members of the Cabinet, A.R. Angers and Mr. Ives, were present, and took the oaths of allegiance of Privy Councilor and of office. Messrs. Curran, Wood, and Wallace toot the oaths of allegiance and office, not being called to the Privy Council.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 7 -- At about 4:15 o'clock this morning Train No. 52, north-bound express from New-York, met with an accident at Ferrisburg which resulted in injuries to several persons, but was, fortunately, unattended by fatal effect. A broken wheel under a sleeping car caused the derailment of that car and a passenger coach forward of it, the two going down a fifteen-foot embankment.

The smile which James W. Morrissey wore when his suit against Mrs. Emma M. Raymond and Miss Mary E.C. Bancker to recover $5,000 for breach of contract was called for trial Tuesday before Judge Beach and a jury, in the Supreme Court, faded from his face yesterday. Judge Beach dismissed the complaint, and Mr. Morrissey looked sad.

The American Harveyized plate recently sent to Russia for entry in the competitive international armor test will be tested on the Ochta proving grounds on Dec. 10, instant. Information to this effect was received in this city yesterday from St. Petersburg. To a TIMES representative Mr. H.A. Harvey, the inventor of the American plate, said yesterday that the American plate was shipped from England on Oct. 31 last.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Charles Wilson Rowe of this city was held in $1,500 bail to-day to answer a charge of obtaining goods on false pretenses, involving a new swindling scheme. The representatives of William Hamlin of Afton, Seneca County, N.Y., was the prosecutor, and testified that Rowe had secured over $700 worth of lumber from him on promise to remit the amount on delivery.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 7 -- A man who has the appearance of a priest is locked up in the Second Precinct Station House in this city accused of obtaining money under false pretenses. He was arrested on the streets during the afternoon on the complaint of Father John McGuire of St. Mary's Church and a number of his parishioners.

The twelfth annual report of the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Childdren shows that since July 18 forty-three children have been received and cared for at "The Shelter," the new house of refuge at 105 Schermerhorn Street, which was opened on that date.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Among the collectors unabated interest continued to-day in the auction sale of the Washington-Madison papers and other Revolutionary letters and relics, held at the art salesrooms of Thomas Birch's Sons, and some of the prices obtained showed that the mania for relics of the Revolutionary period was stronger at the moment than ever before.

Agents of the French Steamship Company are not yet qto clear as to the exact reason why their steamship La Bretagne was detained two days in the bay while other transatlantic vessels were allowed to land their passengers at once without molestation. In an interview yesterday the Collector said that the detention was partly due to the fact that the vessel's passengers were classed as "first," "second," and "third."
MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 7 -- The body of Ella Newton, who was found drowned in East Chester Creek Monday afternoon, was to-day removed to New-York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Cullom, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce, has very little to say relative to the decision of Judge Gresham affecting the validity of the inter-State commerce law, but his manner indicates that he is very indignant over the opinion. "I have not read it and I do not care to say much until I have," said Mr. Cullom.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Agricultural Conference resumed its session in St. James's Hall to-day and proceeded with the programme laid down for discussion.

Thomas F. Oakes, President of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, bought from Edward F. De Lancey last Spring twenty-two acres of land at Orienta Point in Mamaroneck, on Long Island Sound, at the rate of $5,000 an acre. Mr. De Lancey gave Mr. Oakes a warrantee deed which included the land between high and low water mark.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Dec. 8 -- Jacob B. Crowell of Greencastle, Penn., is in Hagerstown in search of two men who yesterday defrauded him out of $5,000. A man visited Mr. Crowell and said that he was a son of Alexander Stewart of Scotland, Penn., and the cashier of a bank in Harrisburg.

A special meeting of the Executive Commit- tee of the New-York Citizens' Alliance was held yesterday afternoon in the office of ex-Senator John G. Boyd, in THE NEW-YORK TIMES Building, at which three resolutions regarding matters of current interest were adopted.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Haussone, Progressist, questioned the Government in regard to the measures employed in suppressing the recent labor disturbances at Tilleur.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 -- Naval Cadet Fred K. Perkins of California was a pepperbox while in the academy and kept himself in constant trouble, and in departing he has left a legacy of evil to thirteen of his admirers.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 8 -- That Mayor "Pat" Gleason of Long Island City is in desperate straits and forced to expedients which, for cool impudence, surpass any of his previous efforts is apparent. City Clerk Thomas P. Burke, who astonished the community by issuing the certificate of re-election to Gleason, despite a plurality for Sanford, has disappeared, and the city is in a fresh ferment.

Sylvester F. Wilson, the manager of girls baseball clubs, who was convicted over a year ago of the abduction of fifteen-year-old Libbie Sunderland, has secured another opportunity to make a fight against serving out the sentence imposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The second of the thirteen-inch guns being made at the Washington Navy Yard met with an accident to-day. In shrinking the jacket over the tube of the gun the jacket grasped the tube unevenly, not fitting in its proper place. Jackets have been successfully removed from smaller guns, although never from one of this calibre.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The first general meeting of the Society of the Colonial Dames of New-Jersey was held here to-day and fifty ladies from various parts of the State attended. They were received by the Misses Barbour, who were attired in Colonial costumes.

The Floating Hotel Danforth is the name of a novel craft that is anchored off the Prentice Stores Cook, Brooklyn. The Danforth was built with all modern improvements at Bath, Me., by Kelley, Spear Co., and is to be taken to New-Smyrna, Fla., whence she will make trips up the Hillsborough and Indian Rivers, returning to New-Smyrna every two weeks.

The Sims-Edison electric torpedo has now been perfected so that it will reach the objective point of attack -- that is to say, the enemy's man-of-war-despite all obstacles in the shape of steel chains, logs, The most serious difficulty in the way of reaching the enemy's vessel would be offered by logs or spars snchored around the ship at a considerable distance from it.

One phase of the interminable litigation between W.E.D. Stokes and his cousin Edward S. Stokes was before Judge Dugro in the Superior Court yesterday. On behalf of W.E. D. Stokes a motion was made to strike out the answer of Edward S. Stokes in the suit to recover $34,200 on four promissory notes. There are other suits pending.

JOHN STRONG NEWBERRY. Prof. John Strong Newberry of Columbia College died at New-Haven, Conn., Wednesday night. He was about seventy years old, having been born in Windsor, Conn., in 1822. He was graduated from Western Reserve College in 1846 and from Cleveland Medical College in 1848.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- William B. Wadsworth, an agent and bill collector of this city, is among the missing. He left his wife and two children behind him, not to mention many creditors. Among them are Frederick Bebbington of the New-York Security Company, Joseph Conway, a coachman, bereft of $200; William McGee and wife, losers of $900; Mrs. Woodruff, $200 poorer, and E.R. Lindsay, who is reported to be several hundred dollars out.

The extraordinary atmospheric performances which New-Yorkers have witnessed within the past few months have been accounted for at last. The Secretary of the weather is preparing a big display for the World's Fair and has been testing his various pieces of apparatus and rehearsing his different specialties so as to make sure that everything is in working order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Representative C.A.O. McLellan of Indiana is quoted as telling a story to illustrate the character of the campaign of the Republicans in his State, and the personal popularity of Postmaster General Wanamaker.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The declaration of the new Ministry was read in the Senate to-day by M. Loubet, Minister of the Interior, and in the Chamber of Deputies by M. Ribot, the Prime Minister. The declaration recalled the events that caused the recent political crisis and affirmed the intention of the Cabinet to aid the Chamber of Deputies by every means in its power to throw light upon The Panama Canal affair.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- During the tours of investigation by Gov. Flower last Summer he became convinced or two things, viz., that New-York State should have better roads and that the Adirondack forest should he preserved. So firmly has he settled these things in his mind that he will make strong recommendations, it is said, in his forthcoming message relative thereto.

Brooklyn has at last discovered that there is some advantage to itself in the proposal to create Greater New-York. Brooklyn's discovery came shortly after the rendering of the annual tax bills, which were discovered to be approximately double the tax bills rendered in New-York. Now, THE TIMES is not in the least doubt regarding the merits of consolidation.

The man who is believed, to have committed all the petty robberies that have occurred in Brooklyn during the past month was arraigned before Police Justice Tighe yesterday and held for examination. He said he was Herbert Nichols, aged nineteen years, and that he lived in a furnished room on Sixth Avenue, this city.

The Panama Canal Committee now sitting in Paris will confine its inquiry for the present to the evidence concerning the payment of bribes to legislators, members of the Cabinet, and the journals of that city, but eventually the investigators will take up, we presume, the charges relating to the extravagance or corrupt action of the canal company with respect to other beneficiaries.

It is reported that dispatches have been re- ceived in this city from Europe which contain the first intimation of the arrangements for the settlement of the claims made by French and English creditors against Peru which Chile, according to the last treaty of peace mads between the two South American republics, has undertaken to meet.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- President A.A. McLeod of the Boston and Maine and Reading Railroad systems was the guest of the Boston Merchants' Club at Parker's this evening, and spoke on the general subject of "Boston's Terminal Facilities."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supervising Architact's report of operations for the year ended Sept 30, 1892, says that during that period 120 public buildings were in course of erection and 25 public buildings were completed. He says that on Sept. 30 there were 95 new public buildings in various stages of erection or extension and repair, and there were 297 completed public buildings subject to repair.

Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge of Kentucky delivered to a large audience in the Strong Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, last evening, a lecture upon "Southern Problems." The first step in the solution of the race question, Mr. Breckinridge said, would be for outsiders to sake their hands from it and leave it to those living among the colored people.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 8 -- John F. Swineburne, a young and well-connected Englishman of twenty-two or twenty-three years, came here nine months ago and during his stay has gotten rid of about $12,000. Swineburne road an advertisement in an English paper of a Montreal (Quebec) firm which offered to secure positions for young men desiring to familiarize themselves with the system of American farming.

A special meeting of the New-England Society was held last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to nominate a board of officers for the ensuing year and to elect new members. Clarence W. Bowen was Moderator. A nominating committee was elected composed of William F. Holcomb, John T. Terry, William E. Webb, Thomas H. Wood, and John P. Townsend.

Samuel J. Thompson, twenty-five years old, of 27 Second Avenue, was held in $3,000 ball in the Tombs Court yesterday for examination tomorrow on the charge of grand larceny. The complainant was Charles Hatchings, sixty-one years old, who said he had no regular home. He testified that Thompson and three others, not yet arrested, had swindled him out of $300 in a bogus horse sale.

An apparently harmless communication same before the Street and Water Commissioners of Jersey City at their meeting Monday morning. It was from the State Electrical Subway Commission. In the hurry of the meeting, Clerk Bouton merely real its title which was: "Communication from the State Subway Commission for the Relief of the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company."

For the monthly meeting of the Union League Club last night the Art Committee, Messrs. Purdy, Watrous, Van Boskerok, Nichols, Bierstadt, Waller, and S.W. Smith, but more especially Messrs. Purdy and Watrous, borrowed seventy-one oil paintings of modern and last-century masters. The smaller gallery contains the old English and Dutch canvases.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The annual election of the senior class of Princeton University for classday officers was held last night by the class of '93 in Examination Hall. The usual strife for honors was manifest. Everything passed off smoothly, however, untill the balloting for the Class-Day Comnittee began. This is one of the greatest honors of the class, and was closely contested.
The proposed Theatre of Arts and Letters was discussed by several speakers at a dinner given by Henry B. McDowell at Sherry's last night.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Notwithstanding the fact that none of Mrs. Maybrick's friends in London had any knowledge that she was critically ill, as was announced in these dispatches yesterday, the representative of the Associated Press caused inquiries to be made at Woking Prison to learn if there was any truth in the report that she was dying.

There is one recommendation made by the President in his message and repeated by the Secretary of the Treasury in his report which is likely to command general approval, and that is that the National Government take entire control of the quarantine service of the country. "In my opinion," says the President, "the whole subject should be taken into the national control."

The International Monetary Conference has not had a very long existence, nor have its members been subjected to any very exacting requirements of either toil or mental strain, but it is evident that they are already very weary, and that the question that chiefly occupies them at the present moment is how they can separate and get back to their homes with a decent appearance of dignity.

Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, the principal owner of the stock of the Brooklyn City and Newtown Railroad, comprising the Franklin and De Kalb Avenue lines, has been approached by the representative of the syndicate which has purchased the Atlantic Avenue Road, and is said to have secured control of the Brooklyn City Road, and was asked to put a price upon his stock at which he would be willing to sell out his interest.

The little gallery at 237 Fifth Avenue, a few doors above Twenty-seventh Street, contains a collection of choice water colors by artists of note, chiefly such as are remarkable as colorists. Venetian sketches by William Gedney Bunce recall the time when his paintings and aquarelles were oftenor seen in New-York. "Pearly Morning" and "Approach to Venice" have his old delicate color sense and liking for the paler yellows.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 8 -- "Dr." William H. Hale, the American quack doctor who was arrested a short time ago on the charges of defrauding a large number of persons and of having obtained money by false representations, was convicted here to-day and sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment at hard labor.

Oliver Sunnier Teall Beams destined this year to meet trouble very early in his annual struggle to provide a "Happy Christmas" for poor children of this city in Madison Square Garden. Last year Mr. Teall encountered strong opposition to his plans for distributing toys on Christmas Day at the big Garden, but despite this opposition be persevered, with the result that a tremendous riot was precipitated when the playthings were given out.

The Immigration Bureau on Ellis Island -- an institution in which 107 Republicans are employed -- is likely to see considerable changes before long. Col. John B. Weber, the local Superintendent of Immigration, recently returned from Washington, where he had held a consultation with the Treasury Department officials in regard to immigration matters.

The seventeenth annual meeting of the Goethe Society was held at the residence of the President, Mr. A.M. Palmer, Sixty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, last night. In consequence or a chance in the constitution, which fixes the date of the annual election in May instead of December, officers were elected to serve until next May.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 8 -- The bill providing for the acceptance of the Home for Aged Confederate Veterans and the payment of $15,000 annually for its support came up in the House of the Georgia Legislature to-day. The home was built by subscriptions from Georgia and all parts of the South. Last year the Alliance Legislature refused to accept the home and the fight in the House this year has been bitter in the extreme.

There is one line in the book of estimates just sent to the House by Secretary of the Treasury Foster that is alike creditable to the Secretary's appreciation of faithful and valuable service and to the man in whose behalf it was made. Under the head of "Salaries, Office of the Secretary of the Treasury," and under the subhead division of "warrants, estimates, and appropriations" appears this memorandam:

The New-York Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, by an entertainment at Sherry's yesterday afternoon, made a good start on a fund to send a statue of Washington to France in return for France's gift to this country of the statue of Lafayette. Over $1,000 was cleared.
What is expected to be the finest lot of postage stamps over issued is now being prepared by the American Bank Note Company for the United States Government.

Senator Hill (Dem., N.Y.) has puzzled the silver Democrats by the introduction of his bill for the repeal of a part of the Sherman Silver Purchase act of 1890. Mr. Bland, (Dem., Mo.,) who has learned to be cautious about attributing too much importance to silver utterances from Mr. Hill, does not pretend to have an opinion about the effect the bill would have if passed.

There was a brief hearing before Referee John E. Ward, at 50 Wall Street, yesterday, in the application of Peter Shute and others to have Lawyers James S. Merriam and A.H. Ely declared in contempt of court for failing to produce certain papers. This is a side suit to the action which Shute and 160 others have brought as next of kin of Aan Drake Seaman to have her will declared void.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 8 -- Some surprise has been caused in political circles in Iowa by an interview with Congressman Hayes, which shows the marks of careful preparation, and which has just been given to the public. In this interview Mr. Hayes intimates that he is likely to be a candidate for United States Senator next year.

The passengers on a bridge train bound for New-York yesterday afternoon, a little after 2 o'clock, were startled to hear Conductor John Comiskey cry suddenly: " Look out! That man is going to jump." Several of those in the car rushed to the windows in time to see a man climbing over the top of the railing of the northern carriageway.

The Union College boys had a jolly time at their annual reunion at Delmonico's test night. Each alumnus wore a garnet pasteboard mortarboard, and every time a toast was proposed they all sang together in a way that brought tears to the eyes of the head waiter and sent him scurrying off for more apollinaris water.

NEWPORT, Ark., Dec. 8 -- A street duel took place yesterday on the streets of Jacksonport, three miles from here, between Lee Jago, for many years Deputy County Clerk of Jackson County, and Edward Blackwood, son of the late Judge W.S. Blackwood of this county.

Gen. Russell A. Alger of Michigan was in this city yesterday in search of a sculptor to make the bronze statue of Gen. Logan which is to be erected in Washington. His visit was preliminary to a meeting which will be held in the office of Secretary of War Elkins at Washington to-morrow of the committees having in charge the erection of statues of Logan, Sheridan, and Hancock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate to-day in executive session ratified the Chilean Claims Convention which was transmitted to that body at the beginning of the present session by the President, with a note calling attention to the necessity of early consideration, and inclosing the following communication on the subject from the Secretary of State:

BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 -- When the International Monetary Conference adjourns at the end of next week it will probably leave the respective Governments represented to decide whether or not it shall reassemble in January. The American and other bimetallic delegates will try to obtain from the conference recommendation to all the Governments to allow from a year to eighteen months to elapse before taking any active measures toward changing the present currency policy.
A story came down from Sing Sing Prison to the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday which may lead to the discovery of much fraud and rascality in the management of that institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- There was a brief and unimportant open session of the Senate to-day. In the executive session a number of nominations made during the recess were confirmed, not including that of Lewis E. McComas to be Judge of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

All arrangements for the music at the Press Club's carnival of sports Dec. 17 have been completed. The West Point Military Band, under the direction of Prof. Arthur A. Clappe, will play at the afternoon performance. For the evening, the musical attraction will be the famous Marine Band of Washington, under the leadership of Prof. Francesco Fanciulli.

The Rev. Father Corrigan of Hoboken was congratulating himself yesterday that a letter published by Archbishop Satolli, the Pope's ablegate in this country, to whom father Corrigan's final appeal must be made in the event of the Diocesan Court deciding against him, is an indorsement of the theories, on the publication of which Bishop Wigger's charges against him are based.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon the Cincinnati Presbytery went into secret session, as the rules provide, to consider the case of Prof. Smith. When they adjourned it was to meet on Monday next. A vote is expected by Tuesday or Wednesday.

The twenty-sixth anniversary of the establishment of the New-York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital was held yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Ladies' Board, of Supervisors, of which Miss Anna Roosevelt is President and Miss Jane Frances Tuckerman is Secretary.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 8 -- The Rook Island has only six operators in Kansas City and its suburbs and they are employed in freight offices. At noon all left their keys. Later, four of them returned to work and the places of the other two men were filled by new men.

The prosecution in the famous heresy trial of Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary rested its case for the present before the adjournment of the session or Presbytery held in the Scotch Church. Four teenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The Presbytery will not reconvene as a court again until Tuesday afternoon.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 8 -- The canvass of State votes was held here to-day by the men who seem to be under agreement to return F. E. Warren to the United States Senate, regardless of the vote cast. Gov. Osborne (Dem.) was kept out, as was also his attorney, T.M. Patterson, of Denver. The Democratic Party was allowed three representatives, as was the other.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 8 -- Passengers from San Francisco who arrived this evening tell of another told attempt at train wrecking made on the Southern Pacific Railway last night at Cow Creek Canon, Oregon, fifty miles north of the California line. At that point the train crosses a long trestle over a high rocky canon, about midway between Grand Pass and Glendale stations.

Mr. Austin Corbin, President of the Long Island Railroad Company, was asked yesterday for information concerning the proposed tunnel in which he and other capitalists are interested, which is to carry freight and passengers, and the route for which is to be from the Long Island Railroad station at Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, under Flatbush Avenue.

Miss Esther Jacobs, twenty-five years old, petite, auburn-haired, and of prepossessing appearance, is making a second attempt to secure $50,000 damages from Henry B. Sire for alleged breach of promise to marry. Miss Jacobs is one of six sisters, all residing with their parents at 122 West Ninety-eighth Street.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 8 -- There is serious trouble brewing in this State, unless the Populists refuse to listen to the advice of their leaders. It was ascertained to-day that there is a concerted effort to bring to Topoka at the opening of the Legislature enough men to protect "Populist rights" and prevent Republican usurpation in the lower house.

The annual meeting of the New-York Driving Club was held last night at the Hotel Metropole Forty-second Street and Broadway. In the absence of President J.C. De La Vorgne, Secretary Thomas Greenwood presided. The report of Treasurer Fred Dietz showed that last year the membership of the club was 290, while this year the number is more than 400.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The operabouffe style in which Coroner Drews of Westchester County and a number of private detectives are trying to solve the mystery surrounding the death of Ella Newton would be amusing it a tragedy were not involved.

The Trotting Association's Board of Review had a comparatively short session yesterday. Much of the time was taken up in arguing a case arising out of the allegation that the black mare Bessie C., owned by W.H. Clarke of Burlington, Vt., was the black mare Old Maid (2:21 1/4) who under the alias of Rose W. Perrin was stopped as a ringer at Belmont in 1888.
The chapters of the Epworth League composing the Elizabeth (N.J.) District held their annual convention yesterday at the Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church at West-Brighton. S.I.

On the strength of a statement made by Marvin Husted, a steerage passenger on the Fall River Line steamboat Pilgrim, a sensational story was published yesterday in one of the afternoon papers to the effect that the State of Massachusetts was dumping her paupers in this city on a wholesale scale.

James S. Zerbe was arrested last August in an action brought by Henry Keim. On Nov. 2 Zerbe's lawyer, J.D. Hallen, took the default of Keim's lawyer, W.M. Safford, and the order of arrest was vacated.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- By order of Attorney General Miller, the case against the recent strikers will be fought to a finish. The injunction suit of the United States Government against the Amalgamated Council and the Presidents of the various labor organizations participating in the recent general strike was called for trial to-day in the United States Circuit Court, before Judges Pardoe and Billings.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 9 -- The story of Naval Cadet Perkins's dismissal from the academy, of his return and fight with a follow-cadet who had long before called him a liar, promptly followed by the arrest of thirteen sympathizers with Perkins, was all told in THE TIMES of this morning.

An audience which crowded Association Hall. Brooklyn, to its utmost seating capacity, listened last night with interest to a lecture delivered by the arctic explorer, R.E. Peary of the United States Navy, on "Arctic Exploration." The lecture was delivered, under the charge of the geographical department of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Not since Last October, when the National Democratic Headquarters were open, has there been such a distinguished gathering of Democratic statesmen in this city as may be found in New-York to-day. And not even during the national campaign was the assembly so large and notable as the present one, because at that time most of the prominent Democrats of the country were in their own States looking after the interest of the party at home.

Miss Esther Jacobs, the young woman who is seeking to recover $50,000 damages from Henry B. Sire for alleged breach of promise, entered the courtroom, Part I, of the Superior Court, yesterday, with a smiling face. She was accompanied by her mother and a young woman. Miss Jacobs wore a close-fitting dress, deep blue in hue, and a broad hat trimmed with blue velvet and turned up at one side.

The glamour of a new session has worn off and the House to-day, at the close of its first week's work, greatly resembled a meeting of that body after its members had been wearied by a six-months attention to important business. The attendance was small and the attention listless.
HAMBURG, Dec. 9 -- A sensation has been caused here by the suspension of Carow Bartels, stock brokers. Carow has fled, but the Police are following him. Bartels has surrendered.

Representatives of the New-York State Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association have been advised by Gov. Flower to refrain from presenting to the coming Legislature radical amendments of the excise law.

SPOKANE, Washington, Dec. 9 -- A terrible riot occurred at Wenatchee last night, and for three hours the town was in control of a mob of frenzied graders. Wenachee is a town about 100 miles west of here on the Great Northern Railroad. The trouble was, started by the luck of a drunken gambler named Tom Guilland. He worked on the Great Northern grade at intervals through the Summer.

FIRST RACE. -- Five furlongs. Enola, 1; Laurenska, 2; Elect, 3. Time -- 1:06 1/2. Other runners -- Common Sense, Zarilla filly, and Topeka. SECOND RACK. --Five furlongs, Persistence, 1; Reute, 2; Caracas, 3. -- Time -- 1:05 1/2. Other runners -- Jack Pot, Kerry Gow, Antrim, Jr., and Nellie Hooker. THIRD RACE. -- Four and one-half furlongs, Miss Olive, 1; Foxford, 2; Power, 3.

Representative Enloe, (Dem., Tenn.,) who assisted in conducting the prosecution in the investigation into the charges against the administration of the Pension Office, at the last session of Congress, has returned to Washington. The majority of the committee which conducted the investigation reported a resolution reciting that it is the judgment of the House that Commissioner Raum should be removed from office by the President.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- A member of the Panama investigating Committee said to-day to the representative of the Associated Press: "When it is considered that we have been working in the dark, unaided by information from the hands of the Government and the courts, we have done well in unearthing corrupt acts. We must now go right on and stop for nothing or nobody.
There was a vague report around the Barge Office yesterday that Col. Weber, Superintendent of immigration, had relinquished his idea of resigning on account of the bureau's shortness of funds.
The Burial Reform Association of this city has undertaken the somewhat arduous task of abolishing customs which, it frankly declares, are intrenched in the reverent observance of centuries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The House Committee on Military Affairs is entitled to the honor of first getting a regular annual appropriation bill into the House at this session. The committee went energetically to work and to-day completed the preparation of the annual bill for the maintenance of the army, and will report it to the House so that it can be taken up next week.
Daniel MoLanghlin, who jumped from the bridge on Thursday, was none the worse physically for his bath yesterday. It was not even necessary to give him medicine.

HELENA, Mon., Dec. 9 -- The great fight for the control of the Montana Legislature began before the Supreme Court to-day. The suit was brought by A.J. Leech (Rep.) to compel the returning board of Choteau County to issue to him a certificate as a Representative from that county.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec, 9 -- The 19th of December is the day get for resuming and completing the canvass or the State vote, begun yesterday. The postponement was made for two reasons. Johnson County failed to send in an abstract of the votes cast for members of the Legislature. The Democratic Committee wants to have a hearing before the State Supreme Court, which will convene on the 15th inst.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 9 -- The details of a terrible crime, supposed to be the work of the Mafia, reached this city late last night. The tragedy, which was nothing less than a triple assassination, took place at Convent, St. James Parish.

There are at present eight vacancies in the carpenter's grade of the navy, and during the next six years this number will be increased by ten, owing to vacancies which will result from forced retirements. A carpenter in the United States Navy ranks as a warrant officer. The pay of the grade ranges from $1,200 to $1,800 per annum.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- The heavy armament is being placed on the coast defense vessel Monterey preparatory to her trial trip. The two ten-inch rifles were placed in position in the after turret yesterday, and the twelve-inch rifles, which weigh forty-six tons each, will be placed in the forward turret to-day. The contractor's preliminary trials in San Francisco Bay will begin on the 19th inst.
