Those who say that the new Congress at an extra session beginning in March should pass certain bills for the removal of duties on raw materials and postpone further revision of the tariff until the regular session appear to overlook the probable effect of such legislation. When the duty on a raw material is removed, the duties on the finished products into which this raw material enters should suffer a corresponding reduction, at least.

The Laural Circle, a society composed of eight young men banded together for the purpose of securing for themselves and their friends a right good time, fulfilled their self-imposed mission by a very successful reception and ball given Thursday night at the Lyceum Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue.

George Lawson of North Broad Street, Elizabeth, N.J., who was injured in the collision of New-Jersey Central Railroad trains near the Greenville station in Jersey City, Thursday, died at the City Hospital in Jersey City yesterday. He did not regain consciousness after removal from the wreck.

There was a gathering of Republican leaders of the State of New-York last evening at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broadway and Twentythird Street. It was presumably gotten together by Thomas C. Platt and one or more of his lieutenants.
The Quarantine Committee of the Board of Trade and Transportation has begun to receive replies to the circular it sent out asking for opinions of the advisability of a national quarantine.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- The Louisiana sugar planters held a meeting here yesterday to consider the questions of bounty and tariff revision. They took no action. A prominent member said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The accident to the thirteen-inch gun at the Washington ordnance shop, as reported in THE TIMES'S Washington dispatches last night, is one of the few serious accidents which have occurred, at this establishment since it has been in operation. The ordnance shops have been remarkably free from accidents, in which particular they have stood practically alone as compared with similar establishments in this country and abroad.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 9 -- A fashionable wedding was celebrated at St. John's Episcopal Church this evening. Over 750 invitations had been issued for the ceremony and reception and the church edifice was packed. The bride was Miss Sallie E. Rennell, a sister of Mr. Frank W. Rennell, who married Miss Helen Hurd, granddaughter of the late P.T. Barnum.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- R.R. Paulaon, fifty-five years old, a wealthy Canadian who, with his wife, had been a guest at the Hotel Thorndlke for several days, shot himself in the head in the bathroom of his suite of rooms early this morning and died instantly.

The demand for seats in the boxes and gallery of the banquet nail in the Madison Square Garden for the Reform Club dinner to-night has been so great that it has been difficult to supply even the members of the club and their friends.

The recent gradual but steady rise in the market value of the stock of the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Railway Company has give rise to persistent rumors to the effect that the Philadelphia cable syndicate, of which John D. Crimmins is the head, was nibbling at the bait with the Idea of swallowing it entire at a favorable opportunity.

MANCHESTER, Dec. 9 -- At a meeting of the representatives of the Masters' Cotton Federation and the Northeast Lancashire Manufacturers' Association a resolution was adopted in favor of the members of the Lancashire Assocition running its mills only throe days in the week. If the resolution is generally enforced, it will have serious consequences for the strikers in South Lancashire, who depend largely upon the weekly levies from the northern operatives.

A flattering report was road by Clerk Thomas G. Shearman, Jr., at the annual meeting of Plymouth Church, in Brooklyn, held last night in the church. There are at present 1,815 members, an increase of 23 during the year. There were 50 baptisms and 34 deaths, among the dead being Augustus Storrs and Edward A. Seecomb.

There was a pleasant reunion of wesleyan University men at the St. Denis Hotel last night, the occasion being the twenty-fourth anual meeting of the Wesleyan University Club of New-York. Nearly 100 gentlemen were present.

Police Superintendent Smith of Jersey City on Nov. 30 sent a letter to the Police Commissioners saying that the Captains, detectives, and patrolmen under him had become careless and indifferent, and that he thought it would be beneficial to change them around. He also suggested that some of the detectives should be returned to patrol duty and their places filled with young, intelligent, and active men.

The body of Charles E. Whitehead, son of Heary M. Whitehead, ex-Judge of the Superior Court of this city, was found near Stapleton, S.I., yesterday morning. A bullet hole in the right temple, blackened by powder, and a revolver beside the body told plainly that his death had been his own act.
The city authorities do not mean to let up in their opposition to the Swan-Green scheme to bridge the Hudson River. This was made very clear at yesterday's meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners.

Warner Van Norden, President of the National Bank or North America, yesterday declined to discuss the recent action of his daughter, Miss Emma Van Norden, in entering the Salvation Army. Both he and his daughter were sorry that comments upon the tact had been printed, because Miss Van Norden's action was entirely her own affair, and the family wished that no further talk might be made about it.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 9. -- The Olympic Club about completed its triple event yesterday by sign- | ing George Dawson, the Australian who defeated Necdham and O'Connell, to meet "Tommy " Ryan of Chicago for the welter-weight championship and a purse of $6,000. Ryan at first placed his figures higher, but finally agreed to come for the sum named.

The old wooden ships of the United States Navy are fast disappearing from the active list. Of the forty wooden sloops-of-war which were on the navy register twenty years ago only nine are now in active cruising service. These nine ships are the Lancaster, Marion, Mohican, Kearsarge, Adams, Alliance, Essex, Thetis, and Yantic.

The ticket offices for the east side lines of the elevated road were closed yesterday at the South Ferry station from 11 o'clock until about 12:30, during which time no trains moved out from that station.

The "Annual of the Office of Naval Intelligence of the Navy Department," issued a few days ago by the Secretary of the Nary, is in general make-up similar to the information series sent out by the Naval Intelligence Office of late years. The present volume is the eleventh in the series of General Information from Abroad.

The proposition to choose the President by the direct votes of the people promises to meet with more than usual consideration by the Committee on the Election of President and Vice President and Representatives in Congress, to which is referred bills and resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution with this end in view.
The New-York Retail Grocers Association has net yet accomplished its purpose of crushing Join V. Alexander, who is employed quite generally by the wholesale grocers to colect bad debts for them.

The contest between Park Commissioner Brower and the Brooklyn City Railroad Company as to the right of the latter to string trolley wires across the Plaza at Prospect Park took on legal shape yesterday when a complaint was drawn up for the latter by S. Stewart Whitehouse in an action against the city to show cause why the Park Commissioner should not he restrained from interfering with the company in its work.

Chiekering Hall was full of people and enthusiasm last night The occasion of the fullness was the first appearance in America of Johannes Wolff, violinist, and Joseph Hollman, violeneellist. These gentlemen were assisted by Alexander Lambert, pianist; Mme. Kate Rolla, mezzo-soprano, and Victor Harris, accompanist.
It looks now as if there would be no Columbian arch. Tho Columbian Arab Committee met at the Plaza Hotel on Nov. 27, and has not held a meeting since.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- Judge Edward O. Billings, in the United States Circuit Court to-day, quashed the indictments against several Chinese for violating the exclusion act, and defined the powers of the Government officials. He said:

JOLIET, Ill., Dec. 9 -- Martin J. Burke, one of the men sent to the Joliet Prison for complicity in the famous murder of Dr. Patrick Cronin of Chicago, died at the penitentiary in this city this evening of quick consumption. His death was not unexpected, as he had been sinking rapidly for some time.

Elizabeth Mulvey, twenty-two years old, was found in Eben Peek's lumber yard, at 523 West Twenty-eighth Street, at 6 o'clock last night suffering from hunger and exposure. She was taken to the Sixteenth Precinct Station House, an ambulance was summoned from the New-York Hospital, and she was taken to that institution.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 -- The appeal from the de cision of the Hamilton Circuit Court ousting the Ohio and Mississippi Railway Company from its charter was argued in the Supreme court to-day, On Nov. 19, 1891, a suit was begun against the company at Cincinnati by John C. Shwartz, Prosecuting Attorney, who alleged the following material facts:

BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 -- It is expected that Senator Jones will wind up the debate on international bimetallism on Tuesday night with an important declaration. The concluding sitting on Thursday will be devoted to an endeavor to crystallize the results of the conference.

There was no correspondence between the Committee on Adjustment of the railroad engineers and the officials of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday, but the committeemen are determined to stay in New-York until they get a definite answer from Mr. Depew.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Marie Cavelito, a little Italian girl fourteen years of age, is held at Police Headquarters to save her from the fury of her father. Yesterday morning, while on her way to Gaetano Papa's hat shop, where she works, she stopped at a store. Papa followed, her in and found Lawrence Wells there with her.

When the Rev. Phoebe A. Hanaford had finished her lecture last evening on "Modern Mental Activity," before tie Manhattan Liberal Club, at German Masonic Hall, 220 East Fifteenth Street, It was very evident that she had considerably antagonized many of the pet notions of the members of the club.

A sister ship to the Ann Arbor, the lake vessel described in THE TIMES on Nov. 27, was launched during the past week from the Craig shipyards of Toledo, Ohio. The new vessel is named the Ann Arbor No. 2 and, like the Ann Arbor, is designed to convey oars across Lake Michigan from Frankfort, Mich., to Kewaunee, Wis.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 9. -- Rumors have been rife for the past few days that there was a hitch in the negotiations for the race for the America's Cup. The hitch was said to be on the action of the Cup Committee on the challenge from Lord Dunraven through the Royal Yacht Squadron which will be presented to the New-York Yacht Club at the meeting next Tuesday evening.

The first private concert of the Friday evening musicale series was given last evening in the drawing rooms of Mrs. Theodore Havemeyer, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. Early in the season Harry Le Grand Cannon concieved the idea of a aeries of private concerts. Many well-known ladies expressed their desire to become subscribers, and the services of the Boston. Symphony Orchestra were secured.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The combination between the Standard Oil Company and the Erie Railway Company to prevent the United States Pipe Line Company from constructing its line across the Delaware River at Hancook, N.Y., thereby blocking its way to tidewater, is said to have been the result of negotiations which were pending for some time between the two companies.

The report of the Directors of the Real Estate Exchange to be issued Monday at the annual meeting of stockholders, deals interchangeably with bogus auction sales and the new salesroom at 111 Broadway. Bogus sales, or the right to post on the Exchange bulletin as genuine sales which were not made, is held up as the issue that divided the Exchange.

The Lenox Lyceum was gayly decorated last night in honor of the fifty-ninth annual entertainment and military reception of the Second Battery, N.G.S.N.Y. The boxes were draped with the Stars and Strines worked into numerous designs, and from the dome hung broad restoons of red, white, and blue.

FERGUS FALLS, Minn., Dec. 9. -- Probably the most curious suit ever brought in a Minnesota court was that filed to-day in this city against the Northern Pacific Railway Company by Miss Elsie Eisele of Breekenridge. Miss Eisele demands that the big corporation pay her $30,000 to compensate her for injuries to her mind and feelings caused by the actions of a brakeman, Frank Murray.

The controversy that has arisen between Dr. PARKHURST and the police is a natural and almost a necessary result of the kind of crusade which Dr. PARKHURST'S society has undertaken. Dr. PARKHURST is undoubtedly right in saying that it is the business of the police to enforce the law without taking upon themselves to consider whether enforcement would not be more mischievous than laxity.

Forty-seven prisoners were arraigned yesterday morning before Justice Ryan, in the Jefferon Market Police Court, as the result of the raid on disorderly houses made late Thursday night by Police Captain Haughey of the Fifteenth Precinct.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 9 -- Since silver fell to 90, mines have constantly been closing, and almost every day a report is received of some property, large or small, discharging men. There are hundreds of mines not being worked. Many of them are small and their output cuts no great figure, but the aggregate of persons thrown out at employment is large enough to exercise a material influence on the general condition of trade.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 9 -- B.J. Martin, the missing cashier of the Webster National Bank of Enpora, Miss., was arrested at the Gayoso Hotel here to-night and was looked up. He came to Memphis from Columbus, Ohio, early in the day to meet A.F. Laurent of the American Guaranty Company. They had a long conference, and it was agreed that Martin should surrender himself.
The Ladies' Auxiliary Committee, the medical staff of the "Babies Wards," and the thirty little patients in the hospital were "at home" yesterday afternoon.

The members of the Board of Education who are opposed to the "ring" rule of President J. L.N. Hunt were very much pleased yesterday when it was reported that Mr. Hunt had decided not to be a candidate for re-election at the meeting which will be bold the first Wednesday in January. They were somewhat disappointed later when the friends of President Hunt said that the report was incorrect.

WILLIAM SPENCER CHILD. The death of the Rev. William Spencer Child, S.T.D., at Jamestown, R. I., is announced by his son, Mr. L.P. Child, who was at the Hotel Savoy yesterday, having just arrived from Europe. The Rev. Dr. Child was seventy-four years old. He was born in Providence, R.I., and was graduated from Brown University in 1840, receiving the highest honors of his class.

On Saturday evening, Dec. 17, a meeting will be hold by the members of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in Association Hall to commemorate the eighty-fifth birthday of John Greenleaf Whittier. William Lloyd Garrison of Boston trill deliver the address of eulogy and the Rev. John W. Chadwick of Brooklyn will road a memorial poem written for the occasion.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 10 -- Newspaper discussion of the riotous conduct indulged in by several Yale freshmen at the local theatres and elsewhere last Saturday night does not abate. Interest in the matter is kept alive by the threatened severe, though yet suspended, action on the part of the Faculty and by the very unexpected ending in court of the cases against the four students who were arrested.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The complaint in the action for separation instituted by Mary Helen Hooker Stuyvesant-Sanford against her husband, Robert Sanford of this city, has been served on the defendant. The allegations made by Mrs. Sanford caused great astonishment in society here. Eleven distinct charges are made against Mr. Sanford.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- This is the cattle show week, when London is filled with more people from the provinces than at any other time during the year. For the theatres it is the most thriving week of the year, the strangers in the city naturally turning to them for amusement.

Books like George H. Ellwanger's "In Gold and Silver" (Appleton) have the calm and triumphant seduction which complete inutility lends to things. It is in their company that one may forget the mechanism of practical civilization, drink the ambrosia of dreams, and, like the shepherds in Laconia, listen to the songs of Spring in the shade of pink laurel trees.

John O'Connor, a young Irishman about twenty-three years old, who for over eight years had been employed in the office of Richard Dorney, business manager of Daly's Theatre, was found dead in bed in his room at the boarding house 317 West Thirty-third Street, yesterday morning, having committed suicide by shooting.

The athletes of the Seventh Regiment brought out the display of fashion that always greets them at their twenty second annual games in their armory last evening. The crowd numbered nearly 6,000, and was enthusiastic in proportion to its size.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 10 -- The complications of Lawyer Pierre Brown and Miss Sara Maria Jackson over a diamond ring came up in court to-day before Justice Seaman here. Miss Jackson sues Lawyer Brown for $100, that being her estimate of the ring's value.

The condition of the real estate market last week showed the improvement that had been forecast for it, and both auctioneers and brokers now regard the outlook for the Winter as exceedingly promising. Everything offered at auction last week attracted bidders, and some of the sales showed that the demand for this kind of property is reviving.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The Rev. Dom Michel Bazlin has been chosen as the new head of the Carthusian Order, an office that also makes him Prior of the Grande Chartreuse, where the worldfamous liquor is distilled. He is, therefore, a man in whom general interest centres, succeeding to the office as the General of the order whose secret has baffled the chemists of the world.

The situation of the negotiations between Lord Dunraven and the New-York Yacht Club for an international yacht race next year is the same today as it was a week ago with the exception that the America's Cup Committee of the club has referred the challenge to a special meeting of the club to be held next Tuesday evening at 67 Madison Avenue.

The agitation of this question of annexation at the Real Estate Exchange meeting on Wednesday has frightened the local papers, and they have begun to denounce the proposed change with great vigor but very little logic. They are actuated solely by the fear that the sum of $15,000, which is now given annually to each paper by the political leaders, will be taken away from them in case these leaders are legislated out of power.

The United States cruiser Newark, the flagship of Rear Admiral A.E.K. Benham, has been ordered to cruise during the remainder of the present month, along the coast of Turkey. The Newark is now at Messina, Sicily, where she arrived on Dec. 8. The Newark will visit all the important ports of Turkey, going up to Constantinople, and en route will visit Grecian ports.

The New-Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals, the highest of the New-Jersey State courts, has confirmed Jersey City's title to what is known as the "State grant" in the South Cove. The decision enriches the city to the extent of a round million of dollars, and brings to her, besides, a water frontage that she has long needed.

Everybody will agree with the Adjutant General when he says, as does Gen. Porter in his annual report, "The one thing demonstrated at Buffalo, next to the patriotic spirit and the soldierly qualities of the officers and men, was the great value of the Camp of instruction at Peekskill and the system of instruction pursued there."

A rumor was current yesterday that T. Suffern Tailer, the clever young whip and writer on coaching matters, had been blackballed at the last election for members of the Coaching Club, of which Col. William Jay is President.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Presbyterian Hospital was held yesterday afternoon, in the dispensary building, Madison Avenue and Seventieth Street. Previous to the formal exercises, the members of the association and their guests were afforded an opportunity of inspecting the hospital and its workings, the several wards being thrown open for their benefit, a privilege enjoyed by nearly 300 ladies and gentlemen.

Carl Werner, a convict in Sing Sing Prison was taken to the Supreme Court, Brooklyn yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus directing Warden Brown to produce him and show cause why he should not be liberated. Werner was convicted of perjury and sentenced on Nov. 23, 1887, to seven years and three months' impris onment.

Although David A. Boody is Mayor of Brooklyn, and in that capacity is supposed to study the needs of the city and to favor measures which are for the public good, irrespective of whether the political leaders like them or not, yet for some unknown reason he has refused to say whether he is or is not opposed to the annexation of New-York and Brooklyn.

Last evening Miss Pauline Whitney, daughter of ex-Secretary and Mrs. William C. Whitney, made her social debut. The Whitney mansion, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, has been the scene of many notable social events, but none have been more brilliant than the reception given last evening by Mr. and Mrs. Whitney for their daughter from 9 until 12 o'clock.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- Dr. Dudley A. Sargent, the director of the gymnasium, has compiled a list of the strong men in college this year. It shows forty-four men whose strength is above 740, according to Dr. Sargent's system of tests. E. Cockrell, '95, is the strongest man tested this year. His total is 1016.6, as against the total of F. Mason, Low School, the strongest man last year, whose record then was 992.8.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Naval Paint Board has given up its practice of applying sample paints to iron and steel plates for immersion in the water at the navy yards. It is found that this does not afford a fair test of samples submitted.

Local politics did not get much incentive from the return of Mayor-elect Thomas P. Gilroy, because as soon as Mr. Gilroy got back to the city from his vacation he promptly decided to discuss politics with no one, possibly making on exception of the big men in Tammany who are in his confidence.

Democratic leaders, at an informal gathering at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, discussed the possibilities of preventing Republicans from capturing by fraud enough Legislatures in five or six Western States to give the Republican Party control of the United States Senate after March 4. A majority of the Campaign Committee of the Democratic National Committee was present, and with thorn as advisers were Senator Carlisle, William C. Whitney, and several well-known Democrats from Western States.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 10 -- The fight for the United States Senatorship, which becomes vacant by the expiration of Senator Stockbridge's term next month, is assuming a new phase. As the Republicans have a big majority in the Legislature, which will meet on the 4th of next January, the contest is entirely within the ranks of that party.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- General Manager St. John of the Rock Island persists in his denial of the statement of Chief Ramsey of the Order of Railway Telegraphers that 85 per cent. of the men in the telegraph department are out and that the road is crippled by the strike. Mr. St. John said to-day:

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- A new story about Bismarck -- the great Bismarck we used to know -- is something of a rarity. This, I think, has never appeared in type before. It was at Versailles, in that fateful February of 1871, when Paris had just capitulated, and the spokesmen of victorious Germany and humbled France were haggling over the bargain of a peace.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The case of the Rev. Levi Bird for slandering city officers took another sensational turn to-day when was it learned that the reverned gentleman had repudiated the-major part of the abject apology made in his behalf by his counsel in open court yesterday, and winch saved him from sure punishment.

The Sardou of "Americana Abroad" is soarcely the Sardou or "Los Pattes do Mouohos," "Patrie," and "Fedora," but this little and somewhat trivial piece from his workshop is good enough for a respectable hearing and, perhaps, even deserves the excellent treatment it gets at the Lyceum Theatre. With the recent crude efforts of American playmakers in view, we are not going to underrate its value.

A horse attached to a light wagon became frightened at a trolley car on Washington Street and dashed up on the sidewalk and into the arched entrance to the Universal Building. There were a dozen men and boys near by and several of them were knocked down. Among those who were injured were George Nuriker, 257 West Thirty-fifth Street, New-York; Joseph Baker and Ernest Ringheim of 496 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

Papers have been prepared which promise to take into the courts again the contest over the Will of Daniel B. Fayerweather. The present proceeding is brought by John B. Reynolds and Morris B. Beardsley as executors of the will of Mrs. Fayerweather.

The Republicans will hold their primary else tions in every Assembly district in this city Tuesday. Those earnest Republicans who have been hoping that something of a reformation would be effected in the old machine through the coming primary can now rest assured that no change of consequence will result from it. The old bosses of the machine have seen to that.

The reported discovery of new and valuable diamond fields in the Snake River country of Idaho is rather questioned by local experts, G. F. Hunz, one of the best-known authorities on the subject, is very doubtful whether the fields will be found as extensive as their discoverers seem to regard them.

Deputy Sheriff Young has received an execution for $311 against the firm of Dahl, Lehman Bodenheimer, manufacturers of smoking jackets at 27 and 29 Walker Street, in favor of the H.B. Claflin Company. When the Sheriff went to their place of business, he was informed that they had disposed of all their effects and had moved away two weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- So far as Senator Quay and his Philadelphia henchmen are concerned, Caleb Thompson will again be elected Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Resident Clerk Charles E. Voorhees will be promoted to the Chief Clerkship. A.D. Fetterholf of Norristown will be Journal Clerk and Jere B. Rex of Huntingdon Reading Clerk.

Ex-Judge William H. Kelly, representing the Thomson-Houston Electric Light Company, intimated broadly in the Mayor's office yesterday that something was wrong with the report of the Board of Electrical Control upon which the order was issued to cut down numerous overhead wires. He intimated that some one wanted to get money out of his company, and, becoming angry, he used the word "blackmail."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: THE TIMES of Nov. 22, in its article on the revision of the tariff, hits the nail on the head in speaking of the advice so freely offered to Congress by persons who evidently have no practical knowledge of the tariff or its workings, when it says that --

Although it will by no means be safe for the American people to relax the jealous vigilance with which they regard any attack upon the American system of public instruction, the danger from these attacks seems to be distinctly less than it was a few years ago. For it has been clearly shown of late that, while the non-Catholic part of the American people is virtually united, the Catholic part of them is divided.

It is not often that such a gathering of men can be brought together as assembled yesterday morning at Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, to attend me funeral of Wilson G. Hunt. Men eminent in all the important walks of city life were among Mr. Hunt's friends, and they came together to pay the last tribute to him.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 10 -- George Gray is now completing his eighth year as United States Senator from the State of Delaware, and there is no doubt that the Legislature, at the biennial session which begins, on the first Tuesday in January, will elect him to another term of six years from the 4th of next March.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Flower to-day granted a commutation of sentence in the case of Vaclav Rozdek, who was convicted in February, 1891, of assault in the second degree, and was sentenced to imprisonment for four years and ten months. In January, 1891, the employes of a firm of cigar manufacturers in New-York struck for higher wages, Rozdak being one of the number.

Western Union stock scored another sharp advance yesterday. It hail advanced 3 points on Friday, sad in the short session of the Stock Exchange which the Saturday half holiday allowed it jumped up over 4 points more. It closed at 9658.

If the weather permits, the Essex Country Toboggan Club will open its season at Orange, N.J., on Dec. 17. Arrangements have been made to have music in the clubhouse every Saturday night and at the top of the slides much oftener than last year. The sides, platform, and clubhouse will be illuminated by incandescent lights, and the clubhouse will be redecorated.

DOYLESTOWN, Penn., Dec. 10 -- Facts developed at the sitting of the Coroner's jury in case of Jacob M. Detwiler, who was found dead yesterday in a stream in Bedminster Township, leave little doubt that he was murdered and robbed.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Dec. 10 -- The oyster cultivators along the lower end of Long Island Sound report that the ravages of that natural enemy of the oyster, the starfish, have been greater this season than ever before, and have extended all along the deep waterbeds, from the headwaters of Long Island Sound, near New-York, to Buzzard's Bay.

ANNAPOLIS, Md, Dec. 10 -- The first class won the championship of the Naval Academy football to-day by defeating the third class by a score of 12 to 0. Lang and Brady each made touch-downs, and Brady kicked two goals.

The revolt against the Republican machine in this city was emphasized last night by the Citizen Voters' Republican Association of the Ninth Assembly District. At the regular meeting resolutions were passed as follows:

HAVERHILL, Mass., Dec. 10 -- Last night an employe of Charles A. Jacques, at his stable on State Street, found in a hay loft two small coffins containing the bodies of two infants. The find was reported to the police, and Capt. Ryan and Medical Examiner Croston went to the stable. The bodies wore badly decomposed. They were taken to the police station, and, under orders from Medical Examiner Croston.

Before the Brooklyn Press Club, at a meeting held beginning at 10:30 o'clock last night, Mr. William C. De Witt read an address commemorative of the life and works of the late William Swinton, whose most intimate friend he had been for thirty years. The salient features of the address are appended:
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Referring to the communication of Mr. Louis Windmuller in your issue of Nov. 29, may I be permitted to express a thought on the same subject?

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- At the session to-day of the Panama Committee, M. Brisaon, the President, stated that he agreed with the proposal made by M. Bourgeois, Minister of Justice, that a sub-committee, composed of seven members of the committee, including its President, be appointed to examine the Panama legal documents to ascertain it any members of the Chamber of Deputies were compromised in the scandal.

Amateur photographers for the last month have been busy developing their plates of pictures taken during the Columbian celebration. Many of them have turned out excellent pictures. Others have been failures. A number of plates are always spoiled when a great many are exposed, as was the case when the three days of celebration gave the picture takers all the work they wanted.

Wall Street stopped discussing silver yesterday and the day before to contemplate Western Union. Also to trade in it. Of all the Gould properties there was none more certain to advance than Western Union, and Manhattan next. Public estimate of tie property was favorable enough to have justified the stock selling about par any time within the past four or five years; but over it there was always the fear of Mr. Gould.

Barzilla Howes, for many rears the keeper of the Scotland lightship, has been removed. This action is the outcome of an investigation recently mode by Capt. W.S. Schley, United States Navy, who is the Inspector of this lighthouse district. One day Capt. Schley paid an official visit to the Sandy Hook lightship. While there, as was his custom, he asked the men if they were treated right and were satisfied.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Dec. 10 -- A large party of young men and girls while skating this afternoon on Yates's Pond, at Westwood, broke through the ice, and a number of them, including Maude Perry, Euphemia Perry, Stella Kent, Lulu Hazzard, "Tot" Millen, Thomas Kent, Ralph Planck, and William Griffin, narrowly escaped being drowned.

Several large stockholders of the Ohio Southern Railroad sent a letter to the Board of Directors some time ago asking that the money in the company's Treasury be applied to the payment of dividends on the stock. President Saul has replied in behalf of the Directors, and urges that the resumption of the payment of dividends had better be postponed until alter the company's new line from Springfield to Lima. Ohio, is completed.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- As the holiday crush appears is the streets, Boston shows symptoms of severe congestion. The Mayor and his co-workers are looking the situation in the face and are alive to the pressing demand for more unobstructed travel. Realizing that any broad and comprehensive plan of relief mast require years of work, they see that no time should be lost in undertaking the great reform.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 10 -- Kansas has another county seat war. It is not a new one, but a continuance of the county seat war that has raged for the past seven years. The scene of the disturbance is in Seward County, and the combatants are the rival towns of Springfield and Liberal, each of which wants the county seat, and wants it bad -- bad enough indeed to light for it.

The French Line steamship La Bretagne seems wedded to mischance. Somebody blundered when the vessel last came into port, and the result was that both passengers and ship were detained an uncomfortable long time off Liberty Island. Another error which was made yesterday will result in a still longer detention.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 10 -- Burglars Charles McLaughlan and Frank Maybray this morning filed through the bars of their cell, walked around the jail until they reached a window leading to the outside building, where they repeated the operation and then were at liberty. Later three other burglars, John Hughey, James Ryan, and William Jones, slipped into the cell formerly occupied by McLaughlan and Maybray, and availed themselves of the same avenue of escape.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, Dec. 10 -- P.M. To-day's market was unusually active, more than 250,000 shares changing hands in the two hours. But 64 cent. of the business was done in five stocks, namely, Western Union, Atchison, Sugar, Whisky, and Missouri Pacific. Western Union went up with a rush to 97, but closed at 96 5/8, a net gain of 4 points. Manhattan Consolidated gained 3 3/8 and Missouri Pacific 1 1/2 points.

COAL CONSUMPTION OF LONDON -- Some 13,000,000 tons of coal are burned in London yearly. About 4,000,000 are utilized by tie gas-manufacturing companies; 9,000,000 are burned in household and industrial ire grates. Each ton contains sufficient ammonia to produce, if treated with sulhuric acid, 22 to 28 pounds of sulphate of ammonia.

FRESNO, Cal., Dec. 10 -- The defeated machine politician may rage, and the unbought floater may lament, but the plain people of California are mightily pleased with their late trial of the Australian fashion of voting. Up to the morning of the day of election the new-fangled system was regarded with doubt, not to say suspicion, by a large proportion of voters.

Four million boxes of oranges. That was the record of Florida last year as a fruit-producing State. It means that there were shipped from the State at least 700,000,000 of the luscious golden balls of juice to Northern and Western States to tempt the palates of fruit lovers. The fruit did what was expected of it, and Florida oranges alone found a ready market.

HELENA, Mon., Dec. 10 -- The Democrats have lost the Choteau County case, and probably the Legislature. This afternoon Chief Justice Blake issued a writ of mandamus during the vacation of the Supreme Court, ordering the Canvassing Board of Choteau County to count Box Elder Precinot. Yesterday attorneys for Hamilton, the Democrat to whom the legislative certificate was issued, made a motion to quash the writ.

The languid person who represents the Department of Justice in the Cabinet should be informed by some friend that the leading organ of his party in Chicago is publishing unkind remarks about him. The Inter Ocean has at last discovered that there are Trusts in this country and that the Sherman Anti-Trust law has not been enforced.
The German Liederkranz will nave its second annual skat tournament at the clubhouse on Saturday evening, Dec. 17. Skat is a complicated German game of cards.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- A meeting of the Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad was held in New-York city this afternoon. It was voted to issue convertible debenture certificates to an amount not exceeding $15,000,000. A circular was issued by the Directors in relation to the action which reads:

Since the announcement by Commissioner Robert Maclay that he had not decided whether he would be a candidate for the Presidency of the Board of Education, President Hunt's friends have become anxious to know what President Hunt will do. It had been said within the last two days that the present incumbent had decided not to run for the office again.

The English Government has at last accepted the offer of Mr. HENRY TATE of London, who proposed to give his large collection of modern British paintings to the nation, provided a suitable building were erected for it on a suitable site. Near that point where the Lambeth Suspension Bridge crosses the Thames is the gloomy set of buildings called the Millbank Prison.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The American representatives on the Intercontinental Railway Commission have just handed to the Secretary or state a report of the operations of the times surveying parties which were sent into the field in April, 1891, one in Central America, another in Ecuador and Colombia, ana the third in Ecuador and Peru.

The Arion Society has had remarkable success since the return of its singers from their trip to Germany last Summer. From 25 to 50 applicants for membership have been initiated each month, and now the society has 1,475 members. Richard K. Katzenmeyer, the President, said yesterday that when the society had 1,500 passive members the doors would be closed and none would be admitted to membership except as vacancies occurred.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 10 -- There was a bad wreck on the New-York and New-England Road, between South Ford and Pomperaug Valley, at 7:30 this morning. Local Freight No. 219, going west, and Regular Freight No. 214, going east, ran into each other, badly blocking train service.

The Secretary of the Treasury has ordered Capt. Russell Glover and Chief Engineer T.C. Ball, both of the United States Revenue Marine, to proceed to Dubuque, Iowa, and superintend the construction of the new revenue steamer Windom. Thin vessel is being built at the yards of the Iowa Iron Works of Dubuque.

It was high noon, and traffic through the city gate of Dilnaghar had died away. One by one, creaking bullock carts and footsore travelers, toiling across the dusty plain toward the ancient Kattiawar stronghold, had come to a halt under what shade they could find by the wayside, to wait for the cool of the evening for the fulfillment of their journey.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A large party assembled at Windsor Castle to-day to greet Crown Prince Ferdinand of Roumania, who arrived there this morning on a visit to his flancee, Princess Marie, daughter of the Duke of Edinburgh. In the party were the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Marquis of Lorne and Princess Louise, the Hon. Charles Robert Spencer, Member of Parliament, youngest son of the Earl of Sponcer, and Admiral Stephenson.

The Rev. Patrick Corrigan of Hoboken, whose trial on Bishop Wigger's charges before the diocesan court in Newark, N.J., is expected to begin to-morrow, last night sent to the Associated Press a letter protesting against the "scurrilous charges" which he says Michael Walsh continues to make against him "in his capacity of 'orthodox Catholic editor and defender of Archbishop Corrigan, Bishop Wigger, and Mgr. Conoilio.'" He says:

There is special interest in furs just before Christmas because of their extensive use as holiday presents. The woman who receives one of this year's beautiful fur wraps will be particularly fortunate. The skill shown in the manufacture of fur garments is increasing steadily. Looking back to the work of only a few seasons ago it seems clumsy and wholly unworthy of the lovely material employed.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 10 -- Leading Liberal papers are agitating for the abolition by Canada of duties on British-made goods. The members of the new Thompson Government declare the scheme to be utterly impracticable. They favor, instead, a revision of the tariff to meet what they declare to be the altered circumstances of the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national tank circulation $167,356,500, as follows: Currency sixes, $11,852,000; 4 per cents, $133,406,650; 2 per cents. $22,097,850.

A company of talented amateur artists, who have given many representations of comedy and operetta here in drawing rooms, will this Winter lend their services for the benefit of the Little Mothers' Aid Society, the Manhattan Working Girls' Society, and the Bethany Pay Nursery. The first performance will be given Thursday evening at the American Art Galleries, Madison Square South.

The United States Lighthouse Department at Tompkinsvlile, S.I., has received a new magnesium Uash apparatus, the invention of Prof. C.C. Sehirm of Berlin. The apparatus was described at some length in THE TIMES cable dispatches several months ago, at the time the United States Government purchased the machine from Prof. Sohirm, which has just been received, for experimental purposes.

A well-attended meeting of the James G. Blaine Club of Harlem took place at the rooms of the club, 112 East One Hundred and Tenth Street, last night. The club is composed of Republicans, chiefly of the Twenty-sixth Assembly District, and the meeting was specially called last evening to protest against the action of the District Committee of the Republican organization in the nomination of the regular ticket for the primary election of Tuesday.

The United States Lighthouse Department at Tompkinsvlile, S.I., has received a new magnesium Uash apparatus, the invention of Prof. C.C. Sehirm of Berlin. The apparatus was described at some length in THE TIMES cable dispatches several months ago, at the time the United States Government purchased the machine from Prof. Sohirm, which has just been received, for experimental purposes.

The practice of literary forgery, especially where popular actresses are the victims, seems to be spreading rapidly. While it was confined to insignificant country newspapers it attracted comparatively little notice, but now large and influential journals apparently think it no harm to attach the name of an actor or actress to any absurd story that it may suit their fancy to credit to a professional as the author.

A convention under the direction of the Central Labor Union is to be held this evening to draft amendments to be presented to the next State Constitutional Convention. The Legislative Committee of the Central Labor Union met last evening and formulated several suggestions. In making some of these suggestions the committee did not show a high standard of statesmanship nor very extensive knowledge.
Francis Murphy, the apostle of temperance, started a week's campaign in this city yesterday afternoon in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, in Washington Square, and spoke to a large audience.

Col. Robert G. Ingersoll delivered his lecture on Voltaire last night to an audience that filled every seat in the Broadway Theatre and two or three hundred extra seats which were placed on the stage. He was frequently and loudly applauded.

The third of the people's singing classes, established under the supervision of Frank Damrosch, commenced its sessions yesterday afternoon in the large hall of the Hebrew Institute, at Jefferson Street and East Broadway. There were 400 names on the list before the doors were opened, and about 500 came in and enrolled themselves as members for the term.

-- The new edition of the romances of Dumas, which Little, Browu Co. will issue by subscription, will contain nearly 250 full-page plates, including etchings, photogravures, and portraits. It will be limited to 1,000 numbered sets.

Albert De Leur, whose home is in Milwaukee, Wis., and who is a contractor of considerable means, arrived in this city from Chicago on Thursday, Dec. 1. He went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he had staid during previous visits, and before going to his room sent a dispatch to his wife in Milwaukee, saying that he was all right and would be home on the following Monday, Dec. 5.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the Hebrew Free School Association was held yesterday morning in the Hebrew Institute Building, East Broadway and Jefferson Street. Most of the time of the meeting was taken up with the discussion of a plan originated by Jacob H. Schiff of consolidating all the branches of the Hebrew educational system in the Educational Alliance.
The Diocesan Criminal Curia of Newark will convene this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the residence of Mgr. Doane, in Newark, N.J., to try the charges against the Rev. Patrick Corrigan of Hoboken, N.J.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 11 -- The promise of relief from the burdensome McKinley duties on raw materials implied in the election of Mr. Cleveland has already brought about a novel departure in Lake Erie commerce. A number of capitalists of this city have purchased the London and Port Stanley Railroad, running twenty-six miles through good agricultural country from London. Ontario, to Port Stanley, almost directly across Lake Erie from Cleveland.

It will be remembered that at the close of the last session of Congress a committee was appointed in the House for the special purpose of revising and codifying the mass of statutory provisions relating to pensions. The committee consisted of five member, of whom Mr. PEARSON, Ohio, Chairman; Mr. MARTIN, Indiana, and Mr. WILSON, Missouri, are Democrats, while Mr. FLICK, Iowa, and Mr. WAUGH, Indiana, are Republicans.

About every man of nearly 700 in the New-York Press Club is working enthusiastically those days to secure the $100,000 which must be paid on New Year's Day to obtain the site for the new Press Club Building. This appeal from the Executive Committee has just been issued:

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- A local paper announced this morning the formation of a trust which aimed to control the publication of subscription books. The originators declare that the movement is not a trust, but simply a consolidation of four houses representing different branches of the printing and publishing business, with the intention of forming the largest complete printing and publishing house in the world.

Amy Levy, who bloomed, for a short season and whose tender yet despairing verse is not forgotten, wrote a romance of Jewish life in London, giving one phase of it -- the rather material one -- and possibly her slightly-sketched story was barely appreciated because little understood. Mr. Zangwill, in his "Children of the Ghetto," presents a panoramic view.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A gradual weakening of discount rates was apparent last week. The final quotations weze. Three months, 2; short, 1. At these figures bills were readily taken. The Continental competition which lately helped to increase rates has almost ceased, as the attention of the competitors has been directed to their own markets, where rates in a majority of cases have risen above London quotations.

Emil Kuckelhorn, an engineer in the employ of Thomas Wylie, lithographers at 132 and 134 West Twenty-fourth Street, was found dead in his engine room yesterday morning at 11 o'clock by officer Rinehart of the Nineteenth Precinct. The police believe Kuckelhorn was murdered and they expect to arrest the murderer.

"I was surprised," remarked M. Theophile Gignac, glancing round the walls of the Fencers' Club at the rows of foils and masks and the portraits of distinguished men of the sword -- "I was surprised on my arrival in Now-York the other day to find fencing here so live a sport. Certainly Paris alone can show so many good fencers."

At the evensong service in St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, last night, the anthem was an ingeniously-constructed selection from Handel's "Samson," covering a little over an hour in its performance by the choir, of which Mr. Alfred Stubbs Baker is the organist and musical director.

HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 11 -- A freight train on the Pennsylvania Railroad was wrecked at Silver Brook this morning. The train parted, the advance portion, with the engine attached, running far ahead of the rear. On approaching Silver Brook the red board was turned and Engineer Dewald reversed his engine and applied the airbrakes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The railroad managers of the country are a good deal interested in what Congress may do with the fifth section of the act to regulate commerce, which section forbids the pooling of freights and the division of earnings.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The reverses which have been experienced by the Democrats of this State in the municipal contests so far held may be accounted for in two ways. First, the best and most reliable candidates have not been put forward as leaders and standardbearers. Secondly, the mass of the Democratic voters believe that the mischievous and demoralizing alliance between the Police Department of this city and the liquor dealers should be rebuked.

"It will be impossible for Republican manipu- lators in Western States to unseat a Democrat who is rightfully elected without a struggle which will mean business," said a Democrat who had attended the sessions of the Campaign Committee during the last two days.

The Ninth Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., under orders from its commander, Col. William Seward, Jr., assembled at the armory on West Twenty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon, and went to church. It was the annual "march out" for Calvary Church, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, where the Rev. Dr. Maynard, Chaplain of the Regiment, preached his annual sermon.

In the Kingdom of Belgium, which is essentially a commercial and industrial country, and in which the mines especially require the employment of large bodies of men of varying degrees of intelligence, the question of good relations between the employers and the employed has been for many years a very difficult and thorny one.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 11 -- A bee tree, a scuttied boat, and a woman played prominent parts in what seems to be the murder of two men in Henrico County on Thursday last, but the facts were not known until late last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- The Committee on Ceremonies at the dedication of the World's Fair buildings will to-morrow figure up the dedication expenses. The report will show that $183,868.22 has been paid out and that about $35,000 is still to be paid.

President E. Ellery Andersen of the Reform Club said very emphatically yesterday that no slight had been intended to Speaker Crisp in not calling on him for a speech at the dinner in Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 11 -- Thomas E. Murphy, the temperance agitator, who has been holding meetings in this city for a fortnight, achieved a success to-day which is most remarkable. He advertised an address at the Grand Opera House at 7 o'clock, and at 6:45 the house was so crowded that, by orders of the Fire Marshal, the doors had to be closed.

Many prominent Democrats called on Mr. Cleveland Saturday. Some were Congressmen and Some were member of the National Committee. They talked about various matters of public interest. Some spoke about the advisability of calling an extra session. On this question Mr. Cleveland allowed his visitors to do most of the talking, and no one came away with a definite idea of his intentions as to this matter.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Now that there is a general scramble for the offices in the gift of the next administration, there is a great overhauling of the records of some of the incumbents, with a view to producing evidence that will justify their removal just as soon, as possible after the new administration gets into power.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 11 -- At the meeting of the Monetary Conference yesterday Herr Hans I. Forsell of the Sweden and Norway delegation, referring to Congressman McCleary's declared preference for a fixed ratio between gold and silver of 16 to 1, asked the Americana if they would agree to a ratio of 20 to 1, which would be a nearer approach to the present silver value.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- The papers consider that Major Hoininger-Heune's object in refusing to support the provision in the Army bill increasing the peace effective, and insisting that the two years' system be fixed by statute, is to prevent a compromise between the Centrists and the Government.

A large gang of men were at work yesterday, making repairs to the damaged bow of the French Line steamship La Bretagne, which was badly stove in by a collision Saturday afternoon with the pier at the foot of Franklin Street, North River.

Yesterday's services at the Memorial Baptist Church. Washington Square South, were devoted almost wholly to the dedication of the Hiram Deats Memorial Home for Children. The home is in the tower of the church edifice, the tower having been especially constructed for the purpose to which it has been devoted.

"Birdie" is lost. She's a small skye terrier which has lived for eleven years in Levi L. Brown's house at 9 West Fiftieth Street. There are many aristocratic dogs in that neighborhood, but none has been more exclusive than Birdie. She has been the pet of the family and an object of especial affection because of a chronic malady which has made her an invalid for several years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Rev. Father Ducey of New-York came to Washington to-day and his presence has revived the rumors concerning Mr. Blaine's religious views. To-night it is the talk at the hotels that the ex-Secretary of State is to become a member of the Roman Catholic Church, through the offices of Father Ducey, in a day or two.

The Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter of the Baptist Tabernacle, Tenth street and Second Avenue, preached yesterday morning on "Delivering the City from Crime," taking for his text the words," Deliver us from evil."

Congressman Benton McMillin of Tennessee, one of the half dozen candidates mentioned for Speaker of the Fifty-third House, gave his views yesterday about the tariff. "I think," he said, "there should be a prompt and general revision of the tariff. I do not think the mere touching up of the present tariff here and there will give the people the relief that they have a right to expect.

Some of the Republicans who attended the meeting of the leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Friday night, at which an attempt was made to determine Who should be the leader of the minority in the next Assembly, said yesterday that the action at that meeting would tear open old sores and add to the bitterness with which the fight for the somewhat empty honor is waging.

Nobody has any doubt what the election of Mr. CLEVELAND means. He haa explained it too often and too courageously to leave any question on that point, and he has explained it both before his nomination and since his election. The people have accepted his explanation, and nobody is in doubt as to what he means to do.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 11 -- The mystery of Miss Julia Hall of New-Canaan, who wandered from home last Friday and has remained secluded from her friends since that time, has been solved. Searching parties have scoured the woods and fields near her homo since her disappearance, but without success.

Joseph Siegel, thirty years old, a law clerk in the office of Henry Melville at 120 Broadway, was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Saturday night insane from overstudy. He was for several years the confidential clerk and stenographer of Daniel Dougherty, who died some months ago. Siegel's great ambition was to become a lawyer, particularly since the advent of female stenographers and typewriters had materially reduced the remuneration for that kind of work.

The Rev. Dr. Ensign McChesney, pastor of the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, at Sixtieth Street, was one of the passengers on the disabled North German Lloyd steamship Spree, and he assisted Evangelist Moody at the famous prayer meeting. Last night Dr. McChesney declared to his congregation that he was by no means sure that prayer saved the ship.

The first series of the Board of Education's free lectures for 1892-3 will end this week. Under the supervision of Dr. H.M. Leipziger, ninety lectures have been delivered to audiences averaging 500. The rapid growth of the course in popular favor may be seen from the fact that in 1890-91 the nightly attendances at each lecture was but 80.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- It is rarely that any legislation of practical importance is achieved in Congress before the new year, with the possible exception of one of the annual appropriation bills, and this session is not likely to prove exceptional in this regard. In both houses the work is progressing in a manner that indicates the lack of real earnestness.

The report of Mr. HEPBURN, the Controller of the Currency, contains many facts of decided interest, some recommendations of importance, and a little theorizing of no special significance, the unsoundness of which does not therefore require particular attention. During the year expiring Oct. 31 the number of banks increased by 94, bringing the total up to 3,788, and the capital stock by $9,112,800, making the total nearly $700,000,000, ($693,868,665.)

Secretary of the Navy B.F. Tracy begins his annual report for the year 1892, made to the President, by pointing out that nineteen vessels of the new navy have been put in commission during the present Administration, with an aggregate of 54,832 tons, and that eighteen vessels in process of construction are certain to be completed, should their armor be delivered, within the next year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Edmund P. Edwards, President of the Elizabeth Branch of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and who is one of the oldest and best-known business men of this city had a narrow escape from death last evening, being struck by a train from Newark while in the act of crossing the Central Railroad tracks from the station to the Union news stand.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 11 -- A Sunday paper published a startling story to-day of a conspiracy to poison, by wholesale, the non-union men at the Carnegie steel plant in Homestead. The developments made, it is said, implicate members of the Advisory Committee, members of the Amalgamated Association, and officers of some of the labor organizations sympathizing with the locked-out men at Homestead.

Ex-Alderman Samuel Henry Balley died of apoplexy at the residence of Joan Farrell, fourth Avenue and One Hundred and Third Street, Sunday afternoon. He was born in this city in 1846 and at the outbreak of the war entered the Forty-seventh New-York Volunteers, although he was but fourteen years old. After serving three years Mr. Balley left the army and took up a trade -- that of a marble cutter.

The three gangs of men sent out by the Bureau of Incumbrances to take down the illegally-strong overhead wires continued their wort yesterday. They confined themselves mainly to the wires of the Brush, Mount Morris, and United States Electric Light Companies in Grennwich, Cortlandt, Dey, Duane, State, and Whitehall Streets.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Dec. 12 -- P.M. Western Union, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Chicago Gas were the active stocks in today's market Western Union opened 7/8 up, and advanced to 98 1/2 in the first hour. After that there was considerable realizing, and for the remainder of the day the tendency was downward.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- Several of Boston's wellknown clergymen were seen yesterday and asked to give their opinions upon the claim of Evangelist Dwight L. Moody that the steamer Spree and her freight of 700 human beings were saved by prayer.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 12 -- The family of Benjamin E. Fanning, a farmer on Middle Road, Riverhead Township, L.I., had a wonderful escape from death by poisoning on Saturday, and a farm hand named Charles Ryder is in jail charged with the attempt on their lives.

-- Industrials yesterday were the feature in a stock market which, despite the announcement of gold engagements footing up several millions or dollars, was very active and strong throughout the day. Chicago Gas, Distillers, National Lead, National Starch, Cordage, Sugar, Cotton Oil -- all were higher.

The New-York Presbytery held its regular monthly session in the old Scotch Presbyterian Church, Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue yesterday afternoon. The attendance was small. The only matter of importance which, came up was the consideration of a report from a committee which had been appointed to consider the spiritual needs of the several sections of the city and ascertain the duty of Presbytery in relation thereto.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 12 -- President Harrison's measage to Congress continues to be closely scrutinized. The Hon. Mr. Foster, Dominion Minister of Finance, who recently returned from England, on being asked what he thought of the message, said:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 12 -- The Cincinnati Presbytery, in secret session, voted late this afternoon upon the second and third charges against Prof Henry P. Smith of Lane Theological Seminary, and he was found guilty of both charges.

It was farewell night in Shepard Hall last evening. A new curved sign on the building on the northeast corner of Fifty-seventh. Street and Sixth Avenue told passers-by that the room which Col Elliott F. Shepard hag given rent free to the Twenty-first District Republicans was to be found up stairs, but otherwise the place was not decorated in honor of the event.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- It has been known for some time by the friends of Elijah Halford, the President's private secretary, that he has wished to be sent to some consular post or as Minister to some foreign country. He has wanted an appointment of this kind, not for the emoluments of the office, but because his health is delicate and he thought that a stay abroad for a year or two would be beneficial.

The latest English papers are filled with the speech of Mr. CECIL RHODES before the shareholders of the British South Africa Company, of which he is President, and with comments on the speech. Certainly the achievements of that gentleman and of his First Lieutenant, Dr. JAMESON, are of the most impressive character as reported, toy Mr. RHODES.

The proposed tunnel from the Flatbush Avenue (Brooklyn.) station of the Long Island Railroad to the Pennsylvania station in Jersey City is taking shape rapidly, and Austin Corbin, who is engineering it, has interested a great many Pennsylvania men in the deal. He has his working plans all drawn up and will apply to the Aldermen for a franchise within a few weeks.

Negotiations nave been completed for the erection of another fine new hotel in this city. The site of the proposed structure is at Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue, at present occupied by the Hotel Wellington. William S. Hawk and Gardner Wetherbee, proprietors of the Windsor Hotel, and Bernhard Belnecke and Joseph Headorfer, provision dealers at 196 Fulton Street, are the promoters of the enterprise.

Thomas Dixon, Jr., attracted considerable attention at yesterday's mooting of the Baptist ministers. A week ago the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter was reported in the morning newspapers as having in his Sunday's sermon passed some scatching criticisms on a minister in his own denomination, who, although no name was mentioned, was known by every one to be Mr. Dixon.

Matthew Johnson, the West Indian negro at whose hands Engineer Emil Kuckelhorn met his death on Saturday afternoon, was arrested at 10 o'clock last night by Detectives Burns, Sulivan, and Lang at the corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street. He made no resistance, and went peaceably to the Thirtieth Street Station House with his captors.

The last number of the London Economist contains two articles on the general subject of the International Monetary Conference and the matters with which it has to deal. Both are very calm in tone, very careful in the statement of facts, logical in construction, and, above all, apply to the questions an amount of clear common sense quite unusual in the treatment of the conference.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- In the Reichstag to-day Count von Mirbach, a member of the Conservative Party, asked the Government to assist the bimetallists at the International Monetary Conference at Brussels.

The downward course of the market price of silver is shown incidentally by certain statistics in the report of the Controller of the Currency, Under the act of 1878 the Government paid $308,199,262 for silver bullion, and coined this silver into dollar pieces. At the market-price a month and a half ago, when these statistics were prepared, the Government could have sold this silver for not more than $260,493,936.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Philip D. Armour, the millionaire packer, started to-night for New-York on his way to Europe, leaving behind him a Christmas gift of over $1,500,000 to the City of Chicago. Absolutely unknown to the public, work has been going on for a year past toward the erection of a magnificent five-story building on Armour Avenue, and it is now all but ready for occupancy.

NEW-YORK -- The Christmas number of the Sunday Mercury contains in its fifty-two pages a choice collection of stories by John Habberton, Octave Thanet, George Parsons Lathrop, Julian Hawthorne, Ida Burwash, and Edmund F. Sheppard. The illustrations are very attractive, while the cover has a picture in seven colors, "Ye Gentlemen and Dames of Oldon Times."

Thomas G. Ritch has not yet prepared his answer in the Fayerweather suit. He has turned the matter over to his law partner, ex-Judge Arnoux, who will get it ready in a few days. Mr. Ritch said yesterday that there would be no needless delay.

On the night of Dec. 1 the wife of Police Justice Meade and her daughter went to the Manhattan Opera House, and after the performance, as they rose to leave, Miss Moado's purse fell from her lap to the floor. She discovered her loss when she reached the lobby and went back to see if she could find the missing pocketbook.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The trial of Father Corrigan, which must show whether there is room for Americanism within the Catholio Church, was begun this afternoon at the residence of Mgr. Doane, 35 Bleecker Street, this city.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 12 -- A new and unexpected element has entered into the Senatorial contest that not only surprises the Populist and Republican leaders, but somewhat non-pluses the former.

The Patriarchs were twenty years old yester- day, and they celebrated the entrance upon the third decade of their history with a "function" that surpassed in size and brilliancy all of the previous Parriarchs' balls. The dance was, as usual, given at Delmonice's, and for the sixtieth time the Patriarchs were the hosts of the wealth and beauty of New-York.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The poet, William, Watson, who was recently granted L200 from the Royal Bounty Fund for writing the best ode on Tennyson, and has even been urged for the Laureateship, has become violently insane and has been placed in an asylum by order of the court at at Windsor, where he was arraigned to-day as the result of an escapade.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 12 -- "Whoop Up," a grade camp on the Burlington Road, near Sheridan, Wyoming, was the scene Saturday night of a robbery accompanied by two murders. A.J. Case's saloon, where money was kept to redeem due bills, wae raided.

The trial of the Rev. PATRICK CORRIGAN, which began yesterday, is likely to have very interesting and momentous results. It is the first occasion on which issue has been fairly joined between those ecclesiastics who favor and those who obstruct the Americanizing of the Roman Catholic Church.

The anticipated fight over the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, caused by the belief of William Richardson, John G. Jenkins, and William Marshall that the minority stockholders were going to be swindled when the road is leased to the proposed Brooklyn Traction Company, subsided very quickly yesterday. President Lewis called a meeting of the Executive Committee, to which he invited Mr. Marshall and Mr. Jenkins, and explained everything to their satisfaction.

The act passed by the last Legislature creating the Board of Records, the business of which will be to superintend the re-indexing of the records in the Register's office under the block system, says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A comprehensive bill to enable national banks to increase their circulation and to suspend further purchases of silver was introduced in the House to-day by Representative Andrew (Dam., Mass.)

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Supreme Court of me United States to-day decided in favor of Collis P. Huntington in his suit against Henry Y. Attrill to recover the amount of a judgment of $102,000. Attrill was a large stockholder end Director in theRockaway Beach Improvement Company, Limited.
The following business was transacted at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom yesterday, Monday, Dec. 12:

Senator Carlisle, who came to this city from Washington to confer with members of the Democratic National Campaign Committee on the situation In several Western States which are to elect United States Senators this year, returned yesterday afternoon. During the day the only fresh information received in this city, aside from toe newspaper dispatches from Montana, was a dispatch from California which briefly outlined the situation in that State.
The long-drawn contest over the will of Mrs. Levinia O. Van Emburg, which has been before Surrogate Stephens of Richmond County for nearly a year, will be brought to a close on Dec. 30.

There was nothing in the appearance of Miss Esther Jacobs, plaintiff in the fifty-thousand-dollar breach of promise suit brought by her against Henry B. Sire to indicate, as she took a seat in the Superior Court room, Part I., yesterday morning that she carried a bleading heart. On the contrary, she seemed to be in the possession of excellent health and a mind free from eare.

The gold exporting business took a boom yesterday, when $2,250,000 is coin was taken from the Sub-Treasury for shipment to-day on the North German Lloyd steamer Saale. Heidelbach, Ickelhelmer Co. took $1,000,000, Baring, Magoun Co. $300,000, and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. $750,000.

By order of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction the bones that may be accumulated by the department the coming year, the coal tar that may be produced by it, and the grease, mixed rags, old brass, empty iron-bound whisky barrels, empty iron-bound oil and vinegar barrels, and empty syrup barrels that may be piled up the coming year were sold in advance at auction at the department headquarters yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 12 -- J. Tonel and Matt O'Dougherty, attorneys for K.J. Beatty, supposed to be connected, with the Homestead poisoning case, to-day applied to Judge Toney, in the Law and Equity Court, for a writ of habeas corpus.

Many statements have been made by the illadvised friends of Speaker Crisp as to the arrangements for the Reform Club dinner last Saturday night, which, according to President E. Ellery Andersen, are not founded on fact.

The city authorities are preparing to make a rigorous protest against the bill pending in the United States Senate which proposes to give the authority of the National Government for the construction of the bridge across the Hudson River projected by the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The Government practice cruiser Bancroft at 11:40 A.M. to-day was cut loose from her moorings at the wharf of the Samuel L. Moore Sons Company at Elizabethport, and with a jolly party of seventy-five guests aboard steamed down through the Kills and New-York Bay and through the Narrows out as far as Scotland Light on her preliminary trial trip.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- At the annual meeting of the Union League to-night John Russell Young was elected President. The much-talked-of question of disciplining the leaguers who voted for and aided the candidacy of President-elect Cleveland was brought up early in the meeting by C. Eugene Claghorn, who offered a resolution looking to that end.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 12 -- The Navy Department has had a thorogh inspection made of the two new transport steamers Ann Arbor and Ann Arbor No. 2, constructed within the past few weeks at this port, with the view of having plans drawn up for the immediate conversion of these two ships into powerful fighting vessels, in the event of a sudden defense being necessary of the great lakes frontier.

A continuous storm of applause greeted the athletes at the annual Winter games of the Twelfth Regiment Athletic Club, held last night at the armory, Sixty-second Street and Ninth Avenue. They were witnessed by a crowd of over 2,000 persons, who cheered anything and everything, from the victorious prize-winners to the plucky bat unfortunate stragglers.

The will and three codicils disposing of the wealth of Jay Gould, were filed in the surrogate's Court with Probate Clerk Tinney by exJudge John F. Dillon. The citations were made returnable Dec. 27. Accompanying the will and codicils were the petition for probate and an affidavit in accordance with statute, giving the estimated value of the real estate disposed of specifically.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- President Rompers opened the twelfth annual session of the American Federation of Labor in Independence Hall this morning. The most striking figure in the hall was ex-President Weihe of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers. W.A. Carney, his successor, also came in for a share of attention, as did all the men who were engaged in the Homestead fight, who occupied seats together close to the President's desk.

A novel foot race took place in London a short time ago. It was open only to men fifty years of age or over, and the contestants were allowed a handicap of fifty yards fop every year over fifty. Among the entries was Jackson, the "American Deer," who is seventy-one years old. One of the men who faced the starter, B. Moorhouse, is seventy-three years old.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Temps to-day states that the first examination of the remains of Baron Reinach proves that he died from the effects of poison, and not from apoplexy, which was at first given as the cause of death.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Real Estate Exchange yesterday afternoon proved to be the liveliest -- so far as acrimony or debate was concerned -- that the organization ever held. Since the meeting of 1891 the auctioneers' accession and migration to 111 Broadway have taken, place, and yesterday the first chance was given for both sides to get together and express free opinions in open meeting on the merits of the controversy.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 12 -- George M. Woodbridge, the cashier of the Savings Bank of Richmond and a prominent man here, committed suicide this evening by shooting himself through the heart. The tragedy occurred at the borne of Mr. Woodbridge, in the fashionable neighborhood of Franklin Street, near Third. He was at his desk in the bank all day and appeared in the best of spirits.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 12 -- Informations are to be made shortly against persons implicated in the alleged poisoning plot against Homestead steel workers, and sensational developments are expected. As yet the attorneys for the Carnegie Steel Company are reticent, as the publication came before their plans had fully matured.
BUFFALO, Dec. 12 -- "Assemblyman Guenther has announced himself a candidate for Speaker," said a reporter to Lieut. Gov. Sheehan.

Mrs. James H. Disbrow died some months ago, leaving an estate valued at over $200,000, and her sons and daughters, as well as her sons-in-law, have been fighting over it ever since. They have stirred up so much, bad blood that they were all forced into a police court yesterday during an enforced adjournment of the contest over the will of Mrs. Disbrow.

To the Rev. Dr. Alexander Mackay-Smith, exArchdeacon of New-York, who is about to assume the pastorate of St. John's Church, Washington, D.C., a fare troll dinner was given yesterday by his former associates in the New-York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society. The dinner was served at St. Barnabas's House on Mulberry Street.

Within the coming six weeks there will be offered for sale at auction marts in different sections of the country something like 2,500 horses that are known to trotting breeders as "standard bred" animals. Most of these are horses that will naturally move at the trotting gait, though there are a number of pacers among them.

The good Col. Elliott P. Shepard of the Mail and Express betook himself and a couple of lawyers to Part II. of the Supreme Court yesterday, to defend his purse and his character from the assaults of Frank S. Gray, who was for several months in charge of the Colonel's paper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A singular state of affairs in the Circuit Court of Appeals, embracing the States of Ohio and Indiana, was developed to-day in the United States Supreme Court, when a motion was made in the suit arising out of the operations of the "young Napoleon of finance," Henry S.
