Ives, in the affairs of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Commander in Chief Woissert of the national Grand Army of the Republic, has appointed the following comrades as Aides de Camp on his staff:

Robert Fitzsimmons, the auburn-haired congneror of "Jack " Dempsey, ana James Hall, the tall youth who recently cut short the pugilistic career of "Ted " Pritchard, the pride of the English prize ring, met in the office of Sporting Editor Dickinson yesterday afternoon and arranged all preliminaries for their fight, which is to take place at the Crescent City Club, New-Orleans, next March.

A fire which, long after the engines were in full operation, appeared destined to sweep away stock and property worth $1,500,000 at 561 and 563 Broadway, was announced a little after 6 P.M. yesterday by an automatic signal. The men of Engine Company No. 20 found the north side or the third floor, occupied by the Holland Manufacturing Company of Willimantio, Conn., manufacturers of spool silk, all ablaze.

The will of Wilson G. Hunt, the wealthy retired cloth merchant, who died at the Clarendon Hotel on Dec. 7, was filed for probate yesterday. It disposes of an estate estimated to amount to between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000, the bulk of which is left to the family of the testator's brother Thomas.

The celebrated Russian artist, Prof. T. Aivasovsky, who is visiting this city, sent a crisp new one-hundred-dollar bill to the Press Club Building and Charity Fund yesterday as a token of his appreciation of the charitable activities of that organization. Prof. Aivasovsky will remain in New-York until April, when he will go to Chicago as one of the Russian Commissioners to the exposition.

President John L.N. Hunt of the Board of Education has not yet decided to make a statement as to whether he intends to be a candidate for re-election at the meeting of the board on the first Wednesday in January. He said yesterday: "The idea of there being a ring in the board is preposterous." Mr. Maclay, who is also mentioned as a candidate, has not said definitely what he intends to do.

Since the very great extent of the victory won for tariff reform became entirely plain, we have learned of opinions expressed by a considerable number of manufacturers regarding the future of their business. In each of some twenty cases these gentlemen were engaged in what have been known as highly "protected" industries, and those precisely such as, according to the predictions of the Republicans before the election, would be ruined by tariff reform.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Light receipts of hogs, with higher prices at the yards, gave the provision market considerable strength early. The feature of the morning was the selling of January and buying of May product by traders who have been on the long side and made so much money on the advance in January stuff. The market was unsettled and after several turns, closed irregularly, some deliveries being higher and some lower than Monday.

The University Settlement Society held its annual meeting last night at the Buckingham Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue. Mr. Henry Holt presided. The chief feature of the evening was an address by Dr. Stanton Colt, the founder of the movement out of which the present society has grown.

Very peaceful affairs, as a rule, were the Republican primary elections held in all the Assembly districts yesterday. A week ago there was brave talk about the great fights that were going to take place at some of the primaries, but the talk simmered down into inactivity in most cases, and only a few impotent contests against the old machine were made.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Chauncey M. Depew, who is in Washington to give the InterState Commerce Committee of the Senate his views of the scope of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, met a number of friends in the Arlington lobby to-night. Among them was William Brookfield, Chairman of the New-York State Republican Committee, and the two talked freely of politics and business.

Capt. O'Connor and his staff of detectives were busy yesterday in gathering up all the ends of evidence which may convict the colored man Johnson of murdering Engineer Kuckelhorn. They have no doubt of the prisoner's guilt.

The suit of Frank S. Gray, formerly general manager of the Mail and Express, to recover between $18,000 and $19,000 in cash from Elliott F. Shepard, the owner of that paper, for breach of contract, was continued yesterday before Judge Parker in Part II. of the Supreme Court.

At the meeting, of the Board of Managers of the Metropolitan Association, Amateur Athletic Union, on Oct. 15, the President, William B. Curtis, requested the members to appoint their own standing committees, but they refused to do so, and passed a resolution instructing President Curtis himself to appoint the standing committees and to submit a list to each of the members for their approval or disapproval by mail vote.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 13 -- Despite the stay received by counsel for Mayor Gleason of this city, Clerk Thomas P. Burke, that much-sought-for official, failed to appear at the Common Council meeting to perform his duties last night. Alderman William M. Heidt was made temporary Clerk in the absence of Burke in order that the minutes of the meeting could be cerilfied to.

The Central Cleveland and Stevenson Campaign Club of Brooklyn, the largest Democratic organization in that city, which held weekly meetings during the campaign in the Criterion Theatre, Brooklyn, held a meeting at Haviland Hall Monday evening and by unanimous vote adopted the following:

Arrangements for the big carnival of sports in Madison Square Garden by the New-York Press Club on Saturday afternoon are now nearly completed and an excellent entertainment of sports is promised. In the atternoon the events will be particularly pleasing to women and children. Much care has been exercised in the selection of the sports. It will be unobjectionable to the most fastidious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Two bills, nearly identical in language, the one relating to the famous La Abra Company claim and the other to the claim or Abraham Weil, were to-day passed by the House. Both bills had been passed at the last session of the Senate.

The Chamber of Commerce of this city has performed an inestimable public service in causing a special committee to investigate and report upon the quarantine service of this port. The action of this committee and of the Medical Advisory Committee which it appointed to assist in its work did much to mitigate the evils of the administration of the service as they found it and to institute improvements.

MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The authorities at the lunatic asylum at this place were somewhat startled the other day at receiving official notice from the Passaic County Board of Chosen Freeholders to the effect that from and after Jan. 1 next that body would no longer pay for the support of county patients who had been, in the asylum for more than three years.

Representatives in this city of transatlantic steamship lines were greatly interested yesterday on learning of the action iaken, in view of the possibility of the suspension of immigration by the United States Government, by the Continental Steamship Conference, the headquarters of which are in London.

NEW-LIGHT, N.C., Dec. 13 -- The ingenious contrivances of the moonshiners of the Southern States to outwit the revenue officials are many and of the most unique kind. The latest was unearthed near this place last week.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The new State Board, of Arbitration held another meeting at the State House to-day. Joseph P. McDonnell of Paterson presided. The board appointed Col. John W. Romaine of Paterson clerk of the board at a per diem compensation for services.

The New-York Mercantile Exchange had its annual election yesterday, and the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President -- William Wills; Vice Presidents -- W.E. Smith, M.W. Carr, W.G. French, A.G.,Reed; Treasurer -- D.B. Halstead; Executive Committee -- W.H. Duckworth, W.L. McKinney, Edward Zimmer, S. Rowland, Edward Ruhlman, C.H. Zinn, B.F. Van Valkenburgh, G.H. Stege, Henry Hanson; Inspectors of Election -- J.R. Soutwick, I.H. MacBride, J.H. Groght.

Miss Esther Jacobs, plaintiff in the Jacobs-Sire breach of promise case, had the same air of self-possession when she took the stand yesterday in Part I., Superior Court that she were when she was under examination Monday. Mr. Sire, the defendant, occupied a seat in the rear of his three lawyers, and was somewhat shielded from the eyes of the jury.

The joint committee from the Senate and Assembly appointed to inquire into the subject of taxation met yesterday at the Hotel Normandie and organized for an investigation which it is expected will continue for several days. The process of organization took up the greater portion of the afternoon, because of a squabble over the choice of a stenographer.

Recorder Smyth and City Chamberlain Crain, acting as a committee of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, met in the Chamberlain's office yesterday afternoon and heard evidence as to the value of the property fronting on Riverside Park needed by the city for the protection of the park.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Inconsequence of M. Clemenceau's letter published in the Figaro connecting M. Rouvier, the Finance Minister, with the Panama scandal, M. Rouvier called upon President Carnot at the Palace of the Elysee to-day and handed in the resignation of his Finance portfolio.

The Hudson County Bar Association, after electing Washington B. Williams President, William P. Douglas Vice President, James A. Gordon Treasurer, and William C. Cudlipp Secretary, adopted resolutions, at a meeting held in Jersey City Monday night, indorsing the proposed appointment of Job H. Lippincott to the Supreme Court Judgeship which Judge Werts is to step out of when he becomes Governor next month.

Two men assaulted James H. Morton of 319 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, as he was coming down the stairs leading from the platform of the down-town elevated railroad station at the Bowery and Houston Street last evening, cut him severely on the back of the head, and robbed him of a diamond stud valued at $500, with which they escaped.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 13 -- Two hundred teachers and other employes of the Long Island City schools learned yesterday that they cannot hope to get their arrearages of salaries, to say nothing of those to come, for many months.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- The general debate on the Army bill was continued in the Reichstag today. The Saxon Minister of War spoke strongly in favor of the bill. He said that his Government indorsed it in every particular, and thus contradicted the rumors to the effect that the King of Saxony was irreconcilably opposed to the passing of the bill.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13 -- There were no new developments to-day in the case of Bishop Wigger against his priest. Father Corrigan of Hoboken. A lot of wild rumors found their way into various papers in Newark and New-York. It was stated that there had been a compromise and that the case would never be tried.

President Seth Low was the chief guest at the annual dinner of the alumni of Columbia College in the Hotel de Logerot last night. He made a pleasant speech, fall of interesting reminiscences and also of encouragement for the college's future. He said that the union of the College of Physicians and Surgeons with Columbia was a great thing for both institutions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The naval ordnance experts propose to try smokeless powder in the eight-inch breech-loading guns, having had such encouraging success with the powder fired in the six-inch rifle.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- At to-day's session of the American Federation of Labor President Gompers road a communication from Congressman Amos J. Cummings, who had received an invitation too late to be present. In writing on the struggle of labor he said:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 13 -- The news that the remnants of Catarina Garza's revolutionary army have again started a campaign against Mexico created much excitement at Military Department Headquarters here to-day and among the Mexican population of San Antonio. The first confirmatory or official news received here of the battle near San Ygnacio was contained in the following telegram to Dr. Plutarco Ornclas, the Mexican Consul here, this morning:

-- The annual meeting or the stockholders of the Baltimore and Philadelphia Railroad Company was held in Wilmington, Del. yesterday. For the ensuyear Thomas M. King, J.B. Washington, William M. Canby. William Canby, Henry A. Dupont, George De B. Keim, Theodore Frothingham, and J. Vau Smith wore re-elected Directors.

National Quarantine is demanded by the needs of the country; Dr. Jenkins is not a competen Health Officer of the Port of New-York. These are the conclusions reached by the Special Committee on Quarantine of the Chamber of Commerce after a lons and thorough investigation.

There was a full meeting of the Directors of the Manhattan Railway yesterday and George J. Gould was elected President of the company without a dissenting vote. Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan made a little speech in which he referred to Mr. Jay Gould's long identification with the elevated railroad system ana Mr. George Gould's familiarity with the details of its management.

Mrs. George F. Shrndy's dancing class had its first gathering for this season last evening. This class was organized by Mrs. Shrady a year ago and held a series of successful dances in Hodgson's Assembly Rooms. The increase in the attendance uecessitated larger quarters, so that the dances this year will be held in the Mendelssohn Assembly Rooms, in West Fiftyfifth Street.

Members of the Republican Club gave a dinner to John Sabine Smith at the clubhouse, 450 Fifth Avenue, last night. Mr. Smith was the candidate for Additional Surrogate at the recent election and ran ahead of his ticket, and the dinner was a love feast to celebrate that fact. About seventy-five Republicans were present.

There seems to be little doubt now that the late Jay Gould had in mind, at one time some plan of a public bequest, and that as a result one educational institution will profit by it to some extent. Those in a position to speak with authority on the subject are inclined to be reticent in regard to the matter. Mr. Russell Sage alone vouchsafes anything that borders on definiteness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The ladies of the Cabinet families have made the official announcement that they will not be at home to callers on Wednesdays during the present month. This was decided on Saturday last. It was also decided that the Cabinet houses should not be open for reception on New Year's Day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- There is a good deal of talk among the World's Fair Directors and others immediately connected with the management of the "White City" of continuing the fair for another year after November next. The leaders believe that six months is rather a short time for the life of the splendid palaces that have been erected at Jackson Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Naval Hydrographic Office continues to receive favorable reports of the use of oil on occasions of high seas. This practice has been urged upon mariners by the Hydrographic officers and a record is kept of the different methods pursued at sea during storms.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Under the law the State Board of Canvassers must meet on Thursday and conclude their labors on Monday. The now law provides that nothing but the total vote of all persons voted for greater than a county officer be canvassed by the State Board. This does away with the certifying of the tabulated vote by counties.

The New-York Quill Club had its twenty-fourth monthly meeting last evening, and, after a dinner at Clark's, listened to a discussion on "Tramps." The principal addresses were made by Prof. MoCook of Trinity College of Hartford and W.M.F. Round, Corresponding Secretary of the Prison Association of New-York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- One of the moat interesting possibilities of the World's Fair year is a boat race for the championship of the world between the winning crew of the Oxford-Cambridge boat race and the winning crew of the Harvard-Yale race. It in proposed that this race tke place in Chicago or near it, and already the two great American colleges have had considerable correspondence with the English universities.

At a special meeting of the New-York Yacht Club, held last night at the clubhouse, 67 Madison Avenue, the challenge of the Royal Yacht Squadron in behalf of Lord Dunraven to race for the America's Cup next year was unanimously accepted. The Cup Committee, appointed Oct. 18 to correspond with Dunraven, presented a long report of the correspondence in detail, and at its suggestion the following was adopted:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A few days after the election James L. Norris, member of the Democratic National Committee for the District of Columbia, called a meeting of Democrats of the District, and appointed a committee to arrange for the inauguration of Mr. Cleveland. Some of the Democrats of a faction opposed to Mr. Norris made a very lively protest against the action, and appealed to Chairman Harrity to have the proceeding set aside.

MERRITT, Minn., Dec. 13 -- When the iron-producing industry of the United States was first established it was imperative to build the small blast furnaces at sufficient distance from the Atlantic seaboard to establish a freight-protective zone between the furnaces of the interior and the ports into which iron-laden British ships sailed.

Controller Theodore W. Myers wants to have the franchise of the North and East River Railway Company declared forfeited, because the company never has paid a cent to the city for the franchise. The franchise was bought at auction under the Cantor act in May, 1887, and was for an electric street railway running through Fulton and West Streets and connectine the Fulton and Chambers Street Ferries.

The Nineteenth Century Club met last evening in the white-and-gold ballroom at Sherry's to listen to a discussion on the "Significance of the New-England Transformation," in two papers read by President William De Witt Hyde of the New-England Institute and Edward Atkinson of Massachusetts, the famous economist.

The Elizabeth Home for Girls, recently taken pessession of by the Children's Aid Society at 307 East Twelfth Street, was formally opened yesterday and dedicated to the purposes for which it was designed by the donors.

Sheriff John J. McPhillips of Hudson County, N.J., died in Jersey City last evening. He injured his knee while getting into his carriage a few days ago. Tho iron step at the carriage's side is said to have out into the flesh. Blood poisoning set in, and since Sunday night he had been unconscious.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Union of Conservative Associations held its annual meeting in Sheffield to-day. The attendance of delegates from all parts of the kingdom was very large, over 1,000 representatives from the various associations being present. The first business proceeded with was the election of officers of the union for the ensuing year.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13 -- There is a determination in Georgia to have a new Constitutional Convention. The question has taken shape in the Legislature through Willis Reagan's measure for that purpose now before the House. The author of the bill had passed at the Summer session of the General Assembly the bill providing for the holding of a State Constitutional Convention for the purpose of changing the Constitution and framing a new one.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Henry F. Allen, the referee appointed by Justice Height in the matter of The People vs. The Life and Reserve Association of Buffalo, which involves charges of dishonesty against ex-Judge Harlan J. Swift, a prominent attorney of this city, who was once President of the association, and also a Director, has filed his report exonerating Judge Swift.

The New-York Tribune has begun to point out serious defects in the McKinley tariff, which it has so many times described as "the bravest and wisest of tariff bills yet framed." It recently asserted that the makers of this tariff were guilty of "unbusinesslike" conduct in framing that part of this "wisest" of all tariff laws which relates to reciprocity, so called, and to the duties on certain products of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 13 -- A naval engineer has been delving into the old records and has discovered some interesting and significant facts, Passed Assistant Engineer L.N. Hollis, who recently delivered a series of lectures on steam engineering before the student officers at the Naval War College at Newport, has compared the old ship Wampanoag, condemned in 1869, with, the Charleston and Cruiser No. 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Immediately upon taking charge of the war portfolio, Secretary Elkins announced a plan of reorganization in a general order to the army. Brig. Gen. Williams, Adjutant General of the army, was placed in charge of the Division of Military Information, with Major MacArthur, Assistant Adjutant General, as assistant in charge.

Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday reserved his decision on a motion to have H.W.T. Steinway compelled to reply to new matter brought out in the answer of William Steinway to his complaint in a suit brought against him and the corporation of Steinway Sons. H.W.T. Steinway is a nephew of William Steinway, and his suit is brought as a stockholder in Steinway Sons.

CINAINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 13 -- The Cincinnati Presbytery, by a vote of 31 to 27 as unofficially reported, has silenced one of its brightest scholars until such time as he shall agree to renounce his views upon inspiration and cease to teach them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The so-called dynamite cruiser Vesuvius will be subjected to another trial with, a view to showing the efficiency of her fixed pneumatic weapons. The trial will not take place in Narragansett Bay, as was originally intended, but at Port Royal, S.C.

The Dramatic Authors' Club sat down to its first annual banquet at midnight last night. The circumstance requiring the hour was that the managers and actors who had been invited could not get around until after the theatres closed.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark.. Dec. 13 -- The Pulaski County Grand Jury reached a decision in the missing scrip case this morning, and as a result of their deliberations ex-State Treasurer William Woodruff has been arrested, holding him responsible for the mysterious disappearance of $15,000 live scrip, which subsequently turned up in the German Bank in this city.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The casino of the Union County Country Club was brilliantly lightly and profusely decorated last evening for the first of the "assemblies" for the season of 1892-3. These dances were started, a few years ago, and have grown in popularity each season under the careful management of the Board of Directors, consisting of wires of members of the Union County Country Club.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- One of the largest and most destructive fires that over visited the water front of this city started shortly after 8 o'clock this morning in the cotton warehouse of Alexander Brown, at the corner of Bond and Thames Streets, and quickly spread throughout the adjoining five buildings, covering an area of about two acres.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 -- At the sitting to-day of the International Monetary Conference, Sir Guildford D. Houldsworth, one of the two delegates representing the Indian Government, protested against the constructions offered by the British delegates at this and previous conferences. But for the tactics employed by the representatives of Great Britain, the currency question would have been settled long ago.

One more attempt to reorganize the shattered ranks of the Republican Party in Kings County was made last night, and one more failure was recorded. The subject which has been talked of for months came up, a long report was read and then buried under a resolution to table it.

The Bar Association stamped with its disapproval the appointment or Isaac H. Waynard to the bunch or the Court of Appeals by Gov. Flower as a reward for his work in aid of the schemes of David B. Hill. The disapproval took the form of a memorial to the Legislature asking for the removal of Judge Maynard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The atttention of the Secretary of State, John W. Foster, was called to the long interview, which was telegraphed from Ottawa yesterday, with the Canadian Minister of Finance, the Hon. George E. Foster, containing a detailed review or President Harrison's message. Secretary Foster stated that the Canadian Finance Minister's arraignment of the President was neither justified by the message nor sustained by his long criticism.

GUERRERO, Mexico, Dec. 13 -- The Government telegraph line which passes through this place has been repaired and for the first time a complete official report of the bloody battle near San Ygnacio was sent to military headquarters to-day. The invasion of the revolutionists has produced intense excitement throughout the Rio Grande border country, both on the United States and Mexican side of the river.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- The State Commission in Lunacy has made an older defining the rules which must be observed by Superintendents of State hospitals, by all county, city, and town officials, and by relatives and friends when unaccompanied by a public officer, in the removal of insane patients to State hospitals and in their transfer from one State hospital to another.
NEW-YORK, Tuesday, Dec. 13, 1892. Coal -- The outlet has considerably increased, and stocks are now down to a basis easily controlled. Prices are firm and unchanged.

At a meeting of the bondholders of the Oregon Pacific Railway, in the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company Building, yesterday, the announcement was made that the plan of reorganization which was formed last Spring was a failure. The road is now in the hands of a receiver, and under an order from the Oregon Supreme Court it is to be sold at public auction Jan. 16.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 14.--With the remainder of the State officers refusing to recognize John E. Osborne as Governor, Wyoming is without an Executive. Mr. Osborne's sensational introduction into office two weeks ago was a seizure in the belief that there was no other way to get the place from the Republicans, as the law was obscure.

The plays to be produced at the opening performance at Proctor's Theatre this evening of the Theatre of Arts and Letters were named yesterday by Mr. McDowoll. For a curtain raiser, at 8:30 o'clock, the one-act play selected is entitled "Drifting." The piece to follow, which is termed by the as yet unknown author "a dramatic impreaaion," bears the designation of "Mary Maberly."

The congregation of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, of which the late Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby was pastor, voted last night to extend a unanimous call to the Rev. John B. Davies of Tyrone, Penn. The meeting was harmonious, and was representative of every interest in the church.

One of the newest and worthiest charitable organizations formed by citizens of foreign birth for the bettering of the condition of their countrymen is the Spanish-American Benevolent Society, rounded last February and incorporated under New-York laws. Its President is Dr. Ramon L. Miranda, the Vice President is Dr. Buenaventura Portuondo, the Secretary is Gonzalo de Quesada of 307 West Twenty-eighth Street, and the Treasurer is Manuel F. Barranco.

FARGO, N.D., Dec. 14 -- Chairman Daniel Mara of the Democratic State Central Committee was here to-day malting arrangements to contest the issue of a certificate to one of the Harrison Presidential Electors, one Wamberg, who has a majority of eight votes on the face of the returns.

The Board of Directors of the National Fire Insurance Company of 35 Pine Street, which was established in 1838, having decided to liquidate the company's affairs, its outstanding risks have been reinsured in the Commercial Union Assurance Company of London, England.

The Captain, first officer, and eight of the crew of the Red Star Liner Noordland were presented yesterday with the medals of the New-York Life-Saving Benevolent Association on account of their recent gallant rescue of the crew of the Norwegian bark Konig Oscar II. The presentation took place just before noon on board the Noordland, which lay at her pier in Jersey City.

The annual reception yesterday of the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, 487 Hudson Street, was largely attended. In connection with the formal exercises which prefaced the sociability a very pretty fair was opened by its promoters among whom Mrs. Bryson, Mrs. Kane, Mrs. O'Connor, Mrs. Williams, and Miss Emily Beach were conspicuous.

Counsel for Henry B. Sire, defendant in the suit brought by Miss Esther Jacobs to recover $50,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, opened fire on the plaintiff yesterday in the Superior Court, Part I. The attack was directed against her claims to being a fine singer, entitled to especial damages because of alleged abandonment of a promising musical career at Sire's request.

There was a large wedding at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Tucker of 419 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, at 7 o'clock last evening. Their daughter, Miss Emma Josephine Tucker, was married to William Anthon Nicolay of this city. The venerable Dr. Theodore Cuyler, formerly pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, performed the ceremony.

In their eighth annual report, winch the Commissioners of the State Reservation at Niagara will soon make to the Legislature of New-York through the President of the board, Andrew H. Green, a special appropriation of $25,000 will be requested for the purpose of completing certain improvements already under way.

Steamship agents were not disposed to be communicative yesterday concerning the proposed establishment of a national quarantine. They seemed, however, to consider that a Federal control of quarantine would be a good thing.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Dec. 14 -- Chief of Police Turner cleared up the Chesapeake and Ohio vestibule-train robbery and murder to-day by the arrest of Tom Collins at Bradrick, just across the river, in Ohio. He was charged with the murder of the German passenger and with being a confederate of Burrell Forgey, who was taken into custody last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wood gave a reception and dance at Delmonico's last evening in honor of their daughter, Miss Emma Wood. Mrs. and Miss Wood were assisted in receiving by Mrs. Lucien B. Chase. Mrs. Wood were a gown of pearl gray satin. Miss Wood was dressed in white satin with delicate embroidery of gold lace.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- A fearful explosion occur- red to-day at the Bamfurlong Colliery, Wigan, and many lives have been lost.
The old fight between the men who drive horses and the men who ride horses in Central Park was resumed before the Part Commissioners yesterday.

The Navy Department has decided to place the new coast-defense battle snip Monterey in commission as soon as her steam trials are ended. To enable this to be done, the turrets will be given a temporary jacketing of one-half-inch steel plates. This recourse will make toe turret space impervious to water, and the vessel, in consequence, seaworthy.

When Prof. Charles Augustus Brings of Union Theological Seminary, defendant in the great heresy trial before the New-York Presbytery in the old Scotch Church, Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, went to the reading desk yesterday afternoon he found there a superb bunch of assorted roses. Who the donor was he had no idea, but the tribute was none the less a bright spot in the ordeal through which he was passing.

Sidney Thomas, the speedy distance runner, who paid a visit to this country a few years ago with the Salford Harriers team, was beaten recently by F.E. Bacon, a now aspirant for athletic honors in England. It was a four-mile match race. Bacon has been doing some remarkably last work and he was, strange to say, a 5 to 4 favorite before the race began.
The Board of Trade and Transportation went on record on the immigration question yesterday by adopting the resolutions submitted by a special committee:

There can be no doubt that the French Ministry has been strengthened by the resignation of M. ROUVIER, the Minister of Finance. M. ROUVIER is a specimen of a type of which we, in this country, have had many examples -- the type of a man who, having long held public offices at moderate salaries, has accumulated a handsome fortune.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The principal witnesses exAmined by the Panama Canal Committee to-day were M. Rouvier, who yesterday resigned the Finance Portfolio; M. Constana. a former Minister of the Interior, and M. Georges Clemenceau, the well-known Radical Deputy.

Howard E. Raymond, the Chairman of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board, who was sent to England as a delegate to the International Conference from his organization, returned home on the City of Paris yesterday. A party of Mr. Raymond's friends, members of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club, met the steamer at Quarantine and took the newly-elected President of the International Cyclists' Union off the steamer.

President William Steinway of the Rapid Transit commission said last evening that he could not agree with John R. Dos Passos concerning the "utter impracticability" of the rapid-transit scheme. "I haven't the slightest doubt," Mr. Steinway said, "that capitalists would have eagerly sought the opportunity now presented to them for investment in the rapid-transit scheme for New-York had it not been for the unfortunate failure of the Baring Brothers of London.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 14 -- District Master Workmen Dempsey of the Knights of Labor was seen to-day in regard to the confession of Patrick Gallagher, the cook, at Homestead, in which it was alleged that Dompsey furnished the drug to poison the non-union workmen. Mr. Dempsey was indignant.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 -- Gov. McKinney or Virginia, in an interview regarding Virginia's chances for representation in Mr. Cleveland's Cabinet, says:

A.B. George, one of the fastest middle-distance runners who has raced in this country, and a prominent athlete of the Manhattan Athletic Club and Seventh Regiment, sailed for England on the Majestic yesterday. He returns to England to enter into partnership with his brother, W.G. George, the proprietor of the Coach and Horses Hotel in Birmingham.

Both Mgr. Deane or Newark, N.J., and the Rev. Dr. Alexander F. McSweeney yesterday formally signified their willingness to act as referees to decide whether Vicar General John J. O'Connor is biased, and therefore incompetent to act as judge in Father Corrigan's trial on Bishop Wigger's charges.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 14 -- A pretty home wedding occurred at 6 o'clock this evening at the country home here of Mr. and Mrs. Gilford Mayer, 201 Park Avenue, when their daughter, Miss Addie Longworthy Mayer, was married to Thomas Sherman Wheeler of New-York. Mr. Wheeler is the son of Theodore Wheeler and a nephew of Oved Wheeler and of W.B. Wheeler of 64 Broadway, New-York.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The eighteenth annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Horticultural Society was begun in the State House to-day. There were about seventy-five horticulturists from all parts of the State.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 14 -- Two meetings held in this city within a few days and attended by clergymen and lay delegates gave some evidence of a tendency toward liberalism on the part of the younger members of the Congregational Church and the doing away with the manner in which the Church has been governed since the days of the Puritans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- James G. Blaine, it is believed, is now on his death bed. The exhausting malady from which he has suffered for so long a time has assumed a form which warns his family and friends of a speedy fatal termination. The disease attached his lungs a short time ago, and its course has baffled the skill of his physicians.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 14 -- The pretty Church of the Holy Name of Mary Our Lady of the Isle never looted more gay than it did at noon to-day when Miss Helen Louise Gammell was married, there to Arthur Herbert of London. Immense palm trees were massed on either side of the chancel, and towering high above all else were two specimen tree ferns which gave a decided tropical effect to the decorations.

Mrs. Ann Day, an Irishwoman about eighty years old, who for several years had lived alone in a small room in the tenement house 417 East Twenty-fifth Street, was found sick in her room on the 8th inst., and was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where she died two days after. Daring her stay in the East Twenty-fifth Street house the woman gained the reputation of being a miser owing to her penurious habits.

Some of the Tammany braves of the First Assembly District are up in arms against the plan of the Tammany Committee of Thirty to make ex-Senator Michael C. Murphy the Tammany leader of the First Assembly District, to succeed Frank T. Fitzgerald.

The members of the Union League Club of Brooklyn threw open their clubhouse last evening to ladies. It was the second annual reception to ladies since the clubhouse was erected, and no means were spared to make the occasion a success. There was dancing from 9 to 3 o'clock.

In addition to its ordinary work, which is carried on without intermission the year round, the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor is in the habit of relieving, both at Thanksgiving and Christmas, when funds are provided for the purpose, a number of poor families in their own homes who are well known to the society by thorough, investigation and found to be worthy of such consideration.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 14 -- The Populist State Government-elect will indulge in no frivolities during its term of office. This was determined upon to-day at a meeting of the officers-elect and the Citizens' Committee, at which the nature of the ceremonies inaugurating the new Government were discussed.

The reckless expenditure or money by the Brooklyn authorities at the recent Columbian celebration was taken up by the Grand Jury yesterday, and a rumor spread that several indictments had been found. This was not true, but it may have been only premature.

County Clerk McLaughlin of Hudson County, N.J., yesterday sent formal notice to Gov. Abbett of the death of Sheriff McPhillips, and it is thought that within the next few days the Governor will name his ad interim successor. Ex-Sheriff Ferdinand Heintze, Mayor Stanton of Hoboken, Frank Kimmerly, and City Collector Patrick H. O'Neill are among those talked of.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 -- The publishing house of John Murphy Co. to-day issued for private circulation among the Bishops of the Catholic Church in the United States an authentic "Abstract of the Minutes of the Third Annual Conference of the Most Reverend Archbishops of the United States." This authorized abstract is signed " P.L. Chapelle, Secretary," and is accompanied by the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The President's statements concerning the diversion to the Canadian Pacific Railway of business that should be secured by American lines is attracting the attention and criticism of those who are interested in international traffic, and who have found that part of the message peculiarly important to them.

The fact that the San Antonio and Aransas Pass Railroad, in Texas, is likely to pass into the control of C.P. Hnntington was made apparent yesterday when the Reorganization Committee submitted a plan for the issue of new securities to be guaranteed, principal and interest, by the Southern Pacific Railroad. The members of the committee are: Frederic P. Olcott, Joseph Wharton, Henry Budge, Frederic Cromwell, J. Kennedy Tod, Alfred S. Heidelbach, and Eric P. Swenson.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 -- There is much bad feeling over the invitations sent out for the banquet to be given Governor-elect William J. Stone at the Mercantile Club on Thursday night. Many active Democrats who worked indefatigably in the Stone campaign have been ignored, while others who took no part in the campaign will be prominent guests.

SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 14 -- A dispatch from Carrizo, Texas, says that the two companies of cavalrymen from Fort Macintosh have arrived at that place under command of Lieut. J.A. Hettington in search of the Mexican bandits who made the attack upon the Mexican troops at San Ygnace last Saturday. There is also a large force of United States Deputy Marshals in the field scouting for the marauders.

The Hon. "Paddy" Gleason was, metaphorically, thrown out of the General Term Court in Brooklyn yesterday when he tried to have Judges Barnard, Pratt. and Dykman listen to his appeal from Judge Bartlett's mandamus directing City Clerk Burke to send back all the election returns to the canvassers for correction of the spelling of Candidate Sanford's name.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The Regents of the University held a public meeting in memory of the late Chancellor, George William Curtis, and of Kegent Francis Kernan in the Senate Chamber at the Capitol to-night. A distinguished audience filled the room. So many Regents of the University never attended a meeting before.

-- Nicholas Latrobe Roosevelt, who died at his home, 36 West Twelfth Street, of pneumonia, yesterday afternoon, was a son of the late Samuel Roosevelt, a nephew of James A. and Robert B. Roosevelt, and a cousin of Theodore, Elliott, and J.R. Roosevelt, who married Miss Astor. Mr. Roosevelt married Miss Eleanor Dean of Morristown, N.J., where he had a country seat.

The trial of Morris Spiegel in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Russell, on the charge of having presented false certificates of loss to insurance companies, developed somewhat sensational features yesterday. Spiegel did business as a wine merchant at 101 and 103 Broad Street. There was a fire at his place Dec. 16, 1891.

The joint committee from the Senate and Assembly, appointed to investigate the subject of taxation, began its work at the Hotel Metropole yesterday afternoon. Tax Commissioner Thomas L. Foitner was on the stand for two hours, talking, for the most part, of taxation of personal property. He recommended a general change in the system of levying taxes.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 14 -- The Soldiers' Home bill is dead for this session at least. It can possibly be revived at the next session of the General Assembly, but so far as the present is concerned Hector was not deader than it is. The Senate killed it, and this is the way it happened:

Yachtsmen in this city were more than pleased yesterday to know that a challenge to race for the America's Cup had been accepted by the New-York Yacht Club. Throughout the whole five years of dead-lock over the "new deed of gift" the real sportsmen among yachtsmen have cried, "Never mind the deed! Burn it up and give us a race!" At the New-York Yacht Club meeting Tuesday night this sentiment prevailed.
John Emile Lemoinne, Senator, member of the Academic Francaise, editor of the Journal des Debats, died in Paris yesterday.

Lieut G.N. Whistler, United States Army, in his report on the first firing of the Brown segmental tube wire five-inch gun at Birdsborough, Penn., on Saturday, the 30 inst., states that the firing was made with the tube only rough bored, the object being chiefly to test the working of the breech mechanism rather than to experiment with high pressure in the gun.

"Dick" Burge, the English champion light-weight, who has come over to thin country for the purpose of meeting "Jack" McAuliffo, the American champion, arrived here yesterday on the City of Paris. He was accompanied by "Jack" Haggerty and George Macdonald. Haggerty is a fast swimmer. Macdonald is a trainer, and he handled Sullivan while he was preparing for his encounter with Charley Mitchell in Chantilly, in France, a few years ago.

Every now and then the Stock Exchange authorities take a "shy" at the rival establishment on the other side of New Street known as the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange. For years a policy of non-intercourse between the two Exchanges has been insisted upon by the officers of the older one, and various rules, with appalling penalties for violations thereof, have been promulgated by the Governing Committee.

When the hearing on the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge scheme was finished before Controller Myers and Chamberlain Crain, sitting in the Controller's office us a committee of the Sinking Fund Commissioners, yesterday, the following dispatch was sent to Senators Hiscock and Hill:

BERLIN, Dec. 14.--The debate on the first reading of the Army bill was continued in the Reichstag to-day. Freiherr von Manteuffel, a prominent leader of the Conservative Party, made a speech on the measure, in the course of which he resented the aspersions cast upon the Conservative Party by Chancellor von Caprivi, who a few days ago declared in the Reichstag that the Conservatives were supporters of Rector Ahlwardt.

What the outcome of the postponed election of the stockholders in the Berkeley Athletic Association, which is to be held at 23 West Forty-fourth Street at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, will be is uncertain. The loaders of both the White and anti-White parties protest that there is no doubt about the result, but many of the followers on either side do not seem so sure of this.

The correspondence between Commander Erben of the Brooklyn Navy Yard and Superintendent Byrnes relating to the alleged payment of the New-York police for their services at the funeral of Commander Rosweil D. Hitchcock of the United States Navy, mention of which was made in yesterday's TIMES, was given out yesterday by Mr. Byrnes.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The body of Patrick McDrury of Brooklyn, N.Y., was found to-day in the hold of the Anchor Line steamship Bolivia, at Glasgow from New-York, imbedded in the grain.

A lot of goods seized by customs officers were sold yesterday morning by J. Thomas Stearns Co., 268 West Street. Some paintings were catalogued as part of the lot seized from Mrs. Campbell-Caoacil, but they were withdrawn.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The attempt of the Conservatives to have D. Naoroji, Liberal member of Parliament for Central Finsbury, unseated was defeated to-day and the petition of the contestants denied. Mr. Kaoroji is known as "Lord Salisbury's black man," the ex-Premier having alluded to Naoroji in one of his speeches as "a black man."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Representatives of all the big shipbuilding concerns of the country are in the city to-night.They are interested directly or indirectly in the opening of bids at the Navy Department to-morrow for two of the biggest ships that have been planned for the navy. The money available for construction on these two ships amounts to $7,500,000.

Several bills have already been introduced in the House and Senate at Washington to repeal so much of the Sherman act of 1890 as requires the purchase of 54,000,000 ounces of silver bullion per year. Two of these have been presented by Mr. ANDREW of Massachusetts. One of them relates to the Sherman act alone, and was sent to the Committee on Coinage, of which Mr. BLAND of Missouri is Chairman.

The thoroughness with which Prof. Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary, whose trial for heresy has been going on for more than two weeks past in the old Scotch Presbyterian Church, Fourteenth. Street, near Sixth Avenue, is handling his own case is a cause of wonder even to those who have the greatest faith in the man's profound learning and sense of learning.

The Sheriff's officers had a lively time yesterday searching for property of Lipman Co., the failed importers of burlaps and jute at 83 Leonard Street and of Dundee, Scotland, under the attachments. Many oases of goods were found on various docks, where they were being unloaded from European steamers.

The contract between the Brooklyn City Railroad Company and its employes expires with the present year, and the men yesterday appointed a committee to visit President Lewis and ascertain if it was to be renewed. The adoption of the trolley system will soon result in the dismissal of all the stablemen and towboys and of many drivers who are not regarded as competent to handle an eleotrro motor.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- A general effort throughout the State is being made to secure the pardon of ex-State Treasurer Stevenson Archer, who is now in the penitentiary. He has served nearly two years of his term and has been a model prisoner. The sympathy for him and his family is great and there is no difficulty in getting signatures to the petitions, the first one of which reached the Governor this week.

Some of those who had called on Mr. Cleveland within the last two days said yesterday that Mr. Cleveland had left the impression in their minds that he did not favor an extra session of Congress, but rather the appointment of a special committee from the members of the present House of Representatives who are members-elect of the next Congress, to consider the tariff during the Summer and report when Congress meets.

When the Gas Commission met in the Mayor's office yesterday to award contracts for gas and electric lights tor the streets, some of the electric light bids were rejected because the commission believed that the electric companies had entered into a combine to keep up the prices.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The attention of the District Attorney of New-York City will probably soon be called to a serious breach of the law in regard to keeping murderers in the Tombs after they have been sentenced to death, and on appeal filed which acts as a stay. At present there are at least two criminalin the Tombs that should be in Sing Sing, Carlyle W. Harris and Thomas Pallister.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Mr. J.S. Piza of the firm of Piza Nephews Co. of New-York gave an illustration to-day of the objections felt by Americans as a class to getting left. Mr. Piza intended to take the mall train from Dublin and then to catch the White Star Line steamer Teutonic at Queenstown. He missed the train and was for the moment nonplused as to how he would get to Queenstown.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 -- The committee appointed by the International Monetary Conference to consider the various projects submitted to the conference has adopted a report, in which it states that in considering the various proposals submitted to it it confined itself to the study of general principles and did not discuss the details necessary to give the several proposals effect.

The arrest of William Dubey, alias William Franklin, a private in the First United States Artillery on Staten Island, yesterday, on a charge of criminal libel, brought out a remarkable story of marital complications.

The 23,000 shares of stock in the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad held by Anthony Barrett as trustee for somebody, end in reference to which a vain effort was made to gain information a year ago, are again the subject of judicial inquiry.
Immigration may have been somewhat checked by the recent restrictions which have been placed upon it, but steerage passengers still continue to pour into the country.

The first performance of the so-called Theatrs of Arts and Letters was given last night at Proctor's Theatre. This scheme was born in the brain of a hitherto unknown young man named Henry Burden McDowell, whose sagacity has been already amply proved. What he may do in time for art no one can tell, but art is not the main object of his newly-incorporated institution, which ought properly to be called the Theatre of Sociabillty.

The story of Hampton Institute and its progress during the last year or more was told last evening in the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church by the Rev. Herbert B. Turner, an officer of the school under Gen. Armstrong.
Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, has written a letter to the Board of Trade and Transportation about the preposition to use prison labor on the roads. In this letter he says:

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--At the closing session of the New-England Christian Association to-day the Rev. J.M. Foster of Boston, the newly-elected President, upon assuming the chair made a stirring address against secret societies, particularly assailing Jesuitism and Masonry.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 15 -- The question of abolishing the time-honored custom of compulsory attendance upon morning prayers and chapel service on Sunday at Yale is being vigorously agitated. The magazines of the university are strenuously advocating the repeal of the practice, which from time immemorial has been in vogue, and the Evening Leader of this city has extended the crusade by publishing a series of interviews with prominent professors of the university on the snbject.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Mrs. Annie B. Cox, whose suit to procure a divorce from her husband, a well-known Philadelphia lawyer, has engaged the attention of Vice Chancellor Green for the last day or two, was a witness sworn in her husband's suit to-day. Her husband has filed a cross bill against her, naming Robert B. McCarthy, a Now-York lawyer, as co-respondent.

The fifth season of the Church Choral Society began auspiciously last night at the Church of Zion and St. Timothy, in Fifty-seventh Street, near Eighth Avenue. The service revealed the fact that Mr. Richard Henry Warren, the conductor of the organization, does not weary of welldoing, but preserves all the ardor which has enabled him to lead the chorus to its present noteworthy excellence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Speaking of the Grand Trunk Railway's new arrangement for steamship service from Portland, Me., a man who stands high in financial circles said to-day: "This is only in accordance with the Grand Trunk's past record of bringing its best endeavors to protect the interest of the American lines and consequently the American shippers.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Ex-Assemblyman Frank M. McDermitt created a sensation in Judge Kirkpatrick's court to-day. During the course of the ante-convention canvass for the Gubernatorial nomination, McDermitt, favoring one candidate, became embroiled with James Smith, Jr., who favored another candidate. He emphasized his opposition to the big boss by standing himself as a candidate for Assembly against a man whom Mr. Smith supported.

Linus E. Post, the Tecoma (Washington) business man who mysteriously disappeared the middle of last months probably in Europe. Mr. Post's family and friends in Tacoma feared that he had become dospondent and had killed himself either in this city or Chicago. Mr. Post had no weighty reason for disappearing except that his business methods had been rather loose and he was liable to censure.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 15 -- Rohert J. Beatty, who is alleged to be implicated in the Homestead poisoning conspiracy, reached Pittsburg from Louisville this morning in charge of Deputy Sheriff Farrell. He was taken to Alderman McMaster's office, where an additional information of felonious assault was lodged against him.

A service was held yesterday in the beautiful St. Michael's Church at Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street to celebrate the completion of fifty years of service as layman, deacon, and priest in that parish of the Rev. Dr. Thomas McClure Peters, the oldest rector, in point of continuous inoumbency, in the City and Diocese of New-York.

RUSSELL -- BROWN. The wedding took place last evening at the home of Mrs. M.A. Bliss, 207 Washington Park, Brooklyn, of Miss Lena Duryea Brown, daughter of Mrs. Lena M. Brown and granddaughter of Mrs. Bliss, and Samuel Russell, Jr.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The annual banquet of the Boston Merchants' Association was held at the Hotel Vendome this evening. For ten years these banquets have been the most brilliant gatherings of the kind in the city. The subject of the discussion to-night wan: "The Consular Service of the United States."

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- At the annual meeting of the Yonkers Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children Treasurer Lyman Cobb, Jr., reported that there bad been received from all sources $436.13 and expended $593,76.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- A case of great interest to workmen on railroads came up in the Court of Appeals to-day. The appeal was in the case of the People versus James B. Phyfe, on a demurrer to an indictment found by the Grand Jury in Westchester County, charging Phyfe with a violation of Chapter 711, Laws of 1892, which provides for limit of the hours of service on railroads.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Cramps of Philadelphia will secure the contract for building the battle ship Iowa and the armored cruiser Minneapolis, for which bids were opened in Secretary Tracy's office at noon to-day in the presence of the leading shipbuilders of the country.

The First Battery had its twenty-seventh annual reception, ball, and review last night at its armory in West Forty-fourth Street. All the military guests appeared in uniform, and the result was a brilliant picture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- There is decided objection on the part of the Republican Senators to the expression "steering committee." They are willing enough to take any steps that might keep the Democrats out of the control of Senate, but they wish to adopt high-sounding methods in order to fool the people.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- The Merchants and Manufacturers' Association in its annual report makes extended reference to the fact that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is granting to Philadelphia privileges which it is not giving to Baltimore. As this city gave the road the benefit of its credit in the critical periods of its history, there is considerable feeling over the matter, and there is talk of a boycott; but this the association condemns.

The Barefoot Mission, an organization with the laudable purpose of supplying poor children with shoes and stockings, will have a Christmas tree at 151 Sixth Avenue on the evening of Monday, Dee. 26, when these very necessary articles of apparel will be distributed among the deserving holding tickets. Tello J. d'Apery, who has made a life work of this special form of charity, will have charge of the tree.

A feast was spread in the large dining hall of Delmonico's establishment last evening for the second panel of the Sheriff's jury and its guests. This banquet is an annual affair, which affords the members of the second panel, who, through the year preceding, have met only as jurors in such cases as have come under the Sheriff's jurisdiction, the opportunity to meet socially.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 15 -- The Fayette County proceedings in mandamus, by which it is sought to compel the Board of Deputy Election Supervisors to sign and return to the Secretary of State Abstract No. 3, containing the vote for Circuit Judge, was up for final hearing in the Supreme Court to-day, the Democratic defendants having filed voluminous depositions and a supplementary answer since the preliminary hearing.
Edison has won again. His legal contest with the Westinghouse people has ended with a decision in his favor.

Interested spectators, some of them women, occupied all of the seats in the courtroom of the Superior Court, Part I., when Mrs. Amelia Sire was called to the witness stand yesterday to testify in the Jacobs-Sire breach of promise trial. Officers were stationed at the doors to keep back large crowd of people who desired admission.

In that long statement about the AntiTrust law which the Chicago Inter Ocean procured three or four weeks ago from exSenator EDMUNDS of Vermont, who was Chairman of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary when the bill was reported to the Senate, the following questions and answers may he found:

The annual election of officers of the New-York Catholic Protectory held yesterday afternoon at 415 Broome Street resulted in the choice of the following: President -- Bryan Lawrence, (to succeed Richard H. Clarke, resigned;) First Vice President -- James E. Floyd; Second Vice President -- M.P. Breslin; Treasurer -- Eugene Kelly; Secretary -- William J. Fanning.

Replies to the circular of the Board or Trade And Transportation asking for opinions on the subject of a national quarantine continue to be received. Among the letters arriving yesterday was one from James E. Boyd, Governor of Nebraska, who wrote:

It was plainly indicated at last night's meeting of the Republican County Committee in Grand Opera House Hall that there is some fun ahead for the machine, and that, when the County Committee for 1893 organizes, a strong effort will be made to retire Jacob M. Patterion as Chairman of the Executive Committee of the County Committee.

Some twelve or fourteen years ago a little book entitled "The Commonwealth Reconstructed" appeared and excited very great interest among all serious students of our politics to whose notice it was brought. The author of the book was Dr. C.C.P. CLARK, a practicing physician of Oswego, N.Y., who had also been a politician to the extent of holding important offices, and who therefore had knowledge of the practical operation of our politics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 15 -- Up to the present year Californians have contented themselves with breeding race horses for the rest of the world to buy. The race meetings that have been hold here have been nothing in the way of a credit to the State, but have been quite the contrary as a rule, with all sorts of rascality rampant. But all this has changed this year.

At the end of the session two documents relating to the former "serious trouble" between Father Corriean and the Bishop were put in evidence and embodied in the record. The first is a warning to Father Corrigan, and commands him to recall certain pamphlets published by film without episcopal permission. The pamphlets created a great sensation at the time of their publication, and pained widespread fame for their author.
The Aldermen met yesterday to pass a lot of general orders, but there were not enough members present to enable the board to do any work in that direction.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 15 -- The Democratic State Central Committee has been in session all the afternoon, called together for the purpose of harmonizing the party in the Senatorial matter as well as in the division of offices. Nothing was accomplished, owing to the peculiar condition found to exist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A committee, composed of Walter Gresham of Texas, Charles M. Shelly of Alabama, Mr. Maybury of Michigan, Edward F. Cragin of Illinois, F.J. Odendahl of Louisiana, and Richard L. Edwards of New-York, made its appearance in the city this morning to promote the Nicaragua Canal project in Congress.

Charles Balmer, head of the well-known music house of Balmer Weber, at St. Louis, died yesterday, aged seventy-five years. He was the most prolific as well as one of the greatest of American composers and writers. He arranged during his lifetime fully 6,000 pieces. For thirty-nine years he was organist of Christ Church Cathedral and the President of the Philharmonie Society.

The Huguenot Society of America held its first regular meeting of the Winter season last evening at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Lawton of 37 Fifth Avenue. The meeting was to have taken the form of a reception to the venerable John Jay, who is President of the society, but Mr. Jay, owing to ill health, was unable to be present.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Leopold Morse, one of Boston's oldest and most respected business men, died from a stroke of paralysis at 8:30 o'clock to-night. The circumstances of his death were dramatic and painful. At the Hotel Vendome to-night the Merchants' Club were to hold their annual banquet, which is one of the events of the year in business circles.

Full preparations have been made by the officers of the First Battalion Naval Reserves of New-York for the inspection of that battalion to-morrow night at the Twelfth Regiment Armory. The inspection will be made by the Inspector General of the New-York National Guard, Brig. Gen. Thomas J. McGrath. This inspection will be in accordance with the State regulations governing such events.

The alumni of Williams College who live in or near Naw-York dined at the Hotel Brunswick, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, last night, and there they held one of the most successful reunions in the history of their organization. About 100 of the graduates were present. John C. Goodridge, the executive officer of the association, presided.

PANAMA, Dec. 15 -- The report of an attempt to assassinate President Hippolyte of Haiti is confirmed by reliable advices that have reached here, notwithstanding a severe censorship of the mails as well as of the Haitian press. It is claimed by Hippolyte's enemies that all letters suspected of containing matter hostile to the Government are opened, and their contents, if the suspicion is justified, seized and taken to President Hippolyte for personal perusal.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Gwyneth Maude, the young girl who yesterday in the Old Bailey pleaded guilty to the charge of swindling Messrs. Spink Son, silversmiths, was brought up for sentence to-day. The courtroom was crowded with persons who desired to see the prisoner, whose romantic family history has already been told at length in these dispatches.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 15 -- Tom Kelly, a bright, good-natured boy of thirteen years, who was taken away by the detectives from a gang of crooks, liea in the City Hospital. A few weeks ago a gang of professional thieves from Chicago began to work the city systematically. They took lodgings at several cheap boarding houses in the city, never staying any length of time at one place.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- At a Cabinet meeting held at the Elysee to-day, M. Bourgeois, Minister of Justice, announced that he would oppose in the Chamber of Deputies the proposal of M. Pourquery de Boisserin to invest the Panama Investigation Commission with judicial powers.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 15 -- P.M. The bears had everything their own way today. They succeeded in forcing out considerable long stock and in reaching stock orders on the decline, so that at one time there seemed to be no bottom to prices. Each succeeding quotation was lower than its predecessor. The short interest was largely increased.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Provisions developed a good deal of strength and attracted much attention daring the morning. The receipts of hogs were under the estimates, and buying by influential traders like Cudahy started the ball. Then the shorts came in freely and pork went to $16.40 in a hurry. The receipts of product wore larger, with moderate shipments.

-- George J. McGourkey died Wednesday at his residence, 6 East Sixty-ninth Street. He was fifty-nine years old and was a native of Albany. His father, also a native of Albany, was for thirty years Deputy Auditor in the Canal Department. Mr. McGourkey's boyhood was passed in Albany. When he was eighteen he came to New-York and entered a Wall Street broker's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- All the worry that has been felt over and over again at different times during the last two or three years about the health of Mr. Blaine was renewed this morning by the publication in THE TIMES of the dispatch reporting his illness to nave taken a serious turn and suggesting the probability that he would not recover from this last severe attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- An unusual incident has occurred in the navy. Ensign Walter S. Burke has changed places with Assistant Engineer Victor Blue. The transfer is made on the mutual request of the officers concerned.

Company F. Twenty-second Regiment, had its second annual dinner at the Belvedere House last night. Preparations were made in a liberal way characteristic of Company F. Guests were present both from within and without the regiment. The menu, an excellent one, was printed on a handsome card, the front page of which was emblazoned with flags and eagles, and the motto of the regiment, "Defendam."
TRENTON, N.J., Dec, 15 -- The New-Jersey State Horticultural Society concluded its annual session this afternoon in the State House, and elected the following new set of officers:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15 -- Joseph Mendel, dealer in diamonds at 151 West Main Street, was robbed of $1,500 worth of diamonds by a thief this afternoon. Mendel does a pawn business in diamonds and is about eighty years old. He has one of the biggest stocks in the city in his line, and was sitting by a stove in the rear of his store, when a stranger entered.

At the annual meeting of the New-England Society at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Broadway and Twenty-third Street, last night, the following officers wore elected: President -- Daniel G. Rollins; First Vice President -- Elihu Root; Second Vice President -- Charles C. Beaman; Treasurer -- William Dowd; Secretary -- Luther Prescott Hubbard; Directors -- John L. Dudley, Edward Holbrook, Seth M. Milliken, and Myrick Plummer.

-- The pool which has been booming the prices of the various industrial stocks the first few flays of the week yesterday began to take in some of their profits that had accumulated in the advances they had engineered. The result was a heavy break in prices that spread throughout the whole list. The industrials of course suffered the heaviest declines.

Argument was heard by Judge Bischoff in the Court of Common Pieas, yesterday, on the application of Daniel Kilmartin for an injunction to restrain the erection of a new building by the New-York Post-Graduate Medical College and Hospital at the northeast corner of Twentieth Street and Second Avenue. Mr. Kilmartin lives at 305 East Twentieth Street.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 -- Governor-elect W.J. Stone was tendered a banquet to-night at the Mercantile Club. It was an important and significant event, for the reason that the entertainment was gotten up by the wing of the party that professes superior respectability and is not prejudiced against soap and water. Mayor Noonan was not invited, although great pressure was brought to bear to get his name on the list.

United States Senator Randall Lee Gibson died at Hot Springs, Ark., yesterday afternoon. At the time of his death he was surrounded by the members of his family and several close friends. Senator Gibson passed away as though he had merely gone to sleep. There was no struggle, no suffering. He had been confined to his bed since the 12th of November, since which time his death had been expected daily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The House committee appointed to investigate the Reading Railroad anthracite coal combination resumed this morning, in the Commerce Committee room, the inquiry it conducted into this subject during the recess in New-York, Philadelphia, and elsewhere.

Notwithstanding the pretense of prominent Republicans that they were willing to give the Democrats "full swing" after the 4th of March by conceding to them the control of the Senate, the present majority in that body is evidently intent upon retaining control if the thing can be compassed by stealing the Legislatures of certain close States beyond the Mississippi River.
NEW-YORK. -- Frederick Narr of Philadelphia was reinstated as a member of the Stock Exchange yesterday.

LAREDO, Texas, Dec. 15 -- No reports of additional trouble in the lower country have been received since Monday, but couriers are hourly expected with news of probably a sensational character. The man who stepped into Garza's shoes is now known, and his name is Francisco Benavides, nicknamed "El Turto," which means one-eyed.

The new building, intended to be fourteen stories high, which the Home Life Insurance Company is putting up on the northwest corner of Warren Street and Broadway, is hardly a blessing to its next-door neighbor, the Merchants' Exchange National Bank, at 257 Broadway, which, owing to the enlargement of its foundations necessitated by the building growing up beside it, has sunk several inches on its southern side, giving it an ugly list.

NEW-YORK. -- Officers of the army, navy, and National Guard are to be given a lecture this evening at the rooms of the United Service Club on the subject of smokeless powders. The lecturer, Mr. L. Duff Grant, is one of the best-known nitrate men in his line in British military circles.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Just at present the Corporation Clerk's Department of the Secretary of State's office is a busy place. During the past month the documents sent in for filling have more than trebled. This is by reason of the requiremonts under Sections 15 and 16 of the general corporation law, (Chapter 687, Laws of 1892,) which require foreign stock corporations other than moneyed corporations to secure authority to do business in this State.

When the Board of Aldermen recalled from the hands of the Mayor the resolution granting the New-York Power Company permission to tear up the streets indiscriminately, it was sent back to the Committee on Streets, with directions to hold a public hearing upon it. This hearing was scheduled for 1 o'clock yesterday in the Common Council Chamber, but the only member of the committee present was Alderman Flynn.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 16 -- A fine of $100, the extreme penalty of the law, was imposed by Judge Rufus S. Pickett this noon upon Jamea A. McCrea of Pittsburg, Penn., and F.M. Wyrehause of St. Paul, Minn., the Yale students who were charged with breach of the peace on Dec. 3 during a celebration of the football successes by the freshman class.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 16 -- When asked by a reporter to-day as to the mission of Mgr. Satolli, and the extent of his powers. Archbishop Ireland replied that in view of the contradictory reports put into circulation regarding Mgr. Satolli, and of the uncertainty into which, in consequence, the public mind had been thrown, he was not now unwilling to speak, however persistent was heretofore his resolve to be silent.

The work of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association in this city has been so successful and the results so beneficial that steps have recently been taken to form at an early day a National Hospital Association, which will work along the lines of the association in this city.

It has become very clear within the last twenty-four hours that the Court of Arbitration, which failed to agree on the question of Father O'Connor's fitness to act as Judge in the trial of Father Corrigan on Bishop Wigger's charges, will also fail finally to arbitrate the matter. At its meeting to-day its members, Mgr. Doane and Father McSweeney, will probably agree to select a third man, who may or may not serve.

The City Club of New-York held a sort of house warming last night at its home, 677 Fifth Avenue. It has been in official existence since April 4, but last night, for the first time in permanent quarters, it welcomed its friends in a social reception. Before the reception there was a business meeting of the club of more than usual interest.

Cornelius Vanderbilt yesterday sent his check for $5,000 to President Martin of the Board of Polios Commissioners. Accompanying the check was a letter saying that the money was to be added to the Police Pension Fund. Chauncey M. Depew delivered the letter to President Martin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- Judge Finn rendered a decision to-day in the case of John Chetwood, Jr., vs. the California National Bank, which suspended Dec. 15, 1888. Action is brought by the plaintiff, as stockholder, against the Executive Committee of the bank. The charge is that they were negligent in the discharge of their duties.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 16 -- A case of cannibalism, committed in Colorado in 1873, was called to mind to-day by the hearing of an argument of habeas corpus proceedings, brought by the attorney of Alfred Packer, who is at present serving time in the Canon City Penitentiary, charged with having killed and partially eaten five of his companions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- There was an interesting discussion of the immigration question to-day before the joint Immigration Committees of the Senate and House at the Capitol. The representatives of the various transatlantic steamship lines had been invited to appear before the committees and be heard concerning the Chandler bill, which seeks to prohibit immigration for one year.

We are glad to see that our neighbor, the World, acknowledges the merit of the proposition made by THE TIMES two or three weeks ago that the Fifty-third Congress should be called in extra session in September or October next, and not in March. For almost a month our neighbor has been urging that there should be an extra session beginning in March, immediately after the inauguration of Mr. CLEVELAND.

A rumor was printed yesterday that a movement was on foot to patch up the split in Presbyterian ranks growing out of the Briggsheresy trial. The story was that a number of the friends of Dr. Briggs -- the chief movers in this attempt at reconciliation -- met at dinner Tuesday night at the residence of the Rev. Dr. Van Dyke, 10 West Thirty-ninth Street, where the details of the proposed peace were discussed.

Two peculiarities of ocean-going craft are a regrettable tendency to sink when they should not, and to keep afloat when there is no further reason why they should remain above the surface. The latter peculiarity has been that of the derelict schooner Wyer G. Sargent, whose wanderings about the North Atlantic for nearly two years have attracted much attention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- The electric-light station on Court Street of the General Electric Company in tills city was gutted by fire this morning and most of the valuable machinery was ruinad. The fire was caused by electricity. It broke out at the switchboard, near the rear of the building. The night men were at work in the building and an alarm was quickly turned in.

It cannot be denied that the disclosures in the Panama scandal have brought about something much more serious than a parliamentary crisis. Thus far the political result has been the resignation of one Ministry and the appointment of another containing very nearly the same names, with some rearrangement of functions.

In Wall Street yesterday the money rate was up to 25 and 30 per cent at one time. That was far above the rate, however, at which most of the loans were made, the bulk of the business being between 10 and 15 per cent. At the close of the day the rate was down to 6 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- M. Charles de Lesseps, M. Marius Etienne Fontaine, and M. San-Leroy have been arrested by direction of the Minister of Justice, M. Bourgeois, for their alleged connection with the Panama Canal frauds. M. Henri Louis Felix Cottu, for whose arrest an order was also issued, has fled to Vienna.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Dec. 16 -- The second game of the chess match was scored by Showalter in fine style. Lasker, somewhat tired after an almost continuous sitting for eleven hours on the day previous, gave Showalter an opening for an attack, of which the latter availed himself with promptitude. The Kentuckian pressed his advantage with the utmost vigor, and by brilliant sacrificing tactics forced a win on the fortieth move, alter tour hours of play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The American Forestry Association will meet at the Department of Agriculture on Dec. 20 at 10 A.M. for the annual election of officers and to discuss means to advance the policy of the association with regard to the public timber lands.

Among the Wall Street men who meet at the Windsor Hotel there was much gossip last night over the fact that Edward P.
