Chamberlain, who had long been one of their number, had not been seen in his accustomed up-town haunts for several weeks. He appeared to have dropped out of sight completely. When the fact of his absence was talked over none of his acqaintances seemed to have any idea of his whereabouts.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 16 -- A Gainaville special to the Times-Union says that the Grand Jury of Alchua County has brought in an indictment for murder against Thornton B. Stringfellow of that city for the killing of Charles H. Pratt, formerly editor of the Gainsville Leader, on the night of Nov. 26. Stringfellow caught Pratt and Mrs. Stringfellow together in the latter's bedroom and shot the editor dead.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- The annual dinner of the New-England Tariff Reform League was held at the American House this evening. President Henry L. Pierce was presiding officer. The speakers were the Hon. Charles S. Fairohild, Secretary of the Treasury under Mr. Cleveland; the Hon. Harvey N. Shepard, Joslah Quincy, and William Brice, late candidate for Councillor in Massachusetts against David Hall Rye.

An order by Judge Truax for the reopening of a foreclosure sale promises to ventilate a subject which has lately bothered the real estate market not a little. The property involved is 352 West Sixteenth Street. It was offered for sale under foreclosure Nov. 15, as 111 Broadway, to satiety a lien of $5,472. Timothy Donovan bought it for $7,175.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 16 -- The Illinois State Grange has adopted the following resolutions:

We have had occasion to describe the devices by which the Republican managers are seeking to retain a majority in the United States Senate. They are not honorable at best, and some of them may fairly be described as base. Were the stake for which this desperate game is being played one of ordinary politics no such means would be resorted to.

The members of the Board of Managers of the House of Refuge on Randall's Island, and the persons at Albany who passed the Freedom-of-Worship act last Winter, seem likely to find themselves very soon in the predicament which THE TIMES has so frequently pointed out. The Catholic Church, having obtained what it asked for, is now complaining that that is not enough, and will very soon be going actively to work to get more.

An opinion of great interest to executors and trustees was handed down yesterday by the General Term of the Supreme Court in regard to the payment of the collateral inheritance tax on the bequests to Grace Church and the Metropolitan Museum of Art made in the will of Catharine Lorillard Wolfe. The opinion was written by Presiding Justice Van Brunt and concurred in by Judges Barrett and O'Brien.

An opinion was handed down yesterday by the General Term of the Supreme Court fixing the compensation to be paid to the Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners at $5,000 each. The opinion was per curiam, and in it the court says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- "Uncle Jerry" Rusk and Mr. Hamilton Disston of Philadelphia, together with Representative Hatch (Dom., Mo.,) and Representatives Harmer and Huff, (Reps., Penn.,) have just returned from Florida, whither they went to loot at some of the lands that Mr. Disston has drained for sugar culture.

"Hospital Sunday" occurs this year on Christmas Day. This concurrence of two so important events in our Church annals is somewhat unfortunate, for the reason that in some churches the Christmas collection has for years had a fixed object, and where this is the case pastors have arranged to take the hospital collection either to-morrow or on a Sunday early in the new year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- At to-day's session of the American Federation of Labor the proposition to hold an international labor congress was defeated, and the federation decided to meet next year at the usual time.

Frank W. Roehl, who has been on trial before Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, for the past five days, upon an indictment charging him with the murder, on Sept. 29, of Frank Fauleen, an aged war veteran, who lived at 139 Hestor Street, was convicted yesterday. He was remanded until next Friday for sentence.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 -- A political sensation is created here by the open quarrel of two prominent Republican State officers. Secretary of State C.L. Poorman submitted his annual report to Gov. McKinley for the time of his occupancy of the office. Col. Poorman was appointed to the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Daniel J. Ryan, who was appointed Ohio Executive Commissioner for the World's Fair.
The North German Lloyd steamship Stuttgart, which arrived from Bremen Thursday with 2,260 steerage passengers on board, was yesterday allowed to go to the company's pier in Hoboken.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 16 -- Probably the greatest railroad deal of recent years, so far as Western Massachusetts is concerned, was checkmated last night and to-day. The New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad on Tuesday last secured from the Directors of the Connecticut River Railroad their consent to lease that road, the idea being eventually to make it a portion of the consolidated system.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- George Bowers was killed by his wife at 1 o'clock this morning at the village of Greenwich, where they were visiting. Bowers was employed as a fireman on the Central Railroad of New-Jersey. He and his wife lived in Bridgeton with their three children, the youngest a baby twelve weeks old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Many messages of sympathy were left at the Blaine mansion to-day. The belief has become general that Mr. Blaine is a very sick man, with slight chances of recovery, and his friends in Washington are hastening to assure the members of his family of their sorrow over his sad condition. Very few of the many callers get beyond the door of the mansion.

Yesterday was the fifth day of the trial of the Esther Jacobs-Henry B. Sire breach of promise case, and, as on previous days, the courtroom of Part I., Superior Court, was not large enough to hold the crowd which sought to gain admission.
GUERRERO, Mexico, Dec. 16 -- Secret agents of the border revolutionists last night circulated several hundred revolutionary proclamations in this city and throughout this entire section.

Cable news was received in this city yesterday from St. Petersburg stating briefly that the new American Harveyized armor plate recently sent to Russia to compete with foreign armor plates has been tested by the Russian Government, and that the American plate has stood a successful test.
Anthony Comstock of the Society for the Suppression of Vice made a most important seizure of green-goods literature yesterday.

MARION, N.C., Dec. 16 -- This little mountain town was the scene of a very romantic marriage on Sunday last. Miss Emma Bradley is the daughter of Miles Bradley, who lives at Old Fort, in this county. Miss Bradley is a pretty blonde, a little above medium height, with a symmetrical form and beautiful features. She has been well educated and is the belle of Old Fort.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 16 -- In the little courtroom here Dr. W.W. Meiners, the Coroner of Queens County, last evening heard a story of personal bravery, deserving not only of the highest praise bat of the attention of the Life-Saving Department of the Government.

A petition was presented to the Board of Excise yesterday morning by the West Side Protective Association asking to have the liquor licenses of four saloon keepers revoked for breaking the law in keeping open on Sunday. The men against whom this move is made are George Walling, 292 Amsterdam Avenue; Thomas Camen, 1,475 Columbus Avenue; John McCormack, 436 Columbus Avenue, and William O'Connell, Boulevard and Seventy-fifth Street.

Dr. Theodore Walser of New-Brighton, S.I., has written a loiter upon the cholera and quarantine questions. The doctor attended the majority of cholera cases which come under the charge of the Commissioners of Emigration from 1852 to 1865 and has made a life study of contagious and infectious diseases.

SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- There will be only one execution at Sing Sing Prison next Monday. There were to have been two -- Frederick McGuire, who murdered Mrs. Amelia Gregory at Middletown, N.Y., and Peter Schultz, a sixteen-year-old boy, who killed a baby on Long Island. The latter has obtained a stay of execution while his case is taken to the Court of Appeals.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The statement by Archbishop Corrigan, published in New-York recently, in regard to a settlement of the differences between the Churoh and the Rev. Father MoGiynn, has received full confirmation at the Vatican.

The initiation of Grover Cleveland as an honorary member of the Sigma Chi fraternity is probably near at hand. The Alumni Chapter of the society in this city, of which the Rev. Dr. Theodore A.K. Gessler is Consul, has sent the following letter to the persons interested in the ceremony:

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- The Commercial Bulletin will to-morrow publish the results of a correspondence with members of the New-England Congressional delegation on the currency and its future. There is substantial unanimity in favor of a substitution of more conservative legislation for the act of 1890. As to the future of the currency, there is great division of opinion.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 16 -- The Hon. George F. Foster, Minister of Finance, recently made a criticism of President Harrison's message to Congress. This evoked a vigorous reply from Mr. John W. Foster, the United States Secretary of State, who criticised many of his namesake's statements of fact.

Dr. S.A. Brown, who mates his home at the United States Hotel, Fulton and Water Streets, was aroused yesterday morning about 3 o'clock by a tremendous pounding on the door of his apartment. He got up, opened the door, and found, standing in the dimly-lighted hall, a man, dressed only in his night shirt, whose hands clutched his throat, whose eyes were as big as saucers, and whose face was purple and greatly puffed up.

As long ago as last May City Works Commissioner Adams of Brooklyn notified the Board of Aldermen that two of the pumping engines at the Ridgewood water station were old and liable to break down, and that an accident would mean that the daily consumption of water would exceed the daily supply.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 16 -- The work of laying the sixteen-inch iron water pipes, which are to carry Perth Amboy's new water supply under the Raritan River, progresses slowly, hindered by unavoidable accidents which attend so difficult a piece of hydraulic engineering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Some of the Democrats here are wondering whether it will be necessary to appoint a sub-committee to the "steering committee" of the Senate to look after the committee. The wonderers are inspired by a feeling of doubt as to whether all of the Democratic Senators are equally anxious to have a Democratic majority in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The ordnance officers in the War Department have been a good deal interested in the strike at the arsenal at West Troy, N.Y. The first-information they had of the trouble was through the Times's dispatches, and it was some time before they learned officially of the circumstances which led to the strike.
Mr. Franklin W. Smith of Boston delivered a lacture last evening at 9 University Place on his design and prospectus for a National Gallery of History and Art at Washington, D.C.
Keeper William J. McNamara of the Tombs, who on Thursday permitted Richard Kyle to escape from him, was yesterday discharged by the Commissioners of Charities and Correction.

Ten books which would have brought $1,000 in any book auction room of this city, in mid-summer and while every book lover was out of town, were sold by the Sheriff at Topping's Auction Rooms yesterday morning for $55. They were superb in condition, in quality, and in style of binding. They were such works as men who are not experts are in greater danger of overvaluing than of undervaluing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Money is to be expended freely for improvements durine the coming year by the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Company. General Manager McDoel has just returned from New-York with full permission from President Samuel Thomas to carry out his own ideas with regard to betterments, new equipment, and everything required for the convenient and expeditions handling of business during the World's Fair year.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- State Controller Campbell will make a recommendation to the next Legislature, which he expects will more than double the amount of money raised annually by the Ives pool tax on racing associations, the proceeds of which are distributed by the State Agricultural Society among the county agricultural societies in the State for their encouragement.

WEST POINT, Ga., Dec. 16 -- Newton Reed, a farmer living ten miles from here, found that his corn crib was on fire last night about 9 o'clock. All left the hones except Mrs. Reed. After lighting the fire for an hour Mr. Reed sent a negro to the house to see if everything was all right. In a few moments the boy came back crying that Mrs. Rood had been killed.

-- Thomas Daly, a teamster, met with a remarkable accident yesterday at Wilkesbarre, Penn. He was loading coal into a wagon from chutes in a coal breaker when a loaded car rushed down the steep incline 1,000 feet; bounded over the wagon and horses, Striking Daly, who was standing at the horses' heads. The man was instantly killed, but the horses were not injured.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16 -- A steel steam lightship carrying a white electric flashlight was anchored off Cornfield Point Shoal yesterday. She is the only vessel of her class in Long Island Sound, and is said to be the finest lightship in the world. She was built in Bay City, Mich., and steamed here, coming through the great lakes and down the coast.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- A verdict for $5,500 damages was to-day awarded to Miss Annette D. Munson in her salt against George W. Little, Jr., and his brother, father, and mother. Miss Munson and George Little, both of whom belong to well-known families, were sweethearts. On the evening of March 7, 1891, George and his brother Albert went to Annette's house.

Judge Newburger, in the City Court, on applications made in behalf of judgment creditors of Charles J. Schmitt, wno does business under the name of C.J. Schmitt Co. in West Washington Market, has granted third-party orders restraining a number of banks from paying out accounts to the credit of various firm names, all alleged to be held by Schmitt.

A fire which, broke out at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the Empire Storage Warehouse at Hudson and West Houston Streets was not subdued until the two upper floors of the building were entirely gutted, the roof burned off, and the lower floors drenched with water.

How completely John. I. Davenport is permitted to run things in the Federal courts in this city regardless of law is strikingly illustrated by the case of James H. Gartlan, who wants to sue Davenport for $25,000 damages for false imprisonment, but is prevented by the fact that the Federal Supervisor of Election is permitted to carry public court records in his pockets.

Bishop Potter, the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, and fifty professional and business men who met last Wednesday evening at the Diocesan House, 29 Lafayette Place, at the invitation of the Bishop, came to the conclusion that the only hope for effective mission work in the lower east side was through the kindergarten.

The taxpayers of Brooklyn did not have to look very tax ahead, or even through a millstone, to see what Senator John McCarty was alter when he induced the last Legislature to pass a bill exempting Kings County from the provisions of the Cantor act. What McCarty and his political allies objected to in the law then existing was that it gave the taxpayers some sort of chance for their money.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- John Stetson's new Globe Theatre company made its first appearance at that house Monday evening, presenting "The Crust ol Society." The play is an adaptation of Dumas's "Le Demi-Monde," the joint work of Miss Louise Imogena Guiney and Mr. William Seymour. The company is beaded by Joseph Haworth and Miss Carrie Turner, and includes also Edgar L. Davenport and Harry St. Maur.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Some of the line officers of the navy are disposed to discover something significant in the remarks on the personnel of the service made by Mr. Tracy in his annual report. Being line officers, they are bound to think this significance is against those who are regarded as antagonists -- the officers of tlie staff.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 17 -- Four beautiful female slaves were recently presented by the Khedive of Egypt to the Sultan of Turkey and placed in the imperial harem. The Sultan was much pleased with them, and when, a few days ago, they were found murdered in their beds, victims to poison, he is said to have been deeply enraged.

To the singularly sensitive nature of Edward Davis the misbehavior of his cousin, "Teddy" Davis, had been a constant irritant, for their names were identical. No one, indeed, would speak of Edward as "Teddy," nor of "Teddy as Edward, but when boyish pranks had been chronicled in print there had been no each discrimination, and to Edward had come the agonies of doubtful explanation.

At noon yesterday Miss Rose Northrup, daughter of the late Warren Northrup of this city, was married to William Harvey Hildreth of Boston. The wedding took place in the Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street, the Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet officiating. Dr. John Woodman was the best man, and James S. McCobb, Louis M. Ogden, J. Clinton Spencer, and Dr. J. Dyson Aspinwall were the ushers.

In the interesting review of our recent naval progress which Secretary TRACY has just made, prominence is naturally given to the work of construction. There have been other gains in the last ten years. The bureau system of administration when Secretary WHITNEY came into office was in need of reform, and he was not long in beginning it.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 17 -- What is expected to be a valuable organization for Yale University is the Graduate Club, organized two years ago, which is now furnishing a very attractive clubhouse on Elm Street. Its object is to establish a union between the graduate students of the university both for social and literary purposes, and also to strengthen the graduate department.

It now appears that the trolley system of ransit in use in the cities of this country in not only a constant menace to life and limb, but that it has the additional unhappy faculty of annoying its neighbors of the electrical kind to a very serious extent.

-- The invitations to the Columbia College Junior Christmas ball, which, were issued last week, are "very proper" in form, being large and square, and printed in bold artistic type. According to the tickets, the ball will be given in aid of the college athletics, under the management of Philip R.M. Hildreth, Joseph Peter Grace, Henry Merwin Shrady, J. Philip Benkard, Campbell Erie Lookie, and Harry Pelham Robbing.

AMESBURY, Mass., Dec. 17 -- For many years Amesbury people have observed the 17th of December as the birthday of their beloved fellow-citizen, John G. Whittier. His home and his grave remind them of their loss. Many people from abroad visited the town to-day to attend the services.

The list for 1892 of the Knickerbocker Club has recently been issued, and it contains some interesting figures. The waiting list of this club has been kept up to the limit, but in the course of the year there have been twelve deaths -- rather a large percentage for a small club -- and ten new members admitted. Among the recent Knickerbockers is Reginald De Koven.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 17 -- Several weeks since the Pittsburg Art Society adopted resolutions recommending the acceptance of Andrew Carnegie's gift of a public library to the City of Pittsburg. In the resolutions the society deplored the stand taken by several labor organizations against accepting Mr. Carnegie's gift to Pittsburg.

In this volume there is much concerning African travel, with its adventures and mishaps. But the parts which are of greatest interest to us are those relating to Mr. Bent's study of the extraordinary ruins at Zimbabwe. Tho deductions which he makes are novel, and the volume opens a new page of archteology.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Indian Bureau has received from Agent Simons, at the Fort Belknap Agency, the following report, giving the particulars of the affray at that agency on the 10th inst.:

Mgr. O'Connell, rector of the American College at Rome, who came over the seas with Ablegate Satolli, sailed for Europe on the Bremen steamer Kaiser Wilhelm II. from Hoboken yesterday. A reporter, who has a personal acquaintance with him, succeeded in having an interesting interview with him before he sailed.

Another destructive warehouse fire, similar to that in Harbeok'e Stores a few weeks ago, visited Brooklyn yesterday morning and wiped out about $350,000 worth of property besides imperiling the lives of eight Bremen.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 17 -- The approach of the holidays was manifest in the House to-day. Few of the very few members in attendance paid any attention to the proceedings. The Committee on Military Affairs succeeded in passing a few bills of little importance.

There was a large crowd at the carnival of sports in aid of the Press Club building fund in Madison Square Garden last night. Every box was taken, all the reserved seats were occupied, and there was large orowd in the galleries. It was estimated that 5,000 persons were present. They witnessed one or the most interesting athletic programmes ever presented to a sport-loving public, and the club will clear about $7,000 on the entertainment.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 17 -- None of the State commissions which Gov. Morris will be called upon to fill in January will create a wider interest in the capital than the Bureau of Labor Statistics and that of Superintendent of Insurance. Both are remunerative offices as public positions go in Connecticut.

Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, had a word to say yesterday about the interference of Justices of the Supreme Court with matters concerning only the administration of justice in this court. The occasion was furnished by an application made by Assistant District Attorney Stapler to have the stay granted by Judge Pratt of Brooklyn in the case of Sylvester F. Wilson set aside.

Nearly all the influential surface railroad men in Brooklyn held a conference in the office of President Lewis of the Brooklyn City Company yesterday in regard to the proposed consolidation of the street railroads under one management. Among those present were Gen. Henry W. Slocum, E.W. Bliss, William Marshall, and Frank A. Barnaby.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Gen. Grubb, late United States Minister to Spain, in an article in the North American Review tells an interesting story of how he accepted the Gubernatorial nomination against Gov. Abbett in 1889, without any idea at being elected, but wholly for the purpose of exposing the Hudson County frauds. This is the way ha tells it:

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The situation in Paris grows more ominous day by day. Cool observers here -- I speak of men high in British politics, who pay special attention to and have intimate knowledge of French affairs -- do not see cause yet to despair of the republic, but they say that the corner must be turned very soon if the whole concern is not to go to smash on the rocks.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 -- This city is first to do away with the mental strain upon pupils in the public schools who have been annually compelled to take examinations for promotion before passing from a lower to a higher grade. Examinations are done away with and the teachers are required to keep a record of proficiency of pupils.

Gen. Horace Porter presided at a meeting held in Chickering Hall last night for the purpose of enlisting public interest in the Grand Army Mission, at 396 and 398 Canal Street. The hall was comfortably filled. On the stage were Mr. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer, President of the mission; Major Gen. O.O. Howard, United States Army; Col. H.H. Hadley, Superintendent; Col. Frank C. Loveland, Pension Agent; W.T. Wardwell, and other well-known friends of Union veterans.

When Mr. Cleveland reached his office in the Mills Building yesterday, at a few minutes after noon, he found a group of editors of Southern newspapers waiting at the elevator landing. They were the party with whom Mr. Cleveland had made an appointment the day before, and they were ready to call on him, as they supposed, until they ascertained that one of their number was missing.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 17 -- The news that his demented wire would be promptly restored to him with recovered reason so overjoyed George Westlake of Long Island City that he died of shook at his home here on Thursday night.

LENOX, Dec. 17 -- A jolly house party will be in Lenox Christmas week at the country plane of Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes. Christmas week in Lenox is always pleasant, and other houses may be open, including those of John D. Parsons, D.W. Bishop, and George H. Morgan.

Some of the politicians and contractors who were mixed up in the frauds by which Brooklyn and Kings County wore swindled oat of thousands of dollars during, the recent Columbian celebration, and whose connection with that affair is being investigated by the Grand Jury, have began to leave town until alter the Christmas holidays.

Mr. Quilter's writings on art are familiar to most readers of English periodicals. On the pre-Raphaelite movement he produced a well-remembered series, and his successive criticisms of the Royal Academy exhibitions, many of which papers are included in this large illustrated octavo, have made him widely known to the English public.

Mr. Whitney's 600 octavo pages do not constitute a biography of Lincoln, nor do they relate solely to knowledge of him derived during the time he and Mr. Whitney spent together "on the circuit." Properly they are reminiscences of an acquaintance that continued until Lincoln died, but they are written without any attempt at orderly arrangement.

The following officers will constitute the official board for the Navy Department on the trial to-morrow of the new coast-defense battleship Monterey: Rear Admiral George Brown, President; Capt. Louis Kempff, Chief Engineers G.F. Kutz, Joseph Trilley, and George J. Burnap; Lieut. Commander E.C. Pendleton, Lieuts. J.W. Carlin and R.F. Nicholson, and Naval Constructor D.W. Taylor.

The readvertisement for bids for the erection of the new City Hall in Jersey City, and the attempt to make a scapegoat of ex-Finance Commissioner Joseph Warren in connection with it, are the culmination of an unusually neat plot on the part of the local contractors' ring to defeat the awarding of the contract to a bidder who had overreached them.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 16 -- The Picayune's Havana cable special says: Sugarmaking is becoming general throughout the island, and new sugars have been received at Matanzas. The weather continues fine and dry. This is good for taking off the crop, but rain is much needed for vegetables, to which large tracts of land in the vicinity of Guines have been seeded.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 17 -- What will become of the Rev. Henry Preserved Smith, who has just been suspended from the ministry by the Cincinnati Presbytery, is a question often asked. Prof. Smith himself does not yet know, but his position is this: In the first place, he will appeal to the Synod of Ohio and if necessary to the General Assembly.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The official trial of the new practice cruiser Bancroft will take place in the first week of January. As soon as the marine railway in Moore's shipyards is vacated the Bancroft will be hauled out and her bottom given a thorough overhauling. The regulation navy anti-fouling paint will be applied, and the present cast-iron screws of the boat will be exchanged for a set of manganese bronze propellers.

A bill imposing a duty of half a cent a pound on raw sugar was recently introduced in the House by Mr. HARTER. The New-York Tribune tries to mislead its readers as to the effect of this bill by saying that Mr. BARTER "thinks the people are desirous of paying more for their sugar than they do now."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 17. -- Dr. Plutarco Ornelus, the Mexican Consul here, is in receipt of a large amount of official correspondence bearing upon the recent outrage committed by the Mexican freebooters at San Ygnacio. From this correspondence the Consul bases the folloping conservative statement of facts:

The opening of a new college settlement in Boston calls to mind the fact that this particular phase of philanthropy is Raining in favor. Like its two predecessors -- for there are still only three in our country strictly of this kind -- it is founded and carried on by the alumnee and friends of women's colleges, having for a common parent Toynbee Hall in London.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Probably the most notable dinner ever given to a citizen of Philadelphia was spread at the Art Club to-night in honor of William F. Harrity, Secretary of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and Chairman of the National Democratic Committee.

New-York merchants and manufacturers who expect to exhibit at the World's Fair have been complaining for some time that they have been unable to learn from the World's Fair people the amount of space that would be allotted to them. In view of this fact the International Exhibitors' Association sent a telegram to the Director General asking when the majority of allotments of space would be completed.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 17 -- G.C. Power, the special agent of the Illinois Central system, who has for several years been endeavoring to improve the Central American trade through New-Orleans, came here yesterday on a new mission. He has been appointed Industrial Commissioner of the road, and has been South for the last two or three weeks, locating industries alone both the Illinois Central and the Yazoo and Mississippi Valley routes.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 17 -- The first course of the new United States Naval War College closed the last week in October. Since then the President, Capt. Mahan, has been engaged in reviewing the written solutions of the problems given to the class and reporting to the Navy Department the names of those whose work has seemed to him worthy of notice and commendation.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Vanity Fair says that the Home Ruls bill merely proposes the establishment of an Irish Congress, composed of Irish peers and commoners, which will hold periodical meetings in Dublin and prepare measures to be acted, upon by the Imperial Parliament at Westminister. Local authority is to be exercised by Parish and County Councils.
The controversy between Bishop Wigger of Newark, N.J., and Father Corrigan of Hoboken, was rather abruptly terminated last night. The trial is stopped and the charge withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Out in Montana, where there are no Democrats who are likely to be called Mugwumps because they are opposed to Speaker Crisp, the Democrats are not all as much "snubbed" by the Reform Club failure to ask Crisp to speak as were the Republicans in Congress and the Chairmen of committees appointed by Crisp.

Last night will be long remembered in the Naval Reserve of the State of New-York. In the presence of hundreds of applauding friends at the Twelfth Regiment Armory it fought a desperate naval battle, repelled the efforts of the enemy to board the vessel it was on, gave a variety of drills, showed some fine marching, and was inspected by Inspector General H.T. McGrath and reviewed by Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 17 -- The uppermost athletic topic among Yale men is the promise of an indoor baseball diamond and running track. It is to develop through the modest generosity of a Yale graduate, resident in New-York, who has offered $5,000 for this purpose. The building cannot be had this Winter, but it will be ready before the snow blows again.

Ex-Mayor and Mrs. William R. Grace introduced their second daughter, Miss Lilias J. Grace, into the social world yesterday afternoon, when they gave a reception from 4 to 7 o'clock in their handsome home, 31 East Thirty-eighth Street.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 17 -- Trouble has arisen from a moat unexpected source over the will of P.T. Barnum.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- The State Board of Commissioners of Quarantine have determined it to be necessary to improve and enlarge Hoffman Island for the accommodation of a larger number of steerage passengers, and also to provide a suitable place for the reception of cabin passengers who may be detained in New-York Bay, especially during a cholera scourge.
Fire broke out at 1:45 o'clock this morning in the wholesale grocery establishment of W.B. A. Jurgens, 248 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn.

Mr. Hamerton is so well known through his former works relating to the fine arts and his monthly contributions to the Portfolio that the reader who has been pleased or irritated by him will come to "Man in Art" already fairly apprized of what he is to find. In the first place there is always the good taste in the outward appearance of a volume that appears with Mr. Hamerton's name on the titlepage.

Commissioners of Charities and Correction Charles E. Simmons and Edward C. Sheehy, who were arrested just prior to election charged with illegally inducing and advising the inmates of the pauper institutions on Randall's Island to register in tills city, were brought before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday for examination.

The story cabled from London recently and published in THE TIMES hinting that the collection of Burns and other manuscripts, recently purchased in Edinburgh by Mr. John S. Kennedy. President of the Lenox Library, this city, and now in the possession of that institution, was mainly, if not altogether, made up of forgeries, has created considerable surprise.

Some still existing superstitions among fishermen are communicated by a resident in Fraserburg to the Daily Free Press. At the beginning of the herring season the crew all try to seize the herring first on board to see if it be male or female. If it is a male, their fishing may be expected to be a poor one; it a female, a good one.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Within the last few weeks three millionaires have died leaving estates valued at $85,000,000. The greater part of this amount consisted of personal property, from which the State derived but a very small tax. State Controller Campbell has been looking the matter over, and has made up his mind that a law should be passed by which these vast personal estates should be taxed at least once in a generation.

The quarterly number of the publication of the American Society of Naval Engineers just issued contains as a leader a revision of the recent lecture of Passed Assistant Engineer I.N. Hollis before the Naval War College. Naval Constructor D.W. Taylor discusses at length the subject of speed trials of ship. Mr. Taylor favors the adoption of a one-hour speed course in lieu of the present contractors'four-hour run.

We are very much in favor of Grover Cleveland for President of the United States. It seems to us that this has been the expression of the people's wish, delivered in no unequivocal manner. Hence, in all matters or executive policy now and hereafter, we are greatly inclined to favor the views of Mr. Cleveland.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 17 -- Democrats are elated over the outcome of their first tilt with the Republicans in the State Supreme Court in furtherance of a fair count.

The visit of Health Officer JENKINS to Albany and his interview with Gov. FLOWER are followed by the announcement that the Quarantine Commissioners have waked up and decided to enlarge and improve the establishment down the bay. It is said that they are going to extend Hoffman Island and either build a ship or a new island for the reception of cabin passengers.

The Navy Department and the Pacific Mall Steamship Company are just now at "outs." Recently the Navy Department had occasion to negotiate with the Pacific Mail Steamship Company for the transportation of 100 seamen to San Francisco via the Isthmus of Panama. The seamen to be sent out to the Pacific are to constitute a part of the crew of the new United States coast-defense battle ship Monterey.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 17 -- Augustus H. Hornsby, who has relatives in the English nobility, and who four years ago was worth $300,000, has run away. He leaves debts amounting to $20,000, and is wanted for forging the name of Mrs. Antonio Wortman, a widow, to a deed to valuable St. Paul real estate, on which he secured a large sum of money.

Mr. Andrew Lang should read Mr. Harris's happy preface, where he touches lightly on folk-lore. "The folk-lore branch of the subject," says he, "I gladly leave to those who think they know something about it. My own utter ignorance I confess without a pang. To know that you are ignorant is a valuable form of knowledge, and I am gradually accumulating a vast stock of it."
At a meeting of the Century Club last evening Parke Godwin delivered a memorial address on George William Curtis.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17 -- The passing of McKinley and the Kepublican fad of nigh protection continues to be the theme of discussion in this State. Gen. J. Warren Keifer, ex-Speaker of the House of Representatives, had this to say to THE TIMES'S correspondent:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Mr. Blaine's physician has declared, in an official statement that bears out all the recent statements concerning Mr. Blaine's serious illness and disposes of the ineffectual and melancholy attempts to deny these statements, that he is hopelessly ill.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- State Engineer Schenek said to-day that, in his opinion, a rotten state of affairs bad existed in the Adirondack region for many years past. The law, as it now stands, provides that lands of non-residents shall not be sold for delinquent taxes unless a notice is first served on the occupant. Knowing this, private owners denude their acreage of lumber and them default in the payment of the State tax.

The week ending at noon yesterday there were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics 727 deaths, 994 births, and 403 marriages. The deaths were 32 more than the preceding week, but 55 below the average for the corresponding week during the past five years. The death rate was 20.43 in an estimated population of 1,856,995, as against 19.54 the preceding week and 21.97 average for the corresponding week the past five years.

The trotting stock belonging to the estate of the late Walter S. Hobart of California is due by special express at New-York early this morning, and will be taken immediately to the American Institute Building. The celebrated stallion Stamboul -- 2:07 1/2 -- is among them. At Chicago, where a two days' rest occurred, he was visited by a large number of horsemen, and was in fine fettle.
The enterprising tourist firm of Raymond Whitcomb announces that its hotel at Chicago, which is being constructed for the entertainment of its patrons, is rapidly approaching completion.

From the fact that Mr. W.H. PREECE, who is Chief Engineer and Electrician of the Post Office Department in Great Britain, has succeeded in sending through a distance of three miles a telephonic message from the mainland to an island in the Channel, and this without using a wire extending from coast to coast, the London Spectator concludes that in this experiment we have the germ of interplanetary communication.

A memorial meeting in commemoration of the eighty-fifth anniversary of the birth of John Greenleaf Whittier was held last night at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. 502 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. Gen. John B. Woodward, President of the institute, delivered a brief introductory address. A hymn written by Whittier was sung, and then the Rev. John W. Chadwick read a memorial poem, a tribute to the virtues of the Quaker poet.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- M. Charles de Lesseps and his fellow-prisoners arrested for connection with the Panama Canal frauds, protested to-day against the rigid seclusion to which they are subjected in the Mazas Prison. They said they were confined like common criminals, and subjected to the same treatment as robbers and other offenders of the vilest type, and they demanded the privilege of being allowed to see visitors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- There was a remarkable test of a curved armor plate at the naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Head today. It was the first curved Harveyized plate to he fired at. It came from the Bethlehem Iron Works, and was ten and a half inches in thickness. It was curved first and then submitted to the Harvey process.

A woman whose home for several years was in Zanzibar, where as wife of a United States Consul she enjoyed special privileges, told at a luncheon the other day of her visit to the chief Sultana of the late Sultan's household. His family included 140 Sultanas, with one, a full-blooded Arab, leading all the others and invested with special privileges.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Dec. 17 -- Within the last week a diamond excitement has broken out in this city as well as the surrounding country. There was one of a similar nature in 1864 and 1865, and Caleb Lyons, then Governor of Idaho, took a very active interest in the matter, but returned home to New-York State and died, and no further steps were taken to develop the fields.
The total value of city real estate sold at auction at the Real Estate Exchange for the week ending with yesterday. Dec. 17, was $473,846, against $996,139, the figures for the week previous.

BUFFALO, Dec. 17 -- In the days when Fort Erie was a rival of Buffalo in size and Black Rock was bigger than either, smuggling was a calling, as history and legend show, pursued by adventurous spirits residing on both, sides of the imaginary line passing through the centre of the navigable channel of the Niagara River and separating the United States from Canada.

The celebration of the fifty-year jubilee of the Hebrew Congregation Rodeph Sholom was continued yesterday morning in the temple at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street. This congregation was organized Sept. 29, 1842, and was composed of fifty members, of whom only eleven are still alive. The first service was held in the synagogue at 157 and 159 Attorney Street, and the dedicatory services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Merzbacher.

Mrs. Ernest Hart's name is well known in connection with the revival and promotion of Irish industries, particularly in the part of Ireland known as the congested districts of Donegal. In this and in other counties of Ireland Mrs. Hart has trained her workers to produce beautiful and artistic woolen and linen fabrics, rich embroideries, and fine laces.

SYRACUSK, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The Surrogate's Court had just opened for the day's business this morning when Morris A. Graves and Jacob Nottingham, the executors under the will of the millionaire, D. Edgar Crouse, and ex-Surrogate Cook entered with the petition for the probate of the will. The formalities were short, and consisted simply or banding up the somewhat voluminous petition.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The Montclair Dramatic Club opened its season at the Montclair Club Hall last night with the seventh subscription performance since its organization. The play presented was J. Palgrave Simpson's comedy, "Court Cards." The hall was well filled with an audience composed of the most prominent society leaders of this city.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- General Traffic Manager Berry of the Boston and Maine Railroad has sent the following communication to J.F. Goddard, Chairman of the Trunk Line Committee in New-York, and to J.W. Midgeley, Chairman of the Western Traffic Association in Chicago:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The inquest into the cause of the death of Ella Newton, whose body was found floating in a bathing pool at Invermere Hotel on East Chester Creek, was continued this evening. No verdict was rendered, and it will be continued next Wednesday evening at 7 o'clock.
The Thingvalla Line steamship Hokla yesterday reached port after an unusually eventful passage. The voyage across the Atlantic was marked by tempestuous weather throughout.

Lawyers Charles W. Brooke and John Lindley were in a cheerful mood yesterday when asked if they had any reasons for thinking that the jury in the Jacobs-Sire breach-of-promise case had rendered a verdict awarding heavy damages to their fair client.
That was the elevator boy's song. When he had sung it, he sighed. The solitary passenger asked: "What's the matter with you?"

They were all in one car. It is remarkable how many pretty women do get crowded togather in one car sometimes. A Broadway car when there is a sudden flurry of rain is worth getting jammed up in just to see the pretty women and their pretty gowns. They are like flowers massed in a bouquet, only some of them, instead of looking as sweet as they might, look almost cross.

-- A collision between freight trains occurred yesterday morning on the central Hudson Railroad between Churchville and Chill, in which three freight trains were involved and twenty-eight cars were wrecked. One train was taking water when a second ran again at it at the rear, and a third ran into the wreck. No person was hurt.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 17 -- All the Orange society leaders who take an interest in equestrianism, and their number is legion, were to be found on Thursday night at the annual entertainment of the Gentlemen's Riding Club of East Orange, given in the North Clinton Street Academy. The entertainment was one of the best ever given by the club.

One of the most significant local political events of the week was the visit which a delegation of prominent members of Tammany's General Committee of the First Assembly District made to Richard Croker for the purpose of protesting against the plan to make ex-Senator Michael C. Murphy Tammany leader in that district and the clearly-expressed determination of Mr. Croker to adhere to the plan and make Mr. Murphy the leader.

The last few days have been very important ones in the history of the National League for Good Roads, and the results of the efforts put forth during this time have been an additional impetus to this great reform which is spreading through this country.

The non-sharpshooters' match in the Seventh Regiment Armory last night proved a veritable surprise party. Only "duffers" were eligible, the competition, while open to all members of the regiment, rigidly excluding those who in any army rifle club match or in a competition for the Abeel or Le Boutillier Trophy had ever made a score of 65 points or better in 14 shots.

PHILADELPHIA,Dec. 17 -- Postmaster General Wanamaker was seen at his store hero to-day in reference to the statement published this morning that he was one of a number of capitalists who bad secured the control of the right to collect the customs revenues of the Republic of San Domingo.

It was decided by the Episcopal Board of Managers of Missions at its last meeting to decline further Government subsidies for the support of its schools. This action was determined upon when the question of renewing the contracts with the Government for the conduct of schools in Alaska was under consideration.

The reported disappearance of Edward P. Chamberlain, executor of the estate of John M. George, was discussed yesterday somewhat in a spirit of levity by those who know the man. It had been his habit for years to disappear periodically and to remain away weeks at a time. The demands upon him were not urgent, and it was not necessary for him to attend constantly to business.

The Water Color Club, a recent corner among the art organizations of New-York, makes for a third time an exhibition of water colors and pastels, and again forestalls the Water Color Society. This time the galleries near Thirty-fifth Street on Fifth Avenue have been chosen. They are filled with pictures of various merit by artists of name and of no name.

The ceremonies in connection with the laying of the cornerstone of the new Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday were of the simplest description. There was no parade of the regiment nor of the organization of the National Guard which is to occupy the completed structure with it, the Second Battery; merely a coming together of the officers of the active commands and a few of the veterans of the organizations.

That the interest shown by the Commander in Chief in the National Guard extends to the Naval Reserve is evidenced by the application to the General Government on the part of Gov. Flower for the old frigate New-Hampshire to be employed as an armory by the First Battalion. Everybody will rejoice with the natty young tars constituting the command of Commander Miller over the fact of their having at length secured an abiding place.

There is reason to fear that unless Euphrosyne arouses herself to new exertion in behalf of this fair land the old and long honored term, "American humor," will have no significance that is not purely historical before the beginning of the new century. As the nineteenth century is fading away, American humor fades with it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of to-day you report a lecture of Col. Robert G. Ingersoll delivered last night in the Broadway Theatre. You quote him as saying that "Voltaire was one of whom no orthodox preacher ever told the truth."

After June 1 the New Park Theatre, Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street, now managed by Hyde Behman of Brooklyn as a variety theatre, will change bands, but who will succeed the present management no one knows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- There is a chance that the Cramps will not secure the contract for both naval ships for which bids were opened at the Navy Department on Thursday. A contract for one of the vessels may go to the Union Iron Works of San Francisco. There is nothing in the law, say the legal officers of the department, to prevent the division of the work.

-- The question of opening museums of art on Sunday baa reached in England the point of belligerency. Just now the openers have it all their own way. The Sunday Society has undertaken to found an annual festival called Museum Sunday, on which special services more or less religious, according to taste, shall be held in museums.

That the discovery or Jupiter's fifth satellite, announced recently as having boon made by Prof. Barnard at the Lick Observatory, should in reality have been made here in Hartford, by Gov. Winthrop or Connecticut, away back in the year 1664, only about twenty years after Galileo's death, seems an astonishing fact, and one hard to accept at first implicitly.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Dec. 17 -- James Wendall and Lycurgus Sarsfield, two Boston scientists, have returned to this city from the eastern put of Idaho County, where they had been investigating the reported discovery of several glaciers and glacial lakes. F.B. Schmuhorn, an agent of World's Fair Commissioner Wells, was the discoverer of the surprising phenomena, and the scientists' reports agree with the description given by Schmuhorn.

-- Chiekering Hall has been engaged for next Friday evening, Dec. 23, for an operatic concert. Among the artists who will appear are Signer Natale the Sperati, tenor; Mile. Ermine da Rouvillain, soprano; Mile. Flora Margueritte Bertelle, soprano; Miss Alice Goodrich, contralto; Herr Carl Schachner, baritone; Signor Luigl Sartori, basso; Signor Ceruclos, pianist, and Signer B. Giannint, musical director and accompanist.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 17 -- The Hearing in the case of Robert Beatty, charged with furnishing poison with which to poison non-union workmen at Homestead, was held this afternoon before Squire McMasters. W.S. Brennan represented the defendant, who was brought into the room by Special Officer Farrell, and the prosecution was represented by E.Y. Beck.

BOISE CITY, Dec. 17 -- Two weeks ago the Board of State Canvassers met at the Capitol Building in this city, in accordance with the terms of the statute, for the purpose of canvassing the Electoral returns from the several counties.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is indeed fortunate for those housekeepers who are enthusiastic over holiday observances that the rich fruit cake, jumbles, and the like, which are considered indispensable to such feasts, will not only keep a long time, but are the better for keeping. This is true of all cakes that are made without the addition of yeast or baking-powder and wetted with eggs or spirits, and not with milk.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A heavy gale swept the southeast coast of Scotland to-day.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The report was circulated last evening that Senator Jules Guichard would be made President of the Suez Canal Company in the place of Charles de Lesseps, now in Mazas Prison awaiting trial for complicity in the Panama Canal frauds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A resolution was passed by the House Committee on the Judiciary, at its last meeting, requesting the Committee on Rules to appoint an early day for the consideration of the Torrey Bankruptcy bill. This bill was reported by the Judiciary Committee in the last session, only four members out of the fifteen on the committee opposing the report.

After a seven days' journey across the continent the horses forming the stock of the Hobart Stud in California reached this city safely yesterday morning and were at once taken to the American Institute Building, where they will be sold to-morrow. The lot were headed by the champion trotting stallion of the world, Stamboul, 2:07 1/2, and they were in fairly good condition when they ware placed in their stalls.

Calamity howlers, who insisted that Democratic success at the recent election would mean a general paralysis of business, with a strong tendency toward national ruin, have found little to comfort them or bear out their prophecies in the behavior of the iron market since the Republican defeat.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Dec. 18 -- The meeting of the Indiana State Chess Association closed yesterday with an exhibition of simultaneous play by Showalter, who won nine out of ten games. Showalter parted from Lasker in the friendliest manner. To-day Lasker gave a lecture on chess before a large audience.

The jubilee exercises in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Hebrew Congregation Rodeph Sholom, which began last Friday, were brought to a close yesterday at the temple, at sixty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. The 300 children of the religious school were the principal participators in yesterday's exercises, under the direction of Benjamin Blumenthal.

Ex-City Chamberlain William M. Ivins got back home yesterday from South America, after an absence of many months. He came on the Seguranca of the United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Company, of which he is President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Representative Watson of Georgia said to-day that the report that he intended to institute a series of individual prosecutions for illegal voting and intimidation at the recent Congressional election in his district was unfounded and untrue. What he will do, he says, is to contest the seat of his opponent, Mr. Black.

It was something like old times in Dr. McGlynn's lecture room in the Cooper Union last night. There was the largest audience that the Anti-Poverty Society has entertained for many a day, and it wan as enthusiastic and emotional as the assemblages which used to greet the expastor of St. Stephen's just after he was unfrockced and when he was holding public conferences, supported by Henry George, who has long since deserted him.

The export of some four and three-quarter millions of gold last week would not, in itself, be an occurrence that need to produce any apprehension in business circles. It is unusual, of course, but if it were produced by ordinary and what may be called legitimate causes, it would not greatly influence the course of opinion.

Sir Henry Parkes is not a name unknown in these latitudes. His fame as an Australian statesman of fifty years' standing is familiar to all persons who read newspapers, which essentially is all men who read at all. On at least two occasions he has visited America, and the attentions he received attracted more than passing notice.

SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Fred McGuire, who murdered Mrs. Amelia Gregory at Middletown, Oct. 14, 1891, and who is to die by electricity to-morrow, is apparently resigned to his fate. He passed his last Sunday quietly. He was visited by the Rev. D.L. Conkling of Middletown and the Rev. S.W. Egerton, the prison chaplain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary or the Treasury Charles Foster talked to-day respecting the alarm felt in financial circles over anticipated large sold exports. He said he looked upon the situation not simply as a spectator awaiting his retirement from office.

Interesting services were held yesterday morning at the new St. Luke's Church, in Hamilton Grango, One Hundred and Forty-first Street and Convent Avenue, the occasion being the formal opening of the new church for public worship. The handsome edifice was filled with worshippers. The Rev. Dr. Isaac H. Tuttle, who for more than forty years has ministered to the parish, conducted the services and preached the sermon.

The entrances to New-York Harbor are admittedly well lighted, and the course of the navigator from Fire Island to the city is plain enough in clear weather. But at night, espe- cially if the weather is thick enough, to obscure the range lights, the mariner finds that an improvement can be made in the system of lights which mark the shoals of the lower bay.

A mail pouch of registered matter was stolen from a mail wagon on Saturday night somewhere between Station D, Ninth Street, near Third Avenue, and the Post Office Building. The driver of the wagon is under arrest and will be arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields to-day. What burden of guilt rests on him cannot be stated until the Post Office Inspectors give their evidence.

The nearest approach to Irish fair squabbles in this country arises from the Gaelic football games and the hurling matches. Broken heads are common incidents of these games. There was one of these real old-fashioned hurling matches yesterday. The Irish-American and Wolf Tone teams, both members of the Gaelic Association of America, met yesterday afternoon at Wallace's Park, Ridgewood, L. I.

-- The annual election of officers of the Riverside Wheelmen of this city will be held on Jan. 6. The ticket to be voted for is as follows: President -- J.L. Miller; Vice President -- J.F. Fitch; Secretary -- R. W. Harrington; Treasurer -- W. Walton; Captain -- E.A. Powers; Lieutenants -- Judge, Potter, and Granger.

Disastrous flies have been so common of late in Brooklyn that the insurance companies are almost frantic. The record of fires for twenty-four hours was ably sustained yesterday morning, when a three-hundred-thousand-dollar blaze was added to what had taken place before. With the fire which destroyed a portion of Arnott's Stores, at the foot of Twenty-seventh Street, on Saturday morning, the total loss in less than twenty-four hours was in the neighborhood of $700,000.

AURORA, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Founder's Day, Dec. 12, was suitably observed. Flowers adorned the founder's picture, and Mrs. Piutti. 77, Professor of Physical Culture give in the morning exercises an interesting sketch of Mr. Weils's life and character. With reminiscences of his personal relations to the college when she was a student.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 18 -- After the failure of the First National Bank of Wilmington about a year ago there was a contest for the receivership. Mr. W.S. O'B, Robinson of Goldaborough was one of many applicants. Controller Lacy had intimate personal relations with State Senator Z.V. Walser of Lexington, N.C., and was disposed to appoint him.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 18 -- The Commissioners to locate and establish the correct boundary line between the States of Pennsylvania and Delaware have encountered an unexpected difficulty in the completion of their duties, and one that threatens to create a miniature revolution before the trouble is satisfactorily adjusted.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 18 -- By July next the State University of Iowa at Iowa City will have under its supervision an expedition covering a distance from the Northwest Territory to Cuba. Frank Russell, '92, is now in the former region in the interest of the Zo-ological Department. In May the university will send a scientific expedition to the Bahamas.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 -- After M. di Renzl's motion had been proposed at the Monetary Conference yesterday, Senator Allison made a short speech in behalf of the United States delegation. He laid emphasis upon the fact that throughout the debate nobody had suggested that either of the money metals be disoarded. During the adjournment, he said, the delegates would have time to study the Rothschild and other proposals that had been submitted.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- At 11 P.M. Drs. Johnston and Hyatt saw Mr. Blaine and gave out for publication the following statement:
Samuel Smiles has nearly completed his eighty-first year, but he is hard at work on a biography of Josiah Wedgwood, to whom English pottery is so much indebted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Treasury Department people in charge of immigration, including Superintendent of Immigration Owen, are not disposed to accept the suggestions of the representatives of the steamship companies who appeared before the joint Immigration Committee at the Capitol. They do not think any system of supervision and quarantine an the port of departure is possible.

The Rev. Father Harry Adams has resigned the rectorship of the Church of the Redeemer, at Park Avenue and Thirty-second Street, in favor of his former associate, the Rev. Father W.E. Johnson. Father Adams will continue as associate rector and Father Johnson will have entire charge of the parish work. They will equally share the annual stipend of $2,000.

Possible turf legislation at the coming session of the Assembly, now so near at hand, is the principal thing about which racing men gossip nowadays, the publication in THE TIMES, of the intention of the race track managers to ask for an extension of the racing season from April to November, instead of from May to October, as at present, having brought this about.
-- Judge John T. Cunningham, for several years Jndge of the Superior Court in Montgomery, Ala., a lawyer in Atlanta, and a prominent fruit grower, died at Atlanta yesterday.

The annual public meeting of the New-York City Mission and Tract Society was held last night in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. John Hall is pastor. President Morris K. Jesup presided, and on the platform were the Vice President, the Rev. Dr. A.F. Schaufiler, and some or the male and female workers of the society.

The War Department has decided again to garrison Key West, Fla. During the past west orders were received by Col. L. La Rhett Livingston, commanding the Third Regiment United States Artillery, to select on his own judgment three batteries of artillery for service in Florida. Two of the batteries he is directed to send to Fort Barrancas and the third to Key West.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 18 -- A special to the Tribune from Alexandria, Minn., says: A freight accident occurred on the Great Northern Railroad this morning at Nelson Station, five miles east of here, in which eight men were killed and five were injured.

When Chief Bonner planned the oode of fire signals which went into effect early in 1890 he filled up assignments for twenty-five engines to answer from first to fifth alarms for Station 265, because from this station would be sent an announcement of any fire that might occur in what was the Grand Central and is now the Broadway Central Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The dispatches which have gone from Washington reflecting upon the honesty of Secretary Tracy in his adoption of the circular in place of the conical turret for the New-York and the battle ships are unjust to the head of the Navy Department, besides being a misrepresentation of the situation.

-- After the Garrison-Morris match at 100 birds, $300 a side, was shot at Coney Island Saturday, and won by the Jockey. Judge Newton of the Coney Island Athletic Club offered to match Morris against Garrison again on the same terms for $500 or $1,000 a side. Garrison did not accept at the time, but said that if Morris would shoot him twenty-one yards boundary he would make a match.

Neither the detectives who are looking for him nor the friends who believe in his integrity have seen or heard anything of Edward P. Chamberlin, the missing business man of 41 Wall Street and the trustee of the estate of John W. George. He has not been seen by any acquaintances or at his usual haunts since Monday, Nov. 7.

The estate of D. Edgar Crouse, whose will has been offered for probate in Syracuse, is worth about $4,000,000. Just what disposition will be made of this sum will depend to a great extent upon who is next of kin to the testator. After some special bequests it is calculated that about $3,000,000 will remain in the executor's hands.

NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- Newark did not have an entirely dry Sunday to-day. The police bad received complaints from mothers and wives that their sons and husbands found the all-night saloons too attractive, and that they frequently tarried in them till they had spent the larger part, if not all, of their week's earnings. The result was that those dependent upon them at home often had to go without the necessaries of life.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The recent agitation in various parts of Westchester County over the subject of electric railroads, particularly in the lower part of the county -- Yonkers, Mount Vernon, William's Bridge, and New-Rochelle -- has created a desire for the carrying out of the oft-proposed road from Tarrytown on the Hudson River to this village, and from here to Port Chester on Long Island Sound.

Mr. Cleveland entertained two members of his old Cabinet at his house, 12 West Fifty-first Street, Saturday afternoon and evening, and while his visitors were there important matters affecting the Northwest were under discussion. The visitors were Don M. Dickinson, Chairman or the Campaign Committee of the National Democratic Committee, and Senator William F. Vilas of Wisconsin.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 18 -- Albert Sharrard, sixteen years old, is terrorizing the ranchers near Dungeness. So recently broke into a settler's cabin and carried off two rifles and a quantity of ammunition. Two Deputy Sheriffs with warrants were sent to arrest the boy, but he intercepted the officers, covered, them with his rifle, and forced them to lay down their arms and turn back, with their hands above their heads.

The central figure at the third annual sundown supper of the Tenderloin Club last night at Jaeger's. Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, was Miss Marie Tempest. She sang her favorite song, the "Nightingale," as she -- so she said herself -- had never sung it before. This was no doubt due to the inspiration she must have received from the enthusiasm with which she was welcomed.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Perhaps the moat serious questions to come before the Legislature this Winter are those relating to taxation. Besides the Legislative Commission now sitting in New-York, there is a Tax. Revision Committee, consisting of Prof. Collin and J. Newton Fiero, and it has prepared some very radical amendments for presentation, notably a system for taxing personal property and one for taxing corporations on their earnings as they increase.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 18 -- Louis Sim, a Hungarian, who worked at the Carnegie Steel Works at Homestead during the strike, died at the Allegheny General Hospital to-day, and the physicians say it is believed he was poisoned.

The Fish and Game Protective Association of Sullivan County invites every man who fishes in that county to join the organization. Its object is simply to better the fishing for the public. It does not and will not own an acre of ground or water, or the exclusive right to fish or stock thereon. It gathers public-spirited sportsmen in a working body to preserve and protect the fish in free streams.

Among the answers received by the Board of Trade and Transportation to its circular asking for opinions on the advisability of a national quarantine is a letter from Hempstead Washburns, Mayor of Chicago, a city which the World's Fair makes particularly awake to the danger of an invasion or cholora. In it Mr. Washburne says:

The courtroom of Part L Superior Court was filled with spectators yesterday morning when the jurors in the Jacobs-Sire breach-of-promise case took their seats to hear their verdict of $25,000 damages for the plaintiff announced. Miss Esther Jacobs, looking somewhat pale, was present, with her mother and sister Clara. The defendant did not put in an appearance, and was represented, by his brother Albert and Lawyer Crandall.

Mrs. Ernest Hart, founder and honorary manager of the Donegal Industrial Fund for technical teaching in the congested districts of Donegal, lectured yesterday at the borne of Miss Cooper, 118 East Twenty-first Street, upon her work and her struggles in carrying it out. Mrs. Hart's mission to this country is to get Americans, who have been the best patrons of her school products, interested in the work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Mr. Cleveland's friends in the District of Columbia seem to have been completely cut out of the business of preparing for the inauguration. But the friends of some other candidates, and particularly the friends of German, appear to have managed to get the upper hand after Chairman Harrity had left the business in what he supposed, and as Mr. Gorman advised him, very good condition.

The Society of Colonial Wars gave a dinner at Delmonico's last night, and held its first election of officers. The gathering was officially designated as the "First General Court." The society was incorporated Oct. 18, this year, and its membership is limited to lineal descendants of those who fought in the colonial wars -- the Pequot war, King William's war, King George's war, Queen Anne's war, and the French and Indian wars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Unless the Senate Judiciary Committee takes decisive action at its regular meeting Wednesday concerning the nomination of ex-Representative McComas of Maryland to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, it is likely that the matter will go over until after the holidays.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- A special to the Herald from Springfield, Mass., says: "That the New-York New-Haven and Hartford officials do not propose to give up the fight to obtain control of the Connecticut River Railroad was shown by the fact that Vice President Tuttle and two other officials of the Consolidated Road were in this city till a late hour Saturday night.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19 -- The Populists have all along claimed that they would organize the lower house of the Legislature, although the Republicans had a majority of one. There has been much speculation as to the manner in which they would attempt this revolutionary proceeding, but the secret has been well kept until, in his cups, one of the managers furnished the key, which soon gave the full explanation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 19 -- District Attorney Burleigh made information this afternoon before Alderman McMaster, charging H.F. Dempsey, District Master Workmen or the Knights of Labor, and James Davidson and Patrick Gallagher with felonious assault and battery and administering poison. The men are implicated in the attempted poison conspiracy at Homestead.

There has been no end of talk since Cleveland and Stevenson were elected President and Vice President of the United States as to what "demands" the Tammany Hall organization in this city was going to make in the matter of appointments as soon as Mr. Cleveland was inaugurated:

-- Application was made to Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court Chambers, yesterday in behalf of Edward S. Innet, W.C. Muschenheimer, Gus A. Vett as Trustees of Adelphic Lodge, F. and A.M., for leave to sell the lodge's plot in Greenwood Cemetery. The lodge has owned the lot since 1863, and in that time only two of its members have been buried there.

Year after year the question of revising the tax laws of this State has come up in the Legislature and been dealt with in an ineffective fashion. There are indications that at the coming session it will receive more attention than usual, and it is important that it should be dealt with intelligently.

Sylvester F. Wilson does not intend to rest with Judge Ingraham's order vacating the stay of his sentence to fire years' imprisonment and $1,000 fine for the abduction of Libbie Sunderland. As soon as Judge Ingraham's order was served yesterday upon J.D. Hallen, Wilson's counsel, Mr. Hallen filed notice of appeal from it at the District Attorney's office.

There was a public hearing yesterday in the Council Chamber of the Board of Aldermen before the Committee on Streets on the application of the New-York Power Company for a franchise that will permit it to dig up the city streets to enable it to lay its mains. J. Murray Mitchell and Charles E. Coddington appeared as the counsel for the company.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- At 12:30 o'clock this afternoon a terrific explosion occurred in the elevator shaft of the Fort Orange Milling Company's building, facing oil the river front and backing up on the Erie Canal basin. The sparks set fire to the dry grain and flour. In an instant the blaze rushed up the shaft, and before an alarm was sent in the entire structure was a mass of flames.

The first step toward the consolidation of all the anti-machine Democratic organizations in Kings County will be taken to-night at a meeting to be held in the Johnston Building, at Fulton Street and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met in the Mayor's Office yesterday, and took up the financial budget for 1893 for final consideration. At the outset Mayor Grant made the following statement:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 19 -- Gov. Tillman today added another "damn" to the political history of the State, and one that is pretty sure to be the occasion of a big fight. The Legislature has just passed a severe railroad law Officers and others have used every effort to have him withhold his signature from the bill, and to-night a committee representing 8,000 railroad laborers called on him.

Every effort was made yesterday by the police of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station to discover who throw the acid on the crowd of boys who were gathered on Sunday afternoon in front of 1,746 Lexington Avenue, but no evidence could be obtained to warrant an arrest. There was no serious injury done to any of the boys, but most of them had more or less of their clothing ruined.

The New-York post Office did an immense business with the rest of the world during the month of November. There were handled, in all, 46,367,727 letters, bundles, and parcels, as against 39,286,979 during November, 1891, an increase of 7,080,748.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 16 -- There appears to be considerable trouble brewing for United States Senator C.J. Faulkner this Winter. The West Virginia Legislature will meet on Jan. 11, and among the important duties to be performed by the people's representatives at the coming session is the election of a member of the United States Senate to succeed Senator Faulkner, whose term expires on March 4 next.

An informal meeting of the stockholders of the New-York Baseball Club, called by President Day, was held yesterday afternoon at Spalding's, 492 Broome Street. The stockholders present Mere John B. Day. C. T. Dillingham, E.B. Taloot, F.B. Robinson, F.A. Abeel, E.A. McAlpin, and James O'Rourke. After hearing a statement of last year's receipts and disbursements, a plan for raising money to pay the deficiency was looked into.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The report of the Inter-state Commerce Commission for the year ended Nov. 30, 1892, was to-day transmitted to Congress. It opens with a review of the reasons which induced the passage of the act to regulate commerce, which are given in view of results realized in administering the act and the necessity for amendments which experience has disclosed.

NEW-YORK. -- A meeting of the new Directors of the Berkeley Athletic Association was held yesterday afternoon, but owing to the absence of three of the nine Directors the meeting was adjourned till Thursday, when no doubt the officers will be elected.

Edmund M. Smedherg, owner of 100 shares in the Vermont Marble Company, has brought suit in the Supremo Court, in which he makes ugly charges against Senator Redfield Proctor of Vermont. The defendants in the suit, besides Senator Proctor, are the company, Fletcher D. Proctor, its present President; F.A. Baker, Frank C. Partridge, Adolphus Smedberg, F.B. Riggs, J.R. Myera, E.J. Ormsbee, W.W. Grout, and Emily J. Proctor.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 19 -- The locality about Crawsfordaville is greatly excited over the flight of Milo Tomlinson, the well-known breeder of fine stock. Tomlinson has for several years done a large business in all kinds of stock. His running horses won many honors last season. Both he and his wife are of prominent and influential families.

Dr. Henry A. Hartt, the founder and Medical Director of the Columbian Institute for the Preservation of Health and the Cure of Chronic Diseases, 142 East Thirty-fourth Street, died on Saturday. He was born in Fredericton, the capital of New-Brunswick, in 1813, and received his early education in the academy and King's College in his native town.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 19 -- A local paper to-day prints replies to letters sent to 250 prominent Republicans in the State requesting their views on the proposition to nominate a candidate for United States Senator at the State Convention which will meet next Summer, after the plan adopted by the Democrats of Illinois.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Jane Savage, a workingwoman in Lincoln, while cleaning house last week placed her brother's small razor between her teeth that she intent have both hands free to take down a shelf. As she reached for the shelf, the razor slipped half way down her throat.

SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Frederic McGuire was executed by electricity at the prison here to-day. He was the tenth murderer who has paid the penalty in the electric chair under the present law, and his life was taken so quickly and with so little apparent suffering on his part that the execution was pronounced by those who have witnessed others the most successful of any.

The failure of the American Wood Paper Company was reported yesterday. The company has an office in this city at Church and Chambers Streets, with mills at Manayunk and Spring City, Penn., and headquarters at Providence, R.I. Deputy Sheriff Tracy yesterday received an attachment against the company for $2,750, in favor of George H. Remington, and levied upon funds in the hands of a third party.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Dennis E. Sibley, one of the oldest and best-known Board of Trade dealers, was forced to make an assignment to-day for the benefit of his creditors.
