Sibley's liabilities will reach $268,223,92. His assets are as yet undetermined, but it is thought they will yet exceed $70,000, but possibly may reach $90,000.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Dec. 19 -- P.M. Chicago Gas and Distilling and Cattle Feeding broke sharply to-day, the former 7 3/4 and the latter 7 points, and at the same time the other industrials developad great weakness. But notwithstanding the rattling down in this group railway stocks stood comparatively firm. Reading developed weakness in the last hour but its decline was brought about by a separate piece of manipulation.

SIM. SING, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Editor Michael Moran of the Democratic Register has filed a petition with Gov. Flower asking that William R. Brown, Warden of the prison here be removed from that office. Accompanying this request is an ailldavit from Mr. Moran in which he says some of the details of an assault which he says the Warden made on him a week age last Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Don M. Dickinson reached Washington to-day and spent several hours at the Capitol. He has business before the Supreme Court, and will remain a day or two. Knowing that he had just come from a visit to Mr. Cleveland, he was in great demand among those who are anxious to know the composition of the next Cabinet.

A big break in industrial securities, an advance in the rate for call loans to 40 per cent., and engagements of almost $4,000,000 in gold for shipment to Europe combined to give Wall Street lively times yesterday. On the Stock Exchange there was more excitement than that institution had soon in months. For a time it looked as if the stock market was in for a panic.

YANKTON, S.D., Dec. 19 -- Judge E.G. Smith of the First Judicial Circuit Court to-day rendered a decision on the application of Mrs. Daisy Winslow for temporary alimony in the case of divorce pending against her brought by her husband, Herbert Hall Winslow, the playwright.

Simon and Isidor Wormser used to have poetical thoughts as they gazed from the windows of their Fifth Avenue residence up the avenue and toward the upper end of Central Park. But their view and their poetical thoughts were interfered with by the building of bay windows on the new house of Mr. and Mrs. William Watts Sherman.

As bearing on the question of the value of the franchise for the new rapid-transit roads, the original cost of the present elevated system is of importance. The mileage of these roads (exclusive of the suburban line) is a little over thirty-two miles. The lines were only completed in 1880, and nothing was added to them from that time until the short suburban line was recently taken in by lease and exchange of stock.

POUGUKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Judge Dykman, in his decision removing George G. Titus of Pine Plains, Dutchess County, from the office of attorney and counselor, after referring to the fact that the referee's findings convict Titus of misconduct of great enormity, concludes as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 -- His son a self-murderer, himself deposed from his high office, a shortage in his accounts of $63,020.16, with absolute ruin staring him in the face, Michael J. Foerstel, until to-night City Treasurer of St. Louis, is one of the most unfortunate of men.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 19 -- The Sunday opening question has been taken into court. An application has been made for an injunction restraining the World's Fair Directors from closing the gates on Sunday, and Judge Tuley will hear arguments on the matter on Jan. 3.

The "Authors and Actors' Carnival" began at the Lenox Lyceum last night with a concert by Cappa's Band and nine Christmas tableaus designed and arranged by Capt. Alfred Thompson. On entering the Lyceum visitors found several unfinished booths and a number of pretty young women engaged in decorating the bare frames of the booths and trying to be hap py under somewhat irritating conditions.

If the dealers in Christmas greens are to be believed, there will be poor picking at high prices for late comers this year in the way of trees, wreaths, and pine roping. The demand has already set in with a rush, and prices are quite as high, if not higher, than they were last year. This is true particularly of Christmas trees.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The Globe prints a story, purporting to have been told by a fellow-convict, or the escape of James M. Bradley, alias Walter Maitland, who succeeded in getting away from the State prison last Thanksgiving Day and who has not yet been recaptured.

Hangman Van Hise carried the beams and crossbeams on which he expects to hang Hallinger, the negro wife murderer, Thursday, to the Hudson County Jail, in Jersey City Heights, yesterday, and began to put them in position. Meanwhile Counselor Peshal made application to Chancellor McGill for a writ of error and a stay of execution.

An afternoon with Brahms was enjoyed by a numerous and fashionable audience at the studio of Mr. Ferdinand Binzig, 246 West Forty-third Street, yesterday. Mr. Sinzig, whose artistic standing as a pianist is assured, had the valuable assistance on this occasion of Mr. Victor Herbert, violoncellist, and the Schmidt-Herbert Quartet.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- The Young Men's Demo cratic Club of Massachusetts held its annual meeting this afternoon at the clubroom, and elected A. George Bullock of Worcester President. This evening the annual banquet of the club was the occasion for a large gathering of well-known Democrats from all parts of the State, and the speeches made aroused great enthusiasm.

The Brooklyn City Railroad Company, whose present franchise is valued at $5,000,000, but for which the city was never paid a single cent, took the first step yesterday in what promises to be a long-drawn-out legal contest with the new Kings County Electric Company, owned by a few politicians and managed by Patrick Flynn, Alderman Coffey, and Senator McCarty.

In the opinion of Crane Lockwood, attorneys for Joseph George in the examination of the books of the George estate, until lately in charge of Edward P. Chamberlin, the story of the missing bonds and money has been about all told. The apparent deficit remains unchanged at $16,000, represented by ten one-thousand-dollar bonds of the Northern Pacific and Montana Railroad Company and $6,000 cash.

Representatives of the domestic mission societies of the Presbyterian, Congregational, and Reformed Churches met yesterday at the offices of the Presbyterian Board, 53 Fifth Avenue. The purpose of the conference was to decide upon some line of action which would obviate the multiplication of churches of different denominations in the home mission fields in the West and South.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19 -- The catalogue of Yale University for 1892-3, the one hundred and ninety-third issue, appeared to-day, and exhibits marked growth in general in the university.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 19 -- In the Federal court here to-day Judge S.F. Maxey passed sentence upon three of Garza's Lieutenants in his revolutionary army. Juan Antonio Floreo, who commanded one division of the army, and Carmen Yleenez and Cecileo Salinas were given each three years in the House of Correction at Detroit, Mich., and were fined $10.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 19 -- It is now stated on good authority that the shortage in the Louisville and Nashville freight office in this city will be at least $50,000. Agent McCourt was relieved several days ago. To-day Cashier Shotwell's successor was appointed. The company has attached all the real estate and other property of McCourt, placing its claim at $30,000, but it is not stated in the salt that this is the whole claim.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The plates, frames, angle irons, and castings employed in the hull of the new United States revenue steamer Windom will be furnished by the West Superior (Wis.) Steel Works. The Windom is building at the Iowa Iron Works, Dubuque, Iowa, and the above order is a sub-let contract of the Dubuque establishment.

The ring in control of municipal affairs in Hoboken is getting its political household in order preparatory to the resignation of Mayor Stanton, to take the position of Sheriff, to which Gov. Abbett is expected to appoint him.
The attendance at yesterday's meeting of the Baptist ministers was one of the largest on record. Nothing was left but standing room a few minutes after the Moderator had formally opened the meeting.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 19 -- The press dispatch from Washington purporting to represent the views of a high official of the War Department, to the effect that the United States has furnished ample protection for settlers on this side of the Rio Grande River, and that the Republic of Mexico has not properly guarded its side of the border, has been received with indignation, by people, civil and military.

Undoubtedly the apathy of the French press while the promoters of the Panama Canal Company were "exploiting" the small French investor is the most serions and discouraging feature of all the disclosures that have been made about the matter. It is equally discouraging socially and politically.

There should be a full attendance of members of the Chamber of Commerce at the meeting to-day at which the report of the Special Committee on Quarantine will come up for consideration. The members have had time to study the facts and recommendations of that report, and they concern very deeply the mercantile interests of this community and of the whole country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The public anxiety about Mr. Blaine, which was promoted, yesterday by the alarming reports circulated late in the day, was allayed to-day by the bulletins from the three attending physicians.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Ex-Assemblyman Frank M. McDermitt, who astonished the State the other day by pleading guilty to the indictments for libel that bad been found against him because he had charged the City Street and Waster Board with bribery in connection with the purchase of the new water supply, was fined $1,000 and costs by Judge Kirkpatrick today.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- M. Monchicourt, liquidator of the Panama Canal Company, was before the Parliamentary Investigating Committee for the second time to-day. When examined two weeks ago, M. Monchicourt excused his reticence on the ground of "professional secrecy." To-day he testified, more freely, although occasionally questions were repeated several times before he gave the desired answer.

A Pittsburg trade paper publishes letters from several firms that have undertaken the manufacture of tin plate. These firms were requested to give their opinions as to the probable action of the Fifty-third Congress with respect to the duty on tin plate and to furnish a list of the prices of their products.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Executive Committee of the National Association of Democratic Clubs held a meeting at the Ebbitt House to-day. The committee organized by the reelection of William L. Wilson of West Virginia as Chairman, and Mr. Lawrence Gardner as Secretary. The committee, by unanimous vote, determined to continue its headquarters at Washington.

Six Brooklyn Aldermen were examined by the Grand Jury yesterday in reference to the wholesale frauds on the occasion of the recent Columbian celebration, and from this fact grow a rumor that these same Aldermen had been indicted for the part they took in it.

The officers of the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the National Guard gave a dinner to Col. James Cavanagh last night at Delmonico's in celebra- tion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his first election as the commanding officer of the regiment. Gen. M.T. McMahon, who was his predecessor in the Colonelcy, presided over the feast, and at his right was Col. Cavanagh.

It was recently announced that the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company had completed negotiations for obtaining control of the Connecticut River Railroad by means of a lease, the terms of which were regarded as very favorable to the stockholders of the Connecticut River Company.

-- A big street railway deal was closed in Syracuse yesterday. The People's Railway Company and the Consolidated Railway Company were bought by a syndicate which is supposed to represent the Thomson-Houston Electric Company. The negotiations have been carried on very quietly, so quietly, in fact, that the stockholders in the People's Company did not know until yesterday that the Consolidated Company was included in the deal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- "I think there is a popular misapprehension in regard to the results so far of the International Monetary Conference," said Secretary Charles Foster to a reporter at the Treasury Department this afternoon. "It is a grave mistake," he said, "to assume that the conference will prove to he a failure.

MADRID, Dec. 20 -- The Anarchists appear to be resuming their activity in Spain. Three petards were exploded in Seville on Sunday last with disastrous results to the mansions of a merchant named Pons and of the Marquis of Villapanes, two of the most prominent residents of Seville. The residence of the Marquis was considerably damaged, but no person was injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Mr. Blame has held for twenty-four hours the improvement which was noted in his condition yesterday morning. He rested well during the night, entered on the morning refreshed, and consequently is better prepared to a very slight degree to resist the ravages of the disease which has brought him face to face with death.

Behind the fact that Gen. Martin T. McMahon did not preside at the dinner given by the Sixty-ninth Regiment to Col. Cavanagh, its commanding officer, at Delmonico's Monday night, there is a story that is stirring up an unusually interesting controversy in the regiment.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Dec. 20 -- A reign of terror exists in Komper County, and every citizen who had anything to do with the hanging of old man Tolbert and bringing Tom and Walter Tolbert to justice is now in peril of his life. A week ago William Beckham, known to have been prominent in the war on the Tolberts, was assassinated while sitting by his own fireside.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Some very valuable information relative to the laboring classes of Europe was submitted to the joint Committee on Immigration, which met this morning to confer about the bill introduced by Mr. Chandler in the Senate to suspend immigration for one year.

The bill Introduced by Mr. Bate (Dem., Tenn.,) on Dec. 5, "to repeal all statutes relating to Supervisors of Elections and special duties," was taken up in the Senate to-day, and Mr. Bate made an argument in its favor.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 20 -- An unparalleled affliction has fallen upon the freshman class at Yale. The Faculty has had the matter of punishing tee members of '96 who participated in the football celebration at the New-Haven Opera House on Dec. 3 in hand for some time, and this afternoon a concurrent meeting of the instructors of the academic and scientific departments was held for the purpose of reaching a final decision.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 20 -- A man giving the name of David W. Tucker of Milton, Mass., secured a room on the Boston boat last night, and when the boat arrived here this morning was missing. In his stateroom was found clothing, a wallet containing $1, and a note to the Captain saying that he had left the boat at 9 o'clock and asking that his effects be sent to his family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Hill returns to Albany this week, and it is reported that he will remain there until Mr. Hiscock's successor in the United states Senate is elected by the New-York State Legislature.

Those who oppose the confirmation of ex-Representative McComas as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia have filed charges with the Senate Judiciary Committee, touching his conduct while he was competing for the nomination to Congress in the Sixth Maryland District with Mr. Wellington, a Republican, four years ago.

Dr. George W. Nash, one of Health Officer Jenkina's deputies, and possessor of a wide reputation as an expert bacteriologist, will leave for Hamburg in a few days to be the recognized representative in Hamburg of this port He will co-operate with both the United States Consul and the German health authorities.

The wholesale liquor dealers or this city are greatly exercised over recent advances in the price of spirits sold by the Whisky Trust. Before Dec. 5 spirits sold for $1.23 per gallon. On Dec. 5 the price was advanced 5 cents, on Dec. 9 there was another advance of 5 cents, and on Dec. 15 a third advance of 5 cents was made, making in ten days a total advance of 15 cents.

The Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association devoted the principal part of its session yesterday to a discussion of the question of annual and time passes. For some time past there has been a feeling among the officers of the large and important trunk lines that the annual pass lists which they were asked to fill out each year was assuming altogether too large proportions.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Mgr. Satolli has sent to Cardinal Rampolla an important letter containing the two decisions and report of the proceedings of the American Bishops' Conference, and Rampolla has replied without delay expressing the Pope's satisfaction with the communication, and giving farther instructions regarding Satolli's mission to the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- When the Inman Line steamship City of New-York shall leave New-York on Feb. 29 her bow will point toward Southampton, the new European terminal of the International Navigation Company. At the same time it is expected that she will initially fly the Stars and stripes and become an American in reality as well as in name.

When the bells in the church tower chimed faint and clear over Fernymead last night, nobody who heard thorn could have doubted that the scene they brought to an end was the proof and culmination of a real success. The chimes were heard by the people who filled Herrmann's Theatre, gathered there to see what Miss Marion Manola, long known here as a singer in light opera, could do in comedy.

The effort to work up opposition in the Chamber of Commerce to the report of its committee in favor of a national quarantine utterly failed. The report and the accompanying resolutions were adopted unanimously. A mild substitute in favor of retaining some of the quarantine jurisdiction of the State received no support, and such perfunctory remarks as were made against complete national control received no favor in the meeting.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20 -- Despite the fact that Mr. Cleveland has written here expressing regrets at not being able to attend the big Democratic banquet on Jan. 25, some little hope is entertained that he will reconsider his decision, as some prominent Virginia leaders have written to the President-elect urging him to do so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The President has at last sent to the Senate the nominations for the three vacant staff positions in the army. There have been many applications for the places, and the fight has been fierce. An unusual feature of the three nominations is the fact that the officers selected come from artillery regiments, an arm of the service not generally recognized in the distribution of favors.

The Masonic lodges under the jurisdiction of the Grand Lodge of the State of New-York hold their elections for officers for the ensuing year in the month of December, and the following list includes all of the returns made up to date. The list contains the names of Masters, Senior Wardens, Junior Wardens, and Secretaries, and, in some reports, appointed officers:

HELENA, Ark., Dec. 20 -- There is great excitement here over the sudden and unexplained death of four convicts, and the probably fatal sickness of a dozen more, all in the camp of Sam Apperson, a contractor, who is doing work here for the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railway. About 110 convicts were brought here a week ago Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Carlisle of Kentucky has, it is said by his friends, boon asked to accept the office of Secretary of the Treasury in the Cabinet of President Cleveland. The proposition seems to have been made some time ago, and since it was suggested to Mr. Carlisle be has had occasion to consult his personal and party friends about accepting it.

The special committee from the Senate and Assembly that is investigating the subject of taxation considered, the assessment of personal property in this city at its session yesterday afternoon. The meeting was held in the courtroom of Part II. of General Sessions, and in addition to the members of the committee there were present Senators Plunkitt and Walker and Assemblymen HcManus and Ryder.

A joint meeting of representatives of the Presbyterian, Reformed, and Collegiate Reformed Churches was held yesterday at the Presbyterian Board of Missions, 53 Fifth Avenue, to determine upon the arrangements of the conferences, in this city, on Jan. 11, 12, and 13, of all churches holding the Presbyterian form of government.

Samuel Gompers, President of the American. Federation of Labor, returned yesterday from the convention of the federation hold in Philadelphia. He said that he had also been in Washington, where he had consulted with Congressmen Geary of California and Amos J. Cummings of New-York about labor legislation.

MONTERY, Mexico, Dec. 20 -- It was learned here to-day that Cecilic Salinas, who was yesterday sentenced to three years' imprisonment by the Federal court at San Antonio, Texas, for violation of the United States neutrality laws, spent the months of August, September, and October in Montorey and at other points in the interior of Mexico working up a sentiment for the revolutionary movement which was recently started on the Rio Grande border.

The verdict in the famous heresy trial of Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary is now near at hand. Yesterday afternoon a portion of the closing argument of the Prosecuting Committee was read by the Rev. Joseph J. Lampe. It will be finished to-day in all probability. As Prof. Briggs feared, the argument proven not to be one merely in rebuttal, but an exhaustive treatise, covering the entire field of the charges.

NEW-YORK. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Jerome Park Villa Site and Improvement Company was held yesterday at the office of the company, 115 Broadway, at which the following Board of Directors was elected: William A. Duer, John A. Stewart, Theodore Moss, Frederick A. Lovecraft, George R. Fearing, William R. Travers, and Charles F. Bauerdorf.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 20 -- The expressions of "both Populist and Republican" members of the Legislature indicate that there will be very material insurance legislation. Fire companies will be most affected, and it is reasonably certain that a law trill be passed compelling the payment of the face of a policy in oases of total loss.

The latest step in the scheme to consolidate all the Brooklyn surface railroads under one management, that of the proposed Brooklyn Traction Company, was the purchase yesterday of the Montague Street Cable Company. The buyers are hiding behind the Knickerbocker Trust Company of this city, but they have ofered every stockholder $75 per share for stock.

Mr. DurDorow (DeM., ill.,) introduced in the House to-day a joint resolution repealing the religious legislation pertaining to the World's Fair. The resolution proposes to amend the act of Congress approved Aug. 5, 1892, so as to leave the matter of Sunday observance entirely within the power of the regularly-constituted authorities of the World's Columbian Exposition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The final order for rapid-fire guns for the navy, out of money available under the present Administration, has been placed by the Bureau of Ordnance. The order consists of twenty-five high-powered one-pounder Hotchkiss guns, and is being filled by the Pratt Whitney establishment of Hartford, Conn.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 20 -- The expose of the Populist plans to capture the Legislature has caused a change, and, rendered desperate, a novel and revolutionary action was finally agreed upon this afternoon. As soon as the plan given to the public this morning came to their knowledge, J.W. Briedenthal, Judge Frank Doster, (candidate for United States Senator,) and Judge W.C. Webb, the legal adviser of the Populist committee, went into consultation.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Dec. 20 -- At the annual banquet of the Business Men's Association here to-night Erastus Wiman delivered the principal address. He discussed the probable bearing of the recent election on the future commercial policy of the United States and the effect upon the commerce of this country from closer commercial intimacy with Canada.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club and the late Cleveland and Stevenson campaign dabs were formally consolidated last evening into one large organization, to be known in the future as the Brooklyn Democratic club.
There was an unusual thing about yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen. Every member was present. This has only happened once before this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 --Secretary of the Navy Tracy is expected to settle, in a day or two, the placing of the contracts on the now armored cruiser Brooklyn and the sea-going battle ship Iowa. Mr. Irving M. Scott, President of the Union Iron Works of San Francisco, is still in this city, and his establishment may be expected to make a strong fight to secure one of the two vessels.

The Bar Association last night expressed a pain its disapproval of the course of Judge Isaac H. Maynard in rating from the Controller's office election returns that baa been mailed to the Controller, and thus aiding Gov. Hill in his scheme for the capture of the State Senate. Last Spring the association petitioned the Legislature to remove Judge Maynard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 20 -- The second of the series of five matches between J.A.R. Elliott of Kansas City, present champion trap shot of America, and E.D. Fulford, the crack shot of Harrisburg, Penn., resulted in a victory for Fulford. Each man shot at 100 birds. Following is the score:

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20 -- Samuel Garrett, a typical country youth in manners and appearance, was to-day lodged in the Fulton County Jail, charged with violating Uncle Sam's postal laws. Garrett lives in Towns County, on his father's plantation. The nearest Post Office is Mountain Scene.

The Chicago Herald, a prominent Democratic paper, remarks that THE TIMES has "delivered an elaborate lecture" to "those who say that the new Congress at an extra session beginning in March should pass certain bills for the removal of duties on raw materials and postpone further revision until the regular session."

The members of Mrs. John T. Hall's class met at Sherry's last evening and danced their second cotillion this season. Mrs. Hall and Miss Elsie Hall, being in mourning for Miss Elliott Roosevelt, were unable to attend the dance.

The manner in which the pauper insane are treated by the Department of Charities and Correction came in for some sharp criticism at the session of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's office yesterday.

Carlylo W. Harris was taken from the Tombs yesterday to the Court of Oyer and Terminer on a writ of habeas corpus procured by his counsel, Howe Hummel. Harris had appealed to the Court of Appeals from his conviction in the Court of General Sessions of murdering his wife, Helen Potts Harris. The appeal had been argued, but no decision had been made.

Two suits brought by a tradesman against the Manhattan Athletic Club on Saturday, coupled with suits which were recently brought, have given foundation for the rumor that the organization is in a bad way financially, and that unless some organic change be made in the management the club must go to the wall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Reports are reaching the public from day to day of the alleged inteution of the President to stretch the civil service regulations over several branches of the public service that are not now included in those regulations. Cabinet meetings are said to have been hold principally to weigh this important proposition.
CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 20 -- The active pursuit of bandits on the frontier by the United States authorities is highly appreciated here.

Another sotback was experienced by the Green-Swan bridge jobbers to-day, which ought to make their Christmas anything but merry. The Senato refused to take up the bill providing for a paper bridge across the Hudson River between New-York and New-Jersey. Mr. Black-burn, its Kentucky sponsor, could not have hit upon a more inauspicious lime for bringing the bill to the front.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The Court of Pardons to-day yielded to the importuning of the two wives of the bogus Count Kookogey to release him from the State prison on parole. The story of Kookogey's dual marriage and the infatuation of both women is best told by the records on file in the Court of Pardons and in the Court of Chancery.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The twentieth annual session of the State Grange of New-Jersey Patrons of Husbandry began yesterday in the Assembly Chamber in the State House. John Statesir of Monmouth County, the Grand Master, presided. Upward of 100 delegates were present.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Paris correspondent of the Morning Post says: "Needless indignities are inflicted upon Charles de Lesseps and his colleagues in the Mazas Prison. They are treated with ostentatious severity. They were not even allowed the favor of a private carriage when taken out for examination yesterday, but were placed in the cellular police van.
Mayor Grant made the following statement yesterday, in which he gives his views on local annexation and a "greater New-York":

The name of sawyer Frank J. Dupignao was presented for membership before the Bar Association at the meeting last Tuesday night and acted upon unfavorably. As a result there is considerable feeling in certain circles.

By unanimous vote the Chamber of Commerce yesterday approved the report of the Special Committee on Quarantine, submitted a week ago, and took stops toward carrying out the recommendations of the committee.

ANNISTON, Ala., Dec. 20 -- The trip or Gen. Adlai E. Stevenson to Alabama has developed enthusiasm on the part of the people, but no significant speechmaking on the part of the guest. The Vice President-elect and patty arrived at Anniston at noon on a special train, and will remain in the city until eight o'clock to-morrow morning, when they leave for Atlanta.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- In its annual report the State Board of Charities will discuss, among other things, the ways and means of diminishing pauper immigration. A session of the board was held to-day and the forthcoming report was outlined.

The college chess tournament, in which Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton are interested, will be commenced on Tuesday afternoon, Dec. 27, at Berkeley School, 20 West Forty-fourth Street. The games will begin at 4 P.M. The players and schedule of games are as follows:

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Dec. 20 -- At 4:30 this morning a party of miscreants smashed in the front door of the Catholic church in Old Albuquerque, also the door of the residence of the Jesuit Fathers, adjoining the church on one side, and the doors of the sisters' convent, adjoining the same edifice on the other.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Gen. Paine's position as to the building of a cup defender was made known to-day when he authorized the statement that he would not build.

-- At the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre tonight the members of the Columbia College Musical Society make their first appearance as minstrels. The society is composed of the College Glee Club, the Mandolin Club, and the Banjo Club. These clubs have been rehearsing for this performance during the last six weeks, and everything points to a successful entertainment.

The second concert or the second season of the New-York Symphony String Quartet was given last night in the chamber music room of Music Hall. There was an audience of good size and laudatory disposition. The entertainment was, on the whole, worthy of the applause which it evoked, though it was, perhaps, not quite so excellent as some of those present thought it was.

Controller Myers, at a meeting on Monday of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, is reported to have declared that too much money was being spent by the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in running expenses and for the salaries of Gen. Di Cesnola and his staff, and that too much coal was being burned in the museum building.

The Administration's axe of economy fell yesterday on Bills Island and left four Contract Labor Inspectors headless. The decapitated ones are Major S.C. Osborne, Major George Wanser, William Grogan, and the colored Inspector Charles Morris.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- A meeting of the creditors of the Marquis of Allesbury was held here to-day. It was announced that the estate would not realize more than 7s. 6d. in the pound.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- M. Floquet, President of the Chamber of Deputies, announced to the house to-day that be had received an application for authority to prosecute M. Ronvier, ex-Minister of Finance; M. Jules Rocho, ex-Minister of Commerce; Emanuel Arene, member for Corsica; Antonin Proust, member for Deux-Sevres, Baron Jean de Soubeyran, member for London, and Joseph Dugue de la Fauconnerie, member for Orne.

Stamboul, the champion trotting stallion of the world, was sold yesterday morning at the American Institute Building. E.H. Harriman, a banker doing business at 216 Broadway, and having a town residence on West Thirty-fourth Street, was the purchaser, and a very lucky one, for the horse was knocked down, to him for $41,000, which is certainly not much more than half the value of the animal.

It seems to be agreed that the special committees of both houses of Congress will unite in the recommendation that immigration shall be entirely suspended during the coming Summer. While this action is undoubtedly duo to the fear of cholera, it is unlikely that it would be adopted but for the agitation of the subject that has gone on for several years.

Reference has been made in the cable dispatches from London and Paris regarding the Panama Canal scandal to the probability that there will soon be made known a feature of the matter which will be of especial interest to Americans, as it will involve a banker, who is described as of "world-wide reputation, and as well known in New-York as in Paris."

The second New-Brighton (S.I.) assembly of the season was held at the Hotel Castleton, on Brighton Heights, last evening, and was one of the most successful ever given. Over 300 Staten Island society people were present, and a number of dinner parties were given before the ball.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Col. and Mrs. Norman G. Lieter this afternoon introduced their daughter to society. Hiss Lieter's friends had sent sifts of flowers which completely hid the upright piano from view and banked the mantel of the first parlor, in which the receiving party stood. The debutante stood beside bar mother, in a gown of white silk mull and valenciennes lace, carrying a large bouquet of maidenhair ferns and lilies of the valley.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day North Chicago sold at 278 @ 276, West Chicago at 211 1/4 @ 211 1/2. Chicago Brewing common sold at 36 3/4, and Milwaukee Brewing common at 33 1/4. Money, 5 @ 6 cent. Bank clearings, $19,138,073. New-York exchange, 250 premium.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Meriden, one of the strongholds of Connecticut Democracy, took a backward step to-day when it elected a majority of Republicans on the municipal ticket for the first time in six years. There has been dissension in the Democratic ranks in that city for some time, and to-day it exhibited itself in the 425 votes which were cast for the Populist candidates.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20 -- Despite the objections of those citizens to whom a completion of the work, according to present plans, means a transfer of their domiciles from Delaware to Pennsylvania soil, the first atone from which the new boundary line between the two States is to be run was yesterday pat in position.

William Easton dined well last evening. The result was that the sale of J.B. Hoggin's trotting-brod horses set for 7:30 last evening did not begin until an hour later. The crowd waited with ill-concealed impatience for the auctioneer to appear. When he arrived fun began, and the sale at once took on more of the character of a circus than a serious business affair.

Frank Valesh, the Deputy Commissioner of State Labor Statistics of Minnesota, who is in this city to investigate the sweating system, began his labors yesterday. At night he expressed himself as disgusted with what he saw.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Although the subject is an old one in dialectics, I have not seen this view of the trial of Dr. Briggs much ventilated.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 21 -- A large number of sporting men came to this city to-day expecting to witness the battle between Heavyweights Cattanach of this city and Doherty of Boston at the Metropole Club.

CULVERTON, Ga., Dec. 21 -- Mr. John Turner of Sins Sing, N.Y., senior member of the firm of Jonathan T. Turner's Sons, manufacturers of cottonigine and saws, which firm was establiehed in 1834, is now on a visit to this State. His presence recalls a curious story, which may not be known to his friends in New-York State.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 21 -- The important question of what shall be taught in the grammar schools is now receiving much attention in Cambridge. An interesting report on the subject has been made by a special committee, of which Dr. Albert Bushnell Hart, Professor of American History at Harvard College, is the Chairman.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 21 -- A searching investigation in this city fails to find any trace of Gen. Lostenas Rocha, the instructor at the National Military Academy at Chapultepec, although the Minister of Foreign Affairs and other officials of the Government yesterday asserted that the General was here.

Assistant Commissioner of Immigration O'Beirno declared yesterday that the report that at least one-half of the 1,100 Italians who recently arrived on the steamship Elysla were unnecessarily detained by him was inaccurate. This would be seen, he said, by the certificate of the Superintendent of the Registry Division and of Major Sansey, in charge of the Detention Department.

A statement answering the purposes of a prospectus was issued yesterday by the officers of the New-York and Brooklyn Railway Company, in whose behalf application was made Tuesday for a franchise from the Aldermen to authorize the construction of a tunnel under the East River, with a terminus at Spruce and Nassau Streets.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21 -- Atlanta to-day gave a hearty welcome to Vice President-elect Stevenson, who reached the city shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon. He declined to discuss politics, but concerning the South and the Administration he said:

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Dowager Duchess of Sutherland was defeated to-day in the attempt to gain possession of the estate known an Tittensor Chase, near Trentham, from the possession of which she has been debarred by the present Duke. The Dowager Duchess made an application to the Court of Chancery to have the Duke restrained from interfering with her possession of Tittensor Chase, and to-day a decision was announced refusing the application.

-- Of the eight gentlemen nominated to fill the vacant positions of the Board of Governors of the New-York Athletic Club six have accepted the nominations. They are J.H. Booth, W.R. Bassett, E.C. Roosevolt, T.L. Watson, J. Warren Fisher, and C. T. Wills. Favorable answers are also expected from the other two. J.F.C. Blackhurst of the outgoing board was unanimously nominated to serve two years more, but was obliged to decline, owing to business cares.

The Hoboken Council board last night elected a Mayor to succeed Edward R. Stanton, who has become Sheriff of Hudson County. President Erlenkoetter claimed the right to act as Mayor, but the ''bosses" had decreed otherwise.

The special committee of Manhattan Railway Directors, appointed by President George J. Gould to consider the subject of increasing the facilities of the elevated roads in this city, met in the office of the Chairman, J. Pierpont Morgan, yesterday afternoon. All of the members were present, including Samuel Sloan, Russell Sage, George Bliss, and R. M. Gallaway, with Mr. Gould as an ex-officio member.

The second dance of the class patronized by Mrs. Henri Braem took place at Sherry's last night. About one hundred and fifty were present. Mrs. Braem's class dances two cotillions, one before and the other after supper. This plan assures a prompt beginning and winding up of the dance. Supper was served last night at midnight.

The New-England Society of the City of Brooklyn last night celebrated the two hundred and seventy-second anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims -- that is, the anniversary according to the reckoning prevailing on the other side of the East River. The Brooklyn society celebrates on Dec. 21; the New-York body prefers Dec. 22.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- "If Canada has built and armed three vessels for service on the lakes as described by the officers of the Revenue Marina Service at Washington it amounts to a declaration of war," said Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles, to-day, alluding to the report that the Dominion has increased its armed force on the great lakes.

LAMPASAS, Mexico, Dec. 21 -- The famous Iguana mines near this city have again proved o bonanza. Ore has been found valued at from $2,000 to $3,000 a ton. These mines were originally worked by the Spaniards, and were abandoned in 1680.

The hospital Collection under the direction of the Saturday and Sunday Association is now fairly under way in the trades, upon the Exchanges, by the Woman's Auxillary, and by the Various other ways employed by the association for reaching the charitable public. Among the amounts reported by the General Treasurer, Charles Lanier, 17 Nassau Street, as received up to date, are the following:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 -- The farmers made it decidedly lively for Gov. Brown last week. Their association was in session here, and the veto of the Reassessment bill was the burden of the speeches and resolutions.
Over 2,000 persons of the poor class go crazy in New-York every year. To the average citizen this will seem to be an astonishing statement, but it is none the leas true.

After those trotting men who desired to establish, a speedway in Central Park, to the ruin of the Park as a public pleasure ground, had been defeated by an unexpected outbreak of public indignation, it was supposed that they had relinquished their purpose. But there are signs that they have not.

The Board of Education discussed for several hours last evening the report of the Committee on By-laws upon a resolution setting whether it was advisable to appoint teachers in night schools for good behavior and allow them to hold over from year to year, or to stick to the present method of appointing teachers for a season only.

The new building at 219 Sullivan Street, erected for the Industrial School of the Children's Aid Society in that section of the city, was formally opened and dedicated yesterday with appropriate exercises. The institution was completed last September at a cost of $90,000, the gift of Mrs. Joseph M. White and Miss M.W. Bruce of the Children's Aid Society.

As soon as the Congress adjourns to-morrow the Montana delegation in the Senate and the House and all the Montana contingent in Washington will "light out" for their State, and they will not return until after the election of a Senator to succeed Col. Sanders. There is one thing as certain as can be, and that is that Sanders will not come back to swell over a re-election.

Jacob Siedeman of 587 Lexington Avenue, this city, whose two boys were found in Brooklyn on Sunday and who declared that their names were Morris and Leo Levine, went to Brooklyn yesterday to get them. He called at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, where the boys had been sent, and produced photographs of them.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- The first game between Lasker and Martinez last night was scored by the former in true hurricane style. Martinez early in the opening could have won a pawn, but he wanted to avoid a troublesome attack. His line of play, however, subjected him nevertheless to a harassing attack, with nothing to compensate him. Lasker exploited his advantage with the utmost vigor, forcing a speedy win.

When Isidor Dreyfuss, a court reporter at Essex Market, went to Alderman "Silver Dollar" Smith, about two years ago and asked him for the hand of his daughter "Tillie" in marriage, "Silver Dollar" gave for an answer, "Well, Issie, she's talk'n about you all the time and I've no objection, but don't have the wedding until I say so."

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 21 -- The jury in the case of Elia Newton, the young girl whose body was found floating in East Chester Creek, near the Invermere Hotel, on the evening of Dec. 5, to-night rendered the following verdict:

The effects of Tuesday night's peculiar performance at a horse sale at Tattersalls were apparent last evening, when the sale or Mr. J. B. Haggin's trotting-bred stock was concluded. The attendance was very small, and well-Known buyers and breeders were conspicuous by their absence. The sale, instead of being a longdrawn-out farce, as on Tuesday, was rushed through as if Mr. Easton was anxious to get the job off his hands.

Judge Charles McLouth of Palmyra, State Engineer John Bogert, and President Evan Thomas of the Produce Exchange, the commission appointed by Gov. Flower to examine into the proposed supply ot water to the Erie Canal from the Genesee River and to report the result of its investigations to the Legislature, met in the President's room of the New-York Produce Exchange yesterday and spent considerable time listening to reports.

Wholesale liquor dealers of this city, representing $20,000,000 or more, yesterday decided to fight the Whisky Trust. This action was caused by the increase in the price of spirits. Since Dec. 4 the trust has advanced the price 15 cents a gallon, and it is rumored, that a further advance will be made to-day. Before Dec. 5 spirits sold for $1.23 par gallon.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 21 -- Something of a reign of terror prevails in many towns in this vicinity. It is due to acts of violence perpetrated by what seems to be an organized gang.

The suit of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company against Mrs. Honora Powers and others, in which it is expected that the facts about the ownership of 23,000 shares of stock held by "Tony " Barrett as trustee will be disclosed, was continued before Referee Horatio C. King in Brooklyn yesterday.

Frank Gately, a discharged employe of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Railroad, bought a new revolver on Sept. 19, went to the office of the company, and shot Denis Sullivan, the Superintendent, twice in the back. Mr. Sullivan lingered between life and death for a fortnight, but finally recovered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Nicaragua Canal bill, which has held the attention of the Foreign Relations Committee since the beginning of the session, has at last been completed, and was today favorably reported by its author, Senator Sharman, who gave notice in the Sonata that he would call it up at an early date and endeavor to secure prompt action upon it.

-- The big dress goods and clothing mills of F.A. Bachman Co. at Second and Library Streets, Phil, adelphia, were almost entirely destroyed yesterday afternoon by a fire which originated in the basment from spontaneous combustion. Loss, $235,000. Of this loss $165,000 represents the valuable machinery which filled the building and a considerable amount of finished goods and raw material.

Peter C. Kellogg finished the sale of the stock belonging to the estate of the late W.S. Hobart at the American Institute Building yesterday, twenty-two animals selling for a total of $82,450, which, added to the $125,410 obtained for the forty-four animals sold on Tuesday, makes a total of $207,860, an average for the sixty-six head of $3,149, on the whole a most satisfactory showing.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- The Dutchess County Court room was crowded beyond its capacity to-day when the case of Clinton W. Chapp, under indictment for having written obscene letters to Mrs. Elizabeth Smith of Wappinger's Falls was called. Both Mr. Clapp and Mrs. Smith are prominent in the village, and are loading members of the Baptist Church there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- The tramp steamer Montserrat, which recently carried a cargo of Gilbert Islanders to the Guatemala coffee plantations, has now been bought by the slave dealers, and will be used to transport by the wholesale these poor ignorant South Sea islanders to the unhealthy coffee plantations of Central America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Those who were disposed to accept as truthful the statements of Republicans at the beginning of this session of Congress, that no attempt would be made by the Republican Senators to prevent the Democrats organizing the next Senate, are beginning to see how wide of the truth such statements were.

ST. JOSEPH, Mc., Dec. 21 -- In the United States court to-day Judge Parker sentenced George W. Howell, general manager of the lumber firm of Howell, Jewett Co., and Edward Tibbetts, an employe of the firm, to eighteen months at hard labor in the Jefferson City Penitentiary and to pay a fine of $2,000.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 21 -- Gov. Brown to-day pardoned Henry Spencer, a life prisoner in the Maryland Penitentiary for murder. The pardon is conditional upon Spencer leaving Maryland.

Max and Solomon Joseph were arrested yesterday by Deputy Sheriff Gifford on an order of arrest issued by Judge Lawrance of the Supreme Court in a suit brought by C.B. Richards Co. to recover $4,437.50. They were held in $5,000 ball each, and, being unable to furnish it, were taken to Ludlow Street Jail.
The following is the statement in full which was made by Mr. Michael Coleman, formerly President of the Department of Taxes, before the joint Legislative Committee at Tuesday's session:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- It is not unlikely that there will be a renewed effort, during this session of Congress, to secure authority for the construction of a sixteen-inch breech-loading rifle for the navy. It will be intended merely for experimental purposes, as thero is no new ship in contemplation which would or could carry this tremendous weapon.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 21 -- Reports from all parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia show that the snowstorm was general to-day, though the temperature has not gone below 20 above zero in Western Oregon. Snow has fallen to a depth of from five to ten inches in the valleys. Telegraph and telephone companies have experienced considerable trouble south of here because of snow breaking down wires and poles.

Miss Antoinette E. Pinchot was married yesterday to the Hon. Alan Johnstone of England Instead of taking place in St. George's Church as originally intended, the ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James W. Pinchot of Gramercy Park. The house was decorated simply, but effectively, with palms and banks of cut roses.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21 -- C.C. Antoine, the colored Lieutenant Governor under William Pitt Kellogg, from 1872 to 1876, has had a hard-fought but successful battle with the criminal law. Last April Antoine sold a piece of property to J.N. Woltson, a notary public. Antoine represented that the property was worth $500 and that it was free from incumbrances except for a two-hundred and fifty-dollar mortgage.

A remarkable exhibition of designs for fabrics and wall paper was opened yesterday by the New-York School of Applied Design for Women at its house, 200 West Twenty-third Street. It consisted of a showing of the work completed the first two months of the school's existence. In this time about 130 pupils have received instruction.

That the revival of "As You Like It" at Daly's was timely was amply proved by the large audience, composed principally of women, that attended the first matinee of the play, yesterday afternoon. In spite of the attractions of shopping, which, injure the theatres so seriously every season the week before Christmas, the house was well filled and the audience was an unusually enthusiastic one for a matinee.

WESTERLY, R.I., Dec. 21 -- Marvelous and successful, and yet unsuccessful, attempts have been made by Fish Hatcher Ernest Rounseville of the East Freetown (Mass.) hatcheries, not far from here, to raise two-headed trout. The Freetown hatcheries are in the secluded and romantic Sampson Pond locality and are owned by a company of Lynn (Mass.) capitalists.

Two interesting experiments were made last night at the experimental station of the lighthouse Board at Tompkinsville, S.I., by Major David P. Heap and Capt W.S. Schley. One was with a new light, to be placed on Hallet's Point, in Hell Gate, on Dec. 31.

The two concerts given at Music Hall by Mme. Lineff and her Russian choir -- one last Saturday night and another last night -- were by all means the most remarkable, interesting, and instructive musical entertainments given in this city this season, and they will remain among the choicest memories of those to whom music is something higher than a mere concourse of sweet sounds.

Gov. FLOWER'S response to the New-York Bar Association's protest is a public statement that he will "at the proper time appoint the Hon. ISAAC IL MAYNARD Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals in the place of Judge ANDREWS, who on Jan. 1 will become Chief Judge." Much as this insensibility to the opinion of the bar and to public sentiment is to be deplored, it was to be expected.

A score or more members of the New-York City Association of Union ex-Prisoners of War met at the Colonnade Cafe last night for the twelfth anniversary dinner of the organization. Gen. Alexander Shaler, President of the association, presided. Informal remarks and personal reminiscences of the war were made the features of the evening.

Petitions continue to pour in upon Congress against the nefarious New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill. No bill introduced in the Senate or House ever met with such opposition as that which is directed against this one. To-day a committee of the Associated Trades of NewYork City came to Washington and presented the following protest against the Green-Swan job.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The excitement over the Panama scandals is to-day greater than ever, and the wildest reports are afloat of Monarchist plots and coming arrests. It is asserted that Herz has been in communication in London with agents of the Count of Paris and that the exposure of the Thierree checks is directly attributable to Royalist influence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Rev. Father T.J. Ducey came to Washington this evening and placed his name on the Arlington register. After he had removed the stains of travel and dined, he walked out on Vermont Avenue, and was seen no more by the hotel people until a late hour.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 21 -- Bishop O'Hara of the Scranton Diocese celebrated his golden jubilee as priest and his silver jubilee as Bishop in St. Peter's Cathedral to-day, in the presence of a brilliant assemblage, which included Cardinal Gibbons, Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia, and Bishops Keane of the Catholic University at Washington, McDonnell of Brooklyn, Mullen of Erie, McGovern of Harrisburg, Horstmann of Cleveland, and about 300 priests.

Farmers in different parts of the country have been sending letters to correspondents in this city complaining that butter, veal, and other provisions which they had sent to be sold on commission to F.H. Brock Co., who some timo ago did business at 123 Warren Street, had not been paid for, and asking the correspondents to collect the money for them or to refer them to some lawyers hero to enforce payment.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21 -- Georgia will go back to the old system of collecting taxes, every man placing his own valuation on his property. Of the dozen or more bills to repeal the Board of Tax Equalization statute one passed both, branches and has become a law.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Dec. 21 -- The Whittier memorial services under the auspices of a committee appointed, by the City Council were held in the City Hall this afternoon, and were attended by a great gathering of distinguished men and women.

The peddlers who have erected stands on the sidewalks, and who yell in the cars of the crowds who are passing by from early morning until late at night, have to pattribute to the storekeepers in front of whoso business places they stand.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 21 -- At to-day's session of the Connecticut Agricultural Society resolutions were adopted by a large majority requesting the Connecticut Senators in Washington to support the Anti-Option bill as a measure calculated "to greatly advance the agricultural and legitimate business interests or our country by preventing speculation and gambling in the staple products of life."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 22. -- Charles A. Harden, the Adams Express messenger, suspected of tampering with the package of $35,000 sent from New-York to Galveston, via Cincinnati, reported for duty to-night to go on his regular run from hero to Nashville. He did not sleep a this regular place last night.

The graduates of Hamilton College were out in force last night to greet the new President of the college, the Rev. Dr. Melanothon W. Stryker, at the annual dinner of the New-York Alumni Association, at the Hoffman House. The Rev. George W. Hubbell of the class of '67, President of the association, presided, and President Stryker sat at his right.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22. -- It is rumored in National Guard circles that a determined effort is to be made at the next session of the Legislature to abolish the office of Division Commander, now held by Major Gen. Plume of Newark, and to have the Adjutant General instead transmit all orders to the Brigade Commanders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The Rev. H.H. George, General Field Agent of the American Sabbath Union, Col. Shepard President, called upon Secretary Foster at the Treasury this afternoon in some alarm to treat the news to Mr. Foster that an injunction had been applied for in Chicago to prevent the closing of Jackson Park, in which the World's Fair is to be held, on Sunday.

The Directors of three of the Vanderbilt railroads met in their respective offices inline Grand Central Station yesterday, received the financial statements for the month, of December, and declared semi-annual dividends.

Among the letters on national quarantine re- ceived by the Board of Trade and Transporta- tion is one from Benjamin Lee, Secretary of the State Board of Health of Pennsylvania, who says, among other things:

Commissioners Charles W. Dayton, James H. Haslin, Walter Katte, John Fox, and George W. Birdsall, members of the Board for the Park Avenue Improvement, met at 32 Park Avenue yeaterday afternoon to receive bids and esti- mates for the building of foundations, brick pedestals, and the setting of base castings for an elevated structure in Park Avenue between One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and the Har- lem River.

A preliminary trial preparatory to the offi- cial tests of the Gordon disappearing gun carriage was begun at the Government proving grounds at Sandy Hook Wednesday. A broken crosshead, however, put an end to the tests after the first shot. The new castings that will have to be made and put in place before the trial can go on will necessitate a delay of from two to three weeks.

Officers of the Treasury Department ordered to inspect the United States revenue steamer Johnson report that fully $7,000 worth of re- pairs is needed upon that ship to enable her to be placed in commission in May. The Johnson is laid up "in ordinary" at Milwaukee, Wis. The vessel's cruising ground embraces Lakes Michigan and Superior.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- An adjourned special meeting of the Ocean Grove Camp Meet- ing Association was held to-day in the office of the association here. The principal business of the meeting was to consider the building of a new auditorium. Plans submitted are for a building of wood, glass, and iron, 150 by 175, wita a turtle-shaped roof, making a sounding board.

Edward W. Hallinger, the murderer of his mistress, was hanged in the Hudson County Jail, on Jersey City Heights, soon after 10 o'clock yesterday morning. There was still some doubt as to whether Lawyer Peshal, who was chasing about the country trying to get a writ of error and stay, would not succeed for the fourth time in obtaining a respite at the last moment.

At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Berkeley Athletic Association yesterday the letter written by Dr. White to John M. Bowers on Dec. 12 was the principal subject of discussion. In this letter Dr. White offered to lease the property of the athletic association for two consecutive years, paying the interest on loans, taxes, and insurance, besides a rental equivalent to 4 per cent on the par value of the stock. $197,500.
THE HAGUE, Dec. 22. -- The Secretary of the Dutch Commission for the Chicago Exhibition said to-day:

Under an order issued by Judge Pratt to compel Clark, Ward Co., bankers at 70 Broadway, to appear before a referee and explain their possession of securities amounting to $300,000, which, it is alleged, were deposited with them by Edward M. Field of Field, Lindley, Wiechers Co. just before the failure of his firm, there was a bearing yesterday before Levi A. Fuller of 261 Broadway.
Among the articles to be deposited in the cornerstone of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on next Tuesday is a fragment of brick bearing on a silver plate the following inscription:

An amateur dramatic entertainment was given in the new Music Hall at Sailors' Snug Harbor, S.L, last evening, with the parts in the plays sustained by leaders in the younger set in Staten Island society. The performance was given for the entertainment of the inmates of the Harbor, and the aged sailors filled the parquet floor.

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- The will of Asaph Churchill, late of Milton, a leading and prominent lawyer of the Norfolk and Suffolk bars, has been probated at Dedham. In it he says: "Greatly fearing the influence in matters of property of the Church and clergy of the sect to which my youngest daughter, Harriet B. Churchill, has become attached, I make some restrictions and special provisions in my will."

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Some sixty members of the New-England Society of Orange assembled at Upper Music Hall to-night to discuss the annual dinner of the society given in celebration of Forefathers' Day.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 22. -- Fifteen thousand persons paraded to-day in commemoration of Bishop O'Hara's golden jubilee. In it were marching clubs from every city in the diocese. The column was reviewed by Cardinal Gibbons, Archbishop Ryan, and the visiting Bishops and clergy. Bishop O'Hara received a cablegram conveying the Papal blessing.

The great shopping thoroughfares of the city were thronged with, sightseers and purchasers of holiday gifts last night, despite the nipping air. Most of the large business houses, and for that matter the small ones too, were in holiday dress and their show windows were ablaze with light, presenting a dazzling, bewildering array of attractions calculated to charm money from the pockets of even the most parsimonious.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Gen. Felix Gustave Saussier, the Military Governor of Paris and veteran of service in the Crimea, Italy, Mexico, and Africa, refused to act as an arbitrator between M. Deroulede and M. Clemenceau, and no resource was left but for the two Deputies to meet each other upon the field of honor.

VIENNA, Dec. 22. -- A serious revolt occurred to-day in the prison at Znalm, a town of over 10,000 inhabitants, forty-seven miles northwest of this city. A woman prisoner who was allowed the freedom of the corridors suddenly became hysterical while on the top floor of the building, and with a terrible shriek threw herself over the ran guarding the opening which extends from the ground floor.

Jonn R. Nugent, member of the Republican State Committee, member of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, and Republican leader of the Tenth Assembly District, left the Republican Party yesterday and went into Tammany Hall.

Ex-Register John Reilly, the Tammany leader of the new Tenth District, and Leader James P. Keating of the new Fourteenth District have been exchanging courtesies. Under the old reapportionment Mr. Reilly was leader of the Fourteenth District and Mr. Seating of the Eighteenth.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Cook of Elwood, L.I., formerly of Brooklyn, have boon married eight or nine years. Mrs. Cook was formerly Mrs. George H. Gasking. She secured a divorce from Gasking after he had left her because of Cook's attentions to her.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 22. -- If the first act of the Democratic Congress is to abolish the office of Federal Supervisor of Elections, the hearty thanks of the Democrats of Rhode Island will be extended to the statesmen. Up to to-day, quietness reigned in political circles here, but Chief Supervisor Blodgett has started a discussion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The joint Committee on Immigration to-day found itself unable to agree upon a measure, and so decided to report two bills -- one to the House and the other to the Senate. That reported to the House will be the bill prepared by Mr. Stump, (Dem., Md.,) and the one presented to the Senate will be Senator Chandler's bill, which suspends all immigration for one year.

Fire raised havoc yesterday forenoon in the residence of Mrs. Lloyd Aspinwall, at 106 East Twentieth Street. It was all so sudden and swift that Mr. Aspinwall and two maid servants had narrow and thrilling escapes from death.

The exposure in THE TIMES of yestarday of the queer dealings of the produce firm of F.H. Brook Co., which suddenly shut down about a couple of months ago without notifying their creditors and then started in business again under the name of John H. Johnson, has given much satisfaction to reputable commission merchants.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Dr. Herz, whose conneetion with the Panama scandal in Paris is causing such a sensation, was once a resident of this city, having come here just prior to the big fire.

The two White Star steamships which were upon the ocean last week had similar experiences with Atlantic gales. According to the cable reports the Majestic tumbled her way eastward through seas as stormy as any even encountered by a mariner. Her sister ship, the Teutonic, westward bound, had very much the same experience.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22.-- Hog product was lower in sympathy with the decline in hogs, and the improve- ment it grain reflected little strength into this mar- ket. There was a good deal of selling of long stuff bought the day before on the theory that the com- bine was to put the price up, and these offerings added to the feeling of depression. Receipts of products were large and shipments free.

The annual reports of the Board of Charities of this State for the last twelve years have contained much valuable information concerning the reception of undesirable immigrants in this country and have indicated that the national authorities might procure from the board much useful testimony in addition to that which is published in the reports.

The famous heresy trial of Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary is ended, except for the finding of a verdict. At the session yesterday, held in the old Sootch Presbytarian Church, Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, the Prosecuting Committee finished the long closing argument which the Rev. Joseph J. Lampe had prepared.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dee. 22. -- Reports re- ceived to-night from the upper Hudson any that the river is freezing at all points and that the end of navigation is close at hand. No boats will be able to get through to-morrow. Ferry boats at Hudson, Catskill, and Rhinebeck are still running, bat have a hard time of it.

The exhibition at the new building of the American Fine Art Society deserves a longer life than twenty days, not alone because of the Retrospective show of paintings made by the Society of American Artists. That show, while by no means as fine as would have been possible had more time existed to hunt up the very best work of members, is nevertheless quite the best the society has made.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- Among the various amendments to the tax laws of the State under course of development in the hands of the Special Tax Commission, which will make its report at the coming session of the Legislature, is one which will declare that all deposits in State Savings Banks are subject to taxation the same as all other personal property.

The McGarrahan bill had the attention of the Senate for half the time that to-day's session lasted, and Mr. Hunton (Dem., Va.,) closed his three days' speech in its favor. Several Senators intend to speak in opposition, and on that account a suggestion to have a day and hour fixed for voting on it after the holidays did not meet with favor.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- To-day it is the Bonapartists that are stepping to the front to take advantage of the difficulties of the republic. The activity of the Royalists aroused the jealousy of the Imperialist leaders, and at a secret conclave they drafted a, manifesto, addressed to the people of France, urging them to recall the house of Bonaparte to the throne.

CHICORA, Penn., Dec. 22. -- This town has four victims of the poisoners who did business at Homestead -- L.H. Craig, George Amy, H.B. Thompson, and George North. Each, of these men had good paying positions in the mill, but they were among the first to be stricken with the mysterious malady, which they say has sent more men to their graves than the general public dreams of.

" WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- To-day has been an uneventful one for Mr. Blaine," said Dr. Johnston at 9:30 o'clock this evening when met at the door of the Blaine residence. "I have just come from his bedside and found him holding his own. The fact that he does not seem to lose strength is encouraging. He converses whenever permitted; in fact, is inclined to talk too much for his own good.

Prof. Gaetano Russo, the soulptor of the Columbus Monument which the patriotism of New-York's Italian citizens recently erected at Fifty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue, was accorded the distinction of a banquet at Webster Hall last night. The programme announced that it was designed to be a popular affair. It was easily that, and more.

The special legislative Committee on Taxation devoted a good portion of its time at yester- day's session to a discussion of taxes in the agricultural districts of the State. Senator McClelland, the Chairman, took an active part in conducting the examination, and the witnesses were men who had had experience in the State rather than in the New-York City Tax Depart- ment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- With the amendments to the Inter-State Commerce act proposed by Senator Cullom, (Rep., Ill.,) that law will not, in the estimation its friends, be subject to the derision of Dr. Depew. It is provided by the principal amendment that it shall be lawful for common carriers to enter into traffic arrangements with each other to establish and maintain just and reasonable rates and to prevent unjust discrimination.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- The failure of the Democratic State Committee to nominate a straightout Democrat for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals last Fall gave offense to a great many dyed-in-the-wool Democrats. There are those Democrats who boast of having never voted for anything but a Democrat, and who would as soon think of cutting off a hand as to cast a vote for any candidate but a Democrat.

Controller MYERS thinks that the newspapers have been too critical about the condition of the streets, and says that everything cannot be done in a single night. Well, it is a good many nights since the newspapers began to be critical and to contend for clean streets. It is a number of months since the new system of cleaning was authorized, and it is not carried into full effect yet.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, the court of final resort in customs cases, de- cided yesterday that the airy appurtenances which Agnes Huntington brought to this country over a year ago to clothe her chorus troupe are actually "tools of trade," and the duty which the opera singer paid under protest will be refunded to her.

The first of the series of Winter sales of trotting-bred horses was brought to a close at the American Institute Building yesterday afternoon. The attendance was small, for there was nothing in the list of offerings that would bring out a general crowd, and so the man who were in search of stock had a good opportunity to examine the horses that were offered without being crowded and troubled by curiosity seekers.
LAREDO, Texas, Dec. 22. -- It is reported here that Gen. Estrad, a prominent Mexican officer stationed near Mier, is missing from his post, and he is thought to be with the revolutionists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Col. Robert Neville, who slapped Mr. S.S. Holland in the face at the Madison Square Garden and was fined for that misdemeanor by a Police Justice, has, according to the Evening News, been reprimanded and suspended for two weeks by the Board of Governors of the Metropolitan Club of this city. It says: ...

That ex-Senator Michael C. Murphy is not only to be made leader of the First Assembly District, to succeed Additional Surrogate-elect Frank T. Fitzgerald, but is also to be appointed Police Justice in place of Patrick Gavan Duffy, whose term is now holding ever, is the belief of many of the politicians in the First District.

Secretary of the Navy Tracy is expected to render decisions on the Meeker and Sullivan court-martial cases, now before him, either today or to-morrow, In the opinion of those in a position to know the findings of the Meeker case will be set aside, and the sentence imposed on Paymaster Sullivan considerably reduced.

HAMBURG, Dec. 22. -- It was thought that the extraordinary measures taken by the authorities would prevent another outbreak of cholera in the Spring, but the indications now point to the recurrence of the disease in an epidemic form when warm weather sets in. Several cases of the Asiatic type of the disease have occurred recently, and the outlook is serious.

Louis Reilly, a boy of seven years, was knocked down by trolley car No. 307 of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Road yesterday afternoon, run over, and instantly killed. He was a son of Paul G. Reilly, a salesman for Browning, King Co., and lived at 57 Wil- loughby Street, Brooklyn.

Lieut. Col. James Moron has written a communication giving his version of the trouble in the Sixty-ninth Regiment growing out of the substitution of himself in place of Gen. McMahon as presiding officer at the dinner to Col. Cavanagh. He disclaims having insisted upon presiding by virtue of his being the ranking officer of the regiment.

The charges made before Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court, touching the conduct of Lawyer John K. Van Ness and Robert Lewis Humphreys in the foreclosure sale of the prop- erty at 319 Tenth Avenue were dwelt on briefly in an opinion handed down yesterday by Judge Ingraham. In granting the motion made by Henry White, representing Melvin Stephens, the plaintiff in the foreclosure suit, to nave the purchaser, James Wilson, compelled to take title.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- The loss during the past season of the three lake steamers Western Reserve, Gilcher, and Great Western is still serving as a damper on lake marine construc- tion work for the Winter. The three ships were built at Cleveland, Ohio, the greatest ship- building port on the lakes, and in the case of each ship the loss is now looked upon as having resulted from the craft breaking in two.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- Copies of the schemata presented by Mgr. Satolli, apostolic delegate to the United States, to the congress of American Archbishops as the bases of their deliberations on the subject of the settlement of the school questions and the imparting of religious education have been received here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

There could be no better illustration of the endless perplexities of the system of taxing personal property than the differences of opinion that prevail among those who advocate it. Hardly any two of them agree as to what should be done to make it effective. Most of them, while ostensibly contending for equality, would violate some of the plainest principles of justice.
Dr. Edward Everett Hale of Boston responded to the toast, "Forefathers' Day," saying in part:

The near approach of the session of the Legis- lature at which a Senator is to be selected has aroused new interest in the topic among Kings County politicians, and they were busy yester- day discussing the action of Hugh McLauehlin in notifying the local Senators and Assembly- men that they would be required to hold a cau- cus early next week, probably on Tuesday or Wednesday night.

Mr. Daniel McKeever, who is Secretary of the Importers' League and a member of the special committee of the Chamber of Commerce appointed to report as to the workings of the Ad- ministrative act and suggest necessary amendments, and who has made a careful study of the bill from its start, said yesterday to a TIMES re- porter:

The Agricultural Society of Connecticut has adopted resolutions calling upon the Senators of that State to support the Anti-Option bill as a measure calculated "to greatly advance the agricultural and legitimate business interests of our country by preventing speculation and gambling in the staple products of life."

When the Board of Apportionment refused yesterday to transfer more than $6,000 from unexpended balances to the credit of the Fire Department, its Commissioners met at their headquarters, and on motion of President Purroy passed those resolutions:

HONOLULU, Dec. 15. -- The new Ministry is now experiencing some trouble with the various political factions. On Dec. 8, just after the steamer Australia left port, a bill to authorize the Ministers to contract a national loan in the sum of $200,000 for the commencement of a railroad on the island of Hawaii, near the port of Hilo, came up for consideration.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Mrs. Lillie Langtry is rather better and the fever from which she is suffering has subsided sufficiently to allow her to sleep. Her servants were kept busy answering the messages of inquiry regarding her which have been received from many distinguished persons, including, it is reported, the Prince of Wales through his private secretary.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Gov. Flower's announcement yesterday that he would reappoint the discredited Isaac H. Maynard to the Court of Appeals in place of Judge Andrews, who on Jan. 1 becomes Chief Justice, is regarded here with astonishment in the light of certain statements made by Mr. Flower soon after he had designated the purloiner of election returns as a member of the court of last resort.
