The Iron Age of the 22dinst. reports the sale of 10,000 tons of foreign rails to be delivered at Seattle for use on the Pacific coast.

A number of New-York men are interested in the formation of a company for the purpose of making extensive improvements in the dockago facilities of Buffalo. Although much has been done within the past ten years to increase the capacity of that important Lake Erie shipping port, a great deal more must be done before the Buffalo harbor can be said to be adequate to the existing commercial needs.

From the Utica Observer. In a diary kept by one of the surveyors engaged in the surrey of the Holland Land Company's purchase at the very beginning of this century an entry occurs to the effect that near the headwaters of the Allegany River, in this State, was a spring upon the water from which, when conducted into shallow pools, would collect quantities of oil.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Gov. Flower, who is spending the Christmas holidays in this city, to-day issued a pardon and restored to full citizenship Cumberland G. White, who was recently sentenced to two years' imprisonment on Blackwell's Island. Mr. White was for many years a member of the New-York Stock Exchange.

When the New-York Jockey Club was first organized, invitations to join it were sent out broadcast and with little discrimination, as the then Secretary, Mr. Kock, had but little idea of the value of some club memberships in this city and the invitations got into the hands of men that were not fitted for membership in such a club as it was proposed to make of this one.

Those patients in the German Hospital, Seventy-seventh Street and Fourth Avenue, who were not too sick to leave their cots were treated to an excellent musical and literary entertainment yesterday in honor of the Christmas festival. The Ladies' Aid Society of the hospital determined some weeks ago that the coming Christmas Day should he memorable in the lives of the unfortunate sick who were under its care.

From the San Francisco Examiner, Dec. 19. A number of members of the Tamalpais Sporting Club went over to their preserves on the great Throckmorton estate in Marin County yesterday. This place is thronged with game, so that it is even better sport than the Country Club's domain. Among the members who went on horseback were Dr. William John Berg and several friends.

EDINBURGH, Dec. 26. -- A skating party broke through the Ice on Loch An Eilan, near Inverness, this afternoon. Several young women and three officers of the Cameron Highlanders, who were in the party, were plunged into the water. The women were rescued by their escorts.

Edward B. Ires, First lieutenant and Assistant Signal Officer commanding the Signal and Telegraph Corps of the First Brigade, has issued "Order No. 15," announcing to the command the death of Commissioner Gallup, who was the Signal Officer of the corps, and requesting that all members of the corps who can do so shall attend the funeral at Grace Church this morning at 9:30 o'clock.

From the Philadelphia Press, (Rep.,) Dec. 26 The situation as to the United-States Sonatorship, briefly stated, is this: The friends of Senator Quay concede twelve votes in Allegheny to John Dalzell. The number may be greater, but we take the Quay figures, which were given in the Record on Saturday, as entirely safe and moderate.

An audience that recalled the days of the Kendals, so numerous was it, and so noticeable was its social grandeur, gathered at the Star Theatre last evening and welcomed with a cordiality no doubt Bin core the appearance here of Mrs. Minna Gale-Haynes as a star. She bad chosen Knowles's "Hunchback" in which to try the metropolitan fates.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 26. -- On the 9th of July last the National Council of Education, a department of the National Education Association, then in session in Saratoga, adopted the following resolutions:

Gay Hill (Texas) Utter to the Galveston-News. The recent hailstorm near Gay Hill occurred about 4:30 P.M. Tuesday, 6th inst About 2 P.M. heavy clouds appeared in the west, and as they slowly approached, a roaring sound was beard, such as usually indicates a coming ballstorm. Lightning, accompanied by distant' thunder, suggested an unusual storm.

Eladia Rubria, the elderly and well-connected woman arrested, on Saturday afternoon for shoplifting in Ehrich Brothers' store and arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court Sanday morning and held in lack of $500 bail, was bailed out yesterday morning.

Dr. Paul Gibior, in a paper read before the meeting of the Modioal Society of the County of New-York last night at 17 West Forty-third Street, discussed a new treatment for epilepsy. In the opinion of the doctor the profession is approaching a new field in therapeutics generally, which promises good and lasting results.

The members of the Young Men's Institute, connected with the Bowery Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, entertained each other and crowds of their friends yesterday afternoon and evening with a Christmas oelebration, which began at 9 o'clock in the morning and lasted until 10 o'clock at night.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 26. -- William J. Leary and George Jennines started with a horse and buggy this morning to go on a gunning expedition near Long Pond, Freetown, some ten miles away. On the way they stopped at several saloons and Leary became badly intoxicated.

The North Atlantic at this season of the year is not a region that conscientious mariners would be likely to recommend to persons not fond of excitement. Swept by wintry gales, that turbulent stretch of water is generally a locality to be avoided during the mouth of December by persons who have a preference for a quiet life, but this December the weather along the transatlantic steam line has out-Decembered December.

The ferryboat Fanvrood, belonging to the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, dashed with full speed Into her slip at the foot of Liberty Street, North River, at 12:15 o'clock yesterday morning. She orasned into the bridge with a big boom. The bridge was shored with great force against the platform of the ferry house and the platform was pushed nearly two feet into West Street.

Senator HANSBROUGH of North Dakota may not be entirely right in his prediction that Republican Senators in the next Congress will let the Democrats have their way in regard to tariff legislation, but ho is correct in his opinion that a national Quarantine should be adopted, and very promptly.

To the Editor of the New York Times: An article in your last Sunday's issue, which was evidently written by some one who was uninformed as to the facts, does the class of '83, United States Naval Academy, much injustice.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The Matin to-day says that M. Antonin Proust, one of the members of the Chamber of Deputies, who is threatened with prosecution because of his connection with the Panama scandal, is suffering from congestion of the brain. The paper adds that his family refuses to give any information regarding his condition.

Henry Rood, a German sailor, and Maria Bedley, a Swedish woman, were found unconscious and barely alive in the room of the latter at 88 Cherry Street yesterday afternoon. The room was full of gas which was pouring from an unlighted jet.

If Congress does not increase the number of cadets at the Military Academy or decrease the number of Second Lieutenants in the army-neither of which propositions, though both have been made, is likely to be carried out at present-the enlisted men may henceforth rejoice in the prospect of trying for commissions under the new rules.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 26. -- The law and the labor organizations have been after the violators of the Sunday law for some weeks past, and there are likely to be some very heavy payments to mollify outraged justice. During the last administration Mayor Shakespeare allowed the law to be disregarded, as working only hardship upon the poor dealers, as the saloons found a way to get around the law.

The seven-hundred, and-odd children of the House of Refuge had a grand time in celebration of Santa Claus's annual visit to Randall's Island yesterday. A big Christmas dinner and a Christmas tree with a present for everybody make a powerful combination to produce joy in the youthful mind, and the minds of the boys and girls at the Refuge certainly proved very fertile in this respect.

Dr. C.W. Aby, manager of Frederick Gebhard's Gnenoo stud farm in California, arrived in this city on Saturday for consultation with his employer and the trainer of the Gebhard horses, Frank McCabe. They are now at work preparing the entries for the stakes that close this and next month.

Criticisms of the dog-in-the-manger policy of W.R. Allen, owner of Kremlin and President of the American Register Association, which has announced its intention of refusing to accept the 2:07 1/2 record of Stamboul while accepting the 2:07 3/4 of Kremlin, made at Nashville, have apparently stirred up Mr. Allen, for he has announced through his organ in this city that his horse Kremlin will be prepared "to meet any trotting stallion on earth" next season.

New-Yorte didn't celebrate the 26th of December Christmas, yesterday, in a boisterous manner. On the streets one might have supposed it was Sunday, except at the time when crowds were wending their way to the theatres, and later, when they hastened from the theatres to the elevated railroad stations.

WILMINGTON, Ohio, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Clara Plummer, wife of George Pluramor, committed suicide in her room on South Street just as the bells were ringing out Christmas Day. Sue had been married fourteen years, and was the mother of three children. Domestic trouble caused her to separate from her husband, bat the pair wore reunited and came to live on a farm at Bloomington, near this place.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 26. -- John Harvey, the naval architect, arrived here from New-York two days ago and concluded negotiations for the sale of the fast and handsome British schooner yacht Miranda, laid up at Noank, near here, to Mr. Coleman of San Francisco. Mr. Harvey, who was the designer and builder of this famous craft, found her as sound as a nut.

NEVADA, Mo., Dec. 26. -- The Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway and the Kansas City, Nevada and Fort Smith are engaged in a lively crossing war, which threatens to result seriously. The seat of war is twelve miles west of here, "where the Kansas City Road seeks to build a crossing over the Missouri, Kansas and Texas tracks.

The First Battery's Cadet Company had Us second annual mounted battery, sabre, and broadsword drill last evening at Wendel's Assembly Rooms, West Forty-fourth, Street. There are fifty boys in the company, and forty of them have uniforms, and also lour small brass cannon with miniature caissons, which are drawn by hand.

The management of the Brooklyn Bridge has done a thing which has won for it the gratitude of all those who are accustomed to cross the bridge after 1 o'clock in the morning, the hour at which locomotives begin to draw the trains. The cause for thankfulness is the provision of warm, comfortable cars in which to stay while waiting for train time.

From the Railroad Gazette. It is stated in a Philadelphia paper that the Pennsylvania Railroad has issued notices to be placed in prominent positions in all the stations within a radius of twenty-five miles of Philadelphia, requesting passengers to board and alight from all trains as expeditiously as possible. The reason for this, it is said, is that it is very hard, under existing circumstances, to maintain the schedules to the exact minute.

Considerable interest attaches to the action to be taken this afternoon by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in regard to the threatened resignation of School Commissioner Robert Maclay, Chairman of the Committee on Buildings of the Board of Education. He asked last Friday for $92,382 for "repairs and changes on ninety-eight buildings," and waxed very indignant when the Board of Estimate and Apportionment declined to grant the full amount.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- A serious wreck occurred at Pencoyd Station, a short distance from this city, on the main line of the Reading Railroad, about 1:30 this afternoon, which resulted in the injuring of an engineer, fireman, and several passengers, none of whom, however, was seriously hurt.

There's a man over in Brooklyn who spends ten hours a day -- so it is said -- watching the movement of trains on that part of the Kings County Elevated Road between the bridge station and Fulton Ferry. He is a reminder of a man once well known along the New-England circus circuit, who persisted in following a certain menagerie from town to town so that he might see the elephant kill his keeper.

Only the early approach of a new election, when the matter can be straightened out by the people at the polls, saves Hoboken from being torn by the strife of two claimants to her Mayoralty. The resignation of Mayor Stanton to accept the Shrievalty of the county, made vacant by the death of Sheriff McPhillips, brought about a series of complications that have not yet been satisfactorily adjusted.

HAMBURG, Dec. 26. -- Prince Bismarck celebrated Christmas Eve with his family at Friedrichsruh. The Christmas tree, on which all the presents were hung, was a gift from a farmer whoso land joins the Prince's estate. The Prince's presents from abroad were opened by the Princess and hung by her upon the tree without his having seen them.

From the Sun Francisco Examiner, Dec. 19. Close upon the adoption of the Unitarian faith by the Rev. J. Herndon Garnett of San Jose comes the announcement that two Congregational ministers from Oakland have renounced their creed and are now preaching the Unitarian beliefs throughout the State.

Alice, the Central Park lioness which gave birth to a whelp last Friday night, proved herself again an unnatural mother, and yesterday morning Superintendent Burns decided to take the baby lion away from her and try to bring it up himself. Ever since the whelp was born Alice has seemed to regard the little stranger with a sort of apathetic curiosity.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- The North Shrewsbury River Ice Yacht Club held its first race of the season this afternoon. There was a big crowd of people on the ice. The weather was all that could be desired. A fresh, crisp wind blew from over the hills of Middletown, and the ice was as hard as flint. There were several patches of snow, but it was not over an inch deep.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Attorney General Miller is somewhat disturbed, by the report that "Bill" Dalton, the notorious outlaw, has been appointed a United States Deputy Marshal at Coffeyville, Kan. He said to-day that the first intimation he had received in regard to the matter was when Senator Vest alluded to it in his speech in the Senate last week.
The following clergymen participated in the ceremonies, robed and occupying seats in the chancel:

The first annual chess tournament between the colleges of Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton commenced to-day at Berkeley School, 20 West Forty-fourth Street. A reception was held at the armory, the use of which was expressly tendered to the committee by the Head Master, Dr. John S. White, Harvard, '79. Chairman Rives, Columbia, '68, made the introductory remarks, and was followed by E.P. Wilder, Yale, '79.

The laying of the cornerstone of the Cathe dral or St. John the Divine will be remembered by those who witnessed, it as an event by fat the most interesting in the history of the New York Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church. As a ceremony, no great affair could have been conducted with greater simplicity. But its significance was impressed upon every feature of the sacred office.

The Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club was revived and reorganized last night. The members or this club in large part organized the Reform Club of tills City some years ago, and they devoted most of their time and influence to the New-York society, with the result that the Brooklyn club has remained comparatively inactive for four years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The friends of Chairman Harrity who are in his confidence say that he is not a candidate for Cabinet honors, and has disposed of the question by insisting that no effort be made in his behalf, as it would be impossible for him to accept any position under the incoming Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Mr. Cullom, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce, is not permitting many hours to go to waste during the holiday recess. He is at his committee room almost daily, and is devoting a great deal of time to the consideration of the numerous bills amendatory to the inter-State commerce law that have been introduced in the Senate this session.

That Mr. Cleveland is opposed to the election, of Edward Murphy to the United States senate to succeed Mr. Hiscock was authoritatively settled yesterday by a direct statement from the President-elect.

Fishermen who love to angle for the king of salt-water fishes, the tarpon, have rejoiced greatly at the reception of news from Florida that the fishermen on both the east coast, along the Indian, Banana, and Halifax Rivers, and other inlets of the sea, and down about Charlotte Harbor, are making great hauls of mullet. Reports from the Caloosahatchee and the Hillsborough Rivers say that the waters are absolutely alive with mullet.
The American Trade Press Association met at the Marlborough Hotel last evening and discussed "second-class mail matter" with all its present discouragements, so far as New-York City is concerned.
The lion whelp which was born in the Central Park menagerie on Friday night is no more. She died in the Superintendent's office Monday night.

The special committee from the Senate and Assembly, which has been investigating the subject of taxation, completed its work in this city at a session yesterday afternoon in Part II of the Superior Court.
G.S. Armstrong, Secretary of the Washington State Board of Health, has written a letter to the Board of Trade and Transportation, in which he says among other things:

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 27. -- The State Supreme Court, with its three Republican members, stands a noble, commanding and impartial figure between the men who have so desperately endeavored to capture the Legislature for United States Senator Warren (Rep.) and the people. A decision of the tribunal rendered today leaves the schemers dangling in midair.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 27. -- Numerous arrests continue to be made at Kiev of persons enspected of Nihilism. Nine more officers are among those imprisoned, either under suspicion or on direct charges of connection with a conspiracy against the Czar.
The Cunard steamship Umbria is about sixty hours overdue. She sailed from Liverpool for New-York on Dec. 17 and touched at Queenstown on Dec. 18, leaving there at 2:22 o'clock in the afternoon.

We confess to some impatience with those persons who oppose every project of municipal improvement which is supported by Tammany. There can be no question that the majority of the voters of this city, after a fair fight, in which the issue was clearly presented and understood, have chosen Tammany to rule over them, and that we must look forward for a time, indefinite but considerable, to the rule of Tammany.

If a certificate which was filed yesterday with the Bureau of Vital Statistics is correct, the oldest person in the world died in New-York Monday morning. She was Leah Lesozynski, and she lived with her great-grandchildren in the tenement, 143 Norfolk Street.

A german was given for Miss Edith Van Cortlandt Jay last evening by her parents. Dr. and Mrs. John Clarkeon Jay of 54 West Forty-seventh Street. It was the first entertainment given in Dr. Jay's newly-renovated house, and the affair took somewhat of the form of a house-warming.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The right of a bank to charge commission besides the full legal rate of interest for a loan is raised in a plea filed in the Superior Court to-day. The case is that of the Western National Bank of New-York against Allison, Shatter Co.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The following telegram has been received at the War Department from Gen. Wheaton, commanding the Department of Texas, dated the 23th inst.:

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- The scientific and literary world of Paris assembled to-day to honor Louis Pasteur for the benefits he has conferred upon humanity. The spacious amphitheatre of the Sorhonne, the home of the French Academy of Sciences, was uncomfortably packed by persons eager to take part in commemorating the seventieth anniversary of his birth.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Before Judge Herrick, in Special Term here to-day, George Hasbrouck, counsel for Mr. Lounsbury, the Republican Assemblyman from Ulster County, made an application for a writ to restrain Judge Alton B. Parker of Kingston from proceeding with the investigation on the contention of George H. Bush for the seat awarded to Mr. Lounsbury by the Ulster County Board of Canvassers.

City Marshal Sol Cohen appeared at the establishment of B.M. Cowperth walt Co., 193 to 205 Park Row, yesterday, with an execution for a judgment, obtained from Judge Clancy in the Second District Court, for $45, for violation of the city ordinance against obstructing the sidewalks. First he decided to levy on two rolls of carpet that were then on the sidewalk.

After reading the burial service over the body of Albert Galiup yesterday and laying the cornerstone of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in the afternoon, at 6 o'clock last evening Bishop Potter concluded his labors for the day by conducting the services at the opening and benediction of the Emily Bruce Lines Memorial Parish House, at the Church of the Beloved Disciple, 67 East Eighty-ninth Street.

Importers in general in this city pronounce the Customs Administrative act a failure. A business man put it this way yesterday: "The bill as it is now administered by the Board of Appraisers is a curse to all honest importers."
The work of making up the financial budget for 1893 was continued yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

The Deputy Superintendent of Insurance of this State, Michael Shannon, is investigating the management of various co-operative fire insurance companies of this city of the class referred to as follows by State Superintendent James F. Pierce in his annual report of 1891:

-- Herman Thimig, widely known as a bottler of beer, died yesterday morning at his home, 436 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long and very painful illness. He went to Florida about two months ago to spend the Winter, but the physicians told him his case was hopeless, so he returned home last Friday to die. He was born in Saxony in 1835 and landed in America is 1865 without a dollar.

The criminal responsibility for the recent illegal expenditures made by the Kings County Supervisors for the Columbian celebration is being investigated by the Grand Jury, but the civil liability for that waste of the public funds is to be tested in a series of suits in the Supreme Court, the first of which was begun yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The Rev. Thomas R. Moran of this place has been made a domestic prelate of the Pope, with the title of Monsignor. The ceremonies connected with the investiture of the purple were held to-day. A large crowd assembled from surrounding towns and cities to witness the ceremonies. Bishop O'Farrell of the diocese conferred the purple.

COLE -- BABBITT. At noon yesterday Miss Ella Lloyd Babbitt, daughter of Mrs. T. Annerly Allcook of Pittsburg, Penn., was married to Prof. George Fremont Cole of this city in St Ignatius's Church, 56 West Fortieth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Ritchie, rector of the church.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 27. -- Fred Erving, the burglar who was wounded by a policeman recently, has confessed that he and a pal had plotted to rob the churches of this city during Christmas week. A young man supposed to be the pal was seen Christmas night acting suspiciously on the cathedral grounds and in the Unitarian Church, but made his escape.

The New-York and Pacific Steamship Company. Limited, which was recently formed in London, with a capital of u250,000, proposes to run a line of freight steamers from this city around Cape Horn to ports on the west coast of South America in opposition to the sailing vessels which are now engaged in that trade.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 27. -- A blizzard struck Charleston this morning, and for the first time in fifteen years housetops were covered with a thin coating of snow and sleet. The mercury averaged about 3 or 4 below freezing. The orange trees in the city are injured somewhat, and will probably bear only one crop this year.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 27. -- Yesterday nearly all me election returns sent in by the Election Inspectors, representing the suffrages of Long Island City's voters, were missing. Today It Is the Inspectors themselves who are dinappearing.

The correspondent of the Philadelphia Ledger, who is one of the most conscientious and trustworthy of the Washington correspondents, reports a statement by Senator SHERMAN regarding the purchase of silver which is extremely significant. The Senator has a deep interest in the silver law of 1890, which, by no means to the advantage of his reputation, has passed into current history under his name.

If it was George J. Gould's desire to advance the price of Manhattan Railway stock, his shrewdness in putting J. Pierpont Morgan forward as a dominating influence in that property has had a speedy reward. The price of the stock, which on the day after Jay Gould's death was quoted in the Stock Exchange at 132 1/2, rose yesterday to 148 3/4 and closed at 147 1/2.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 27. -- While Julius Uihlein, a butcher, of 146 Middleberg Avenue, this city, was at work at his chopping block waiting upon customers, soon after dark last evening, there came the report of a gun, the crashing of class, and Uihlein fell unconscious to the floor with a load of birdshot in his right side.

Grace Church was crowded yesterday morning with the friends of the late Albert Gallup. They were there to hear the last words spoken over his coffin. Bishop Potter read the burial service of the Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, and the Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet of the Church of the Holy Communion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Chief Drummond of the Secret Service division, has cautioned his agents to exercise the closest possible scrutiny to prevent any counterfeiting of the Columbian souvenir coins.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 27. -- One of the promoters of the International Navigation Company was interviewed here to-day with reference to telegrams from Washington, credited to the State Department, to the effect that the United States authorities were not informed as to plans of the International Navigation Company. The promoter is here negotiating with the Canadian Government for the necessary charter powers.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 27. -- Rafael Montuar, representative of Guatemala on the Mexican-Guatemalan Mixed Claims Commission, has given out an interesting statement in regard to the finances of that republic. He states that Guatemala is financially sound, notwithstanding certain discriminations that have been made against its bonded indebtedness.
Two steamships, the Denmark of the National Line and La Normandie of the Compagnie Genersle Transatlantique, got in safely yesterday, after experiencing unusually severe weather.

Ten Police Justices attended the meeting of their board at Jefferson Market Police Court last night. Justice Grady, as Chairman of a committee appointed to consider a communication coming from the President of the Police Commissioners and suggested by Superintendent Byrnes, reported the following resolution to be adopted as Rule 9, governing the Board of Police Justices:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Capt. John G. Bourke of the Third Cavalry, who has been called to Washington to give the Secretaries of War and of State the benefit of his acquaintance with the condition of things on the Rio Grande frontier, says he "really believes things cannot help being worse before they are better."
The last regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen for 1892 was held yesterday, but the board will hold a special meeting to-morrow to finish up its business.

The statement that Cora Urquhart Potter, the actress, was to be examined in supplementary proceedings caused a small crowd of curious persons to assemble yesterday afternoon in the General Term. Room of the Supreme Court Mrs. Potter was there on time. She sat at a little table talking to a happy-looking young man as if examination in supplementary proceedings had no terrors for her.

It was announced yesterday by President William Ratney Harper of the University of Chicago, who is in New-York for a few days, that John D. Rockefeller had given another million of dollars to the university as a Christmas present. This brings the total of his gifts to the university to $3,600,000, out of a total endowment of $7,000,000.

ST. JOHN, N. B., Dec. 27. -- The Curlew, one of the Canadian lake gunboats, is now in this port. She has been employed, in the Bay of Fundy in fishery-protection service for about four months, so that the statement about her wintering at Hamilton is incorrect.

Plans have been filed with the Building Department for extensive alterations in the Music Hall at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. The proposed work will cost at the loweat $800,000. When the charges are completed the building will be much more commodious and more commanding in appearance, W.B. Tuthill, who is one of the Directors of the Music Hall Company, is the architect.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- Lieut Robert E. Peary, the arctic explorer, when interviewed by a reporter, said that he had already written to St John's. N. F., to engage a ship for his proposed expendition to the north next Summer. Applications to join his party, he continued, were coming in with every mail, and he had not yet been able to attend to any of them.

There was a hearing in Commissioner Gilroy's office yesterday on the two sets of plans that have been prepared for the new Third Avenue bridge -- one by T.C. Clarke of Mr. Gilrey's staff, and one by Louis A. Risse of Commissioner Heintz's staff.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 27. -- There will be a meeting here to-morrow of representatives of the athletic organization of all the leading Southern colleges. The object is to perfect the organization of the Inter-Southern Collegiate Athletic Association. Prominent in this movement is Mr. Robertson of the University of Virginia. For some time past he and others interested in the movement have discussed this subject.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The annual meeting of the American Societies of Naturalists, Physiologists, and Morphologists convened today in the college halls. The societies are composed of all eminent scientists in the eastern hair of the United States. The meeting this rear is attended by a larger number than any in the history or the societies.
Practically every establishment in this city engaged in the production of stained and decorative glasswork is idle at present on account of a strike among the workmen.

Masonic lodges la the jurisdiction of the Grand Lodge of the State of New-York have reported the election of the following officers for the ensuing year. There are a few returns to be made before the Grand Lodge session to be hold next June, but all the lodge elections have been held:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Representative William L. Wilson of West Virginia will undoubtedly be the candidate for Speaker of the Fifty-third Congress of those Democrats who do not believe that it is reasonable to hope for effective organization of the House with Speaker Crisp re-elected.

The stated meeting of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners was omitted yesterday, but the engineers of the board were busy with maps, plans, and figures, presumably for the purpose of furnishing whatever additional information may be required by capitalists and others interested in the auction sale of the franchise of the proposed road, which will he held to-morrow noon in the City Hall rotunda.

At the Coney Island Athletic Club to-night Plimmer and McGrath will contest for bantam-weight honors. Both are in good condition and confident of victory. The preliminary contests will be between Leedom and Flaherty and Boyle and Sullivan.

The Jersey City Street and Water Board, yesterday directed Corporation Counsel Edwards to prepare a contract with the Hodgkiss-Clark Company for a new water supply for Jersey City. The directions do not seem to have been given at the public session of the board, but a member of the board admitted to THE TIMES'S reporter after the meeting had adjourned that the order had been given.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Dec. 27. -- A Government military courier has brought news of another outrage in the State of Sonora, of which the warring Yaqui Indians were the perpetrators. The trouble occurred in the little town of Belen at the foot of one of the ranges in the Sierra Madre Mountains, near the mouth of the Yaqui River.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27. -- A City or Mexico dispatch says: "Bishop Manuel Arnezquita of the Tabasco Diocese of Mexico has issued an appeal to all Catholics of Mexico, the United States, and Canada, for money to be used in the erection of a magnificent cathedral on the bank of the Grigelva River, of the very spot where the first mass was said on the American continent.

The silver trowel and other implements used by Bishop Potter in laying the cornerstone were made and presented by Tiffany Co. They were received by Bishop Potter as a Christmas gift for the cathedral accompanied by the following letter under date of Dec. 26:
LONDON, Dec, 27. -- The Belgian steamer Noordland, which left New-York Dec. 14 for Antwerp, has been towed into Queenstown by the steamer Ohio. The Noordland has a shaft broken.

Bishop Doane of Albany then delivered the address, taking as his theme "The Lesson of the Cornerstone." Science, he said, had disclosed, through the medium of the microscope, that stones, which were denominated speechless, were yet possessed of motion, which had been described as "leaping and swinging" with incredible swiftness.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 27. -- No official news has been received, at military department headquarters here to-day concerning the reported skirmish between a detachment of United States troops and the border bandits in Zapata County.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- In the greater excitement attending the proceedings in the Chamber of Deputies and the revelations compromising so many prominent men in the Panama Canal scandal, sight has been lost to a certain extent of the autopsy on Baron de Beinach, whose mysterious death has been attributed to various causes -- apoplexy, suicide, and murder.

John Dalfino of 418 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, who shot Mrs. Caroline Gesell of 49 Degraw Street late on Tuesday night after an evening spent in drinking, was captured yesterday and held to await the result of the woman's injuries.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 28. -- A dispatch from Currlzo Springs. Dimmil County, says that twenty-five miles south of that place, near the Encinal Road, has been discovered an ovaltopped mound covered with petrified human skulls. The mound is about 100 feet in height, circular in form, and joined on one side to a shore range of hills of about the same height.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 28. -- The Delaware Legislature will meet at Dover next Tuesday morning for reorganization, and the night previous the Democratic members of the two houses will meet in caucus for the purpose of nominating speakers and other officers. There are numerous candidates for the minor offices of both branclies, and the caucuses will prove interesting and exciting.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 28. -- At an early hour this morning Company G of the Twentythird United States Infantry, stationed at Fort Sam Houston, left here by special train for the lower Rio Grando border. It is in command of First Lieut. Stephen O'Connor. From Laredo they will proceed overland to Rendado, Ranche, Zapata County, which is said to be in the very centre of the bandits stronghold.

BAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 28. -- John M. Roberts of Metehuala; Mexico, was married to-day at St. Mary's Catholic Church in this city to Miss Margarite M. Curtin of North Park, Col. The chronicle of the mere fact of the marriage would leave untold as pretty a romance as ever blessed and beautified a wedding.
In the spacious drawing rooms of the residence of Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Smith, at 412 Madison Avenue, was held last night a young people's Christmas dance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- When Secretary Tracy returns from New-York in the morning he will find that the matter of awarding contracts for two big war ships has grown to uncomfortable proportions.
"Our Christmas business has quite a tail to it," said a salesman in one of the big retail stores where women go a-shopping.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 28. -- Interesting facts in connection with the Smith heresy trial have just leaked out. The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Lane Seminary had resolved to keep the entire matter a profound secret. But last week at a meeting of the Executive Committee, which practically runs the institution, Prof. Henry Preserved Smith was present, and was anxious to have an official declaration from the board.

Two indictments against Julio Campo, a Colombian, charging him with grand larceny, were yesterday dismissed by Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, upon the recommendation of Assistant District Attorney Weeks.
ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The Mills Club entertained as its guest this evening Senator Roger Q. Mills. The event was a dinner, and it was given in excellent style at the Fort Orange Club.

Among the letters on national quarantine received by the Board of Trade and Transportation is one from Dr. H.B. Millard of this city, a foreign corresponding member of the Academy of Medicine of Paris, who writes:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Capt J. W. Collins, assistant in charge of the Division of Fisheries under Commissioner McDonald of the United States Fish Commission, has resigned that position and will hereafter devote himself to the business of Chief of the Department of fisheries in the World's Columbian Exposition.

Suit has been begun in the Supreme Court in this city by Edward Parker Deacon for an absolute divorce from his wife, Florence Deacon. Coudert Brothers are the attorneys for Mr. Deacon, and on their application Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday signed an order directing that the summons be served on Mrs. Deacon by publication.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28. -- At a meeting here today of representatives of eight of the leading Southern colleges and universities a Southern intercollegiate athletic association was formed. The officers of the new organization are: J.B. Robertson of the University of Virginia, President; W.T. Symington of Johns Hopkins University of Maryland, Vice President; W.H. Graham, University of the South, Secretary and Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Senator and Mrs. Calvin S. Brice gave a tea at their residence this afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock to introduce their second daughter, Miss Katharine Margaret Brioe, to society, and Senator and Mrs. Brice stood frith their daughter to receive in the white-and-green ballroom, where towering palms formed a background and arched above their heads.
PANAMA, VIA GALVESTON, Dec. 28. -- The boundary dispute between Costa Rica and Nicaragua is assuming threatening dimensions and hostilities may commence at any moment.

When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday. President Purroy of the Fire Department was on hand to ask for another transfer to his apparatus and supplies account, to enable the Fire Department to get along for the rest of this year.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Lasker beat H.G. Voge last evening, after forty-one moves, in a queen pawn game. The moves follow:

At the Catholic Club last night, while a pleas ant reception and concert was taking place there, a committee of laymen, known as the Committee on Catholic Interests, met in the Governors' room and discussed in an informal manner the situation in the Catholic Church in this city in relation to the restoration of Dr. McGlynn.

Information has been received by Navy Department officials to the effect that China will not be represented in the coming Columbian naval review because of her inability to man her heavy ships. China's inability to be represented was officially announced to the United States Government some three weeks ago, but the reason ascribed at the time was unfamiliarity on the part of Chinese officers in the navigation of American waters.

Persons claiming to speak for an international syndicate wnich proposes to apply in Ottawa, Canada, for a Dominion charter for the International Navigation Company, have without authority from Major George W. McNulty, engineer of the Broadway Cable Road, connected his name with the scheme.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Chicago society is agitated over the appearance of a picture of Mrs. Potter Palmer on a brewery calendar for 1893, used without her consent and without her knowledge. Mr. Palmer was a very angry man to-day.

The committee appointed by the Trustees of the Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association of this city to solicit subsoriptions and arrange for the purchase of one or more distilleries, so that spirits can be manufactured for the liquor trade at prices lower than charged by the Whisky Trust, met yesterday afternoon in Parlor L of the Astor House.

The opening of the second round of the great intercollegiate chess matches found Yale with 1 1/2 points in the lead, owing to Bumstead's victory over Dicky of Princeton. The latter was at one time the exchange ahead, but entered into a sacrificing combination which stranded upon the Yale man's correct defense. Columbia and Princeton scored one game each, while Harvard had to content herself with half a point.

RED BANK, N. J, Dec. 28. -- The wind blew strong this afternoon when the North Shrewsbury Club's ice yachts started in the third race of the season for the challenge pennants. Not a single sail was roefed, however, and some exciting sport was the result. The yachts were divided into two classes, as follows:

Reuben Cohen, a dealer in tailors' trimmings at 161 Division Street, was held in $1,000 bail by Justice Hogan in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday for examination on next Wednesday on charges of obtaining goods from Zachariah Isear, a clothing manufacturer of 194 East Broad-way, by falsely representing his financial condition, and of secreting money and merchandise in order to defraud, his creditors.

At a meeting of the Board of Health yesterday the following resolutions were adopted: Resolved, That this board hereby records its high appreciation of the valuable and devoted services of the following employes of this and the Police Department, who bravely died while in the performance of their duties during the visitation of typhus fever last Spring:

The lobby of the Standard Theatre last night was gayly decked with, evergreens, palms, and flowers, and in the auditorium of the theatre the box fronts were covered with screens of evergreen, bearing legends in letters made of red immortelles, proclaiming the glory of John Drew and "The Masked Ball." The one hundredth consecutive performance of the Bisson farce was seen by an audience that crowded every part of the theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- "For God's sake, save me! I don't want to go back there any more!" shouted a thinly-clad woman who ran into a policeman's arms at the corner of Sherman and Van Buren Streets this morning. The woman had just jumped from the second-story window of the Atlantic Hotel.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28. -- The theft of five blank checks from the United States Pension Agency, signed by Pension Agent Kelly, constitutes the first loss in all the years during which this agency has been established.

Reports of rough weather upon the Atlantic continue to be brought by incoming vessels. The steamship Vega, twenty days out from Lisbon, came into port yesterday afternoon considerably damaged by an encounter with a hurricane out in mid-Atlantic.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. -- The reports from NewYork that Dr. McGlynn, the reinstated Catholic Driest, would probably be assigned to this archdiocese, has caused some comment in local Catholic circles. In East Baltimore, particularly, the subject is being liberally discussed in connection with the vacant rectorship of St. Patrick's Church.

Secretary of the Navy Tracy has been in the city for the past two days on private business. During his absence from Washington Assistant Secretary Soley has been in charge of affairs. Those in a position to know say that Mr. Tracy and Mr. Soley will establish a law office in this city in the Spring and practice together in Admiralty court cases.

A pithy and witty talk about "The Theatre in Modern Life" was given in the salon of the Hotel Brunswick last night. The talker was Mr. Henry A. Clapp, the well-known Boston critic, and the listeners were the members of the Goethe Society, the occasion being the first of the monthly assemblies or that society for this season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- The light receipts of hogs, with an advance at the yards, were responsible for a stronger opening in the provision market, but the advance offered an opportunity to the longs of which they were not below to avail themselves. Realizing sales were liberal by some of these holders, and there was a break to below the closing prices of the previous day.

After every Presidential election there is more or less discussion of the defects of the Electoral system and of the desirability of change in the method of choosing the president and Vice President. Several times there have been propositions introduced in Congress having this object in view, but they have been allowed to drop out of sight without action and generally without any serious debate.

NEW-YORK. -- Bail in the case of Roundsman Matthew F. Dailey, who was convicted of assaulting Mrs. Hannan, was yesterday fixed at $2,500 and furnished by Dailey's mother-in-law. Dailey went to Police Headquarters after surety had been furnished to demand an assignment to duty, but he did not see Superintendent Byrnes. He will try again to-morrow.

Dr. John Silas White, Head Master of the Berkeley School and originator and ex-President of the Berkeley Athletic Association, is in more trouble on account of his propensity for having a band in athletic organizations. The present difficulty is over the debts of the Berkeley Athletic Club, an appendage to the association, which became extinct nearly a year ago.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors intends to reduce the emoluments of the various Coroners materially. It has adopted a preamble and resolution as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- The case for docking horses' tails against William Leddy in Judge Bradwell's court to-day attracted great attention because it was a test case and because Leddy's work was really done for John W. Doane, the wholesale merchant who has been mentioned for a Cabinet office under Mr. Cleveland, and who likes to drive a fashionable team.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 28. -- Gov. Flower will give a reception to the Presidential Electors and to the members of the Legislature on the evening of Jan. 9. It is expected that a large number of Democrats from all parts of the State will be present. The following correspondence is self-explanatory:

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 28. -- Since Gen. fame declared himself out of the field of America's Cup defenders, Boston yachtsmen have been looking to Henry Bryant to represent the city. To-day, however, Mr. Bryantalso declared himself out of the contest and so one more chance for this city to he represanted is gone.

To-day the franchise for the construction of the rapid-transit railroad will be offered for sale to the highest bidder on the terms and conditions presented by the RapidTransit Commission. During the period of advertising this sale much interest in the subject has been displayed, and there is plenty of evidence that men of capital have been giving it their serious attention.

ST. PETEESBURG, Dec. 28. -- A court-martial in Tashkend has passed sentence on the leaders of the cholera riots of July 6 last. Seventy men were tried. Eight were sentenced to be Strangled, four to the loss of all civil rights and deportation to Siberia for life, and thirtythree to long terms of imprisonment. Twentyfive were acquitted.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28. -- The time for filing legislative contests, expired at 6 o'clock tills evening. Among the contests is one in Doniphan County, in which the Republican receiving 1,300 majority is asked to be thrown out by the Populists ; also, in Shawnee County, where A. C. Sherman, with 500 majority, is notified that he has been guilty of fraud, for which reason his seat will he contested.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 28. -- The fishing schooner Welcome of Gloucester went ashore near Race Point this morning. The crew or sixteen men were brought safely ashore by the Race Point life-saving crew. The vessel is in a bad position, and if the northeast wind increases to a gale, which is now indicated, she will probably be a total loss.

The forty-first anniversary of the Orphans' Home and Asylum of the Protestant Episcopal Church was celebrated yesterday morning at the home, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The fact that the date of the institution's foundation, falls so near Christmas is made occasion for also holding the Christmas festival on that day.
The dedication of the large and handsome new borne of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum Society of Brooklyn yesterday drew together a large number of distinguished persons from this city and, Brooklyn.
The fifth annual Christmas ride of the pupils of Durland's Biding School was held at the academy, Columbus Plaza, last night.
No formal meeting of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners was held yesterday at their office on William Street, but they were busy enough answering questions.

To Col. John A. Cockerill, who retires after five years of service as President of the NewYork Press Club, to be succeeded by John W. Keller, a dinner was given last evening at the Hotel Logerot by members of the club. The occasion was quite informal and most enjoyable. About 100 sat at the tables. George H. Fleming presided.

From, the Philadelphia Ledger, Dec. 27 The January payments of interest and dividends in this city are the heaviest of the year. Upon Jan. 1 interest matures on a large portion of the national debt, and the Government will pay the quarterly interest on the 4 per cents, about $5,596,000, and also $1,938,705 semiannual interest on the Pacific Railroad bonds, known as the " Currency 6s."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 28. -- At 2 o'clock this morning a bomb was thrown into the main building of the south side plant of the Milwaukee Street Railway. There was a tremendous explosion, and in a moment the interior of the building was in a blaze, In a few minutes the fire was beyond control, and in less than an hour the entire plant was consumed, entailing a loss of $510,000.

The Glenmore Rod and Gun Club had its regular monthly shoot at Dexter Park, Long Island, yesterday. Several events were shot off besides the club shoot. A sweepstake at five birds, $1 entrance, was shot. J. Schliemann killed 5 straight and won; L. Eppig scored 3, and C. Engelbrecht 2. A second sweepstake, same conditions, was won by J.A. Still, killing 5 straight; M.E. Hayden was second with 3.
When Richard Croker was asked yesterday if he had anything to say about the statement made by President-elect Cleveland as to Edward Murphy's candidacy for the United States Senate he said:

At its final meeting for 1892 the Board of Education yesterday, by a vote of 18 to 6, refused to consent to a change in the by-laws of the board suggested by Commissioner Knex, that wherever the designations "male" and "female" occurred in connection with the schools of the city, "boys" and "girls" be substituted.

The fourth annual ball of the Deaf-Mutes' Union League came off last night at Central Turn Verein Hall. Sixty-seventh Street, near Third Avenue. Nearly one hundred well-dressed couples participated in the dancing. While the mutes, many of them pretty young women and bright-looking young men, were getting ready for the opening grand march, Francis W. Nubeer, Treasurer of the league, said to a TIMES reporter:

Dr. Henry E. Jennings, a dentist who has attained considerable notoriety as an expert amateur billiardist, and who has a dentist's office on the parlor floor of 80 Court Street, Brooklyn, with living rooms above, left his office about noon yesterday to come to this city, telling his wife that he would return in an hour.

Conjecture strayed into numerous channel yesterday regarding the welfare and whereabouts of the long overdue Cunarder Umbria and her 570 passengers. She sailed from Queenstown Dec. 18, and under ordinary circumstauces should have reached this port last Sunday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 28. -- Two more convicts have died at the penitentiary from a mysterious cause, and another has gone after an illness with what the physician claims is pneumonia. Ernest Creiso, sent up from Jackson County for three years for assault, and Andrew Falls, serving a three-year sentence for bigamy, were among the convicts who were taken suddenly and mysteriously ill at the Helena camp about ten days ago.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The American engaged in the duel at Monte Carlo with a Russian known as the Count Peter Romanoff was named Jay Brockton, and he was not from Brooklyn, as before stated, the suggestion that he was from Brooklyn having evidently been caused by a mistake as to his name.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Dr. Lagorio, the Director of the Chicago Pasteur Institute, says be is the discoverer of the new cure for epilepsy that is now attracting the attention of physicians. Dr. Paul Gibler, the President of the New-York Bacteriological Society, read an exhaustive paper before the Medical Society of the County of New-York, in which the new treatment is discussed, but he does not give Dr. Lagorio the credit or the discovery.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The measure pending in Congress providing for the transfer of the Revenue Marine to the naval establishment will, it is hoped, be reached and disposed of finally during the present session. The secretary of the Navy, in his report recently sub. mitted, refers to the proposed transfer as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 29. -- Business and manufacturing interests here will begin the new year with a lively concern about fire insurance. The Cleveland Board of Underwriters has just issued a statement telling why rates have advanced, but it does not give all the facts. During the past two years all the insurance companies doing business in this city have sustained heavy losses.

OSSAWATOMIE, Kan., Dec. 28. -- A most destructive fire to life and property occured in this place last night. Three large two-story dwellings on Bon Crouch Avenue, owned by William Chestnut, caught fire from natural gas and were entirely consumed, nothing being saved. Four persons were cremated, and several had narrow escapes in their night clothes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The House sub-committee having charge of the subject of establishing a national quarantine -- Mr. Rayner (Dem., Md.,) Chairman -- has agreed upon a bill, which it will report to the full committee at its next regular meeting after the recess, on Friday week.

The literature of the litigation between W. E. D. Stokes and his cousin, Edward S. Stokes, has been increased by a complaint making a pamphlet of forty pages, wherein W. E. D. Stokes tells what a bad man Cousin Edward S. is, charges that Edward has mismanaged the affairs of the Hoffman House Corporation, and asks that a receiver be appointed to take charge of the property.

By signing his name to the permission granted by the Board of Alderman to the Union Railway Company for the extension of its "huckleberry" system Mayor Grant yesterday gave the trolley its first foothold on Manhattan Island.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 26. -- The New-York and Yonkers curlers, who arrived here to-day wore busy till after 10:30 to-night with matches with the Toronto curlers. The three visiting teams are pretty well exhausted with their fatigues of journey added to the good, hard work they accomplished at Utica so that today's play cannot be considered a fair criterion of the kind of mettle they can under ordinary circum.

The three-story brick building at 37 and 39 South Third Street, Williamsburg, occupied by Peter Young as a bagging factory, was entirely gutted by fire late last night. Three alarms were rung in, but it was impossible to save the building. This is the fourth time the place has been visited by fire.

The Presbytery of New-York has gone into secret session to determine upon its verdict in the famous hereey trial of Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary. At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon Moderator Bliss requested all except those who had the right to vote on the charges to retire from the vestry room of the scotch Presbyterian Church, Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue.
If the Tammany Tiger does not have a bad case of political indigestion after the great meal he had last night, the tiger will be in big luck.
Arthur Glyn Bogge, whoso present address is the Tombs, is a young Englishman whose short career in this city has been an exceedingly profitless one forthe people with whom he has come in contact.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 28. -- A terrific explosion shook Long Island City from end to end this morning, and foretold an awful tragedy. At precisely 8 o'clock nearly 100 pounds of dynamite exploded in the very heart of the city, and caused the death of five persons. The injured are at least a score.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 28. -- The Senatorial contest in this State has taken a new turn during the past forty-eight hours. A conference has been held with ex-Congressman Brandagee of New-London, with the idea of introducing him into the canvass as a third candidate. His consent to the plan is expected at any hour by friends in this city.
" Are you to be regarded as an anti-Administration candidate for Speaker " was asked of Speaker Crisp yesterday after he had come from visit to Mr. Cleveland.

For the first time in ten years Jamaica Bay is frozen from Canarsie Landing to Ruffle Bar, a distance of three miles. Yesterday morning the Windward Ice Yacht Club of Canarsie, although organized five years ago, hold its first race on the bay. Although an impromptu race, it was thoroughly enjoyed by the participants. Commodore Richard HalBey acted as judge, while Messrs. Gayles and Markham did the timing.

NUEVA LAREDO, Mexico, Dec. 28. -- This has been a day of suppressed excitement and anxiety in military circles hero, as there was every reason for believing that the revolutionists would make an attack on Guerrero, where a large quantity of arms and ammunition are stored.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- G.W.G. Ferris, a mechanical engineer in the Rookery Building, is one of the inventors of a canal lock that is expected to revolutionize the canal building of the world and develop the building of ship canals to connect the United States and Canada and to give the principal cities of the United States direct rapid water transit connection with the great lakes and oceans.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 28. -- This was a busy day for the scientists. The four societies of morphologists. anatomists, physiologists, and naturaliats held meetings throughout the day. Some of the sessions began as early as 9 o'clock this morning and the business of the day was not completed until after the annual dinner this evening at 11 o'clock.

Joseph Hollman, 'cellist, and Johannes Wolf. Violinist, began a series of matinees yesterday afternoon at Palmer's Theatre. A large audience listened to their playing and hung with rapt attention on their ingenious distribution of aforzandi and morendi. The two artists are adepts in the use of that exaggerated sentimentality of expression which is so dear to the inexperienced in art.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Pending the negotiations which are now under way for the purpose of bringing the Jacksonville Southeastern Road into the Western Passenger Association, the Atchison Company has temporarily withdrawn its request for the exemption of the Southwestern Missouri River business from the requirements of the agreement. Should the negotiations prove successful the notice will be canceled altogether, as the cause for it will then be removed.

From the brief summary of the Quarantine bill agreed upon by the sub-committee of the House it would appear that its purpose is merely to supplement the quarantine regulations of the several States and to place their enforcement under the direction of the Hospital Service of the Revenue Marine.

MILWAUKER, Wis., Dec. 29. -- Two hundred Citizens attended the meeting held in the Chamber of Commorce this forenoon for the purpose of taking action in the matter of the many disastrous fires which have recently occurred here. The meeting resulted in a defeat of the people who entertain the theory that all the fires wore of incendiary origin.
The dancing class patronized by Mrs. Henry Braem, Mrs. Henry A. Barclay, Miss Furniss, Mrs. John C. Eno, Mrs. Louis V. Bell, and others held its third gathering last evening at Sherry's.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- This was the final day of the convention of the scientists, and was characterized by the usual rush of business of a last day's session. Moat of the morphologists, who completed their work yesterday noon, left last evening for their homes. The physiologists also completed their business and discussions late last evening and left town early this morning.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 29. -- The text of the decision of Judge Shaw granting a divorce to Mrs. A.E. Brunson from her husband, Judge Brunson, has just been made public. This is the case in which Mrs. Mary O.H. Stoneman, wife of Gen. George H. Stoneman, ex-Governor of this State, was named as co-respondent.

Mrs. Mary Scott Rowland and James Dunlap, the pardoned Northampton Bank burglar, arrived in this city late yesterday afternoon. They were driven in a coach to 123 Fifth Avenue, where Mrs. Rowland lives and has rooms in which she sells perfumes and those mysterious preparations used for the beautifying of ladies' complexions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. --Information has reached Washington that Senator Hill does not contemplate a war upon President Cleveland, but that he will devote himself after March 4 to watching the appearance of Mugwump nominations. Nominations of that sort are to be opposed by him "tooth and nail," and there seems to be an impression that he expects to employ a good deal of tooth and nail daring the next four years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Apothecaries in the navy must hereafter enlist in the service as petty officers of the first class, which is the nominal classification of these assistants to the Surgeons afloat.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 29. -- N.A. Bagley, a prominent commission merchant of this city who shipped several hundred thousand bushels of corn to Mexico during the recent demand for that grain in that country, returned to-day from a two months' business trip to the City of Mexico.

A curious thing happened at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen. Alderman School offered a resolution providing for a franchise to permit the New-York United Gas Company to dig up the streets for the purpose of laying mains and pipes.

The biggest and most powerful railroad locomotive in the world, according to Locomotive Engineering for January, will soon be running on the Mexican Central Railroad. It was constructed at the Rhode Island Locomotive Works, with a couple of like companions. The monster weighs 130 tons when in working order, and was built to climb steep grades in the mountains or Mexico and to drag heavy loads around sharp curves safely.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 29. -- The anti-fusion, circular issued by the officers of the National Populist Committee, under date of Indianapolis, has caused much uneasiness among the Democrats here, who have been entertaining hopes of the election of a United States Senator.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Provisions were moderately active, and after a rather easy opening, there was a sharp advance on the support offered by prominent traders and la sympathy with the improvement in wheat and corn. Receipts of hogs were liberal, though not up to the estimates, and prices were a trifle lower. This apparently had little effect on the speculative market.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The fear that immigrants may bring cholera with them has naturally created a desire to close our ports against them, and at the same time it has revived the old spirit of the Amorican Party. This was a secret organization, formed about 1853, for the purpose of checking the influence of foreigners.

BROOKLYN. -- William J. Coombs will give a free lecture on "Foreign Commerce as Related to American Civilization" before the Brooklyn Ethical Association in the Second Unitarian Church, corner of Clinton and Congress Streets. Brooklyn, on Sunday evening at 7:30 o'clock. The question will be discussed by Walter S. Logan, James A. Skilton, and Dr. Robert G. Eccles.

The third round of the inter-university chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton opened with a brilliant victory by Edward Hymes, Columbia, over Samuel Dickey, Princeton. The latter, unhappily, selected a disadvantageous opening. He defended with a queen's fianchetto, and Columbia's champion lost no time in exploiting his superior position.

The affairs of the Life-Union Insurance Company of 187 Broadway will be speedily wound up and the concern merged with some other mutual society, it the plans of its President and a majority of the Board of Directors are not interfered with. If the wishes of the minority of the Directors prevail, the Attorney General of the State will ask for the appointment of a receiver.

BRINKLEY, Ark., Dec. 29. -- One of the Strangest murder cases ever brought to light in Eastern Arkansas is the one in which John Thomas, a thirteen-year-old boy, is charged with the murder of hid mother on Monday in the dark country neighborhood south of this place.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 29. -- According to the public accounts for the fiscal year ended June 30,1892, the revenue of the Dominion on account of the Consolidated Fund amounted to $36,921,871, and the expenditure to $36,765,894, leaving a surplus of $155,977, which is $2,079,765 under the surplus of the previous year.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 29. -- The purchase of 23,500 acres of coal land on the New River, in Raleigh County, this State, by Drexel, Morgan Co. of Philadelphia who are supposed to represent the Vanderbllt interests, which was consummated a few days ago, has created a great stir among coal operators and capitalists here and elsewhere.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Four persona were killed and three times that number were injured this morning by the collision of a street car and a locomotive at Forty-seventh Street and Stewart Avenue, The street car was crowded and was creasing the Fort Wayne Railway tracks, when a Fort Wayne train crashed into it so suddenly that the occupants had no time to escape.

Among Democrats of national prominence who were in this city yesterday there was considerable Cabinet talk. Some who had recently called on Mr. Cleveland or his nearest advisers in this city said they believed that there were three men who could have positions if they would accept them. These were John G. Carlisle of Kentucky, William E. Morrison of Illinois, and J. Randolph Tucker of Virginia.

HAVANA, Dec. 29. -- Shortly alter landing here yesterday the members of the commission appointed by the United States Congress to examine into the Cuban quarantine methods and Diner subjects of a similar character visited the Governor General. They were hospitably received and were promised Government assistance in their investigations.

Wall Street in just now digesting some rather odd stories, which bring in close association the names of President Harrison, Secretary of the Treasury Foster, and a number of Stock Exchange bankers, brokers, and speculators.

The Tariff Association of New-York recently raised the rates of insurance on Brooklyn property 25 cents because of the inefficiency of the Fire Department of that city and the many disastrous fires that have occurred during the present year.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Dec. 29 -- P.M. A relaxing of rates of foreign exchange and consequently decreasing chances of gold exports and an easier money market combined to foster a better feeling in the stock market today. It was also apparent early in the day that the liquidation in Northern Pacific was over for the time being at least, and, when the suspension of Messrs.

The reverend ministers and Elders of the Presbytery of New-York who are sitting behind barred doors in Judgment on the charges of heresy against Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs of Union Theological Seminary are having a merry time of It. It seems too bad that the public is deprived of a full report of the interesting proceedings.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- James Dunlap, whose pardon was signed by Gov. Russell yesterday, was released from State prison at 9:45 o'clock this morning, and left by the Boston and Albany express for New-York City. He was accompanied by his friends, Mrs. Mary Scott Rowland and George Abbott James.

It has long been held that in preparing the floating defenses designed to protect a port, what is known as the tactical unit should be carefully kept in view. The idea of Commodore FOLGER in offering his present plan of a ram is said to be that two such vessels and also two torpedo boats shonld be attendants upon a great battle ship or armored coast defender mounting heavy guns.

Senator Chandler, Chairman of the Committee on Immigration; Senator Harris, Chairman of the Committee on Infections Diseases; Surgeon General Wyman, ex-Surgeon General Hamilton, ana Drs. Edson and Jenkins visited the quarantine stations down the bay yesterday. The entire day was spent in looking over the accommodations at Bills Island, Hamilton and Swinburne Islands, at Quarantine, and at Sandy Hook, with a view to ascertaining the present accommodations and possibilities for the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The President still has two staff vacancies in the army to fill. One is a Captaincy in the Subsistence Department and the other a Majority in the Adjutant General's Department. The latter has been standing some time; the former was created by the promotion of Gen. Hawkins to be Commissary General of Subsistence, in place of Gen. Du Barry, retired.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 29. -- The official trial of the new coast-defense vessel Monterey will not occur until next week, as the contractors, the Union Iron Worts, have determined to alter the pitch of the screws for the purpose of obtaining a greater number of revolutions and thereby developing an increased horse power.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29. -- W.L. Sachteleben of Alton, Ill., and Thomas C. Allen of Ferguson, Mo., two young bicyclists who started on a tour around the world on their wheels in June, 1890, have arrived here from Vancouver. They bought their bicycles in Liverpool, and after a tour of the British Isles, wheeled across the Continent to the Mediterranean, to Athens and Constantinople.

A reception was given to the members of the Ladies' Out-Door Club of Staten Island by the Staten Island Cricket Club last evening at its clubhouse at Livingaton. It was the second entertainment given by the gentlemen of the cricket club to the ladies, who occupy a part of their grounds during the tennis season, one having been held last Winter.

DUBLIN, Dec. 29. -- Considerable excitement has been caused in Irish home rule circles by the news that the imperial authorities have instructed Scotland Yard to take the spy known as Major Le Caron into the employ of the Government for the purpose of tracing out the guilty parties connected with the Dublin explosion.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- The baggagetransfer business of this city has passed Into the control of the Consolidated. Transfer Company, which is already in possession of this class, of business throughout the State.

Mrs. Grover Cleveland left the city last evening for Buffalo, where she is to pay a visit to her mother. She was accompanied by Mrs. Lamont, Baby Ruth, and her maid. The party traveled in private car "100," which belongs to President Depew of the New-York Central. Mr. Depew had courteously placed it at the disposal of Mrs. Cleveland.
William Sohaus, the well-known importer of and dealer in works of art, died yesterday at his home, 30 East Thirty-eighth Street.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- In a light northwest breeze the North Shrewsbury River Ice Yacht Club sailed to-day its fourth race of the Winter. The prizes were the challenge pennants in the second and third classes. There was the usual large crowd of spectators, and the river presented a lively appearance.

Considerable of the anxiety which has been, felt concerning the safety of the overdue Cunarder Umbria was dissipated yesterday when the steamship Galileo reached port. That vessel brought reassuring tidings of the laggard.

A fire that should have been extinguished in a few minutes broke out on the top floor of the six-story factory building at Pearl and Front Streets, Brooklyn, about 10 o'clock last evening, but the local firemen sent out three alarms and let it rage for over two hours.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 29. -- In the handsome building known as the Barnum Institute of Science and History, built with money given by the late P.T. Barnum and belonging to the Scientific Society and the Fairfield County Historical Society, it was intended to have a tower, a which was to be placed a large telescope. Longstaff Hurd, the architects, gave $500 to help build it, as the $100,000 Mr. Barnum gave had all been expended.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Dec. 29. -- The chief officers of the conductors, switchmen, trainmen, firemen, and telegraphera' associations have been holding a secret conference in this city today with federation for the chief topic of discussion. It was evident that nearly all of the representatives were in favor of some sort of union.

After a combination of manufacturers has been completed, the managers of it tax their brains for some device that will discourage the building of new factories outside of the ring -- if the industry has practically been monopolized-or prevent the profitable operation of the one or two or three factories that still retain their independence.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 29. -- This town, which is essentially Southern in its characteristics, has become excited over the fact that a number of Drury College boys dined with a local negro preacher. There were other negroes present. The first President of the college, Dr. Morrison, and its late President, Dr. Ingalls, brother of ex-Senator Ingalls, believed in co-education of the races.

There are stories from the West afloat among racing men here to the effect that Chris Smith, owner of the Kendall Stable and the most desperate plunger on the turf, is "broke," and that his stable of horses will have to be sold to meet his indebtedness. This in spite of the fact that his stable, which cost him about $35,000 to run during the season, won about $80,000 in stakes and purses.
Now that the trolley system is likely to get a foothold on Manhattan Island, the insurance men are seriously contemplating increasing the rates on all risks in New-York City.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The latest advices from St. Petersburg and other parts of Russia show that the persecution of the Jews and the inhumanity of the Czar's officials toward that unhappy race are greater than ever before. Six edicts have been issued aiming to disperse the Jewish, subjects of Russia, weaken their position in the trading centres, and crash out their religion.

Paris, Dec. 29. -- M. Castelbon, who was in the list of the twenty-six Thierree checks as having received a check for 20,000f. from Baron Reinach, was a witness before the Panama Commission of the Chamber of Deputies to-day.

President Newton of the Coney Island Athletic Club last night denied the report that he canceled the McAuliffe-Burge fight because he heard rumors of a deal between the two pugilists. He does not believe that McAuliffe would resort to such tactics. The failure to arrange the fight can, he says, alone be attributed to Burge.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 29. -- The good folks of Long Island will be very much disappointed to-morrow morning when they learn that they have been deprived of a fertile subject of gossip by the lizzle of the duel which it was announced would take place at Woodside, a little town about three miles out of this city tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29. -- On Christmas Eve two negroes went into the country store of A. Silver at Luling, in St. Oharles Parian, a short distance above New Orleans, to buy something. They did not make a purchase, however, and started out. Emannel Bastel, a white man, who was clerking in the store, proceeded to close up his place and was about to put in the bolts when some one knocked on the door.

The rapid-transit franchise was offered for sale at noon yesterday in the rotunda of the City Hall without success, although what purported to be a bid and an alternate bid were made for the franchise. The bid proposed to give $500 cash and one-half of 1 per cent. yearly of the gross receipts for the full term of the lease of 999 years.

The Manhattan Athletic Club is going to try a now deal. It is going to make a great effort to straighten out the tangle in its financial affairs. Last night it settled this point, and the members who attended the special meeting at which the policy was outlined and indorsed displayed such interest and enthusiasm that the officers of the club are confident that it will be carried out.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 29. -- A hard fight is being made by the District Attorney's office to enforce the act commonly known as the Sunday law, which has for some years lapsed into desuetude. Urged on by the newly-appointed Judges of the Criminal Court and the Grand Jury, District Attorney Butler and Assistant District Attorney Adams demand that the police shall arrest all barkeepers and others discovered in the actual violation of the act.

HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 29. -- An explosion occurred at Milnesville this morning by which eight men narrowly escaped instant death. As it is, three of them, James Jamison, Abra Kolokoski, and Monroe Fritzinger, are dangerously wounded and the other five loss seriously hurt.

PANAMA, Dec. 22. -- From the Central American republic of Salvador comes an account of an attempt to assassinate the President. A banquet was given in Sonsonate to President Ezeta, and the invited guests were seated at a table when a policeman entered and arrested an individual who had been introduced as a servant.
