PARIS, Dec. 29. -- An explosion at 1:30 o'clock this morning in the hall leading to the suite of offices between the ground floor and the first story of the Prefecture of Police has caused a sensation. The authorities are not decided as to whether the explosion was the work of Anarchists or merely an accident caused by a leakage of gas.

In the hold of the steamship Galileo, which arrived yesterday from Hull, England, were the three prize St. Bernard dogs bought by Col. Jacob Rupport, Jr. The dogs were taken yesterday from Wilson's Piers, Brooklyn, to the Dutchess Kennel, 1,639 Third Avenue, where Col. Ruppert will keep them for breeding and show purposes.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 29. -- The excitement to Long Island City created, by the tragical dynamite explosion of yesterday, which killed five persons and maimed half a hundred others, has not yet subsided. Developments have rather intensified popalar indignation over the occurrence. Crowds have surrounded the spot all day.

The two hundredth anniversary of the introduction of the art of printing in New-York is to be celebrated on the 12th of April next by a dinner at Delmonioo's. The dinner will be given under the management of the Typothetao Society and the printing and publishing trades Of this city.

One man lost his life and a man and a boy were badly injured in a fire that broke out at 7:30 o'clock last night on the ground floor of the four-story brick building 3 Mechanic Alley, a narrow passage running from Monroe to Cherry Street, between Market and Pike Streets. The building, which is an old-fashioned structure, is in the rear of 7-4 Monroe Street, and is owned by Thomas Joyce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- At the request of Postmaster General Wanamaker, A.B. Maze, the Superintendent of Mails in the New-York City Post Office, came over from New-York this morning and joined in a conference with the loading officials of the Post-Office Department as to what, if anything, can further he done to relieve the extreme pressure for room in the New-York City Post Office.

The open declaration of President-elect Cleveland against the candidacy of Edward Murphy. Jr., for the Senate was discussed by many politicians yesterday. Those who had favored Mr. Murphy ever since he was first announced as the Tammany candidate were for the most part emphatic in their declarations that Mr. Murphy would receive as many votes to-day as he would have received before Mr. Cleveland's declaration was made public.

Mr. RICHARD W. THOMPSON, who resigned the office of Secretary of the Navy in Mr. HAYES'S Cabinet to become Chairman of the Panama Canal Company's American Committee, emerges again from his seclusion at Terre Haute, Ind., to assert that he has no knowledge of a single cent having been expended to influence legislation [in this country] in favor of the company, or of the existence of a lobby for that purpose."

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Buel, well known as a learned theologian of the Protestant Episcopal Church, died at the family residence, 344 West Eighteenth Street, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. Dr. Buel was formerly Emeritus Professor of Systematic Divinity and Dogmatic Theology in the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

DOVER, N. H., Dec. 30. -- A dispatch from Capt. Philpot of the schooner Mary E.H.G. Dow, which is ashore at the mouth of Chesa. peake Bay. near Caps Charles, states that the vessel will be a total loss. She cost upward of $60,000, and between $25,000 and $30,000 of the stock is owned here. Mrs. Dow. for whom the vessel is named, has $13,000 invested.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- The caucus on the United States Senatorship will be held in the Assembly Chamber on Monday night, Jan. 16. On the following day each of the co-ordinate branches will ballot. On Wednesday, the 18th, both houses will meet in joint session in the Assembly Chamber, Lieut. Gov. Sheehan presiding, and will formally ballot.
In regard to the plan of uniting the Brooklyn Elevated Road and the Kings County Road, Edward Lauterbach said yesterday:
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 30. -- The Evening Herald, one of the leading Democratic papers or Georgia, speaking of Senator Hill's present attitude, says editorially:

A gay crowd of young people danced last night away at Jaeger's, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The party was organized by Miss Bessie Baltes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fernando Baltes of 100 East Seventy-third Street, and about 100 young people attended.

The Fifth Avenue Protective Association, as will be seen by our news columns, has modified the bill it caused, to be introduced into the legislature last year to prevent the use of Fifth Avenue for heavy traffic. The modifications tend to render the bill more acceptable, perhaps, to those who opposed it last year.
The Umbria is safe. She was sighted off Fire Island just after midnight proceeding slowly toward this port.

There was little new developed yesterday about the financial side of the failure of Wayland Trask Co., bankers and brokers, of 18 Wall Street, who suspended Thursday. Expert accountants who had been set at work on the books of the firm had not completed their work, and nobody knew the exact amount of the assets and liabilities.

ROME, Dec. 30. -- The Pope is greatly incensed at the opposition displayed to Mgr. Satolli and a peaceful and moderate solution of the school question in the United States. The Pope has already on several occasions given expression to his feelings on the subject with considerable warmth:

Six new cases of typhus fever were presented to the attention of the health authorities yesterday. Two of the cases were discovered early in the forenoon. The other four cases were found later in the day, making nine cases in all that the health authorities now have on their hands.
Adrian H. Fairchild, one of the most expert and best-known, divers and submarine explorers, met with sudden death yesterday morning while thirty-five foot below the surface of the water.

The most surprising occurrence of recent times is the sudden announcement of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners that they propose to give up the task which they were appointed to perform and upon which they have been working for two years, because the offer of the franchise for their underground railroad did not result in any substantial bid from bona-fide capitalists.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 30. -- United States Marshal Paul Fricke to-day received a telegram from Deputy Marshal Eugene Yglesias of Webb County. He said he had just received advices by wire from Guerrero, Mexico, that Second Lieut. C.A. Hedekin, with Troop G, Third Cavairy, and Deputy United States Marshal "Pink" Hall and his posse were in hot pursuit of a detachment of Mexican bandits in Zapata County, Texas.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The boom for James Smith, Jr., for United States Senator shows signs of unusual activity in this (Essex) county -- which is Mr. Smith's home, by the way. The Joel Parker Association, one of the most considerable political organizations in this city, declared for him last night. The Rosoville Democratic Association did likewise at about the same hour.

"Deacon" S.V. White completed a great achievement yesterday by paying off the last of his creditors. He mailed checks to all of them for the fall amount of their claims against him, with interest from the time of the smash of the corner he attempted to run in September corn in 1891.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The championship iceyacht pennant of New-Jersey remains at Red Bank, and the North Shrewsbury yachtsmen are happy. The race to decide the ownership of the trophy for the ensuing year was sailed, here this afternoon. It was open only to third-class yachts, the challenger being the Burlington Ice Yacht Club, which had a yacht built two years ago especially for the purpose of racing for the trophy.

That New Year's, with its round of sociability, is at our doors is apparent at a glance over the shopping centres of the city. In every neighborhood where retail stores abound the streets are filled with eager shoppers, laying in stocks of finery for the New Year's season.
Mrs. Annetta Ahrons, a German widow seventy-seven years old, was found dead yesterday morning in her bedroom in the frame house 424 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Wall Street was much interested -- as were hosts of people outside of Wall Street -- in THE TIMES'S chronicle yesterday of the quiet little conference at the New Club on Fifth Avenue last Sunday between Secretary of the Treasury Foster and some of Wall Street's important financiers.

The annual performance of Handel's masterpiece, "The Messiah," is now regarded as one of the fixtures of the musical season. The familiar oratorio seems, since too musical taste of the city has been subjected to the vitalizing in fluence of German opera, to have taken a fresh hold on the popular fancy, and it is now one of the strongest attractions of the concert list.

The cold spell, preceded by a gale along the Long island shores, sent the ducks flying southward in a hurry. Some seasons the web-footed fowl do not depart from the Great South Bay from Fall till Spring, when they go to the North to nest. They are the hardy black ducks that thus remain, provided the bay is clear of ice and the temperature does not get too cold.

The exactions and offensive, unbusinesslike methods of the District Telegraph Companies of this city have at last aroused the wrath of a foeman worthy of their steel. That well-known fighter, Lawyer George Bliss of 54 West Thirty-ninth Street, is in a belligerent mood and stands ready to lead an assault on wires of the company that are strung over and attached to private houses without authority from any source.
The following correspondence between Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell and Miss Elien Collins and the Supervisory Board of the New-York City Civil Service Boards is self-explanatory:

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- It is doubtful whether the capital of New-York State, or any other State, has ever been so thoroughly dead seventy-two hours before the assembling of the State Legislature as Albany is to-night. Up to 11 o'clock only one of the 160 members of the Legislature had reported, Jacob Rice of Ulster, and he became so terrified over the death-like stillness that he returned by the first train to his home.

Manager Benton, the representative of Burge, the English fighter, has prepared a statement in view of the many contradictory reports regarding the failure to make a match with "Jack" McAuliffe. He says that when he reached New-York he failed to find any one authorized to act for the Coney Island club for two days. Then Judge Newton, the President, was seen for ten minutes.

-- Alfred W. Bates, a dry goods commission merchant of this city, and member of the firm of Faulkner, Page Co., died of pneumonia on Thursday at his home, 113 West Seventy-second Street. Mr. Bates was born in 1835 at Mansfield, Mass., and went into the dry goods business at an early age as a clerk in the firm of Lawrence, Stine Co., in Boston.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- The Superior Court Grand Jury, which for several weeks has been considering election fraud cases, this afternoon presented indictments against Alderman William Summers of the Fifth Ward, Julius Haas of the State Department of Health, George T. Crowley, brother of Democratic Assessor Thomas Crowley, and Patrick J. Quirk.

An authority high in the Catholic Church has advanced an ingenious plan by which any friction on account of Dr. McGlynn's reinstatement may be done away with. The gentleman stated his views in the premises as if he thought the plan would be the one adopted by the Church authorities.

All eyes have turned lately to William Newland Amory, promoter of public enterprises, financier, and man of affairs. He has just now achieved fame, if not fortune. The latter may be on the eve of coming to aim. It is confidently believed by his friends as by himself that this will come about if he shall be permitted to carry through the projects which he has now in hand.

A fine family row, involving the alleged kidnapping of an old man worth about $200,000, was aired yesterday before Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court. The story came out in the course of a hearing on a writ of habeas corpus issued by Judge Lawrence on Dec. 21 for the production in court of John Graham, who made a large fortune some years ago as a blacksmith and a real estate operator.

Controller Myers yesterday sold the franchise for the extension of the Ninth Avenue surface railroad up Columbus Avenue from Sixty-fourth Street to One Hundred and Tenth Street, with a braneh through One Hundred and Sixth Street to Amsterdam Avenue, to connect with the Tenth Avenue road.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 30. -- Seven hundred delegates were present at the meeting to-day of the Indian National Congress at Allahabad, the capital of the Northwest Provinces. The congress includes many of the ablest of the native Indians, and the resolutions submitted showed the growing spirit in favor of Indian self-government.

It was declared yesterday in well-posted naval circles that Bear Admiral A.E.R. Benham will shortly succeed Acting Rear Admiral John G. Walker in command of the North Atlantic squadron. It was further said that Secretary Traoy proposes making Benham second in command to Gherardi during the Columbian naval review if it be possible to effect this arrangement by orders issued before Secretary Tracy has left the Navy Department.
The coming of the new year will bring one change among down-town business men which will be of great interest to many all over the world who are interested in advertising.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Interest in the will of the multi-millionaire D. Edgar Crouse was revived to-day by the announcement that the heirs had a meeting and in the expectancy of litigation on the part of Mrs. Kosterlitz on behalf of her daughter, Dorothea Edgarita Crouse Wilson, had appointed a committee to take charge of whatever matter might come before it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- According to a local paper some of the most serious charges of discrimination ever made against American railroads have just been filed with the Inter-State Commerce Commission by William C. Bissell of San Francisco. Every charge is backed up by the positive testimony of correspondence between interested officials and the published tariffs of the railroads.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- "This is a reform, and an economical administration," said Gov. Flower this afternoon upon learning that Charles F. Peck of the Bureau of Labor Statistics had lopped off half a dozen branches Iron his office. "When informed that Peek had promised to restore some of the deposed clerks on March 1, the Governor's eyes twinkled.
The following additional amounts are reported on account of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection by the General Treasurer, Charles Lanier, 17 Nassau Street:

The Wall-Paper Trust is making rapid progress in its effort to acquire a complete monopoly of the business in this country. There are only two dozen factories of any size in the United States, and of these the trust now has under its wing about all but two -- that of William Campbell Co. on West Forty-second Street, this city, and that of M.H. Birge's Sons Co. of Buffalo.

Three gray-coated policemen stood guard on the little lake in Central Part near the Fifth Avenue entrance yesterday forenoon and hardened their hearts like three Pharaohs and would not let the children go on the ice.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 30. -- Major Gillain of the Guards and Eugene Vanderbergen, Krupp's resident agent, fought a duel in a private garden on the Bois de la Cambre last night. Vanderbergen was shot through the heart and died instantly.

The Police Commissioners held their final meeting for the year yesterday, and in addition to making a number or promotions and transfers went through the formality of dismissing Roundsman Matthew F. Dailey from the force.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30. -- At this morning's session of the Geological Society a telegram was read from Sir William Daweon, the newly-elected President of the society, from Savannah. Ga., thanking his fellow-geologists for the honor conferred upon him.

A festival was held yesterday at the beautiful new home of the American Fine Arts Society, in West Fifty-seventh Street At 4 o'clock in the afternoon George W. Vanderbilt announced to the Trustees of the Gift Fund, of which Henry G. Marquand is President that he would give the organization $100,000 as its Christmas and New Year's present.

ODESSA, Dec. 30. -- Letters from Tashkend report that Gen. Baranok, who recently dial at that town and is generally believed to have been poisoned by persons having cause to apprehend the result of the administrative reforms which he was about to introduce in Turkestan, had in hand at the time of his death a commission of exceptional delicacy and difficulty.

Yesterday was ladies day at the intercollegiate chess tournament. The fair sex was very well represented, and watched the games with intense interest. Every girl wore the color other favorite college.

Outline plans of John Jacob Astor's proposed new house or palace at Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, made by Richard M. Hunt, are now on file in the Park Department, and the Park Commissioners have approved of them. Their approval was necessary because two bay windows on Fifth Avenue jut out for 3 feet over the sidewalk, and two similar windows on Sixty-fifth Street jut out 2 feet.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec., 30. -- Congressman Jerry simpson has arrived, and already he assumes the role of dictator, declaring what shall and shall not be done. He says that the people of Kansas intended that the Populists should have the Legislature, and if through some error they did not receive enough votes to elect both houses, they should have them anyway, and he will see that they get them.

Although they were plainly in a state of exultation the members of the Manhattan Railway Company's recently-appointed Committee on Extensions and Improvements, through which the "co-operation" between the elevated railroad people and the Rapid-Transit Commission is being carried on, were yesterday very reticent when asked to divulge their plans for extending the elevated system to accommodate the necessities of rapid transit.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 30. -- Assiatant City Clerk John P. Hayes has done much to-day to right the wrong done Mayor-elect Sanford by the missing City Clerk. Thomas P. Burke. Intrusted by Judge Bartlett with the task of hunting up the Election Inspectors of eleven city districts and having their returns corrected by Saturday, he has had this done in seven cases, and expects to have two more early in the morning.

The recent dismissal of many employes of the Long Island Railroad has led to speculation as to its cause by those not intimate with the workings of the road. It was learned yesterday that President Austin Corbin proposes to weed out vigorously those of his employes in responsible positions who drink. He has issued an order to that effect.

From the Rochester Post-Express. We presume that behind the immediate controversy Hostile important issue of a constitution for the Catholic Church of the United States. For years the authorities at Borne have arced the adoption of a settled organization which will secure the rights of the priests; and the American Bishops have op posed a change, maintaining that the best interests of the Church require the missionary system which, has prevailed hitherto.

Among the passengers on the steamer Lahn, which arrived in port yesterday morning, was Senator William B. Allison of Iowa. The Senator was Chairman of the American delegation to the International Monetary Conference. All his associates he left in Europe. Senator John C. Jones is still at Brussels, keeping track of the translators, who are turning his speech into French.

The entry list for the annual boxing and wrestling championships of the Amateur Athletic Union is a long one and contains the names of many who have long successful in the specialty. Mr. M.W. Moore of this city will act as referee at the contests, which are to be held in Philadelphia next Thursday and Saturday under the direction of the Philadelphia Amateur Swimming Club.

The big Glasgow liner Pomeranian sailed from Glasgow Dec. 16 bound for this port. Coincident with her departure the New-Jersey pilot boat E.E. Barrett left the Highlands astern and stood out to the eastward, cruising for incoming ships. The two met three days ago in a locality more than 500 miles to the eastward of this port.

BOSTON, Dec. 30. -- "The Knickerbockers," the Bestonians' new opera, is to have its first presentation on any stage at the Tremont Theatre, this city, next Thursday evening. Mr. Harry B. Smith, the librettist, has written a good many jingle verses, and if Mr. DeKoven's music is all that it seems to be in rehearsal, the new piece is in a fair way to duplicate the "Robin Hood " hit.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 30. -- Detectives from Chicago agencies and the local authorities this morning began a crusade against the car robbers. For months large quantities of valuable goods have been stolen from Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad and Philadelphia and Erie Railroad trains. During the month of December the Lake Shore has lost over $10,000 worth of goods.
John N. Senia, for twenty years the chimer of Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, died at his residence, 128 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Nothing has yet been done at the Navy Department concerning the award at contracts for the Iowa and the Brooklyn. The Secretary was at the department to-day and saw Mr. Boost of the Union Iron Works and the representatives of the Newport News Company. Later in the day he talked with Charles Cramp.

-- The students of the Royal College of Music recently performed Gluck's says about this is what the Pall Mall Gazette says about the contralto: "The Orpheus of Miss Clara Butt was more than merely satisfactory. She has a fine contralto voice, full and sweet, and or coniderable power; it is remarkably even in tone, and her transition to the lower notes almost unnoticable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The extension of the term of Commodore A.W. Weaver as the commandant of the Norfolk Navy Yard, as noted in these dispatches, is to be of short duration. He will be detached from that yard on Jan. 16 and will become President of the Naval Retiring Board in this city, relieving Rear Admiral Greer, who will continue as Chairman of the Lighthouse Board.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30. -- A picturesque procession of men filed up from the wharf of the Eastern Shore Steamboat Company to Marshal Airey's office this afternoon. They arrived on the boat from Crisfield, and were the first batch of oyster dredgers taken from the pungles, bugeyes, and sloops engaged in the oyster trade down the bay.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- Premier Ribot held a conference to-day with M. Loubet, Minister of the Interior, and M. Bourgeois, Minister of Justice, for the purpose of discussing with them measures to frustrate the plans of the Socialists and Anarchists of Paris. A matter for special consideration was the proposed organization of Socialists and Anarchists for the purpose of taking advantage of the present political excitement to overthrow the present form of Government.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 30. -- Some excitement was caused in operatic and theatrical circles here to-day by the tragic death of Elsa Roge. Several months ago, while fulfilling an engagement here she became acquainted with Prince Stolewski, and he finally induced her to leave the stage.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- At to-day's session of the University Extension Conference the Rev. Herbert Alleman of the Chambersburg (Penn.) Centre was the first speaker. The aim of his paper was to show how the local body could become the agent in organizing other similar bodies in contiguous towns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Some of the Democrats here who are not so much shocked as some others because Mr. Grover Cleveland has taken the liberty of saying that he considers inadvisable the proposition to elect Mr. Edward Murphy, Jr., to be a Senator of the United States have directed attention to some of the critics of Mr. Cleveland as being unfair and one-sided in their objections and dictations.

The observance of New Year's Day in New-York has fallen into absolute desuetude within the last ten years. The custom of calling, which was once considered the solemn duty of every self-respecting man, has long been declared obsolete. At present we are content to simply rest from our labors of the week before, perhaps the more conveniently to meditate on the awful possibilities of another twelvemonth.

The beautiful clubhouse of the Players in Gramercy Park was the scene of a notable gathering last night, when, in accordance with their custom, the Players assembled for their annual celebration of Founder's Night. This celebration occurs on New Year's Eve, and on this night alone of all the year outsiders are not allowed in the clubhouse.

Mayor Grant received two reports from the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday. One was the result of their investigation into the affairs of the Department of Charities and Correction covering the years 1888, 1889, and 1890, and the other was the result of their investigation into the affairs of the Board of Education and covered 1888, 1889, 1890 and 1891.

Thursday evening comes the first Assembly ball in the Madison Square Garden. The Assembly balls are awaited with more anticipation even than the dances of the Patriarchs, as the dance is larger and the younger element in the married and unmarried sets is given the preference when the invitations are issued. The first of the Assembly balls will be the larger of the two.

A mail pouch which left this city Dec. 22 in a mail car on the New-York Central Railroad was missing when the train reached Albany. Antonio Sperda, an Italian employed in crushing stone at Cold Spring, Putnam County, was arrested yesterday by Post Office Inspector Shopp charged with opening and extracting letters from the pouch, but how he came into its possession is considerable of a mystery.

Acting under instructions of the Sinking Fund Commissioners of this city, Corporation Counsel Clark will prepare several amendments to the Swan New-York, New-Jersey, and Hudson River Bridge bill. Those amendments will, if adopted by the Legislature, interfere very materially with the present plans of the bridge company, by cutting off various proposed approaches to the bridge.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 31. -- In order more closely to cement their interests and to stop the cutting of prices the plate-glass manufacturers of the United States have appointed a general agent to sell the product of their factories and distribute the orders. The agent elected is S.E. Wheeler, General Manager of the Standard Plate Glass Works at Butler.

The city's budget for 1893 was passed and signed in the Mayor's office just after 11:30 o'clock yesterday forenoon. The Board of Estimate and Apportionment, made up of Mayor Grant, Controller Myers, President Barter of the Tax Department, and President John H.V. Arnold of the Board of Aldermen, met at 10:30 o'clock to finish up the work and complete and sign the budget before the Saturday half holiday.

The "Little Mothers" who are so generoualy cared for during the hot Summer months are not forgotten when Winter sets in. The brightest incidents in the lives of these children of the poor, who are housekeepers as well as babytenders in their tenement-house homes, are the Summer-day vacations at Pelham Bay Park and the celebrations of Thanksgiving. Christmas, and Easter.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31. -- The last week of the old year has been a very cold one, and Christmas and the days following were genuinely oldfashioned if ice and snow could make them so. The festivities of Christmas extended over Monday, and much family feasting and many Christmas trees kept the ball going that day.

The fact that Henry M. Cornell was somewhere in Europe, and therefore could not join with his brother, J.M. Cornell, and his mother, Minnie R.D. Cornell, in signing the satisfaction piece of a mortgage, led to the refusal of Register Fitzgerald to cancel the mortgage.

Now that Prof. Charles Augustus Briggs has been acquitted of the heresy charges that have been hanging over his head for the past fourteen months, Presbyterians everywhere are asking how it came about. The only answer is the good American one, that he had a majority of the votes. What the end of it all is going to tie is also generally asked.
Mrs. Etta Harrington, a nervoas, hysterical woman, thirty-two years old, shot herselt in the left breast about midnight Friday night for a most extraordinary reason.

When Balzac wrote "Le Dernier Chouan" the first romance signed by him, Charles X. was King and a reactionary tendency had set in. The date of "The Chouans" is 1829, and 1830 was to bring the downfall of the Bourbon King and place an Orleanist on the throne. With inconceivable force and power of contrast.

From the Philadelphia Record. Examination of the World's Fair souvenir half-dollar coins with a microscope or small magnifying glass reveals on the collar surrounding the imprint of the head of Columbus a tiny letter "B." After the "B" has once been discerned by the aid of the glass it can be plainly seen by the naked eye.

ASBURY PARK, Dec. 31. -- The most extensive realty transaction over made in this part of New-Jersey was completed this week by Milan Ross of this town, who represents a syndicate of Now-York and Detroit capitalists. The land comprised in the deal includes the Hathaway. Drummond, and Uendrickson farms at Deal Beach.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 31. -- Triumphant Democracy is the condition here now. Senator F. E. Warren, along with his domination and oppressive ring, has been ignominiously defeated. They are put to rout completely and the people are in the saddle once again. Conservative men say that Wyoming will be Democratic for the next ten years.

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- The Attorney General has handed down an opinion upon the application of the State Commission in Lunacy to compel the Brunswick Home, a corporation at Amityville, Suffolk County, for the cure of idiots, epileptics, and persons of unsound mind, to procure a license from the commission or go out of business.

The long-drawn-out marksman's badge, with its nearly score of bars, is an eyesore to the State official having in his charge the shooting interests of the National Guard, and its replacement by a decoration which shall be more in keeping with the fitness of things has been recommended and will be urged on artistic grounds by the head of the Department of Rifle Practice, Brig. Gen. Whitlock, upon the military authorities at Albany.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31. -- Miss Mary Elizabeth Garrett's gift of $306,977 to Johns Hopkins University, in addition to the $47,787.50 which She had previously given to the fund for the Medical School, is a happy and interesting culmination to a long chapter of the university's history.

The following full data of the recent international armor test at St. Petersburg arrived by the Umbria's Russian mail of yesterday. The account deals with the test of the Victors Harveyized solid steel plate, which is the plate of the type recently adopted for the new battle ships of the United States.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 31. -- The proposal to prohibit immigration into the United States next year has led to a good deal of discussion in Canada. The occasion may be a favorable one to secure a large number of settlers for the Dominion. On this question Goldwin Smith today said:

The annual futile cry of the public against speculating in theatre tickets is going up, and newspapers are urged by correspondents who are aggrieved by the tax of the speculators to renew the fight against this species of petty extortion. It is a hopeless fight from the very nature of things, because, practically, the only agency by which it can be won is the aggrieved public itself, and that agency refuses to act.

Landing Agent Moore, at Ellis Island, yesterday issued the following statement of the number of steerage and cabin passengers that came from Europe each month of the past year, and of the number of steamers that brought them:

The restoration of Dr. McGLYNN to the Roman Catholic priesthood and the acquittal of Dr. BRIGGS from the charge of heresy are two events that show forth with great clearness the modernization or Americanization of the Churches concerned. The offense charged was in one case an offense against discipline and in the other an offense against doctrine.

Sam and I had boon loitering along the summit of the main cascade range hunting white grouse and the extension of a silver load that I desired to locate. Below us and stretching to the northeast and southwest the great glacier of Thunder Creek glistened in the strong sunlight. We had been fairly successful in killing grouse, and not at all successful in finding the extension of the Little Ruby silver lead.

Just after the adjournment of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday, Willis Holly, the Mayor's secretary, and Commissioner Holme, who was formerly the Mayor's secretary. Invited Mayor Grant to step into the inner office, where the employes of the office had already gathered. As soon as he arrived, the covering was pulled off a life-size bronze bust of the Mayor, and thereupon Mr. Holly made a presentation speech.

JAMAICA, L. I., Dec. 31. -- For the last three or four years Jamaica had an odd character within its gates in the person of Edward Cornelius Freel, who was eccentric to the last degree and who uncomplainingly bore the jibes of feeble wits, whose jests his peculiarities and queer appearance subjected him to.

Vernon H. Brown, General Agent of the Cunard Line, had not been home for two days, when seen at his office in Bowling Green yesterday afternoon, a few hours after the Umbria had been made fast to her dock. He was a very tired looking man, bat in spite of that he acted as if he was exceedingly happy.

The safe arrival of the Umbria, after a voyage of fourteen days, is an illustration not so much of the dangers of the sea as of the triumph over these dangers of modern science in ship building and navigation. A generation ago a voyage of this duration would have been a "crack passage." The modern steamer is commonly supposed to be a helpless bulk so soon as her machinery is disabled.

The question of rapid transit for this city is quite independent of that of improving the existing facilities for local travel. The present systems need improving, but they can adequately supply only the means of communication from one part of the city to another for relatively short distances.

The manager of a fashionable glove shop up town fell to talking the other day about the making of kid gloves. "Only a small percentage of the gloves sold as kid are such." he said. "Millions of kid gloves are demanded while comparatively only a few goats are raised in the world, and of these a large number must be kept until full grown for breeding purposes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- The week at the theatres has been a pleasurable one. Two new plays of merit have been produced, and public recognition of their excellence and the excellence of their production has been prompt.

Ex-Gov. Henry C. Baldwin of Detroit, who has been ill for several weeks, died yesterday afternoon. The cause of his death was old age principally, along with a complication, of stomach and other troubles.

WENATCHEE, Washington, Dec. 31. -- The term Evergreen State as applied to Washington is beautiful but deceptive. It has given the people of the East the impression that the whole State is a vast unbroken forest region. Even some who have made a tour of the Northwest have a firm belief to that effect.

According to the report of the Health Department for last year there have been 16,001 marriages, 49,437 births, and 44,317 deaths here since last New Year's Day. That is an increase over the previous year of 237 in marriages, 2,533 in births, and 658 in deaths. The number of marriages was 154 above the average for the last five years, and the number of births was 8,317 greater than the average for the same period.

The Virginia Chapter of Colonial Dames, which has just been formed at Richmond, Va., promises to be one of the most brilliant of the many branches of the national society. The rules for admission to it are very strict, only ladies of the highest lineage, whose ancestors fought and aided in the Revolution and held high positions, are eligible to membership.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- On the nomination of Col. McDonald, United States Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, the President has appointed Dr. Tarleton H. Bean assistant in charge of the Division of Fish Culture. United States Fish Commission, as the representative of the commission on the Government Board of Management and Control of the World's Columbian Exposition, vice Capt J.W. Collins, resigned.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 31. -- To-night has been an occasion of grave concern to thoughtful citizens in Long Island City, and signs have not been wanting to prove that a crisis in the city's affairs is near at hand. It seems as if little provocation were needed to cause a riot.

Isaac A. Hopper, who has been named as a possible successor of Mayor-elect Gilroy as Commissioner of Public Works, is a resident of Harlem, a School Commissioner, and one of the leading builders in the city. Mr. Hopper is a man of marked executive ability and thoroughly familiar with the conduct and management of large works, both public and private.

"No one would imagine," said a railroad, passenger accent a few days ago, "the extent to which railroads seek individual custom. I do not mean little cross-country roads, but all railroads, from the smallest to the greatest in the country. The general belief is that a railroad is a great grasping corporation that cares for nobody, and that any one who wishes to do business with it must go to it.

TOPEKA, Dec. 31. -- The "Brotherhood of Soldiers" and the "Boys in Blue," two new organizations, with Generals, Major Generals, Colonels, and Captains as officers, have been instituted with a common purpose, although they occupy different fields. They have in view another raid on the Treasury of the General Government, offering in exchange for lawful money their past services as patriots in the army.

-- The British cruiser Curacoa which recently on her arrival at Sydney from Samoa reported striking on a rock in the Jaudi waters at a spot where the chart indicated twelve fathoms. The tide was rising and the ship was got off in an hour after striking with but slight damage to her copper. During the voyage the British flag was hoisted at Dangar, Gardner, Nassau, and other islands.

Mrs. Moses Taylor, who died yesterday at the old Taylor Mansion, 122 Fifth Avenue, was the widow of Moses Taylor, one of the wealthiest bankers in New-York City. Mrs. Taylor was born eighty-three years ago, and was the daughter of a tradesman in this city named Wilson. She married Moses Taylor, who was a self-made man, when a very young girl.

The negotiations openly begun Friday between the Rapid-Transit Commissioners and the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company furnished an important topic of discussion yesterday through the business districts.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- The effect of the propulsive power of the mainspring of the Democratic machine was illustrated in Lowville to-day, when the Lewis County cog of the Wheel put in its work in the shape of a minute passed by the County Committee. The action of the committee reminds one of the way in which the snap caucuses and conventions of the last Winter were held.

With this initial volume the Messrs. Putnam enter upon another of a series of enterprises from which in late years they have derived enviable honor. Their editions of the writings of the statesmen who, in the last century and early in this, laid the broad foundations on which has risen the imposing fabric of this free and mighty Nation, have been admired wherever known, and have awakened among political students a general sense of gratitude.

Habeas corpus proceedings for the release of John Murray and Gustav Darton from an imprisonment of sixty days to which Justice Brischer had condemned them engaged the attention of Judge Lippincott in the Hudson County (N.J.) Common Plea.

Commissioner of Public Works Thomas F. Gilroy sent his last report to Mayor Grant yesterday. It covered the operations of the Department of Public Works for the year 1892. A digest of it furnished to the reporters is as follows:

ORANGE, Dec. 31. -- One of the most enjoyable social events of the week was the dance given at the Essex County Country Club Wednesday night by Mrs. William A. Brewer, in honor of her daughter, Miss Clara Brewer. The ball and supper rooms were handsomely decorated. About 200 young people were present from all parts of Essex County and New-York.

Frederic Romington, the well-known illustrator, is about to give an exhibition of a hundred of his paintings at the rooms of the American Art Association in Twenty-third Street. They will be shown during the seven days following Jan. 6, and will be sold on the last day of the exhibition. A very great proportion of the subjects of those paintings are Western, and deal with frontier army and Indian life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- This was the last day which Commodore William M. Folger put in at the Navy Department as Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- The most interesting boat under construction in this city at the present time is andoubtedly the forty-six-foot fin-keel Carmita, which Waterhouse Cheseborough have designed for Mr. C.H.W. Foster, owner of the forty-six-footer Barbara, the Fife design, which was handsome to look at, but which was not quite so speedy as the Burgess and the Herreshoff fliers.

President Gustav Schwab or the North German Lloyd Steamship Line and Dr. George Q. Glavis of Washington rendered the members and guests of the Gridiron Club of Washington a dinner last night on board the steamship Lahn at her dock, Hoboken.

The Hydrographic Office in Washington has issued the January pilot chart of the North Atlantic. The chart shows three derelict vessels in the transatlantic steamship lines southward of the British Isles.

One charm of Col. Dodge's Great Captains Series is the absolute frankness with which he makes known his estimates of the campaigns and the characters of his heroes. There is not a quality or attribute that belongs to soldiership on which he hesitates to say how he relatively ranks the world's foremost military leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Senator Chandler, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Immigration, has returned from New-York, in company with Senator Harris, the Chairman of the Committee on Epidemic Diseases; Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service, and Dr. Hamilton, who established Camp Low last Fall by direction of the Treasury Department.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Dec. 31. -- Three little colored children were burned to death at Stony Brook at dusk yesterday. There were four children in the house, the eldest a boy of ten years and the youngest two years. Only one of the four children escaped.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn yesterday received the formal notice of the appointment of a committee by the New-York Tariff Association of Underwriters to investigate the management of the Brooklyn Fire Department, and at once arranged to have the gentlemen moot him in the City Hall on Wednesday next at 11 A.M.

LENOX, Mass., Dec. 31. -- The mercury has reached zero or below nearly every day this week. This fact alone has made the few cottagers who remain think of going to New-York. D.W. Bishop, David Lydig, and Richard Goodman will shut up their places in a few days and spend the remaining cold weather in that city.

The authorities of Columbia College announce a series of lectures at 11 o'clock Saturday mornings, beginning this weak, in co-operation with the Motropolitan Museum of Art. The lectures will be illustrated with specimens, which, when necessary, will be projected by the stereopticon. No tickets of admission will be required. The first lecture wiil be by Russell Sturgis on "How Styles Originate and Grow."

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- The careful presentation in to-day's NEW-YORK. TIMES of the political career and political methods of Edward Murphy, Jr., the candidate of the regency for United States Senator, was widely read, and it produced an effect that bodes anything but future comfort to the machine should the plan now agreed upon be carried out.

The splendid work done by the National League for Good Roads is bearing ample fruit. Every day the Secretary of the league receives numerous letters of inquiry and of support from every quarter of the Union. County leagues are forming everywhere, and at the national convention, which will take place at Washington on Jan. 17, over two-thirds of the States in the Union will be represented.

A public meeting to devise means for protecting the terminals of the Erie Canal has been called by a number of boat owners to take place Wednesday at 1 o'clock at Kingston Hall, 10 South Street. All friends of the State's free canal system are urged to be present.

At a special meeting of the members of the Home Benefit Association called yesterday at the offices, 137 Broadway, it was decided to wind up the affairs of the concern and adopt a proposition made by the Commercial Alliance Life Insurance Company to re-insure all the Home Benefit's risks. The change was not effected without opposition, but the vote to carry out the plan was almost unanimous.

From the Portland (Me.) Press. In the office of the New Light Company in the Union Mutual Building are displayed several samples of the models of Maine fish which are to be exhibited at Chicago. These models are made of gelatine, of life size, from living models, and painted so accurately that the oldest angler would be deceived.

Alfred Carr, who formerly conducted a business of stock brokerage at 36 Pine Street, under the name of Alfred Carr Co., and who was arrested in Boston last Friday, where he had been engaged in the same business under the name of William H. Albertson, arrived in this city yesterday in the custody of a central Office detective.

William A. Doane of 127 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, this city, went skating on the lake in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, last night. He thought that he could give the Brooklyn skaters points, and refused to pay need to the warning of the park police that there were certain parts of the ice that were not safe.

NEW-YORK. -- The certificate of incorporation of the New-York School of Applied Design for Women was filed yesterday in the office of the County Clerk. Its object is to educate women as practical designers. The Directors for the first year are Judge George L. Ingraham, J. Carroll Beckwith, Elihu Root, John Wesley Brown, Benjamin C. Porter, William H. Fuller, Ellen M. Hopkins, Sarah E. Harriman, and Mary R. Callender.

The Canard pier on the North River and the adjacent water front was the scene of an enlivening spectacle yesterday morning. Fully a thousand persons were assembled there, and all were in a most joyous mood. They were there to welcome the big Cunard steamship Umbria and the many passengers the vessel carried.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 31. -- The report from Washington that President Harrison has determined to make his outgoing blow at Canada, in the shape of the long-threatened Presidential proclamation abolishing the privileges now enjoyed by Canadian railways of transporting merchandise in bond through the United States free of duty, created little anxiety in official circles here.

When the every-day man, or body of men, waits a week after Christmas to hold a holiday jubilee there is likely to be rather a dull time. The New-York Stook Exchange, however, is able to postpone a celebration and yet get all the more fun out of it. That was proved yesterday.

A score of the personal friends of the late Prof. Jean Roomer stood around his grave at Woodlawn Cemetery yesterday, while the Rev. Henry Mottet repeated the commitment service of the Episcopal Church. The minister added two stanzas from "Jerusalem the Golden," the Lord's Prayer was repeated in unison by the assemblage, and the service was brought to a close with the benediction.

SPOKANE, Washington, Dec. 31. -- Charles Hall and Alexander Parker, lumbermen employed by Small Colby, eleven miles up Coeur d'Alene River from Kingston, walked to town Saturday to buy food. They could not get their checks cashed and started far home with a quart of whisky, but no food. Neighbors met them at dusk six miles from camp weak and staggering.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 31. -- The Picayune's Havana special says: Alter more than two months of continued drought we have been favored with copious rains, which nave extended throughout the north coast of Cuba, reviving the growing crops and facilitating the grinding of cane, which has become almost as hard as wood.

An old university town like Pierson is ordinarily so distracted by sports and revels foreign to its age and repugnant to its quality that between terms it dozes. Little wonder, then, that, on one last night of the year, when the snow was falling thickly and the gale from the Sound gave a cutting tinge to the cold, its rest should have deepened into slumber.

SALT LAKE, Dec. 31. -- The preparations for trips to the San Juan placer country from this place are proceeding rapidly. The excitement hero is increasing every hour, and the rash to the gold fields is increasing day by day.

A new oratory has just been built in the episcopal residence of the Bishop of New-York at 29 Lafayette Place. It was not until Friday evening last that Bishop Potter knew anything of the Christmas present that was in store for him.

A gay company of young people clad in fantastic costumes saw the old year out last night at 265 West Seventy-third Street as the guests of Miss Edna Brook and Miss Georgie Brook. There were seventy-five masqueraders present.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The truce in political feuds customary during the Christmas recess of the Reichstag has been, observed as usual this season, and the truce has been accentuated by the anger that is felt against each other by the political parties. The official press, however, flaunts the non-compromise flag over the Army bill, while the Opposition papers respond, challenging the Government to dissolve the Reicnstag.

Now that the House Committee on Commerce in Congress has concurred with the Senate committee in reporting favorably a bill to restore to his former grade of First Lieutenant in the United States Revenue Marine Second Lieut. Samuel H. Howard, a brief sketch of unwritten history of the late war comes up in which a prominent figure is this present officer.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- The Boston public by no means shares in the satisfaction of the City Fathers over the passage of the Loan bill authorizing an indebtedness of $1,467,000 on the part of the City of Boston.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- The present week at the Boston theatres has been one of not more than moderate interest. Although the attractions have averaged fairly in merit, not one of them was new to the city. Still, business has genererally been good.

Ask the average New-Yorker where he would prefer to live, whether in Brooklyn or on Blackwell's Island, and the chances are that he will name Blackwell's Island. "There's more life there," he will say; "it's more like New-York there." Compelled actually to choose a residence from toe two places he wouldn't go to "the Island" -- that's certain; and this suggests that a great deal that one hears in New-York about Brooklyn is said jokingly.

The farmers of England are exposed to new and formidable competition in their home market by the rapidly-growing exports of dairy produce and mutton from Australia and New-Zealand. The growth of this trade has been stimulated by the intelligent efforts of the colonial Governments and greatly assisted by the use of cold-storage chambers in the steamers which ply between the colonies and the mother country.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Dec. 31. -- Rain to-day broke the ice gorge in the Ohio River in front of this city. Several boats loaded, with coal in the Swenthel coal harbor were carried away. Two barges were sunk at the landing. The steamers Believue and Reliance were badly damaged. The loss will aggregate $15,000. The steamer Snsie Brown also broke loose, but safely landed on the Kentucky shore.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- Charles East, a Dutchess County farmer, dropped dead this morning while removing goods from his burning house. Be resided on the Boardman place about three miles from this city.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 31. -- Gen. G.M. Dodge, a Director of the Union Pacific and a large stockholder of the Texas and Pacific and the Missouri Pacific, has been in the city several days. He is accompanied by Gen. David Stanley of the United States Army and J.S. Granger of New-York, Gen. Dodge's partner. Their trip is one of observation and pleasure. They have already visited Omaha, Denver, Trinidad, and Fort Worth.

Mr. Galton devotes his life to the elucidation of the queer and the curious. Undoubtedly there is nothing a man masters which is not of some benefit to his fellows, though centuries may elapse before the application comes. In his present volume Mr. Galton gives the results of a number of years of research, devoted to those tiny ridges of skin which appear in the ends of the fingers.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- Henry J. Smith, an odd character who for the last few months has lived alone in a small house four miles north of this place, disappeared on Thursday. It was believed at first that he had committed suicide, but those who knew him think he has started for a warmer clime for the Winter.

MONTCLAIR, Dec. 31. -- One of the most brilliant social events of the season was the reception given Thursday night by Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Burgess of Mountain Avenue in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Burgess, who have recently returned from their wedding tour. Scores of colored lanterns illuminated the house and lawn, and with the addition of calcium lights on the latter made a very pretty scene.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 31. -- A number of New-York curlers arrived here this morning and played three rinks against the Thistle Curling Club of Hamilton during the day at Thistle Rink. The Hamilton Curlers were victorious. The visitors wore well entertained by the home clubs and left for the East this evening.

During the coming week Dr. J.W. Day of Waterloo, in this State, owner of the Patchen Stock Farm, will sail for Europe with a string of fourteen horses, all bred at the doctor's farm. With the horses he will take a dozen light speeding carts, a couple of bicycle sulkies, and all the necessaries of a training stable, as well as a lot of the American light road wagons.
Up to yesterday morning nine cases of typhus fever had been reported to the Health, Department and taken charge of by its officers since Wednesday, and yesterday there were five new ones.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- When Bishop Keane, the Rector of the Catholic University, was acted to-day concerning the rumor that Dr. McGlynn would be tendered the Chair of Sacred Oratory in the university, he pronounced it as totally without foundation in fact.

John L. Wilson was employed about four months ago by M. Wineburgh, advertising agent, with an office in THE TIMES Building, as a general clerk. Yesterday he was arrested charged with swindling his employer and with forgery. He admitted that he had been dishonest, and drew up two confessions, which he signed. Wilson was locked up in the Oak Street Station, and he will probably be remanded to-day.

The Twenty-third Regiment Athletic Asssociation made merry the closing hours of the old year by giving a "stag" entertainment at their armory, Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, last night. About 2,500 spectators, all males, witnessed the performance.

Senator John G. Carlisle, after an extended conference with Mr. Cleveland at the latter's residence 12 West Fifty-first Street, returned to Washington yesterday afternoon. Mr. Carlisle had been the guest of Mr. Cleveland during his stay in the city, going to the Cleveland residence immediately on his arrival Friday, and except for the time spent at a theatre that evening, remained at the house until he started for the train at about 3 o'clock yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Baroness de Roques, the matter of Mrs. Maybrick, states to-day that her daughter's health is improving.

French advices received in this city yesterday announce the details of important tests recently conducted by a French naval special commission in the use of petroleum in torpedo boats and the adverse decision of the commission against this form of fuel.

The great intellectual strife between the colleges of Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton was continued over four chessboards yesterday. The result of the fifth round of the tourney was that Colombia and Yale quit even for the day and that Harvard kept the crimson above the orange and black. Harvard is now in second place, one and a half games behind Columbia.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The Vorwaerts, the Socialist organ, says that a scrutiny of 100 receipts given for payments from the Guelph Fund has disclosed the fact that part of the fund was paid to court officials, Generals, Judges, journalists, and members of Parliament.

LANDER, Wyoming, Dec. 31. -- Trouble that may lead to war between the two Indian tribes is now brewing among the Arapahoes and Shoshones, who occupy the Shoshono Reservation near this city. Last year Congress appointed a commission to treat with the Shoshones for a part of their reservation, and subsequently a treaty was entered into, by which the Government was to receive one-half of the Indian lands.

That the character of the New-York Ledger is to be maintained at the standard established in the last two or three years by Robert Bonner's Sons is evident from the recent Christmas issue, which contained contributions by Maurice Thompson, Minnie Hauk, (the prima donna,) Helen Marshall North, the Rev. S.P. Cadman, Mrs. William Winter. ("Isabella Castelar,") Mrs. E.D.E.N. Southworth, and other wellknown authors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- There was a very small supply or cattle on to-day's market and prices were firm. The few hundred head on sale were bought up in good season on a basis of $1.25@$3.50 for inferior to choice cows and bulls, $2@$3.65 for stockers and feeders, and $3@$5.85 for very common to extra steers.

Statistics showing the work done in the Superior Court, the Court or Common Pleas, and the City Court were completed yesterday. The statistics for the Supreme Court are not yet prepared. In the Supreme Court, however, about 1,500 cases have been disposed of in the year passed, and there are about 3,200 on the calendar.

The Umbrin's passengers underwent their enforced delay and passed through the hazard of the accident with a remarkable degree of fortitude. The officers have no words but those of praise for the bravery of the men and women under the trying circumstances of the accident.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- The Rev. Thomas O'Flaherty, who has been under the ban of the Roman Catholic Church for twenty-four years, and whose sentence of excommunication is reported to have been removed by Mgr. Satolli, was pastor of the Holy Family Church, Auburn, N.Y., for five years, previous to Bishop McQuald's elevation to the Episcopacy, in 1868.

The holiday week, except perhaps for a like period in the depths of midsummer, is the dullest of the year at the up-town clubs. Many clubmen take advantage of the holidays to pay visits to the country, and the suburban clubs are crowded with city visitors, while the rooms of city clubs are comparatively empty.

After holding its franchise for nineteen years and doing little else but defend suits instituted by other gas companies in Brooklyn, the Equity Gaslight Company of that city has turned over its office at 204 Broadway, Williamsburg, to a syndicate of New-York capitalists headed by Benjamin I.H. Trask. The price paid by the syndicate, it is said is, $750,000.

The Rev. A.C. Dixon yesterday afternoon began his Sunday afternoon services in the theatres of Brooklyn for the purpose of reaching those persons who do not go to church. The rain no doubt kept down the attendance. He held his service at the Grand Opera House, in Elm Place.

Dr. George L. Miller of Omaba, one of the pillars of the Nebraska Democracy, and A.L. New, Chairman of the Wyoming Democratic State Committee, arrived in New-York yesterday morning. They came here especially to see Mr. Cleveland and to talk with him about the Senatorial outlook in their States. They called upon the President-elect at his residence and had a long talk with him.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 1. -- No such excitement as exists in Helena to-night has been known in the Montana capital in many years. The city is full of members of the Legislature, determined to get the best of the contest which is to begin to-morrow. Everything centres around the United States Senatorship, and at 9 o'clock to-night all the indications point to a dual House.

The learned Professor of Church History in the Union Theological Seminary is one of the most indefatigable and successful workers in his department which the nineteenth century has produced. The present large volume is the seventh in order, treating of "Modern Christianity." Over 900 pages are here occupied with the history of "The Swiss Reformation."

The recent passage of the new Mexican Pension bill has properly been referred to as an illustration of the results of altering standard values of pensions. One would hardly have expected, in the present state of the Treasury, another costly general pension bill. But the simple explanation is that, having previously fixed on $12 instead of the familiar $8 a month for dependent Union veterans in the Disability bill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The past week was one of unusual importance and gayety to the younger portion of society, marking, as it did, the formal introduction of a number of debutantes.

The members of New-York Lodge No. 1, Benevelent and Protective Order of Elks, dedicated their new headquarters at Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street yesterday, and many of the old-timers turned out and helped make a long and jolly New Year's. The formal services of dedication were held in the afternoon.

The cruiser Atlanta will be directed on her arrival at La Guayra to return to the United States by the last week in March. Her orders direct her to proceed from the Venezuela coast directly to Hampton Roads, Va. The Atlanta is now in the West Indies. She sailed on Dec. 26 from Norfolk for Haiti and San Domingo. She had on board Minister Durham.

Mr. Batchellor is one of the leading lawyers of the Granite State and has had much to do with public affairs in the last ten years. His work in collecting these records illustrative of the time has been done with much faithfulness and intelligence. The Revolutionary War had come to a close and the process of cementing the States into a permanent union was the chief matter in hand.

John T. Farrell of 324 East Twenty-fifth Street, who was twenty-two years old, and who had been a wagon driver for an ice cream maker, was shot and killed last night at William Purcell's saloon, 375 First Avenue, near the Eighteenth Precinct Station House, whither he went at 10 o'clock with Joseph McGee to get a drink.

The sanitary authorities frankly admitted yesterday that the second visitation of typhus fever in 1892 was more serious than they believed it would be, as, during Saturday night and up to 4 A.M. yesterday, a corps of physicians and the ambulance service had worked incessantly to remove twenty-eight new cases to the fever hospital on North, Brother Island.

No visitors were permitted on board the Umbria yesterday, and the watchman who guarded the gates of the pier had received orders not to admit any one to the vessel, nor to allow cards to be sent to any of the officers. One of the engineers was seen, however, and from him it was learned that repairs to the injured section of the Cunarder's shaft would be commenced to-day.

Due regard for precision of statement requires that the supporters of the Hon. EDWARD MURPHY, Jr., should cease to proclaim him as the candidate of the regular Democracy for the United States Senate. He is nothing of the kind. The Democracy of the State of New-York is not an admirer of Mr. MUHPHY, and is opposed to his senseless Senatorial aspirations.

The examination of the Sandy Hook pneumatic gun carriage the other day by a board of navy officers will doubtless determine whether the disappearing gun is suited for naval purposes. The vessel specially proposed for utilizing it is one designed by Mr. NIXON, chief constructor for the CRAMPS, which, while of only 1,550 tons' displacement, would yet carry a belt of armor and the remarkable battery of four eight-inch guns.

Mr. VAN COTT'S declaration that the inefficiency of the New-York Post Office is due to the meagre appropriations made for the service is effectively countered by the declarations of the local members of Congress. These gentlemen explain that they have received no complaints that the appropriations were insufficient, and that the appropriations could have been made large enough to do the work if such complaints had been made.

The late Sir Daniel Wilson described this volume as "a few carefully-studied monographs, linked together by a slender thread of ethnographic relationship." Very touching is the preface, wherein a daughter of the President of the University of Toronto tells of the solicitude of her father in regard to that book, and that his last request was that the proofs should be properly corrected and that an index should be furnished.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- A preliminary report on income and expenditure of railways for the year ended June 30, 1892, compiled by the statistician, to the Inter-State Commerce Commission, will soon be made public.

The now postage stamps have made their appearance in a series of bright-hued oblong squares, considerably longer than high, in denominations from 1 cent to $5. They are for convenience called stamps, but in fact they are little chromos after pictures that refer to COLUMBUS and the discovery of America.

We advise Mr. SPENCER to resign from the Rapid-Transit Commission before it is too late. The commission is a very queer body. The more its procedures are examined the queerer it looks. It is going to be roundly condemned by the public one of these days as a humbug -- or worse. Mr. SPENCER, good, innocent soul, must not continne in such company.
In two of the front windows of a house that one passes going up town on the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad are cardboard signs on which appear the words "Resolutions Engrossed."

Congressman William J. Coombs talked about "Foreign Commerce" last night to members of the Brooklyn Ethical Association, in the Second Unitarian Church, Clinton and Congress Streets. Notwithstanding the storm there was a good audience, and Mr. Coombs's address was frequently applauded.

Durward Lely, the tenor who is to accompany the Patti company through this country, and is likely to be heard hero in English opera before beginning that engagement, is regarded as one of the foremost professional vocalists of the British operatic stage or concert platform. He is a native of Blairgowne, Scotland, where he is better known by his real name, James Durward Lyall, than by his more euphonic stage appellation.

NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, Jan. 1. -- Col. Ceron, commander of the Mexican military garrison here, received a dispatch this morning from Guerrero, Mexico, giving an account of another engagement which took place on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande River, just north of that place, Friday evening between 150 revolutionists and about 80 Mexican troops belonging to the Sixth Cavalry.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 1. -- The News and Courier will say to-morrow under the head "Murphy and the Machine":
AN EVENING ENTERTAINMENT. -- "C.R.": Kindly inform me of a new and interesting way to entertain a small and bright evening party.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 1. -- The year which has just closed was the worst the Southern railroads have passed through in a long time. Managers are not sorry to see a new one. They are heartily glad that 1892 is dead.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- The old year was closed last night with a terrible tragedy by which Sydney McCoy, a young lawyer, aged thirty-three, lost his life, and Mrs. Grace King, aged nineteen, is in an unconscious condition.

Dr. S.G. Perry of 46 West Thirty-seventh Street is the happy possessor of a brand-new Colton violin. Most persons are under the impression that a brand-new violin is not a thing to be desired, but the members of the inner circle of the brotherhood of violin collectors and Players know that this depends on who made the instrument.

The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn lectured to a very large and enthusiastic audience at Cooper Union last night on what he called "A Doctrinal Statement." This was simply an exposition of the doctrine which he had advocated from the platform for the past six years.

A fire occurred at the College of St. Francis Xavier, at Sixteenth Street and Sixth Avenue, yesterday morning, that resulted in the death of one of the Jesuit brothers, destroyed the college theatre, and for a time threatened to wipe out the entire building.

MONTEREY, Mexico, Jan. 1. -- The Mexican Government, through the efforts of Gen. Benardo Reya, Governor of the State of Nueva Leon, has secured positive evidence implicating 200 prominent Mexicans of the State of Tamaulipas and the Texas frontier in the present revolutionary movement. This evidence is in the nature of a secret revolutionary pronunciamento, distributed among those believed to be in sympathy with the cause.
A judgment of the Supreme Court was filed Saturday in favor of Adrian Iselin, the banker of 36 Wall Street, against John H. Starin, the owner of Glen Island.

In hotel corridors so dark from the heavy clouds outside that the gas was kept lighted all day, many well-known men spent the first day of 1893 making believe that it was "a Happy New Year." The storm prevented the usual out-of-door exercise and observation which strangers in the city incline to on a Sunday, and so they strolled up and down the corridors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- The following programme, after considerable discussion, has been agreed upon by the Caledonian and similar societies here for what is called the "Scotch Week" at the Columbian Exposition. Mr. L.D. McMichael is Chairman of the committee having the matter in charge:
DENVER, Col., Jan. 1. -- A sale of the Bassick Mine at Rosita, Custor County, was made to New-York parties yesterday for $700,000, contingent on the taxes against the property being reduced.

To-morrow the Press Club will become the owner of the site for its proposed new clubhouse, on the northwest corner of Frankfort and William Streets. This will come about by the payment of $100,000 leaving $140,000 yet to be paid.
The following data are given by the War Department officers relative to the new Gordon disappearing gun-carriage system, now at Sandy Hook and shortly to be tried:

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The gentleman who met in conference at Taylor's Hotel in Jersey City the other day promise that the address they propose to issue for the purpose of exposing the reasons why Leon Abbett should not be promoted to the United States Senate three weeks from now is to be something fine. It should be.

Yesterday was a day of rejoicing for the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street. The mortgage of $87,000, which had been upon the church property for several years, was about to be raised. The money to discharge the obligation had been fully pledged, and the church was starting the new year practically free from debt.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Jan. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ashton, married on the day after Christmas, narrowly escaped death by suffocation yesterday afternoon. The groom is a gasfitter by occupation, a steady, industrious young man and employed by W.E. Butter Co. The bride, a handsome young woman, belonged in Paterson, N.J. and it was there that her husband went to claim her on Christmas Eve.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- The ferryboat Tiburon, one of the largest on San Francisco Bay, was totally destroyed by fire this afternoon. The loss is $140,000; the insurance, $50,000.

NEW-YORK, Monday, Jan. 2 -- A.M. The chief-trading last week was in Manhattan, Northern Pacific, Reading, and New-England, Manhattan advanced a dozen points on the prospect that the company will continue to control the rapid-transit business of the city indefinitely, the proposed underground system having been abandoned by the commission.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- A beautiful object lesson was afforded the student of the American form of government this afternoon, when the young man who has been selected by the Democratic bosses of the State to preside over the Assembly reported at the Delavan House. The people who elected the members of Assembly exert no influence compared with the bosses who control the nominating conventions.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 1. -- President Charles Dixon yesterday received a letter from Ted Pritchard saying that he was anxious to come to America and meet "Aleck" Greggains before the Olympic Club. He wants $500 for expenses. It is probable that the Englishman wants to come to this country to witness the mill between Hall and Fitzsimmons, as well as to arrange for some matches on his own account.

When the last New Year's Eve reveler went to bed, some time yesterday morning, he had an idea that he would wake up and find all of New-York buried under a gentle cloak of snow. Before midnight a gentle fall of dry snow began and it seemed to the amateur weather sharp to be the beginning of a heavy storm. Not so, however, to the professional prognosticator at the top of the Equitable Building.

From the Richmond (Va.) State, (Dem.) In short, Mr. Cleveland has done what he considers his duty, and leaves the responsibility with the New-York Democratic Legislature. Of course it is folly for Mr. Murphy's partisans to expect that their opposition can affect Mr. Cleveland's Administration. The President-elect is of the opinion that at least one New-York Senator should come from the chief metropolitan city of the Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission, by Commissioner Knapp, has tendered its opinion in the case of the Board of Trade of Chattanooga against the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway Company and others.

-- The recent French work "La Jeunesse," which has made a reputation for its author, Charles Wagner, will be issued here by Dodd, Mead Co., under the title "Youth," and with the author's sanction. The work represents the reaction against realism and materialism.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 1. -- James B. Grosvenor, L. Wilson, and E. Litchfield of New-York, and S. Seabury of New-Jersey have brought suit against Commodore Folger, Chief of Ordnance of the Navy, for infringement upon a patent for an improved breech-loading cannon.

The meeting at the Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room on Wednesday, for the purpose of taking steps to procure the construction of the underground rapid-transit railroad by the city, is to take place at 1 o'clock, instead of 10, as previously stated. That there will be an emphatic expression of public sentiment in the matter is already clearly established.

Mrs. Etta Harrington, who shot herself on Friday night in her parents' apartments at 18 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, for the reason that Sadie Carson, with whom she had been infatuated for about ten years, had refused longer to continue the intimacy, was reported at the Harlem Hospital yesterday as having a fair chance of recovery.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- The new year was ushered in in the usual way at the old castle, a military band playing appropriate selections in the royal chapel in the presence of the imperial family and the members of the household.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- The attempts of several newspapers to smother in ridicule the Guelph Fund scandal have not succeeded. The details given in the Vorioaerts's article concerning the distribution of the money are too minute, to be dismissed as mere fabrications.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Jan. 1. -- Ever since the destruction by fire of the Pequot Casino, two months ago, it has been a question with the Directors whether to build again on the old site, near the Pequot House, or to select a location further east of the hotel and nearer the water front. The choice has been left to a committee of which James D. Lynch and Dr. Norrie, Fequot Summer colonists, are members.

State Controller Frank Campbell was at the Hoffman House, Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, and with some of his callers he discussed the Senatorial election which is to determine who shall succeed Mr. Hiscook.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 1. -- With the arrival of Senator Stockbridge from Washington last night the Senatorial battle was fairly begun. Ex-Gov. Luce will not be here until to-morrow, but Major Miles Campbell, Secretary of his campaign committee, has established headquarters at the Hotel Downey, and is looking alter the early arrivals.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. -- An insane man caused an incipient panic in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas Aquinas this morning at mass, during which a number of women fainted. A stampede for the doors, which would probably have resulted in serious bodily injury, and perhaps loss of life, was averted by the courage and presence of mind of the rector, the Rev. M.J. Lawler, against whom the intruder's efforts were alone directed.
PORT CHESTER, Jan. 1. -- The ceremonies incident to ushering in the new year at Port Chester were rather more exciting than usual this year and culminated this morning in a general riot.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Jan. 2. -- Just after 12 o'clock, noon, to-day three sturdy knocks resounded upon the door of the Mayor's office in the City Hall in Long Island City. The door was opened by Police Sergeant Thomas Carroll from the inside and in walked Mayor-elect Horatio S. Banford to demand possession of the office of the autocratic Mr. Gleason.
The record of crimes for 1893 was begun yesterday afternoon with a deed of peculiar atrocity, in which the criminal was a woman and the object of her insane fury a three-months-old baby.

"Things are not what they used to be on New Year's Day," said a society beau of the old school yesterday morning, as he reclined in a big armchair before his back-parlor grate. "Why, I can recall the time back in the fifties when I had to pay $20 a day for a cab to go calling in, and then I had to send in my order two weeks before New Year's Day.

Koster Bial's concert hall was crowded to its fullest capacity last night, and as everybody seemed in the best of humor, the programme was applauded from begining to end. Violette, chanteuse excentrique from the Follea Bergere, Paris, made her first appearance in, America, and sang three songs, each of which, was rapturously received.
